These Gu·πáas prove as bondage, and when they are got over, then the man is free from the bondage. and becomes immortal. The distinguishing characteristic of one who is free from these three Gu·πáas is a quiet undisturbed serene mood, in which happiness and misery are alike, and gold, olod of earth and stone are alike, in which agreeable and disagreeable. things are alike, and praise and censure are also alike, etc. He who invariably resorts to Bhagavatby Bhaktiyoga becomes free from these three Gu·πáas and attains to the condition of Brahman.Bhagavat is the support of the immortal and unchanging Brahman and of eternal righteousness (duty) and of unending happiness.

Here then is a distinct affirmation of the soul’s attainment of freedom from passions by means of continuous devotion to Bhaga

vat or God. The word Brahmayoni occurs in MU. III. 1. 3, and is to be interpreted, in the light of the opening statement in the above, as one whose Yoni is Brahman.

¬ß 24. Chapter XV. Bhagavat proceeds to the comparison of Sa·πÅsƒÅra, or the whole extent of things, to the Pippal-tree. This tree is to be cut by the weapon of indifference or non-attachment; and then should be sought that place from which there is no return. One should surrender himself to the original Puru·π£a. Those reach that unchanging position or place, who are free from pride, ignorance, desires, and the pair of happiness and misery. That is the highest abode of Bhagavat, which is not illuminated by the sun, the moon or the fire. When a soul departs from a body, it takes away the Indriyas, of which Manas is the sixth, and brings them in when it assumes another body. The soul itself is a part of Bhagavat and is eternal. This soul, placing itself in these six Indriyas, resorts to all objects of sense. The brilliance. existing in the sun, which illumines the whole world, and which exists in the moon as well as in fire, is to be known as that of Bhagavat. By becoming Soma, Bhagavat raises all herbs. By becoming fire be contributes to digestion. He dwells in the heart. of all. From him proceeds consciousness of one’s condition, knowledge, and the rejection of what is not true. Bhagavat alone is to be known by means of all the Vedas and as the author of VedƒÅntas and the knower of the Veds. There are two souls in the world, one that changes, and the other that is unchangeable. Besides these. there is another who is the highest and is called ParamƒÅtman, and who as the unchangeable lord supports all the three worlds after entering into them. Bhagavat is known to be that Highest Soul in the ordinary world and also in the Vedas.

There is one new point brought out in this chapter. And that is that the animal soul goes out of the body along with the six senses and enters new ones in that condition.The comparison of the composite universe to the Pippal-tree ocours in KU. (VI.1), MaiU. (VI. 4), and the non-illumination of the highest abode of Bhagavat is mentioned in a verse in KU. (V. 15), MU, (II. 2. 10), and SU. (VI. 14). The doctrine of the existence of the third highest Puru·π£a should also be noted as a characteristic of this theistic work. The triad, K·π£ara, Ak·π£ara or ƒÄtman (individual

soul), and the ruling one God, is mentioned in SU. (I. 10), which work is a precursor of the Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅ.

¬ß 25. Chapter XVI. Bhagavat now proceeds to enumerate the virtues which constitute the divine endowments (Daivƒ´Sa·πÅpad), and the vices that constitute demoniacal possessions. From divine. endowments results final deliverance, and from the demoniacal possessions, follows destruction. There are two classes of created beings: one is divine and the other demoniacal. In persons of the latter class there is no purity nor correct conduct nor truth. They regard the world as unreal, without substratum or support, without God, disconnected and what more, springing from lust. Holding this view these wicked and dull persons with their ferocious deeds bring about the destruction of the world. Full of insatiable lust and possessed of vanity, pride, and arrogance, they act in an un holy manner, sticking to their own false conceits. They accumulate wealth by foul means for enjoyment and boasting of their possessions, their power, their parentage, they treat others with contempt and eventually go to the infernal regions. If they worship at all, they simply utter the name and assume a false garb. They are full of egotism and hate Bhagavat, as abiding in their own bodies and those of others. These wicked men he consigns to the race of the demons. Desire, anger and covetousness. are the three doors to hell. These three, therefore, should be abandoned. He who avoids these three doors reaches the highest goal. He who abandons sacred precepts and acts according. to his own will, does not obtain success, happiness or the highest goal. The sacred precepts must, therefore, be followed whenever a man has to do anything or avoid anything.

Here two classes of men, good and bad, are mentioned. Among the latter are included not only worldly men who do not care for God or morality, but the followers of philosophical or religious systems, different from that of Bhagavat seem also to be included. They set aside the sacred ≈öƒÅstra or precepts, denied God, as Buddhists and Jainas did, and regarded the world as unsubstantial or unreal, as the former did.

¬ß 26. Chapter XVII. Arjuna asks: “What is the frame of mind of those who set aside the sacred precepts and still worship

with faith? Is it characterised by the quality of goodness, activity or ignorance?” Bhagavat answers: “Faith is of three kinds, characterised by goodness, activity, and darkness or ignorance. The faith of a man depends upon the quality of his heart. A man is what faith makes of him. As is his faith, so is the man”. The good worship gods, the active, Yak·π£as and Rak·π£ases or evil spirits, and the ignorant, ghosts and spectres. Men of demoniacal frame of mind perform terrible ansterities full of ostentation and egotism, and cause attenuation of the elements composing the body and of the Bhagavat who dwells in it. He then mentions three kinds of food, modes of worship, austerities and gifts, in keeping with the threo qualities. For instance, in the case of worship or sacrifice, that is in keeping with the quality of goodness, which is performed without any regard for the fruit and in accordance with the sacred ritual. That springs from the quality of activity, which is done for the attainment of fruit and out of ostentation; and that which is done without regard for the sacred precepts and without Dak·π£i·πáƒÅor rewards to the priest and without any faith, proceeds from the quality of ignorance. As to charitable gifts, those spring from the quality of goodness, which are made because it is a duty to give to one from whom no return is expected; while that which is made with an interested motive and with a desire for return, springs from the quality of activity. And in this manner all the four subjects are treated. At the end the doing of good acts by is mentioned. the repetition of the syllables “Om, tat, sat” is mentioned.

In this chapter the truth that man’s religious faith and the character of the God that he worships, depend upon his own character whether good or bad, is clearly recognised. Not only the nature of the God worshipped, but also the diet, the mode of worship, charity or gifts, and the practice of austerity differ according as a man’s nature is influenced by one or other of the three qualities, goodness, activity, and ignorance.

¬ß 27.Chapter XVIII. This chapter begins with a question by Arjuna as to the principles of renunciation and abandonment. Bhagavat replies that renunciation is the giving up of works springing from desires, and abandonment is the abandonment of fruits of actions. Some say that all Karmian should be abandond; others say that worship, charity and austerity should not be given

up. The decision is that these last should not be abandoned, as they bring about purity of the soul.The actions should be done. without being attached to them or desiring for the fruits. That duty that must be done, should not be abandoned. Giving up. that duty is an ignorant deed. When action is avoided because it is wearisome, its abandonment springs from the quality of passion. When the essential action is done because it should be done without any desire for fruit or attachment, that abandonment springs from goodness. It is not possible for a living being. to abandon all actions. He who abandons only the fruit, is really. one who has abandoned actions. According to the SƒÅ·πÅkhya doctrine, there are five different causes: the resting place, agent, instrument, varied movements and fate. In this manner it goes on, Some acts or states of mind are represented to vary according. to the three qualities, such as knowledge, the deed done and the doer, Buddhi or will, firmness and happiness, and the duties of the different castes.

The man who worships Him, from whom all beings have sprung and who has spread out all this, by doing the duties assigned to him, for which the three qualities have fitted him, attains final success. He then proceeds to mention all those virtues and other states of mind, such as self-control, freedom and passions, which conduce to the realisation of the Brahma-condition. When this condition is realised, a man is free from sorrow and desire, and, being equally disposed towards all beings, he develops in himself the highest love for Bhagavat, and knowing Bhagavat fully and truly,enters into the Bhagavat. One should do all acts, intent only upon God, and then one obtains the eternal place by the favour of God. A man should fix his mind upon Bhagavat alone, dedicating all his actions to him, and then he gets over all evils by the grace of Bhagavat.

Then Bhagavat winds up the whole by teaching Arjuna to surrender himself with all his heart to God (the Ruler), who abides in the hearts of all things and moves them, as if forming parts of a wheel; and then he says, by his favour Arjuna would obtain perfect peace and an eternal resting-place. He is further instructed to dedicate his whole mind to Bhagavat, to become

his devotee, to worship him, to bow to him, and in this way he (Arjuns) would reach him. This is styled the deepest secret. Then Arjuna is told to set aside all other methods of salvation and surrender himself to Bhagavat alone, and Bhagavat would then. free him from all his sins. And thus the chapter ends.

This is the EkƒÅntika Dharms or monotheistic religion, which,as the NƒÅrƒÅya·πáƒ´ya tells us, was communicated to Arjuna. The method of salvation here revealed is to lead a life of action, but the fruit of the action one should not be intent on. The action should be done disinterestedly, that is, a man should be selfless in doing it. The action should be dedicated to Brahman, that is, it should be done because the Universal Order requires it to be done. This is tantamount to saying that one should do one’s duty. because it is a duty. When a more personel interpretation is given to it, the doctrine comes to this, that one should act with the sole object of carrying out God’s will. The frame of mind. that is generated by consistently acting in this manner, is free- dom from passion, a sense of the omnipresence of God and an equal regard for all things. This leads to the realisation of the highest love of God, and, knowing Bhagavat thoroughly, by this means a man is absorbed in him.

But to do one’s duty consistently and selflessly is a matter difficult, since all beings are subject to the influence of the three. qualities or, in our modern phraseology, of passions and appetencies.These can be got over by surrendering oneself to God.

VI. The Sources of the Religion of the Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅ.

¬ß 28. This constant insistence on action being done without any regard for the fruit, that is, distinterestedly or selflessly. forms & peculiarity of the Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅ. But the idea is not new. In the ƒ™≈õopani·π£ad it is stated in the second verse, that a man should desire to live a hundred years doing actions resolutely. and in that way and no other, will action not contaminate him. And the non-contamination as the result of an elevated state of mind is spoken of in ChU. IV. 14. 3; BU. 4. 23; and MaiU. VI. 20.

The attributes of the Supreme Being the Gƒ´tƒÅdraws from the Upani·π£ads, as has been already shown in the remarks on the different chapters. While the personality of God is fully acknowledged in certain parts of the Upani·π£ads, mere Brahman, the personality of which is not so distinct, is also spoken of in some places. When the Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅtakes in these passages, it takes care to distinctly personalise the Ak·π£ara or Brahman, as we have. shown. The source from which the Gƒ´tƒÅ derives its doctrines about the conquest of the self and the attainment of a condition of a peace and serenity, is the general atmosphere of religious and moral sentiment, that came to prevail from the beginning of the earliest Upani·π£ad speculations to the formation of definite roligious systems,orthodox and heterodox.Consequently, though the Gƒ´tƒÅ speaks of the Brahma-NirvƒÅ·πáa, it ought not to be supposed that it borrows this doctrine of final peace and serenity from Buddhism. The source resorted to by these systems was commonto all.

Besides the Upani·π£ads and the religious and moral atmosphere. prevalent at that time, the Gƒ´tƒÅ avails itself of the philosophy that. had come into existence in early times. This is the philosophy. of the SƒÅ·πÅkhya and the Yoga. Though the twenty-four principles. of the former system, together with the Puru·π£a or soul as the twenty-fifth, as known in later times, and the doctrine of the activity of the Prak·πõti only and the non-activity of Puru·π£a, aro alluded to in the Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅ, still it adds another soul called the Uttama Puru·π£a or the Supreme Soul, which is not found in the later SƒÅ·πÅkhya, thus giving a theistic character to the philosophy. In their account of the creation, the Pura·πáas follow this philosophy, and the later Vai·π£·πáava and ≈öaivasystems adopt it in a more or less qualified manner.

But the word SƒÅ·πÅkhya does not seem to be used in the Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅ to indicate the later non-theistic system. In the second chapter and in the fifth, SƒÅ·πÅkhya indicates & philosophy based upon knowledge, and Yogs, one based on action. Again the five causes, that are alluded in the last chapter as mentioned in the SƒÅ·πÅkhya system, do not appear to be known. to the later SƒÅ·πÅkhya. The speculative philosophy, therefore, that existed about the time of the ≈övetƒÅ≈õvatara-Upani·π£ad and the Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅ, was known by the name of SƒÅ·πÅkhya, and out. of it grew the non-theistic system of later times. The Yoga,

the philosophy of action, too did prevail, but it culminated, as indicated before, into a concentration of mind, the ordinary operation being suspended, on the Brahman, Ak·π£ara, or the Supreme Soul.

¬ß 29. Thus the Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅis the result of development of the religious and philosophic speculation that prevailed before the rise of Buddhism. But the origin of the idea of Bhakti, or love. of God, which is the characteristic of the work, has formed the subject of a great deal of speculation in modern times, and to this point we will now turn. In the Upani·π£ads, UpƒÅsan√£, or fervent meditation of a number of things such as Manas (mind), the sun, the Puru·π£a in the sun or the moon, food, vital breath, etc., regarded as Brahman, i.e., thinking of them as Brahman-is proscribed. Such a fervent meditation cannot but magnify the thing and give it a glorious form so as to excite admiration and even love. Again what is called the Internal ƒÄtman (soul) is said in the B·πõhadƒÅra·πáyaka to be dearer than a son, wealth and everything. else (I. 4. 8.). Here the word ƒÄtman may possibly be taken to mean one’s own soul. In the same Upani·π£ad there is another passage which runs thus: “This is that Great Unborn, who is of the form of thought among vital airs, who dwells in the cavity of the heart, who is controller of all, ruler of all, the lord of all, By doing good or evil deeds he does not become better or worse. He is the ruler of all beings, he is the causeway or dike that separates things from one another and prevents them being confused together (he is the preserver of order). The BrƒÅhma·πáas desire to know him by the words of the Vedas, by worship, charity and austerity. Knowing him, one becomes a sage. The recluses desiring him as the place to live in, renounce the world. On this account the wise, men of old did not desire progeny, saying to themselves: What shall we do with progeny, when we have got this Being, this world to live in?’; and thus they gave up desire for sons, wealth and the world and lived the life of mendicants” (IV. 4. 22).

Now, if those wise men of old gave up all the pleasures of the world to contemplate and dwell with the Supreme Being, so eloquently described, must it not be considered that they were actuated by love for Him, though the word Bhakti does not occur

here? And at the bottom of all those rapturous sayings about the peace attained by seeing the Supreme Soul in the world and the heart of man, there must be a feeling akin to love. And during the period when the ·πögveda poetry was composed, love for God or gods was often an abiding sentiment in the heart of the poet, as is evident from the words: “Dyaus is my father” (RV. I. 104. 33), “Aditi (the boundless) is father, mother, and son” (RV. I. 89. 10); and from such prayers as " O father Dyaus, avert all evils”, “Be accessible to us and gracious as a father to the son”, etc. Though the later sacrificial ritual destroyed the spirit of these verses and converted them into simple verbal formulae, still, the feeling that was in the heart at the time when they were composed, must have continued, though it found no expression for a time and exhibited itself again mixed with wonder and admiration in the times of the Upani·π£ads. It certainly was not absent during this last period. The text about the two birds, the friends and companions of each other, by which are meant the Supreme and Individual souls exists in the ·πöksa·πÅhitƒÅ(I. 164. 20) and is repeated in the Mu·πá·∏çaka-Upani≈üad (VII. 1.1).

In the last (MU. III. 2. 3), and in the KU. (II. 23), there is a verse to the effect that this Supreme Soul is not to be attained by lectures (from a teacher), nor by intelligence, nor by much learning; he is to be attained by him whom the Supreme Soul favours; to him he discloses his form. Again we have the dootrine that the supremely wise Being, the life of all, leads a man to do good deeds, whom he desires to elevate (KBU. III. 8); and another, that God dwelling in the heart of all beings, controls. them which latter forms the subject of a celebrated passage in the BU. III. 7. From this it is clear that the doctrine that the individual soul is dependent on the Supreme and that the latter alone works out his salvation, was acknowledged in Upani·π£ad times.

¬ß 30. In this manner all the points that constitute the EkƒÅntika religion of the Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅare to be found in the older religious. literature. The word Bhakti, however, in the sense of love is not to be found except in a verse in SU. But that word is not alwaysused in the sense of love even by RƒÅmƒÅnuja. In his system Bhakti means constant meditation and corresponds to the UpƒÅsanƒÅof

the Upani·π£ads. The word etymologically signifies resorting to and then loving the thing resorted to. It is used in this sense by PƒÅ·πáini in S≈´tra IV. 3.95; but the word, as explained by the commentators, has a passive sense and means a thing resorted. to, liked or loved: and general and special terminations are prescribed, which, when affixed to a noun, indicate one by whom the thing expressed by the noun is liked or loved. In this senso the word Bhakti is used by YƒÅska also, when he speaks of certain things ns Agnibhaktƒ´ni, Indrabhaktƒ´ni, i. o., things which resort to, or relate themselves to, Agni, occ. Thus the idea of love was associated with the word in early times, though it then signified loved instead of love. Properly speaking, by the rules of PƒÅ·πáini himself, it ought to signify the latter, as the suffix // indicates BhƒÅva or condition. Howsoevor the word may have come into use in later tintes, the thing expressed by it. viz., love for the ƒÄtman or the Supreme Suul, was an idea implied and often expressed by the word Priya or Prayas in the Upani·π£ad period.

¬ß 31. The state of things which must have led to the evoluttion of the religion of the Gƒ´tƒÅ seems to me to be this. About the time when the systems of religion we have been considering Brose, there was a tendency amongst the people which often worked itself out, as is evident from the Pali Birth-Stories, to give up worldly life and betake themselves to a residence in forests or mountains. Even Buddhism, Jainism and other like systems considered an ascetic life to be a sine qua non of religious elevation. There is reason to believe that ≈örama·πáas existed before the rise of Buddhism. The religious systems that had sprung up were mostly atheistic. The Indian mind had become prone to indulge in mere moral discourses and thoughts of moral exaltasion, unassociated with a theistic faith, as appears clear from Buddhism and other systems, and also from dry moral dissertations of which the MahƒÅbhƒÅratais fall. Such a system as that of the Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅ was, therefore, necessary to counterset these tendencies. Theistic ideas were so scattered in the Upani·π£ads, that it was necessary for practical purposes to work them up into a system of redemption capable of bing grasped castiy.

These appear to be the conditions under which the Gƒ´tƒÅcame

into existence. I am not inclined to dissolve VƒÅsudeva and Arjuna into solar myths; but VƒÅsudeva could not have been living when the Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅwas composed as a discourse delivered by him, any more than Buddha was living when his discourses were. reduced to the form of books. It is worthy of remark that both of them are called Bhagavats when speaking. VƒÅsudeva must already have been doified before the Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅwas written.

As regards the attitude of the Bhagavat to the older belief, it is evident that it is conservative and he came to fulfil the law and not supersede it. It must already have been seen that he looks at the sacrificial religion from almost the same point of view as the Upani·π£ads. The cherishing of desires which the sacrificial rites encourged is considered harmful, and the fruit attained by means of them is perishable. It was because this. EkƒÅntikareligion was so conservative, that it gradually made its way into Hindu society in general, though it did not succeed. in uprooting the religion of sacrifices. Still it always retained. its character as a religion for women and for all castes, ≈ö≈´dras included, and in its later development it was associated with such Vedic rites as then remained when it was professed by the BrƒÅhma·πáas, but not so associated when its followers were of lower castes, among whom it continued to exercise great influence. The Bhagavat’s attitude towards the worshippers of other gods. has already been explained. It was strictly liberal. All worship. to whomsoever it was directed, reaches him ultimately, but the devotees of other gods do not know Bhagavat as he truly is and thus go wrong. This attitude must have had something to do with the influence of the VƒÅsudeva-K·πõ·π£·πáa cult over the lower classes.

VII. Identification of VƒÅsudeva with NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa.

¬ß 32. The word NƒÅrƒÅya·πáais similar to NƒÅ·∏çƒÅya·πáa, which last is formed by P. IV. 1. 99 and means the Gotra NƒÅ·∏çƒÅya·πáa. The termination is significative and means in this case the resting place or the place to which NƒÅ·∏ça or a collection of Na·∏ças go. So NƒÅrƒÅya·πáameans the resting place or goal of NƒÅra or a collection of NƒÅras13. In theNƒÅrƒÅya·πáƒ´ya (XII. 341) Ke≈õava or

Hari says to Arjuna that he is known as the resting place or goal of men (NarƒÅ·πáƒÅm). The word N·πõor Na·πõa is also used to denote gods as manly persons, especially in the Vodas, so that NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa may be construed as the resting place or goal of gods. There is a tradition which connects NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa with the primeval waters. Manu (1.10), and also Hari in the above passage say that the waters were called NƒÅrƒÅs because they were the sons of Nara, and, since they were the first resting place of BrahmƒÅin the first case and of Hari in the second, the two were called NƒÅrƒÅya·πáas. The PurƒÅ·πáas, such as the VƒÅyu and the Vi·π£·πáu, agree with Manu. Again there is a tradition that Brahmadeva sprang from the lotus in the navel of NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa or Vi·π£·πáu (M Bh. III, 12, 34 and XII 349. 18), In the VƒÅyu-PurƒÅ·πáa NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa is represented as prior to Avyakta or matter in an undeveloped form, and from Avyakta sprang the mundane egg, and from the latter arose Brahmadeva.

All these traditions in various forms seem to go back to RV. X. 82.5 and 6, which may be thus translated: “Prior to the sky, prior to this earth, prior to the living gods, what is that embryo. which the waters held first and in which all the gods existed? The waters held that same embryo in which all gods exist or find themselves; on the navel of the unborn stood something in which. all beings stood”. In this we have first the waters mentioned; on those waters stood the embryo, which corresponds to the BrahmƒÅof the later tradition, who created everything; and the unborn corresponds to NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa from whose navel he sprang. In this embryo all the gods, it is said, found themselves. This corresponds to the Naras, men or gods, whose goal or resting place was NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, so that this confirms the identity between BrahmƒÅand NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa mentioned by Manu and some of the PurƒÅ·πáas. NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa therefore, who,by the other authorities cited above, is considered prior to Brahmadeva and to the Svaya·πÅbh≈´of Manu, is another. person and has a cosmic character and is not a historical or mythological individual. This idea of NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa was developed in the period of the later BrƒÅhma·πáas and ƒÄra·πáyakas.

In the ≈öatapatha-BrƒÅhma·πáa (XII. 3. 4), Puru·π£a NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa is represented to have sent forth from the place of sacrifice Vasus, Rudras and ƒÄdityas by means of the morning, midday and evening libations respectively, he alone remaining in the place, Fra

jƒÅpati tells him to sacrifice again, and the substance of the whole. is that NƒÅrƒÅya·πáaplaced himself in all the worlds, in all the gods, in all the Vedas and in all the vital airs, and they were placed in him. This shadows forth the rising of NƒÅrƒÅya·πáato the dignity of the Supreme Soul, who pervades all and in whom all things. exist and who in the beginning sent forth all the gods, being himself their receptacle or resting place as indicated in RV. X. 82. 6. In another place (XIIL 6. 1) Puru·π£a NƒÅrƒÅya·πáais mentioned as having conceived the idea of a Pa√±carƒÅtra Sattra (continued sacrifices for five days) as the means of obtaining superiority over all beings and becoming all beings. He performed the sacrifices and attained to that dignity. Here also NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa’s becoming the Supreme Ruler and becoming all are spoken of, NƒÅrƒÅya·πáais represented as the author of the Puru·π£as≈´kta (RV. X. 90). This appears to be as much a fanciful representation, as that of Vi≈õvakarman and others as authors of other hymns As in these last cases, it has a connection with the deity to which the hymn refers, so that NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa is another name of the Puru·π£a, and these two names are associated together, as we have seen, in the above citations from the ≈öatapatha-BrƒÅhmana. In the Taittiriya-ƒÄra·πáyaka (X. 11) NƒÅrƒÅya·πáais described with all the attributes of the Supreme soul, which are usually found mentioned in the Upani·π£ads.

In the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and PurƒÅ·πáas, he figures as the supreme god, especially in connection with the creation; mythologically he is represented as lying on the body of a huge serpent in the ocean. of milk, the original conception of his connection with the primeval waters being still kept to. NƒÅrƒÅya·πáathus became an object of worship. In the Ghosu·πá·∏çi Inscription noticed before14, there is what appears to be a dedication of an enclosure to NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa(NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa-VƒÅ·π≠ikƒÅ),

¬ß33. The heaven of this NƒÅrƒÅya·πáawas the ≈övetadvƒ´pa or white. island. In the KathƒÅsaritsƒÅgara (54. 19, 21, 23) NaravƒÅhanadatta is represented to have been carried to the white island by Devasiddhi and to Hari reposing on the body of the serpent ≈öe·π£a and attended by NƒÅrada and other devotees. In another place in the same work (115, 101-3) certain gods are spoken of as having gone to ≈övetadvƒ´pa and seen Hari in a house made of great gems,

lying on the serpent bed with Lak·π£mƒ´sitting at his feet. In the Hariva·πÅ≈õa (14,384 ) it is stated that Yogins and KƒÅpilasƒÅ·πÅkhyas, who desire Mok·π£a or final deliverance, go to the white island or ≈övetadvƒ´pa, by reciting the prayer and praise composed by Balin. Evidently, therefore, ≈övetadvƒ´pa or white island is the heaven in which NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, spoken of sometimes as Hari, dwells. It corresponds to the Vaiku·πá·π≠ha of Vi·π£·πáu, the KailƒÅsa of ≈öiva, and the Goloka of GopƒÅlak·πõ·π£·πána; and to that heaven of NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa it was that NƒÅrada went and saw him and learned from him the monotheistic religion of VƒÅsudeva. There is, therefore, no need to suppose that the white island was a Christian country peopled by white races .

¬ß 34. NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, being thus evolved as the Supreme Being in the later BrƒÅhmanicperiod, was, of course, prior to VƒÅsudeva, and in the epic times when the worship of the latter arose, VƒÅsudeva was identified with NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa. In the Vanaparvan (chaps. 188, 189) there is a description of the condition of things at the time of dissolution of the universe, in which it is stated that there. was water everywhere and there was a boy lying on couch on a branch of a Nyagrodha tree. He opened his mouth and took in MƒÅrka·πá·∏çeya, who roamed in the inside and saw the whole universe and was struck with wonder. Then the boy vomited or threw him out, when he saw again the waters alone. MƒÅrka·πá·∏çeya then asked the boy who he was; then he said: “Formerly I gave to the waters the name of NƒÅrƒÅ·∏•, and those were my resting place (Ayana), and therefore I am NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa”, and thus he goes on to describe his greatness. Finally MƒÅrka·πá·∏çeya, who tells the whole story, says. to Yudhi·π£·π≠hira that JanƒÅrdana, his relative, is this same NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa. The burden of the whole of the NƒÅrƒÅya·πáƒ´ya section seems to be this identity between NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa and VƒÅsudeva.

Besides this NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, the creator of all, there was a tradition about another who was always associated with Nara. This companionship seems to be traceable to the Upani·π£ad idea of two birds. dwelling in a tree, friends and associates of each other. That one of those, who is called the lord and the onlooker, is in the present. tradition NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, and the other, who is engaged in eating the fruit of the tree, Nara. The old idea was transferred to the new conception of NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa as the resting place or abode of all men. In

the opening chapter of the NƒÅrƒÅya·πáƒ´ya it is stated that NƒÅrƒÅya·πáathe eternal soul of the universe, with four forms became the son of Dharma. The four forms or four sons were Nara, NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, Hari and K·πõ·π£·πáa. The first two of these devoted themselves to the practice of austerities in the BadarikƒÅ≈õrama.

The same story is given in the VƒÅmana-PurƒÅ·πáa (chap. 6). These four are represented as the sons of Dharma and had Ahi·πÅsƒÅ(non-killing) as their mother. This story seems to be significant. About the time when the new systems of religion arose, the ideas. that were undergoing fermentation were Dharma or righteousness and Ahi·πÅsƒÅor non-slaughter, as against the old ceremonial of sacrificial rites and the killing of animals in accordance with it. These four names, therefore, were names connected with the introduction of a new system of religion, not heterodox, which concerned itself with righteousness and non-slaughter of animals. That is what appears to be meant by Dharma being called the father of these four and Ahi·πÅsƒÅtheir mother.

Nara and NƒÅrƒÅya·πáaare sometimes called ·πö·π£is, and that is probably to be traced to the conception of NƒÅrƒÅya·πáaas the R·π£i or composer of the Puru·π£as≈´kta. These gods must have been very famous at the time when the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata was composed, since in the opening stanza of the different books obeisance is made to these two gods. In the Vanaparvan (12. 46, 47) JanƒÅrdana is represented to have said to Arjuna: “Oh invincible one, thou art Nara and I am Hari NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, and we, the sages Nara-NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, have come to this world at the proper time; thou art not different from me, oh PƒÅrtha, and I am not different from thee; it is not possible to know any difference between us.” In chap. 30 (verse 1) of the same Parvan, the God of gods (≈öiva) says to Arjuna: “In a former birth (body) thou wast Nara and with NƒÅrƒÅya·πáafor thy companion, performedst austerities for many thousands of years in Badari”. In the Udyogaparvan (49.19) it is said: “The two heores, VƒÅsudeva and Arjuna, who are great warriors, are the old gods Naraand NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa. This is the tradition.” In this manner there are a good many examples of the identification of Arjuna and VƒÅsudeva with Nara and NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa. And thus the old tradition about the two ·πö·π£is who

are warriors at the same time was brought into connection with the two interlocutors of the Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅ.

VIII. Identification of VƒÅsudeva with Vi·π£·πáu.

¬ß 35. Vi·π£·πáu is a Vedic deity. There are but few hymns addressed to him in ·πöV., but his personality is by no means unimportant. The long strides which he takes, and the three steps: by which he measures the universe, are always described with an enthusiastic spirit. His first two steps can be discerned and approached by men, but the third no one car dare transgress, and it is beyond the flight of birds (·πöV. I. 155.5). The wise see the highest place of Vi·π£·πáu(Paramam padam), as it were an eye fixed in the heaven (·πöV. I. 22. 201. In the highest place of Vi·π£·πáu there is a well of honey, and there the gods rejoice (·πöV. I 154, 5). Vi·π£·πáu appears as the comrade and helper of Indra.

Vi·π£·πáu, however, in spite of his comparatively subordinate position in ·πöV, began to rise in importance in the time of the BrƒÅhma·πáas, while during the epic and PurƒÅ·πáic period he rose to the rank of the supreme spirit. The moment which seems to have been in operation during this process of elevation, was reverence for the third step or the mysterious highest abode of Vi·π£·πáu beyond the ken of all. In the BrƒÅhma·πáic period we have the mention of Agni as the lowest of the gods and Vi·π£·πáu as the highest (AB.1.1). Then we have a story in ≈öatapatha-BrƒÅhma·πáa and Taittiriya-ƒÄra·πáyaka of a sacrificial session held by the gods for the attainment of splendour, glory and food. They proposed to themselves that he amongst them, who by his deeds reached the end of the sacrifice before the others, should attain the highest place among them all. Vi·π£·πáu reached the end before the others, and he thus became the highest of the gods; and therefore they say that Vi·π£·πáu is the highest of the gods (≈öB. XIV. 1. 1.). When this was written, Vi·π£·πáu had already attained to the supreme dignity, and the story is invented to account for it. There is again in the same BrƒÅhma·πáa (1. 2. 5) the story of Vi·π£·πáu the dwarf. When the gods and Asuras were contending for a place of sacrifice, the latter agreed that they would allow as much land for the former as was equal to the size of the dwarf. Vi·π£·πáu was then made to lie down, but gradually he grew so large as to encompass the

whole earth, and so the gods got the whole earth. Here a miraculous power has been attributed to Vi·π£·πáu, though he is not necessarily the Supreme Spirit.

In the Maitri-Upani·π£ad (VI. 13) food is called the form of Bhagavad-Vi·π£·πáu, which sustains the universe. In the Ka·π≠ha-Upani·π£ad (III. 9) the progress of the human soul is compared to a journey, and the end of the path which he traverses is called. the highest place of VVi·π£·πáu (Paramam padam). This is the final goal and the abode of eternal bliss, and the use of the word in this sense lends support to the view that the elevation of Vi·π£·πáu to the dignity of the Supreme Being was due to the fact that the expression was capable of being used to denote this sense. Some time after, Vi·π£·πáu became even a household god. In the ceremony of the seven steps contained in the marriage ritual, the bridegroom has to say to the bride, when she puts forth a step :” May Vi·π£·πáu lead you or be with you.” This formula occurs in the G·πõhya-s≈´tras of ƒÄpastamba, Hira·πáyake≈õin and PƒÅraskara, but not in that of ƒÄ≈õvalƒÅyana. In epic times Vi·π£·πáu grew to be in every respect. the Supreme Spirit; and VƒÅsudeva is identified with Vi·π£·πáu. In chapters 65 and 66 of the Bhƒ´·π£maparvan noticed before15, the Supreme Spirit is addressed as NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa and Vi·π£·πáu and is identified with VƒÅsudeva.

In the Anugƒ´tƒÅ portion of the ƒÄ≈õvamedhikaparvan (chap.53-55) K·πõ·π£·πáa, while returning to DvƒÅrakƒÅ, meets on the way a sage of the name of Utta·πÖka of the Bh·πõgu race. The sage asks K·πõ·π£·πáa whether he had established peace between the contending kinsmen, PƒÅ·πá·∏çus and Kurus, and established affectionate relations between them. K·πõ·π£·πáa replies that the Kurus had been destroyed and the PƒÅ·πá·∏çus were in possession of the supreme sovereignty. The sage got angry and said that he would pronounce a curse against K·πõ·π£·πáa , but if he explained to him the philosophy of the soul (AdhyƒÅtma), he would desist. K·πõ·π£·πáa then does explain this philosophy at the request of Utta·πÖka and shows him his universal form (VirƒÅt svar≈´pam). The Svar≈´pa is the same as, or similar to, that shown to Arjuns according to the Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅ, but it is here called the Vai·π£·πáava form (R≈´pa), which name does not occur. in the other passage. Thus then between the period of the BhƒÅga

vadgƒ´tƒÅand that of the Anugƒ´tƒÅ, the identity of VƒÅsudeva-K·πõ·π£·πáa with Vi·π£·πáu had become an established fact. In the ≈öƒÅntiparvan (chap. 43) Yudhi·π£·π≠hira addressing K·πõ·π£·πáa sings a hymn of praise, in which K·πõ·π£·πáa is identified with Vi·π£·πáu. In the epic times, Vi·π£·πáu is regarded as the Supreme Spirit, but the names of NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa and VƒÅsudeva-Vi·π£·πáu apparently occur more frequently or are more. prominent.

¬ß 36. Still many parts of the MƒÅhƒÅbharata represent a condi tion of things in which the divinity VƒÅsudeva-K·πõ·π£·πáa was not generally acknowledged. In the above passage from the Anugƒ´tƒÅ, the sage Utta·πáka is about to pronounce a curse on K·πõ·π£·πáa, as if he was an ordinary individual, and desists only when his universal form is shown to him. Similarly in many passages noticed by Dr. Muir (O. S. T. IV, pp. 205ff.) K·πõ·π£·πáa’s divinity is denied; and Sa·πÅjaya and Bhƒ´·π£ma make strenuous efforts to establish it.

What appears to be the fact is, that the religion of VƒÅsudeva, in which divine honours were paid to him, was professed by the SƒÅtvatas, as observed in several of the passages noticed above, and its gradual extension to other tribes and people of the country is shadowed forth in these portions of the great epic. In the PurƒÅ·πáictimes, however, the cult of VƒÅsudeva ceased to be militant, and three streams of religious thought, namely, the one flowing from Vi·π£·πáu, the Vedic god at its source, another from NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, the cosmic and philosophic god, and the third from VƒÅsudeva, the historical god, mingled together decisively and thus formed the later Vai·π£·πáavism. There is however, a fourth stream, which in modern times in some. of the systems of Vai·π£·πáavism has acquired an aln ost exclusive predominance, and to this we shall now direct our attention.

IX. Identification of VƒÅsudeva-K·πõ·π£·πáa with the
Cowherd God (GopƒÅla-K·πõ·π£·πáa).

¬ß 37. There is no allusion to the cowherd K·πõ·π£·πáain the authorities we have hitberto quoted. The Inscriptions, the work of Pata√±jali and even the NƒÅrƒÅya·πáƒ´ya itself indicate no knowledge of the existence of such a god. In the last the AvƒÅtars of VƒÅsudevais mentioned as having been assumed for the destruction of Ka·πÅsa, but of none of the demens whom the cowered K·πõ·π£·πáakilled in the

cow-settlement (Gokula). The contrast between this and the statements in the Hariva·πÅ≈õa (vv. 5876-5878), VƒÅyu-PurƒÅ·πáa, chap. 98, vv. 100-102, and BhƒÅgavata-PurƒÅ·πáa, II. 7, of K·πõ·π£·πáa’s Avatara having been assumed for destroying all the demons that appeared in the cow-settlement as well as of Ka·πÅsa-is significant. When these works were written, the legend about the cowherd K·πõ·π£·πáa must have already become current and his identification with VƒÅsudeva-K·πõ·π£·πáa been effected. And the story of the V·πõ·π£·πái prince VƒÅsudeva having been brought up in a cow-settlement is incongruous with his later career as depicted in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata. Nor does any part of it require the presupposition of such a boyhood as has been ascribed to him.

In the SabhƒÅparvan (chap. 41), however, ≈öi≈õupƒÅla in traducing K·πõ·π£·πáa alludes to his valorous deeds, such as the killing of P≈´tanƒÅ and others, which were done in the cow-settlement, and speaks of Bhi·π£ma’s having praised them. But the praise bestowed on K·πõ·π£·πáa by Bhi·π£ma (chap. 38) does not contain a mention of these deeds. This passage therefore is interpolated¬π.

___________________________________________________________________________

1.The Southern Recension of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata contains many interpolations.. In the NƒÅrƒÅya·πáƒ´ya, chap. 338 of the Northern Recension corresponds to chap, 344 of the Southern. We have six verses in the latter which are not contained in the former. They speak of animals made of flour being killed. Instead of real live animals. This is a later doctrine, which is strongly advocated by the MƒÅdhva Vai·π£·πáavas, but denied with as much pertinacity by SmƒÅrtas. In the present case in the SabhƒÅparvan, chap. 22, vv. 27-36 about K·πõ·π£·πáa’s doings in Gokula are in S, and not in N. Chapter 23 in S, about K·πõ·π£·πáa’s birth and removal to Gokuls is not in N. Chapter 24, 8, vv. 4-5 about JarƒÅsa·πÅidha’s declining to fight with K·πõ·π£·πáa , because he was a Gopa, are not found in chap. 21, N, which corresponds to that chapter. Chapters. 33 and 34 in S. are not in N. The first is about Sahadeva’s expedition to the PƒÅ·πá·∏çya country and the second about Gha·π≠otkaca’s being sent to La·πÖka and Vibhƒ´·π£a·πáa’s paying tribute out of respect for K·πõ·π£·πáa. At the end of chap. 39 in S, corresponding to chap. 36 in N, there is an interpolated passage, in which the worship done to K·πõ·π£·πáa is derided as having been done to a Gopa or cowlerd. This is not found in N. Chapters 42-61 in 8, are not found in N. They contain a mention of the AvatƒÅras of Vi·π£·πáu and his exploits it Gokula. Chap. 64 in S, corresponds to chap. 41 in N. Thus attempts have always been made to bring by means of interpolations the stories told in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata to the form which they subsequently assume. The passage dealt with in the text is a clear interpolation.

The name Govinda does occur in the Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅand other parts of MahƒÅbhƒÅrata. It is an ancient name, being derived by a VƒÅrttika on P. III. 1. 138. If this name was given to K·πõ·π£·πáa, be cause of his having had to do with cows, while a boy in Gokula, and his previous history in the cow-settlement was known, when the genuine portions of the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata were composed, we should have found an etymology of the name expressive of that connection. But, on the contrary, in the ƒÄdiparvan it is stated that Govinda is so called, because in the form of a boar he found the earth (Go) in the waters, which ho agitated (chap. 21. 12); and in the ≈öƒÅntiparvan (chap. 342. 70) VƒÅsudeva says: “I am called Govinda by the gods, because formerly I found the earth which was lost and lodged in a den”. The origin of the name may be traced to this legend, but more probably Govinda is a later form of Govid, which in the ·πögveda is used as an epithet of Indra in the sense of the finder of the cows. This opithet, as another. Ke≈õini·π£≈´dana which is also applicable to Indra, must have been transferred to VƒÅsudeva-K·πõ·π£·πáa, when he came to be looked upon as the chief god.

From all this it appears that the story of K·πõ·π£·πáa’s boyhood in the Gokula was unknown till about the beginning of the Christian Era. The Hariva·πÅ≈õa which is the chief authority for it, contains the word Dƒ´nƒÅra, corresponding to the Latin word Denarius, and oonsequently must have been written about the third century of the Christian era. Some time before that the stories of K·πõ·π£·πáa’s boyhood must have been current. The nature of the tribe of cowherds among whom K·πõ·π£·πáa lived, is to he gathered from the words of the boy-god-addressed to his foster-father Nanda, in order to dissuade him from celebrating a festival to Indra, and induce. him to worship the mountain Govardhana instead. “We sre cowherds,” he says, he says, “wandering in forests, maintaining our selves on cows, which are cows, which are our wealth; cows are our deities, and mountains and forests” (H. 3808). The cowherds lived in a Gho·π£a or temporary encampment, which was capable of being easily removed from place to place, as when they left Vraja and encamped in V·πõndƒÅvana (H. 3532). Gho·π£a is defined as ƒÄbhirapallƒ´, which is generally understood as the enclosure of cowherds.

But the original signification of the word ƒÄbhƒ´ra is not a cow

herd. It is the name of a race, whose original oooupation was the tending of cows; and consequently the name became in later. times equivalent to a ‘cowherd’. For these reasons the cowherda among whom the boy-god K·πõ·π£·πáa lived, belong to a nomadic tribe of the name of ƒÄbhƒ´ras. These ƒÄbhƒ´ras occupied the tract of country from Madhuvana near MathurƒÅto An≈´pa and ƒÄnarta, the regions about DvƒÅraka (H. 5161-5163). The ƒÄbhƒ´ras are mentioned in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata (Mausalaparvan, chap. 7) as having attacked Arjuna, who was carrying the women of the V·πõ·π£·πáis from DvƒÅraka to Kuruk·π£etra after the extinction of the male members. of the V·πõ·π£·πáirace. They are described as robbers and Mleochas, and lived near Pa√±canada, which is probably Punjab. The Vi·π£·πáu-PurƒÅ·πáa locates them near the AparƒÅntas (Konkan) and SaurƒÅ·π£tras, and VarƒÅhamihira assigns them nearly the same position. Though they are mentioned as the southern people ( B·πõ. S. 14. 12), and as living in the southwest (B·πõ. S. 14. 18), the ƒÄbhƒ´ras must have. migrated in large hordes into the country. They were at first. mere nomads and afterwards settled in the country from about the eastern confines of the Punjab to the vicinity of MathurƒÅand in the south up to SaurƒÅ·π£·π≠ra and Kathiavad, i. e., they must have. occupied the whole of RaiputƒÅna and a tract to the northeast of it. After they were settled, they took to various occupations, one. of which was of course the old one, namely the tending of cows.

The descendants of the old ƒÄbhƒ´ras are called ƒÄhirs at the present day, and we have now ƒÄhirs following the occupation of carpenters, goldsmiths, cowherds and even priesthood. At one time they founded a kingdom in the nothern part of the Maratha country, and an Inscription of the ninth year of the ƒÄbhƒ´ra king. I≈õvarasena, the son of ƒÄbhƒ´ra ≈öivadatta, is found at Nasik16. From the form of the characters the Inscription probably belongs. to the end of the third century. The PurƒÅ·πáas mention a dynasty of ƒÄbhƒ´ras composed of ten princes. Another Inscription of an earlier date is found at GundƒÅ17in Kathiavad, in which the charities of Rudrabh≈´ti, a general, who is called an ƒÄbhƒ´ra, are mentioned. The Inscription belongs to the reign of a K·π£atrapa

king of the name of Rudrasi·πÅha, who held power in ≈öaka 102 corresponding to 180 A. D.

If then about the end of the second century and in the third, the ƒÄbhiras enjoyed high political position, they must have migrated into the country in the first century. They probably brought with them the worship of the boy-god and the story of his humble birth, his reputed father’s knowledge that he was not his son, and the massacre of the innocents.The two last correspond to Nanda’s knowing that he was not the father of K·πõ·π£·πáa and Ka·πÅsa’s killing all children. The stories of K·πõ·π£·πáa’s hoyhood, such as that of killing Dhenuka, a demon in the form of a wild ass, were brought by ƒÄbhiras18, and others were developed after they came to India. It is possible that they brought with them the name Christ also, and this name probably led to the identification of the boy-god with VƒÅsudeva-K·πõ·π£·πáa, The Goanese and the Bengalis often pronounce the name K·πõ·π£·πáa as Ku·π£·π≠o or Kri·π£·π≠o, and so the Christ of the ƒÄbhiras was recognised as the Sanskrit K·πõ·π£·πáa.

The dalliance of K·πõ·π£·πáa with cowherdesses, which introduced an element inconsistent with the advance of morality into the VƒÅsudeva religion, was also an after-growth, consequent upon the freer intercourse between the wandering ƒÄbhƒ´ras and their more civilised ƒÄryan neighbours. Morality cannot be expected. to be high or strict among races in the condition of the ƒÄbhƒ´ras at the time and their gay neighbours took advantage of its looseness. Besides, the ƒÄbhƒ´rawomen must have been fair and handsome as those of the ƒÄhir-Gavaliyas or cowherds of the present day are.

¬ß 38. The story in the Buddhistic GhatajƒÅtaka represents VƒÅsudeva and his brothers to be the sons of Ka·πÅsa’s sister DevagabbhƒÅand UpasƒÅgara. They were made over to a man of the name of Andhakave·πáhu and to his wife NandagopƒÅ who was the attendant of DevagabbhƒÅ. In this version there is a remi niscence of Devakƒ´ in the name DevagabbhƒÅ; and Nanda and Ya≈õodƒÅ or GopƒÅof Gokula are compounded together to form the name of the maid-servant who brought up DevagabbhƒÅ’s sons as

her sons. And in Andhakave·πáhu the names of the two kindred YƒÅdava tribes, Andhaka and V·πõ·π£·πái, are compounded together, and the compound becomes the name of the husband of the maid-servant. Now as Andhaka and V·πõ·π£·πái were according to the highest authorities two distinot names, and were the names of the two tribes, this story contains a confused reminiscence of the true legend and was of a later growth. All the JƒÅtakas were not written at one and the same time. While sone belong to a pre-Christian period, others must be assigned to post-Christian times, and the GhatajƒÅtaka appears to me to belong to the latter class. The compound NandagopƒÅ, therefore, though it contains a clear reminiscence of the foster-parents of the boy-god K·πõ·π£·πáa, cannot be considered to point to a pre-Christian period for the identification of VƒÅsudeva-K·πõ·π£·πáa with GopƒÅla-K·πõ·π£·πáa.

X. The PƒÅ√±carƒÅtra or BhƒÅgavata System.

¬ß 39. We have thus gone over the last element which goes to form the Vai·π£·πáavism of the later times. That element, however, does not formi a prominent part, or forms no part at all, of the systems which are based upon the old PƒÅ√±carƒÅtra doctrines As we have seen, the EkƒÅntika Dharma or monotheistic religion was that which was promulgated by the Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅ; but the PƒÅ√±carƒÅtrasystem, consisting, as it did, of the worship of VƒÅsudeva and his several forms, shows no organic connection with that work, though Bhakti or devotion is common to both. That system must have developed in about the third century B. C., as. we have already seen from the Inscriptions and passages in books referred to before. Their being free from the GopƒÅla-K·πõ·π£·πáa element is thus intelligible, and the later Vai·π£·πáava systems, such as that of RƒÅmƒÅnuja and Madhva, which more or less recognise the old BhƒÅgavata doctrines or ideas, have entirely neglected that element. In other systems, however, it is recognised and in a general way in popular Vai·π£·πáavism.

The authorities on which the BhƒÅgavata system was based are the PƒÅ√±carƒÅtra-Sa·πÅhitƒÅs; and RƒÅmƒÅnuja in his comments on the Brahmas≈´tras, II. 2. 39-42, quotes from some of these. The first quotation is from the Pau·π£kara-Sa·πÅhitƒÅ, which is intended to show that, when BrƒÅhma·πáas worship the fourfold soul with the

traditional names, it should be considered authoritative. The second is from the SƒÅtvata-Sa·πÅhitƒÅ, which is to the effect that this great ≈öƒÅstra contains the secret of Brahman and imparts discrimination to BrƒÅhma·πáas who worship the true Brahmani bearing the name of VƒÅsudeva. There are two from the Parama-Sa·πÅhitƒÅ. One of these gives the nature of Prak·πõti, which is unsentient, of use to another than “itself”, eternal, always changeable, composed of three qualities, and is the sphere within which the action of agents is done. The other represents somebody, probably ≈öƒÅ·πá·∏çilya himself, as saying that he has studied all the Vedas with the dependent treatises and VƒÅkovƒÅkya, but not. having found the way to supreme bliss clearly stated in them.

One of these Sa·πÅhitƒÅs, bearing the name of SƒÅtvata, has been printed and is available. It begins by saying that Narada saw Para≈õurƒÅma on the Malaya Mountain and was told by him to visit the ·πösis, who were in search of the place of Hari, and to instruct them in the SƒÅtvatamethod of worship (KriyƒÅmƒÅrga). NƒÅrada does this and explains to them the secret traditional methods (RahasyƒÅmnƒÅya). NƒÅrƒÅyana is spoken of here as the supreme spirit. The secret methods were formerly explained by the bearer of the discus (VƒÅsudeva ), when asked by Sa·πÅkar·π£a·πáa. Sa·πÅkar·π£a·πáa spoke to Vi·π£·πáu at the beginning of the TretƒÅage, asking why his countenance had become red. The answer is: “Because the people will be afflicted with passion in this age”. Being asked how they will be delivered from passion, Sa·πÅkar·π£a·πáa is told that they will be delivered by adoring the eternal and highest Brahman in three ways. The Supreme Spirit, who has hands and feet and eyes everywhere and is endowed with six Gu·πáas or qualities, is Para or the Highest. It is one and the support of all. Besides this there is a triad, each member of which is distinguished from the others by a distinction in knowledge and other qualities. These three should be known as Vy≈´has, or forms, who confer the desired fruit with ease.

BalarƒÅma then asks about the mode of service. Bhagvat then explains it as follows” When the pure BrƒÅhman, which is the aim and end of the creation, exists in the heart of qualified BrƒÅhma·πáas, who worship VƒÅsudeva, the highest ≈öƒÅstra, which is a

great Upani·π£ad of Brahman, springs forth from it for the redemption of the world and confers discrimination; it contains divine. methods and has for its fruit final deliverance¬π. I will then explain that to you which is of verious kinds. This ≈öƒÅstra, along with Rahasya, is fruitful to those who have gone through Yoga with its eight parts, and whose soul is devoted to mental sacrifice. The Yogins, who are BrƒÅhma·πáas guided by the Vedas and who have given up the mixed worship, are competent for the worship. of the single one, dwelling in the heart. The three orders, K·π£atriya and others, and those who are Prapanna or have resorted to self-surrender are competent for the worship of the four Vy≈´has accompanied by Mantras, and also unaccompanied by them, so far as regards the series of ceremonies concerning the four Vy≈´has as well as the actions and the collection of Mantras concerning the Vibhavas¬≤. All these persons should be free from attachment and absorbed in the performance of their duties and be devotees of the supreme lord by their deeds, words and mind. In this manner, the four (orders) become competent, when they are initiated (for service) with Mantras. Hear now the process concerning the single form “. Then follows the statement of the mystic arrangement of letters and formulae and the meditations. This work throughout contains the mystic modes of worship by means of Mantras variously arranged.

The allusion at the end of Chapter 66 of the Bhƒ´·π£maparvan to Sa·πÅkarsa·πáa’s having sung or expounded VƒÅsudeva according to the SƒÅtvata rites (Vidhi) refers in all probability to such rites as are detailed in this SƒÅtvata-Sa·πÅhitƒÅ.

≈öa·πÅkarƒÅcƒÅrya, in his notice of the BhƒÅgavataSchool under B·πõ. S. II. 2. 42, gives five methods of worshipping the supreme lord, BhƒÅgavat VƒÅsudeva, in his fourfold form, which, along with the explanations given by the commentators, are as follows:- (1) Abhigamana or going to the temple of the deity with the speech, the body and the mind centred on him; (2) UpƒÅdƒÅns or collecting the materials of worship; (3) IjyƒÅor worship; (4) SvƒÅdhyaya or the muttering of the usual Mantra; (5) Yoga ormeditation. By worshipping him in these ways for a hundred. years, all sin is destroyed and the devotee reaches Bhagavat.

___________________________________________________________________________

1.Two lines out of this are contained in the quotations from RƒÅmƒÅnuja given. above.

2.Vibbavas are the incarnations of the Supreme Spirit.

¬ß40. The book called NƒÅradapa√±carƒÅtra, published by the Asiatic Society of Bengal, contains the Sa·πÅhitƒÅcalled J√±ƒÅnƒÅm·πõitasƒÅra. The glories of the boy K·πõ·π£·πáa are sung in this work. NƒÅrada desiring to know K·πõ·π£·πáa’s greatness and the methods of his worship is recommended to go to ≈öa·πÅkara, or ≈öiva, and seek instruction from him. NƒÅrada repairs to KailƒÅsa and enters the palace of ≈öa·πÅkara, which has seven gates. At these gates there are pictures and sculptures relating to the scenes of K·πõ·π£·πáa’s childhood and his various deeds in the cow-settlement, such as V·πõ·πá·∏çavana, YamunƒÅ, K·πõ·π£·πáa’s sitting on the Kadamba tree with the garments of the cowherdesses and their return from bath in the YamunƒÅ river in a naked condition, the destruction of the serpent KƒÅliya, the holding up of the Govardhana mountain on the palm of his hand, the journey to MathurƒÅ and the lamentations of the. Gopƒ´s and his foster-parents, etc. Sculptures representing some of these events were discovered on a pillar excavated at Mandor near Jodhpur about two years ago19. The age of the pillar has been considered not earlier than the fourth century A. D. The idea of imagining such sculptures on the gates of ≈öiva’s palace could have. occurred to a writer only when the practice of adorning gates and pillars with such sculptures had become general. The J√±ƒÅnƒÅm·πõtasƒÅra, therefore, could not have been earlier than fourthcentury and appears to me to be considerably later, as will be presently shown.

Goloka or the world of cows is the heaven in which K·πõ·π£·πáa dwells and which is reached by those who adore him, and several Mantras are given in this book, the reciters of which are rewarded. with a place in that heaven. The servitude of Hari through devotion is the highest Mukti or absolution according to this work. There are six modes of adoring Hari; viz., (1) remembrance of him, (2) utterance, ( of his name and glory ). ( 3 ) salutation, (4) resorting to his feet, (5) constant worship of him with devotion, and (6) surrender of the whole soul to him. The BhƒÅgavata-PurƒÅ·πáa adds three more, viz., hearing (his praise ), servitude, and companionship (·π†akhyam). These last two are preliminary to

the surrendering of the whole soul. In this book RƒÅdhƒÅ is mentioned as the highest of the women whom K·πõ·π£·πáa loved, and she is represented to have been formed by the original lord becoming two, one of which was RƒÅdhƒÅ (IL 3. 24ff.). The exaltation of this woman is thus one of the main objects of this Sa·πÅhitƒÅ.

The Sa·πÅhitƒÅ we have been considering, seems thus to be entirely devoted to the advancement of the cult of the K·πõ·π£·πáa of the cow-settlement or Gokula and of his beloved mistress RƒÅdhƒÅ, now raised to the dignity of his eternal consort. The Vy≈´has which form a peculiarity of the PƒÅ√±carƒÅtra School, are not mentioned. in it. The creed afterwards promulgated by VallabhƒÅoƒÅrya is exactly similar to that set forth in this book. This Sa·πÅhitƒÅ, therefore, must have heen written a short time before Vallabha, that is about the beginning of the sixteenth century. The RƒÅmƒÅnujiyas consider this Sa·πÅhitƒÅ to be apocryphal.

XI. The AvatƒÅras of Vi·π£·πáu or NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa.

¬ß 41. An AvatƒÅra or incarnation of a god differs from mereidentification of two gods in this, that in the former case the god that is considered an incarnation acts like a human being, or even a brute, at the same time that he has the miraculous powers of a god. The transition, however, from the idea of identification to that of incarnation is easy. The person in the flesh is identified with the god who is a mere spirit, so that the habit of thought which in Vedic times led to the identification of some of the Vedic deities with Agni, has been at work even in this conception of the AvatƒÅras.

The AvatƒÅras of NƒÅrƒÅya·πáaor Vi·π£·πáu are variously given by the various authorities. In the passage in the NƒÅrƒÅya·πáƒ´yatranslated above20,’ six only are given, viz, the boar, the manlion, the dwarf, RƒÅma of the Bh·πõgu race,RƒÅma DƒÅ≈õarathi and that assumed for the destruction of Ka·πÅsa (VƒÅsudeva-K·πõ·π£·πáaThis passage is followed after a short interval by another in which the incarnations are given as ten, the additions being Ha·πÅsa (swan), K≈´rma (turtoise), and Matsya (fish) in the beignning and Kalkin at the end. The one preceding Kalkin is called SƒÅtvata, i. e.. VƒÅsudeva-K·πõ·π£·πáa. This passage, following so closely on the

first, appears to be interpolated when the number of AvatƒÅras became fixed at ten.

The Hariva·πÅ≈õa mentions the six given in the first of these two passages. The VƒÅyu-PurƒÅ·πáa gives the incarnations in two passages (Chap. 97, vv. 72. and Chap. 98, vv. 63ff.), in the first of which there are twelve, but some of them appear rather to be incarnations of ≈öiva and Indra. In the second the number ten, which about that time must have come into usage, is made up by adding to the six mentioned above the four: DattƒÅtreya, one unnamed called the fifth, VedavyƒÅsa, and Kalkin. In the VarƒÅha-PurƒÅ≈Üa we have the ten incarnations which came to be accepted later, oon- taining the Fish, Tortoise, Buddha, and Kalkin, in addition to the six mentioned above. The Agni-PurƒÅ·πáa gives the same ten.

The BhƒÅgavata-PurƒÅ·πáa enumerates the incarnations in three. different passages. In the first, contained in Chapter 3 of Book I, twenty-two are mentioned. In the passage in Chapter 7 of Book II, we have twenty-three, and in Chapter 4 of Book XI, sixteen are given. It deserves notice that among the AvatƒÅras mentioned in this PurƒÅ·πáa are SanatkumƒÅra; the divine sage (NƒÅrada), who expounded the SƒÅtvata system; Kapila who explain d to ƒÄsuri the SƒÅ·πÅkhyasystem, which determines the collection. of principles; DattƒÅtreya, who is represented to have taught ƒÄnvƒ´k·π£ikƒ´ to Alarka and the PrahrƒÅda and the attainment of excellence hy means of Yoga to Yadu and Haihaya; ·πö·π£abha, son of NƒÅbhi and Merudevƒ´, who abandoned attachment to all things, acquired serenity, and looking at all things alike and possessing Yoga power, acted as if he were a non-living creature; and lastly Dhanvantari, the teacher of the science of medicine.

·πö·π£abha, from the parentage given here and other indications, appears clearly to be the same as the first Tƒ´rtha·πÅkara of the Jainas. He was probably raised to the dignity of an incarnation as the Buddha of the Buddhists was. There is hardly a wide-spread cult of any of these incarnations except DattƒÅtreya, who is adored and worshipped by a large number of people to this day, and RƒÅma of whom more will have to be said hereafter. K·πõ·π£·πáa, of course, though. included in the AvatƒÅras stands on independent grounds and his worship over the widest area is due, not to his having been con

sidered an AvatƒÅra, but to his being the peculiar object of adora. tion of the followers of a new religion or religious reform, as I have ventured to call it, which first took its rise among the SƒÅtvatas.

XII. Later Traces of the BhƒÅgavata School;
and General Vai·π£·πáavism.

¬ß 42. We will now resume the chronological thread we have traced from Megasthenes to the latest Inscription, that at Nanaghat, which is to be referred to the first century B. C. For about four centuries after this there are no epigraphical or sculptural traces of any BrƒÅhmanic religious system; and they reappear about the time when the Guptas rose to power in the first quarter of the fourth century. The Gupta princes, Candragupta II, KumƒÅragupta, and Skandagupta, are styled ParamabhƒÅgavatas on their coins. They were thus worshippers of Bhagavat or VƒÅsudeva. Their dates range from 400 to 464 A. D.

On a panel at Udayagiri, there is a figure of a four-armed god, who is probably Vi·π£·πáu. The Inscription below bears the date. 82 G. E., i. e.. 400 A. D.21

There is a pillar at Bhitari in the Ghazipur District of the U. P., on which there is an Inscription which records the installation of an image of ≈öƒÅr·πÖgin and the grant of a village for its worship by Skandagupts, whose dates range between 454 and 464 A. D22. ≈öƒÅr·πÖgin must have been VƒÅsudeva-K·πõ·π£·πáa,Skanda- gupta himself being a BhƒÅgavata.

A temple of Vi·π£·πáu was erected in 456 A. D. by CakrapƒÅlita, son of Par·πáadatta, appointed viceroy of SurƒÅ·π£·π≠ra or Kathiavad by Skandagupta. The Inscription, which records this, opens with an invocation of Vi·π£·πáu in the VƒÅmana or the dwarf incarnation23.

In an Inscription at Eran in the Sagar district, C. P., belonging to the reign of Budhagupta and bearing the date 165 G. E., corresponding to 483 A. D., MƒÅtrvi·π£·πáu and his younger brother Dhanyavi·π£·πáuare represented to have erected & Dhvajastambha or flag-

staff in honour of the god JanƒÅrdana. MƒÅt·πõvi·π£·πáu is called a great devotee of BhƒÅgavat (Atyanta-Bhagavad-bhakta24). The god JanƒÅrdana must therefore be VƒÅsudeva-Kr·π£·πáa.

A copper-plate Inscription of A. D. 495, found near the village. of Khoh in Baghelkhand, records the grant of a village, by a chief named JayanƒÅtha, to Bhagavat for repairs to the temple of that god and for the performance of ordinary ceremonies25.

An Inscription on an iron pillar near Kutub Minar at Delhi speaks of that pillar as a flag-staff to Vi·π£·πáu erected by a great king named Candra, who enjoyed universal sovereignty and was a great devotee of Vi·π£·πáu. The Inscription is not dated, but if the Candra referred to here was Candragupta II, it belongs to the latter part of the fourth century or the beginning of the fifth26.

In his Meghad≈´ta (v. 15) KalidƒÅsa compares the cloud adorned with a piece of a rain-bow, with Vi·π£·πáu in the shape of the cow-herd. adorned with a shining peacock feather. Here there is an identification of GopƒÅla-Kr·π£·πáa with Vi·π£·πáu; and, if the VikramƒÅditya who was the patron of KalidƒÅsa was Candragupta II of the Gupta Dynasty, this must be considered to be a record belonging to the early part of the fifth century.

We have already alluded to the sculptures on a pillar excavated at Mandor near Jodhpur. These sculptures represent the overturning of a cart by the baby Kr·π£·πáa, the holding of the Govardhana Mountain by Kr·π£·πáa on the palm of his hand, and such other events. I refer them tentatively to the fifth century.

In ≈öaka 500, Ma·πÖgalƒ´≈õa, a prince belonging to the early CƒÅlukya dynasty of the Deccan, got a cave scooped out, in which a temple to Vi·π£·πáu was constructed, and an image of Vi·π£·πáu was installed in it. The provision for the performance of NƒÅrƒÅya·πáabali (offerings to NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa) was made by assigning the revenues of a village for the purpose27. In this cave-temple there are figures. of Vi·π£·πáu and NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa lying on the body of a serpent, with Lak≈ümƒ´rubbing his feet, and of the Boar and Narasi·πÅha incarna

tions, and of Harihara in which the peculiar marks of Hari, or Vi·π£·πáu, and of Hara, or ≈öiva, are combined28.

In mentioning the priests who are qualified to install and conseorate the images of certain gods, VarƒÅhamihira says that this function in the case of Vi·π£·πáu should be assigned to BhƒÅgavatas29. BhƒÅgavatas were thus recognised in his time as the peculiar worshippers of Vi·π£·πáu. VarƒÅhamihira died in ≈öaka, i. e. 587 A.D.30

Amarasi·πÅha, the author of the well-known Ko≈õa or thesaurus, was a Buddhist. After giving the words expressive of gods. generally, when he comes to the names of particular gods, he begins by giving those of Buddha and proceeds next to give the names Vi·π£·πáu, NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa etc., of which we have thirty-nine. After finishing these he says that VƒÅsudeva was his father. This means that the thirty-nine names proviously given are the names of VƒÅsudeva. If we examine these, we shall find that hefore Amare’s time VƒÅsudeva had already been identified with Vi·π£·πáu and NƒÅrƒÅya·πáaExcept the name DƒÅmodara, there is no other con- necting VƒÅsudeva with Gokula, and the etymology of DƒÅmodara which connects him with that cow-settlement is doubtful. While Ka·πÅsƒÅrƒÅti, or the enemy of Ka·πÅsa, does occur, we have no such name as P≈´tanƒÅri, the enemy of P≈´tanƒÅ, or any other derived. from the names of the many demons he slew while he was a boy. There are also no names of incarnations except the doubtful one, Balidhva·πÅsin, which however, has been interpreted by one. commentator as the destroyer of ignorance by means of Bali or oblations. There are, of course, several names derived from those. of other demons, such as Madhuripu and Kaitabhajit, but these are not the enemies destroyed by Vi·π£·πáu in his incarnations as they are usually mentioned. After giving the name of the father of VƒÅsudeva-K·πõ·π£·πáa, Amara proceeds to mention those of Sa·πÅkarsana, or Baladeva, and afterwards of Pradyumna and Aniruddha. Thereafter he mentions those of Lak·π£mi, the wife of NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa or Vi·π£·πáu, then those of the weapons of the god and his ornaments, and ends with the names of Garu·∏ça, the vehicle of Vi·π£·πáu After

finishing these he proceeds to the other great god of the Hindus, ≈öambhu or ≈öiva.

Here Amara appears clearly to have in view the four forms, or Vy≈´has, of VƒÅsudeva recognised by the BhƒÅgavatas, so that in his time the prevalent form of Vai·π£·πáavism was that embraced by the BhƒÅgavatas. Amara’s exact age is doubtful, but, if he was a Buddhist, he must have belonged to the MahƒÅyƒÅna sect, the sacred language of which was Sanskrit. This system was in full swing in the fourth, fifth and sixth centuries¬π. Amarasi·πÅha, therefore, must have flourished in this last century, or, if we believe in the traditional verse which asserts his contemporaneousness with KalidƒÅsa and in Candragupta II as VikramƒÅditya, the famous patron of learning, he must have flourished in the early part of the fifth century. The identity of VƒÅsudeva-K·πõ·π£·πáa with GopalaK·πõ·π£·πáa is very rarely alluded to, while that with Vi·π£·πáu and NƒÅrƒÅya·πáaa is clearly set forth.

About the middle of the seventh century, BƒÅ·πáain his Har·π£acarita represents a sage of the name of DivƒÅkaramitra, who, originally a BrƒÅhma·πáa, became a Buddhist, as being surrounded in the Vindhya mountains, where he had his abode, by followers of a number of sects two of which were the BhƒÅgavatas and PƒÅ√±carƒÅtras.

In the Da≈õƒÅvatƒÅra temple at Ellora there is a figure of Vi·π£·πáu on the body of a serpent with Lak·π£mi rubbing his feet and BrahmƒÅseated on a lotus coming out of his navel. There are also images of the Narasi·πÅha, VƒÅmana and VarƒÅha incarnations, as well as of K·πõ·π£·πáa holding the Govardhana Mountain over the flocks of the cow-settlement. This temple was constructed about the middle of the eighth century in the time of Dantidurga of the RƒÅ·π£·π≠rak≈´·π≠a race. There are similar figures of AvatƒÅras in the KailƒÅsa temple. scooped out in the latter part of the eighth century, in the time of K·πõ·π£·πáa I, uncle of Dantidurga. Among these is also the scene of the destruction of KƒÅliya by K·πõ·π£·πáa.

There is an Inscription in a cave at Pabhosa, about 32 miles south-west of Allahabad, which probably had a human figure. above and runs thus: “The maker of the images of Sri-K·πõ·π£·πáa andthe milk-maids”. The date is uncertain, but the Inscription is referred to the seventh or eighth century by B√ºhler31.

___________________________________________________________________________

1.Vide my ‘Peep into the Early History of India’, JBBRAS, Vol. XX. p. 305;

[=Volume I of this Edition, p. 48 N. B. U.]

At Sirpur in the Raipur district, C. P.. over the front of a shrine-door there is a sculpture of Vi·π£·πáu or NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa reclining on the folds of the serpent ≈öe·π£a, and from his navel springs a lotus on which is seated BrahmƒÅ. Down the two outer sides of the shrinedoor are some of the incarnations of Vi·π£·πáu , one of which is that of RƒÅma and another of Buddha, whose image is in the usual meditative attitude. The temple belongs probably to the eighth century¬≤.

At Osia, 32 miles north of Jodhpur, there is an old temple adjoining to the house of the local Jahagirdar. On two pilasters. projecting from the shrine into the SabhƒÅma·πá·∏çapa, are two images of deities both seated on Garu·∏ça. Both have four hands, but one. of them holds a conch-shell, the discus, the mace and the lotus, and the other bears a plough-share and a mace in his two hands, the other two being empty. The last has his head canopied by a five-hooded serpent. They are apparently VƒÅsudeva and Sa·πÅkar·π£a·πáa. The temple cannot be later than the ninth century¬≥.

In a work called Dharmaparƒ´k·π£ƒÅ, Amitagati, the author, who was a Digambara Jaina, says that there were according to the legendary lore current among the Jainas sixty-three eminent men: the twelve supreme sovereigns, the twenty-four Arhats (Jinas), and nine RƒÅmas, nine Ke≈õavas, and the nine enemies of these mine. The last of the Vi·π£·πáus ( Ke≈õavas) was the son of VƒÅsudeva, and his BrƒÅhma·πáa devotees call him the pure, the supreme being. They say: “He who meditates upon the god Vi·π£·πáu, who is allpervading, a whole without parts, indestructible and unchangeable, who frees a man from old age and death, is free from misery”.He is traditionally known to have ton forms or incarnations. These ten forms are the same as mentioned in the VarƒÅha and AgniPurƒÅ·πáas32 and which are now generally accepted. Thus Buddha had come to be recognised as an incarnation of Vi·π£·πáu before

___________________________________________________________________________

2.Annual Progress Report of Archeological Survey, Western Circle, for 1903-04, p. 21.

3.See the forthcoming Annual Report of the Arch. Surv. of India [This note is printed as in the original Edition.-N. B. U.]

the date of the Dharmaparƒ´k·π£a, which is VikrƒÅma 1070, corresponding to 1014 A. D. If the approximate date assigned to the temple at Sirpur is correct, Buddha must have been admitted into the BrƒÅhma·πáicpantheon before the eighth century. Amitagati also speaks of the mighty Vi·π£·πáu having become a cowherd in Nanda’s Gokula and of the all-knowing, all-pervading protector of the world (RƒÅma) as being oppressed by the fire. of separation from Sit√§ like a mortal lover¬π.

Hence, we have evidence of the existence of the cult of Vi·π£·πáu, principally in accordance with the mode professed by the BhƒÅgavatas from the fourth to the eleventh century. The doctrine of the incarnations had also become an article of ordinary faith, and the founder of Buddhism and the first Tirtha·πÅkara of the Jainas also came later to be recognised as incarnations of Vi·π£·πáu.

XIII. The Cult of RƒÅma.

¬ß The architectural remains passed under review contain only figures of the incarnations of Vi·π£·πáu and are not to be taken. as proving the existence of the cult of any of these incarnations. But at the present day the cult of RƒÅmaexists over a pretty wide area. In the temples and other religious structures hitherto noticed, there is none dedicated to his worship nor any flag-staff like those erected in honour of JanƒÅrdana or VƒÅsudeva-K·πõ·π£·πáa. RƒÅma, however, was considered as an incarnation of Vi·π£·πáu even in very early times. There are passages in the RƒÅmaya·πáa pointing to this, but there is good reason to believe that they are spurious or interpolated. But the passage in the NƒÅrƒÅya·πáƒ´ya, which we have. frequently referred to, contains his name, and so do all the PurƒÅ·πáas that have been noticed. These in themselves are not sufficient to enable us to determine approximately the period in which he came to be regarded as an incarnation. But in the tenth chapter of the Raghuva·πÅ≈õa the story of the birth of RƒÅma is preceded by the usual appeal to Vi·π£·πáu or NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa lying on the body of the great serpent, with Lak·π£mi rubbing his feet, in the milky ocean and his promise to be born as a son of Da≈õaratha for the destruction of RƒÅva·πáa.

___________________________________________________________________________

1.For Amitagati’s work, see Vol. II of this edition, pp. 308ff.[N.B.U.]

[R. G. Bhandarker’s Works, Vol. IV.]

Amitagati also speaks in 1014 A. D., as we have seen33, of RƒÅma’s being regarded as the all-knowing, all-pervading protector of the world. The VƒÅyu-PurƒÅ·πáa, which is the earliest work of that class, must have been written about the fifth century; so that the belief in RƒÅma’s being an incarnation of Vi·π£·πáu existed. in all probability in the early centuries of the Christian Era. But there is no mention of his name in such a work as that of Pata√±jali, nor is there any old Inscription in which it occurs. Amarasi·πÅha, too, has no place for him in his scheme of BrƒÅhma·πáic gods. These circumstances, as well as those mentioned above, show that, though he was regarded as an AvatƒÅra, there was no cult in his honour. Still, as depicted by VƒÅlmƒ´ki, RƒÅma was a high-souled hero, and poets, including those nameless ones. who wrote PurƒÅ·πáas in the names of old ·πö·π£i, particularly Bhavabh≈´ti, still more highly exalted his character. RƒÅma, therefore, won a place in the heart of the Indian people, and that must have. soon led to the foundation of the cult. But when this took place it is difficult to say. Madhva or ƒÄnandatƒ´rtha, the founder of a sect to be noticed hereafter, is represented to have brought the image of Digvijaya RƒÅma from BadarikƒÅ≈õrama and sent Naraharitƒ´rtha to JagannƒÅtha about the year 1264 A. D34., to bring what was called the original idols of RƒÅma and Sits. The cult of RƒÅma, therefore, must have come into existence about the eleventh century. There exist manuals giving the modes of worship by means of Mantras or formulae and magic circles, like those proscribed in the SƒÅtvata-Sa·πÅhitƒÅfor the worship of VƒÅsudeva. The ceremony in connection with his birth on the 9th of the bright half of Caitra is given in his Vratakha·πá·∏ça35.")by HemƒÅdri, who flourished in the thirteenth century.
