That writer, as well as V·πõddhƒÅ-HƒÅrita‚Å¥, gives the modes of worshipping him as an incarnation along with others on certain occasions, so that it appears that his worship as an incarnation has been of a longer duration than that based on terms of equality with VƒÅsudeva-K·πõ·π£·πáa.

Twenty-four images, differing from each other in the order in which the four objects, viz., the conch-shell, disous, mace

___________________________________________________________________________

4.Vratakha·πá·∏ça pp. 1034ff.; Vrddba-HƒÅrita-Smrti (ƒÄnandƒÅ≈õrama Sanskrit Series), chap. X. v. 145.P.

and lotus, are placed in the four hands of the principal god VƒÅsudeva or Vi·π£·πáu, are mentioned by both those authors, and the twenty-four names¬π corresponding to the twenty-four images. Ke≈õava, NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, Govinda, etc., which include those of the four Vy≈´has, are repeated by us at the beginning of every ceremony that we perform at the present day; that is, obeisance is made to the twenty-four forms of the god by using the word Nama·∏• (salutations) after the dative of each of the names, and the sense is ‘Saluations to Ke≈õava, NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, etc,’. The name of RƒÅma, however, is not included in them, while two other AvatƒÅras, Narasi·πÅha and VƒÅmana, are mentioned. Every ≈örƒÅddha ceremony is wound up by the expression May JanƒÅrdana-VƒÅsudeva, who is a form of the ancestors, or the father, grandfather and great grandfather, be satisfied by this act”. All this shows that VƒÅsudevism has penetrated into every one of our ordinary ceremonies, which include a repetition even of Vedic Mantras, while this is not at all the case. with the cult of RƒÅma, which is, therefore of a modern growth.

There is a work, entitled the AdhyƒÅtma-RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa, which EkanƒÅtha36, a MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠ra saint, who flourished in the sixteenth century, calls a modern treatise, composed of excerpts from older writings and having no pretence to be considered as emanating from the old ·πö·π£is. The object of this work throughout has. been to set forth the divinity of RƒÅma. The first book of it com- prises what is called RƒÅmah·πõdaya, which which was narrated to Han≈´mat by Sƒ´tƒÅ, who says that as the original Prak·πõti, she does every thing and did all the deeds mentioned in the RƒÅmaya·πáa, while RƒÅma as the only existing soul is inactive, unchangeable and blessed, and is a mere witness of her deeds. After she has concluded, RƒÅma explains the threefold nature of the knowing spirit, viz., (1) the original, (2) that conditioned by Buddhi or

___________________________________________________________________________

1.(1) Ke≈õava, (2) NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, (3) Madhava, (4) Govinda, (5) Vi·π£·πáu, (6) Madhus≈´dana, (7) TrivikRƒÅma, (8) VƒÅmana. (9) ≈örƒ´dhara, (10) H·πõ·π£ike≈õa, (11) PadmanƒÅbha. (12) DƒÅmodara, (13) Sa·πÅkar·π£a·πáa, (14) VƒÅsudeva. (15) Pradyumna, (16) Aniruddha, (17) Puru·π£ottama. (18) Adhok·π£aja, (19) Narasi·πÅha, (20) Acyuta, (21) JanƒÅrdana, (23) Upendra, (23) Harl, (24) ≈örƒ´K·πõ·π£·πáa.

finiteintelligence, and (3) the appearances, the last two of which are fictitious. The fifth canto of the last book is styled RƒÅmagƒ´tƒÅ, which is meant to correspond to the Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅof VƒÅsudeva and which is narrated by RƒÅma to Lak·π£ma·πáa, who takes the place of Arjuna. The doctrine is thoroughly adualistic as that of the previous portion. The world and the individual soul are illusory, and one spirit alone exists. There is another book called RƒÅmagitƒÅ published in Madras, which represents itself to be contained in a larger work called SattvapƒÅrƒÅya·πáa and is composed of eighteen chapters like the genuine Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅ. It is narrated. to Han≈´mat by RƒÅma. In the beginning it professes itself to be based on the one hundred and eight Upan·π£iads, some of which are manifestly very rocent. This work, therefore, must be a very modern compilation. Thus the works designed to give importance to RƒÅma as a religious teacher are of recent origin.

XIV. VƒÅsudevism or Vai·π£·πáavism in the South,

¬ß 44. We have seen that Sa·πÅkar·π£a·πáa and VƒÅsudeva had come to be worshipped as gods in the Maratha country by about the first century B. C. The cult must have spread further south up to the Tamil country, but there is no evidence to show at what time it was introduced there. The BhƒÅgavata-PurƒÅ·πáa (Book XI, chap. 5, vv. 38-40) says, in the usual prophetic. style, that in the Kali age there will be found men here. and there devoted to NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, but in large numbers. in the Dravi·∏ça country, where flow the rivors Tamrapar·πáƒ´, KƒÅverƒ´and others, and that those who drink the water of these rivers will mostly be pure-hearted devotees of VƒÅsudeva. When the PurƒÅ·πáa goes out of its beaten track to make such a statement as this, the fame of the devotees of VƒÅsudeva, who had flourished in the Tamil country, must have spread over either parts of India. when the PurƒÅ·πáa was compiled. The PurƒÅ·πáa was regarded as sacred in the thirteenth century, when ƒÄnandatƒ´rtha, who flourished between about 1199 and 1278 A.D., places it on the same level as the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and devotes a treatise to the determination of its drift, as to that of the latter. About the same time Bopadeva prepared an abstract of it at the request of the councillor HemƒÅdri. The BhƒÅgavata, therefore, must have been composed at the least

two centuries before ƒÄnandatƒ´rtha to account for the reputation of the sacred character which it acquired in his time. It cannot be very much older, for its style often looks modern and in copying from the older PurƒÅ·πáas it falls into mistakes, such as the one pointed out by me in another place¬π. The Dravi·∏ça devotees, therefore, noticed in the BhƒÅgavata, must have mostly flourished before the eleventh century.

These devotees, who are known by the name of ƒÄlvƒÅrs, are generally reckoned as twelve in number and are divided into three classes by S. Krishnaswami Aiyengar37 in accordance with the received chronology which he follows to determine. their sequence, though in itself it assigns a preposterously high antiquity to them. Their names, Tamil and Sanskrit, are as follows:‚Äî
Class Tamil name Sanskrit name
Ancient Poygai ƒÄlvƒÅr Saroyogin
Bh≈´tnttƒÅr Bh≈´tayogin
Pƒìy ƒÄlvƒÅr Mabadyogin or BhrƒÅntayogin
Tirumali≈õai ƒÄlvƒÅr BhaktisƒÅra
Later Namm ƒÄlvƒÅr ≈öa·π≠hakopa
Periy ƒÄlvƒÅr Madhurakavi
A·πá·∏çƒÅl Kula≈õekhara
Vi·π£·πáoitta
GodƒÅ
Last To·πá·∏çara·∏çippo·∏çi BhaktƒÅ·πÖghrire·πáu
TiruppƒÅ·πáƒÄlvƒÅrr YogivƒÅhana
Tirumangai ƒÄlvƒÅr ParakƒÅla

The date of the first, ordinarily given, is B. C. 4203 and of the last, B. C. 2706, and the others range between these two. Not only are these dates fanciful, but even the sequence shown above is unreliable. Krishnaswami places the last in the earlier half of the eighth century A. D., and all the preceding ones impliedly before that date. But there is distinct evidence to show that Kula≈õekhara flourished much later. He was a king of Travancore, and one ofthe works composed by him styled MukundamƒÅla contains a verse from the BhƒÅgavata-PurƒÅ·πáa (XI. 2. 36)38.

___________________________________________________________________________

1.Early History of the Deccan (Second Edition), pp. 32-33. [=Vol. III, p. 46 of this Edition-N. B. U.]

Again in an Inscription on a tablet, existing in a temple at Narƒìgal in the Dharwar district, translated by Dr. Fleet39, it is stated that PermƒÅ·∏çi of the Sinda dynasty vanquished Kula≈õekharƒÅ·πÖka, besieged Cha·π≠·π≠a, pursued Jayak≈õin, and seized upon the royal power of Poysala and invested Dhorasamudra, the capital of the Poysala dynasty. In another Inscription40this PermƒÅ·∏çi is represented to be a vassal of Jagadekamalla II, whose dates range between A. D. 1138 and 1150. While the former was in power as MahƒÅma·πá·∏çale≈õvara in the seventh year of Jagadekamalla, i. e., in A. D. 1144, a certain grant was made by a body of sellers of betel. leaves and nuts. The Kula≈õekharƒÅ·πÖka, mentioned as being. vanquished by this PermƒÅ·∏çi, must be a prince reigning on the western coast, as the others, Jayake≈õin, the Kadamba prince of Goa, the Hoysala king, and so forth, were. Putting this statement and the quotation from the BhƒÅgavata-PurƒÅ·πáa together, it appears. highly probable that the ƒÄlvƒÅr Kula≈õekhara lived in the first half of the twelfth century. The sequence, therefore, given above cannot be implicitly believed in.

Still it may be admitted that the earliest ƒÄlvƒÅrs flourished about the time of the revival of BrƒÅhama·πáism and Hinduism in the North, which extended up to the Maratha country, as wel have shown from Inscriptions and antiquarian remains, and must have extended still farther to the South. The earliest ƒÄlvƒÅrs may be placed before about the fifth or sixth century, but there is nothing to show that Vai·π£·πáavism had not penetrated to the Tamil country earlier, i. e., about the first century. But an impetus, such as the rise of the ƒÄlvƒÅrs indicates, could in all probability come. only from the energy of the revival. The hostile relations into which the ƒÄlvƒÅrs and the ≈öaiva saints, NƒÅyanmƒÅrs, came with the Buddhists and Jainas, lend support to the view we have. advocated.

TheƒÄlvƒÅrs composed mostly in Tamil, what are called Prabandhas or songs in praise of the deity full of piety and devotion and

containing also religious truth. They are considered as very sacred and spoken of as the Vai·π£·πáava Veda. The reverence paid to the ƒÄlvƒÅrs is very great, and their images are placed by the side of the god representing Vi·π£·πáuor NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa in some form and worshipped.It may be noted here that Kula≈õekhara-ƒÄlvƒÅr’s favourite deity was RƒÅma, the son of Da≈õaratha.

XV. RƒÅmƒÅnuja.

¬ß 45. There were two classes of teachers among the Vai·π£·πáavaof the South, viz, the ƒÄlvƒÅrs and the ƒÄcƒÅryas. The former devoted themselves to the culture of the feeling of love and devotion for Vi·π£·πáu or NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, and composed songs, while the object of the latter was to carry on disputations and controversies and seek to establish their own theories and creeds. The first class we have already noticed briefly. The first of the second class appears to have been NƒÅthamuni. His successor was YƒÅmunƒÅcƒÅrya or YƒÅmunamuni. RƒÅmƒÅnuja succeeded YƒÅmunamuni, one of whose last directions to his successor was to compose a commentary on BƒÅdƒÅrayana’s Brahmas≈´tra. The necessity for such a work was felt by the leaders of the Vai·π£·πáava falth, since they found it not. possible to maintain the doctrine of Bhakti or love in the face of the theory of Advaita or Monism of Spirit set up by ≈öa·πÅkarƒÅcƒÅrya as based upon the Brahmas≈´tras and the Upani·π£ads.

During the period of the revival of BrƒÅhmanism and Hinduism. there was such a fermentation of thought as that which existed when Buddhism, Jainism and other heterodox systems on the one. hand, and VƒÅsudevism on the other, arose. The present fermentation, however, did not rest on independent thought, but was based upon the sacred works that had been handed down from the earlier times. The Pali Buddhism made way for the Sanskrit MahƒÅyƒÅnism, and against this last, controversies were carried on by the School of NyƒÅya founded by Gautama and by the MimƒÅ·πÅsakas, especially by ≈öabarsvƒÅmin and KumƒÅrilabha·π≠·π≠a. But the MimƒÅ·πÅsakas attacked not only the Buddhists, but the Aupani·π£adas, or a school of thought based upon the Upani·π£ads.They maintained the efficacy of the sacrificial religion alone and denied it to the faith and practices of the latter school. The efforts of this. school were therefore directed towards the maintenance of their position that their system alone can lead to supreme bliss.

The person who appeared prominently on the scene on this occasion was Gau·∏çapƒÅdƒÅcƒÅrya and some time after him the pupil of his pupil, ≈öa·πÅkarƒÅcƒÅrya. The theory that this latter set up, was that there exists one spirit alone, and the feelings of individuality and other attributes of the animal spirit and the variety of the inanimate world, owe their origin to a principle of illusion, and are consequently unreal. This doctrine left no room for the exercise of love and piety in the world of reality, though its followers allow it in the ordinary illusive condition of the human souls, and therefore it laid the axe at the root of Vai·π£·πáavism. The great wish of the Southern leaders of the latter faith was the overthrow of this doctrine of illusion, or M√£y√£, on the same Aupani·π£ada grounds on which it was set up. And this wish of his predecessor was carried out by RƒÅmƒÅnuja, and henceforward every Vai·π£·πáava system, and even., in one or two cases, ≈öaiva systems had to tack on Aupani·π£ada or VedƒÅntic theories to their own doctrines.

¬ß 46. RƒÅmƒÅnuja was born in ≈öaka 938 corresponding to 1016. or 1017 A. D. In his youth he lived at KƒÅ√±cƒ´pura or Conjeevaram and was a pupil of YƒÅdavaprakƒÅ≈õa, who was an Advaita philosopher and therefore professed spiritual monism. RƒÅmƒÅnuja whose inclinations were towards Vai·π£·πáavism, was dissatisfied with the teachings of his master, and the ultimate result was his seperation from him. He applied himself to the study of the Prabandhas of the ƒÄlvƒÅrs and drank in their spirit. When he became a successor of YƒÅmunƒÅcƒÅrya, he lived at ≈örƒ´ra·πÖgam, near Trichinopoly, and did his life’s work there. He is said to have gone on a pilgrimage to the noted holy places of Upper India. In the latter. years of his age he was subjected to persecution by the Cols Fprince of his time, who wanted him to renounce Vai·π£·πáavism for ≈öaivism, in consequence of which he took refuge in 1096 A. D. in the dominions of the Hoysala YƒÅdava princes, who reigned in Mysore and whose capital was Dvarasamudra, the modern Halebid. There he converted Vitthala Deva, popularly called Bi·π≠·π≠i Deva, Bi·π≠·π≠i being, in all likelihood, the corruption of Vi·π≠·π≠hala or Vi·π≠·π≠hi. This took place in 1098 A. D. Vi·π≠·π≠hala Deva was not the reigning prince, but administered some of the frontier provinces in the name of his brother BallƒÅla, who was on the

throne¬π. Vi·π≠·π≠hala Deva or Bi·π≠·π≠i Deva was called Vi·π£·πáuvardhana after his conversion to Vai·π£·πáavism. This is the ordinary account. But what appeurs true is that his name was originally Vi·π£·πáu, which was corrupted into Bi·π≠·π≠u or Bi·π≠·π≠i in the Kanarese, the vernacular of the district, so that his original name Bi·π≠·π≠i Deva is the same as Vi·π£·πáu Deva which he is represented to have assumed after his conversion. He reigned from 1104 to 1141 A. D41. RƒÅmƒÅnuja composed the following works: VedƒÅntasƒÅra,‚ÄîVedƒÅrthasa·πÅgraha, VedƒÅntadƒ´pa, and commentaries, or BhƒÅ·π£yas, on the Brah·πÅas≈´tras and the Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅ¬≥.

¬ß 47.The VedƒÅntic theory, or the theory based upon the Brahmas≈´tras and the Upani·π£ads, which RƒÅmƒÅnuja set up to provide scope for the feeling of Bhakti, or love for God and the spirit of worship, was that there are three eternal principles, the individual or animal soul (Cit), the insensate world (Acit), and the Supreme Soul (ƒ™≈õvara).

There are Upan·π£iad texts to support this, and one of them is that in the SU. (I. 12) to the effect that all Brahman, regarded as composed of the enjoyer or sufferer, the objects. from which enjoyment or suffering springs, and the controller or mover, is threefold. But the Brahmas≈´tras lay it down. on the authority of the Upan·π£iad that Brahman is the material. as well as the efficient cause of the world. To make this possible. in his system, RƒÅmƒÅnuja resorts to the passage in BU. of the MƒÅdhya·πÅdina school, beginning from III. 7. 3, in which the Supreme Soul is stated to be the internal controller (AntaryƒÅmin) of the individual soul as well as of the external world. The form that he gives to his theory is that the individual soul and the insensate world are the attributes of the Supreme Soul. They constitute his body, as stated in the Upan·π£iad also, and thus, they with the controlling inward Supreme Soul constitute one entity called Brahman, just as the body and the in-dwelling soul constitute the human being.

___________________________________________________________________________

1.See Krishnaswamƒ´Aiyangar’s paper in No. 8 of the magazine Vi≈õi·π£·π≠ƒÅdvaitin for most of these facts.

3.See Krishnaswamƒ´’s paper alluded to al above.

Before creation the body of the Supreme Soul exists in a subtle form, and when creation takes place, it develops in the form of the existing universe; thus Brahman is the material cause of the external world. It is also the efficient cause, when, as the internal controlling soul, it wills to creat. The subtle form of the insensate world is the Prak·πõti, a term first invented by the original author of the SƒÅ·πÅkhya doctrine. It develops under the guidance of the in-dwelling Supreme Spirit until the mundane egg is produced. The successive stages of Mahat, Aha·πÅkƒÅra, etc., are like those of the SƒÅ·πÅkhya system, which has been adopted by the PurƒÅ·πáas also in the account of the creation. And the creation after the production of the mundane egg is also made by ƒ™≈õvara as the internal controller of Brahmadeva, Dak·π£a, etc.

ƒ™≈õvara or God is free from all faults or defects. He is eternal, pervades all living and non-living things, is the internal controller. of all, is pure joy or blessedness, is possessed of the auspicious qualities of knowledge, power, etc., is the creator, protector and destroyer of the world, and is resorted to by those who are afflicted, who wish to gain knowledge, who seek to attain a certain end, and who are already enlightened¬π. He confers the fourfold fruit of existence¬≤. He is possessed of a wonderful celestial body of unsurpassable beauty and has for his consorts Lak·π£mi¬≥, Bh≈´ (the earth), and Lƒ´lƒÅ(sport).

This ƒ™≈õvara appears in five different modes :‚Äî

I. Para or the highest, in which mode, NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, called also Para-Brahman and Para-VƒÅsudeva, lives in a city called Vaiku·πá·π≠ha, which is guarded by certain persons and which has door-keepers; seated in a pavilion of gems on a couch in the form of the serpent ≈öe·π£a, placed on a throne having the eight legs, Dharma and others; attended by ≈örƒ´, Bh≈´ and Lƒ´lƒÅ; holding the celestial weapons, conch-shell, discus, and others; adorned. with celestial ornaments, such as a tiara and others: possessed of numberless auspicious attributes, knowledge, power, and others;and his presence being enjoyed by the eternal spirits, such as Ananta, Garu·∏ça, Vi·π£vaksena, and others, and by delivered souls.

___________________________________________________________________________

1.These are the four, ƒÄrta, JijnÃÑƒÅsu, atc., mentioned in BhG. (7. 16).

2.Artha, or worldly prosperity, KƒÅma, or the objects of desire, Dharma, or religious merit, and Mok·π£a, or final deliverance, are the four objects of existence.

3.From the Tattvatrayaof LokƒÅcƒÅrya.

II. Vy≈´ha, in which the Para himself has assumed four forma, VƒÅsudeva, Sa·πÅkar·π£a·πáa, Pradyumna and Aniruddha for convenience of worship, and for purposes such as creation, etc. Of these. VƒÅsudeva is possessed of the six qualities; Sa·πÅkar·π£a·πáa has two, viz., omniscience and sustaining power! Pradyumna two, viz. controlling power and unchangeableness, and Aniruddha, creative power and all-overcoming prowess¬π.

III. Vibhava, which mode consists of the ten AvatƒÅras, fish, tortoise, etc.

IV. AntaryƒÅmin, in which mode he dwells in the heart and is to be seen by Yogins and accompanies the individual souls even when they go to heaven or hell.

V. Idols or images set up in houses, villages, towns, etc., made up of a material chosen by the worshipper, in which he dwells. with a body not made up of matter42.

Other authorities leave out VƒÅsudeva from the Vy≈´has and have the other three only. The Arthapa√±caka has another form. of the AntaryƒÅmin, in which form he dwells in everything and rules over all, is bodiless, all-pervading and store of all good attributes, and is called Vi·π£·πáu, NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, VƒÅsudeva¬≥, etc.

Self-consciousness, knowledge, union as a soul with a body, agency, are attributes common to the supreme and individual souls43. The latter is self-illumined, joyous, eternal, atomic, imperceptible to the senses, unthinkable, devoid of parts, unchangeable, the substratum of knowledge, subject to God’s control, depending on God’s existence for his own existence and an attribute of God44. This description of the individual soul differs agreat deal from that of S≈öa·πÅkarƒÅcƒÅrya, who attributes no agency or substantiality to it; and the dependence on God in a variety of ways cannot, of course, be thought of under the doctrine of spiritual monism. The soul’s being an atom is also denied by ≈öamkara’s school and various others. The souls are many and are divided into:‚Äî

___________________________________________________________________________

1.These are translations of the words J√±ƒÅna, Bala, Ai≈õvarya, Virya, ≈öakti, and Tƒìjas, according to the definitions in the Yatƒ´ndramatadƒ´pikƒÅ.

3.See my Report on the Search for Sanskrit Manuscripts during 1883-84, p. 69, [Volume II of this Edition, p. 184-N. B. U.]

(1) Baddha or tied down to the circle of existences from Brahmadeva to the vilest worm, as well as the vegetable souls;

(2) Mukta or finally delivered; and

(3) Nitya or eternal.

Of the first class, those that are rational, that is, not brutes or vegetables, are of two sorts: (1) desirous of enjoyment; (2) desirous of final deliverance. Of those that are desirous of enjoyment, some devote themselves to the acquisition of wealth and the satisfaction of carnal desires, and others, who seek to attain the happiness of heaven, perform all rites and sacrifices, make pilgrimages to holy places and give in charity. Some of these devote themselves to Bhagavat and others to other deities.

Some of those who desire final deliverance seek the consciousness of their pure soul only (Kevalin), and others eternal bliss. Of these latter, some are Bhaktas, who seek to attain God by resorting to Bhakti with all its details, having first of all studied the Vedas and acquainted themselves with the VedƒÅnta and the philosophy of rites (Karman). The three upper orders alone can practise Bhakti, but not the S≈´dras. Others are Prapannas, who are those who take refuge in God, feeling themselves poor and helpless. Of Prapannas, some seek the first three objects of life, while the rest, finding no happiness in these, renouncing everything worldly, desire eternal bliss ( Mok·π£a) alone, and, seeking the advice of a preceptor and acquiring from him the impulse to action, fling themselves on the will of God, not having the power of going through the Bhakti process and being helpless. This Prapatti or surrender to God can be practised by all orders, including ≈ö≈´dras45.

What are necessary for the efficacy of the method of Bhakti,

are Karmayoga or the performance of actions, and J√±ƒÅnayoga or the acquisition of knowledge Karmayoga is the performance of all acts, rites and ceremonies without regard for the fruit resulting from them. These are the worship of the deity, practice of austerity, pilgrimage to holy places, giving in charity and sacrifices.

This Karmayoga purifies the soul and leads to J√±ƒÅnayoga, or acquisition of knowledge. This knowledge consists in seeing oneself as distinct from Prak·πõti, or matter, and as an attribute of God himself (≈öe·π£a). This J√±ƒÅnayoga leads to Bhakti.

Bhaktiyoga, or the method of Bhakti, consists in continuous meditation accompanied by the practice of the eight Yoga processes, Yama, Niyama, etc. This is to be attained. by (1) the purification of the body by the use of unpolluted and unprohibited food, (2) chastity, (3) constant practice, (4) the performance of five great rites and ceremonies according to one’s means, (5) virtues such as truth, uprightness, compassion, obarity, non-destruction of life, (6) hopefulness or absence of despondency, and (7) absence of elatedness. Bhakti, as promoted by these seven means, assumes the form of actually seeing (God) and produces the final mental perception.

Prapatti consists in the resolution to yield, the avoidance of opposition¬π, a faith that God will protect, acceptance of him as saviour or praying him to save and sense of helplessness resulting in throwing one’s whole soul on him¬≤. Prapatti thus comes to selfsurrender46.

The Arthspa√±caka mentions a fifth way called AcƒÅryƒÅbhimanƒÅyoga, which is for one who is unable to follow any of the others, and consists in surrendering oneself to an ƒÄcƒÅrya or preceptor and being guided by him in everything. The preceptor goesthrough all that is necessary to effect his pupil’s deliverance as a mother takes medicine herself to cure an infant.

___________________________________________________________________________

1.The two expressions thus translated have also been otherwise oxplained as bearing good-will to all and the absence of ill-will.

2.There is another ronding hare which should be translated as"throwing one-self upon him and a feeling of helplessness.” Thus there are six constituents of Prapatti. These are;(1)ƒÄnuk≈´lyasya sa·πÅkalpa·∏• (2) prƒÅtik≈´lyasya varjanam, (3) rak·π£i·π£yantƒ´ti vi≈õvƒÅso (4) g≈çpt·πõvavara·πáa·πÅ tathƒÅ, (5)ƒÅtmanik·π£epa - (6) karpa·πáne·π£a·∏çvidhƒÅ≈õara·πáƒÅgati·∏•.

Sixteen modes of worship are to be practised by the devotees of Vi·π£·πáu, as stated in a passage quoted from the Padma-PurƒÅ·πáa by a recent writer of the RƒÅmƒÅnuja school. Eight of these are the same. as those included in the nine modes of Bhakti enumerated in al previous Section47as mentioned in the BhƒÅgavata-PurƒÅ·πáa, Sakhya, or friendship or companionship, boing omitted. The other eight are : (1) imprinting the marks of the conch-shell and the discus. and other weapons of Hari on the body; (2) the making of a vertical mark on the forehead; (3) repeating of Mantras on the occasion; (4) drinking the water used in washing the feet of Hari; (5) the eating of the offerings of cooked food made to him; (6) doing service to his devotees: (7) the observance of fast on the 11th of the bright and dark halves of each lunar month; (8) laying Tulasi leaves on the idol of Hari.

A text from the HƒÅrƒ´tasm·πõti is also quoted giving nine modes of worship (Bhakti), three of which are common to it with the BhƒÅgavata-PurƒÅ·πáa. The other six are the same as the eight in the above, the first two being combined and the third being omitted. The vertical mark on the forehead mentioned above consists of two lines made with white earth and a connecting cross line at the bottom, with, in the middle, a yellow line made with turmeric powder or a red line composed of the same material reddened by mixing it with lime.

¬ß 48. In Northern India there are not many followers of RƒÅmƒÅnuja; in Southern India there is a very large number. There are two Schools among them, known by the names of Va·∏çakalai or northern learning, and Tenkalai or southern learning. The essential difference between them is brought out by the different illustrations¬≤ that they give of the connection between God’s grace and man’s effort in bringing about final deliverance. The illustration. used by the former, or the northern, is that of a female monkey and her cub. The cub has to hold fast its mother on the abdomen tobe conveyed to a safe place. The southerners use the illustration of the cat and its kittens. The female cat catches hold of the kitten, without any effort on its part, and takes it to a place of safety. In the first case the doctrine is that the process of deliverance must begin with an act of a person seeking it. In the other case the process begins with God himself.

___________________________________________________________________________

2.The following remarks are based on Vi≈õi·π£·π≠ƒÅdvaitin, Vol. I, No. 8, pp. 200ff., and Mr. Govindacharya’s article, JRAS, 1910, pp. 1103 ff.

In keeping with this distinction is the idea of Prapatti or self-surrender held by the two Sects. The first maintains that Prapatti is one of the ways resorted to by the devotee and begins with him. The southern School holds that it is not one of the ways, but it is. a frame of mind which characterises all those who seek absolution, and reject all other ways in favour of this. Those who resort to other ways have not arrived at the right mood which leads to God. When a soul is in this frame of mind, God himself takes. entire possession of him, while by the other ways, man, as it were, makes approaches towards him. The Va·∏çakalai lays down that Prapatti is for those who cannot follow other ways, such as Karmayoga, J√±ƒÅnayoga and Bhaktiyoga, while the Tenkalai holds that it is necessary for all, whether able or not, to follow the other ways. The first School says that one should give himself up to God when one finds other ways, which have been resorted to, to be fruitless. The second holds that self-abandonment to God. should precede the trial of other ways Self-assertiveness is the characteristic of the first, but it is forbidden by the second and self- abandonment is enjoined. The northerners say that the six ways of Prapatti or self-surrender given above are preliminaries to the Prapatti which results from them. The southerners say that Prapatti must take place first and then the six follow as results.

The nothern School teaches that a person belonging to an inferior caste should be treated well only so far as conversation by words is concerned. The southerners say that they should be. admitted to an equal treatment in all respects and no distinction be made. The syllable Om should be omitted from the eight- syllabled Mantra, according to the Va·∏çakalai, when taught to others than BrƒÅhma·πáas; the Tenkalai does not make this distinction and provides for the teaching of the whole Mantra in the same form to all48.

¬ß 49. It will be seen from the short summery here given that RƒÅmƒÅnuja derives his metaphysical doctrines from texts in the Upani·π£ads and from the Brahmas≈´tras, while his theory of the external world is that adopted by the PurƒÅ·πáas and based on the twenty-four elements of the SƒÅ·πÅkhya system. His Vai·π£·πáavism is the VƒÅsudevism of the old PƒÅ√±carƒÅtra system combined with the NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa and Vi·π£·πáu elements. The last name does not occur. often in the literature of his school. The most prominent name is NNƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, though VƒÅsudeva takes his proper place when the Supreme Soul and the Vy≈´has are spoken of. The name of GopƒÅlak·πõ·π£·πáa is conspicuous by its absence, and RamƒÅnuja’s system is free from that repulsive form which Vai·π£·πáavism assumes when RƒÅdhƒÅand other cowherdesses are introduced. RƒÅma too does not appear to be a favourite deity. RƒÅmƒÅnuja’s doctrines as to the way of reaching the Supreme Soul are the same as, or amplified forms of, those in the Bhagavadgƒ´tƒÅ. But in this system Bhakti is reduced to the form of a continuous meditation on the Supreme Soul. It thus corresponds to the UpƒÅsan√£s, or meditations, described by BƒÅdarƒÅya·πáa, and does not mean a boundless love for God, as the word is commonly understood, though the meditation that is enjoined implies tacitly a feeling of love.

The tendency of RƒÅmƒÅnuja’s system seems to be to give an exclusive BrƒÅhma·πáic form to the traditional method of Bhakti, or devotion to God, and this is distinctly seen in the doctrines of the Va·∏çakalai; while Tenkalai, or southern learning, is more liberal and so shapes the doctrines of the system as to make them applicable to ≈ö≈´dras also. But we shall find the ≈ö≈´dras asserting themselves when we come to the disciples of RƒÅmƒÅnanda and to the MarƒÅ·π≠ha saints and teachers, NƒÅmdeva and TukƒÅrƒÅma.

The fifth UpƒÅya, or way to God, given in the Arthapa√±caka, of surrendering oneself completely to a teacher or preceptor, doing nothing oneself and the preceptor doing all that is necessary for one’s redemption, seems suspicious. It has a striking resemblance to the Christian doctrine of Christ suffering, or in the words of our author, going through the processes necessary for redemption, the believer doing nothing but putting complete faith in his saviour. If the prevalence of Christianity in and before the time of RƒÅmƒÅnuja in the country about Madras is a proved fact, this

doctrine as well as some of the finer points in the theory of Prapatti may be traced to the influence of Christianity. RƒÅmƒÅnuja’s system is known by the name of ≈örƒ´sa·πÅpradƒÅya or the tradition springing from ≈örƒ´.

XVI Madhva or ƒÄnandatƒ´rtha

¬ß 50. The great object of the Vai·π£·πáava teachers of the eleventh century and upwards was to confute the theory of MƒÅyƒÅ, or the unreality of the world, and establish the doctrine of Bhakti, or love and faith, on a secure basis RƒÅmƒÅnuja effected this by the system which he promulgated and which we have already noticed. But in order to reconcile his doctrine with the theory set forth in the Brahmas≈´tras on the basis of the Upan·π£iad, that God is the material as well as the efficient cause of the world, he propounded the doctrine of God’s being a composite person, having for his body the individual souls and the inanimate world. Even this Madhva considered objectionable as having a tendency to depreciate the independent majesty of God, and therefore he denies his being the material cause of the world. All the S≈´tras of BƒÅdarƒÅya·πáa which set forth that doctrine have been interpreted by him. in an entirely different way. Probably he would have set aside the Brahms≈´tras altogether, but he could not do so, since the work had acquired an uncontested authoritativeness as regards. religious truth before his time. He had therefore to show that his system did not go against the Brahms≈´tras, and therefore accepted them and interpreted them in almost a fantastic manner. Texts from the Upani≈üads, too, which do not agree with his doctrines, he treats similarly.

In opposition to the pure monism of ≈öa·πÅkara and the qualified. monism of RƒÅmƒÅnuja, ƒÄnandatƒ´rthasets forth five eternal distinotions or individualities, viz., the distinction between

(1) God and the individual spirit,

(2) God and the inanimate world,

(3) the individual spirit and the inanimate world,

(4) one individual spirit and another,

(5) one inanimate object and another.

According to the Madhvavijaya, or the history of the triumphs of Madhva, by NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, the son of Trivikrama, there was in the

town of Rajatapƒ´·π≠ha a family known by the name of Madhyageha.MƒÅdhva’s father was called Madhyagehabha·π≠·π≠a¬π; the name given. to Madhva after his birth was VƒÅsudeva. After VƒÅsudeva had received the usual education of a BrƒÅhma·πáa, he was initiated as an anchorite by Acyutaprek·π£ƒÅcarya who thus became his Guru. After his initiation he went to BadarikƒÅ≈õrama in the HimƒÅlaya and brought back the idols of Digvijaya RƒÅmaand VedavyƒÅsa. He was raised to the seat of high priest in the presenceof kings.

ƒÄnandatƒ´r·π≠ha went from country to country, putting down the advocates of the doctrine of MƒÅyƒÅand others, established the Vai·π£·πáava creed. He had for his pupils PadmanƒÅbhatƒ´r·π≠ha, Naraharitƒ´r·π≠ha, MƒÅdhavatƒ´r·π≠ha, and Ak·π£obhyattƒ´r·π≠ha. Naraharitƒ´r·π≠ha was sent to JagannƒÅtha in Orissa to bring the original idols of RƒÅma and Sƒ´tƒÅ. ƒÄnandatƒ´rtha’s other names. were P≈´r·πáapraj√±a and MadhyamandƒÅra, or wish-giving tree of the family of Madhya.

The date of his death given in the list preserved in several of the Ma·π≠has, or establishments of the sect, is ≈öaka 1119, and as he lived for seventy-nine years, the death of his birth has been given as ≈öaka 1040. But these statements are open to serious doubts. There is an Inscription in the K≈´rme≈õvara temple at ≈örƒ´k≈´rmam in the Chicacole Taluka of the Ganjam District, in which Naraharitƒ´r·π≠ha is represented to have constructed a temple and placed in it an idol of YogƒÅnandanarasi·πÅha in the year ≈öaka 120349.The first person therein mentioned is Puru·π£ottamatƒ´r·π≠ha, who is the same as Acyutaprek·π£a50, then his pupil ƒÄnandatƒ´r·π≠ha, and the last is Narabaritƒ´r·π≠ha, the pupil of ƒÄnandatƒ´rtha. This Narabaritƒ´r·π≠ha is considered by some, to have been the ruler of Orissa. But this arises from a confusion between him and a king bearing the same name, in the slightly modified form of Narasi·πÅha, who was the actual ruler of the country from about ≈öaka 1191 to

___________________________________________________________________________

1.Kallianpur in the Udipi Taluka of the district of South Kanara is stated to be the birth-place of Madhva. It was probably the same as the Rajatapƒ´·π≠haof the Madhvavijnya. (Imp. Gas, Vol. XIV, page 314.)

1225. He is mentioned in an Inscription at ≈örƒ´k≈´rmam of Naraharitƒ´rtha himself, hearing the date ≈öaka 1215, which is represented as the eighteenth year of the king’s reign51. He was Narasi·πÅha II, and was the prince panegyrised in a work on rhetoric, the EkƒÅvali¬≤. Naraharitƒ´rtha’s other dates gathered from other Inscriptions range between ≈öaka 1186 and 121252. All these epigraphical records confirm the truth of the tradition that Naraharitƒ´rtha was sent by ƒÄnandatƒ´rtha to Orissa. He appears to have. hold a very high position there.

Now if Naraharitƒ´rtha’s active period extended from ≈öaka 1186 to 1215, his master could not have died in ≈öaka 1119, i. e., fully 67 years before. It seems, therefore, reasonable to take the date. given in Madhva’s MahƒÅbhƒÅratatƒÅtparyanir·πáaya, which is 4300 of the Kali age, to be the correct date of his birth. It corresponds to ≈öaka 1121, which, bearing in mind the fact that some use the current year of an era and some the past, we must regard as equivalent to ≈öaka 1119, the date given in the lists for ƒÄnandatƒ´rtha’s death. But instead of taking it as the date of his death, we shall have to regard it as the date of his birth. He lived for 79 years according to the current account, so that his death must be placed in ≈öaka 1198‚Å¥. The two dates may, therefore, be taken as settled.

ƒÄnandatƒ´rtha thus lived in the first three quarters of the thirteenth century. He was succeeded, according to the list, by Padmanabhatƒ´rtha who held the pontificate for seven years, i, e., up. to ≈öaka 1205. He was succeeded by Naraharitƒ´rtha who occupied. the pontifical seat for nine years, i, e., up to ≈öaka 1214, or, if we regard 1121 as the date of the first pontiff’s birth according to the strict interpretation of the Kali date, up to ≈öaka 1216; and, as wel have seen, his latest date in the Inscriptions is ≈öaka 1215.

¬ß 51. The MƒÅdhvas follow the method of Vai≈õe·π£ikas and divide all existing things into the categories of substance, qualities, etc.,

___________________________________________________________________________

2.See my note in Trivedi’s edition of the work, BSS. [= Volume II of this Edition, pp. 139. N. B. U.]

4.This agrees with the tradition existing in the Ma·π≠ha at PhalmƒÅru, near Mulki in South Canara, to the effect that ƒÄnandatƒ´rtha was born in ≈öaka 1119 and died in ≈öaka 1199, Ep. Ind., VI, p. 263, note.

with some modifications of their own¬π. God is a substance. The supreme soul possesses innumerable or an infinite number of qualities. His functions are eight, viz., (1) creation, (2) protection, (3) dissolution, (4) controlling all things, (5) giving knowledge, (6) manifestation of himself, (7) tying beings down to the world, (8) redemption. He is omniscient, expressible by all words, and entirely different from the individual souls and the inanimate world. He possesses the holy form made up of knowledge, joy, etc., independent of every thing, and one only, assuming different forms. All his forms are his full manifestations, and he is identically the same with his incarnations in qualities, parts, and actions. Lak·π£mƒ´is distinct from the Supreme Soul, but entirely dependent on him. She is eternal and blessed (Makta) like the Supreme Soul and is his consort. She has various forms, but no material body, and is thus like the Supreme Soul, and like him ist expressible by all words. She possesses the same extension in space. and time as the Supreme Soul, i. e., is concomitant with him.

Jƒ´vas or individual souls go through the usual succession of existences and are characterised by ignorance or other defects. They are innumerable individually, or as members of groups, such as ·πòjus53 who are fit for attaining Brahmahood, and others who are fit for the attainment of the dignity of Rudra, Garu·∏ça, Asuras, or demons, etc. They are of three kinds: (1) fit for attaining final bliss, (2) always going through the circle of existences, and (3) fit for the conditon of darkness. The gods, ·πö·π£is, and the manes, and the best of men, belong to the first class, ordinary men belong to the second class, and demons, ghosts, and the vilest of men, etc., to the the third class. All these individual souls are distinct from each other and from the Supreme Soul.

Creation begins when the Supreme Soul disturbs the equilibrium of the Prak·πõti, which then develops into all the other principles of the Samkhya system, as modified by the PurƒÅ·πáas, until the mundane egg is produced. Then placing the sentient and non-

___________________________________________________________________________

1.This account of the system is abridged from a work called MadhvasiddhƒÅntasƒÅraby PadmanƒÅbhas≈´ri, printed in Bombay by Javaji Dadaj irnayasagara Press, published at Kumbhakonam in ≈öaka 1815, corresponding to 1883 A. D. The tedious details are omitted.

sentient objects into his inside, he enters into the mundane egg. Then, at the end of a thousand celestial years he produces from his navel a lotus, which is the seat of the four-faced Brahmadeva; and from this last after a long time the ordinary creation takes place.

All knowledge springs from ParamƒÅtman, whatever the means by which it is produced. It is of two kinds-that which leads to worldly existence, and that which leads to Mok·π£a. Vi·π£·πáu bestows knowledge on the ignorant, and Mok·π£a on those who have knowledge. The knowledge, or feeling which creates an attachment to the body, child or wife, leads to a worldly life. This is not true. knowledge, but ignorance from which results that worldly life, and that ignornce is dispelled by the knowledge of God.

Mok·π£a is attained by the direct knowledge or perception of Hari by means of a method of service possible to oneself and in a body fitted for it. That direct perception is possible to all good individual souls from Brahmadeva to the best of men. This direct perception is to be attained by many means.

What are necessary for direct knowledge, which leads to Mok·π£a, are (1) VairƒÅgya, or the disgust of enjoyments of this world. or the next, generated by seeing the vanity of the world by the company of good persons; (2) equanimity (≈öama) and self-control (Dama), etc.; (3) acquaintance with the lore; (4) self-surrender (≈öara·πáƒÅgati), in which the mind is devoted to God, as the best of all beings, and is full of the highest love and in which everything is resigned to God and he is worshipped with devotedness in the three ways, and which is accompanied with the faith that He will unfailingly protect and the feeling that the devotee is His: (5) attendance on a Guru, or preceptor, and propitiation of him, which is necessary for Mok·π£a or redemption (6) acquisition of knowledge from the Guru and not from books, or, in the absence of a Guru, from a good Vai·π£·πáava, and, in rare cases, from books also; (7) reflection over what has been taught; (8) devotion, in the order of their merits, to a preceptor and persons. better than oneself and deserving respect; (9) love of God (ParamƒÅtmabhakti) consequent on the knowledge of God’s greatness and his being the best of all. This love should be firm and higher

than that for all others, and this leads to Mok·π£a or eternal bliss. (10) sympathy for those who are inferior, but good men, love for those who are equal, as if they were the same as themselves, and respectful love or reverence for superiors; (11) performing rites and ceremonies deliberately without any desire, which has the effect of purifying the soul; (12) the avoidance of prohibited deeds, i.e., sins. great and small; (13) resigning every act to Hari as done by him. and not by oneself; (14) the knowledge of the comparative position of beings and of Vi·π£·πáu as the highest of all; (15) knowledge. of the five distinctions already mentioned: (16) distinguishing Prak·πõti from Puru·π£a, all beings (from NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa down to men, with their consorts) being Puru·π£as, and the inanimate world being the Prak·πõti (17) reprobation of false doctrines; (18) UpƒÅsanƒÅor worship. This last is of two kinds, viz., (1) the learning of the ≈öastras, (2) meditation. Meditation (NididhyƒÅsa) is placing Bhagavat. before the mind’s eye to the exclusion of everything else. This meditation is possible for one who has a distinct knowledge of a thing acquired after the removal of ignorance, doubt and delusion. by means of reading or hearing something read and reflection. Some people meditate on Bhagavat as a single spirit and others on him. as having four phases as Sat (existence), Cit (knowledge), ƒÄnandaJoy) ƒÄtman (spirit). Then are given meditations resorted to by gods and some of those mentioned in the Brahmas≈´tras.

All these eighteen ways lead to the direct knowledge of God, which is possible for all from Brahmadeva to man. The direct knowledge of God attained by men is comparable with the coruscation of lightning, and that attained by gods to the bright disk of the sun. Garu·∏ça and Rudra have that knowledge in the shape of a reflection, while Brahmadeva has the knowledge of the whole with all its parts, and some have the knowledge of Him as dwelling in the universe and limited by the universe. The direct knowledge is simply mental.

¬ß 52. The followers of Madhva wear a mark on the forehead. composed of two white perpendicular lines made with an earth called Gopƒ´candana above the bridge of the nose, and a dark line. in the middle with a reddish spot in the centrel The two white lines are joined by a cross line on the bridge of the nose. They

wear on the shoulders and on the other parts of their body prints, made with the same white earth, of the conch-shell, the discus, and other weapons of Vi·π£·πáu. These are impressed occasionally with a heated metallic stamp on the skin, so as to leave a permanent scar. Members of this sect exist in pretty large numbers in the Kanarese Districts of the Bombay Presidency, Mysore, and on the Western Coast from Gon to South Kanara, and there are only scattered adherents in Northern India. There are eight establishments, or Ma·π≠has, for the dissemination and preservation of the creed in South Kanara and three in the inner country. Some of these were founded by ƒÄnandatƒ´rtha himself.

ƒÄnandatƒ´rtha composed thirty-seven¬π different treatises. He includes among the authorities enumerated by him in support of his system the PƒÅ√±carƒÅtra-Sa·πÅhitƒÅs; but it will be seen from the account given above that in his creed there is no place for the Vy≈´has, VƒÅsudeva and others, and the name by which the Supreme Spirit is spoken of is mostly Vi·π£·πáu. Some of His incarnations, especially RƒÅmaand Kr·π£·πáa, are also adored But the GopƒÅla-Kr·π£·πáa element seems to be entirely absent from his system, and RƒÅdhƒÅand the cowherdesses are not mentioned.

It thus appears that the PƒÅ√±carƒÅtra or BhƒÅgavata system hast been set aside by ƒÄnandatƒ´rtha or thrown into the background. The old traditional VƒÅsudevism of the BhƒÅgavata school gradually disappeared about his time and made room for general. Vai·π£·πáavism.

XVII. NimbƒÅrka.

¬ß 53. We have thus noticed the form which Vai·π£·πáavism assumed in the South from the middle of the eleventh century to the middle of the thirteenth. A strong feeling of Bhakti, or love, and a fear of the dangerous consequences of the doctrine of MƒÅyƒÅ, or illusion, were the guiding principles of the new development. The influence of this last extended itself to the North, and we can distinguish between two classes of founders of sects, viz.,

(1) those who wrote in Sanskrit,and (2) those who used the vernacular for the propagation of their creed.

___________________________________________________________________________

1.For the names of these, see the GranthamƒÅlikƒÅstotra in my Report on the Search for Sanskrit Manuscripts during 1882-83, p. 207. [= Volume II of this Edition, p. 24f. N. B. U. ]

The first of the former class we have to notice is NimbƒÅrka NimbƒÅrka is said to have been a Tailanga BrƒÅhma·πáa by birth and to have lived in a village called NimbƒÅ¬π, which perhaps is. the same as NimbƒÅpura in the Bellary District. He was born. on the 3rd of the bright half of Vai≈õƒÅkha, and his father’s name was JagannƒÅtha, who was a BhƒÅgavata, and his mother’s Sarasvati¬≤. He is believed by his followers to be an incarnation of the Sudar≈õana, or the discus of Vi·π£·πáu. As to when he flourished wel have no definite information, but he appears to have lived some time after RƒÅmƒÅnuja¬≥. NimbƒÅrka composed the VedƒÅntapƒÅrijƒÅta-

___________________________________________________________________________

1.Manuscript No. 706 of the Collection of 1884-7. NimbƒÅrka was the” Sun of Nimba.”

2.Introduction to the commentary on Da≈õa≈õlokƒ´by HarivyƒÅsadeva. It is to be regretted that the commentator does not give the year of NimbƒÅrka’s birth.

3.In my Report on the Search for Sanskrit Manuscripts for the year 1882-83, I have given two succession lists of spiritual teachers, one of the sect of ƒÄnandatirtha (p. 203) and another of that founded by NimbƒÅrka (pp. 208- 13). This contains 37 names. There is another list in Manuscript 709 of the Collection of 1884-7, which contains 45 names. The two lists agree to No. 32 HarivyƒÅsadeva. After that, while the first has only five names, the second has thirteen names, and none of these agrees with any of the five, so that after HarivyƒÅsadeva, the lino appears to have divided itself into two branches, No. 709 of the same Collection was written in Sa·πÅvat 1800 corresponding to 1750 A. D., when GosvƒÅmin DƒÅmodara was living. He was the thirty-third after NimbƒÅrka in the new branch line. The thirty- third after ƒÄnandatirtha died in 1876 A. D. ƒÄnandatirtha according to our revised date died in 1276 A. D., so that thirty-three successors occupied 603 years. Supposing that the thirty-three successors of NimbƒÅrka occupied about the same period, and allowing about fifteen years of life to DƒÅmodara GosvƒÅmin, who was living in 1750 A. D., and subtracting from 1765 A. D. 603 years, we have 1162 which is about the date of NimbƒÅrka’s death, so that he lived after RƒÅmƒÅnuja. This calculation of ours is of course very rough, and, besides, the date of the Manuscript No, 706, which is read as 1913 by some, but which looks like 1813, conflicts with this calculation, as nine more ƒÄcƒÅryas flourished after DƒÅmodara. And, if 1813 is the correct date, seven years cannot suffice for these, though 107 may, if the date is read 1913.

saurabha, which is a short commentary on the Brahmas≈´tras, and also a small work containing ten stanzas of the name of SiddhƒÅntƒÅratna, usually called Da≈õa≈õloki, from the number of stanzas contained in it. ≈örƒ´nivƒÅsa, the immediate follower of NimbƒÅrka, wrote a commentary called BhƒÅ·π£ya on the first, and HarivyƒÅsadeva, the thirty-second in the list of succession, wrote on the second. The thirteenth in the list, DevƒÅcƒÅrya, wrote the SiddhƒÅntajƒÅhnavƒ´, and his successor, Sundarabha·π≠·π≠a, wrote a commentary on it, called Setu. The thirtieth in the list composed a commentary, or BhƒÅ·π£ya, on the Brahmas≈´tras. His name was Kesava Ka≈õmƒ´rin.

¬ß 52. NimbƒÅrka’s VedƒÅntic theory is monistic as well as pluralistic. The inanimate world, the individual soul and God are distinct from one another as well as identical. Identical they are in the sense that the first two have no independent existence, but are dependent on God for their existence and action. The theory of the Brahmas≈´tras that Brahman is the material cause of the universe, is thus understood: To be the material cause of an effect is (1) to possess the capacity of assuming the form of that effect, and (2) to be fitted to do so. Brahman possesses various capacities which are of the nature of the animate and inanimate worlds. These in a subtle form constitute its natural condition. This satisfies the first of the two requirements. The capacities again contain in them the rudiment of the effect, i. e., the world, in a subtle form. This meets the second requirement. By realising these capacities. and bringing the subtle rudiment into a gross form, Brahman becomes the material cause of the world. RƒÅmƒÅnuja’s theory of Brahman forming with the animate and inanimate world a composite personality and of its being the material cause in so far as the bodily portion of the composite personality becomes developed, is rejected by the school54. For a further knowledge of the system, I will here give a translation of the Da≈õa≈õloki.

I. Jƒ´va, or the individual soul, is knowledge, dependent on Hari, and is in a condition to be associated with, or dissociated from, a body; is an atom, different in different bodies, and is a knower and numberless.

It is called knowledge here to show that it is able to know

without the organs of sense, and it is not to be understood hero that the soul is the mere phenomenon of knowledge, and not a substance, which is the doctrine of ≈öamkarƒÅcƒÅrya.

II. The individual soul has his form distorted by its contact with MƒÅyƒÅ, or the constituent principle with the three qualities which has no beginning. Its true nature becomes known by the grace of God.

Individual souls are of two sorts: (1) those delivered or in a supremely blissful condition; (2) those tied down to the circle of existences. The first are of two kinds: (I) those who are eternally in a supremely blissful condition, such as (a) Garu·∏ça, Vi·π£vaksena, and (b) the crown, ear-ornaments and the flute considered as living beings; and (II) those who are freed from the trammels of life. Of these last some attain to the likeness of God and others are content with the perception of the nature of their own soul. Corresponding to these two last are two kinds of Mumuk·π£u, those who seek deliverance of either kind.

III. The inanimate objects are of three kinds: (1) not derived from Prak·πõti; (2) derived from Prak·πõti, and (3) time. In the things derived from Prak·πõti we have the ordinary material objects having the three colours, viz., red, white, and dark.

The first class consists of those which are spoken of figuratively. by the use of the names of objects belonging to the second class, such as the sunlike refulgence of the Supreme Soul. It is a rofulgence not arising from the Prak·πõti. Similarly the body, hands, feet, and ornaments of God, as well as all the surroundings, such as garden, palace, etc., belong to the first class and are of an inanimate nature, though they are not made of matter, i. e., not derived from Prak·πõti¬π.

IV. I meditate on the highest Brahman, viz., Kr·π£·πáa, who has eyes like the lotus, who naturally is free from all faults, is the store of all beneficent attributes, who has Vyuhas for his parts, and who is adored by all.

____________________________________________________________________________________________

1.The physical attributes, given to God by RƒÅmƒÅnuja and the rest and to which the word ‘celestial’ is sometimes prefixed,are to be understood in this sense.

The Vy≈´has here mentioned are those usually referred to in the PƒÅ√±carƒÅtra and RƒÅmƒÅnuja systems. The commentators understand. the incarnations also by this expression. One gives a large number of these, divided into classes on certain principles. Kr·π£·πáa is called Vare·πáya or adored by all, because he has a holy celestial body and bodily qualities, such as beauty, tenderness, sweetness and charm. All these are of course non-material (AprƒÅk·πõta), though inanimate according to Stanza III.

V. I reflect on the daughter of V·πõ·π£abhƒÅnu (RƒÅdhikƒÅ), who shines with a corresponding beauty on the left side (of Kr·π£·πáa), ist attended on by thousands of female friends, and who always confers all desired objects.

VI. This Parabrahman should be always worshipped uninterruptedly by men in order to be free from the darkness in the shape of ignorance, in which they are enveloped. So was NƒÅrada, who directly perceived the whole truth, taught by Sanandana and others.

VII. All things having Brahman for their souls in accordance with the ≈örutis and Sm·πõtis, the knowledge that [ Brahman ] is all is true. This is the doctrine of those who know the Vedas, and at the same time the three forms are true as determined from the sacred precepts (Sm·πõtis) and the S≈´tras.

Here is laid down the unity of all things in so far as Brahman. is the inner controlling soul of all and is concomitant with them, and their existence and actions are dependent on it, and also pluralism, since there are three distinct substances, which are called forms of Brahman in the Stanza, vix, the inanimate world, the individual soul and the Supreme Soul.

VIII. There appears no way to salvation except the lotus-like feet of K·πõ·π£·πáa, which are adored by Brahmadeva, ≈öiva and others Kr·π£·πáa, who, at the desire of a devotee, assumes a form easy of meditation and whose power is unthinkable and whose essence cannot be comprehended.

IX. His grace extends itself to those who have a feeling of helples·π£·πáess and other qualifications, and by that grace is generated. Bhakti, or devotion, consisting of special love for Him, Who has

no superior lord. This Bhakti is of two kinds: the highest is one, and the other is that which leads to or is instrumental to it.

By the feeling of helples·π£·πáess and other qualifications are meant the six modes of Prapatti given in connection with RƒÅmƒÅnuja’s system. The Bhakti which is instrumental to that which is the highest, is of the nature of the six or nine modes mentioned in previous Sections.

X. These five things should be known by the devotees: (1) the nature of the being to be worshipped; (2) the nature of the worshipper: (3) the fruit of Gods’s grace; (4) the feeling of enjoyment consequent on Bhakti, or love; (5) obstructions to the attainment of God.

The first is the knowing of the nature of the Supreme Being as existence, intelligence and joy (SaccidƒÅnanda ), of his possessing a colestial body (non-material), of his dwelling in such places as the cow-settlement (Vraja), which is called the celestial city (Vyomapura), of his being the cause of all, omnipotent, tender, merciful, gracious towards his devotees, and so forth. The second consists in knowing the worshipper as an atom, possessing knowledge aud joy, and as the servant of Kr·π£·πáa, etc. The third is the self-surrender and the giving up of all actions except the service of God, which results in self-surrender. The fourth arises from serenity, servitude, friendliness, affection, and enthusiasm. These states of mind are consequent upon the peculiar relation to God of each individual, as affection was the feeling of Nanda, VƒÅsudeva and Devakƒ´, and enthusiasm, of RƒÅdhƒÅand Rukmi·πáƒ´. The fifth are such as regarding the body as the soul, dependence. on others than God and one’s preceptor, indifference to the com- mands of God contained in the sacred books, worshipping other gods, giving up one’s own peculiar duties, ingratitude, spending one’s life in a worthless manner, vilification of good men, and many others.

¬ß 55. These ten Stanzas contain the quintessence of NimbƒÅrka’s system. This appears to have RƒÅmƒÅnuja’s doctrines for its basis and is a sidewise development of it. It gives predominance to Prapatti or self-surrender of the six kinds, alluded to above, and then, by the grace of God, love for Him is generated. His SƒÅdhana

Bhakti comprehends all the Yogas of RƒÅmƒÅnuja’s system. RƒÅmƒÅnuja, as we have already remarked55, changes the original sense of Bhakti and renders it equivalent to the UpƒÅsanƒÅ, or the meditation prescribed in the Upan·π£iads. But NimbƒÅrka keeps to the original sense. His doctrines make a nearor approach to the Tenkalai, or Southern Learning, of the RƒÅmƒÅnujiyas. But the great difference between the two teachers is, that, while RƒÅmƒÅnuja confines himself to NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa and his consorts Lak·π£mi, Bh≈´ and Lƒ´lƒÅ, NimbƒÅrka gives almost an exclusive prominence to Kr·π£·πáa and his mistress, RƒÅdhƒÅ, attended on by thousands of her female companions. Thus the fourth element of Vai·π£·πáavism which we have mentioned56 rises to the surface in Vai·π£·πáavism about this. time, and retains its place in Northern India, including Bengal, except in the case of those sects whose favourite deity is RƒÅmaand not Kr·π£·πáa; and to these for the present we will now turn our attention, coming back again to Kr·π£·πáaism later on.

NimbƒÅrka’s system is known by the name of Sanakasa·πÅpradƒÅya, or the tradition originating with Sanaka. Though NimbƒÅrka was a Southerner, he lived at V·πõndƒÅvana near MathurƒÅ, which accounts for the preference given by him to the RadhaKr·π£·πáaform of Vai·π£·πáavism. His followers are scattered over the whole of Northern India, and exist in large numbers near MathurƒÅand in Bengal. They wear two perpendicular lines of Gopƒ´candana with a black spot in the middle on the forehead, and use a necklace and rosary of the wood of the Tulasƒ´plant. They are divided into two classes, the ascetics and householders. This distinction appears to have originated at the time of HarivyƒÅsadeva, after whom, as I have observed in a note, the successors of NimbƒÅrka were divided into two branches. The reason for the division was probably this new distinction.

XVIII. RƒÅmƒÅnanda.

¬ß 56. A spirit of sympathy for the lower castes and classes of Hindu society has from the beginning been a distinguishing feature of Vai·π£·πáavism. Still, so far as we have advanced, the great teachers kept these castes and classes into, what might be

called, an outer court, though they were admitted to the benefits of the new dispensation. They had not, as the pure VedƒÅntinsassert, to do the duties prescribed for their mean position, and rise in succeeding lives until they were finally born as BrƒÅhma·πáas, when alone they could avail themselves of the methods laid down for the attainment of Mok·π£a, or deliverance. They could attain this even as members of the lowest caste by resorting to devotion, but the Brahmanic teachers, RƒÅmƒÅnuja and others, made the methods based on the study of the Vedic literature accessible. only to the higher castes, leaving other methods to the rest.

But RƒÅmƒÅnanda now began a radical reform and made no distinction between BrƒÅhma·πáas and members of the degraded. castes, and all could even dine together, provided they were the devotees of Vi·π£·πáu and had been admitted into the fold. Another reform, which must be traced to RƒÅmƒÅnanda, was the use of the Vernaculars for the propagation of the new creed. And a third very important reform made by him was the introduction of the purer and more chaste worship of RƒÅmƒÅ and Sƒ´tƒÅinstead of that of Kr·π£·πáa and RƒÅdhƒÅ.

Mr. Macauliffe mentions Mailkot as the place of his birth and says that he must have flourished in the end of the fourteenth and the first half of the fifteenth century, which, he states, corresponds with a reckoning which gives 1398 A D., as the date of the birth of Kabƒ´r. This would rather make RƒÅmƒÅnanda live long before. the end of the fourteenth century, as Kabir was his successor, and ordinarily believed to be his pupil¬π. The authority¬≤ I have. consulted states that he was born at PrayƒÅga as the son of a KƒÅnyakubja BrƒÅhma·πáa, named Punyasadans, and his wife Su≈õƒ´lƒÅ. The date of his birth is given as 4400 of the Kali age, equivalent to 1356 of Vikkrama-Sa·πÅvat. This corresponds to 1299 or 1300 A. D., and is more consistent with the traditional statement that there were three generations between him and RƒÅmƒÅnuja. Thedate of RƒÅmƒÅnuja’s death is usually given as 1137 A. D., though. it makes him out as having lived for 120 years. The lapse of three. generations between 1137 and 1300 A. D., is a more reasonable. supposition than between 1137 and the end of the fourteenth century. This last date, therefore, given for RƒÅmƒÅnanda is manifestly wrong, and that occurring in the book I have consulted appears to be correct in all probability.

____________________________________________________________________________________________

1.The Sikh Religion, ate., by M. A. Macauliffe, Vol. VI, pp. 100-1. 1908 A. D. is said by Macauliffe to correspond to the 510th year of his ara. By his he must mean Kabƒ´r’s.

2.Chapters from the Agastya-Sa·πÅhitƒÅwith a Hindi translation by RƒÅmƒÅ NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa DƒÅsa, completed in Sa·πÅvat 1960, corresponding to 1904 A. D.

From PrayƒÅga RƒÅmƒÅnanda was sent to Benares for the usual education of a BrƒÅhma·πáa. After he finished this, he became a disciple of RƒÅghavƒÅnanda, a teachar of the Vi≈õi·π£·π≠ƒÅdvaita school of RƒÅmƒÅnuja After some time he gave up some of the restrictive practices of the sect, such as that of taking food without being seen by anybody, and separated himself from his preceptor, and himself became the founder of a school. As indicated above, he took pupils from the degraded castes also. Thirteen of them became noted and their names are: 1. AnantƒÅnanda, 2. SurasarƒÅnanda, 3. SukhƒÅnanda, 4. Naraharƒ´yƒÅnanda, 5. YogƒÅnanda, 6. Pƒ´pƒÅ, 7. Kabƒ´r, 8. BhƒÅvanƒÅnda, 9. SenƒÅ, 10. DhannƒÅ, 11. GƒÅlavƒÅnanda, 12. RƒÅidƒÅs, and 13. PadmƒÅvatƒ´.

Of these Pƒ´pƒÅwas a Rajput, Kabƒ´r was a ≈ö≈´dra and spoken of also as a Mahomedan following the profession of a weaver, SenƒÅ was a barber, DhannƒÅa JƒÅt, RƒÅidƒÅs belonged to the degraded caste of curriers or workers in leather, and PadmƒÅvatƒ´was a woman. With the first twelve he went about the country visiting holy places, conducting disputations with the advocates of the MƒÅyƒÅ doctrine, Jaius, Buddhists, etc., establishing his own Vi≈õi·π£·π≠ƒÅdvaita theory, and converting men to his views and admitting them as his disciples. RƒÅmƒÅnanda is stated to have died in 1467 of Vikrama-Sa·πÅvat, corresponding to 1411 A. D. This gives him a life of 111 years, which is rather improbable. Some of his pupils became the founders of different schools, and through them the worship of RƒÅmƒÅ spread over an extensive portion of Northern and Central India, successfully competing with that of GopƒÅla-Kr·π£·πáa.

XIX. Kabƒ´r.

¬ß 57. The few particulars that have come down to us about the birth and life of Kabƒ´r are these. He was the son of a

BrƒÅhma·πáa widow who cast him away as soon as he was born, to hide her shame, near the Lahar Tank in Benares. A Mahomedan weaver of the name of Nir≈´was passing by the way with his wife Nƒ´mƒÅ, when the latter saw the child and carried it home. He was nurtured and brought up by her and her husband Nir≈´, and Kabƒ´r when he had grown up, followed the occupation of a weaver. He showed leanings towards the Hindu faith, and the idea of making RƒÅmƒÅnanda his Guru, or preceptor, arose in his mind. But he conceived it not possible that that sage should receive a Mahomedan as his disciple and therefore had recourse to a contrivance. He laid himself down on the GhƒÅ·π≠a, or pavement on the Ganges, at which RƒÅmƒÅnanda bathed very early in the morning. On the way RƒÅmƒÅnanda trampled on the boy and exclaimed “RƒÅma, RƒÅma! What poor creature is it that I have trampled upon ?”. Kabƒ´r rose up and received the exclamation “RƒÅma, RƒÅma” as a Mantra communicated to him by RƒÅmƒÅnanda, and he understood that he had thus been made a disciple.

Another account is that, being trampled on, Kabƒ´r rose up and cried aloud, when RƒÅmƒÅnanda told him to be quiet and go on uttering the name of “RƒÅmƒÅ”. Considering that he had thus been accepted as a pupil, Kabƒ´r went on with his adorations of God, proclaiming that he was the disciple of RƒÅmƒÅnanda. Some Hindus went to the latter and asked him whether he had initiated Kabƒ´r.Thereupon Kabƒ´r was sent for and asked by RƒÅmƒÅnanda, when it was that he had been initiated. Kabƒ´r mentioned to him. the incident of his having been trampled upon the GhƒÅ·π≠a, Then RƒÅmƒÅnanda remembered the matter and clasped Kabƒ´r to his breast. Since that time Kabƒ´r regularly attended at his master’s Ma·π≠ha and joined him in his disputations with the Pandits.

For some time Kabƒ´r lived at Manikapur, as is mentioned in one of his Ramainƒ´s. There he heard of the fame of Shaikh Taqqi and of twenty-one Pƒ´rs. He heard their discourses, condemned. their teachings and said: “O Shaikhs, of whatever name! listen to me, Open your eyes and see the origin and the end of all things and their creation and dissolution”. In one of the books of this sect, Shaikh Taqqi is represented as an enemy of Kabƒ´r, and a Pƒ´r, or the religious guide, of Sikandar Lodi. At his advice the emperor persecuted Kabƒ´r and used various methods to destroy

him. But Kabƒ´r miraculously escaped death and was eventually reconciled to Sikandar Lodi, who received him into his favour.

Kabƒ´r died at Maghar, and there was a dispute between the Hindus and the Mahomedans as to the disposal of his dead body, which was covered by a sheet of cloth. When the sheet was removed, the body had disappeared, and in its stead there was a heap of flowers. The Mahomedans took one-half of the quantity and buried it at Maghar and erected a tomb over it, and the Hindus took their share to Benares, where it was burnt. Kabƒ´r had a wife of the name of Loi, a son of the name KamƒÅl, and a daughter of the name of KamƒÅlƒ´. But there are miraculous stories. as to how Kabƒ´r came by them.

As to how much of this account is historical and how much legendary, it is difficult to say. But that he was a Mahomedan weaver at the beginning may be accepted as a fact. And that Shaikh Taqqi, a Mahomedan Pƒ´r, who is mentioned in one of the Ramainƒ´s, as stated above, was his rival and that Kabƒ´r lived about the time of Sikandar Lodi may also be regarded as historical. As to whether Kabƒ´r was a disciple of RƒÅmƒÅnanda, there is some question, as will be presently mentioned. Mr. Westcott considers it not impossible that he should have been both a Mahomedan and a S≈´fi¬π, but all his writings show a complete familiarity with the names occurring in Hindu religious. literature and Hindu manners and customs, so that it appears to me that there is little or nothing in Kabƒ´r’s writings calculated to show that his teachings had a Mahomedan basis. The basis appears to be purely Hindu, though Kabƒ´r was a bold and uncompromising reformer and hurled anathemas at the Pandits, the BrƒÅhma·πáas proud of their caste, and the teachers of the existing sects of the Hindus, and thus appears to have come under the influence of Mahomedanism.

The dates given by various writers for the birth and death of Kabƒ´r are conflicting. Mr. Westcott makes him live for 78 years, from 1440 to 1518 A. D.57, and according to Mr. Macauliffe he

___________________________________________________________________________

1.Kabƒ´r and the Kabir Panth by Rev. G. H. Westcott. Cawnpore, 1907, p. 44.

13 [ R. G. Bhandarkar’s Works, Vol. IV. ]

was born in Sa·πÅvat 1455, corresponding to A. D. 139858, and ha died in A. D. 151859, having lived for 119 years, five months and twenty-seven days. In a footnote he quotes from an original work the date ≈öaka 1370, corresponding to 1448 A. D., as the date of his death. Sikandar Lodi was on the throne of Delhi from 1488 to 1517 A. D. The last of the three dates does not harmonise with this, and so it must be given up. RƒÅmƒÅnanda, we have seen, is spoken of as having been born in 1298 A. D. and died in 1411 A. D. If Mr. Westcott’s date for Kabƒ´r’s birth is true, Kabƒ´r cannot have been a disciple of RƒÅmƒÅnanda. If that of Mr. Macauliffe is accepted, it is just possible that he should have so become, for at the time of RƒÅmƒÅnanda’s death, Kabƒ´r must have been thirteen years of age, and he is represented in one of the legends to have been but a boy when he was accepted as a disciple by the old sage. The date 1518 A. D. given by both the writers for his death may be accepted as correct. But if that of his birth given by Mr. Macauliffe is also accepted, we shall have to suppose that Kabƒ´r lived for 119 years; RƒÅmƒÅnanda also according to the dates given in the last section lived for 113 years. Whether both of them lived. such long lives might well be questioned. But, until we have more evidence, the dates for RƒÅmƒÅnanda already noticed, and for Kabƒ´r as given by Mr. Macauliffe may be provisionally accepted, and thus Kabƒ´r might be considered to have really been a disciple of RƒÅmƒÅnanda, though of course, being a boy of thirteen, he could not have taken part in his master’s disputations with Pandits. In Kabƒ´r’s works, however, so far as I have seen them, RƒÅmƒÅnanda’s namedoes not occur, though the name RƒÅmaas that of the Supreme Being and also the relation of the individual soul with RƒÅma, as well as his refutation of the doctrine of God’s being Videha or Nirgu·πáa, i. e., without attributes, must have been borrowed from RƒÅmƒÅnanda’s doctrines, which again are based on RƒÅmƒÅnuja’s system.

¬ß 58. We now give a translation of a few passages illustra tive of the teachings of Kabƒ´r¬≥.

___________________________________________________________________________

3.The edition consulted is that published with a commentary under the ordeft of Raghurajasimha, Maharaja of Rewab, in Sa·πÅvat 1924.

First Ramainƒ™.¬π

1.There was in the inside a substance called Jƒ´va or individual soul; the Internal Light illuminated [it]. 2. And then followed. a woman of the name of ‘desire’; and she was called GƒÅyatrƒ´. 3.That woman gave birth to three sons; BrahmƒÅ, Vi·π£·πáu and Mahe≈õa, 4. Then BrahmƒÅasked the woman who was her husband and whose wife she was. 5. (She replied:) “Thou and I, I and thou, and there is no third, Thou art my husband and I am thy wife.” 6. The father and son had a common wife; and one mother has a two-fold character; there is no son who is good son and who will endeavour to recognise his father.

Second Ramainƒ´.

1.In the light there was sound, which was a woman. 2. And of the woman were Hari, BrahmƒÅ and the enemy of the three cities (≈öiva). 3.Then BrahmƒÅcreated an egg and divided it into fourteen regions. 4-6. Then Hari, Hara and BrahmƒÅ settled in three regions, and thus they arranged the whole BrƒÅhma·πá·∏ça and the six philosophies and ninety-six heresies. Nobody then taught the Veda for his sustenance; and Turuk did not come for making circumcision. 7.The woman brought forth from her womb. children. They became distinct individuals and followed different courses of action. 8.Therefore I and thou are of one blood and. are one life. Distinctness arises from ignorance. 9. From one woman all sprang, and what knowledge is it that brought about distinctness between them? 13 (SƒÅkhƒ´). Kabƒ´r proclaims: All this ordinary world is destructible; without knowing the name of RƒÅma all individuals are drowned in the ocean of existence.

Kabƒ´r’s account of creation seems to be this. In the light of RƒÅma there existed a substance which was the subtle element, the sum total of all individual souls. And then that substance was illuminated by that light. Then followed a desire in the shape of a woman, which was at the same time called GƒÅyatrƒ´and sound. (≈öabda), and from her the creation took its rise. His idea thus

___________________________________________________________________________

1.Ramainƒ´ is a piece of composition consisting of several CaupƒÅƒ´s (Sk. Catu·π£padƒ´), which are stanzas consisting of four lines with the ends of the first two and of the last two rhyming with each other, and a SƒÅkhƒ´(which is another species of metre) at the end.

seems to be that individual souls came into being, or were developed out of a substance which was their subtle form, at the will of the Supreme Soul, which (will) was uttered in the form of a sound. That is to say, the Supreme Soul was not the material cause of the world, but a distinct subtle entity. What, in the language of the Upan·π£iads, became many was this entity and not the Supreme Soul himself. Kabƒ´r’s philosophy is thus not a monism, but. dualism. All individuals sprang into existence from the same cause, there was one blood and one life, and consequently the distinction of castes and races was a later fiction. Kabƒ´r thus appears to be an opponent of this distinction.

Fifth RƒÅmainƒ´.

The substance of the first five CaupƒÅƒ´s seems to be that Hari, Hara and BrahmƒÅ, taking the two letters (RƒÅma), laid the foundation of all learning, and gradually the Vedas and KitƒÅbs (books) came to be composed. 6-8. In all the four ages the devotees devised systems, but were not aware that the bundle they had tied up was torn. Men ran in all directions for salvation, being afraid. Abandoning their lord they ran towards hell.

Eighth Ramainƒ´.

1.The precept “Tat tvam asi " ( that thou art) is the message of the Upani·π£ads. 2.They lay great stress upon it, and those who are qualified explain it (at great length). 3. Sanaka and NƒÅrada became happy by regarding the highest principle to be distinct. from themselves, 4. The colloquy between Janaka and YƒÅjnÃÑavalkya comes to the same effect, and that same sweet sentiment was tested by DattƒÅtreya. 5.VƒÅsi·π£·π≠ha and RƒÅma sang together the same thing, and that same thing was explained to Uddhava. 6.That same thing was substantiated by Janaka, and though her had a body, he was called bodiless (Videha ). 7 (Sakhƒ´). No mortal becomes immortal without abandoning the pride of birth. That which one cannot see by experience is to be considered as “unseen” or “unperceived”.

In this Ramainƒ´ Kabƒ´r shows acquaintance with the Upan·π£iads and other branches of Hiudu sacred literature, so that he cannot have been a mere “S≈´fi and Mahomedan”. He rejects the theory of the identity between the Supreme and the individual souls,

which is regarded as being laid down in the expression “That thou art of the ChƒÅndogya Upan·π£iad. The commentator says. that by “that” is to be understood the subtle body of sixteen parts and the expression means “Thou art that subtle body”. Kabƒ´rtakes all the individuals he has named in this Ramainƒ´ to have preached duality.

In the fourteenth Ramainƒ´there is a condemnation of the several systems of religion-that contained in the PurƒÅ·πáas, that of BrahmƒÅ, Ha·πÅsa, GopƒÅla, ≈öa·πÅbhu, ghosts and goblins and various forms of worship upto the Nevaja of the Mahomedan.

Thirty-fourth Ramainƒ´.

1.The Pandits were misled by the study of the Vedas which are based on the Gu·πáas, or qualities, and did not know their own nature and their true friend (God). 2.They practise Sa·πÅdhyƒÅ, Tarpa·πáa, the six rites and various other such ceremonies. 3. In all the four Yugas GƒÅyatrƒ´has been taught; ask who obtained salvation (Mukti) by its means. 4. When you are touched by other people, you bathe; tell me who is more degraded than yourselves. 5. You are very proud of your virtues. Too much pride is not good. 6.How can he whose name destroys all pride. bear this proud behaviour? 7.(SƒÅkhƒ´).
