Giving up the traditional mode of worship of the family, they seek the place of NirvƒÅ·πáa; having destroyed the seed and sprout, they became an entity without attributes (Videha or Nirgu·πáa).

Kabƒ´r here condemns the rites, ceremonies and other practices of the BrƒÅhma·πáas, the pride that is generated in them by these, the contempt in which they hold people of other castes, and also their search of NirvƒÅ·πáa, or a condition without any attributes, i. e., the Advaita, or adualistic, system which they follow.

Fortieth Ramainƒ´.

1.The sea, which is a collection of waters, is a ditch, and in it are the sun, the moon, and the thirty-three crores of brothers. 2.In the whirlpools (of such a universe) they (men and gods) have seated themselves and desire happiness, but have not shunned the touch of misery. 3.Nobody knows the secret of misery, and the world has become mad in a variety of ways.

4.Everybody is a fool or a sage in himself and nobody knows RƒÅma who dwells in the heart. 5. (SƒÅkhƒ´). They themselves are Hari (God), they themselves are lords, they themselves are the slaves of Hari. When there is no guarantee, the lady (Mukti or salvation) goes away disappointed.

Here again there is a condemnation of various systems and of the self-confidence which has given rise to them and the neglect of God dwelling in the heart.

SƒÅkhƒ´s.

I.

  1. The crowds went by the path traversed by the Pandits. Lofty is the ascent to RƒÅma. Kabƒ´r has climbed it. 135. The whole world has gone astray by partiality for one’s own system. He who, becoming free from partiality, adores Hari, is a wise sage. 138. The great ones are lost in their own greatness; pridel peers out through every pore; when they are not familiar with a wise preceptor, all the orders of men are of the Cam√£r caste, i. e., the degraded caste of curriers. 182. The Kali is a wicked age; the world is blind and nobody believes in the true word. He to whom a salutary advice is given, becomes an enemy. 211. Three things went to a holy place (the body, the fickle heart, and the mind which is a thief). They did not destroy a single sin, but on the contrary the mind contracted ten others. 260, The Kabƒ´rs (men in general) polluted the path of Bhakti, or faith, by washing pebbles and stones. Keeping poison within, they have thrown out the nectar. 358. “I am the author of the whole creation, there is no other who is superior to me.” (This is what some people think). Kabƒ´r says that, when one does not know what one is oneself, one thinks everything to be contained in oneself. 365. In this world all have passed away considering themselves to bei RƒÅma, but no one actually became RƒÅma. Kabƒ´r says that those who know RƒÅma as he truly is, attain all their objects. 366. This world has become mad and has conceived a love for something which can be no matter of experience; and denying all authoritativeness to actual experience, they attach themselves to a soul without attributes (Videha). 372. Seeing a void, men were misled

and went about searching in all quarters till they died, but did not find a form without attributes.

II.

  1. The bee loiters in the garden, being enticed by the innumerable flowers in it. In the same manner the individual soul loiters among the objects of sense and at the end goes away disappointed. 95. The soul is to the mind as a monkey is to a showman. Making it dance in a variety of ways, it (mind) finally retains it in its own hands. 96. The mind is fickle, a thief and perfect swindler. The gods and the sages fell off in consequence of the mind and mind finds a hundred thousand openings. 136. If a man gives up his belongings, it does not mean much. Egotism, or self-pride, cannot be given up. Self-pride, which led astray the great Munis, devours all. Running after gold and women, men are burnt by the passion generated by an illusion. Kabƒ´r says, how can they be saved, being like cotton which has come in contact with fire? 147. All became subject to the power of illusion: BrahmƒÅ, Vi·π£·πáu, Mahe≈õa, and the four, NƒÅrada, ≈öƒÅrada, Sanaks, and Ga·πáe≈õa, the son of Gaurƒ´. 209. Do not kill a poor living creature; the life of all is the same. You will not be free from (the sin of) killing, even if you hear crores of PurƒÅ·πáas.

III.

  1. He to attain whom the great sages (Munis) go through austerities and whose virtuos the Vedas sing, himself gives instruction, but nobody believes. 208. One single poor soul is bound. u by many fetters. If the father (God) will not liberate him, what power has the soul himself to do so? 243. I (God) instructi him, but he does not understand and sells himself into the hands of others. I pull him towards myself; but he runs away to the city of death (Yama). 282. If you endeavour to acquire one thing (God), every other thing will come to you; but if you endeavour to acquire every other thing, that one thing will be lost. If you. water the root of a tree, you will obtain a sufficiency of flowers. and fruits. 310. If you want me (God), give up your desire for every other thing and become mine, and then everything will be yours. 236. He has entered into every body and remains there. fully watchful. When one wants a certain accomplishment, he

inspires him with the corresponding thoughts (calculated to enable him to achieve success).

Here the first group contains a condemnation of the current religious doctrines; the second gives a specimen of Kabƒ´r’s moral teachings, and the third explains the way in which God’s graca operates towards the deliverance of man. Kabƒ´r, therefore, was as much a constructive reformer as destructive. In SƒÅkhƒ´260 of the first group, Kabƒ´r, it will be seen, condemns the worship of idols. The religion which he promulgated, therefore, was a pure spiritual theism. The mode of worship used by his followers up to the present day consists of prayers and praises only.

Kabƒ´r founded a Pantha, or a sect, and the Ma·π≠has, or establishments of that sect exist in several parts of India. The principal one is at Benares, with a branch at Maghar in the Gorakhpur District, where he died. This last is said to be in the charge of a Mahomedan Mahant, or superior. The second was established by DharmadƒÅs, his chief disciple, in the Chattisgarh District of the Central Provinces¬π. The followers of Kabƒ´r’s sect are to be found principally among the lower castes, but the sage is highly venerated by all Vai·π£·πáavas of whatever caste or class.

XX. Other RƒÅmƒÅnandins.

¬ß 59. MalukdƒÅs, who lived about the end of Akbar’s reign, i. e, about the end of the sixteenth century, was a worshipper of RƒÅma. The tradition that he belonged to the school of RƒÅmƒÅnanda appears to be correct. Like Kabƒ´r, he seems to have been a non-idolater, since in a hymn which I have seen, he ridicules men and women who hammer valuable metals into gods, worship them, and, whenever there is a necessity, sell them for the price of the metal, and says that the true way was shown to him by his wise. preceptor. The sect founded by him has seven Ma·π≠has, or establishments, and its adherents follow the occupation of householders.

DƒÅdu was a cotton cleaner at Ahmedabad. At twelve he removed to Sambhar and finally settled at Naraina, about twenty Ko≈õas from Jaipur. He flourished about 1600 A. D., at the end of Akbar’s reign. His doctrines appear to be similar to those of Kabƒ´r. The only mode of worship was Japa, or the repetition ofthe name of RƒÅma. The sect does not worship Images of RƒÅma and it erects no temples. DƒÅdu inculcates faith in, and love of, RƒÅma and meditation on him. His followers His followers are divided into threa classes: (1) Viraktas, (2) NƒÅgas, and (3) VistaradhƒÅrins. The firstlive the life of ascetics, the second are bearers of arms and enter into the service of princes as soldiers, and the third lead an ordinary life.

___________________________________________________________________________

1.For details, see Rev. G. H. Westcott’s Volume on Kabƒ´r referred to above.

RƒÅidƒÅs, a pupil of RƒÅmƒÅnanda, was a founder of a sect the followers of which are to be found in the caste of CamƒÅrs. or leather-workers. NƒÅbhƒÅjƒ´in his BhaktamƒÅlƒÅtolls many legends. about him. Under the name of RohidƒÅs he is known and revered even in the Maratha country, and Mahƒ´pati, the Maratha writer on saints, devotes a chapter to him.

SenƒÅthe barber, a follower of RƒÅmƒÅnanda, is also reported to have founded a sect. He too is known in the Maratha country60.

XXI. Tulasƒ´dƒÅs.

¬ß 60. Another person who contributed to the propagation of the cult of RƒÅmaover Northern Indis, was the famous Tulasƒ´dƒÅs, whom we will now briefly notice. Tulasƒ´dƒÅs belonged to the SaravaryƒÅor Saray≈´parƒ´·πáa caste of BrƒÅhma·πáas and was born in Sa·πÅvat 1589, corresponding to 1532 A. D., under an inauspicious constellation. He was abandoned by his parents and was picked. up by a SƒÅdhu, or a pious man, in whose company he visited many places in India. His father’s name was ƒÄtmƒÅrƒÅma ≈öukla D≈´be, his mother’s Hulasƒ´, and his own RƒÅma B≈çta. His father-in-law was a man of the name of Dƒ´nabandhu PƒÅ·π≠haka, and hist wife was called RatnƒÅvalƒ´His son’s name was TƒÅraka.

Tulasƒ´dƒÅs commenced the composition of his great work, RƒÅmacaritamƒÅnasa, usually known as RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa, at AyodhyƒÅin 1574 A. D., and finished it at Benares. He wrote eleven other works, six of which were smaller. Tulasƒ´dƒÅs was not a sturdy reformer like Kabƒ´r and does not seem to have founded a sect or even to have promulgated a definite VedƒÅntic theory. In this respect he appears to have been, like a host of other persons who flourished in the country, a teacher of the BhaktimƒÅrga, or the path of devotion, which is based upon a dualistic philosophy with a leaning towards spiritual monism of the Advaita system. Tulasƒ´dƒÅs died in 1623 A. D.¬π

¬ß 61. I will now give a short specimen of Tulasƒ´dƒÅs’ teachings. from his RƒÅma-Satasaƒ´, the composition of which, as stated in DohƒÅ 21 of the first chapter, was commenced on Thursday, the ninth of the bright half of Vai≈õƒÅkha, Sa·πÅvat 1642 = 1585 A. D.

Chapter I.

(DohƒÅ 3) The highest soul, the highest excellent place, than whom or which there is no other, Tulasƒ´ understands and hears to be RƒÅma, the blessed. (DohƒÅ4) “RƒÅma whose attributes confer blessings upon all is himself free from all desires. He fulfils all desires, is the benefactor of all. The sages assert this."‚ÄîSo says! Tulasƒ´. (DohƒÅ 15) Tulasƒ´ sees plainly that in every pore of RƒÅma there is an endless universe. He is pure, is unchangeable and is irresistible. (DohƒÅ 6) The blessed JƒÅnakƒ´is the mother of the world, and RƒÅma the father. Both are beneficent. Their grace destroys sin, and creates conscience (confers the knowledge of distinguishing good from evil). (DohƒÅ 44) Where there is RƒÅma, there is no [evil] desire; where there is [evil] desire, there is no RƒÅma. Oh Tulasƒ´ !the sun and the night do not exist in one place. (DohƒÅ 45) When RƒÅma is afar, MƒÅyƒÅ(illusion or temptation) is strong. When he is known, it becomes tiny or thin. When the sun is at a distance, the shadow is long; when ho is on the head, it is below the feet. (DohƒÅ 48) Says Tulasƒ´ : “If there is no love for RƒÅma, all learning is thrown into an oven and Yama takes away knowledge and devours it; everything burns away and the very root is destroyed”. (DohƒÅ 57) All things by which a man is surrounded, serve as hindrances, and none proves a help (towards the way of bliss); and, in such circumstances, if the end is good, it can become so only through RƒÅma’s grace.

Chapter II

(DohƒÅ 17) Says Tulsƒ´ : “Through the disobedience of God, man brings evil on himself and all his associates. The king ofthe Kurus, while governing his kingdom, was reduced to dust along with his army and family”. (Doha 18) Says Tulasƒ´: “From sweet words results good on all sides. This is a spell that. overcomes everything; avoid all harsh words”. (Doha 19) “A man attains happiness by the grace of RƒÅma, and it escapes ono without it”, says Tulas√¨, “though they know this, bad men neglect to adore RƒÅma.”

___________________________________________________________________________

1.For details, see Dr. Grierson’s articles in the Indian Antiquary, Vol. XXII.

Chapter IV.61

82 (89 B. I). The excellent retentive faculty is called GirƒÅor Sarasvatƒ´, and the immutable Dharma is a Va·π≠a tree. Dharma consists of a triad of confluent rivers destroying sin. Oh Tulasƒ´, conceive no dislike for these and accept these.

The triad is given by the commentator as action, knowledge, and Bhakti, or devotion.

83 (90 B. I.). One becomes clean by bathing (in these three. confluent rivers), i. e., grasping the trind by the understanding. The dirt in the shape of immortality is washed off, and then there is no doubt as to the easy attainment of the place of Rama. 84 (91 B. I. ). Forgiveness is holy VƒÅrƒÅnasƒ´. Bhakti, or devotion, is like the river of gods (Ga·πÖgƒÅ) and clear knowledge is like Vi≈°ve≈°vara. These together with compassion, which is power PƒÅrvatƒ´), shine.

The commentator remarks that just as Benares with the other. three brings about deliverance, so do forgiveness, devotion, knowledge, and compassion.

85 (92 B. I.). VƒÅrƒÅnasƒ´is not far from him whose heart dwells in the house which is K·π£amƒÅ(forgiveness)‚ÄîVƒÅrƒÅnasƒ´, in which shines, oh Tulasƒ´the celestial river in the shape of Bhakti, which results in numerous virtuous deeds. 86 (93 B. L.). KƒÅsƒ´is the bright half of a month and Magaha, or Magadha, is the dark half in which dwell covetousness, infatuation, intoxication, and lust. Oh Tulasƒ´considering which is beneficial and which is injurious, do [choose where to] reside during all the watches of the day.

___________________________________________________________________________

The editions consulted are those published by Navalkisora at Lakhnau in 1886 and in the Bibliotheco Indica in 1897.

KƒÅ≈õƒ´is associated with the four virtues mentioned above, and Magadha with the vices noticed here. So one is told to practise what is beneficial and to avoid what is injurious.

87 (94 B. I.). What has gone away will not come again. Therefore do acquire knowledge. The same thing that you have today you will have tomorrow; therefore, oh Tulasƒ´ ! give up all infatuation.

The idea seems to be : Do not waste time by procrastination; begin your devotions at once.

88 (95 B. I.). The past and the future hang together on the present. Oh Tulasƒ´do not entertain any doubt, get through that which is before you at present.

89 (96 B. I.). A good soul is like the MƒÅnasa (lake), and in it is the pure water of the sweet glory of RƒÅma. Sin is washed off and the heart becomes pure (by bathing in that water); and this calm water is not inaccesible to the wise.

The idea seems to be that in a good soul a taste for devotion to RƒÅma springs up, and when it is cultivated, the soul become pure.

From these extracts it will be seen that according to Tulasƒ´dƒÅs RƒÅma is the supreme God, and that through his grace man becomes holy and blessed. He should, therefore, be adored; where he is, sin is not, and therefore, for the purification of the mind, he should always be thought of and meditated on. The ways to God usually followed are, he says, inefficacious and as such may be thrown into the fire.

XXII. Vallabha.

¬ß 62. We will now turn our attention to the more extensive and almost exclusive cult of the K·πõ·π£·πáa of Gokula. The founder of it was Vallabha. He was the son of a Taila·πÖga BrƒÅhma·πáa named Lak·π£ma·πáa Bha·π≠·π≠a, who was a student of the Black Yajurveda and lived at a village named KƒÅnkarava in the Telugu country. On one occasion Lak·π£ma·πáa Bha·π≠·π≠a went on a pilgrimage to Benares. with his wife, ElamƒÅgƒÅra. On the way she gave birth to a son on the eleventh of the dark half of Vai≈õƒÅkha of the Vikrama year

1535, corresponding to 1479 A.D.62 That son was known as Vallabha.

Vallabha lived for some time in V·πõndƒÅvana and for some time. at MathurƒÅ. About that time it is alleged that GopƒÅla-Kr·π£·πáa manifested himself on the Govardhana Hill by the name of Devadamana, called also ≈örƒ´-NƒÅthajƒ´. The God told Vallabha in at dream to come and see him, informing him that his companions in the cow-settlement, when he became incarnate as Kr·π£·πáa, were born again in the present age, and commissioned him to make. them his attendants, that he might sport with them as in the former age. Accordingly, Vallabha went and saw Devadamana or ≈örƒ´-NƒÅthajƒ´. ≈örƒ´-NƒÅthajƒ´ commanded him to erect a shrine for himself and to promulgate the method of worshipping him, without which a man would not be admissible to the Pu·π£·π≠imƒÅrga, or the path of divine grace, which Vallabha had founded. The meaning of this seems to be that Vallabha connected his system with a special manifestation of Kr·π£·πáa known by the name of ≈örƒ´-NƒÅthajƒ´¬≤.

Vallabha’s VedƒÅntic theory is the same as that of an earlier. author of the name of Vi·π£·πáusvƒÅmin. This Vi·π£·πáusvƒÅmin is said. to have been the son of the councillor of a Dravi·∏ça chief dependent upon the Emperor of Delhi63. NƒÅbhƒÅjƒ´in his BhaktamƒÅlƒÅmakes J√±ƒÅnadeva, NƒÅmdeva, Trilocana, and lastly Vallabha his successors‚Å¥. The first was J√±ƒÅnadeva, who is represented as a follower of his system (Sa·πÅpradƒÅya). He was one of three sons born to a man, who became a householder after he had assumed the order of an ascetic. He was, therefore, excommunicated and was not allowed to learn the Vedas. But he himself by his miraculous. power made a male buffalo repeat the Vedas. This story is the same as that related of the J√±ƒÅnadeva of MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠ra, the author of a Vernacular commentary on the Bhagavadgita. But the Marathas do not know of Vi·π£·πáusvƒÅmin as his Guru, or teacher,or of J√±ƒÅnadevabeing his successor or follower. If, however, the tradition reported by NƒÅbhƒÅjƒ´is correct, Vi·π£·πáusvƒÅmin must have lived about the middle of the thirteenth century. The date of the commentary above alluded to is ≈õaka 1212, corresponding to 1290 A. D.

___________________________________________________________________________

2.see HarirƒÅya MahƒÅrƒÅja GovardhanaprƒÅka·π≠yakƒ´VƒÅrtƒÅ, published in SƒÅ·πÅvat 1935, p. 11.

4.Ed. by Khemaraj, Bombay, ≈öaka 1827 (1905 A. D.). pp. 95-98.

The VedƒÅntic theory of Vi·π£·πáusvƒÅmin which is the same as that of Vallabha is as follows. The one primeval soul was not joyful, because he was alone (BU. I. 4. 3), and, desiring to be many, he himself became the inanimate world, the individual soul, and the inward controlling soul. These sprang from him like sparks from a burning fire and are his parts (MU. II. 1). By his own inscrutable power he rendered the properties of intelligence and joy imperceptible in the first, and his joy alone in the second, while the third has all the attributes perceptible in it. Simple Brahman as such has perceptible joy prevailing in it¬π.

¬ß 63. The following particulars have been gleaned from two works belonging to VallabhƒÅcƒÅrya’s sect¬≤. The whole world hasBrahman for its material cause. The perception of forms. apparently different from the Brahman is due to ignorance or delusion and to the true nature of Brahman being rendered imperceptible. The individual soul is identical with Brahman, a part of Brahman and atomic. From the Ak·π£ara composed of existence, intelligence, and joy (SaccidƒÅnanda) particles come out as sparks from fire. From the predominance of the Sat portion in them the joy portion is concealed, and thus we have the indivi dual souls possessing Sat, existence, and Cit, intelligence. The individual soul is not a form of the Supreme Soul altered by a third thing being involved in it, such as the MƒÅyƒÅ (illusive power), but is itself the same substance as the Supreme Soul with one attribute rendered imperceptible. The relation between the two is thus that of identity (Advaita), both being in the pristine unchanged form, i. e., identity of untransformed souls (≈öuddhƒÅdvaita).

The individual soul is of two kinds: (1) going through the circle

__________________________________________________________________________

1.SakalƒÅcƒÅryamatasa·πÅgraha by ≈örƒ´nivƒÅsa, Chowkh. Series.

2.≈öuddhƒÅdvaitamƒÅrta·πá·∏ça y Giridhara, and PrameyaratnƒÅr·πáva by BƒÅlak·πõ·π£·πáa Bha·π≠·π≠a ,Chowkh. Series.

of existences, and (2) delivered from the trammels of life. The first is subject to misery in consequence of his delusion that his body and senses are his soul. He remains in this condition till he acquires knowledge, sees the vanity of the world and devotes himself to meditation and the love of God, when he is delivered. The delivered souls are: (1) those who have become so while in their previous condition, by the termination of ignorance or delusion, such as Sanaka and others; and (2) those who dwell in the world of the Bhagavat, other than the pervading Vaiku·πá·π≠ha¬π, where they attain the condition of pure Brahman by the favour of the Bhagavat; (3) there are others, who, having the divine nature in them, and coming in contact with good men, resort to various ways of Bhakti, or the propitiation of God, until perfect love alone for Him comes to dwell in their heart, and finally become the associates of the Bhagavat in His eternal sports and amusements. This last is the Mok·π£a, or deliverance.

That class of worldly souls who have no divine nature in them, and in whom evil predominates, are ever moving in the circle of existences. The souls who have the divine nature in them are of two kinds: (1) those who subject themselves to certain moral. discipline (MaryƒÅdƒÅjƒ´va), and (2) those who depend entirely on God’s grace (Pu·π£·π≠jƒ´va). Both attain final deliverance, but there is a difference which corresponds to that between (2) and (3) above and which will be further explained below.

≈örƒ´-K·πõ·π£·πáa is the highest Brahman. He has hands and feet not made up of ordinary matter (AprƒÅk·πõta), but celestial. His body consists of Sat, existence; Cit, intelligence; ƒÄnanda, joy. He is called Puru·π£ottama, as the most excellent of all beings, and has all attributes which are not ordinary, but celestial. All his sports

___________________________________________________________________________

1.I translate the word VyƒÅpi-Vaiku·πá·π≠ha thus. The VyƒÅpi-Vaiku·πá·π≠ha above the Vaiku·πá·π≠ha of Vi·π£·πáu, the protector of the world. There dwells. Puru·π£ottama, who manifests himself variously to his various devotees. To those in whom Bhakti has risen to the highest pitch and has become baunting passion be manifests himself as the sportive. Kr·π£·πáa. In a portion of the VyƒÅpi-Vaiku·πá·π≠ha there is the Goloka with V·πõndƒÅvana in which there are extensive trees, bowers of croopers, and the river YamunƒÅ. The highest Bhaktas are transferred to this V·πõndƒÅvana, and Kr·π£·πáa sports with them there.

are eternal. He, with his four arms or two arms, sports with his various devotees, or Bhaktas, in the extensive Vaiku·πá·π≠ha, which contains V·πõndƒÅvana with its large forests. Kr·π£·πáa is, therefore. the hight joy (ParamƒÅnanda). By his will, his Sattva portion overcomes the ƒÄnanda or joy portion, and, becoming Ak·π£ara, or unchangeable, he is the cause of all causes and creates the world. Then Ak·π£arabrahman is of two kinds: (1) that which is recognised by the devotees as the place of Puru·π£ottama, which has the attributes of the extensive Vaiku·πá·π≠ha and others; (2) to the enlightened it appears in the form of existence, intelligence and joy, infinite in time and space, self-manifesting and devoid of all qualities Therefore, in the form in which the enlightened see it, all the positive qualities are hidden or rendered imperceptible by the inscrutable power referred to above, and therefore they are not to be regarded as non-existing. When Brahman is spoken of as devoid of all qualities, what is meant is just this. There are thus. three forms of the Supreme Being, Puru·π£ottama and the two kinds of the Unchangeable here mentioned.

To explain the controlling of all by Puru·π£ottama, that form of his that dwells in the sun, the gods, the earth, etc., is called AntaryƒÅmin (the inward controller). It is this inward controller that becomes incarnate in the various forms usually mentioned. The celestial Sattva quatity of Kr·π£·πáa becomes Vi·π£·πáu, and in this form he becomes the protector of all. Similarly the qualities of Rajas and Tamas assume the forms of Brahmadeva and Siva for discharging the functions of creation and destruction.

Pu·π£·π≠i is the grace (Anugraha) of God which is to be inferred from its fruit or the results, which are ordinary, or of this world, and extraordinary, or of the next world. MahƒÅpu·π£·π≠i, or the highest grace, is that which removes great obstacles and conduces: to the attainment of God himself. Pu·π£·π≠i enables one to attain the four objects of life. Extraordinary, or special Pusti, conduces to Bhakti, which leads to the attainment of God. The Bhakti, or devotion generated by this special grace, is called Pu·π£·π≠ibhakti The frame of mind generated by this kind of devotion is the desire of the attainment of God to the exclusion of everything else.

This Pu·π£·π≠ibhakti is of four kinds: (1) PravƒÅha-Pu·π£·π≠ibbakti,

(2) MaryƒÅdƒÅ-Pu·π£·π≠ibhakti, (3) Pu·π£·π≠i-Pu·π£·π≠ibhakti, (4) ≈öuddha-Pu·π£·π≠ibhakti. The first is the path of those who, while engaged in a worldly life with its me and mine, which is compared to a stream (PravƒÅha), do acts calculated to bring about the attainment of God. The second is of those who, withdrawing their minds from worldly enjoyments, devote themselves to God by hearing discourses about him, singing his name, and such other processes. The third is of those who already enjoying God’s grace are made by another grace competent to acquire knowledge useful for adoration; and thus they come to know all about the ways of God. The followers of this path have to depend on their own efforts for the acquisition of knowledge referred to. The fourth is of those who through mere love devote themselves to the singing and praising of God as if it were a haunting passion. This Bhakti is generated by God himself and does not depend upon man’s will as the third, mentioned above, does. First a liking for Himself is generated by God in the mind of a man to whom his grace extends. Then a man sets about acquiring knowledge about God, and all this is called Premabhakti (love-adoration). Now the stages in the development of this are as follows: (1) love or liking (Preman), (2) attachment or addictedness (ƒÄsakti), (3) a haunting passion, which is the mature condition of the first two (Vyasana).

The haunting passion leads to attainment of the end, that is, the highest bliss. Those in whom Bhakti has attained to this pitch reject with scorn the four kinds of Mukti and choose the eternal service of Hari, as noticed in the section on the PƒÅ√±carƒÅtra system. By the haunting passion about Hari he is seen everywhere, and therefore everything becomes an object of love, and the devotee identifies himself with everything. Then the inner and the outer world is, for the devotee, full of Puru·π£ottama, or the highest soul.

The final fruit of this devotion is admission to the eternal sports of Kr·π£·πáa. The Bhaktas join in these sports, assuming the forms of cows, beasts, birds, trees, rivers, etc., and enjoy the company of Puru·π£ottama, which confers boundless joy. These eternal sports are like those which Kr·π£·πáa went through when he

became incarnate in Vraja and V·πõndƒÅvana. Some of the devoteer become, in the celestial VrndƒÅvana, Gopas and Gopƒ´s and join is the sports. The MaryƒÅdƒÅbhaktas attain Mukti called SƒÅyujya which consists in being one with Hari. The Pu·π£·π≠ibhaktas reject it with scorn and seek for participation in the sports of Hari.

¬ß 64. These are the doctrines of the school of Vallabha. will now proceed to give a short description of the practical modes of worship. Vallabha had a son named Vi·π≠·π≠hale≈õa, and they are spoken of respectively as ƒÄcƒÅrya and GosƒÅƒ´·πÅor GosvƒÅmin. The latter had seven sons of the names of Giridhara GovindarƒÅya, BƒÅlak·πõ·π£·πáa, GokulanƒÅtha, RaghunƒÅtha, YadunƒÅtha, and Ghana≈õyƒÅma. The Gurus of this sect ordinarily called MahƒÅrƒÅjas are descendants of these seven. Each Guru has a temple of his own, and there are no public places of worship. The devotee should visit the temple of his Guru at stated intervals, which are eight in number during the day. The mode of worship is as follows.

The conductor of the worship should rise early in the morning, utter the name of Bhagavat and rinse his mouth and drink a little of the washings of the feet [of Bhagavat], and, with his face to the north or the east, should utter the name of the ƒÄcƒÅrya and pray to him and make a bow. The same should be done to Vi·π≠·π≠hale≈õa and the names of his seven sons should be uttered, as well as of one’s own Guru, and then a bow should be made to K·πõ·π£·πáa after uttering the names Govardhana and others. Then the river YamunƒÅshould be remembered and bowed to, and six stanzas of a poem called Bhramaragƒ´tƒÅ should be repeated; and then the Gopƒ´s, or cowherdesses, should be adored.

After this the worshipper should answer the call of nature, wash his hands, feet and face, and then drink a portion of the washings of the feet of Kr·π£·πáa, and eat the residue of the betel leaves supposed to be eaten by Kr·π£·πáa. Then he should besmear his body with oil and bathe. After bathing he should drink in a little water, after repeating the name of NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa. Then he should make a perpendicular mark on his forehead with white earth, the mark of a lotus on the bosom and of a bamboo leaf on the arms, etc., twelve in all, to represent the twelve

forms of Vi·π£·πáu, Ke≈õava, NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, MƒÅdhava, etc. He should then print the forms of the various weapons of Vi·π£·πáu on his body, and then, saluting VallabhƒÅcƒÅrya, should adore Kr·π£·πáa with the Gopƒ´s. Heshould then open the door of the temple, and going into the sleeping apartments, bring out the wreaths of flowers and all other things used on the previous day, and then sweep and clean the apartments. He should then brush the throne and make all the arrangements necessary for the reception of Kr·π£·πáa awakened from sleep.

He should then approach the bed-room and sing a song calling upon Kr·π£·πáa to rise from sleep, to take the refreshments prepared for him and to go with his companions to the forest for grazing. the cows. Kr·π£·πáa should be brought out and placed on the throne. RƒÅdhƒÅshould be placed to his left hand, and then the worshipper should prostrate himself before her. The refreshments already prepared should then be placed before them, and they should be requested to eat them. Then the bed should be dusted and cleaned and then Kr·π£·πáa should be made to wash his mouth. Other refreshments should be then placed before the two. And at the end of all an ƒÄratƒ´, or waving of lamps, should be gone through with a song. VallabhƒÅcƒÅrya should then be saluted.

Then comes the bath of Kr·π£·πáa. After bathing saffron paint should be applied. Then he should be dressed and milk given to him. Afterwards by the churning of milk, froth should be prepared and offered to Kr·π£·πáa. He should be then told to wash his mouth. with water. Then betel leaves should be offered to him. Then a cradle should be adorned and Kr·π£·πáa should he told to get into. it, and then it should be rocked and toys should be got ready for the divine boy.

Afterwards the mid-day dinner should be prepared. A CaukƒÅ, or a small four-legged table, should be placed before him and viands of all kinds in cups should be put on the table. The lord should then be told to eat them. A little rice should be placed in a small plate and, mixed with ghee, five or seven mouthfuls. should be held before him. Then lamps should be waved about him. Subsequently all the other dishes should be offered. In this manner the ceremonies go on. A meal is again prepared

at night and Kr·π£·πáa is laid on the sleeping cot and made to sleep again.

Thus the order of the ceremonies is as follows: (1) the ringing of the bell; (2) the blowing of the conoh-shell, (3) awakening of the Lord (ThƒÅkurji) and offering morning refreshments, (4) waving of lamps, (5) bathing, (6) dressing, (7) Gopƒ´vallabha food, (8) leading the cows out for grazing, (9) the mid-day dinner, (10) waving of lamps; (11) after the last, the screen is drawn up and the God cannot be seen; this interval is called Anosara or Anavasara,-i. e., no time for seeing him,-(12) the finishing up, (13) the evening meal, (14) going to bed.

Besides the ordinary worship detailed above, the followers of this sect hold a number of feasts and festivals, some of which are in honour of VallabhƒÅcƒÅrya, his son and seven grandsons. The influence exercised by Vallabha and his successors over their adherents seems to have been immense, and this has come down to their descendants or existing Gurus of the sect also. This is kept up by the fact that the God cannot be worshipped independently in a public place of worship, but in the house and temple of the Guru or the Maharaja, which therefore has to be regularly visited by the devotees with offerings. The followers of this system consist principally of the trading classes of GujarƒÅt, RƒÅjputƒÅna and further to the north about Mathura. The principal doctrine which these latter are taught is that all their belongings should be dedicated to their Guru; and this doctrine is not seldom carried to an extreme.

Among the different kinds of Bhakti mentioned above there is only one which contemplates non-attachment to worldly objects. The highest Bhakti as well as the others are generated in the heart of man by the grace of God, and the first even ripens into a haunting passion. This grace of God one may enjoy even while engaged in a worldly life. The MaryƒÅdƒÅ-Pu·π£·π≠i, which is one of the four forms and requires the restraint of passions, does not conduce to the attainment of the highest bliss, which consists in joining in the eternal sports of Hari in the Goloka. The spirit of this system, therefore, sooms to be sportive enjoyments and it connot but be expected to influence the ordinary life of its

followers. Moral rigidity oulminating in indifference to worldly enjoyments and self-abnegation does not appear to be a characteristicof this school. VallabhƒÅcƒÅrya himself was a married man, and so were all his successors and so are all the Gurus of the seot, who are as much men of the world as their followers.

¬ß65. From the account we have given, it will be seen that the fourth element of Vai·π£·πáavism, that we have described in a preceding section, alone constitutes the religion of Vallabha. The sportive boy Kr·π£·πáa of the cow-settlement with all his pranks is the highest god of this school, and his mistress RƒÅdhƒÅ, who is mentioned only in the later books and dignified into his eternal consort, as will be mentioned further on, is the object of the deepest adoration. This sportive Kr·π£·πáa with his RƒÅdhƒÅ is transferred to a heaven which is in a region higher than the ordinary Vaiku·πá·π≠ha of NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa or Vi·π£·πáu, and is called Goloka. The highest aim of man’s life is to get to this place and join in the sports Thus the doings of Kr·π£·πáa in Gokula, and his relations. with the men and women as well as the inferior animals, trees, and even the river YamunƒÅ, constitute the basis of Vallabha’s system and also its goal when transferred to Goloka.

XXIII. Caitanya.

¬ß 66. About the same time as Vallabha, there flourished in Bengal another propagator of the religion of RƒÅdhƒÅ and Kr·π£·πáa , who is known by the name of Caitanya. The prominent distinction between the two appears to be, that while Vallabha and those who followed him developed the ceremonial side of the religion, Caitanya and his successors devoted themselves to the cultivation of the emotional side, Caitanya endeavoured to win the hearts of man, by instituting Kirtanas or the fervent singing of songs about the love of RƒÅdhƒÅ and Kr·π£·πáa and other devotional matters. The love of the cow-herd god and his mistress. had already become the subject of bewitching songs by Jayadeva in Sanskrit and by other poets in the Vernacular.

Caitanya also was a more courageous reformer in so far as he cried down the mechanical religious ceremonial of the prevalent Hinduism, and preached spiritual devotion and at the same time condemned the distinctions of onstes, and admitted all, including even Mahomedans, as his pupils.

¬ß 67. Caitanya’s original name was Bisambhar (Vi≈õva·πÅbhara) Mi≈õra, and his father’s name was JagannƒÅtha Mi≈õra and mother’s Sacƒ´Debƒ´. The father lived originally in Sylhet in Eastern Bengal, but had emigrated to Nadiya (Nabadvƒ´pa) before the birth of Bisambhar, his youngest son. The eldest son’s name was Bisvar≈´pa, who is called NityƒÅnanda in the history of Caitanya. These were the only two sons of JagannƒÅtha, and between these were eight daughters, who died young.

Caitanya was born on the full-moon day of PhƒÅlguna in the year 1407 of the ≈öaka era, corresponding to 1485 A. D. He was afterwards called Kr·π£·πáaCaitanya and was considered by his disciples an incarnation of Kr·π£·πáa himself. As such he is reported to have played pranks with the women of the village, which, however, cannot be considered as historically true. Caitanya is also known by the name of GaurƒÅ·πÖga, i. e., possessed of a fair and not a dark body, and Gauracandra, or a fair moon. When he was eighteen years of age, he married a wife of the name of Lachmƒ´Debƒ´and began to live the life of a householder, taking pupils and giving them secular instruction. Soon after he took. to a wandering life and visited many places in Eastern Bengal. Begging and singing were his occupation, and he is said to have. collected a great deal of money. During his peregrinations his wife died, and on his return home he married another. When he was about twenty-three years of age, he went to GayƒÅto make offerings to his manes and on his return he began the mission of his life. He condemned the ritualistic system of the BrƒÅhma·πáas and proached faith in Hari and the love of Him as well as singing His name as the only effectual ways to salvation. He also preached the doctrine of the brotherhood of men, denouncing the system of castes.

It is stated that the doctrine of faith and love had been preached before Caitanya by a person of the name AdvaitƒÅcƒÅrys, whose practice it was, after the performance of the usual Brahmanic rites, to go to the banks of the Ganges and call out for the appearance of God to substitute the doctrine of faith and love for

that of the performance of various rites. It is also said that this. ƒÄcƒÅrya was at first the instructor of Caitanya and afterwards. became his pupil. Whatever it may have been, the new doctrine was first publicly proclaimed to the exclusion of others. by K·πõ·π£·πáa Caitanya.He was assisted by his brother NityƒÅnanda, who was regarded as an incarnation of BalarƒÅma, the brother of the god K·πõ·π£·πáa.

Caitanya now began to hold meetings for the singing and glorification of the name of Hari. These were at first private. and held in the house of a pupil named Srƒ´bƒÅsa. The doings of these devotees met with scorn and ridicule, especially at the hands of the worshippers of KƒÅlƒ´, one of whom put red flowers. and goat’s blood on the steps of the door of the house in which the Vai·π£·πáva meetings were held. The fervour displayed at these Kƒ´rtanas, or singing of the name of Hari, gradually increased in intensity, until the loud singers, and principally Caitanya himself, swooned away and dropped senseless on the ground.

In the year 1510 Caitanya became a Sa·πÅnyƒÅsin, or an ascetic, and was initiated into the order by Ke≈õab BhƒÅratƒ´of Katva. After this he first went to Purƒ´to visit the shrine of JagannƒÅtha, and thence wandered about the country for six years preaching his new faith¬π. On one occasion he went to Benares, where he is reported to have held a disputation with PrakƒÅ≈õƒÅnanda,a teacher of the monistic VedƒÅnta of ≈öa·πÅkarƒÅcƒÅrya. Caitanya condemned ≈öa·πÅkara’s commentary on the VedƒÅntas≈´tra and said that it mystified the sense of the original. ≈öa·πÅkarƒÅcƒÅrya did not give the plain ordinary sense of the words of BƒÅdarƒÅya·πáa but forced his own views into them. The doctrine of development (Pari·πáƒÅmavƒÅda) was held by the author of the S≈´tras, while≈öa·πÅkarƒÅcƒÅrya rejects it and brings in his doctrine of illusion. (VivartavƒÅda). The former alone is true according to Caitanya. After these wanderings he returned to Purƒ´, where he spent the last eighteen years of his life, and died in ≈öaka1455, corresponding to 1533 A. D.

¬ß 68. Some of the doctrines attributed to Caitanya are as

___________________________________________________________________________

1.The above is no abstract of the account given by J. Beames in his paper published in Ind. Ant. Vol. II, pp. 1 ff.

follows. K·πõ·π£·πáa is the highest god and is so beautiful that he excites love for himself even in the heart of the God of love, and is enamoured of himself. His Parabrahma≈õakti (power) pervades the universe and assumes a corporeal form by his wondercreating power (MƒÅyƒÅ≈õakti), though he is the soul of all. He possesses a self-multiplying power (VilƒÅsa≈õakti) which is of two kinds. By one of these, in sporting with the cowherdesses, he bocame as many Kr·π£·πáas as were sufficient to give one to every two of them (PrƒÅbhavavilƒÅsa ). By the other self-multiplying power (VaibhavavilƒÅsa) he assumes the forms of the four Vy≈´has, or forms of VƒÅsudeva, Samkarsa·πáa, etc., VƒÅsudeva representing intelligence, SSa·πÅkar·π£a·πáa, consciousness, Pradyumna, the love, and Aniruddha, sprotiveness.

Here, it will be seen, the functions of the four Vy≈´has are changed, and the principle of love is attributed to Pradyumna, instead of that of the mind as in the older system, and that of sportiveness, instead of self-consciousness, which is transferred to Sa·πÅkar·π£a·πáa, is attributed to Aniruddha. This change is in consonance with a system of which love and sport form the distin guishing characteristics. All the usual incarnations spring from one or other of the Vy≈´has. According as the quality of Sattva, Rajas, or Tamas predominates, Kr·π£·πáa becomes Vi·π£·πáu, Brahmadeva, or ≈öiva, respectively.

The sports of Kr·π£·πáa go on always, as the rising and setting. of the sun. His eternal sports are carried on in the Goloka, Kr·π£·πáa has three powers: the internal which is intelligence, the external which generates appearances, and the differentiated which forms the Jƒ´va, or individual soul. His chief power is that which creates dilatation of the heart, or joy. This appears to be the power of love. When this love becomes settled in the heart of the devoteo, it constitutes MahƒÅbhƒÅva, or the best feeling. When love attains to the highest pitch, it constitutes itself into RƒÅdhƒÅ, who is the most loveable of all and full of all qualities. She was the object of the highest love of Kr·π£·πáa, and being idealised as love, some of the agreeable feelings of the heart are considered her ornaments. The sports of the cowherdesses were due to simple love (Preman), and this it was that Uddhava and other devotees sought to attain.

The Supreme Soul (ParamƒÅtman) is boundless and is full intelligence itself. The individual soul is an atom having nintelligence. They are necessarily connected together and this connection can never be destroyed. K·πõ·π£·πáa is the support (ƒÄ≈õraya) and Jƒ´va resta on him (ƒÄ≈õrita ). The relation between the two is identity as well as difference. Thus the VedƒÅntic theory of Caitanya’s system is the same as that of NimbƒÅrka. As the beet is distinct from the honey and hovers about it, and, when it drinks it, is full of it, i. e., is one with it, so the individual soul is at first distinct from the Supreme Soul, seeks the Supreme Soul consistently and continuously, and, when through love he is full of the Supreme Soul, he becomes unconscious of his individual. existence, and becomes, as it were, absorbed in him. Herein is. described the ecstatic condition in which the individual soul becomes one with God, though they are really distinct. K·πõ·π£·πáa is the lord of the power of delusion or ignorance (MƒÅyƒÅ), and Jƒ´va is the slave of it. When the latter cuts off its shackles, he dis- tinctly sees his own nature and his true relation to God. K·πõ·π£·πáa is to be approached and attained by Bhakti alone¬π.

¬ß 69. K·πõ·π£·πáa Caitanya, NityƒÅnanda and AdvaitƒÅnanda are called the three Prabhus, or masters of the sect. The descendants. of NityƒÅnanda live at Nadiya, and those of Advaita at ≈öƒÅntipur. They are the spiritual heads of the sect. NityƒÅnanda was appointed by Caitanya himself as the superior of the church. His female descendants live at BƒÅlegor, and male ones at Khordunear Barrackpur. There are temples belonging to Caitanya’s followers at MƒÅthurƒÅ, V·πõndƒÅvana, and three principal ones in Bengal one at Nadiya dedicated to Caitanya, the other at AmbikƒÅ, to NityƒÅnanda, and the third at Agradvipa, to GopinƒÅtha. There is a shrine dedicated to Caitanya in the vicinity of DhƒÅkƒÅdak·π£i·πáa in Northern Sylhet, where his father originally lived. It is visited by pilgrims from all parts of the district and even from Bengal. At Khetur, in the Raja·π£ƒÅhi district, a temple is erected in his honour, where a religious fair is held in the month of October, which is attended by about 25,000 persons.

___________________________________________________________________________

1.See GaurƒÅ·πÖgatattvasaba GaurƒÅ·πÖgaaarita by Prasanna KumƒÅra VidyƒÅratna, printed at Calcutta.

The sectarian marks worn by the followers of Caitanya ara two white perpendicular lines on the forehead joined together at the bridge of the nose and a line continued up to the tip of the nose. They also use necklaces of three strings of Tulast berds and a rosary of the same, as a help in the muttering of Hari’s The worship of Gurus, or spiritual heads, as gods characterises this system. Most of Advaita’s followers observe caste distinctions, but a minority consists of BairƒÅgis, or recluses In one branch of the sect there are monks as well as nuns. They live in the same convent. And there is only And there is only a platonic relation between them.

A person of the name of RƒÅm Saram PƒÅl of the Sadgopa caste founded about two hundred years ago a branch of the sect called KartƒÅbhƒÅjas, or worshippers of the KartƒÅ, or headman. It admits of recruits from all castes and observes no distinction. The founder, also called KartƒÅ BƒÅbƒÅ, died at Gho·π£apur, and his votaries assemble periodically to do honour to him. The spiritual teachers of Caitanya’s sect, whether male or female, are celibates.

The three Prabhus, or masters, did not leave any compositions. But Caitanya’s pupils, especially R≈´pa and SanƒÅtana, wrote s great deal. A work by the latter entitled RasƒÅm·πõtasindhu contains an analysis of the feeling of love, or Bhakti, explaining the states of mind which lead to it and its various forms. A considerable body of literature has grown up round this system of religion.

XXIV. Debasement of Vai·π£·πáavism.

  1. The worship of RƒÅdhƒÅ, more prominently even than that of K·πõ·π£·πáa, has given rise to a sect, the members of which assume the garb of women with all their ordinary manners and affect to be subject even to their monthly sickness. Their appearance and acts are so disgusting that they do not show themselves very much in public, and their number is small. Their goal is the realisation of the position of female companions and attendants of RƒÅdhƒÅ; and hence probably they assume the name of Sakhƒ´bhƒÅvas (literally, the condition of companions). They deserve notice here only to show that, when the female element is idolised and made the object of special worship, such disgusting corruptions must ensue. The worship of DurgƒÅin the form of Tripurasundarƒ´ has led to the same result.

Though the Vai·π£·πáava systems of NimbƒÅrka, Vallabha and Caitanys are based on the fourth element of Vai·π£·πáavism that wer have pointed out in a precoding Section, still that element has undergone an important modification. Before, K·πõ·π£·πáa was a person who had amorous dalliances with the Gopƒ´s generally. But now K·πõ·π£·πáa had a definite consort in RƒÅdhƒÅ, who had a large number of female companions, who were probably the original Gopƒ´s. She is indissolubly united with him in the creed of worshippers.

This RƒÅdhƒÅ is not mentioned by name in the Hariva·πÅ≈õa, Vi·π£·πáu-PurƒÅ·πáa and the BhƒÅgavata. In the last, however, among the cowherdesses engaged in K·πõ·π£·πáa’s amorous sports in V·πõndƒÅvana on an autumnal moonlight night, there was one with whom the youthful god carred on his dalliance further, after he had become invisible to the rest. This woman became proud of K·πõ·π£·πáa’s special attachment for her, whereupon the god disappeared from her also. Here was contained a suggestion which probably led to the creation of RƒÅdhƒÅin later times. In the apocryphal NƒÅradapa√±caƒÅ√°tra-Sa·πÅhitƒÅ, as mentioned before64, the one single lord is represented to have become two, one a woman and the other a man, who was he himself. He then bad amorous intercourse with her. The woman was RƒÅdhƒÅ. In the Brahmavaivarta-PurƒÅ·πáa she has been made to spring from the primordial body of K·πõ·π£·πáa forming its left. side, and is eternally associated with him in his amorous sports in this world as well as the world of cows (Goloka). The name of Rukmi·πái occurs in the ordinary form of K·πõ·π£·πáaism, but in the systems named above it is entirely absent. The introduction of RƒÅdhƒÅ’s name, and her elevation to a higher position even than K·πõ·π£·πáa’s, operated as a degrading element in Vai·π£·πáavism, not only because she was a woman, but also because she was originally a mistress of the cowhard god, and her amorous dealing were of an overt character.

In the RƒÅma cultus, Sƒ´tƒÅis a dutiful and loving wife, and is

benignant towards the devotees of her husband. She holds a postition entirely subordinate to RƒÅma, while RƒÅdhƒÅis often preferredto K·πõ·π£·πáa. There is no amorous suggestion in her story as in that of RƒÅdhƒÅ, and consequently the moral influence of RƒÅmaism is more wholesome. Kabƒ´r does not, so far as I know, mention the name of Sƒ´tƒÅat all. He was a strict monotheist, and his RƒÅma was the supreme lord (SƒÅheb) only. Those other teachers who followed him maintain the same attitude, so that the RƒÅma cultus represents a saner and purer form of Hindu religious thought than RƒÅdhƒÅk·πõ·π£naism.

XXV. NƒÅmadev and TukƒÅrƒÅm.

¬ß 71. The popular Vai·π£·πáavism of the Maratha country centres itself round the shrine of Vi·π≠hobƒÅat Pa·πá·∏çharpur, which is a city situated on the banks of the Bhƒ´mƒÅor Bhƒ´marathƒ´. The full name of the god is Vi·π≠·π≠hal, which is not a Sanskrit name, but the etymology is clear enough. It is stated that the corruption of the Sanskrit name Vi·π£·πáu in the Canarese language is Vi·π≠·π≠hu, and this looks probable, since K·πõ·π£·πáa is corrupted into Ku·π£·π≠a in the Goanese dialect and Ku·π≠·π≠a, Ki·π≠·π≠i, or K·πõ·π£·π≠a in the Canarese; and we have seen that Vi·π£·πáu, the first portion of the name of the. Hoysala prince Vi·π£·πáuvardhana, was corrupted to Vi·π≠·π≠i or Bi·π≠·π≠i65. The terminations bƒÅand la are appended to the name Vi·π£·πáu or Vi·π≠·π≠u to indicate additional sense such as tenderness or reverence. When the shrine was established, we have not the means of determining, but we have clear evidence of its being in existence in the middle of the thirteenth century. In a copperplate Inscription of the reign of K·πõ·π£·πáa of the YƒÅdava dynasty of Devagiri, it is stated that Mallise·π≠·π≠i, a general and viceroy of the king, made, while engaged on a military expedition, the grant of a village in the Belgaum district at Pau·πá·∏çarƒ´kak≈õetra, a holy place situated on the Bhƒ´marathƒ´, in the vicinity of the god Vi·π£·πáu, in the year. 1171 of the ≈öaka era corresponding to 1249 A.D66. Now if the Pau·πá·∏çarƒ´kak≈õetra was situated on the Bhƒ´marathƒ´ or Bhƒ´mƒÅriver, it is certainly not unreasonable to suppose that is was the same as Pa·πá·∏çharƒ´which is the alternative name of Pa·πá·∏çharpur; and

the god in whose vicinity the grant was made must therefore. have been Vi·π≠·π≠hal , or Vi·π≠hobƒÅ, here mentioned by his Sanskrit name and not the popular Canarose corruption. In another Inscription on stone, existing at Pa·πá·∏çharpur itself and dated 1192 ≈öaka, which corresponds to 1270 A. D., BhƒÅnu the son of Ke≈õava, is represented to have performed an AptoryƒÅma sacrifice in PƒÅ·πá·∏çura·πÖgapura, in consequence of which crowds of people, and Vi·π≠·π≠hal a together with the gods, were greatly gratified¬π.Here we have another name of Pa·πá·∏çharpur, and that was probably given to it because it was the city of PƒÅ·πá·∏çura·πÖga.

PƒÅ·πá·∏çara·πÖga, or PƒÅ·πá·∏çura·πÖga, is according to Hemacandra a name of Rudra or ≈öiva67. And we have a temple of ≈öiva at Pa·πá·∏çharpur, and pilgrims have to visit it first before going to that of Vi·π≠hoba or Vi·π≠·π≠hal PƒÅ·πá·∏çura·πÖga, which is the same as the PƒÅ·πá·∏çura·πÖga of Hemcandra, is however in modern times a popular name for Vi·π≠·π≠hal .Whether then the city was called. PƒÅ·πá·∏çura·πÖgapura on account of it containing the temple of Vi·π£·πáu or Vi·π≠·π≠hal , or that of ≈öiva is doubtful. But from the wording of the Inscription, in which Vi·π≠·π≠hal a and PƒÅ·πá·∏çura·πÖgapuraare mentioned independently, it would appear as if Vi·π≠·π≠hal had no connection with the name, and it was given to the city on account of its containing a ≈öiva temple. But when Vi·π≠hoba’s importance increased in later times so vastly that ≈öiva was thrown entirely into the shade, Panduranga became identical with Vi·π≠·π≠hala.

The name Pau·πá·∏çarƒ´kaoccuring in the first Inscription seems to owe its origin to a man named Pau·πá·∏çarƒ´ka, the popular legend about whom is to the following effect. The region about Pa·πá·∏çharpur was, it is said, a forest of the name of Di·πá·∏çiravana. There lived a man of the name of Pau·πá·∏çalƒ´ka, who spent all his time in the service of his aged parents, and the god K·πõ·π£·πáawas pleased. with his devotion to them. In the meantime, while K·πõ·π£·πáa Was living at DvƒÅraka, he remembered RƒÅdhƒÅ, who was the object of

___________________________________________________________________________

1.Early History of the Deccan, Second Ed., p. 115, in which, however, Ke≈õava, the father of BhƒÅnu, is by mistake represented as the sacrificer. [= Volume III of this Edition, page 161.‚Äî N. B. U. ]

his fervent love while he was in Gokula. RƒÅdhƒÅ, who had, after K·πõ·π£·πáa’s leaving Gokula, betaken herself to a residence in the HimƒÅlaya mountain, for the practice of austerities in consequenos of her separation from K·πõ·π£·πáa, came to know of this through her innate cognitive power, and came at once to DvƒÅrakƒÅand sat on the lap of K·πõ·π£·πáa. Some time after Rukmi·πáƒ´, the wedded wife of K·πõ·π£·πáa, came to the place, and RƒÅdhƒÅ did not rise up to honour her, as every other woman in similar circumstances did at her approach. K·πõ·π£·πáa even did not take RƒÅdhƒÅ to task for this dishonour of Rukmƒ´·πáƒ´, and Rukmƒ´·πáƒ´ got offended, left DvƒÅraka and wandered about, until she came to Di·πá·∏çiravana, and rested there on the site of the modern Pa·πá·∏çharpur. K·πõ·π£·πáa was filled with sorrow at the disappearance of Rukmƒ´·πáƒ´ and went about in quest of her to all parts of the country, until he came to the place where Rukmi·πáƒ´ was lying. After some explanations she was reconciled to him, and K·πõ·π£·πáa then went to the hut of Pu·πá·∏çalƒ´ka to reward him for his devotion to his parents by personal manifestation. Pu·πá·∏çalƒ´ka being engaged in attending to the wants of his father and mother, was not able to greet him at, once, and threw back a brick (MarƒÅ·π≠hƒ´: vƒ´t) and asked him to stand on it and wait for him until he finished what he was engaged on. K·πõ·π£·πáa stood on the brick and there he was joined by Rukmi·πáƒ´, and thus the shrine of Pa·πá·∏çharpur grew up.

Pu·πá·∏çalƒ´ka has been referred to as the originator of the Vi·π≠·π≠hal cult of devotion both by NƒÅmadev and TukƒÅrƒÅm, and that is the popular belief. The legend points to this fact, and we may therefore take him to be the person who promulgated the cult of Vi·π≠·π≠hobƒÅ, or Vi·π£·πáu, in the Maratha country. He established himself at Pa·πá·∏çharpur and it must be on that account that the city is called the holy place (K·π£etra) Pau·πá·∏çarƒ´ka, which I identify with the modern name Pa·πá·∏çharƒ´in the first Inscription. The Pa·πá·∏çura·πÖgapura of the second may have become the later Pu·πá·∏çhrapur.

There is another historical significance in this legend, and that appears to be this. At first, no woman was connected with the K·πõ·π£·πáa worship, as we have seen in the case of the pure PƒÅ√±csrƒÅtra or BhƒÅgavata system. Then came RƒÅdhƒÅ to be associated with him in the North, as we have seen, in the systems of

NimbƒÅrka, Vallabha and Caitanya, while Rukmi·πáƒ´, the lawful wife, was united with him in the Maratha country. The K·πõ·π£·πáa of Pu·πá·∏çhrapur is almost exclusively known by the name of Vi·π≠·π≠hala or Vi·π≠hobƒÅ, and Rukmi·πáƒ´ by the name of RakhamƒÅƒ´or RakhamƒÅbƒÅƒ´. In the religious literature of the country, Vi·π≠·π≠hala, or K·πõ·π£·πáa, is almost exclusively spoken of as Rukmi·πáƒ´pati or Rukmi·πáƒ´vara, the lord or husband of Rukmi·πáƒ´, and not as RƒÅdhƒÅ- vallabha, or the lover of RƒÅdhƒÅ. Thus the Vai·π£·πáavism of the Maratha country, associated as it is with these two names, is more sober and purer than that of the three systems named above. RƒÅhƒ´the Marathi form of RƒÅdhikƒÅ, is not unknown, but an insignificant place is assigned to her. The sports of K·πõ·π£·πáa in Gokula are also represented occasionally in the mode of worship, but very little importance is attached to them.

This Vai·π£·πáavism of the MarƒÅ·π≠ha country found a fertile soil among the lower classes, though it has had followers among BrƒÅhma·πáas and other higher classes also. Like the Vai·π£·πáavism of the disciples of RƒÅmƒÅnanda, it had no learned or Sanskrit-knowing promulgators, but its prophets were S≈´dras, who, however, had the true religious instinct and possessed a clear spiritual insight. Such were NƒÅmdev and TukƒÅrƒÅm.

¬ß 72. The family of NƒÅmdev originally lived at the village called Narasi VƒÅmanƒ´, situated near Karhad in the Satara District, and now known by the name of Bhayƒì-Narsingpur or Kole·πÅ-Narsingpur. It belonged to the tailor caste and followed that occupation or of dealers in cloth. The name of NƒÅmdev’s father was DƒÅmƒÅ≈öet, and that of his mother, Go·πáƒÅbƒÅƒ´. They migrated to Pau·πá·∏çhrapur, where NƒÅmdev was born in the ≈öaka year 1192, corresponding to 1270 A. D. NƒÅmdev received ordinary education, but showed little capacity for the usual occupation of his family. He became a devoted worshipper of Vi·π≠hobƒÅand had for his Guru a person named VisobƒÅKhecar, who appears to have been a non-idolater. For NƒÅmdevsays of him that he gave him the following instruction :‚Äî

No.191¬π. “A stone-god never speaks. What possibility then of his removing the disease of mundane existence? A stone.

___________________________________________________________________________

1.Tukaram Tatya’s edition, published in Bombay in 1894,

image is regarded as God, but the true God is wholly different. If a stone-god fulfils desires, how is it he breaks when struck. Those who adore a god made of stone, lose everything through their folly. Those who say and hear that a god of stone speaks. to his devotees, are both of them fools. Those who extol the greatness of such a god and call themselves his devotees, should be regarded as worthless persons and their words should not be heard by the ear. If by chiselling a stone, a god is made of it. and is worshipped with care for many years, will he be of use at any time? Do reflect on this well in your mind. Whether a holy place is small or large, there is no god but stone or water. In the village of DvƒÅdasƒ´(BƒÅrsƒ´)¬π instruction was given that. there is no place which is devoid of God. That God was shown to NƒÅma in his heart, and thus Khecar conferred a blessing on him.”

The omnipresence of God and his being neither stock nor stone are well brought out here. The omnipotence of God. NƒÅmdev brings out in the following :‚Äî

No. 151. " The Veda has to speak by thy might and the sun. has to move round; such is the might of thee, the lord of the universe ! Knowing this essential truth, I have surrendered myself to thee. By thy might it is that the clouds have to pour down rain, mountains to rest firm and the wind to blow. Nothing. moves at all (without thee). Oh lord PƒÅ·πá·∏çurang ! thou art the cause of all.‚Äù

It will thus be seen that, though NƒÅmdev worshipped the idol at Pa·πá·∏çharpur, he had full knowledge of the true nature of God, as given in treatises like the Upan·π£iads; and this God it was that he tried to attain.

No.1029. “Your mind is full of vices. What is the use of the pilgrimages you make? What is the use of austere practices, if there is no repentance? The sins resulting from a mental act cannot be effaced by the highest holy place (literally: the father of the holy places). The essence of the matter is very simple : Sin is effaced by repentance”, so says NƒÅmƒÅ.

___________________________________________________________________________

1.BƒÅrsƒ´is a town near Pa·πá·∏çharpur.

No. 887. " Vows, fasts, and austerities are not at all necessary; nor it is necessary for you to go on a pilgrimage. Be you. watchful in your hearts and always sing the name of Hari. It is not necessary to give up eating food or drinking water; fix your mind on the feet of Hari. Yoga or sacrificial ceremonies or giving up objects of desire is not wanted. Realise a fondness for the feet of Hari. Neither is it necessary for you to contemplate (lit. dwell in ) the one without attributes. Hold fast to the lovel of the name of Hari; says NƒÅmƒÅ, be firm in singing the name. and then Pa·πá·∏çurang will render himself manifest to you.”

In these two songs NƒÅmdev urges upon his hearers the total. inefficacy of the usual modes of purification and of the attainment of God, such as pilgrimages, vaws, fasts, or meditation on the absolute, and sacrifices.

No. 245. " Recognise him alone to be a righteous man, who sees VƒÅsudeva in all objects, eradicting all pride or egoism. The rest are entangled in the shackles of delusion. To him all wealth is like earth and the nine species of gems are mere stones. The two, desire and anger, he has thrown out and cherishes in his heart (lit. house) quietude and forgiveness. He constantly repeats the name of Govinda, not desisting even for a moment.”

No.1004. " Firmly grasp the truth which is NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa. Purity of conduct should not be abandoned; one should not be afraid of the censure of people and thus accomplish one’s own purpose. Surrender yourself to your loving friend (God), giving up all ostentation and pride. The censure of people should be regarded as praise and their praise not heeded. One should entertain no longing for being respected and honoured, but should nourish in oneself a liking for devotion. This should be rendered firm in the mind and the name of God should not be neglected even for a moment.”

In these songs NƒÅmdev describes the holy condition of him who is a devotee of VƒÅsudeva and sees him everywhere, and preaches self-surrender to him, regardless of the criticism of the world.

This is a short specimen of the teachings of NƒÅmdev. Purity of heart, humility, self-surrender, forgiveness, and the love of God

form the sum and substance of it. NƒÅmdev wrote songs in Hindƒ´also and some of these are incorporated in the Grantha-SƒÅheb, or the Bible of the Sikhs. I will here translate two of these68:‚Äî

No. 2352. “He is one, [but] fills and encompassess many; wherever you look yon find him there. There is scarcely one who understands him, all being deluded by the variegated picture. drawn by MƒÅyƒÅ(delusive power). Everything is Govinds, everything is Govinda, there is nothing without Govinda. Just as there is one thread and on it are woven breadthwise and length- wise hundreds of thousands of beads, so is everything woven in the lord. The waves, the foam, and the bubbles of water are not different from water. All this extent of the universe is the sport. of Parabrahma, and when we think of it, is not different from it. Illusive phantoms and the objects seen in dreams are regarded as real. When by the instruction of my Guru my mind awoke, I accepted the truth. Reflecting in your mind, see this all to be the creation of Hari, says NƒÅmdev; in the inside of every indivi- dual thing there is one Murari alone without any interstice.”

No.2353. " The pitcher is filled and the water brought to bathe the god. There were forty-two hundreds of thousands of animals in it; there was already Vi·π≠·π≠hal in them. Whom shall I bathe? Wherever we go there is Vi·π≠·π≠hal and he over sports in joy. Flowers have been brought and wreaths woven of them for worshipping God. First of all the flowers were smelt by the bees, there was Vi·π≠·π≠hal there; what shall I do? Milk has been brought and cooked for the offering of Khƒ´r¬≤ to God. The milk was first tasted by the calf, in it was Vi·π≠·π≠hal, what shall I do? Here is Vi·π≠·π≠hal, there is Vi·π≠·π≠hal, there is no world without Vi·π≠·π≠hal. This place and that, thou hast filled. Thou hast filled the whole world, says NƒÅmƒÅhumbly"¬≥.

In these hymns God’s omnipresence is described by NƒÅmdev.

___________________________________________________________________________

2. A preparation of milk and rice mixed with sugar.

3.These two hymns have been translated by Macauliffe in Vol. VI, pp. 41-42 of the Sikh Religion. The readings in the Bombay Ed. have been compared with those in the Grantha-SƒÅheb, pp. 427-28 of the Lucknow Ed. of 1893,

¬ß 73. The date assigned to the birth of NƒÅmdev is, as we have seen, ≈öaka 1192, that is 1270 A. D. This makes him a contemporary of J√±ƒÅndev, the author of the J√±ƒÅndevƒ´, which was finished. in 1290 A. D. But the MarƒÅ·π≠hƒ´of the latter work is decidedly archaic, while that of NƒÅmdev’s writings has a considerably more. modern appearance. NƒÅmdev’s Hindi too looks more modern. than that of the thirteenth century, when the poet Canda flourished¬π. What this is due to, it is difficult to say. But it appears probable that the traditional date of NƒÅmdev’s birth-≈öaka 1192-has been pushed backwards and that he is represented as a contemporary of J√±ƒÅndev. We have seen in a former section69that NabhƒÅji in naming the successors of Vi·π£·πáusvƒÅmin places. Jiandey first and NƒÅmdev afterwards. If we are to judge from NƒÅmdev’s MarƒÅ·π≠hƒ´ and Hindƒ´, his date must be put later by about. a century.

Some conception, however, of the time when NƒÅmdev flourished may be formed from the strong and definite sentiments as to the futility of idol-worship, which his instructor is represented (in one of the hymns translated) to have expressed. Khecar, or Visoba Khecar as he is usually called, appears to have been an uncom- promising opponent of idol-worship from the accounts given of him in the existing biographies. All previous writers, including RƒÅmƒÅnuja, as well as a great many that followed, excused idol- worship in some way or other. If then Khecar’s attitude towards it was definitely hostile, he and his pupil NƒÅmdev must have flourished when the Mahomedan influence had for the first time become very powerful. The Mahomedans established themselves in the Deccan in the beginning of the fourteenth century of the Christian era, and their hatred of idol-worship must have taken about a hundred years to make its way into the understanding of religious Hindus.

But a more direct evidence for the fact that NƒÅmdev flourished after the Mahomedans had established themselves in the MarƒÅ·π≠hƒÅcountry is afforded by his mention in a song (No. 364) of thedestruction of idols by the Turaks, i.e.,Turks. The Mahomedang were often called Turaks in early times by the Hindus. NƒÅmdev, therefore, probably lived about or after the end of the fourteenth century.

___________________________________________________________________________

1.See my Report on the Search for Sanskrit MSS, 1887-1891, page LXXX. [= Volume II of this Edition, p. 343.-N. B. U.]

It will thus be seen that the date of NƒÅmdev’s birth given with such details is quite wrong. Unfortunately the historical spirit has by no means been the distinguishing feature of the intellectual life of us Indians, and we often confuse different persons together, and attribute to one what belongs to another. Some such confusion must have taken place in the present case.

TukƒÅrƒÅm

¬ß 74. TukƒÅrƒÅm was born and lived at a village called Dehu, which is about fourteen miles to the north-east of Poona. The name. of the family to which he belonged was More. It was a family of the MarƒÅ·π≠hƒÅcaste, which caste may have sprung from the old order of K·π£atriyas, but is considered to belong to the ≈ö≈´dra order. Nothing specific is known about the date of his birth, but there is no reason for doubting the truth of the date traditionally assigned to his death, which is ≈öaka 1571, corresponding to 1649 A. D. Hist biographer, Mahƒ´pati, represents him to have become a bankrupt at the end of the first half of his life, when he was twenty-one years of age. From that it is inferred that he lived for 42 years, and he is thus understood to have been born in 1607-8 A. D.

Seven of TukƒÅrƒÅm’s ancestors were devoted worshippers of the god Vi·π≠hobƒÅ. Of these Vi≈õa·πÅbhara was the first who made regular pilgrimages to Pa·πá·∏çharpur, but after some years he constructed a temple in his own village, and placing the idols of Vi·π≠hoba and RukmƒÅƒ´in it, dedicated it to their worship. TukƒÅrƒÅm’s father’s name was Bolhojƒ´and he followed the occupation of a potty trader. When he became old, he proposed to entrust the affairs of his family and his business to SƒÅvjƒ´, his eldest son. But SƒÅvjƒ´was a man for whom a worldly life had no interest, and he declined to undertake the business. It was, therefore, made over to TukƒÅrƒÅm, who was then thirteen years of age. TukƒÅrƒÅm managed the affairs somehow, till he became seventeen years old, when his father died. He naturally felt desolate when this occurred. and being a man of simplicity and liable to be imposed upo gby designing persons, his affairs got into disorder and he incurred loss in his trade.

TukƒÅrƒÅm was at first married to a wife who was sickly, and some time later he married another of the name of JijƒÅbƒÅƒ´or ƒÄvalƒ´, the daughter of a well-to-do trader in Poona. When hist affairs got into confusion, ƒÄvalƒ´ procured a loan for him and set him up again. A short time after, he made a profit in his new trade, and, while coming back from the place to which he had gone for the sale of his goods, he met a man whe was being carried about by the agents of his creditor, and who was crying out for assistance to relieve him from his debt and the impending imprisonment. To this man TukƒÅrƒÅm gave all that he possessed-the capital, and the profit that he had made. He returned to Dehu. empty-handed, and soon after there was a famine, which made him a thorough bankrupt, and his first wife died of hunger.

TukƒÅrƒÅm then made up his mind to renounce his business, but his younger brother KƒÅnhyƒÅ protested against it. Then,sitting on the banks of the IndrƒÅya·πáƒ´, he told his brother to bring all the documents, deeds and bonds relating to their business, divided them. into two parts, gave one to KƒÅnhyƒÅ, and told him to live separately from him, and his own share he threw into the river.

Henceforward he devoted himself to the contemplation of God and singing his praises, spending the day on the top of a hill near Dehu and the night at the temple of Vi·π≠hobain the village.

He read the MarƒÅ·π≠hƒ´works on religious subjects of the saints and sages who had flourished before him. The idea of giving expression to his thoughts and feelings by composing songs in MarƒÅ·π≠hƒ´ soon arose in his mind. The metre used by him was that which is known by the name of Abhang, the measure of which is by no means strict or regular, but which is characterised by the use of rhyming words at specific intervals. A single-minded piety and the desire to be of service to all, even by executing their errands, became settled points in his character. Family matters. had to be attended to by his wife, ƒÄvalƒ´, who often found herself in great straits.

TukƒÅrƒÅm’s chief occupation was the performance of Kƒ´rtans, which consist of religious discourses interspersed with the singing of songs. These discourses gradually became very attractive and drew in crowds of people. The songs he sung at

these had been often prepared by himself, and some were composed. by him extempore while engaged in the discourse.

TukƒÅrƒÅm’s fame spread about not only in his village, but in the surrounding country, and it evoked jealousy, especially in. the minds of BrƒÅhma·πáas, who had set themselves up as religious teachers; and he was subjected to persecution. He, however, maintained an evenness of temper throughout, though there were. struggles in the mind. His fame reached the ears of the rising prince, ≈öivƒÅjƒ´, the future king of the MarƒÅ·π≠hƒÅ. He was eager to hear TukƒÅrƒÅm’s Kƒ´rtans, and on one occasion invited him into his presence, sending him messengers with torches, umbrella and horses, as emblems of high honour. TukƒÅrƒÅm, however, declined to go and sent him a letter written in his usual metre. On another occasion ≈öivƒÅjƒ´ attended his Kƒ´rtan at Lohagaon, about six miles from Poona, and placed before him a plate full of golden coins. TukƒÅrƒÅm, of course, declined to receive them, and they were distributed among the BrƒÅhma·πáas there. When his end approached, he is reported to have gathered together a large body of his followers and to have proceeded to the banks of the IndrƒÅya·πáƒ´, all singing loudly and enthusiastically the praises of God and fully absorbed in it. When they approached the river, TukƒÅrƒÅm suddenly disappeared. No further account of his death has beenhanded down.

¬ß 75. It has been already stated that TukƒÅrƒÅm had acquired a great facility in composing Abha·πÖgs. He spoke in Abha·πÖgs and wrote in Abha·πÖgs. Some of these only could be written and were written, and others were neglected by him or his immediate followers, but retained in the memory of others. The collections, therefore, of his pieces cannot be expected to be of the same size. There are two such printed in Bombay, one containing 4621 pieces and the other 8441. This latter collection is uncritically made and oftentimes one same piece is given a second time with the opening lines omitted. Still, this is a larger collection and contains Abha·πÖgs which are not to be found in the first collection, but are quite in the style of TukƒÅrƒÅm with the usual fervent devotion and purity of thought.

We will now give a few specimens:‚Äî

First collection, No. 2869. " When the auspicious juncture of Si·πÅhastha¬π comes, it brings fortune only to barbers and priests. There are crores of sins in the heart, but externally a man shaves the hair on the head and the beard. What has been shaved off, has disappeared. Tell me what else has changed. The vicious habits are not changed, which might be regarded as a mark of the destruction of sins: says TukƒÅ, without devotion and faith everything else is useless trouble.”

Second collection, No. 4733. " What hast thou done by going to a holy river? Thou hast only outwardly washed thy skin. In what way has the interior been purified? By this thou hast only added a feather to thy cap (lit. prepared a decoration for thyself). Even if the bitter V·πõndƒÅvana fruit is coated with sugar, the settled quality of the interior (bitterness) is in no way lessered. If peace, forgiveness, and sympathy do not come in, why should you take any trouble?”

First coll., No. 90 (1-2). “Sesamum seeds and grains of rice thou hast burnt by throwing into fire, but desire and anger are as mischievous as before. Why hast thou taken trouble in vain, giving up the adoration of PƒÅ·πá·∏çurang?”

Here TukƒÅrƒÅm condemns religious practices which concern the body only, and mechanical rites, such as giving oblations, and enforces the necessity of striving for the attainment of spiritual virtue and of the adoration of God.

In No. 2383 ( first coll.,) TukƒÅrƒÅm condemns the worship of goddesses, JƒÅkhƒÅƒ´JokhƒÅƒ´, of gods like Bhairava and even Ga·πáapati, and of ghosts and goblins, and earnestly recommends the adoration of him whose consort is RakhamƒÅƒ´. TukƒÅrƒÅm was thus & devotee only of Vi·π≠hobƒÅof PƒÅ·πá·∏çharpur and a monotheist in this sense. Though he worshipped the idol at the place, still he had always before his mind’s eye the great Lord of the universe, as the following will show:‚Äî

First coll., No. 4361. “Thy greatness is unsearchable. Even the Vedas became silent and the power of the mind becomes stunted.

___________________________________________________________________________

1.When Jupiter is in the sign of Lon, the period is considered favourable for the washing away of sins, nad Hindus go to holy places, such as Nasik, shave their heads and mustaches and bathe in the river.

What possibility is there of my mental power reaching Him, whose light it is that the sun and the moon display? Even the thousand-tongued (the great serpent) is unable to expound thy greatness. How then shall I be able to do so? Says TukƒÅ, we are thy children, thou art our mother place us under the shadow (protection) of thy grace.’

Fist coll., No. 4419. " All the world says that there is not a space so minute as a sesamum seed without thee. The old ·πö·π£is, sages, poious and holy men said that thou art in the heart of all these things……..Thou hast filled up numberless universes and also a residue still remained. But to me thou hast become. inaccessible.”

First Coll., No. 1870. " God is ours, certainly ours, and is the soul of all souls. God is near to us, certainly near, outside and inside. God is benignant, certainly benignant, and fulfils every longing even of a longing nature. God protects us, certainly protects us, and subdues strife and death. God is merciful, certainly merciful, and protects TukƒÅ.”

This great God is to be attained only by devoted love and by no other means:‚Äî

First coll., No. 810. " This thy nature is beyond the grasp of the mind or of words; and therefore I have made devoted love a measure. I measure the Endless by the measure of love; he is not to be truly measured by any other means. Thou art not to be found by processes of concentration (Yoga), sacrificial rites, practice of austerities, and any bodily exertions, nor by knowledge. Oh Ke≈õave, accept the service which we render to thee in the simplicity of our hearts."

There is peace and pure indescribable bliss in seeing God:‚Äî

Second coll., No. 1411.
