The real syllables in these casesare therefore **‡§Ö‡§Ç, ‡§â‡§Ç, ‡§á‡§Ç,**and ‡§Ö‡§Ç; and this is confirmed by the factthat the remnants of these Apabhra·πÅ≈õa terminations existing insome of the modern vernaculars are destitute of this ‡§π‡•ç and aremere vowel-terminations, as will be seen in a subsequent lecture. Thus, then, ‡§π‡•á may be considered as the aspirated form of the ‡§è ofthe Prakrit feminine ablative, and ‡§π‡•Å of the ‡§â of the masculine ablative¬π. The operation of the law of false analogies is very wide.The abl. pl. ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç, as in ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç, may with Lassen be traced to ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã, the ‡§Æ‡•ç being changed to ‡§π‡•ç and the syllable ‡§§‡•ã dropped, as ‡§§‡§øis in the case of the 3rd pers. pl. of the present, as we shall see.

The genitive singular ‡§∏‡•Å and ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å as in ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Ö‡§£‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å and ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å inverse 4 above, I trace to the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ of the Prakrits, the ‡§â addedby analogy as observed before. Lassen traces is to ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ, which, hesays, must have been added to these nouns to form the genitive;and the being softened to ‡§â, it is reduced to ‡§∏‡•Å. But this doesnot account for the double ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏of the other form; and the additionof such a word as ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ to make up a case-form is altogether unexampled. The suffix ‡§π‡•ã, as in ‡§¶‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§π‡§π‡•ãin the same verse, is butanother form of ‡§∏‡•Å.The genitive plural ‡§π‡§Ç, as in ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•Å‡§∏‡§π‡§Ç for‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç, may with Lassen be derived from the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•çof theSanskrit pronominal declension. But the transference of thistermination to nouns is nowhere seen in the Prakrits; ‡§π‡§Ç isoptionally appended to nouns in or also; and the characteristic ‡§£‡§Çof the gen. is wanting in this dialect. The more probableexplanation, therefore, is that the ‡§£ lost its cerebral element andwas reduced merely to a nasal ‡§Ö, or ‡§Ö with an anusvƒÅra, as isthe case in the instrumental singular, and the ‡§π‡•ç is added, asobserved before, simply to facilitate the pronunciation.

The loc. sing. ends in ‡§è, as in ‡§§‡§≤‡•á, which we see is the oldtermination, or in ‡§á, as in ‡§§‡§≤‡§ø, which is a shortened form of ‡§è.Kramadƒ´≈õvara gives also ‡§π‡§ø‡§Çwhich might be traced to the Pali ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§ø,the Sanskrit ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç, or the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§Çof the Prakrit pronominal declension.The language of Jaina works has this ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§Çin the case of nounsalso. But even here the Prakrit ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø, may, withreason, besupposed to have changed to ‡§á‡§Ç, and the ‡§π‡•çto be, as before, a merespiritus lenis. We have this locative ‡§á‡§Ç in the Marathi. The ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç isextended to the plural also of these nouns. The vocative is formedby using which is evidently an interjection; as ‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§£ ‡§π‡•ã“O young men.”

____________________________________________________________________________________________

1**.** Kramadƒ´≈õvarain Lassan’s extract gives ‡§¶‡•Çinstead of ‡§π‡•Å;but this is anevident misreading.

Nouns in ‡§á or ‡§â

There is no distinction between the nom. and acc. sing. andpl., the original base being used without any modification oraddition.

The instrumental singular is formed by adding ‡§è‡§Ç or ‡§£, as inthe last class of nouns, or simple anusvƒÅra; as ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§è‡§Ç, ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§£, ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§Ç,As ‡§è‡§£ becomes ‡§è‡§Çby dropping the final vowel, so does the ‡§á‡§£‡§æ ofthe Prakrit instrumental here become ‡§á‡§Ç.

The abl. sing. ends in ‡§π‡•á as in ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡•á and ‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡•á; and the gen.sing. also according to Kramadƒ´≈õvara, Hemacandra being silent.These have been transferred from the feminine. Kramadƒ´≈õvaraalso gives ‡§π‡•ã and ‡§π‡§Ç as the terminations of the sing. of these two.cases; but there must be some misreading here in Lassen’sextract from the author, since is a distinctive plural termination. The gen. pl. termination is ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç or ‡§π‡§Ç as in ‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç, ‡§∏‡§â‡§£‡§ø‡§π‡§Ç (‡§∂‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ).The latter has been traced to the old gen.‡§£, and the formerappears to be only another form of it, with the addition of theusual ‡§â.

The loc. sing. has ‡§π‡§ø, as in ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§π‡§ø; and the pl. has ‡§π‡§ø‡§Çand ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç, as in ‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡§ø‡§Çand ‡§â‡§¶‡•Å‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç,.The first must be considered to be the same as fe derivedfrom ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§Çor ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§øwith the anusvƒÅra dropped; or as the ‡§á of Prakritfeminine nouns with the spiritus lenis ‡§π‡•ç. This explanation seemsto be probable, since we have seen other feminine terminationsalso used for the cases of these nouns. The third is to be tracedto the Prakrit ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ç. Kramadƒ´≈õvara in Lassen’s extract gives ‡§π‡§Ç forthe ‡§π‡•Å‡§Çof the abl. pl.‡§π‡•á, and for that of the gen. pl.; but I have tomake the same remark here as before. The instr, and abl. pluralsare the same as those of nouns in ‡§Ö; as ‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡§ø‡§Çand ‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç. Thus theplural of three cases ends in ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç , derived separately of course, andthe plurals of two in ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç.

Feminine nouns

The plurals of the nom. and acc. of feminine nouns preservethe old ‡§ì, or its shortened form ‡§â, as in ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§â ‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ü‡§â in the

second verse, and ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§ñ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§ì ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä‡§ì. The sing. is theoriginal base, as ‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ü, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä &c.

The instr. sing. termination is ‡§è, the old one, as in ‡§∏‡§∏‡§ø‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§Æ‡§è, ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§è&o,: the abl is ‡§π‡•á as in ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§π‡•á for ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É,which is an aspirated ‡§è; and the genitive ‡§π‡•á as in ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§°‡§π‡•áfor ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§ò‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É (‡§°being a nominal suffix) may be similarlyexplained or traced to the of the gen. sing. fem. of thepronouns, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç,and ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç, in the Prakrit. I prefer the formerexplanation. This ‡§π‡•á has been transferred to masculine nouns in‡§á or ‡§â as we have seen. The abl. and gen. pl. ends in ‡§π‡•Å, as in‡§ö‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ö‡§π‡•Å for ‡§µ‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É or ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç, The anusvƒÅra of the ‡§π‡•Å of theother classes of nouns is here omitted and if correctly so, the ‡§π‡•Åof the abl. may be considered an aspirated form of the ‡§âwhichis the ablative termination in the Prakrit: and that of thegenitive may be traced to the ‡§∏‡•Å of the singular of masculinenouns. The instr. pl. and the loc. sing. and pl. take the sameterminations as masculine nouns in ‡§á or ‡§â;as ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø, ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§π‡§ø, and‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç. Lassen gives other terminations; but he appears to menot to have interpreted Kramadƒ´≈õvara correctly. Those I havegiven are all that I have been able to find.

You will thus see how by the various influences at work, thenatural transformation of ‡§∏‡•çto ‡§π‡•ç, the elision of some of theelements, and the aspirated pronunciation of the vowels, most ofthe old terminations have been reduced to syllables composed of ‡§π‡•çand a vowel with or without an anusvƒÅra. Terminations withsuch weak sounds are not adapted to serve the purposes ofordinary intercourse, since they require on the part of thespeakers such care in pronunciation to render themselves intelligible to each other as we have not seen displayed in the courseof our lingual history. The nominative and accusative throughout, and in certain classes of nouns, the other cases also havecome to have the same forms. So that the purpose of expressingthe different relations can be no longer performed by these poorremnants of the old declensional system; and a process of reconstruction must take place. It has already begun in the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa; but we shall find it carried on much further in thevernaculars, which may now be said to have completed theirnew declensional system.

The abl. sing. of pronouns ends in ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç, as ‡§ú‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç, &o., which is tobe traced to the Sanskrit ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•çand the Prakrit ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ, and the loc.sing. in ‡§π‡§ø‡§Çwhich has been explained. The gen. sing. of **‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç, ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç,**and ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç sre optionally ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å, ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å, and ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å, made up by adding theususl ‡§â to ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∏, ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏, and ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏, which again are other forms of ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏,‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏, and ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏, with one of the consonants dropped and thepreceding vowel lengthened as a compensation, a phenomenonto he noticed in going over the vernaculars. In the feminine,these pronouns have ‡§ú‡§π‡•á, ‡§§‡§π‡•á,and ‡§ï‡§π‡•á optionally for the gen. sing.,which are derived from the Prakrit ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡•á, ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•á and ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•á and thePali ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø, ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø, and ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø. The base, however, in theApabhra·πÅ≈õa ends in ‡§Öand not ‡§à, or, the more probable explanation is, that this ‡§π‡•á is the aspirated form of the ‡§èof feminine nours.

‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç has ‡§Ü‡§Ø for its base; the instr. and gen. singulars, forinstance, are ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ and ‡§Ü‡§™‡§π‡•ã. This seems to be taken from thenom. sing. ‡§Ö‡§Ö, or ‡§Ö‡§Øby the rule of the substitution of ‡§Ø for ‡§Ö‡§Ç.The neuter nom. and acc. sing, is ‡§á‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ç.

‡§è‡§π‡•ã er is nom. and acc. sing. masc. of ‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡•ç corresponding to ‡§è‡§∏‡•ã,‡§è‡§π fem. to ‡§è‡§∏‡§æ, and by the application of ‡§âto these we have theneuter ‡§è‡§π‡•Å.‡§è‡§áis the nom. and acc. pl. answering to ‡§è‡§èPrakrit,with the latter ‡§è shortened; and ‡§ì‡§á of ‡§Ö‡§¶‡§∏ which corresponds tothe form ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•á, the ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å being changed to ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•Å‡§Çby a rule beforementioned, and afterwards to ‡§ì; and ‡§ï‡•á to ‡§è, shortened to ‡§á. Inother respects all these pronouns are declined like the corresponding nouns.

The pronouns of the 1st and 2nd persons are thus declined :‚Äî
1st pers. 2nd pers.
sing. pl. sing. pl.
Nom. ‡§á‡§â‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§π‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§π‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á-‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§á‡§Ç
Acc. ‡§Æ‡§π‡§Ç ‚Äî‚Äî ‡§§‡§á‡§Ç ‚Äî‚Äî
Instr.‚Äî ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§á‡§Ç, ‡§§‡§á‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç
Abl. ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Å-‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§π‡§Ç ‡§§‡§â, ‡§§‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù, ‡§§‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§π‡§Ç
Gen.‚Äî‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî ‚Äî
Loc. ‡§Æ‡§á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§™‡§á‡§Ç, ‡§§‡§á‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å

Here we have not the wilderness of forms which we observedin the principal Prakrit. The nom. sing. of the 1st per. is ‡§á‡§â‡§Ç

corresponding to ‡§Ö‡§π‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç, the initial ‡§Ö and the ‡§ï‡•ç being elided andthe usual Apabhra·πÅ≈õa ‡§âadded. In the Prakrits ‡§Ö‡§π‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç, is represented by ‡§Ö‡§á‡§Ö‡§Ç or ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ø‡§Ç, ‡§Æ‡§á‡§Ç is to be traced to the Sanskrit instr.‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ and the ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ø, both of which are reduced to the form of ‡§Æ‡§áin the Prakrit. Here it is extended to the acc. also. The pl. base is‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π, which has been explained. The nom. pl. ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§á‡§Çcorresponds tosuch a form as ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ánom. pl., not loc. as Lassen says, through.‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§è; and the gen. pl. has the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa termination ‡§π‡§Ç. Therest are old. ‡§§‡•Å‡§π is a base derived, as I said in going over thePrakrits, from ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ø‡•ç‡§π‡§Çand is used in the Prakrit also, ‡§™‡§á‡§Çand ‡§§‡§á‡§Ç ofthe acc. instr. and loc. are from ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æand ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø.The second isfound in the older dialects, the first is peculiar to this. Of thecorruption of ‡§§‡•ç‡§µto ‡§™‡•ç‡§™have already spoken.

The abl. and gen.‡§§‡§âcorresponds to a form ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ïwhich withthe Apabhra·πÅ≈õic ‡§â is ‡§§‡§â, the ‡§ï being dropped. Or it may betraced to ‡§§‡§µ with the ‡§µ dissolved into ‡§â. ‡§§‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù is a form found inthe Prakrits also and explained by me as a corruption of the dat.‡§§‡•Å‡§Ø‡•ç‡§π‡§Ç in the Pali and Prakrits, derived from the Skr. ‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç.Thedative forms, you will remember, are put under the gen in theolder dislects. The ‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞of ‡§§‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞is a peculiar Apabhramsic conjunct,formed from ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡•ç. The neuter of ‡§§‡§¶‡•çis similarly ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç and ‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç. Thebase of the plural is ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π, the same as in the Prakrit; and the nom.pl. ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§á‡§Çis to be traced to ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•áfor ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•á nom. pl. All the formsare similar to those of the first personal pronoun.

THE VERB IN THE APABHRA·πÄSA

The Present tense of the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa verb admits, besidesthose of the corresponding Prakrit or ≈öaurasenƒ´ tense, thefollowing forms :‚Äî 1st pers. sing. ‡§≤‡§π‡§â‡§Ç, pl. ‡§≤‡§π‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç; 2nd pers. sing.‡§≤‡§π‡§π‡§ø, pl. ‡§≤‡§π‡§π‡•Å; 3rd pers. sing. ‡§≤‡§π‡§á, pl. ‡§≤‡§π‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç.

It appears that some of these forms have arisen from & confusion of the Present Indicative with the Imperative. The prevailing and distinguishing final of the latter is the vowel ‡§â; and here
we see it is appended to the forms of the 1st pers. sing. and 2ndpers. pl., though it does not occur in those forms in any of theolder dialects.

The ‡§π‡•ç is another characteristio of these paradigms. That ofthe second pers. sing. we get from the old ‡§∏‡§ø, and that of the pl.

exists in the Prakrit, being derived from the Skr. ‡§•. But thethird pers. pl. and the 1st pers. pl. get it simply by an extensionof the analogy or It may have been introduced to prevent ahiatus and thus may, like those of the cases, have been simplya spiritus lenis. The ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç of the latter, however, may be traced to‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•ã, ‡§ìbeing shortened to ‡§â, just as ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æand ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§øof the declensionsbecome ‡§π‡§æ‡§Çand ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç.Instead of the 3rd pers. pl. ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§øwe have ‡§π‡§ø‡§Çinwhich, though the ‡§πis due to analogy, the characteristic ‡§á andthe nasal are preserved.

You will thus see that in the declensions as well as conjugations the prevails ‡§π‡•çin this dialect. The Imperative second pers.sing. ends in , ‡§á, ‡§è or ‡§â. The first two may be traced to the Prakritand Sankrit ‡§π‡§ø, ‡§π‡•ç being dropped as in the Vernaculars; and thelast seems to be substituted for the ‡§Ö of one of the forms in theoriginal dialects by analogy; or it may be the remnant of ‡§Æ‡•Å,changed first to ‡§π‡•Å, and then to ‡§â. But a better and, I may say, the trueexplanation of these forms will be given in going over theVernaculars.

Hemacandra does not give any more forms for the Imperative,but Kramadƒ´≈õvara gives ‡§ä for the second person plural whichmust very likely be ‡§π‡•Å, the same as in the Present, and ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç for thefirst pers. pl. which we have in the Present also. In one of theverses quoted by Hemacandra occurs ‡§™‡§ø‡§Ö‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç which seems to correspond to ‡§™‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å, if the reading is correct. The truth seems tobe that the forms of the Imperative were lost, and the sense confounded with that of the Present, but the distinctive forms werethose of the second pers. sing., and in this respect there is ananalogy with Hindi and Gujarati which resemble the Apabhra·πÅ≈õathe most.

The Future has the Prakrit and ≈öaurasenƒ´forms in ‡§π‡§ø and ‡§á‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏;but one ‡§Æ‡•ç of this latter is dropped, and then the terminations ofthe Apabhra·πÅ≈õa Present are added.

The terminations of the absolutive are ‡§á. ‡§á‡§â, ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø, ‡§á‡§µ‡§ø, ‡§è‡§µ‡§ø,‡§è‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡•Å,‡§è‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§ø, ‡§è‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•Å, ‡§á. is the same as the ≈öaurasenƒ´ ‡§á‡§û‡•ç from the Skr.‡§Ø, ‡§á‡§âis the same, with the usual ‡§â added to it, or is to be tracedto the ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç or ‡§á‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç which is, as we have seen, confounded in thePrakrit with the absolutive, and the rest are various forms of the

Vedic ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§® with the Prakrit augment ‡§á or ‡§è,This ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§®is, by arule before mentioned, changed to ‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§£, which with ‡§âbecomes ‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•Åand by dropping the final ‡§®we have ‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø. This, however, may bederived also from such a form ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä found in the Vedas. This ‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§øor ‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•Åis then softened to ‡§µ‡§ø or ‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡•Å, as ‡§™‡•ç is so softened in manycases. When the augment ‡§á or ‡§èis not prefixed, we have ‡§µ‡§ø inthe form of ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø, the ‡§Ö being the final vowel of the root.

Some of the terminations of the absolutive are also used toform the infinitive, on account of the prevailing confusion between the two. In consequence of this very confusion, recourseis had to other ways of forming the latter which are similar tothose existing in the Prakrits; but these will be noticed hereafter.

The termination ‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø of the potential participle assumes theforms of ‡§á‡§è‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§â‡§Ç, ‡§è‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§â‡§Çand ‡§è‡§µ. The first two represent the formwith the addition of ‡§ï; and the ‡§á of ‡§á‡§è‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§â‡§Çis the usual augmentThe ‡§Ö of the ‡§§of ‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Øwhich remains after the consonantal portionis dropped, is by the influence of the preceding ‡§á changed to ‡§è.

In these points which are not noticed here, the Apabhra·πÅ≈õafollows chiefly the ≈öaurasenƒ´, and the principal Prakrit also tosome extent. Thus in a great measure it represents those dialectsin a further stage of decay; but it must be considered to havederived some words or forms independently also. Thus the ‡§™‡§á ofthe second person pronoun cannot be derived from the Prakrit ‡§§‡§á,nor ‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§£of the absolutive from ‡§§‡•Ç‡§£ or ‡§ä‡§£, or ‡§™‡§£of abstract nounsfrom ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§£, but directly from the Sanskrit ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§® and ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§®. Thiscorruption of ‡§§‡•ç‡§µmust have existed in some of the older dialectstoo, since, as observed before, we have it in A≈õoka’s inscriptions;and the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa derived it as well as a few such peculiarities from them.

LECTURE IV

P ONOLOGY OF THE VERNACULARS OF NORTHERN INDIA

We have now traced the gradual decay of Sanskrit from theform in which it is presented to us in the oldest literary recordsto that which it assumed in the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa dialect. We haveseen how words lost some of their vocal elements on account ofthe natural tendency of men to economize effort, as well as inconsequence of the fact that the vocal organs of the people, whothrough historical nooidents had to speak that language thoughit was not theirs, were untrained to utter the sounds of thatlanguage, and that they imported into it some sounds to whichthey themselves were previously accustomed. We have alsoobserved the effects of the operation of the law of analogy insimplifying the grammar of the language ‚Äî an operation, therange of which, in consequence of the ignorance of those sameforeigners, was very extensive. The declensions and conjugations gradually lost their variety, and became reduced to one or two types by the generalization of the rules, originally applicableonly to the nouns and verbs frequently used in ordinary intercourse. At the same time the terminations themselves of someof the cases, tenses, and moods came through numberless analogies to have the same or similar forms, and their vocal bodygradually became attenuated and in some instances they werealtogether dropped. Thus these processes of simplification werecarried on much further than was consistent with intelligibilityin ordinary intercourse. Hence the necessity arose of inventingnew modes of expression for those relations which came to beimperfectly expressed or ceased to be expressed in the old way.As observed in the last lecture, such new expressions are to bemet with in the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa dialect.

If the Prakrits and the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa which we have examinedreally represent the speech of the Indian people at certain periodsof their past history, we should expect to find a relation of continuity between them and the prevailing speech of modern times.The words and grammatical forms in the modern vernaculars

should either be the same as those existing in those dialects, orshould be easily deducible from them by laws which we haveobserved to be in operation; and if in the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa thegrammatical forms came to be in a condition in which reconstruction was necessary, and if accordingly it was begun, weshould find it carried on much further in the vernaculars andthat on principles used in the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa and the other dialectsand out of materials existing in them. We will therefore proceednow to the examination of the vernaculars with a view to tracethis continuity.

The varieties of speech prevailing in Northern India at thepresent day are almost innumerable. If even a few peculiaritieswere to be regarded as giving individuality to a language, thenumber of dialects spoken in this part of the country wouldexceed even the proverbial fifty-six. But they may be dividedinto classes on the principle of resemblance; and generally thedialects spoken in the adjoining provinces are so alike eachother that they may be regarded as constituting one class or evenone language. Thus we have nine principal languages; andstarting from ourselves, and going northwards, first on thewestern side of the country and then turning to the east andsouth-east, I may state them as the Marathi, the Gujarati, theSindhi, including the Kacchi, the Panjabi, the Kashmiri, the Hindi, the Nepali, the Bengali, and the Oriya.

Of these the Kashmiri and the Nepali have not yet been studied,and no grammars or books are available. Hence my observations will not extend to them. Each of these has its dialects; butthose of some, such as the Gujarati and the Sindhi, differ fromthe main language in unimportant particulars. The same is thecase with the Marathi, except in some corners of the Marathacountry. But in these there are five dialects differing in a greatmany important particulars from the main Marathi. Thus, theGoanese prevails in Goa; the Malvani, my own native tongue,and the Savantvadi, both of which, notwithstanding some minordifferences, may be considered as one, are spoken in the Malvan,Vengorla, and Savantvadi districts. The Chitpavni is used onlyby the caste of Chitpavan Brahmans in the district aboutRatnagiri; the Salsetti is spoken by the original inhabitants of

that island and of Bombay; and the Khandeshi, which is a mixtureof Marathi and Gujarati and contains to an appreciable degreea barbarous element, probably from a Bhil source, prevails inKhandesh.

The Hindi has a great many dialects. Two at least may bedistinguished among the variety of speech prevalent inRajputana, the Mewari spoken in Mewar and the adjoiningdistricts, and the Marwari which prevails in Marwar, Jesselmere,and the other provinces. These, as may be inferred from theirgeographical position, are midway between the Gujarati and theHindi dialects of the North, displaying some of the peculiarcharacteristics of both. Furthernorth, we have the Brajprevailing in the country about Mathura; and to the east,the Kanoji. There is not much difference between these.The language of the history of eighty-four Vai·π£·πáavasand other books of the VallabhƒÅcƒÅryan sects, whichis ordinarily supposed to be the Braj,grammatical forms identical with those mentioned by a recent grammarian as peculiar to the Kanoji. There is a good deal of confusion as regards this matter, the characteristics of one beingfound in the printed books together with those belonging toanother. Then further north, we have the Garhawali and theKumaoni spoken in the provinces of Garhawal and Kumaon.

To the east, we have the Avadhi or the dialect of the provinceof Avadha or Ayodhya, and to the south of this again is theRewai spoken in the State of Rewa. Further to the east is theBhojpuri and kindred dialects prevailing in Bihar and theadjacent districts on the confines of Bengal.

The old literature of the Hindi is principally written in twodialects, the Braj, and what is called the Purbi. S≈´radƒÅsa’s works,Beharilal’s Satasai, and others are written in the former; and tothese I may add the Vallabhha works I have already mentioned.The RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa and Tulasidasa’s other works are written in thelatter. The chief distinction between the idioms of S≈´radƒÅsa andTulasƒ´dƒÅsa appears to me to be, that the latter uses a great manygrammatical forms which are old, and from which those used bythe former are derived. In this respect Purbi might be considered to be a very old form of the Braj. But there are a few other

distinctions, though it is questionable whether they are enough tojustify the Purbi being considered an independent dialect. Thelanguage of Kabƒ´ra’s Ramainƒ´and SƒÅkhiƒ´s presents a few peculiarities found in neither of the above. But the characteristics ofS≈´radƒÅsa and Tulasƒ´dƒÅsa are also to be found in it; so that if weleave out of consideration the other works of Kabƒ´ra, in whichthere is probably another variety of speech, the dialect used bythese Hindi poets may be considered to be the same. This hascome to be regarded as the poetic dialect, and most of the otherHindi poets have written in it. Its modern representative is theBraj, in which the commentaries on Tulasƒ´dƒÅsa’s, Kabƒ´ra’s andBehƒÅrilƒÅl’s works, and on the tenth book of the BhƒÅgavatathat Ihave seen, are written. This then is the Hindi literary dialect.The language, however, which is used as the medium of instruction in the Government schools in the North-Western Provinces,and in which the books published by the Educational Departmentare written, is now regarded as the Standard Hindi, and its grammatical structure is identical with that of the Urdu spoken bythe Mussalmans. This is rather the dialect in which the Hindusof the different provinces in Northern India communicate witheach other, than that which they speak in their own provinces.

The Panjabi has also several dialects; but little is known aboutthem. Oriyi resembles the Bengali in so many respects that oneof them may be considered a dialect of the other. The similaritybetween the Hindi and the Panjabi is also very great.

I will now give short specimens of these dialects.

I Marathi:

‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§™‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§™‡§∏‡§∞‡•ã‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§à‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§ú‡•á ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§Ü‡§ú‡§ö ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§†‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§§ ‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ò‡§°‡§§‡•ã ‡§∂‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§µ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•á‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ ‡§ú‡§ó‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§∏‡•á ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§¨‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ç‡§® ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏ ‡§µ‡•ã‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ò‡•á‡§ä‡§® ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§¨‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø ‡§® ‡§ò‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§†‡§ø‡§£ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç‡§® ‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§π‡•á‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç‡§® ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ ‡§µ‡§°‡§ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ê‡§∏‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ó‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§§‡•á‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§à ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§á‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç ‡•§

(From an old Bakhara or Chronical of Shivaji.)

Some counsellors supplicated the lady-mother in an humbleattitude saying: ‘If you will burn yourself by fire, the kingdomwhich has been acquired goes to ruin this very day; and it will

happen that the king will not bear life; the name of Shahaji Maharaj and Shivaji Maharaj will not remain in the world. Therefore,your ladyship, looking to all these things, should make the kingsit in your lap ( protect), and, not resorting to fire, render yourmind firm, and live. If you do this (burn yourself), it will plainlyappear to all the world that you destroyed the race of the MahƒÅrƒÅj Thus they prevailed on her to live.

II Gujarati :

‡§¶‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§°‡§º‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ü ‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§® ‡§ï‡•á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ö‡•Å‡§Ç\‡•§ ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§õ‡•á ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§è‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ã‡§ï ‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§†‡•ã ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§® ‡§¶‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§µ‡•Ä‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡§π‡•á‡§õ‡•á ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ì ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§® ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ã‡§ï ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ã‡§ï‡§®‡•ã‡§®‡§æ‡§∂ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§•‡§æ‡•§ ‡§™‡§£ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§£ ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•á‡•§

(From Mr. MansukharƒÅma‚Äõs Nala-Damayantƒ´)

Damayanti felt greatly astonished and was in doubt whetherit was a reality or a dream. While moving on, engaged in varioussuch thoughts, sho saw an A≈õoka tree. Going there she said “Olovely A≈õoka, having regard to the greatness of thy name, destroymy ≈öoka(sorrow) and deserve that name.” But who wouldanswer?

III Sindhi :

‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü‡§Æ‡•á ‡§∞‡§æ‡§á ‡§°‡§ø‡§Ü‡§ö‡•Å ‡§®‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§π‡§ø‡§ï‡§°‡•ã ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§π‡•Å ‡§π‡•ã ‡•§ ‡§§‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ú‡•á ‡§≠‡•á‡§£‡•Å ‡§´‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§à ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å ‡§°‡•á‡•§ ‡§´‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§π‡•Å‡§®‡§ñ‡•á ‡§ö‡§ø‡§ì ‡§™‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å ‡§§‡•ã‡§ñ‡•á ‡§•‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ã ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§á ‡§°‡§ø‡§Ü‡§ö‡§ú‡•ã ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§µ‡§¢‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ã‡•§ ‡§π‡•Å‡§® ‡§ö‡§ø‡§ì ‡§â‡§π‡•ã‡§™‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å ‡§à ‡§¨‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡§ø‡§ì ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§ú‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§â‡§ú‡•ã ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å ‡§µ‡§°‡•á‡•§‡§™‡§∞ ‡§´‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ú‡•ã‡§ö‡§µ‡§£‡•Å ‡§•‡§ø‡§ì ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§ü‡§∞‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§® ‡•§ ‡§•‡•ã‡§∞‡•á ‡§ò‡§£‡•á ‡§°‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§°‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§á‡§Ö ‡§™‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§ú‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡•§

                         (From the story of RƒÅi ·∏åiƒÅca in Major Stack‚Äõs Grammar.)

There was s PƒÅ·π≠i≈õƒÅha(king ) of the name of R·π≠i ·∏åiƒÅca. Hissister begged of a Fakir: “Sire, give me a son.” The Fakir saidto her: “A son will be ( born ) to thee, but he will cut off thehead of RƒÅi ·∏åiƒÅca” She said, “Accursed be (lit. fall into awilderness) the son who should cut off my brother’s head.” Butthe Fakir’s word cannot prove vain. In a few days the womangave birth to a son.

IV Panjabi :

‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§´‡•á‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§π‡§ø‡§Ü ‡§π‡•á ‡§™‡§Ç‡§°‡§§‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§§‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§£ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§Æ‡§£‡§ñ‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ß‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡§ä‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ ‡§π‡•à ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡§≤‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡•á ‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§£ ‡§™‡§Ç‡§°‡§§ ‡§ú‡•á ‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡§ä ‡§™‡§æ‡§µ‡•á ‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§∞‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§π‡§∞‡•á ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§Æ‡§£‡§ñ‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§°‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ ‡§π‡•à‡•§ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§á‡§π ‡§ó‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§¨‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§°‡§º‡•Ä ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡§®‡•á

‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï ‡§¨‡•à‡§†‡•á ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§≠ ‡§π‡•à‡§∞‡§æ‡§® ‡§π‡•ã ‡§ó‡§è ‡•§ ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§π‡§ø‡§£ ‡§≤‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§ê ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§á‡§π ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï ‡§π‡•à ‡§Ö‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡•à‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à‡•§

( From the JanamnsƒÅkhƒ´.)

Then again Babe NƒÅnaskjƒ´said:“O Pa·πá·∏çit, hear. Is the religious holiness of Brahmans and K·π£atriyas preserved by the sacred thread or by good deeds? Hear, O Pa·πá·∏çit, if one who is invested with the sacred thread does wicked deeds, does he remain a Brahman or ·π£atriya or become a Ca·πá·∏çƒÅla ?” When ≈örƒ´ Guru BƒÅbejƒ´spoke thus, all the people that were sitting there were astonished. Then they began to exclaim: “O God, he is still but a child, and how wonderfully he speaks”

V Hindi:

‡§á‡§§‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§π ‡§â‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•á ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§π‡§æ‡§• ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á ‡§™‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§≠‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§® ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§æ‡•§‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏ ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§™‡•á‡§ü ‡§´‡§ü ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§§‡•ã ‡§™‡§õ‡§æ‡§°‡§ñ‡§æ‡§µ ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ ‡§§‡§¨ ‡§â‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§∏‡•á ‡§≤‡•ã‡§π‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§π ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ‡•§ ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•à‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§Ü‡§™ ‡§Ü‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§®‡•á ‡§î‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§Ü‡§ó‡•á ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§®‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§è‡§ï ‡§ï‡§¶‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§π‡§§‡§≤‡•á ‡§ñ‡§°‡§π‡•Å‡§è ‡•§

(PremasƒÅgara, chap. 38.)

Having said so much, be made many attempts to throw out. his(K·πõ·π£·πáa’s)hand, but none was of any use. Atlast, he wassuffocated and his belly burst out. Then he fell down, and blood flowed from his body in torrents. At that time the cowherd boys came one after another and began to see; and ≈örƒ´i K·πõ·π£·πáa went forward and stood in the shade of a Kadamba tree in the forest.

VI Braj :

‡§ú‡§¨ ‡§∏‡§¨ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§®‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•Ä ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡§Æ‡§®‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§¨‡§π‡•ã‡§§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó ‡§π‡•à ‡§§‡§¨ ‡§∏‡§¨‡§®‡§®‡•á ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§Ø‡§π ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡•å‡§ú‡•ã ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§π‡•ã‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§∏‡§¨ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§è‡§ï ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ø ‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ø ‡§≠‡•á‡§ü ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã ‡•§ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ü‡§∏‡§™‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§ö‡•å‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∏ ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç ‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•å‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§¨ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡•á ‡§è‡§ï ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¶‡•ã‡§á ‡§¶‡•ã‡§á ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§≠‡•á‡§ü ‡§ï‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§à‡•§ ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§†‡§π‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§∏ ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ï‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•à ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§µ‡§õ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡§Æ‡§®‡§ï‡•ã ‡§≠‡•á‡§ü ‡§ï‡§∞‡•à‡•§ ‡§ê‡§∏‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§ß‡§ø ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ï‡•á ‡§≠‡•á‡§ü ‡§≠‡§à‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§¨ ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§ß ‡§¶‡§π‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ñ‡§® ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§†‡§æ ‡§∏‡§¨ ‡§ò‡§∞‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§Ç ‡•§

(From the Story of the Manifestation of GovardhananƒÅthjƒ´.)

When all the inhabitants of Vraja heard that Devadamana was greatly fond of cows, they all joined and resolved that all who had cows should esch present one or two. And the inhabtants of Vraja joined and caused each of the twenty-four villages

about the mountain (Govardhana) to present one or two cowseach. And it was resolved that in the twenty villages he whose cow should first calveshould present the calf to Devadamana. In this way thousands of cows were presented to the Prosperous One. Then he used the milk, curds, butter and whey of the cows in his home.

VII Bengali :

‡§§‡§¨‡•á ‡§∂‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¨‡•á? ‡§Ü‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞ ‡§ú‡§ñ‡§® ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ó‡§§‡•á ‡§õ‡§ø‡§®‡•Å‚Äì‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø ‡§¨‡§ø‡§õ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§™‡§°‡•á ‡§•‡§æ‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‚Äì‡§â‡§†‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç‡§°‡§æ‡§á‡§¨‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§õ‡§ø‡§≤ ‡§®‡§æ, ‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§â‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§ ‡§á‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§Æ‡§® ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§® ‡§π‡§ì‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§á, ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•á‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ß‡§® ‡§®‡§æ‡§á ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§á‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§° ‡§ï‡§æ‡§õ‡•á ‡§¨‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡•á ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•á‡§∞ ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§£‡§æ ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§π‡§¨‡•á ‡•§ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§æ‡§¨‡•á ‡§®‡§æ‚Äì‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡§õ‡•á ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç‡§°‡§æ‡§á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§á ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§¨‡§≤‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§∑‡•ã‡§≤ ‡§¨‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞ ‡§π‡§á‡§≤ ‡§§‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§ø‡§¨‡§æ‡§π ‡§ï‡§∞‡•á ‡§ó‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§õ‡§ø‚Äì‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‚Äî‡§ü‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§∞‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§§‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§ü‡•á ‡§Ü‡§∏‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§õ‡§ø-‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§¨‚Äì‡§§‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§™‡§ï‡•á ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡•ã ‡§´‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§®‚Äî‡§§‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§π‡§®‡§æ ‡§ñ‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡§æ‡§ì‡•§

( From Peary Chand’s ƒÄlƒÅler gharer dulƒÅla-& Kulina Marriage.)

Will you hear then? That year at the time when I was suffering from intermittent fever, remained lying in bed day and night, and had no strength to rise and stand, my lord (husband) came. I had not seen what sort of a man my husband was since. I ceased to be an infant. Nothing is more valuable to a woman than her husband. I had thought that my suffering would become alleviated, if he sat by my side for a few minutes (lit. two da·πá·∏ças ) and spoke with me. Dear sister, you will not believe me when I say that, as soon as he stood by my side, he said, “It is sixteen years since I married you and went away. You are one of my wives. I come to you, being in need of money, and will go back soon. I spoketo your father; but he put me off. Do pull out the ornament in your arm (round the wrist), and give it to me.

VIII Oriyi :

‡§ó‡•ã‡§ü‡§ø ‡§è ‡§Æ‡§∂‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∑‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§∂‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó ‡§â‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§π‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ü‡§™‡§£‡§æ‡§ï‡•Å ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ù‡§ø ‡§∑‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ï‡•Å ‡§ï‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á ‡§∑‡§£‡•ç‡§° ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å ‡§ú‡•á‡§Ø‡•á ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡•Å ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•á ‡§§‡•á‡§µ‡•á ‡§ï‡§π ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•á ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§® ‡§ï‡•Å ‡§â‡§°‡§ø ‡§ú‡§æ‡§â‡§Ç ‡•§ ‡§è ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ ‡§∂‡•Å‡§£‡§ø ‡§¨‡•É‡§∑ ‡§ï‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡§∂‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å ‡§ú‡•á ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠ ‡§â‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§¨‡§∏‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Å ‡§è ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ü‡•á‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§á ‡§®‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§Ç

    (Fables published by the Caloutts School Book Society.)

A certain gnat sitting on a horn of an ox, and with pride thinking itself heavy, said, “O ox, if in consequence of my sitting you feel heavily weighted, tell me, and I will fly away to another spot’’. Hearing these words the ox said, “O gnat, I had not even the slightest idea that you were sitting on me.”

** * *

In these extracts there are a great many words which on examination will be found to be derived from Sanskrit through the Prakrits; in other words, the vernacular forms will be found. to be the same as, or further developments of, the Prakrit forms.

Thus we have the following:‚Äî

(No. I)

‡§ï‡§ø‡§§, Pr. ‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ö or ‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ö, Skr. ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç with the termination ‡§á‡§ï changed to ‡§á‡§Ö.

** ‡§Ø‡§æ** of ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ç, Pr. ‡§Ö‡§Öor ‡§Ö‡§Øin ‡§Ö‡§Ö‡§Ç nom. sing, Bkr. ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç.

** ‡§™‡§∏‡§∞**, Pr. ‡§™‡§∏‡§∞, Skr. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞ in ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§∞‡§§‡§ø.

** ‡§ï‡•á** of‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä, from Pr ‡§ï‡§Ö or ‡§ï‡§Ø, Skr. ‡§ï‡•É‡§§, ‡§≤ being a termination oftenused in the Prakrits.

‡§ì, Pr, ‡§ú‡§Ö or ‡§ú‡§Ø, Skr. ‡§Ø‡§ï‡§§‡•ç, ‡§ï being a suffix used in the Prakrits generally, and sometimes in Sanskrit also.

‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§ø,Apabhr. ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§à,Pr.‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á or ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§è.Skr such a form as ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•á,by analogy, for ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç.

** ‡§Ü‡§ú**, Pr. ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú Skr.‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø,

** ‡§ú‡§æ** of ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§Ç, Pr.‡§ú‡§æ, Skr. ‡§Ø‡§æ.

‡§´‡•ã‡§π‡•Ä,Pr.‡§ï‡•ã‡§≠‡•Ä:Skr.‡§ï‡•ã‡§≠‡§ø‡§É.

** ‡§†‡•á‡§¨** of ‡§†‡•á‡§¨‡•Ä‡§§, Pr. ‡§†‡§æ‡§µ, Skr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™ in ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø,

** ‡§π‡§æ** ,Apabhr. ‡§è‡§π‡•ã, Pr. ‡§è‡§∏‡§ì ,Skr. ‡§ò‡§ü in ‡§ò‡§ü‡§§‡•á.

** ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ**, Pr. ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ, Skr. ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ.

** ‡§ú‡§ó**, Pr. ‡§ú‡§ó, Skr. ‡§ú‡§ó‡§§‡•ç,

** ‡§π‡•ã** of ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•á, Pr. ‡§π‡•ã, Skr. ‡§≠‡§µ in ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø,

** ‡§µ‡§∞**, Pr. ‡§â‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø, Skr. ‡§â‡§™‡§∞‡§ø

‡§¶‡•á of ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ç‡§®, Pr. ‡§¶‡§ø as in ‡§¶‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§£, Skr. ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§.

** ‡§µ‡•ã‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó** or ‡§ì‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó ,Pr. ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó, skr. ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó. The ‡§õ‡•ç of Sanskrit, Prakrit, Hindi &c., is in Marathi changed to ‡§Æ‡•ç.

** ‡§ò‡•á** of ‡§ò‡•á‡§ä‡§® and ‡§ò‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç, Pr. ‡§ò‡•á as in ‡§ò‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ç‡§£, Skr. ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π as in ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ,

** ‡§®** Pr. and Skr. same.

‡§ï‡§∞ of ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç‡§®, Pr. ‡§ï‡§∞ as in ‡§ï‡§∞‡§á, Skr. ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø.

‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ, Pr. ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ, Skr. ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ.

** ‡§ó‡•á** of ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ, Pr. ‡§ó‡§Ö or ‡§ó‡§Ø,Skr.‡§ó‡§§.

** ‡§µ‡§°‡§ø‡§≤**, Pr. ‡§µ‡§°‡•ç‡§°‡•Ç, Sk. ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß, ‡§á‡§≤ being Prakrit suffix.

** ‡§ê‡§∏‡•á‡§Ç**, Apahhr. ‡§Ö‡§á‡§∏, Pr. ‡§à‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏ Skr. ‡§à‡§¶‡•É‡§∂.

** ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏** of ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§§ Pr. ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏ in ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∏‡§á Skr ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á.

( No. II)

** ‡§§‡•ã**, Apabhr. ‡§§‡§â, Pr. ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ, Skr. ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç.

** ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó**, Pr. ‡§≤‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó, Skr. ‡§≤‡§ó‡•ç‡§®.

** ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á**, Pr. ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á? Skr. ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø.

** ‡§™‡§°**, Pr. ‡§™‡§°, Bkr ‡§™‡§§‡•ç in ‡§™‡§§‡§§‡§ø.

** ‡§§‡•á**, from such Pr. and Skr. forms as ‡§§‡•á, ‡§§‡§Ç, ‡§§‡•á‡§£ or ‡§§‡•á‡§® &o.

** ‡§ï‡•á**. Pr. ‡§ï‡§Ø or ‡§ï‡§Ö, Shr. ‡§ï‡§ï for the crude ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ï‡§¶‡•ç.

** ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•Å‡§Ç**, Apabhr.‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§â‡§Ç, Pr. ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§Ö‡§Ç, Skr, ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç.

** ‡§è‡§µ‡•ã** sing of ‡§è‡§µ‡§æ, Apabhr. ‡§è‡§π‡•Å or ‡§è‡§π‡§â and ‡§Ö‡§á‡§∏‡•ã Pr.‡§á‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡•ã, Skr.‡§à‡§¶‡•É‡§∂.

‡§ï‡§∞ as in No. I.

** ‡§ö‡§æ‡§≤**, Pr. ‡§ö‡§≤, Skr. ‡§ö‡§≤.

** ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§†‡•ã**, Apabhr, ‡§¶‡§ø‡§†‡•ç‡§†‡§â, Pr. ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡•ç‡§ì Skr .‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡§É.

** ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç** Pr. ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§øSkr, ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç.

** ‡§Ü‡§Ø**, from Pr. ‡§Ü‡§Ö‡§ì, or Skr. ‡§Ü‡§ó‡§§‡§É.

** ‡§ï‡§π** Pr. ‡§ï‡§π Skr. ‡§ï‡§• us in ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø.

** ‡§õ‡•á**,Pr. ‡§Ü‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§á, Skr. ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á.

** ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞** of ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ, Apabhr. ‡§§‡•Å‡§π‡§æ‡§∞ for ‡§§‡•Å‡§π‡§Ü‡§∞, ‡§§‡•Å‡§π being the Skr. ‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç and ‡§Ü‡§∞, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞,

** ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ**, Pr. ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ, Skr. ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ.

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ**, Pr. ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ, Skr. ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑.

** ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞** of ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ, Apabhr. ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞ for ‡§Æ‡§π‡§Ü‡§∞, ‡§Æ‡§π heing the Pr. of Skr. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç and ‡§Ü‡§∞ for ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞.

** ‡§•‡§æ**, Pr. ‡§•‡§æ, Skr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ.

** ‡§™‡§£**, Pr. ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ã, Skr, ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É.

** ‡§ï‡•ã‡§£**, Pr. ‡§ï‡§â‡§£, Skr. ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®:

** ‡§Ü‡§™**, Pr. ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§™, Sikr, ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§™,

(No. III )

** ‡§®‡§æ** of ‡§®‡§æ‡§≤‡•á, Pr. and Skr. ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ, ‡§≤ being suffix.

** ‡§π‡•ã**, Apsbhr. ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ö‡§â, Pr. ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ö‡§ì, Skr. ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§É ( ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï‡§É).

‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§øof ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§ú‡•á, Pr. ‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç, Skr. ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç.

** ‡§≠‡•á‡§£‡•Å**, Pr.‡§≠‡§á‡§£‡•Ä, Skr. ‡§≠‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä.

** ‡§∏‡§æ‡§à‡§Ç**, Pr. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä, Skr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä.

** ‡§≠‡•Ç**of ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§ñ‡•á Apabhr. ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Å, Pr. ‡§Æ‡§π, Skr. ‡§Æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç.

** ‡§™‡•Å‡§¶‡•Å**, Pr. ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã, Skr. ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É.

** ‡§§‡•ã** of ‡§§‡•ã‡§ñ‡•á, Apabhr. ‡§§‡§â, Pr. ‡§§‡•Å‡§π, Skr. ‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç.

** ‡•ú‡•á**, Pr. ‡§¶‡§æ, Skr. ‡§¶‡§æ.

** ‡§∞‡§æ‡§á**, Pr. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ö-‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø-‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ü, Skr. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ.

** ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∞** of ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å, Pr. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç, Skr. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç.

** ‡§¨‡§°**, Pr. ‡§¨‡§°‡•ç‡§¢, Skr. ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß.

** ‡§≠‡§æ‡§â**, Pr. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§â‡§ì, Skr, ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ï‡§É.

** ‡§ö‡§µ‡§£**, from Pr. ‡§ö‡§µfor Skr. ‡§µ‡§ö.

** ‡§•‡§ø‡§Ö**, Pr. ‡§•‡§ø‡§Ö, Skr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§.

** ‡§∏‡•ã**, Pr. ‡§∏‡•ã, Skr. ‡§∏‡§É.

** ‡§ï‡•Ä**, Pr. ‡§ï‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç,Skr. ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç.

** ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§á**, Pr. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§á‡§Ü, Skr. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ï‡§æ.

** ‡§•‡•ã‡§∞‡•á, ‡§•‡•ã** from Pr. ‡§•‡•ã‡§Ö, Skr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§ï, and ‡§∞ or ‡§°, suffix.

** ‡§°‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§°**, Apahhr. ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ö‡§π‡§°, ‡§° being & termination often used, Pr. ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ö‡§π Skr. ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏.

** ‡§ú‡§£**, Pr. ‡§ú‡§£, Skr, ‡§ú‡§® of ‡§ú‡§®‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø.

( No. IV )

( No. VII )

** ‡§∂‡•Å‡§®** of ‡§∂‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¨‡•á or ‡§∂‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡•áas ‡§∏‡•Å‡§£ and ‡§∏‡•Å‡§® in Nos. 4 and 6.

** ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ**, Pr. ‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ö, Skr. ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø.

** ‡§Ü‡§õ‡•á** in ‡§õ‡§ø‡§≤, ‡§õ‡§ø‡§®‡•Å &o. Pr. ‡§Ü‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§á, Skr. ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á.

‡§∏‡•á, Pr. ‡§∏‡•ã, Skr. ‡§∏‡§É.

** ‡§Ü‡§∏** of ‡§Ü‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ, Pr. ‡§Ü‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ or ‡§Ü‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ, Skr. ‡§Ü‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ.

** ‡§¶‡•Å‡§á**, Pr. ‡§¶‡•Å‡§µ‡•á, Skr.‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á.

‡§ï‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ of ‡§ï‡§æ‡§õ‡•á, Pr. ‡§ï‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ, Skr. ‡§ï‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ.

** ‡§¨‡§∏** of ‡§¨‡§∏‡•á, Pr. ‡§â‡§µ‡§á‡§∏ Skr. ‡§â‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂.

** ‡§ï‡§π**, as in Nos. I, IV, and VI.

** ‡§¨‡§≤** or ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤ Pr.‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤, Skr. ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç.

** ‡§§‡§ø‡§®‡§ø**, Pr. ‡§§‡§æ‡§£ Skr. ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç, by analogy for ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç.

** ‡§∑‡•ã‡§≤**, Pr. ‡§∏‡•ã‡§≤‡§π, Skr. ‡§∑‡•ã‡§°‡§∂.

** ‡§§‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ** of ‡§§‡•ã‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡•á, Apabhr. ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§π‡§Ç, Pr. ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç, Skr. ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç, by analogy, for ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç,

** ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç**as in Nos. I, II, IV and VI.

** ‡§ó‡•á** or ‡§ó‡§Ø of ‡§ó‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§õ‡§ø rs in Nos. I and V.

** ‡§ú‡§æ** of ‡§ú‡§æ‡§¨, as in Nos. I and V.

** ‡§π‡§æ‡§§**, Pr. ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§•, Skr. ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§.

** ‡§§‡•ã** as in Nos

.

,

‡§¶‡§ø as ‡§¶‡•á in No.I.

(No. VIII)

** ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡§æ**, Pr. ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§Ö, Skr, ‡§Æ‡§∂‡§ï.

‡§¨‡§∏ of ‡§¨‡§∏‡§ø, as in No. VII.

** ‡§Ü‡§™‡§£‡§æ**, Pr. ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§£, Skr. ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç as in ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ &‡•¶.

** ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ù** of ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ù‡§ø Pr. ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù Skr. ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Øas in ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø.

** ‡§ï‡§π**as Nos. II, IV, V and VI.

** ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•á**, Ap‡•çabhr. ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§á, Pr. ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á, Skr. such & form as ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•á or ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á, for,‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ças in No. VII.

** ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠**as ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä in No. I.

** ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó**as in No. II, and as ‡§≤‡§ó‡•ç‡§óand ‡§≤‡§ó in Nos. IV and V.

** ‡§â‡§°** of ‡§â‡§°‡§ø, Pr. ‡§â‡§°‡•ç‡§°, Skr. ‡§â‡§°‡•ç‡§° ss in ‡§â‡§°‡•ç‡§°‡§Ø‡§§‡•á.

** ‡§ú‡§æ**as in Nos. I, V, and VII

** ‡§∂‡•Å‡§£** as in Nos. IV, VI, and VII.

** ‡§§‡•Å** as ‡§§‡•Ç‡§Ç in No. IV.

** ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ö** of ‡§™‡§æ‡§á, as ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶ in No. IV.

** ‡§ú‡•á**as in No. I.

** ‡§è,**Apabhr. ‡§è‡§π, Pr. ‡§è‡§π, Skr.‡§è‡§∑, as ‡§á‡§π in No. IV, and ‡§Ø‡§π in No. VI.

You will find that in the Marathi passage there are about 58 different words of which 26 or a few less than a half are derived from the Sanskrit through the Prakrits; in the Gujarati there are 42 out of which 23 or a few more than a half are of the latter description; in the Sindhi the proportion is 38 to 21, or somewhat greater than a half; in the Panjabi 44 to 23 or a half; in the High

Hindi 48 to 23 or a little less than a half; in the Braj 45 to 29, i. e. about two-thirds; in the Bengali 71 to 27. i. e, about two-fifths; and in the Oriya 32 to 15 or a little less than a half. I have not taken into consideration other words which do come to us undoubtedly through the Prakrits, but the etymology of which is not so obvious. These would increase the proportion and bring. it to more than one-half in most of the cases. In this list there are three or four words such as ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ, and ‡§µ‡§π, which may be called. old Tatsama, since they exist unchanged in the Prakrits, and the rest may be called cld Tadbhavas.

Now in these passages you will also have seen a large number of words such 36 ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§®‡§æ, ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂, ‡§Ü‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§®, ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï, ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞, ‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ, ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞, ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø, ‡§∂‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§® &c., which are exactly the same as in Sanskrit. They could not have existed in those forms in the Prakrits, and hence it is clear that they were introduced long after the Prakrit period; and the tendency now-a-days in our languages is to introduce more of such words. These may be called modern Tatsamas. But some of these have undergone a corruption since they were adopted. Thus ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ is pronounced ‡§ï‡§∞‡§Æ; ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ, ‡§ß‡§∞‡§Æ;‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø, ‡§ñ‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä; ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ú; and ‡§ï‡•É‡§™‡§æ, ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§æ or ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§æ while the Prakrit corruptions of these are ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ. ‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ, ‡§ñ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ö, ‡§ï‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, and ‡§ï‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ .Such words therefore are modern Tadbhavas.

At the end of my observations on the Prakrits in the last lecture, I gave a list of vocables existing in those dialects which are called De≈õyas by native grammarians, and showed that several of them existed in our vernaculars also. We observe from the above passages, which contain such words as ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§µ and ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§π ,that there are in the modern dialects words of an Arabic or Persian origin also. Thus we may distinguish these elements in the vocabulary of the vernaculars of Northern India:‚Äî1. Old Tadbhavs, 2. Old Tatsama, 3. Modern Tadbhava, 4. Modern Tatsama, 5. De≈õya, 6. Arabic, and 7. Persian.

In its nature the old Tatsama element is but a small quantity and the main skeleton of our languages is made up of the old Tadbhava. It forms the principal constituent of the speech of the middle classes. The higher classes, however, use the Modern Tatsama and Tadbhava element to a much larger extent; and

the language spoken by learned men is heavily loaded with pure Sanskrit words. This element has succeeded in driving out a very appreciable portion of the first in some of the languages. The Bengali contains the largest number of pure Sanskrit words, and hence one who knows Sanskrit can master the language in but a few weeks. The old Tadbhava element is reduced to the smallest minimum in what is called SƒÅdhu bhƒÅ·π£ƒÅor the speech of the educated. According to the extent of the modern Tatsama or Tadbhava element, the other languages may be arranged in the following order :‚ÄîOriya, Marathi, Hindi, Gujarati, Punjabi, Sindhi.

It must, however, he remarked that the modern Tatsamas appear in a pure or correct Sanskrit form only in the written language. The Bengalis in actually pronouncing these words. corrupt them in a manner which renders them unrecognizable as Sanskrit words; and often in the same way as the old Prakrit speakers did. Thus ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ is pronounced ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ. ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§á‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞, ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ, &c. The same is the case more or less with the speakers of the other languages, so that the pure Sanskrit words that we meet with in the written modern vernaculars, may be considered modern Tadbhavas and in rare cases Prakrit Tadbhavas. The educated classes, however, in Maharashtra and Gujarat, and to a certain extent in the Hindi provinces, pronounce the Sanskrit words correctly. The Sindi, however, contains but a few pure. Sanskrit words; hence it is rich in the old Tadbhava element, while it draws largely upon the Persian and Arabic.

This foreign element is used in our dialects, principally in political matters. Persian and Arabic words are also used in the concerns of ordinary life. but their number is limited. The higher classes and learned men very rarely use them; while that element enters largely into the speech of the Mahomedans in the different provinces and the Parsis. And the Mahomedans in the Hindi area use such a large number of these words that their language is by some considered an independent dialect and called Urdu, but it differs from the High Hindi in nothing further than in the use of these foreign words.

But though the vocabulary of our languages is thus composite,

the grammar is in every way the same that they have inherited from the Prakrits. Here there is no mixture of different elements. A good many of the forms now in use have been constructed since the Prakrit period; but, as I hope to show you, they are simply combinations or adaptations of existing Prakrit forms. Thus we will divide our examination of the vernaculars into three branches. (I) In the first we will trace out the Sanskrit words which were transformed in the Pali and the Prakrits in the various ways we have noticed, and discover the operation of the same or other laws in their further transformation, if they have undergone any, as also in the transformation of other words which remained unchanged in the Prakrits or were imported from Sanskrit at a later period. (II) In the second we will trace out the Prakrit or Apabhramsa grammatical forms (III) and in the third, examine the new or reconstructed forms and find out the principles upon which they have been made up.

The phonetic changes which the words of a living language undergo involve, as a general rule, economy of exertion in its widest sense; but there are some which do not, or which require increased effort. Economy may sometimes be effected in more ways than one. For instance, the assimilation of vowels to consonants may be effected by changing ‡§Ö to ‡§ì and thence to ‡§â, or to ‡§è and ‡§á. Some people have a predilection for the former, others for the latter. Again, one mode of change may be economical to some and another opposed to it to others. Thus the assimilation involved in the less open vowels ‡§á and ‡§â is of importance to some, but of little consequence to others; and they prefer the economy arising from the change of these vowels to ‡§Ö , since this does not require any movement of the tongue or the lips. Here then we have two kinds of peculiarities. Again, if an ordinary change has a very comprehensive range or is almost universal in a language, and if other ordinary changes do not keep pace with it, and are to be found only in a limited number of instances, that ordinary change must be considered to be due to a peculiar vocal habit or incapacity. The assimilation of conjuncts and of the diphthongs in the Pali and the Prakrits, and the elision of uninitial consonants in the latter, are changes of this nature. And finally, there is all the greater reason

for attributing changes that involve no economy or necessitate greater exertion, such as the change of dentals to cerebrals or of sonants to surds, to vocal peculiarities. These several kinds of peculiarities give distinct individualities, so far as the external forms of words are concerned, to languages derived from one and the same primitive language. Thus then, some phonetic changes are special or peculiar, and others ordinary.

We will now take up in order the instances observable in the Pali and the Prakrits of these two kinds of changes and trace them in the vernaculars, and also endeavour to find out whether these dialects have preserved any of the Pali and Prakrit peculiarities or developed new ones.

And first as regards vowels. The following are some of the in- stances with the vernacular forms of the words in which Sanskrit is ‡§ã changed to ‡§Ö ,‡§á , or ‡§â in the Prakrits:‚Äî

The word ‡§ò‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç has ‡§ò‡§Ö‡§Ç in the Prakrits according to the grammarians, but ‡§ò‡§ø‡§Ö‡§Ç also must have existed; so also ‡§≠‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó has ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã.

Some of the above words have two forms in the Prakrits, but since one of them does not occur in any of the vernaculars, it has been omitted. There are other words having two or even threePrakrit forms, one of which occurs in one of the vernaculars, and the other or others in another. Thus:‚Äî

___________________________________________________________________________

1. Mr. Beams considers the ‡§â of the S.‡§™‡§ø‡§â, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§â &c.,to be the nom, sing, termination and not a transformation of the Sanskrit. But he is evidently wrong, since this ‡§â appears in the oblique cases also, as‡§™‡§ø‡§â‡§ú‡•ã, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§â‡§ú‡•ã. &c.; while the nom. sing ‡§â does not, as in ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§ú‡•ã , icon. sing of ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•Å “a country”. The words have ‡§â even in those language, such as the P. and M., which have discarded the nom. sing. ‡§â and it appears even in the feminine word ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§â which cannot take the masculine termination ‡§â.

** {**M. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø and G.P.H. B.O. ‡§Æ‡§æ are from Pr. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ü,Skr. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ï‡§É brother, Pr.{‡§≠‡§æ‡§á‡§ì, G. S. P. H. B. O ‡§≠‡§æ‡§á or ‡§≠‡§æ‡§à,‡§≠‡§æ‡§â‡§ì, M.S.P ‡§≠‡§æ‡§âor ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ä.

As the Pali and the Prakrit alphabet, on account of these changes, has no ‡§ã, so do the vernacular alphabets not possess it. Sanskrit words containing the vowel have, however, been recently imported into the languages, but since even in those words, it is not correctly pronounced except by a few learned men, it cannot be said really to exist in vernacular speech, notwithstanding the use of those words. The usual modern pronunciation of the vowel is ‡§∞, ‡§∞‡§ø, ‡§∞‡•Å, or ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç.

____________________________________________________________________________________________

*

‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó ‡§ï‡•à‡§≤ ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ B. MahƒÅbhƒÅrata.

Another characteristic change we noticed in the Prakrits is the softening ‡§á and ‡§â to ‡§è and ‡§ì before double consonants. A good many words so changed have descended to the vernaculars. Thus:‚Äî

[Table 5: Skr. ‡§áand ‡§â softened before conjuncts]

Skr ‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡§É red lead, Pr. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ãor ‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ã, M. ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞, H. ‡§∏‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞, G. B. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞, S. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ß‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å.

‡§™‡•á‡§Ç‡§°‡§æ-‡§™‡•á‡§Ç‡§°‡•Ä, H.P. ‡§™‡§ø‡§Ç‡§°‡§æ, G. ‡§™‡§ø‡§Ç‡§°‡•ã, S. ‡§™‡§ø‡§Ç‡§°‡•ã or ‡§™‡§ø‡§Ç‡§°‡•Ä.

Skr. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§Éa mallet, Pr. ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡•ã, M. H. ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ó‡§∞‡§æ, G. ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ó‡§∞, S‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ô‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã, B. O.

Skr. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç value, Pr. ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§Ç, H. M. ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§≤, O. ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤, G. ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§≤.

Skr. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ a kind of grass, Pr. ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ, M. ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§•‡§æ in ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ã‡§•‡§æ, H. P. ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§•‡§æ S. G. ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§•, D. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§•‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Éfree, Pr. ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•ã, M. P. ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï in ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ, G. ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡§Ç in ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡§≤‡•Å‡§Ç, . S ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡§≤, O. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§ó‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ a bunch, Pr. ‡§ó‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ã, B .‡§ó‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø, ‡§ó‡•Å‡§õ‡§ø,or ‡§ó‡•ã‡§õ‡§æ, O. ‡§ó‡•ã‡§õ, M. ‡§ò‡•ã‡§Ç‡§∏, H. P. ‡§ó‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ, G. ‡§ó‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ãS. ‡§õ‡•Å‡§ó‡•ã( by transposition ) or ‡§ó‡•ã‡§∂.

Skr ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡§É elbow, Pr. ‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ã, M. ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞, G. ‡§ï‡•ã‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§Ç.

Skr. ‡§∂‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ the trunk of an elephant, Pr, ‡§∏‡•ã‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ,M. ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ç‡§°, P. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Ç‡§°, H. ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§° or ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§¢, G. ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§¢, S. ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§¢‡§ø.

Skr. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Æ‡•ç apuddle, Pr. ‡§ï‡•ã‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§Ç M. ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç‡§°, G. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§°‡•Ä, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§°‡•Å‡§Ç.

Skr. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§ßfoolish, Pr. ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§ßor‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó, H. P. ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ß‡•Ç, S.‡§≠‡•å‡§Ç‡§¢‡•Ç, ‡§Æ‡•å‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ã, M. ‡§≠‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¢‡•Ç ?

Skr. ‡§§‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶a pot-belly, Pr. ‡§§‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§¶, H. P. ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶,M. ‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶, G. ‡§¶‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶.

The G. ‡§ì‡§ö‡§∞‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç’to pronounce’ from Skr. and Pr. ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ì‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ó‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç‚Äòto transgress‚Äô from Skr. Pr. ‡§â‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò, G, ‡§ì‡§ï‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç M. ‡§ì‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•á, H. ‡§ì‡§ï‡§®‡§æ ’to vomit’from Pr. ‡§â‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞, Skr. ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞, are also later instances of the operstion of the same law.

The change of ‡§á to ‡§è, according to the grammarians, optional in the Prakrits and that of ‡§âto ‡§ìnecessary. But in both cases we find two forms in the vernaculars. Still the prevailing forms in the latter are those in ‡§ì, while those in ‡§âare rare, and mostly to be found in Bengali and Oriya, which languages, and more especially the first, have a predilection for ‡§â, in which case it is possible they may have changed the Prakrit ‡§ìto ‡§â.

In the Pali and Prakrits, the‡§èand ‡§ì in these cases are short; but the vernaculars, having dropped one of the following double consonants, have, according to a general rule to be noticed hereafter, lengthened the vowels. When instead of a double consonant, there is a conjunct of a nasal and a mute as in ‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞and ‡§§‡•ã‡§£‡•ç‡§°the nasal consonant is reduced to a simple anusvƒÅra or nasal sound, so as to give to the conjunct the character of a simple consonant, and the ‡§è or ‡§ì is pronounced long as in ‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞and ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç‡§°. In this manner, though the Prakrit short ‡§è and ‡§ìare, in the instances in which we possess an evidence of their existence, lengthened, I think in some of the vernaculars at least we have these vowels. For in a good many instances in Marathi and Gujarati and air are pronounced short. There is a rule which in Marathi is almost universal, and in Gujarati often observable, in virtue of which the accent or the whole weight of the sound of a word falls on the final ‡§Üor ‡§è‡§Ç of nouns in the former, and the final ‡§ì or ‡§ä‡§Ç in the latter; and the preceding vowels are rendered short while in the original Sanskrit and in Hindi they are long. Thus:‚Äî

**\[Table 6: Treatment of long vowels in Prakrit and Modern Vernaculars\]**

Skr. ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ü‡§ï: a worm, Pr. ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§°‡§ì, H. ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§°‡§æ, M. ‡§ï‡§ø‡§°‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§≤‡§ï‡§É a nsil, Pr. ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§≤‡§ì, H. ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ, M. ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§É well, Pr, ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§µ‡§ì, H. ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§Ü, G. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§µ‡•ã.

Skr. ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§É leopard, Pr. ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§ì, H. ‡§ö‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ, M. ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡§æ, G. ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ã.

Skr. ‡§ö‡•Ç‡§°‡§ï‡§É a bangle, Pr. ‡§ö‡•Ç‡§°‡§ì, H. ‡§ö‡•Ç‡§°‡§æ, M, ‡§ö‡•Å‡§°‡§æ, G. ‡§ö‡•Å‡§°‡•ã.

Skr. ‡§ö‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ï: lime, Pr. ‡§ö‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ö‡§ì, H. ‡§ö‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ, M. ‡§ö‡•Å‡§®‡§æ, G, ‡§ö‡•Å‡§®‡•ã.

And many more instances might be given. Similarly in Marathi the preceding long vowels are shortened when the terminations of the oblique cases are applied, as in ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§∏,‡§™‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏,‡§ï‡§ø‡§°‡•Ä‡§∏,

‡§™‡§ø‡§†‡§æ‡§∏, ‡§â‡§®‡§æ‡§∏, ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•á‡§∏, ‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏, &o., dative singulars of ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§ï ‘beggery,’ ‡§™‡•Ä‡§ï ‘c–≥–æ—Ä,’ ’ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§° ‚Äô,a worm, ‚Äô ‡§™‡•Ä‡§† ‚Äô ‘flour’,‚Äô ‡§ä‡§® ‚Äô sun, ‚Äô‡§≠‡•Ç‡§ï‚Äô ‚Äôhunger,‚Äô ‚Äô‡§ó‡•Ç‡§≤‚Äô ‚Äômolasse‚Äô, &c. If so, then by a necessary law of Marathi speech, the ‡§è and ‡§ì of ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤ ‚Äô gone’, ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤ ‚Äôgone’ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§≤‡§æ ‚Äôa gathering’ ‡§ú‡•á‡§µ‡§¢‡§æ‚Äô as much’ ‡§™‡•á‡§°‡§æ ‚Äôsweetmeat’ ‡§ò‡•ã‡§° ‚Äô a horse’, ‡§ï‡•ã‡§≤‡§∏‡§æ ‘charcoal’, ‡§ó‡•ã‡§´‡§æ ‚Äô the ankle,’ ‡§ú‡•ã‡§°‡§æ’ a pair,’ &c., and of ‡§∂‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§∏, to Gowdung,’ ‡§∂‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§∏ ’to a field,‘‡§™‡•á‡§†‡•á‡§∏ ’to a market, ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏ ’to a child,” ‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡§æ‡§∏ ’to a race, ‡§ö‡•ã‡§∞‡§∏ ’to a thief,’ ‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ ’to a boy, &c., must be short. And if the Marathi speaker will compare his pronunciation. of ‡§Æ‡•á‡§≤, ‡§∂‡•á‡§§, ‡§∂‡•á‡§£, ‡§ó‡•ã‡§§, ‡§™‡•ã‡§∞, &c. with that of ‡§Æ‡•á‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§∂‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ, ‡§∂‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§∏, ‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡§æ‡§∏, , &c., he will find that the quantity of ‡§è and ‡§ì in these latter words is shorter than in the former. Similarly, in Gujarati the first ‡§è and ‡§ì of ‡§ï‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä ‘how large,

‡§™‡•á‡§≤‡•ã mad man, ‡§õ‡•ã‡§°‡•ã ‚Äôend,’ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§≤‡•ã ‚Äôupper storey,’ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§≤‡•ã ‚Äôa gathering’ ‡§ñ‡•á‡§≤‡•ã lap,‡§ò‡•ã‡§¢‡•ã a horse ‡§ö‡•ã‡§ñ‡§æ.pl, ‘rice,’ ‡§™‡•ã‡§≤‡•ã ‘broad,’ ‡§™‡•ã‡§£‡§æ. pl ’three-quarters,” ’ ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ó‡§∞‡•ã ‚Äô jessamine‚Äô, ‡§ï‡•ã‡§≤‡§∏‡•ã ‚Äôcharcoal‚Äô, &c., must be short. In Gujarati the penultimate vowel of a monosyllabic root is, as in Hindi, shortened in the causal, as in ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§¶‡•Å‡§Ç ’to adhere,’ ‡§≤‡§ó‡§æ‡§°‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç to cause to adhere,’ ‘join,” ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§°‡•Å‡§Ç ’ to run,’ ‡§ß‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç to cause to run, ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ñ‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç ’to learn,’ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¨‡§¨‡•Å‡§Ç to teach,’ ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§¶‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç ’to sew,’ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç ’to cause to sew,

‡§¨‡•Ä‡§π‡§°‡•Å‡§Ç ’to fear,

’ ‡§™‡§ø‡§π‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç ’to terrify,’ &o. But in Hindi the short vowels that take the place of ‡§è and ‡§ì are‡§á and ‡§â, as in ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§® ‚Äô to show‚Äô from ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ’to see,‚Äô ‡§ò‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‚Äôto caus to wash’ from ‡§ò‡•ã‡§®‡§æ ’to wash,’ &c. But in Gujarati the ‡§è and ‡§ì are not changed to ‡§á and ‡§â but remain, as in ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§°‡•Å‡§Ç ’to show ‘, ‡§≤‡•á‡§™‡§æ‡§°‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç ’to cause to take’ from ‡§≤‡•á‡§ö‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç to take,‡§ú‡•ã‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç ’to cause to wash from ‡§ò‡•ã‡§¨‡§ö‡•Å‡§Ç ’to wash,’ ‡§ú‡•ã‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡§¨‡•Å‡§Ç ’ to show from ‡§ú‡•ã‡§¨‡§°‡•Å‡§Ç fo take.’ ‡§ß‡•ã‡§¨‡§æ‡§¢‡§µ‡•Ç‡§Ç ’ ‡§ú‡•ã‡§µ‡§°‡•Å‡§Ç ’to see,’ &c., which they cannot do by the general rule if they are long. They must therefore be pronounced short. And as a matter of fact, it will be found that the Gujarati people in these and several other cases, give a short sound to these vowels. In the Malvani dialect of Marathi ‡§ì is very often pronounced like the English o in pot, and ‡§è like e in pet. In Bengali the ‡§ì to which ‡§Ö is converted in ordinary speech is also broad and short, and we have reason to believe that both ‡§è and ‡§ì when they really occur in words, are often pronounced short in that and the Bhojpuri and other dialects of Bihar and Mithila,

It may be urged against one of the arguments I have used, that if the ‡§è and ‡§ì in ‡§∂‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§∏ and ‡§ó‡•ã‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ are short, the first ‡§Üin.

‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏ ’to the hand,’ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§∏ ’to the ear,’ &c., must also be short, and consequently these vowels must be changed to ‡§Ö . But ‡§Ö is not necessarily the short form of ‡§Ü, or ‡§Ü the long form of ‡§Ö. For in pronouncing ‡§Üthe lips and the upper and lower parts of the mouth are much more widely apart from each other than in pronouncing ‡§Ö ; so that the difference between the two is not simply of quantity but of quality also. The first ‡§Ü of such words as ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏ and ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§≤‡§æ ‘maddened, is therefore short ‡§Ü; that is, in pronouneing it, the vocal organs are in the same condition as in pionouncing long ‡§Ü, but the time occupied is shorter than in the case of the latter. The ‡§Ö that we have got in Sanskrit is short, but in most of the vernaculars we have a long ‡§Ö which takes longer time to pronounce than the Sanskrit ‡§Ö , while the oondition of the vocal organs is the same. The final ‡§Ö of words is silent in the vernaculars, but at the same time the vowel of the preceding syllable is lengthened. Thus ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£ ’ virtue’ ‘is, as a Sanskrit word, pronounced g≈´·πáa, but in Marathi and Gujarati it i

s

g≈´·πá

; and in Hindi

g≈´·πá

;

Sanskrit ‡§ó‡•Å‡§°gu-·∏ça ‘molasses’ is in Marathi g≈´l; Sanskrit e ‡§§‡§ø‡§≤ti-la ‘sesamum’ is in Marathi and Gujarati tƒ´l and Hindi til. In the same way, the word ‡§∞‡§• is in Sanskrit pronounc ed ra-tha, but when in vernacular pronunciation it becomes rath, the a is not the short ‡§Ö , but ‡§Ö pronounced long, as if the word were ra-ath without a pause between the two as. The long ‡§Ö and the short are found side by side in such a word as ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§®, which as pronounced in Sanskrit is madana with three consonants each followed by the Sanskrit or short ‡§Ö. In the modern languages, however, the first syllable has its as in Sanskrit, but that of the second is lengthened, and in the last it is dropped, and the word thus becomes madaan.

This peculiarity of softening ‡§á and ‡§â to ‡§è and ‡§ì has been pre- served by the vernaculars. It is not necessary that a conjunct consonant should follow. Thus:-

[Table 7 change of ‡§á and ‡§â short ‡§è and ‡§ì in Modern Vernaculars. ]

Hindustani

** ‡§¨‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§æ** or ‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§æ to mock, from Skr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§°‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®.

** ‡§¨‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§®** or ‡§¨‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§® morning, from Skr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡§Æd, Pr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç.

‡§®‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ invitation from Pr. ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§Skr. ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞.

‡§∏‡•ã‡§π‡§∞ plensing, from Skr. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§ï‡§∞, Pr. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡§Ö‡§∞.

‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡§® or ‡§∏‡•ã‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡§® agreeable, from Pr. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡§® for such a Sunskrit form as ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§™‡§®.

‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§∞‡§æ or ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æfront or van-guard the first part of which is from Pr. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π, Skr.‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ;

‡§â‡§ñ‡§≤ or‡§ì‡§ñ‡§≤ a wooden mortar, from Skr.‡§â‡§≤‡•Ç‡§ñ‡§≤.

Gujarati

‡§Æ‡•ã‡§πin ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§°‡•Å‡§Ç face, from Pr. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π, Skr. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ.

‡§≠‡•ã‡§Øground, the M. and H. form being ‡§≠‡•Å‡§à.

‡§ì‡§∞ in ‡§ì‡§∞‡§°‡§æ, Pr. ‡§â‡§µ‡§∞‡§ì, Skr. ‡§â‡§™‡§∞‡§ï‡§É or ‡§Ö‡§™‡§µ‡§∞‡§ï‡§É; ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§∞ a family priest from Skr. Pr. ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å.

Marathi

‡§Æ‡•á‡§π‡•Å‡§£ a couple, from Pr. ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π‡•Å‡§£, Skr. ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§•‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§µ‡•á‡§°‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•á to mock, Skr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§°‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§®; ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ç‡§°‡•Ä the lock of hair on the head, from Pr. **‡§∂‡§ø‡§π‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§Ö,**Skr. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ; ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§∞‡•á or ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•ã‡§∞‡•á in front of which ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π is from ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π as above; ‡§ì‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä ( dial. ) from Pr. ‡§â‡§µ‡§∞‡§ì as above; ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§°‡§æ or ‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡§°‡§æ& kind of flower.

Panjabi

‡§µ‡§ø‡§π or ‡§µ‡•á‡§π poison, from Pr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏, Skr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑; ‡§™‡§ø‡§â or ‡§™‡•á‡§âfather, for Pr. ‡§™‡§ø‡§â‡§ì, Skr. ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§ï; ‡§®‡•á‡§â‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ invitation from Pr. ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§, Skr. ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞; ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§∞ van-guard, as above; ‡§ì‡§°‡§ï end, from Pr. ‡§â‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï , Skr. ‡§â‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï.

Bengali

‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞ door, for Pr. ‡§¶‡•Å‡§Ü‡§∞; ‡§õ‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ a razor, for Pr. ‡§õ‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ì, Skr. ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∞‡§ï‡§É; B. 0.‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ö mustache, for ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§õ, Pr. ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•Ç . Skr.‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§É; ‡§∂‡•ã‡§® or ‡§∂‡•Å‡§® a to hear, for Pr. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§£; ‡§∂‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤ or ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤ jackal, for Pr. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ü‡§≤‡•ã, Skr. ‡§∂‡•É‡§ó‡§æ‡§≤‡§É.

The ‡§è and ‡§ì , to which ‡§á and ‡§â are thus reduced must be short, since there is no reason here why the quantity should be increased.

Of the instances in which long ‡§à and ‡§ä are softened to long ‡§è and ‡§ì in the Prakrits, the vernaculars have retained the following:‚Äî

[Table 8: change of ‡§à and ‡§ä to long ‡§è and ‡§ì]

Skr. ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡§ï myrobalan, Pr. ‡§¨‡§π‡•á‡§°‡§ì, M. ‡§¨‡•á‡§π‡§°‡§æ, G. ‡§¨‡•á‡§π‡§°‡•Ç‡§Ç. H. P. ‡§¨‡§π‡•á‡§°‡§æ,S. ‡§¨‡§π‡•á‡§°‡•å.

Skr. ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Ç‡§≤ betel leaf, Pr. ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤, H. P. ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤ M. ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤, in ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡•Ä aseller of betel leaves, G.‡§§‡§Ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤ in ‡§§‡§Ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡•Ä.

Skr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ç‡§≤, Pr. ‡§•‡•ã‡§∞, M. ‡§•‡•ã‡§∞.

G. ‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡§µ‡•Ç‡§Ç to scatter from Pr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§á‡§∞ Skr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞.

Of the few instances in which ‡§á is softened to ‡§Ö in the Prakrits, the vernaculars have retained ‡§π‡§≤‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ in the M. G ‡§π‡§≤‡§¶, H. ‡§π‡§≤‡§¶‡•Ä, 0. ‡§π‡§≤‡§¶‡•Ä and P. ‡§π‡§≤‡§π‡§¶‡•Ä or ‡§π‡§≤‡§¶‡•Ä. Though ‡§™‡§°‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§Ü does not occur, still ‡§™‡§°‡§æ which stands for ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø a in this word is preserved in several words, as M. ‡§™‡§°‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶ ,’echo’ for Skr. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶, ‡§™‡§°‡§ú‡•Ä‡§≠, ’the uvula’ for Skr. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§π‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ,, ‡§™‡§°‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ Or ‡§™‡§°‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•Ä, H. ‡§™‡§∞‡§õ‡§æ‡§à for Skr. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ &o. No more instances of this change are given by the grammarians, but, as observed in the last lecture, the substitution of ‡§Ö for ‡§á or ‡§â in one of the two or more places in which it occurs in some words indicates a tendency in the Prakrits towards this change. The vernaculars have got more instances.Thus:‚Äî

[Table 10: ‡§á changed to ‡§Ö]

M. G. S. ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ñ examination, test, H. P. B. O.‡§™‡§∞‡§ñ, Skr.‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ pr. ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ; also the verb ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ñ‡§£‡•á‡§Ç.

** **M. H. G. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ñ‡§∞‡§£‡•á-‡§®‡§æ-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç. P. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§∞‡§®‡§æ to scatter, Skr. ‡§¨‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞, Pr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§ø‡§∞ (S. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ñ‡•á‡§∞‡§£‡•Å‡§Ç ).
