The gods made Bhava the archer, the protector of the VrƒÅtyas, or outcasts, in the intermediate space of the eastern region, ≈öarva of the southern region, Pa≈õupati of the western region. Ugra of the northern region, Rudra of the lower region, MahƒÅdeva of the upper region, and ƒ™≈õƒÅnaof all the intermediate regions (XV. 5.1-7).

¬ß 81. In SB. (VL 1.3.7) and KB. (6.1.9), Rudra is mentioned as the son of U·π£as; and, after he was born, PrajƒÅpati gave him, as he grew up, eight names, seven of which are the same as those. given above from the AV. and the eighth is A≈õani, or the thunderbolt. It would be seen that the AV. regards the seven as different though allied gods, though once Rudra is identified with Pa≈õupati. As in the case of the sun-god, the several ways of looking at him gave rise to the conception of several sun-deities. such as Savit·πõ, S≈´rya, Mitra, P≈´·π£an, etc., so the same terrible and destructive agency in nature, with its benignant and gracious counterpart, looked at from different points of view, gave rise to the belief in the seven different gods mentioned in the AV. They are all regarded as the names of one god in the ≈öB. and KB., and an eighth name is introduced. Of these eight names, four-Rudra, ≈öarva, Ugra and A≈õani, are indicative of the destructive energy, and the other four, viz., Bhava, Pa≈õupati, MahƒÅdeva or MahƒÅn deva·∏•, and ƒ™≈õƒÅna of its beginant counterpart.

It will have been observed that the AV. brings in A Dew element, that of poisons, which the terrific god was believed to send forth and of his shafts being unfailing or the and unavoidable by gods and men. On the other, benignant side, Bhava is represented to be a shining king (RƒÅjan). Rudra is the lord of all creatures. His range is far and wide. He controls the stars and the moon. He reigns in the sky and the middle regions. He is in fire and water, in plants and herbs, and in all beings; and he is the protector of VrƒÅtyas in all quarters; and he is pre-eminently the ruler (ƒ™≈õƒÅna).

Thus the terrible and the destructive God became, when he was propitiated by men in a variety of ways, a benignant God and attained to the whole majesty of the godhead by the time of the YV. and AV., and it is on this majestic form of the god that the theosophic speculations of ≈öU., which we will notice further on, are based.

¬ß 82. But the darker side of the nat are of this god was never forgotten. A sacrifice called ≈ö≈´lagava is mentioned in most of the G·πõhyas≈´tras. A bull is sacrificed to Rudra to appease him. (AG. IV. 9). The rite should be performed beyond the limits. of a village, and its remains should not be brought into it, which rule sufficiently indicates the inauspicious character of the rite. The VapƒÅ, or omentum, should be sacrificed to Rudra by uttering. twelve names, seven of which are the same as the first three in the first group given above, and the four in the second group. A≈õani is omitted, and we have the following five additional names, Hara, M·πõ·∏ça, ≈öiva, Bhƒ´ma, and ≈öa·πÅkara. Or the VapƒÅmay be thrown into the fire by uttering six specific names only or the single name Rudra. This ≈ö≈´lagava sacrifice should be performed in a cow-shed when a cattle disease has to be averted. In PG. (III, 8) the names uttered in throwing the oblations are the wives, IndrƒÅ·πáƒ´, RudrƒÅ·πáƒ´, ≈öarvƒÅ·πáƒ´, and BhavƒÅnƒ´. HG. (II. 3. 8) has the same deities as the eight above-mentioned, Bhƒ´ma being substituted for A≈õani; and oblations are given to the wife of each by repeating the formula " Bhavasya devasya patnyai svƒÅhƒÅ" (to the wife of God Bhava) etc.,and not by uttering their proper names.

Directions are given in PG. (III. 15) to render obeisance to Rudra and pray for safe conduct when traversing a path, coming to a place where four roads meat, crossing a river, getting into a ferry-boat, entering a forest, ascending a mountain, passing by a cemetery or by a cow-shed and such other places. Similarly HG.( I. 5. 16) directs that a traveller should adore Rudra by repeating the specific formula given by him, when he comes to the crossing. of four roads or to a heap of cattle-dung, when serpents creep, and when he is overtaken by tornado, or is entering a river, or comes to a variegated scene, sacrificial site or an old large tree.

It will thus be seen that, in the time of the G·πõhyas≈´tras, Rudra was still a terrible god, who had to be appeased. He was the god that held sway over regions away from home, over fields, wildernesses, cemeteries, mountains, old trees and rivers. Whenever a man came to anything which inspired awe and terror, Rudra was the god thought of and prayed to protect. Herein lies the reason which rendered him in later times the omnipresent supreme lord of the universe to the exclusion of all other Vedio gods except Vi·π£·πáu. Many are the occasions in the life of man, which excite fear; there are epidemic and other diseases, poisons, serpents, storms, thunderbolts and wild and awful scenes, and consequently, the god who brings on these occasions, and protects when appeased, will be thought of oftener than other gods. The lovableness of the works of God, his greatness and majesty and his mysterious nature, are also matters which strike the mind of man; and these appear to have operated in bringing Vi·π£·πáu into prominence.

What contributed to the formation of Vai·π£·πáavism were the appearances and occurrences which excited love, admiration and a spirit of worship; while in Rudra-≈öaivism the sentiment of fear is at the bottom, howsoever concealed it may have become in certain developments of it, and this sentiment it is that has worked itself out in the formation of various Rudra-≈öaiva systems of later times. In the monotheistic religions of other countries. the same god is feared and loved; in India the god that is loved. in Vi·π£·πáu-NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa-VƒÅsudeva-K·πõ·π£·πáa, while the god that is feared. is Rudra-≈öiva.

III. ≈övetƒÅ≈õvatara and Atharva≈õiras Upani·π£ads.

¬ß 83. Before we proceed to the consideration of the Rudra-≈öiva sects, we must devote some time to the consideration of a religio-philosophic treatise which represents the farthest point in the development of the idea of Rudra-≈öiva god worshipped by the Indian ƒÄryas generally. This is the ≈övetƒÅ≈õvatara-Upani·π£ad. It does not appear to be composed in a sectarian spirit. The elevated notions about the nature of God and his relations to man and the world, which had been reached in the time of the early Upani·π£ads, have been disentangled from

their connection with the impersonal Brahman and transferred to the God who had at the time when the Upani·π£ads were written, acquired a living and active personality in the minds of the people. This god was Rudra-≈öiva, who, as we have seen, had by the time of AV. attained to the dignity of the supreme god.

After the preliminaries, the doctrinal points that occur in the first chapter are these: that there are three unborn. elements in the world of these the all-knowing and the ignorant, the ruler and the ruled, are two, and there is a third which has in itself materials of enjoyment and suffering (9). Brahman is of three kinds, viz., the sufferer or enjoyer, what is enjoyed or suffered, and the dispenser or mover. There is nothing further to be known (12). PradhƒÅna is changeable, the immortal is unchangeable; Hara, the one lord, rules over the changeable and the soul. By meditating on him, by devoting oneself to him, by realising him, the whole ignorance is dispelled (10). By making one’s body the lower block of wood, the syllable “Om” the upper, and by the act of meditation, which is (like) the rubbing of the two blocks against each other, one should perceive the hidden god (14). One finds that soul in oneself who seeks him by means of truth and exertion, as oil in seeds, butter in curds, or water in a spring (15).

The three elements mentioned in 9 and 12 are adopted by RƒÅmƒÅnuja in his system, and these texts are quoted by writers of that school. What is set forth in the tenth is similar to that which occurs in the sixteenth and seventeeth verses of chap. 15 of the BhG.

In the second chapter there is first of all a short mention of the Yoga processes, which lead to the perception of the supreme soul and the purity of the self. When by the purified nature of the individual self, as by a lamp, is known the nature of Brahman, or the god who is unborn, unchangeable, pure in every way, one is free from all bondage (15). The chapter closes with the verse which we have noticed as occurring in the AV.

In the third chapter, we have in the beginning a stanza which sets forth that those become immortal who know him who possessing a net, rules by his ruling powers, rules over all the worlds by

his ruling powers, who alone is the cause of production and growth (1). There is only one Rudra‚Äîand they do not recognise another‚Äî who rules these worlds by his ruling powers, who is the inmost soul of all men, who contracts everything on the final day, and, creating all beings, protects them (2). He has his eyes everywhere, his face everywhere, as in RV. X. 81. 3 (3). May Rudra, the cause of the production and growth of the gods, the lord of the universe, the great prophet, and who formerly created Hira·πáyagarbha, endow us with a holy will (4). Then follow two verses from the ≈öatarudriya, praying Rudra to look at the singer with his gracious countenance and not to do harm to men, etc. (5, 6). Knowing the lord (ƒ™≈õa), who is the highest Brahman and the greatest of all, who dwells in the inside of all beings whatever their form, and who encompasses the whole universe, men become immortal (7). Then follow similar verses expressive of the attributes of the supreme God and prescribing a knowledge of him as the door to immortality.

As formerly remarked71,a verse and a half in this chapter occurs word for word in the thirteenth chap, of the BhG. It also deserves remark that the proper names of the supreme being that occur are ƒ™≈õƒÅna, ƒ™≈õa, and ≈öiva, and the epithet BhƒÅgavat, that is used also, deserves notice (11, 12, 15, 17, 20). In verso 20, which occurs also in the MU., there is ƒ™≈õam for ƒÄtmana·∏•which is indicative of the peculiarity of this Upani·π£adwhich we have noticed. There are two verses from the Puru·π£as≈´kta (RV. X. 90),

The fourth chapter opens with the expression of the desire that he who, himself being without form, creates many forms with a certain purpose, in whom in the end as well as in the beginning the universe exists, may endow the adorers with a holy will. Then follows the identification of this supreme soul with fire, sun, wind, moon and a variety of other objects (2-4). We have then the metaphor of one male goat lying down with the female goat and another male goat abandoning her after enjoyment, which represents the soul in the worldly and the delivered conditions (5).

We have next the verse about two birds, the friends and companions of each other, resting on the same tree, one eating the fruit of that tree, and the other simply looking on without eating, which occurs in the RV. (I. 164. 20) and in the MU. (III. 1. 1). The next verse about the weak soul being deluded and in grief and being delivered from his sorrows when he sees the other. soul, who is the ruler (ƒ™≈õa), occurs in the MU. also (III. 1. 2) but not in the RV.

After two verses there is another, in which MƒÅyƒÅ is called Prak·πõti and he who uses this MƒÅyƒÅ is called Mahe≈õvara (10). Mahe≈õvara is a name of ≈öiva. Having known the boon-giver, ƒ™≈õƒÅna, who presides over every productive organ and in whom and from whom are all things, one attains eternal peace or serenity (11) Then there is a repetition here of a verse in the previous chapter (III4), with an unimportant difference of reading (12). Then occurs the second part of the verse in IV., which represents Hira·πáyagarbha to be the lord of two-footed and four-footed animals (X. 121.3), the first part of the latter being paraphrased here (13). This verse was probably suggested by the occurrence of the name of Hira·πáyagarbha in the previous verse.

Having known ≈öiva (the auspicious), who is minuter than the minute, the creator of the universe, of many forms, and who alone encompasses the universe in this medley of the world, one attains eternal peace (14). That same lord of the universe concealed in all objects is the protector of the world in time. Devoting themselves to him and knowing him thus, the Brahmar·π£is and the deities out away nooses of death (15). Knowing ≈öiva, concealed in all beings, who is as subtle as the essence of milk, other than the butter, knowing the god who alone encompasses the universe, one is free from all nooses (16). This god‚Äîthis great soul‚Äîwhose work is the universe always dwells in the hearts of men. He is determined by the heart, the intelligence, and internal consciousness; those who know this become immortal (17).

When there was simple darkness and no. day or light, no entity or non-entity, ≈öiva alone existed. He was the one unchangeable thing, and he was the bright light of the sun,

and from him sprang all intelligence (18). Here appears anides similar to that expressed in RV. X. 129. No one can seize. him above, transversely or in the middle. There is not another like him. Great is his glory (19). His form is invisible. Nobody sees him with the eye. Those who see him, dwelling in the heart, by the heart and the internal consciousness, become immortal (20). This verse is the same as in KU. (VI.9), excepting in the third. line, which there is the same as the third line of v. 17 above. The chapter ends with two verses containing a prayer to Rudra to proteot, the latter of which is the same as RV. I. 114. 8.

In the first verse of the fifth chapter are mentioned two indestructible beings, Brahman and the other, who are endless, in whom there lie, unobserved, knowledge and ignorance. Ignorance is destructible, knowledge is indestructible; and there is another who rules over knowledge and ignorance (1). In the next verse is mentioned the birth of Kapila and his being fed with knowledge. by him who presides over every productive energy (2). Giving various forms to each group (lit. net), the god resolves everything into the original principle. Creating again the lords of beings, he, the great soul, the ruler, wields sovereignty over all (3). As the sun illuminates all quarters, upper and lower and transversal, so also the god, the Bhagavat, presides over the natures of all productive energies (4). The original cause of the world makes natural powers develop, and brings to a mature condition those who are capable of development. He presides over this universe and puts into operation all the qualities (5). That is concealed in Upanisads, which contain the secret of the Vedas. That origin of Brahman, Brahmadeva knows All the ancient gods and ·πö·π£is, who knew that, being absorbed in it, became immortal (6).

The Upani·π£ad then proceeds to mention the individual soul, the lord of the vital airs, who performs actions and enjoys or suffers. their fruit, possesses three qualities and follows three ways, and gues through a succession of births in consequence of his actions (7). He is as big as the thumb, bright like the sun, is conscious of himself, and wills, is as minute as the hundredth part of the hundredth part of the point of a bair, and is ondless. In himself he is not a female nor a male nor sexless. This depends on the body assumed by him (8, 9, 10). He assumes many gross and

subtle forms in accordance with his qualities and the qualities of his actions and of the self. But he who effects their union, is another (12). Then follows a verse similar to IV. 14 and the latter part of 16 (13). In the last verse ≈öiva, the God, the creator and destroyer, is said to bo knowable by BhƒÅva faith, love, or the pure heart (14).

The sixth chapter appears to be a sort of resum√© of what precedes. Among other things it is stated that he who promotes virtue and dispels sin, should be known as existing in oneself (6); that the one God is concealed in all beings, is all-pervading, the internal soul of all beings, presiding over all actions, the support of all beings, the witness of all, the life-giver, absolute and without qualities (11); and that, knowing the cause which is to be understood by means of the Sa·πÅkhya and the Yoga, a man is freefrom all nooses (13).

After this follows a verse to the effect: " nor the sun nor the moon nor the stars nor lightning illuminate him (i. e., make him known); when he shines, everything shines after him, and by his light all this is rendered visible, or is illuminated “(14). This verse occurs in KU. (V. 15) and in MU. (II. 2. 10). The work ends with an expression of the author’s self-surrender to the god, who shines forth in one’s own intelligence, who first created Brahmadeva, and who sent forth the Vedas‚Äîthe god who has no parts, who does not suffer change, who is all peace, has no defects and is unpolluted, the bridge for crossing over to immortality, and who is like fire that has burnt fuel (18. 19).

¬ß 84. From this short summary, it will be seen that this Upani·π£ad contains verses from the Sa·πÅhitƒÅs of the RV. and YV. and others, which must have been in a floating condition, and were appropriated by the Mu·πá·∏çaka and Ka·π≠ha Upani·π£ads as well as by this; and a great many others, which have not been traced elsewhere, are original. All these contain truths about the nature of God, the individual soul and the inanimate world and the relations between them. The way to redemption is meditation. on the Supreme Soul, which way is characteristic of the Upani·π£ad. doctrine in general. Certain Yoga processes are prescribed to reuder this meditation effective, and the final result is a perception of the Supreme Soul as existing everywhere, and this perception constitutes eternal bliss.

This treatise contains the theism of the Upani·π£ad

period in its most mature form with a God distinctly personal at the centre. The attributes of the Supreme Soul are often given in very general terms, and he is referred to by the non-sectarian general name Deva, but as ofton that Deva is identified with Rudra, ≈öiva, ƒ™≈õƒÅna and Mahe≈õvara, and his powers are spoken of as ƒ™≈õƒÅnƒ´s; but there is no indication whatever that these names have been given. for the purpose of raising Rudra-≈öiva to the supreme godhead to the exclusion of another god. Names indicative of Rudra-≈öiva appear to have been used, since he was invested with a personality perceived and acknowledged by all. This Upani·π£ad, therefore, is not a sectarian treatise like others promulgated in later times, and is often quoted by ≈öa·πÅkarƒÅcƒÅrya, RƒÅmƒÅnuja and other writers of the different schools, and not by those of one schoolonly.

It must have been composed before the BhG., since the latter contains, as already stated72, a verse and a half from it, and the nature of the religio-philosophic speculations contained in it, though essentially Upani·π£adic, make a nearer approach to the later Bhakti School than those of any of the older treatises of the class. The description of the godhead and of the final pure serenity are instinct with the glow of love and admiration, and the treatise ends with an expression of self-surrender to the god, who makes himself manifest in one’s own intelligence. The ≈övetƒÅ≈õvatara-Upani·π£ad, therefore, stands at the door of the Bhakti School, and pours its loving adoration on Rudra-≈öivainstead of on VƒÅsudeva-Kr·π£·πáa, as the BhG. did in later times when full swing. VƒÅsudeva-K·πõ·π£·πáa the Bhakti doctrine was in full swing. had a historic basis; and the circumstances which led to his being invested with the supreme godhesd, occurred in later times, while in the age, in which the ≈öveti≈õvatare-Upani·π£ad was composed, Rudra-≈öiva was alone in the field as the supreme god, and the germs of Bhakti, or love, which manifested themselves at the time,were directed towards him; but when VƒÅsudeva-K·πõ·π£·πáa also came into the field, he appealed more to the hearts of men as the

god who had come to dwell amongst them; consequently the germs of Bhakti speedily developed, and he became the object of the heightened feelings in preference to the other.

UmƒÅ-Haimavatƒ´.

¬ß 85. Up to the time at which we have arrived, we meet with no mention of the wife of Rudra or ≈öiva, but in the Kena-Upani·π£ad, which is certainly one of the earlier Upani≈üads, the name of UmƒÅoccurs. She is called Haimavatƒ´, or the daughter of Himavat, but she is not mentioned in the KnU, as the wife of Rudra or ≈öiva, though in later times she was known to be so. The story is Brahman conquered the enemies of the gods for them, but the gods took credit to themselves for the victory and were proud of their achievements. Agni, VƒÅyu and Indra were sitting together, engaged in joyous conversation, when there appeared at some distance a spirit. Agni first went out to see what it was. The spirit asked him the nature and extent of his power and laid down a blade of grass, which it asked him to burn away. Agni was not able to do this and returned bafilled. Then went VƒÅyu, who also was not able to blow away the blade of grass; afterwards. went Indra, and at his approach the spirit disappeared. Indra was disappointed, but he saw a beautiful woman of the name of UmƒÅ-Haimavatƒ´ and asked her who the spirit was. She said it was Brahman. The story represents that condition of things, in which the old Vedio gods had lost their power or hold over men, and Brahman had come into prominence as the supreme spirit. Since it was UmƒÅ that disclosed the nature of the spirit. It may be understood that the Brahman mentioned was Rudra-≈öiva and UmƒÅ was his wife. It would thus appear that she had come to be so regarded some time before the Upan·π£iad was composed.

¬ß86. The Atharva≈õiras is another Upani·π£ad appertaining to Rudra. It is a much later work as is shown even by the very variant texts before me, commented on by NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa and ≈öa·πÅkarƒÅnanda. The gods, it is said, went to heaven and asked Rudra who he was. He said that he alone was, is, or will be, and nothing else. He is in all the quarters, he is GƒÅyatrƒ´, man, woman, etc., and thus a number of things are mentioned with which he is identical. Then Rudra was invisible to them, and they raised. their arms and praised him saying: “He who is Rudra, is

Bhagavat, and who also is Brahimadeva, a how to him”. In the similar sentences that follow, instead of Brahmadeva we have. Vi·π£·πáu, Mahe≈õvara, UmƒÅ, Skanda, VinƒÅyaka, etc. The sun and the constellation are also included. Then O·πÅkƒÅra is mentioned. to which many epithets and opithets of epithets expressive of divine attributes are given, and lastly it is called the one Rudra who is ƒ™≈õƒÅna, Bhagavat, Mahe≈õvara and MahƒÅdeva, Then follow the etymologies of the epithets or names. The only Rudra he is called, because he alone creates and absorbs everything. He is called ƒ™≈õƒÅna, because he rules by the powers called the ƒ™≈õƒÅnƒ´s. Then follow four or five verses from SU. with different readings. In some cases.

The substance of what follows is thus given by ≈öa·πÅkarƒÅnanda. For the knowledge of Rudra one should use moderate food, devote himself to reading (≈örava·πáa), thinking (Manana), etc., become a Paramaha·πÅsa, or a single-minded devotee, and spend his time thus. One should undertake the PƒÅ≈õupata vow (Vrata), which is of the following nature. Greed and anger should be given up. Forgiveness should be realised. The muttering of Om should be practised, and meditation resulting in Avagati, or perception, should be resorted to. The text, of which this is the explanation, may be generally rendered thus:‚Äî " In the inside of the heart exists the subtle body, in which there. are anger, greed and forgiveness. Destroying greed, which is at the bottom of human motives, and concentrating the mind on Rudra, who is one and eternal, one should be moderate in cating and drinking “. Then follows a precept to besmear the body. with ashes by repeating the words: " The ash is fire, the ash is water, the ash is earth, everything is ash, the ether is ash, the mind, the eyes and other senses are ash.” This is the PƒÅ≈õupata vow (Vrata), enjoined for the removal of the noose with which the Pa≈õu, or the individual soul, is tied.

Here the besmearing of the body with ashes after repeating a formula, or Mantra, is prescribed as a vow for the devotees of Pa≈õupati, or Rudra-≈öiva, calculated to effect a deliverance from the trammels of life. The expression " Pa≈õupƒÅ≈õavimok·π£a·πáa which means the loosening of the noose tied round the necks of beings, is a characteristic of the PƒÅ≈õupata sect. This Upani·π£ad

therefore belongs to that sect. Before, however, we pass on to the consideration of this sect, we must cast a glance at the position which Rudra-≈öiva holds in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata.

IV. Rudra-≈öiva in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata and Li·πÖga Worship.

¬ß 87. At the beginning of the Bhƒ´·π£maparvan K·πõ·π£·πáa advises Arjuna to make an obeisance to DurgƒÅbefore the commencement of the battle and pray for success. Arjuna does so after repeating a hymn in honour of DurgƒÅ, containing the names of UmƒÅ, mother of Skanda, KƒÅtyƒÅyanƒ´, KarƒÅlƒ´and a number of others. In the Vanaparvan Arjuna is represented to have gone to the HimƒÅlaya and practised austerities there. Some time after, ≈öiva appears dressed like a KirƒÅta, and a severe fight ensues between them. Arjuna is overpowered in the end and lies on the ground exhausted. He then praises ≈öiva, and, having made an altar of earth, puts flowers on it in the name of ≈öa·πÅkara. These, however, appear as placed on the head of the KirƒÅta, whereupon Arjuna makes him out as ≈öiva the object of his adoration, and surrenders himself to him. ≈öiva becomes pleased and offers him whatever he wishes. Arjuna asks for the weapon presided over by Pa≈õupati (PƒÅ≈õupatƒÅstra), which possesses the power of destroying all formidable enemies (chaps. 38-40).

In the Dro·πáaparvan again, (chaps. 80-81) the attainment. of the PƒÅ≈õupatƒÅstra, which appears to be of another kind, consisting of a bow and arrow, by Arjuna, is mentioned. Arjuna and K·πõ·π£·πáa are spoken of as having gone to the HimƒÅlaya in a vision and seen ≈öa·πÅkara at his dwelling. They bow their heads before him, sing a hymn in his praise, in which they call him the unborn, the creator of the universe, the unchangeable and utter the names which we have given as occurring in earlier works, and thus propitiating him ask for the PƒÅ≈õupata weapon. They are directed to a lake where the Astra bad been thrown. There they saw two venomous serpents, which, however, assumed at the time the forms of a bow and an arrow, and these Arjuna took away.

In the Sauptikaparvan (chap. 7) A≈õvatthƒÅman is mentioned to have propitiated ≈öa·πÅkaraand obtained a sword from him. ≈öiva himself enters into his body, and A≈õvatthƒÅman

carries havoc and destruction with the terrible sword in the camp of the PƒÅ·πá·∏çus, killing all their progeny, and even Dh·πõ·π£·π≠adyumna, who had cut off the head of his father Dro·πáa. Yudhi·π£·π≠hira asksK·πõ·π£·πáa says that he did. K·πõ·π£·πáa how he was able to effect all this. it through the power of ≈öa·πÅkara and relatos another story about him. Brahmadeva once told ≈öa·πÅkara not to create. Whereupon≈öa·πÅkara concealed himself under water for a long time. When, therefore, there was no creation for such a long period, Brahmadeva created another PrajƒÅpati, who brought into existence a large number of beings. These beings, being afflicted with hunger, went to PrajƒÅpati to devour him. He, being afraid, went to Hira·πáyagarbha, who created two kinds of food for those beings and then they were quicted. After some time MahƒÅdeva rose out of the water, and seeing that new beings had been created and were in a flourishing condition, he cut off his organ of generation as no more necessary, and it stuck into the ground. He then went away to perform austerities at the foot of the Mu√±javat mountain.

There is a similar story about MahƒÅdeva’s having ceased to create and become a Yogin in the VƒÅyu PurƒÅ·πáa (chap.10). Brahmadeva told Nƒ´lalohita (MahƒÅdeva) to create, and bringing to mind his wife Satƒ´, he created thousands of beings exactly like. himself, who were immortal. Thereupon he stopped and rendered himself incapable of procreation. He then resorted to all those processes of the Yoga, which in the PurƒÅ·πáa is called the PƒÅ≈õupataYoga.

In the Sauptikaparvan, K·πõ·π£·πáa continues the story of MahƒÅdeva and tells Yudhi·π£·π≠hira that when the gods created the rite of sacrifice and assigned no oblation to Rudra, he was full of wrath and destroyed the sacrifice; whereupon they assigned him a portion and the god was pleased.

In the Anu≈õƒÅsanaparvan (chap. 14),K·πõ·π£·πáa is introduced as recounting the glories of MahƒÅdeva. He says, JƒÅmbavatƒ´, one of his wives, expressed a desire for as good a son as Rukmi·πáƒ´, his chief consort, had. To procure such a son he had recourse to MahƒÅdeva, through whose favour only his wishes could be fulfilled. He then went to the HimƒÅlaya, on which ≈öiva lived. On the way he saw the hermitage of Upamanyu. Upamanyu

enters into a long discourse on the beneficent deeds of MahƒÅdeva. A list is given of persons, including many Daityas, who obtained their desired objects, such as sons, weapons, powers, etc., through the favour of MahƒÅdeva, whom they had propitiated by rigid austere practices and other ways. One of these was ≈öƒÅkalya, to whom was granted the boon that he would be an author and would obtain immortal glory, and his son would be the composer of S≈´tras. The persons alluded to here must be the compiler of the RVS.. and the author of the PƒÅda text. Upamanyu began to practise austerities to propitiate ≈öiva at the instance of his mother, who, in describing the god’s power and beneficence, spoke of him as dancing nakedly and of his having the quarters for his clothing (DigvƒÅsas). In the course of his austerities, MahƒÅdeva, to test Upamanyu’s devotion, appears before him in the form of Indra, and offers him many magnificent boons, which Upamanyu refuses, and declares that he would have boons from ≈öa·πÅkara alone, and that he would become a worm or a butterfly at the command of ≈öa·πÅkara, but did not desire. even the sovereignty of the three worlds given by Indra. In the course of his narrative, Upamanyu says that MahƒÅdeva was the only god, whose organ of generation (Li·πÖga) is worshipped by men. Heand Um√£ were the real creators of animals, as these bear the marks of the two, and not the discus or the conch-shell or marks of any other god. Eventually ≈öiva and Um√£appeared before Upamanyu, seated on a strong towering ox, attended on the one side by Brahmadeva seated on the swan, his vehicle, and on the other, by NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa on Garu·∏ça with the conch-shell, lotus, etc., and conferred on him all the blessings he desired. At his instance K·πõ·π£·πáa also entered on a long course of austerities, at the end of which MahƒÅdeva with UmƒÅ appeared before him in the same manner as they did to Upamanyu. The god conferred eight boons upon him, and his consort eight more; besides she promised him sixteen thousand wives. and altogether the number of boons he obtained was twenty-four inclusive of the birth of such a son as he wanted.

¬ß 88. The characteristics of ≈öiva, or MahƒÅdeva, as brought. out by these accounts appear to be these. He was a powerful, wrathful and impetuous god, but generous and bountiful, and

spared nothing when he was propitiated. Whenever a man conceived a desire for anything, he was the god to be appealed to for its fulfilment. He lived on the HimƒÅlaya with his wife UmƒÅ, PƒÅrvatƒ´, or DurgƒÅ, who had a number of other names such as Kalƒ´, KarƒÅlƒ´, etc., and was attended by a number of beings called. his Ga·πáas or hosts. His vehicle was an I. He had, of course, all the attributes of the supreme godhead. He is represented as having betaken himself to the process of Yoga or contemplation, when he had ceased to be creative.

It will be seen that the object of worship in ≈öaivism is the Li·πÖga, or phallus. We have found no trace of this characteristic in the earlier literature, so far as we have examined it¬π, and the first time we meet with it is in this passage from the Anu≈õƒÅsanaparvan. We have had occasion in a previous section73 to remark that Rudra-≈öiva had a close connection with stragglers in the forest, with VrƒÅtyas, or those who were not included in the Aryan community, and with the wild tribe of the Ni·π£ƒÅdas, and also that the gods of these last were amalgamated with Rudra. Rudra’s partiality for serpents and his being the lord of spirits or Bh≈´tas, were probably due to the influence of the serpent-worship and the devilry of the savage tribes.

There are two places in the RV., in one of which Indra is prayed to not to allow those whose god is ≈öi≈õna, to disturb the rites of the singers (VII. 24. 5); and in another he is represented. to have conquered the riches of a city after killing those whose god is ≈öi≈õna. Here evidently those whose god was Si≈õna, or phallus, are meant as the enemies of the Vedic Aryas, who disturbed their holy rites. Notwithstanding all that is said about the matter, my own belief is that the persons here referred to were really some tribe of the aborigines of the country, who worshipped. the phallus. Just then, as the Rudra-≈öiva cult borrowed several elements from the dwellers in forests and stragglers in places outof the way, so it may have borrowed this element of phallicworship from the barbarian tribes with whom the ƒÄryas came in contact. This element, however, does not appear to have come. in all at once, especially among the learned classes, whose beliefs. are represented in the literature which we have examined.

___________________________________________________________________________

1.I do not, however, deny the possibility that when the ≈öU. in IV. 11 speaks. of the god ƒ™≈õƒÅna as presiding over every Yoni, und in V. 2, of the lord as presiding over all forms and Yonis, an allusion to the physical fact of the Li·πÖga and Yoni connected together, may have been meant as typifying the philosophical doctrine of gods presiding over every creative cause.

The Li·πÖga worship had, it appears, not come into use at the time. of Pata√±jali; for, the instance he gives under P.V. 3.99, is that of an image or likeness (Pratik·πõti) of ≈öiva as an object of worship, and 2001 not of any emblem of that god. It seems to have been unknown. oven in the time of Wema-Kadphises, for, on the reverse of his coins, there is a human figure of ≈öiva with a trident in the hand; and there is also an emblem, but it is Nandin or the bull, and not a Li·πÖga or phallus. But this element must have crept in early enough among ordinary people, who were in closer communication with the uncivilised tribes, and gradually made its way to the higher classes, of whose creed it subsequently became an article. And it is this final stage of its adoption by the higher classes that is represented in Upamanyu’s discourse in the MahƒÅbhƒÅrata.

From all that we have brought forward from the post-Sa·πÅhitƒÅliterature, it will appear that Rudra-≈öiva was a deity whose. worship was common to all ƒÄryas, and who was not at first a sectarian god. As above remarked74,he was in charge of the field before the Vai·π£·πáava or VƒÅsudevic deities came in to contest his supremacy. The G·πõhyas≈´tras, which, as we have seen, give directions as to the adoration of Rudra under various circumstances, cannot be considered as belonging to any ≈öaiva sect. In the time of Pata√±jali, images of ≈öiva, Skanda and Vi≈õƒÅkha. made sometimes of precious metals, were kept for common worship by certain religious persons who derived an income from them75. The images of ≈öiva here alluded to cannot have been meant for the use of a particular sect.

V. Origin and Diffusion of the ≈öaiva Sects and the
Several Classes of ≈öiva Worshippers.

¬ß 89, A ≈öaiva sect is, however, mentioned even by Pata√±jali. The members of it were known as ≈öivabhƒÅgavatas, or devotees of ≈öiva, the Bhagavat, ≈öiva, we have seen, is called Bhagavat in AU.‚ÄîA ≈öivabhƒÅgavata carried in his hand an iron lance as an omblem of the deity he worshipped (under P. V. 2. 76).

In the NƒÅrƒÅya·πáƒ´ya section of MBh., the PƒÅ≈õupata is mentioned.as one of five schools of religious doctrines (≈öƒÅntiparvan, chap. 349, v. 64). ≈öiva-≈örƒ´ka·πá·π≠ha, the consort of UmƒÅ, the lord of spirits and the son of Brahmadeva, is represented to have revealed the tenets of that school (verse 67). Whether this statement is to be understood in the sense that its founder was a human being. afterwards recognized as an incarnation of ≈öiva, or whether it is a mere general statement like that contained in the BU. (II. 4. 10) that the ·πögveda, Yajurveda, etc., are the breath of this great. being, meaning nothing more historically than that the system. gradually came into existence, without any special individual being concerned with it, is a question somewhat difficult to answer definitely; but there is evidence in the PurƒÅ·πáas and Inscriptions, of the existence of a belief in favour of the first supposition.

The VƒÅyu-PurƒÅ·πáa(chap. 23) and the Li·πÖga-PurƒÅ·πáa (chap. 24). represent Mahe≈õvara to have told Brahmadeva that when, at the time of K·πõ·π£·πáa-DvaipƒÅyana during the twenty-eighth repetition of the Yugas, VƒÅsudeva, the best of Yadus, would be born of VƒÅsudeva, he would incarnate himself as a BrahmacƒÅrin by the name of Lakulin after entering a dead body thrown into & cemetery; the place where this would occur, would be called KƒÅyƒÅvatƒÅra or KƒÅyƒÅvaroha·πáa, and he would have four pupils of the names of Ku≈õika, Garga, Mitra and Kauru·π£ya. These PƒÅ≈õupatas, with their bodies sprinkled with ashes, resorting to the Yoga of Mahe≈õvara, would in the end go to the world of Rudra.

Now, in an Inscription in the temple of NƒÅtha near that of Ekalingii,14 miles to the north of Udaipur, Rajputana, it is stated that ≈öiva became incarnate &s a man with a club (Lakula) in his hand, in the country of Bh·πõgukaccha, being propitiated by Bh·πõgu. Sages, Ku≈õika and others, conversant with the PƒÅ≈õupata Yoga, and using ashes and wearing bark-dress and matted hair, are mentioned.

There is another Inscription, usually called the CintraPra≈õasti, which states that ≈öiva became incarnate in the form of Bha·π≠·π≠ƒÅraka ≈örƒ´-Lakulƒ´≈õa, and dwelt at KƒÅroha·πáa in the LƒÅ·π≠a country. There appeared in bodily form four pupils of his of the names of Ku≈õika, G√§rgya, Kauru·π£a and Maitreya for the strict performance of the PƒÅ≈õupata vows, and they became originators of four branches. The date of the first Inscription is Vikrama 1028, or 971 A. D., and the second was composed between A. D. 1274 and 1296. In another Inscription dated 943 A. D., found at HemƒÅvatƒ´in the Sira Taluka, Mysore, Lakulƒ´≈õa is represented to have been born again as MuninƒÅtha Chilluka to preserve the memory of his name and doctrines76.

MƒÅdhava calls the PƒÅ≈õupata system that he explains in his Sarvadar≈õanasa·πÅgraha, Nakulƒ´≈õa-PƒÅ≈õupata, and quotes a few words from what appears to be a work attributed to him. From all this it appears that there lived a certain person, of the name of Lakulin (the holder of a Laku·π≠a, or Lagu·∏ça, or Lakula, i. e., a club) who founded a PƒÅ≈õupata system. Four schools sprang out of it, and their reputed founders, whether historical or legendary, were considered his pupils. Lakulin ist the same as Nakulin, and the fact that his rise has been represented by the PurƒÅ·πáas to be contemporaneous with VƒÅsudeva-K·πõ·π£·πáa, points to the inference that traditionally the system was intended. to take the same place in the Rudra-≈öiva cult that the PƒÅ√±carƒÅtra did in the VƒÅsudeva-K·πõ·π£·πáacult. We may, therefore, place the rise of the PƒÅ≈õupata school mentioned in the NƒÅrƒÅya·πáƒ´ya about a century after that of the PƒÅ√±carƒÅtra system, i. e., about the second century B. C.

¬ß 90. Before we proceed further, we will notice the extent of the diffusion of the creed. At the end of the commentary on the Vai≈õe·π£ikas≈´tras, the author Pr≈õsastapƒÅda ntakes his obeisance to Ka·πáƒÅda, the author of the S≈´tras, and characterises him as having composed the Vai≈õe·π£ikas≈´tras after propitiating Mahe≈õvara by the

greatness of his Yoga (meditation or concentration), and ƒÄcƒÅra (practice). These two ways are common to both the PƒÅ≈õupata and ≈öaiva systems, as will be seen hereafter, and Ka·πáƒÅda, therefore, may have been a follower of the PƒÅ≈õupata or ≈öaiva system. BhƒÅradvƒÅja, the author of the Uddyota, or a gloss on VƒÅtsyƒÅyana’s NyƒÅyabha·π£ya, is called PƒÅ≈õupatƒÅcƒÅrya, or a teacher belonging to the PƒÅ≈õupata school, at the end of his work.

Wema Kadphises, a powerful prince of the Ku·π£anarace, who ruled over a large part of Northwestern India about the middle of the third century A. D., styles himself on the reverse of his coins a devotee of Mahe≈õvara or a member of the Mahe≈õvara sect, and image of Nandin and another of ≈öivawith a trident in his hand occur on the obverse. VarƒÅhamihira in the latter part of the sixth century, lays down the rule that the priests to be employed for the installation of an image of ≈öa·πÅbhu, should be BrƒÅhma·πáas besmearing their bodies. with ashes. By these he means members of a ≈öaiva sect, since, in the case of other gods, the names mentioned are those of the sects founded in the names of those gods.

Haribhadra, an old Jaina author, speaks in his ·π¢a·∏çdar≈õanasamuccaya, of the schools of Gotama and Ka·πáƒÅda as professing the ≈öaiva faith. But his commentator Gu·πáaratna, (who flourished. in the latter part of the fourteenth century77), calls the Vai≈õe·π£ikƒÅs PƒÅ≈õupatas and the other school ≈öaivas. This last must be a mistake, since BhƒÅradvƒÅja of the NyƒÅya school is specifically spoken of as a PƒÅ≈õupatƒÅcƒÅrya, as we have seen.

The Chinese traveller Hiuen-Tsiang in the middle of the seventh century mentions the PƒÅ≈õupatas twelve times in in his book. In some places he saysthat there were temples of Mahe≈õvara at which the PƒÅ≈õupatas worshipped; in one or two temples, he says that they resided. And at Benares he found about ten thousand sectaries who honoured Mahe≈õvara, besmeared their bodies with ashes, went naked and tied their hair. in knots. These and those who lived in temples must have been like the BairƒÅgis, or ascetics, of modern times, who had given up the world; but probably the others mentioned by him were the

followers of the PƒÅ≈õupata faith who lived the ordinary life of householders.

In the copper-plate charter of NƒÅgavardhana, nephew of Pulake≈õin II of MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠ra, who ascended the throne in 610 A. D., and was living in 639 A. D., a grant is recorded of a village near Igatpuri in the Nasik District for the worship of the god KƒÅpƒÅle≈õvara i. e., the lord of the wearers of garlands of skulls, and for the maintenance of the MahƒÅvratins residing in the temple. It will hereafter be shown that the name MahƒÅvratin, or observer of the grent vow designated the KƒÅpƒÅlikas or KƒÅlƒÅmukhas. Thus there. is evidence of the existence in the middle of the seventh centuryof the sect of KƒÅpƒÅlikas in MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠ra78.

In the Karhad grant of K·πõ·π£·πáa III of the RƒÅ·π£trak≈´·π≠adynasty, the king mentions his having granted in ≈öaka 880 (=958 A. D.), a village to Gagana≈õiva, the practiser of great austerities, who was fully versed in all the ≈öivasiddhƒÅntas and was the pupil of ƒ™≈õƒÅna≈õiva, who was an ƒÄcƒÅrya, or preceptor, and the head of the establishment at Valkale≈õvara in KarahƒÅ·π≠a. These holy men and their establishment seem to have belonged to the ≈öaiva sect and not to the PƒÅ≈õupata. The evidence for the existence of KƒÅlƒÅmukha and ≈öaiva sects in Mysore, in the latter part of the twelfth century, will be given in the next section.

Here it seems necessary to make another distinction. BƒÅ·πáa in the KƒÅdambarƒ´represents PƒÅ≈õupatas with red clothing to have been among those who waited to see TƒÅrƒÅpƒ´da’s minister ≈öukanƒÅsa at the door of his house for some private purposes of their own; but in another place he represents VilƒÅsavatƒ´, the queen of TƒÅrƒÅpƒ´da, to have gone to the temple of MahƒÅkƒÅlaon the fourteenth (of the dark half of the month) to worship the god. Bhavabh≈´ti In the MƒÅlatƒ´mƒÅdhava (Act III) represents MƒÅlatƒ´to have gone with her mother to the temple of ≈öa·πÅkara on the fourteenth of the dark half of the month. This fourteenth day still continues to be sacred to ≈öiva when special worship is performed. Now VilƒÅsavatƒ´and MƒÅlatƒ´and her mother can hardly have been meant to be members of that sect, some followers of which with a red clothing were waiting at ≈öukanƒÅsa’s door. It, therefore, appears to be clear that all worshippers of ≈öiva were not members of any of those

sects the names of which have come down to us, as observed in a previous section.

Rudra-≈öiva had gradually from the earliest times grown to be a god commonly worshipped by the Indians, and he has continued. to be their ordinary god to this day. The sects that subsequently arose were based upon specific methods of redemption, when religious and philosophic thought was advancing or perhaps declining, but the old god was resorted to by ordinary people without reference to them. And it must be remarked that those sects must have had. a clerical or ascetic, class as well as a class of lay followers or householders‚Äîand probably in some cases at least Hiuen. Tsiang means these last by his PƒÅ≈õupatas‚Äîand a class of ≈öaiva religious men, as distinct from lay followers, existed in KarahƒÅ·π≠aas we have noticed.

There were thus three classes of ≈öiva worshippers :‚Äî(1) clericals or ascetics, (2) their lay followers, and (3) ordinary people who had no particular connection with any sect. The poets KƒÅlƒ´dasa, Subandhu, BƒÅ·πáa, ≈örƒ´-Har·π£a, Bha·π≠·π≠a-NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, Bhavabh≈´ti and several others adore ≈öiva at the beginning of their works. They may have been the lay followers of any of the sects, but, in all likelihood, they belong to the third class. For of these Subandhu, BƒÅ·πáa and Bha·π≠·π≠a-NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa invoke Hari or another form of Vi·π£·πáuat the same time, thus showing that they were not exclusive adherents of one of the two gods. The many temples of ≈öiva constructed by the early CƒÅlukyas and the RƒÅ·π£·π≠rak≈´·π≠as, and the KailƒÅsa and other cave temples at Ellora excavated by the latter, contain no indication of their being intended for a specific ≈öaiva sect, and therefore they may be regarded as pointing to the diffusion of the general worship of ≈öiva in MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠ra from the seventh to the tenth century.

VI. Names and Doctrines of the ≈öaiva Sects.

¬ß 91. The older ≈öaiva sects had and have a literature of their own, the so-called ƒÄgamas attributed to ≈öiva himself, and a number of works by human authors. But the literature has not yet been published nor even discovered. I bave, therefore, necessarily to resort to the stray notices about the sects and their

doctrines, contained in works not written by the followers of the systems except in one case. With the more modern sects. the case is different, their literature having recently become. available.

≈öa·πÅkara says that the MƒÅhe≈õvaras maintain that Pa≈õupati has revealed five topics (Br. S. II. 2. 37). Thus the sects were. known by the general name of MƒÅhe≈õvara, and Pa≈õupati, or the god ≈öiva, was believed to be their founder. RƒÅmƒÅnuja under the same S≈´tra, which, however, is numbered 35, speaks of the systems as the tenets of Pa≈õupati. Ke≈õava KƒÅ≈õmƒ´rin calls the sects the followers of the “tenets of Pa≈õupati.” ≈örƒ´ka·πá·π≠ha-≈öivƒÅcƒÅrya calls them the “believers in the ƒÄgamas revealed by Parame≈õvara, or the great god”. The name MƒÅhe≈õvara is the old name as is evident from the fact that Wema-Kadphises, as noticed above, and several later princes, especially of the Valabhƒ´dynasty, called. themselves MƒÅhe≈õvaras. Hiuen Tsiang, too, as we have seen, mentions temples of Mahe≈õvara, at which the PƒÅ≈õupatas worshipped. It also follows that all these sects were at the same time known by the name of PƒÅ≈õupata sects; and the founder of them all was believed to be the god Pa≈õupati.

The same conclusion is to be deduced from the Mysore Inscriptions that have been published, the only difference being that the original teacher is called Lakulin or Lakulƒ´≈õa. In one Inscription dated 943 A. D., referred to above, it is stated that Lakulƒ´≈õa, being afraid that his name and doctrines would be forgotten, became incarnate as MuninƒÅtha Cilluks79.”). This appears to be a general name applicable to all systems. In another dated 1078 A. D. one ascetic is called an ornament to the LƒÅkula school and another is spoken of as “a hand to LƒÅkula”80. This appears to be the general name and does not point to a specific sect. In a third dated 1103 A. D. Some≈õvara-S≈´ri ist spoken of as having caused the LƒÅkula doctrine (SiddhƒÅnts) to bloom. He is called a Naiy√£yikaand Vaƒ´≈õe·π£ika81."). This shows

that he belonged to the specific PƒÅ≈õupata seot. In a fourth dated 1177 A. D. certain ascetics are called upholders of the LƒÅkulƒÅgamasamaya, i. e., the system based upon a work of LƒÅkulin, and adherents of KƒÅlƒÅmukhas82.").Here evidently the KƒÅlƒÅmukhas are called LƒÅkulas, which is the same as PƒÅ≈õupatas. The names of the ascetics mentioned in this Inscription end in the word ≈õakti and jƒ´ya, which appear to be characteristic of the KƒÅlƒÅmukha sect. In a fifth dated 1183 A. D. is noticed a grant to NƒÅga≈õiva-Pa·πá·∏çita, who is called an upholder of the LƒÅkula system, and the names of his preceptors in the two preceding generations end in the suffix ≈õiva. Naga≈õiva is praised for emipence in ƒÄgama and in ≈öivatattva¬≥. From the ending suffix ≈õiva in these names and the mention of a proficiency in ƒÄgama and in ≈öivatattva, it appears that NƒÅga≈õiva was a follower of the ≈öaiva school and at the same time he was a LƒÅkula, or PƒÅ≈õupata. A sixth dated 1199 A. D. notices a grant of land to Bammadeva, son of NƒÅgarƒÅsi, the promoter of the system based upon the work. of LƒÅkulin83. The sufflx rƒÅ≈õi is found in a great many names of the devotees of ≈öiva. Whether it is a characteristic of a specific sect is not clear, but it appears that the bearers of it belong to the PƒÅ≈õupata, or the KƒÅlƒÅmukha school. In a seventh dated 1213 A. D. a certain religious man is represented as the upholder of the system known by the name of VƒÅgi-LƒÅkula, i. e. the systemof the learned LƒÅkulin84. In an eighth dated 1285 A. D. the grantor is called a supporter of the new system of LƒÅkulin85."). This perhaps refers to the later school of LingƒÅyatas.

___________________________________________________________________________

3.Ep. Carn. Vol, V, ArsikereTaluq No. 89. Another holy person of the name of NƒÅga with the suffix rƒÅ≈õi instead of ≈õiva is mentioned in Inascr. No. 69 Arsikere Taluq (Ep. Carn. Vol. V, p. 137). A grant in therein recorded to MƒÅdhajƒ´ya, a disciple of NƒÅgarƒÅ≈õi, who belonged to the KƒÅlƒÅmukhas and was himself the disciple of Padma≈õiva-Pa·πá·∏çita. Another NƒÅgarƒÅ≈õi is mentioned in Inscr. No. 48 (Ibid.). The grantes in this case is KalyƒÅ·πáa≈õakti, disciple of ≈öivasaktideva, who was himself the disciple of NƒÅgarƒÅ≈õi,“bound to theKƒÅlƒÅmukhas”. ThisNƒÅgarƒÅ≈õi, or these twoNƒÅgarƒÅ≈õis, appear to me to the different from theNƒÅgarƒÅ≈õi mentioned in the text. And the use of the terminationrƒÅ≈õi in his case, he being aKƒÅlƒÅmukha, and of the word≈õakti in the case of two of the pupils, strengthens my supposition that these were characteristic of theKƒÅlƒÅmukha sect, the former being applicable to thePƒÅ≈õupata also.

Thus it will be seen that LƒÅkula was the general name by which the ≈öaiva sects were called, and the specific name KƒÅlƒÅmukha is associated with the general name in one case. This general name has for its basis the historical fact, noticed above, that a person of the name of LƒÅkulin or Lakulƒ´safounded a ≈öaiva system corresponding to the PƒÅ√±carƒÅtra system, which the VƒÅyuand Li·πÖga PurƒÅ·πáas consider to be contemporaneous with it. The other general name PƒÅ≈õupata arose by dropping the name of the human individual LƒÅkulin and substituting that of the god PƒÅ≈õupati, whose incarnation he was believed to be, as is done in the texts of the MBh. quoted above. But that the ≈öaiva system had a human founder is confirmed by the fact that the name of his work, the Pa√±cƒÅdhyƒÅyƒ´, or Pa√±cƒÅrthavidyƒÅ, has been handed down, as will be shown immediately below, and probably the work is extant, even if it has not yet been discovered, as MƒÅdhava mentions a gloss on the perpetual commentary (BhƒÅ·π£ya) on it, which also will be noticed below.The conclusion therefore appears to be that a certain historical person was the founder of the main ≈öaiva system which was the same as that explained by MƒÅdhava as Nakulƒ´≈õa-PƒÅ≈õupata, and that three other systems arose out of it in later times.

The commentators of ≈öa·πÅkara state that there were four of these schools bearing the names of ≈öaiva, PƒÅ≈õupata, KƒÅrukasiddhƒÅntin and KƒÅpƒÅlika. VƒÅcaspati, however, calls the third. KƒÅru·πáikasiddhƒÅntin. RƒÅmƒÅnuja and Ke≈õava KƒÅ≈õmƒ´rin mention the same four schools, but call KƒÅru·πáikasiddhƒÅntin by the name of KƒÅlƒÅmukha. The word KƒÅruka is probably a corruption of KƒÅuru·π£ya, the name of the third of the four (according to the PurƒÅ·πáas) pupils of Lakuli≈õa, or this last name may be the Sanskritised form of the original KƒÅruka86. The ≈öaiva school, however, is called SiddhƒÅntam√§rga and the KƒÅlƒÅmuklas are called MahƒÅvratadharas."). A work of the name of

___________________________________________________________________________

3.These four schools are mentioned in the VƒÅyavƒ´yasa·πÅhitƒÅ of the ≈öiva-PurƒÅ·πáa (II. 24, 177). The ≈öaiva school, however, is called SiddhƒÅntam√§rga and the KƒÅlƒÅmukhas are called MahƒÅvratadharas.

Pa√±cƒÅdhyƒÅyƒ´, dealing with the five topics alluded to above and attributed to Pa≈õupati, is mentioned by Ke≈õava KƒÅ≈õmƒ´rin and is quoted by RƒÅmƒÅnanda on KƒÅsƒ´kha·πá·∏ça¬π. This must be the same work as that which is quoted from by MƒÅdhava in the section on Nakulƒ´≈õa-PƒÅ≈õupata and attributed by him to Nakulƒ´≈õa or Lakulƒ´≈õa.

VII. The PƒÅ≈õupata System.

¬ß 92. The five topics mentioned by ≈öa·πÅkara and explained by his commentators are these (1) KƒÅrya, or effect, which is Mahat and the rest produced from PradhƒÅna; (2) KƒÅra·πáa, or the cause. which is ƒ™≈õvara or Mahe≈õvara and also PradhƒÅna; (3) Yoga, which is absorption in meditation or the muttering of the syllable O·πÅ, contemplation, concentration, eto.;(4) Vidhi, bathing (in ashes) at the three points of time, i. e., the beginning, the middle and the end of the day, and the rest up to G≈´d·∏•acaryƒÅ, i. e. incognito movement; (5) Du·∏•khƒÅnta, which is final deliverance. This is amplified by MƒÅdhavain the section on the PƒÅ≈õupata sect.

I. Effect (KƒÅrya) is that which is not independent. It is ofthree kinds: (1) cognition (VidyƒÅ), (2) organs (KalƒÅ), and (3) individual soul (Pa≈õu). Of these cognition is the property of the individual and is of two kinds: (1) external, and (2) internal. External cognition is of two kinds: (1) distinct, and (2) indistinct. Distinct external cognition, which is educed by the instruments of knowledge, is called conceptual operation (Citta). For by the conceptual operation every man reduces to definiteness the thing

___________________________________________________________________________

1.See Aufrecht’s Cat. Cat. The VƒÅyavƒ´ya Sa·πÅhita (II, 24, 169) also mentions this work, which it characterises as the highest theosophy (VidyƒÅ) of ≈öiva and gives Pa√±cƒÅrtha as its name, i, e, Pa√±circhavidyt. This Pancarton appears to be alluded to by MƒÅdhava when he refers his reader to the PƒÅncƒÅrthabhƒÅsyƒÅdƒ´pikƒÅ in bis section on Nakulƒ´≈õa-PƒÅ≈õupata. In an Inscription in the temple of Har·π£anƒÅth, which exists in the Sƒ´kar principality of the Jaipur state, a person of the name of Vi≈õvar≈´pa is mentioned as the teacher of the pa√±cƒÅrtha-LƒÅkulƒÅmnƒÅyƒÅ, I. e. the sacred book of Lakulin, called Pa√±cƒÅrtha. The Inscri·πátion is dated V, E. 1013= A. D. 957, so that there can be on question that the PƒÅ≈õupata system was attributed to ’s buman author named Lakulin, the work composed by him being called Pa√±cƒÅrtha (Ep. Ind. II. p. 123).

The occurrence of the names of the schools and of this book in the PurƒÅ·πáa shows that its composition was later than the foundation of the school, which, therefore, must be considered as owing nothing to it.

that has been apprehended definitely or indefinitely by the aid of the light in the shape of the external object. The internal cognition is of the nature of virtue or vice, which forms the objective. of the indul and determines for him the body of precepts he has to follow. Organs are dependent on the cognitive individual and are themselves insensate. They are of two kinds: (1) effects, and (2) causes. The effected organs are of ten kinds: the five elements, earth and others, and the five qualities, colour and others. The organs, which are causes, are of thirteen kinds: the five senses, and the five organs of action, and the three internal organs, viz. intelligence, egoism and mind, the functions of which are the determination of the will, the consciousness of the self, and the formation of a plan respectively. The individual (Pa≈õu) is that which has individualism (Pa≈õutva). It is of two kinds: (1) impure, and (2) pure. The impure individual is that which is connected with the body and the organs, while the pure one is unconnected with them. The details should be seen in the Pa√±cƒÅrthabhƒÅsyadƒ´pikƒÅand other works.

II. The cause (KƒÅra·πáa) is that which effects the destruction of the whole creation and its prosperity or promotion. Though it is one, still on account of its various properties and functions it has many forms, such as lord (Pati), naturally powerful (SƒÅdya), eto. To be the lord means to have the unbounded power of knowing and acting. He is, therefore, the eternal ruler. To be a SƒÅdya is to be possessed of supreme sovereignty, which is not incidental, but natural.

III. Yoga is the connecting of the individual soul with god through the conceptual faculty (Citta). It is of two kinds, consisting in (1) action, and (2) cessation from action. The first consists in muttering syllables and formulas, meditation, etc. The second, or cessation from action, consists in mere feeling (Sa·πÅvid).

IV. Vidhi, or process, is an operation which effects or brings about righteousness. It is of two kinds: (1) primary, and (2) secondary. The first, or primary, is conduct (CaryƒÅ) which induces righteousness directly. That conduct is of two kinds: (1) vows, and (2) means or doors. The vows consist in besmearing

the body with ashes and lying down in ashes, definite practices (UpahƒÅra), muttering and circumambulation. Thus has Nakulƒ´≈õa said: “One should besprinkle one’s body at the three points of the day and lie down in ashes.” The definite practices are six. These have been stated by the author of the S≈´tras to be laughing, singing, dancing, Hu·∏çukkƒÅra, prostration, and inaudible repetition. With these he says one should worship. Laughing is the making of the sound ‘hƒÅ! hƒÅ! hƒÅ! by the forcible stretch. of the throat and the lips. Singing is the contemplation of the attributes of Mahe≈õvara in accordance with the rules of the science of music. Dancing should be resorted to by contracting and stretching forth hands, feet, etc. and all other principal and subsidiary limbs accompanied by the representation of feeling in accordance with the science of dancing and gesticulation. Hu·∏çukkƒÅra is a holy sound resembling that of an ox made by striking the tongue on the palate. Hu·∏çukis an imitative sound like the sacrificial Va·π£a·π≠. When there is a crowd of people, all this should be done so as not to be observed.

The means, or doors, are these: (1) KrƒÅthana, i.e.affecting to be asleep when one is awake; (2) Spandana, which is the moving or the shaking of the limbs as if they were paralysed; (3) Ma·πá·∏çana, or the walking as if one’s legs and other limbs were disabled;(4) ≈ö·πõ·πÖgƒÅra·πáa, which is showing oneself to be in love by means of amorous gestures as if on seeing a beautiful young woman; (5) Avitatkara·πáa, which is doing a thing condemned by all as if one were devoid of the sense of discrimination between. what should be done and what should be avoided; (6) AvitadbhƒÅ·π£a·πáa, which is speaking nonsensical and absurd things.

Secondary processes are those which are intended to help the conduct (CaryƒÅ), such as besmearing with ashes after worship, and to remove the sense of indecency or impropriety attaching itself to begging and eating the remnant of what others have esten. For this purpose the author of the S≈´tras has laid down. that one should besmear his body after the worship and wear the faded flowers and leaves which had been removed from the god. and a Li·πÖga (the image of the phallus).

V. Du·∏•khƒÅnta, or final deliverance, is of two kinds: (1) total

destruction of misery, and (2) an elevated condition consisting in the possession of the power of knowing and acting. The power of knowing is of five kinds: (1) Dar≈õana, or seeing all objects which are atomic, concealed or are at a distance, and touching them; (2) ≈örava·πáa, or the miraculous hearing of all sounds (3) Manana, or the miraculous knowing of all objects of thought; (4) Vij√±ƒÅna, or the miraculous knowledge of all the sciences with that of the treatises on them and the matter contained in these last; and (5) Sarvaj√±atva, or the miraculous. knowledge of the principles (of a science), whether mentioned or unmentioned, succinct and detailed, with their divisions and peculiarities. The peculiarities of the present system are such as these: In other systems the destruction of misery is final deliverance; in this system the attainment of the highest powers. is also to be added. With others, that which comes into existence from non-existence is an effect; here the effect is eternal such as Pa≈õu, or the individual soul. In other systems the cause depends for its operation on a subordinate cause; here the great lord acts independently. With others, the fruit of the Yoga, or concentration, is the attainment of an absolute condition; here it is the attainment of the highest powers. With others Vidhi, or process, has for its fruit heaven and other places, from which there is a return to mortal life; in this system the fruit is proximity etc. (to god ), from which there is no return.

The power of acting, though one, is regarded as threefold: (1) Manojavitva, or the power of doing anything instantly: (2) KƒÅmar≈´pitva, or the power of assuming variety of shapes. and forms or bodies and senses without an effort; (3) Vikrama·πáadharmitva, or the possession of great power, even when the operation of the senses is suspended. Thus then a man acquires these miraculous powers of knowledge and action at the end of a long course of conduct and discipline prescribed by the PƒÅ≈õupata system.

It will be seen how fantastic and wild the processes prescribed in this system for the attainment of the highest condition are. Rudra-≈öiva was the god of the open fields and wild and awful r√©gions away from the habitations of men and worshipped by

aberrant or irregular people. This character did impress itself on the mode of worship for his propitiation, which was developed in later times. The ≈öU. endeavoured to humanise Rudra-≈öiva; but the wild and outlandish character of the god prevailed. We will now proceed to the consideration of the ≈öaiva system which seems to have been established in later times. Here also MƒÅdhava will be our main guide, since the many works that he quotes. from are not available.

VIII. The ≈öaiva System.

¬ß 93. There are three principles: (1) the lord (Pati), (2) the individual soul (Pa≈õu), and (3) fetters (PƒÅ≈õa); and the whole system has four PƒÅdas, or parts, which are knowledge (VidyƒÅ), action (KriyƒÅ), meditation ( Yoga), and conduct, or discipline (CaryƒÅ). The first part contains an explanation of the nature. of the individual soul (Pa≈õu), fetters (PƒÅ≈õa), and god (ƒ™≈õvara), and determines the importance of formulas (Mantra) and the lord presiding over the formulas (Mantre≈õvara). This leads to initiation (Dik·π£ƒÅ), which is necessary for the acquisition of the highest object of life. The second part contains an explanation of the process of initiation (Dƒ´k·π£ƒÅvidhi ), which is of many forms and has many parts. The third part explains meditation, or concentration, along with its subsidiary processes.The fourth teaches discipline, or conduct, consisting in doing what is prescribed and avoiding what is proscribed. Without this Yoga is not possible.

I. Now the lord (Pati) is ≈öiva. ≈öiva acts, being impelled. thereto by the deeds (Karman) of souls, and produces things to be enjoyed or suffered and their means. The exercise of his He does! creative power thus depends on the Karman of man. everything; therefore, he is omniscient. God has not a body like that of an individual soul which has the fetters of taint and Karman, etc.; but he has a body made up of powers, certain specific five formulas (Mantras87 and In the Mah√§m√§r√§ynolya Up. 17. The commentator considers these to refer to the five facos of ≈öiva, respectively. They are Badyojita, VƒÅmadeva, Aghora, Tasparu·π£a and ƒ™≈õƒÅna. They are also called forms of ≈öivaOne of the DƒÅnas, or charitable gifts, mentioned by HemƒÅdri (DƒÅnakha·πá·∏çaVol. I, pp. 789-798 Bibl. Ind.) consists of √ºve images made of gold or other motal fashioned in a particular manner of these five forms of ≈öiva. In giving each a certain verse bas to be repeated. These five forms are Ident fed in a ≈öaiva treatise with the earth, water, fire, wind an d ather, respectively, and they are considered as the creators of these elements la another, viz., Virn-≈öaiva-Cintamani, Sholapur 1908 A. D.")) being imagined to be thedifferent parts of his body. These five are his powers and are also considered his different forms, and by these he does the five actions. which are creation, existence or protection, destruction, concealment, and benefaction. The following four partake of the nature. of ≈öiva: (1) formulas (Mantras), (2) the deity presiding over the formulas (Mantre≈õvara), (3) the great god (Mahe≈õvara), and (4) delivered souls (Mukta).

___________________________________________________________________________

1.These five formulas, or Mantras, are contained in the TA. (X. 43-47) and In the MahƒÅnƒÅrƒÅya·πáƒ´ya Up. 17. The commentator considers these to refer to the five faces of ≈öiva, respectively. They are SadyojƒÅta, VƒÅmadeva, Aghora, Tasparu·π£a and ƒ™≈õƒÅna. They are also called forms of ≈öiva One of the DƒÅnas, or charitable gifts, mentioned by HemƒÅdri (DƒÅnakha·πá·∏ça Vol. I, pp. 789-798 Bibl. Ind.) consists of five images made of gold or other motal fashioned in a particular manner of these five forms of ≈öiva. In giving each a certain verse bas to be repeated. These five forms are Ident fed in a ≈öaiva treatise with the earth, water, fire, wind an d ather, respectively, and they are considered as the creators of these elements la another, viz., Vƒ´ra-≈öaiva-CintƒÅmani, Sholapur 1908 A. D.

II. The Pa≈õu is the individual soul, who is atomic and known.by the name of K·π£etraj√±a (self-conscious) and others. It is eternal and all-pervading. It is not incapable of action nor is it one only, as is maintained by other schools of philosophy. When the fetters are removed, he becomes ≈öiva, possessing eternal and -boundless knowledge and power of action. The Muktas, or delivered ones, are ≈öivas, who have so become by the favour of him who is eternally Mukta, and is a person with five formulas. (Mantras ) for his body, i. e. he is identified with the god ≈öiva himself. Though they become ≈öivas, they are not independent. but depend upon the eternal god, ≈öiva. Pa≈õu is of three kinds: (1) Vij√±ƒÅnƒÅkala, who has shaken off his connection with all the organs (KalƒÅ·∏•88) in consequence of the destruction of the impression of deeds done, by means of knowledge, meditation, asceticism, or by the enjoyment or suffering of the fruit (Bhoga), and has simple taint (Mala). The second is PralayƒÅkala, whose organs are destroyed by the dissolution of the world. He has both impression of deeds (Karman) and taints (Mala). The third is ≈öakala, who has all the three fetters, taint (Mala), impression of deeds. (Karman), and material cause (MƒÅyƒÅ). Vij√±anƒÅkala is of two kinds (1) one whose taint (Kalu·π£a) has ended, and (2) another whoso taint (Kalu·π£a) has not ended. The first are those, who, their taint (Kalu·π£a) having ended, are elevated to the position of Vidye≈õvaras. The Vidye≈õvaras are eight and are as follows: (1) Ananta, or endless, (2) atomic, (3) the most excellent ≈öiva, (4)

the one-eyed. (5) the one Rudra, (6) he with the three forms, (7) ≈örƒ´ka·πá·π≠ha, and (6) ≈öikha·πá·∏çin. Another author says that ≈öiva invests the SamƒÅptakalu·π£a (one whose taint has ended) with Vidye≈õatva, which is of eight kinds, and the AsamƒÅptakalu·π£a (one whose taint has not onded) he raises to the dignity of fomulas. (Mantras) which are seven crores. PralayƒÅkala is also of two kinds. The first is one whose two fetters have matured (and about to be shaken off), and the second is different from him. The first attains Mok·π£a, and the second, entangled with Purya·π£·π≠aka, undergoes many births in accordance with his impressisn of deeds. (Karman). The Purya·π£·π≠aka is a subtle body, wich is composed of elements which are variously enumerated. Of those who have the Purya·π£·π≠aka, some, who are virtuous, are raised to Bhuvanapatitva by Mahe≈õvara Ananta. Sakala is also of two kinds: (1) one whose taint (kalu·π£a) is matured, and (2) one whose taint (kalu·π£a) is not matured. The first is raised to the dignity of Mantre≈õvara of 118 Mantras, i. e of so many kinds. Parame≈õvara, assuming the form of his preceptor by the process of initiation. and the use of power calculated to counteract the matured taint, confers Mok·π£a. Those A·πáus or atomio souls, whose taint has not ripened (i. e. is not in a condition to be wiped away), are made to suffer or enjoy in accordance with their Karman.

III. PƒÅ≈õa (fetter) is of four kinds: (1) Mala, or taint (2) Karman, or the impression of deeds, (3) MƒÅyƒÅ, or material cause, and (4) Rodha≈õakti, or obstructive power. Mala, or tsint, is that which conceals the knowing and acting power of the soul and is like the husk enveloping a grain of rice. Karman is the impression of deeds done for the attainment of fruit. It is righteous or un- righteous. It is unbeginning, ever continuing in succesion in the manner of seed and its sprout. MƒÅyƒÅis that into which the whole creation resolves itself at the time of dissolution and from which it springs out at the time of recreation. The obstructive power is the power of Siva which, because it regulates the three other fetters and conceals the true nature of the soul, is itself called a fetter. It performs its function, because it is the principle. of speech by means of which names are given to things and thus. their nature is determined89.

¬ß 94. This constitutes the first part of the system (VidyƒÅpƒÅda), the nature of the other three parts has been succinetly given above. A few details are these90: The second part (KriyapƒÅda) treats of the accomplishment of Mantra, the twilight adorations, worship, muttering of formulas (Japa), throwing oblations into the fire, acossional ceremonies for the attainment of eternal bliss, anointing of the preceptor and of the person ontering on a course of action for final emancipation (SƒÅdhaka), and one’s own initiatory ceremonies necessary to fit one for a wordly and for an eternal life. In the third, or the Yoga part are mentioned the thirty-six principles; the deities presiding over them; the lords of the different worlds; the individual soul; the all-ruling soul, the power (≈öakti); the direct perception of MƒÅyƒÅand MahƒÅmƒÅyƒÅ, which are the causes of the world; the attainment of the miraculous powers, minuteness, lightness, eto. for those who concern themselves with the worldly element; the methods of the restraint. of the breath, abstraction, meditation, concentration, and absorption in thought (SamƒÅdhi); and the positions of the circles in the body beginning with the root-circle (M≈´lƒÅdhara, or navel). The fourth part treats of penances, a purificatory ceremony (PavitrƒÅropa·πáa), the foundation, and the natures of ≈öivali·πÖga, of the visible Li·πÖga of UmƒÅ and Mahe≈õvara, and of the lord of Ga·πáas, or groups, such as Skanda and Nandin, of the rosary used for the muttering of formulas, and the funeral ≈örƒÅddhas. This last part appears to contain matters subsidiary to, and explanatory of, the actions enjoined in the second part. The proscribed actions mentioned above are: (1) the eating of the residue of what is offered to another deity; (2) the vilification of (a) ≈öiva, (b) of the devotees of ≈öiva, (c) of the system of ≈öiva and (d) of the practices enjoined. in the ≈öaiva system; (3) the enjoyment of things belonging to God; (4) the killing of animals.

¬ß 95.The doctrines of the ≈öaiva school are more moderate and rational than those of the PƒÅ≈õupƒÅta school. This last, as well as the two extreme schools to be mentioned next, are called AtimƒÅrgika, or schools that are away from the path or go astray, and are spoken of by ≈öa·πÅbhudeva, quoted in the above paragraph, as revealed by Rudra. The ≈öaiva schools he calls the SiddhƒÅnta≈õƒÅstra, or the true

≈öƒÅstra based upon the Mantras, and says that it was revealed by≈öiva. The VƒÅyavƒ´yasa·πÅhitƒÅalso calls it the SiddhƒÅnta school.

It will have been seen that both this and the PƒÅ≈õupata schoolare dualistic or pluralistic and maintain that the supreme andindividual souls are distinct entities and the PradhƒÅna the constituent cause of the material world. In the delivered conditionthe individual soul shakes off its ignorance and weakness andattains boundless knowledge and power of action according tothe PƒÅ≈õupata doctrine, while the ≈öaivas hold that he becomes≈öiva himself, i. e. attains perfect resemblance with the God ≈öivawithout, however, the power of creation.

The ≈öaiva school, that developed itself in later times, and isrepresented by ≈öa·πÅbhudeva and ≈örƒ´ka·πá·π≠he≈õivƒÅcƒÅrya, to benoticed hereafter, and supported also by texts in the VƒÅyavƒ´yasa·πÅhitƒÅ, holds that ≈öiva possesses or develops in himself a ≈öakti,or power, consisting of the rudiments of the individual soul andthe material world, and from this power the whole world isdeveloped. This doctrine may, therefore, be called qualifiedspiritual monism like that of RƒÅmƒÅnuja, in-as-much as ≈öivacharacterised by the ≈öakti creates. This last is a tenet of theLi·πÖgƒÅyat school also.

IX. KƒÅpƒÅla and KƒÅlƒÅmukha Sects.

¬ß 96. RƒÅmƒÅnuja tells us under II. 2. 35 or 36 that the KƒÅpƒÅlikas maintain that a man who knows the essence of the sixmarks (MudrikƒÅ) and who is skilful in their use, attains thehighest bliss by concentrating his mind on the soul seated on thefemale organ. The six marks are (1) a necklace, (2) an ornament,(3) an ear-ornament, (4) a crest jewel, (5) ashes, and (6) the sacredthread (Yaj√±opavƒ´ta). He whose body bears these marks is free.from transmigration. The KƒÅlƒÅmukhas hold that the followingare the means for the attainment of desires concerning thisworld and the next:‚Äî(1) eating food in a skull; (2) besmearingthe body with the ashes of a dead body; (3) eating the ashes; (4)holding a club; (5) keeping a pot of wine; and (6) worshippingthe god as seated therein. A bracelet of RudrƒÅk·π£a, one string ofmatted hair on the head, s skull, besmearing the body with ashes, and such other things are mentioned in the ≈öaiva

sacred books. They also maintain that people of other castes.become BrƒÅhma·πáas and attain to the highest order by the performance of certain rites. For it is said “One becomes aBrƒÅhma·πáa immediately after the process of simple initiation, and a man becomes a holy saint by undertaking the vow of a KƒÅpƒÅla”.

In the ≈öa·πÅkaradigvijaya (chap. XV, vv. 1-28) MƒÅdhavabrings ≈öa·πÅkara into contact with the KƒÅpƒÅlikas at a place which,according to the commentator, was Ujjayinƒ´. The preceptor ofthe sect came forward to meet ≈öa·πÅkara. His body was besmearedwith the ashes taken from a burning-ground. He had a skull inhis hand and also an iron lance. He said to ≈öa·πÅkara: “Theashes on your body are all right¬π. But why dost thou carry anunholy potsherd instead of the holy skull? Why dost thou notworship KapƒÅlin who is Bhairava? How will Bhairava become.pleased unless he is worshipped by the skulls red with the blood.of men and with wine?” Then ensues a fight between Sudhanvan,.the king, who accompanied ≈öa·πÅkara in his wanderings and theKƒÅpƒÅlikas. ≈öa·πÅkara also pronounced a curse on them, and theywere all killed. Then Krakaca, the leader of the KƒÅpƒÅlikas,coming up to ≈öa·πÅkara, filled the skull in his band with wine,drank half of it and left the other half and invoked Bhairava.Bhairava came up and Krakaca prayed to him to destroy hisenemy; but as ≈öa·πÅkara was his own incarnation, he destroyed.Krakaca himself and not ≈öa·πÅkara. In ƒÄnandagiri’s book theKƒÅpƒÅlikas, whom ≈öa·πÅkara meets at Ujjayinƒ´, speak of Bhairavabeing the great god, who creates, destroys, etc. They profess tohave their knowing power sharpened by drinking wine andeating a certain kind of food (probably a disgusting substance)and always being embraced by the power (≈öakti) of Kap√§lin, i. e.Bhairava. Bhavabh≈´ti in his Malatimadhava gives ≈örisails asthe principal seat of the KƒÅpƒÅlikas. Miraculous powers of speedymovement attained by the practice of Yoga are attributed tothem. The woman KapƒÅlaku·πá·∏çalƒÅwears a garland of humanskulls. She carries away MƒÅlatƒ´, the heroine of the play, fromthe place where she was sleeping in her father’s palace in thedead of night and places her before the image of KarƒÅla-CƒÅmu·πá·∏çƒÅnear the cemetery to be killed and sacrificed to the goddess byher preceptor Aghoragha·πá·π≠a.

___________________________________________________________________________

1. Lines of ashes are borne on the body by ordinary ≈öaiva’s also, and≈öa·πÅkara’s body was marked with them.

It will be seen how horrible and demoniacal this sect was.The fear which some of the phenomena of external nature inspirein the mind of man led to the Vedicconception of Rudra, andthis has now culminated into the ideal image of the horrid godBhairava with his wife Ca·πá·∏çikƒÅwearing a garland of humanskulls and requiring human sacrifices and offerings of wine forhis propitiation. In the account just given there appears to be aconfusion between the sects of KƒÅpƒÅlikas and KƒÅlƒÅmukhas. From.RƒÅmƒÅnuja’s account the KƒÅlƒÅmukhas appear to be the mostextreme sect; and they are called Mahavratadharas in the ≈öivaPurƒÅ·πáa as noticed above.
