Mah√§vrata means the great vow, andthe greatness of the vow consists in its extraordinary nature,such as eating food placed in a human skull, besmearing the bodywith the ashes of human carcasses and others which are attributedto the KƒÅlƒÅmukhas by R√§m√§nuja. Jagaddhara, the commentatoron the MƒÅlatƒ´mƒÅdhava, however, explains KƒÅpƒÅlikavrata byMahƒÅvrata¬π, and this explanation appears to be correct, since theascetics dwelling in the temple of KƒÅpƒÅle≈õvara in the NƒÅsikdistrict are, as we have seen, called in the grant MahƒÅvratins,or the observers of the great vow. The account of KƒÅpƒÅlikasgiven above from other authorities looks like those of the mostextreme sect. Ordinarily, therefore, people do not seem to havemade a sharp distinction between the KƒÅpƒÅlikas and theKƒÅlƒÅmukhas.

X. Kashmir ≈öaivism.

$ 97. It is a relief now to turn away from this ghastly pictureof the wild aberrations of the human intellect and spirit to asystem of ≈öaivism more humane and rational. The Kashmir≈öaivism has two branches, the Spanda≈õƒÅtra and the Pratyabhij√±ƒÅ≈õastra. The authorship of the first is attributed to Vasuguptaand his pupil Kalla·π≠a. The two principal works of the system.are the ≈öivas≈´tram or ≈öivas≈´tra·πái and the SpandakƒÅrikƒÅs whichare fifty-one verses only. The first are said to have been revealed

___________________________________________________________________________

1.Act I, p. 33, on 1. 127 of my second edition of the play.

to Vasugupta by ≈öiva himself or by a Siddha, or perfected humanbeing. They were inscribed on a rock on the MahƒÅdeva hill, andVasugupta was directed to the rock by ≈öiva. Another account isthat they were revealed by the god in a dream, and another accountstill further confers the credit of the revelation on the prefectedhuman being. These two last occurrences are said to have taken.place on the MahƒÅdeva hill. As to the second work, there arealso varying traditions, one ascribing the authorship of the versesto Vasugupta and another to Kalla·π≠a. A third tradition, however,that Kalla·π≠a obtained the knowledge of the system from Vasugupta and composed the SpandakƒÅrikƒÅs for the instruction of hispupils seems to contain the truth¬π. What the meaning of theroundabout tradition about the ≈öivas≈´tras which do not ascribetheir authorship to Vasugupta directly is, it is difficult to say;perhaps the original work was the SpandakƒÅrikƒÅs and the prose≈öivas≈´tras were composed in later times in the older or moreorthodox form, and as Vasugupta was probably too near the time.when they were composed and as what he did was known to all,& miraculous origin was given to the new S≈´tras and Vasuguptawas represented to have received them from others and not composed them himself.

$ 98. Kalla·π≠a lived in the reign of Avantivarman91, 854 A. D.,wherefore his Guru’s literary activity must be referred to the beginning of the ninth century. The followers of this school boldlydeny the necessity of God’s having a prompting cause, such asKarman, or a material cause, like the PradhƒÅns, for the creation ofthe world. Neitherdo they admit that he is himself the materialcause, as the VedƒÅntas≈´tras maintain, nor do they think thatsome principle of illusion, such as MƒÅyƒÅ, generates appearanceswhich are false. God is sccording to them independent andcreates merely by the force of his will all that comes into existence. He makes the world appear in himself, as if it were distinct from himself, though not so really, as houses or even townsappear in a mirror, and is as unaffected by it as the mirror is by

___________________________________________________________________________

1. For these various traditions see my Report on the Search for SanskritManuscripts during 1883-84, p. 77f. [=Volume II of this Edition p 199f.N. B.U.]

the images reflected in it. Neither does he exist only as realisedin the world, which is the conclusion that follows from thedoctrine that he is the material cause.In a verse attributed toVasugupta an obeisance is made to S≈´lin, or ≈öiva, who is represented as portraying a picture of the world without a canvassand a collection of materials¬π.

Another illustration that they give of creation without anymaterial or prompting cause is that of a Yogin who createsobjects by his mere will without any materials. God himself byhis own wonder-working power appears in the form of the manyindividual souls, and by means of another power, brings into existence the state of things which goes to form what we call thewakeful and dreamy condition of our life¬≤. Thus according tothis system the individual soul is identical with the supremesoul. But the former does not perceive this identity on accountof his impurity.

This impurity, or Mala, is of three kinds. When a soul forgets.his own free and universal nature through ignorance, and believeshimself to be imperfect, and regards things, such as the body,which are not himself, to be himself, and thus reduces himself tofiniteness or subjects himself to limitations, the impurity is called ƒÄ·πáava (littleness). Then his remaining in the body, which isprepared by the originator of things, called MƒÅyƒÅ, is anotherspecies of impurity known as MƒÅyƒ´ya, or effected by MƒÅyƒÅ. Andwhen under the influence of the internal organ, cr the heart, theorgans of action are set in motion, the impurity arising from itis called KƒÅrma, or resulting from action, such as that consistingin a man’s consciousness of having done a good or evil deed.which is to lead to happiness or misery in the end¬≥. These severalkinds of impurity are brought into action by NƒÅda, which is thefemale element constituting a primeval power (≈öakti) of ≈öivaand from which rises speech.

___________________________________________________________________________

1. See MƒÅdhava’s Sarvadar·π°anasa·πÅgraha, Pratyabhij√±ƒÅdar≈õana. This verseis quoted in the KƒÅvyaprakƒÅ≈õa, Chapter IV; and by other writers onAla·πÅkƒÅras.

2. See the first note on p. 80 of my Report for 1883-84[ Volume II of thisEdition, p. 203n2 N. B. U.]

3. ≈öivas≈´travimar≈õinƒ´by K·π£emarƒÅja under S≈´tra I, 2 and 3, published by theKƒÅ≈õmƒ´ra Government.

Without speech the ideas which render a worldly life possiblecannot stand, or assume a shape or form, and therefore theprinciple of speech is believed to be the origin of the Mala, or impurity, which leads to a worldly life. This power is associatedwith others which are personalised as AmbƒÅ, Jye·π£·π≠ha, Raudrƒ´,VƒÅmƒÅ¬π.

The impurity vanishes when by means of intense contemplation the vision of the highest being breaks in upon the mind ofthe devotee and absorbs all finite thought. When this conditionbecomes stable, the individual soul is free and becomes thesupreme soul. The breaking in of the vision is called Bhairava,because it is his and is caused by him92.

¬ß99. The founder of the Pratyabhij√±ƒÅschool of KƒÅ≈õmƒ´ra≈öaivism was SomƒÅnanda, the work written by whom is called≈öivad·πõ·π£·π≠i. But the principal treatise of the school was composedby his pupil UdayƒÅkara, and contains verses which are calledS≈´tras. On these S≈´tras there are glosses and detailed explanations by Abhinavagupta, the pupil of the pupil of Somananda93.Abhinavagupta wrote between 993 and 1015 A. D94., whereforeSomƒÅnanda must be taken to have lived in the first quarter of thetenth century.

The doctrines of the creation of the world and of the relationsbetween the individual and supreme souls set forth by thisschool are the same as those maintained by the preceding one.But the way of the perception of the identity is recognition.according to this system. There is an Upan·π£iad text‚Åµ, fromwhich it follows that every thing shines when He shines and

___________________________________________________________________________

1. Ibid. S≈´tra 4, and Spandapradƒ´pikƒÅ, V. 42. These several kinds of Mala andNƒÅda correspond to PƒÅ≈õas, or fetters, viz., Mala, Karman. MƒÅyƒÅandRodha≈õakti given by MƒÅdhava in the ≈öaivadar≈õana. The word Mala standshere for the PƒÅ≈õa of that system and ƒÄ·πáava for its Mala. It is also calledƒÄ·πáava by ≈öambhudeva.

3.Buhler, Report of a Tour made in Ka≈õmƒ´r; extract from Nos. 465-66, p. OLX.

that everything becomes perceptible by His light, and thus ourknowing power is the same as God’s and everything outside of usbecomes an object of knowledge by his illumining power.Capable of knowledge and action as we are, we partake of thenature of God; but there is no reason to place a limit to thisparticipation, and it must be understood that we are God himself. But the joy and elevation, characteristic of God, we areunconscious of in our present condition, and that is due to thefact that we do not recognise that we are God, though we arereally so. Just as a maiden, stricken with love for a youthwhose excellences have been described to her, is not filled withraptures when she is carried to him and looks upon him as anordinary individual, but is overjoyed and devotes her whole.soul to him when she is told that he is the man whose excellenceshad so fascinated her, so is it with the individual soul. Theserene bliss of godly nature he does not feel, though he is himself God, because he is not aware that those high attributes.But when he iswhich belong to the divine nature exist in himled to believe by his preceptor that he possesses them, i. e when.by his instructions he is enabled to recognise God in himself,then it is that the serene bliss dawns upon him. The Spandaschool mentions the dawning of the form or vision of Bhairava,or God, on the mind in the course of meditation and thereby theclearing away of the impurities as the way to the realisation ofthe identity with God, while this maintains that recognition ofoneself as God is the way.

According to MƒÅdhava, these two systems do not enjoin restraint of the breath, concentration, and all that course of fantasticexternal and internal conduct or discipline which the other.These two schools apparentlyschools prescribe as essentialout themselves off from the old traditional ≈öaivism, whichgradually developed itself into the ghastly KƒÅpƒÅlism or KƒÅlƒÅmukhism, and hence the epithet PƒÅ≈õupata or LƒÅkula cannot beapplied to them in any sense. A fresh revelation, therefore, wastclaimed for Vasugupta, though some of the doctrines of the more.sober ≈öaiva school were preserved in the Spanda system.

XI. The Vƒ´r≈õaiva or Li·πÖgƒÅyat Sect.

¬ß 100. The foundation of this sect is generally attributed to

Basava, who was the son of MƒÅdirƒÅja, a BrƒÅhma·πáa supposed to be of the ƒÄrƒÅdhya sect. His story is given in the BasavapurƒÅ·πáa

1

published in 1905, at Poona. From this story it by no means follows that he founded the sect by settling its doctrines and founding what may be called a church. He, however, appears to be a strenuous supporter of the sect. In the beginning of the BasavapurƒÅ·πáa, NƒÅrada is represented to have gone to ≈öiva and told him that on earth there were devotees of Vi·π£·πáu, followers of the sacrificial religion, Jainas and Buddhists, but that there were no devotees of his. He mentions Visve≈õvarƒÅrƒÅdhya, Pa·πá·∏çitƒÅrƒÅdhya, EkorƒÅma, the great Yogin, and others as having flourished from time to time and established ≈öivabhakti, but there is none now. ≈öiva thereupon told his Nandin to become incarnate on earth for the promotion of his religion and the furtherance of the cause of Vƒ´ra≈õaivas.

From all this it does not appear that Basava was the originator of the sect. He had predecessors, three of whom have just been named. His was a life of political turmoil. From his native. place BƒÅgevƒÅ·∏çi he went to KalyƒÅ·πáa, when Vijjala or Vijja·πáa, was reigning (1157-1167 A. D.). His maternal uncle Baladeva was the minister of the king, and he himself was raised to the position after his death. Basava’s sister, a beautiful woman, was married. by the king. He was in charge of the king’s treasury and spent large amounts in supporting and entertaining members of Li·πÖgƒÅyat mendicants, called Ja·πÖgamas. The matter came to the notice of the king Vija·πáa, who gradually became completely alienated from him, and endeavoured to apprehend him. Basava fled away, and the king sent a few men in persuit. These were easily defeated by Basava, whereupon the king himself advanced with troops to punish him; but Basava had collected a large number of followers and succeeded in defeating him. The king was reconciled to Basava and brought him back to KalyƒÅ·πáa, but there could be no true reconcilement, and after a time Basava caused the king to be assassinated.

___________________________________________________________________________

1. This book and a good many others appertaining to the Li·πÖgƒÅyat sect have been published under the patronage of an influential and enlightenedmember of the sect, the late Mr. MallƒÅppƒÅVƒÅrada of Sholapur.

¬ß 101. There is a work entitled VijjalarƒÅyacarita by a Jaina,which also gives an account of Basava and his relations withVijja·πáa. It is written from the point of view of an enemyof Basava, and mentions Basava’s sister as having been given tothe king as a mistress, which was perhaps true. But since theLi·πÖgƒÅyat account and the Jaina account agree in the main.particulars, they may be accepted as historical¬π. Basava thuswas a scheming politician and could hardly have been the propounder of a new system of doctrines or the organiser of asect. Besides, in the many Li·πÖgƒÅyat works now available, hisname is not mentioned as the name of a teacher of any articles offaith. What he did, therefore, appears to have been that be used hispolitical influence to raise the fortunes of the Vƒ´ra≈õaiva sect, to bringit into prominence, and to disseminate the creed. There is anotherman who has been brought forward by Dr. Fleet, on the strengthof certain Inscriptions, as the founder of the Li·πÖgƒÅyat sect andthat is EkƒÅnta, or EkƒÅntada, RƒÅmayya. An account of this person is also given in the second part of the BasavapurƒÅ·πáa, andthis and that in the Inscriptions come to this that he was anenemy of the Jainas and wished to destroy their gods and shrines.He laid a wager with them that he would cut off his head and layit at the feet of ≈öiva, and if it should be restored to him and replaced on his shoulders as it was before, the Jainas should consent to throw down their idols and profess a belief in ≈öaivism.According to the Inscription, this was first done at Abl≈´r at theplace where it exists, and when RƒÅmayya compelled the Jainasto destroy their idols, they went to KalyƒÅ·πáa and complained toKing Vijja·πáa, who thereupon summoned RƒÅmayya into his presence and required him to explain why he did so. He offered torepeat the feat of cutting off his head and getting it back again inthe presence of the king. The BasavapurƒÅ·πáa represents Basavahimself to have been present when RƒÅmayya laid this wager. Sothat beyond undermining the Jaina seot there is no evidence of RƒÅmavya’s having built up the Vƒ´ra≈õaiva creed.

¬ß 102. In connection with Dƒ´k·π£ƒÅs, or initiatory ceremonies, as,for instance, that which one has to go through when one has to

___________________________________________________________________________

1. For the Li·πÖgƒÅyat nocount see the translation of the BasavapurƒÅ·πáa, Journ.B. B. R. A. S. Vol. VIII, or the BasavapurƒÅ·πáa itself, printed at Poons, andfor the latter see Wilson’s Mackenzie Mss.

Basava, who was the son of MƒÅdirƒÅja, a BrƒÅhma·πáa supposed to be of the ƒÄrƒÅdhya sect. His story is given in the BasavapurƒÅ·πáa¬πpublished in 1905, at Poona. From this story it by no means follows that he founded the sect by settling its doctrines and founding what may be called a church. He, however, appears to be a strenuous supporter of the sect. In the beginning of the BasavapurƒÅ·πáa, NƒÅrada is represented to have gone to ≈öiva and told him that on earth there were devotees of Vi·π£·πáu, followers of the sacrificial religion, Jainas and Buddhists, but that there were no devotees of his. He mentions Visve≈õvarƒÅrƒÅdhya, Pa·πá·∏çitƒÅrƒÅdhya, EkorƒÅma, the great Yogin, and others as having flourished from time to time and established ≈öivabhakti, but there is none now. ≈öiva thereupon told his Nandin to become incarnate on earth for the promotion of his religion and the furtherance of the cause of Vƒ´ra≈õaivas.

From all this it does not appear that Basava was the originator of the sect. He had predecessors, three of whom have just been named. His was a life of political turmoil. From his native. place BƒÅgevƒÅ·∏çi he went to KalyƒÅ·πáa, when Vijjala or Vijja·πáa, was reigning (1157-1167 A. D.). His maternal uncle Baladeva was the minister of the king, and he himself was raised to the position after his death. Basava’s sister, a beautiful woman, was married. by the king. He was in charge of the king’s treasury and spent large amounts in supporting and entertaining members of Li·πÖgƒÅyat mendicants, called Ja·πÖgamas. The matter came to the notice of the king Vija·πáa, who gradually became completely alienated from him, and endeavoured to apprehend him. Basava fled away, and the king sent a few men in persuit. These were easily defeated by Basava, whereupon the king himself advanced with troops to punish him; but Basava had collected a large number of followers and succeeded in defeating him. The king was reconciled to Basava and brought him back to KalyƒÅ·πáa, but there could be no true reconcilement, and after a time Basava caused the king to be assassinated.

___________________________________________________________________________

1. This book and a good many others appertaining to the Li·πÖgƒÅyat seet havebeen published under the patronage of an influential and enlightenedmember of the sect, the late Mr. MallƒÅppƒÅVƒÅrada of Sholapur.

¬ß 101. There is a work entitled VijjalarƒÅyacarita by a Jaina,which also gives an account of Basava and his relations withVijja·πáa. It is written from the point of view of an enemyof Basava, and mentions Basava’s sister as having been given tothe king as a mistress, which was perhaps true. But since theLi·πÖgƒÅyat account and the Jaina account agree in the main.particulars, they may be accepted as historical¬π. Basava thuswas a scheming politician and could hardly have been the propounder of a new system of doctrines or the organiser of asect. Besides, in the many Li·πÖgƒÅyat works now available, hisname is not mentioned as the name of a teacher of any articles offaith. What he did, therefore, appears to have been that be used hispolitical influence to raise the fortunes of the Vƒ´ra≈õaiva sect, to bringit into prominence, and to disseminate the creed. There is anotherman who has been brought forward by Dr. Fleet, on the strengthof certain Inscriptions, as the founder of the Li·πÖgƒÅyat sect andthat is EkƒÅnta, or EkƒÅntada, RƒÅmayya. An account of this person is also given in the second part of the BasavapurƒÅ·πáa, andthis and that in the Inscriptions come to this that he was anenemy of the Jainas and wished to destroy their gods and shrines.He laid a wager with them that he would cut off his head and layit at the feet of ≈öiva, and if it should be restored to him and replaced on his shoulders as it was before, the Jainas should consent to throw down their idols and profess a belief in ≈öaivism.According to the Inscription, this was first done at Abl≈´r at theplace where it exists, and when RƒÅmayya compelled the Jainasto destroy their idols, they went to KalyƒÅ·πáa and complained toKing Vijja·πáa, who thereupon summoned RƒÅmayya into his presence and required him to explain why he did so. He offered torepeat the feat of cutting off his head and getting it back again inthe presence of the king. The BasavapurƒÅ·πáa represents Basavahimself to have been present when RƒÅmayya laid this wager. Sothat beyond undermining the Jaina seot there is no evidence of RƒÅmavya’s having built up the Vƒ´ra≈õaiva creed.

¬ß 102. In connection with Dƒ´k·π£ƒÅs, or initiatory ceremonies, as,for instance, that which one has to go through when one has to

____________________________________________________________________________________________

1. For the Li·πÖgƒÅyat account see the translation of the BasavapurƒÅ·πáa Journ.B. B. B. A. S. Vol. VIII, or the BasavapurƒÅ·πáa itself, printed at Poons, andfor the latter see Wilson’s Mackenzie Mss.

choose a Guru, or preceptor, it is necessary to place four metallicvessols full of water at the four cardinal points and one in themiddle. This last belongs to the person to be consecrated as Guruor preceptor, who is supposed to represent an old ƒÄcƒÅrya, orteacher, of the name of Vi≈õvarƒÅdhya, and the other four to fourother priests chosen as having been brought up in the schools ofReva·πáasiddha, Marulasiddha, EkorƒÅma and Pa·πá·∏çitƒÅrƒÅdhya andconnected with certain Ma·π≠has, or establishments95. The same.list is given in another treatise96. These five vessels. are consocrated to the five faces or forms of ≈öiva, SadyojƒÅta, otc, mentioned in a former section97. The ƒÄcƒÅryas, or teachers, named aboveare believed to have sprung from the five forms of ≈öiva in thisKali age98. Others bearing other names, born in other ages of theworld, are also mentioned, but with these we have nothing to doOf these five teachers three at least are mentioned as having preceded Basavs in the passage quoted at the beginning of thissection.

It will thus appear that the Vƒ´ra≈õaiva, or Li·πÖgƒÅyat, systemcame into existence before Basava. It is affiliated to the moderateor sober school of ≈öaivas known by the name of ≈öaivadar≈õana, orSiddhƒÅntadar≈õana as it is called by its followers; and especiallyto the later form of it alluded to before99. But its technical terms,Sthala, A·πÖga, Li·πÖga, etc. and its ideas are entirely different fromthose of that school as explained by MƒÅdhava and others. Andthese terms we do not meet with elsewhere, so that thismodern school. When it originated, it is difficult to say. But it was clearly in a militant condition in the time of Basava. Itmust, therefore, have originated about a hundred years before.The names of two at least of the five teachers as given above endin the word ar√§

dhya, while in other books all the five have thatepithet attached to their names100. This was the name of a sectallied to the Li·πÖgƒÅyats.

Of the five ƒÄcƒÅryas represented by the five metallic vessels,Mr. Brown¬π does not mention the middle one and calls all the otherfour ƒÄrƒÅdhyas, so that all the five preceptors honoured at the timeof initiation and other ceremonies belong to the ƒÄrƒÅdhya sect,which, according to Mr. Brown, was a sect of the Vƒ´ra≈õaiva creed.There has been a good deal of ill-feeling between the ƒÄrƒÅdhyasand the ordinary Li·πÖgƒÅyats, and that appears to be due to theretention by the former of some BrƒÅhma·πáic rites, such as repeating the holy GƒÅyatrƒ´mantra and wearing the sacred thread. Butthe very name ƒÄrƒÅdhya, which means one to be adored or worshipped, shows that, before the contention between the two sects.arose the ƒÄrƒÅdhyas enjoyed very great respect.

Taking all these circumstances into consideration, what appearsto be the truth is that the Vƒ´ra≈õaiva creed was reduced to a shapeby the ƒÄrƒÅdhyas, who must have been men of learning and helyliving, and the subsequent reformers, such as Basava, gave it adecidedly uncompromising and anti-BrƒÅhma·πáical character. And thus these two sects of the Vƒ´ra≈õaiva faith came into existence.We will now give a short account of the doctrines of this school.

¬ß 103. The One, Highest, Brahman, characterised by existence(Sat), intelligence (Cit), and joy (ƒÄnanda), is the essence of ≈öiva(≈öivatattva) and is called Sthals. Then are given explanations asto why it is called Sthala, two of them based upon an artificialetymology. In the supreme Brahman, or the essence of ≈öiva,Mahat and other principles exist and are eventually resolved intoit. In the first existence the universe, arising from Prak·πõti andPuru·π£a, and to it it returns at the end; therefore it is called Sthala.(The first part stha signifies sthƒÅna, or standing, and the secondpart la signifies laya, or resolution.) That name is given to italso because it is the support of the whole moveable and immoveable world and holds all powers, all luminaries, and all souls.It is the resting place of all beings, of all worlds, and of all possessions. It is the highest place to be attained by those who seekthe highest happiness, and therefore it is called the One only andnon-dualistic Sthala (position).

By the agitation of its innate power (≈öakti), that Sthala becomes divided into two: (1) Li·πÖgasthala, (2) A·πÖgasthala. Li·πÖgasthala is ≈öiva or Rudra and is to be worshipped or adored, whilethe A·πÖgasthala is the individual soul, the worshipper or adorer.In the same manner, the ≈öakti, or power, divides herself into twoby her own will, one of the parts resorting to ≈öiva and beingcalled KalƒÅ, and the other resorting to the individual soul andbeing called Bhakti, or devotion. ≈öakti, or power, has got a certainsusceptibility, which leads it to action and entanglement with theworld, while Bhakti is free from that susceptibility and turnsaway from action and from the world and leads to final deliverance. The ≈öakti, or power makes one an object of worship,while Bhakti makes one a worshipper; therefore, the formerexists in the Li·πÖga or ≈öiva, and the latter in the Anga or individual soul. Eventually, by this Bhakti, there is a union betweenthe soul and ≈öiva.

___________________________________________________________________________

1.Madras journal of Literature and Science, Vol. XI.

The Li·πÖga is ≈öiva himself, and not a mere external emblem ofhim. The Li·πÖgasthala is divided into three: (1) BhƒÅvali·πÖga, (2)PrƒÅ·πáali·πÖga, and (3) I·π£·π≠ali·πÖga. The first is without any parts(KalƒÅ) and is to be perceived by faith. It is simple Sat (existence), not conditioned by space or time, and is higher thanthe highest. The second is to be apprehended by the mind andhas parts and is without parts. The third has parts and isapprehensible by the eye. This confers all desired (i·π£·π≠a) objectsand removes afflictions; or it receives its name because it isworshipped (i·π£·π≠a) with care. The Pranali·πÖga is the intelligence(Cit) of the Supreme Soul, and I·π£·π≠ali·πÖga, the joy. The first isthe highest principle, the second is the subtle form, and the third,the gross form.

These three Li·πÖgas, corresponding to the soul, the life and thegross form, and being characterised by use (Prayoga), formulas.(Mantra) and action (KriyƒÅ), form what are called KalƒÅ, NƒÅdaand Bindu. Each of these three is divided into two; the firstInto MahƒÅli·πÖga and PrasƒÅdali·πÖga, the second into Carali·πÖga and≈öivali·πÖga, and the third into Guruli·πÖga and ƒÄcƒÅrali·πÖga.These six operated on by six kinds of ≈öakti, or power, give riseto the following six forms. (1) When the ≈öiva essenceoperated on by the power of intelligence (Cit), it forms theMahƒÅli·πÖga, the attributes of which are the absence of birth and

death, freedom from taint, perfection, unity, subtleness, beinghigher than the highest, incurruptibility, unfathomableness,capability of being apprehended by faith and love, and idealistic(Caitanyar≈´pa (2) When the ≈öiva essence gets permeatedwith its highest power (ParƒÅ≈õakti), then is produced a principlecalled SƒÅdƒÅkhya¬π which is light, eternal, indivisible, imperceptible to the senses, apprehensible by reason, indestructible, and therudiment that develops; and that principle is called PrasƒÅdali·πÖga.(3) When the ≈öiva essence is operated on by its primeval power(ƒÄdi≈õakti), Carali·πÖga is produced, which is infinite and pervadesthe internal and external world, which is full of light, is aPuru·π£a (a person), and is higher than the PradhƒÅna or Prak·πõti,and capable of being contemplated by the mind alone. (4) Whenpermeated by the will power (IcchƒÅ≈õakti) it forms ≈öivali·πÖga,which is a finite principle with a sense of egoism, possessed ofknowledge and power (KalƒÅ), having a celestial refulgence, withone face, and serene. (5) When perineated with the power ofknowledge (J√±ƒÅna≈õakti) it forms a Guruli·πÖga, which possessesagency, presides over every system or science that instructs, isfull of light, a boundless ocean of joy, and dwells in human intelligence. (6) When influenced by the power of action.(KriyƒÅ≈õakti), it is called ƒÄcƒÅrali·πÖga, which in the shape ofaction serves as the support for the existence of all things, whichis conceivable by the mind, and leads to a life of renunciation.

It will be seen that the original entity becomes divided intoGod and individual soul by its innate power, and the six formsof the first, that are mentioned, are the various ways of lookingat God. The first form is the infinite Being considered independently. The second is the form in which we conceive ofhim as developing or creating by its highest power. The thirdis the form in which he is conceived as distinct from thematerial world. The fourth is a bodily form, the body, however, not being made up of ordinary matter, but celestial like thebody attributed to NƒÅrƒÅya·πáa, or K·πõ·π£·πáa, by the Vai·π£·πáavas. Thefifth is the form in which he instructs mankind. And the sixthinvolves the idea of his guiding the individual soul in hisactions until he is delivered. In this form ≈öiva is the Redeemer.

___________________________________________________________________________

1. The SƒÅdƒÅkhya is the product of the combination of the principle, the≈öivaessence, with the two of the five powers, ParƒÅand ƒÄdi. The SƒÅdƒÅkhyasarefive (1) ≈öivasƒÅdƒÅkhya, which develops into SadƒÅ≈õiva;(2) Am≈´rta, or notfinite, which becomes ƒ™≈õa; (3) Sam≈´rta, or finite, which results in Brahme≈õa;(4) Kart·πõ, or agent, which becomes ƒ™≈õvara; (b) Karman, or action, whichdevelops into ƒ™≈õƒÅna. The SƒÅdƒÅkhya alluded to in the test must be SadƒÅ≈õiva.

Bhakti is the characteristic of the individual souls. It consists in a tendency towards God, and there are three stages inthe progress of this tendency and, corresponding to these, thereare three divisions of the A·πÖgasthala, or the subject of the individual soul. The first or highest division is called YogƒÅ·πÖga, thesecond BhogƒÅ·πÖga, and the third TyƒÅgƒÅ·πÖga. By the first, a manobtains happiness by his union with ≈öiva; by the second, heenjoys along with ≈öiva; and the last involves the abandonmentof the world as transient or illusory. The first corresponds to theresolution into the cause and to the condition of sound sleep, thesecond to the subtle body and to dreamy sleep, and the third tothe gross body and to the wakeful condition. Two varieties ofeach of these are distinguished. Of the first, or YogƒÅ·πÖga, wehave the two, Aikya and ≈öara·πáa. The first consists in sharingthe joys of ≈öiva after one is convinced of the unreality of thewhole world. This is called SamarasƒÅBhakti, in which Godand the soul are united in blissful experience. The second iscalled ≈öara·πáabhakti, in which one sees Li·πÖga, or God, in himselfand everything else. It is a condition of joy for oneself. Thesecond is also of two kinds: (1) PrƒÅ·πásli·πágin and (2) PrasƒÅdin. Thefirst consists in abandoning all regard for life, renunciation ofegoism, and concentration of the whole mind upon the Li·πÖga, orGod. The second is realised, when one resigns all the objects ofone’s enjoyment to the Li·πÖga, or God, and serenity (PrasƒÅda) isacquired. The divisions of the last are M√§he≈õvers and Bhakta.The first is one who has a firm belief in the existence of God, whogoes through the whole discipline consisting in the observance ofvows and restraints, which have ≈öiva for their object, and truth,morality, cleanliness, etc. and a heroically rigid vow based upona firm belief in the unity of the Li·πÖga, or God. A Bhakta is one.who, turning his mind away from all objects by which it is attracted and practising devotion and rites, lives a life of indifference to the world¬π.

This represents the progress of the soul from indifference tothe world, which is the first step, through the intermediate stages,in a reverse order, to SƒÅmarasya, or union in blissful experience.with ≈öiva, which is the highest condition. The goal thus pointedout does not involve a perfect identity between the supreme andindividual souls, or the shaking off of individuality and becoming a simple soul unconscious of itself, which is the doctrine ofthe great non-dualistic school of ≈öa·πÅkars.

The belief of the Vƒ´ra≈õaiva school that the original essence of≈öivadivided itself by its own innate power into Li·πÖga or God,and A·πÖga, or the individual soul, and under the influence of otherpowers the essence became the creator of the world, shows that thedoctrine of that school is that the rudiment of the creation existsin God himself in the shape of his power, but this power is notunreal. This doctrine, therefore, resembles that of RƒÅmƒÅnuja, butwith the latter there is a real rudiment of the soul and of the external world characterising God which afterwards develops, butwith the Vƒ´ra≈õaivas there exists a power only in God which leads tocreation; so that it is the power that characterises God accordingto the latter, while the rudiment is his characteristic according tothe former. The Li·πÖg√§

yat school, therefore, is a school of qualified spiritual monism (Vi≈õi·π£·π≠ƒÅdavaita). It will also have beenseen that the method of redemption taught by this school isthat of Bhakti or love of God, and a course of moral and spiritualdiscipline up to the attainment of SƒÅmarasya with≈ö

iva. In thisrespect also it resembles RƒÅmƒÅnuja’s system.

≈örƒ´ka·πátha≈õivƒÅcƒÅrya, whose BhƒÅ·π£ya on the VeƒÅantas≈´tras haslong been before the public, holds the same view. Under I. 4. 22,he states that the word ƒÄtman in the sense of the individual soulis used to express the supreme soul in BU. (IV. 5. 6), because thelatter is the internal controller of the former and is spoken of asidentical with everything in this sense. Under II. 2. 38, he statesthat ≈öiva as possessed of powers is the material cause of the world;and in his comment on IV. 4. 3-4, he represents the deliveredsoul as similar to the Supreme Soul, that is, as having the attributes of the latter. And under IV. 4, 2, he speaks of the delivered.soul as Samarasa, or united in blissful experience with the Supreme Soul. Thus Srƒ´ka·πá·π≠ha’s view appears to be identicalwith that of the Vƒ´ra≈õaivas. Therefore unlike the four older.schools (PƒÅ≈õupata and others), which are dualistic, these three≈öaiva schools hold a doctrine of qualified spiritual monism.

___________________________________________________________________________

1.The above is an abstract of the matter contained in the Anubhavas≈´tra of Mayideva, Sholapur, 1909,

¬ß 104. The highest class of Li·πÖgƒÅyats is composed of those whocall themselves Li·πÖgi-BrƒÅhma·πáas, the other castes or classes whowear the Li·πÖgabeing simply their followers. The Li·πÖgi-BrƒÅhma·πáas consist of two main classes, the ƒÄcƒÅryasand the Pa√±camas.The legendary account given of these is as follows. The ƒÄcƒÅryaswere originally five in number and sprang from the five faces,SadyojƒÅta, etc., of ≈öiva spoken of in a former section101. They arethe same as those mentioned above as having a metallic vesselplaced in their names on the occasion of any holy ceremony.From these five have sprung up all the priestly classes nowexisting. These five had five Gotras, viz. Vƒ´ra, Nandin, V·πõ·π£abha,Bh·πõ·πÖgin, and Skanda, who were originally persons almost as highas ≈öive himself. From the ƒ™≈õƒÅna face of ≈öiva sprang a Ga·πáe≈õvara(leader of a group), who had five faces. From these five faces.sprang five Pa√±camas, known by the names of MakhƒÅri, KƒÅlƒÅri,PurƒÅri, SmarƒÅri, and VedƒÅri, which, the reader will remember,were the names of ≈öiva himself given to him on account of certaindeeds done by him. From these arose others who are called.Upapa√±camas. Each Pa√±cama has to connect himself with oneof the five ƒÄcƒÅryas as his Guru. The Gotra of the Guru is hisGotra, and there can be no marriage relation between the members of the same Gotra. These Pa√±camas have got Gotra, Pravarsand ≈öƒÅkhƒÅof their own, and the Li·πÖgƒÅyats thus seem to havecopied the Br·πÖhmanic system. The Pa√±icamas are spoken of asthe true devotees of ≈öiva102.

According to the ordinary acccunt the true Li·πÖgƒÅyats aredivided into four classes: (1) Ja·πÖgamas, or priests, (2) ≈öƒ´lavants,

or pious, (3) Banjigs, or traders, and (4) Pa√±camsƒÅlis. The secondand the third classes are based on the occupation or mode of lifefollowed so that even here, there are only the two classes mentioned in the work referred to above. The members of the first orƒÄcƒÅrya class are popularly called Ja·πÖgamas. Of these there aresome who are called Viraktas (passionless) and who devote themselves to contemplation and other religious exercises and live a lifeof celibacy and asceticism. They maintain a convent (Ma·π≠ha)and are adored by all people.

One such convent, which might be called the chief convent, isthat which exists at Chitaldrug in the Mysore territory about ahundred miles from Dharwar. The head monk is held in deepreverence and exercises great influence over the followers of thesect.

The second division of the class comprises those who follow apriestly occupation and conduct all ceremonies. They are marriedmen and lead the life of householders. They exercise religiouscontrol over the Pa√±camas and the followers of their sect. Thesepriestly Ja·πÖgamas are the representatives of one or other of thefive principal establishments located in different parts of thecountry from the HimƒÅlaya to the Mysore province. Any knottyquestion concerning the sect is decided by the final orders issuedat one of these establishments. Besides the true Li·πÖgƒÅyats their isan affiliated class and another composed of half Li·πÖgƒÅyats. TheLi·πÖgƒÅyats abstain from meat and drink. Their widows areallowed to marry. And women are not considered polluted anduntouchable during the days of nonthly sickness, as is the case.among BrƒÅhma·πáic Hindus.

$ 105. There is a Dƒ´k·π£ƒÅceremony among the Vƒ´ra≈õaivas corresponding to Upanayana among the BrƒÅhma·πáas. Instead of theGƒÅyatrƒ´mantra of the latter, they have the Mantra Om nama≈õ≈öivƒÅya’, and have to wear the Li·πÖga, or emblem of ≈öiva, in theplace of Yaj√±opavƒ´ta. On the occasion of the Dƒ´k·π£ƒÅ, the Guruholds a Li·πÖga in his left hand, worships it in the usual sixteenways, and shows it to the disciple. Then placing it in the lefthand of the disciple and enjolning him to look upon it as his ownsoul and as the highest existing thing and so forth, he ties itround the neck of the disciple with a silken cloth by repeating a

Mantra used by the BrƒÅhma·πáas in putting on the Yaj√±opavƒ´ta,This is called the Li·πÖgasv√§yattadƒ´k·π£ƒÅ. This ceremony is performed in the case of girls also, and the women too have to wear theLi·πÖga like men. The Li·πÖgais generally put into a box made ofsilver and suspended round the neck. The Vƒ´ra≈õaivas have togo through daily ceremonies similar to the twilight adorations ofthe BrƒÅhma·πáas, and the Mantra repeated on the occasion is thatgiven above, as also the ≈öiva-GƒÅyatrƒ´, the first two lines ofwhich are the same as the BrƒÅhma·πáicGƒÅyatrƒ´, and the last is’Tan na·∏•≈öva·∏• pracodayƒÅt’.

In the marriage ceremony the Mantra to be repeated on theoccasion of the taking hold of the hand of the bride is the sameas among the BrƒÅhma·πáas, and in the ceremony of walking theseven steps together with the bride, the formulas repeated arethe same as those used by ·πögvedin BrƒÅhma·πáas. But in theirmarriage ceremony, they do not perform the rite of throwingparched rice into the fire as the BrƒÅhma·πáas do. The worship ofthe Li·πÖga, called I·π£·π≠a-Li·πÖga, worn on the body, is their chiefdivine worship; and attendance at temples and worship of theLi·πÖga therein are by no means necessary for them. They donot concern themselves directly with the public temples of ≈öiva.

¬ß 106. There is a traditional legend among the Li·πÖgƒÅyatsthat, when ≈öiva brought Brahmadeva into existence, he told himto create the world. But Brahmadeva said that he did not knowhow to do it. Whereupon ≈öiva created it himself in order that it might serve him as a model. And the ƒÄcƒÅryas and Pa√±camas, asdetailed above with their Gotras and ≈öƒÅkhƒÅs, are that creation of≈öiva. The true import of this legend is that the Li·πÖgƒÅyat set upa system for themselves as a rival to the BrƒÅhma·πáic system andthe close resemblance between the two confirms this view. Buta mere copy was not their object, and they introduced severalreforms, especially in the condition of women, as will have beenseen from the above notice. In this respect, this system differsfrom all other schools, Vai·π£·πáavs or ≈öaiva or even Buddhist orJains, who did not set up for themselves a special system ofsocial relations and domestic rites, though, as shown above, thatframed by the Li·πÖgayats for themselves is a copy of that of theBrƒÅhma·πáas, which, however, is a reformed copy.

The impression that this whole account creates in one is thatLi·πÖgƒÅyatism owes its origin to a spirit of jealousy of the powerexercised by BrƒÅhma·πáism and of rivalry with the system. Sucha spirit of jealousy and rivalry cannot be expected to have arisenin thoroughly depressed minds. The system therefore must havecome into existence among the spirited members of the upperclasses of non-BrƒÅhmanicHindus under the leadership of a bodyof men composed of BrƒÅhma·πáas known by the name of ƒÄrƒÅdhyas.Some of the members of this body did not go far enough in thedesired reform, as mentioned before, and formed a distinct sect¬π.

It will thus be seen that all the Li·πÖgƒÅyats have not sprungup from the ≈ö≈´dra caste, but there is a mixture of the threehigher orders among them. The claim that the two main classesof the sect put forward of their being Li·πÖgi-BrƒÅhma·πáas, i, e.,BrƒÅhma·πáas wearing the Li·πÖgƒÅ, seems to be founded on truth.The ƒÄcƒÅrya or Ja·πÖgama class is said to have sprung from thefive holy persons, adored on the occasion of a religious ceremony,whose names end in the suffix ƒÅrƒÅdhyasignificative of their beingBrƒÅhma·πáas. We might therefore safely take them to be of aBrƒÅhma·πáic descent¬≤. As to the Pa√±camas, they probably represent the Vai≈õya order of the BrƒÅhma·πáicsystem which followedthe occupation of traders and cultivators, and as the Vai≈õyasbelong to the class of the twice-born, so also do the Pa√±camasand hence they are included in the Li·πÖgi-BrƒÅhma·πáa group.

___________________________________________________________________________

1. An ƒÄrƒÅdhya sect is mentioned by AnantƒÅnandagiri as having come intoconflict with ≈öa·πÅkarƒÅcƒÅrya / See≈öa·πÅkarƒÅvljaya, Bibl. Ind., p. 37). In thecorresponding portion of Dhanapati’s Din·∏çima which accompaniesMƒÅdhava’s ≈öa·πÅkaravijaya the name of the seat does not occur; so that itis questionable whether the ƒÄrƒÅdhya seot came into existence before≈öa·πÅkara, even if we suppose that the seat mentioned by AnantƒÅnandagiriwas the same as the one we have noticed as affiliated to the Li·πÖgƒÅyats.Or, on the evidence of AnantƒÅnandagiri the ƒÄrƒÅdhya sect may be considered to have come into existence about the time of ≈öa·πÅkarƒÅcƒÅrya,that is, before the ninth century A. D., and the theory advanced, that theLi·πÖgƒÅyat reform was carried out within its limits, and a portion of theƒÄrƒÅdhya sect adopted the new creed and developed it, while anotherremained orthodox and staunch to some of the BrƒÅhma·πáicpractices. Tothis portion is to be traced the ƒÄrƒÅdhyaseat of the present day.

2. There are Ja·πÖgamas who know Sanskrit, and I have been in communication with one such of the name of MallikƒÅrjuna≈õƒÅstrin, who directed me tosome of the books of the seat wich I have followed in this section, and alsogave oral information on some points. He claims to be a BrƒÅhma·πáaauthorised to study the Vedas, his own Vada being the White Yajurveda.

XII. ≈öaivism in the Dravi·∏ça Country.

¬ß 107. ≈öaivism prevails in the Dravi·∏ça or Tamil country,and possesses an extensive literature of its own. It consists ofeleven collections. The first three contain the hymns composedby a saint held in great reverence, of the name TirunÃÑƒÅnasambandha. They are three hundred and eighty-four in number,each being called a Padigam, which consists of ten stanzas withan eleventh containing the author’s name us ially added. Thenext three were composed by Appar who was an older contemporary of Sambandha, who had renounced Buddhism or ratherJainism and become a ≈öaiva. The seventh collection belongsto Sundara who was a BrƒÅhma·πáa devotee of a later generation.These seven books are called DevƒÅram and are compared to theBr√§hma·πáic Veda. In certain processions, while on the one sidethe hymns of the Br√§hma·πáic Veda are repeated, on the other aresung those contained in the Devaram which are addressed to thedeity. The TiruvƒÅ≈õagam forms the eighth book, and it resembles.the Upani·π£ads. The author of this book is MƒÅnikkavƒÅ≈õagar.The ninth group is made up of hymns composed in imitation ofthe DevƒÅram hymns. One of the writers is KandarƒÅditya, aCola king, from whom RƒÅjarƒÅja Cola, who came to the throne in984-85 A. D., was fifth in descent. The tenth contains mysticsongs of a Yogin called Tirumular. The eleventh collection iscomposed of miscellaneous pieces, the last ten of which werewritten by Nambi ƒÄndƒÅr Nambi. The third of these ten formsthe basis of the Tamil PurƒÅ·πáa called PeriyaPurƒÅ·πáa. These elevencollections together with the PeriyaPurƒÅ·πáa, which are all writtenin the Tamil language, form the sacred literature of the Tamil≈öaivas. Besides these there are the works of what are called.SantƒÅns-ƒÄcƒÅryas, which are fourteen in number and called.SiddhƒÅnta≈õƒÅstras. Their contents are of a philosophical nature.

___________________________________________________________________________

The head monk of the Chitaldrug convent alladed to above was on avisitation to Poons about two months ago with all the state of a spiritualpotentate, having four elephants with him and a number of followers. Hewas a good, courteous and kindly person, bad studied Sanskrit grammarand was able to converse fluently in pure Sanskrit. Some of the books ofthe sect are written in Sanskrit.

The most highly honoured of all these writers is Tiru√±ƒÅnasambandha. He was a BrƒÅhma·πáa by birth, and the poeticfaculty was developed in him very early in life. His hymns arefull of the purest devotional feeling and are melodious. Thetunes in which they were originally sung were Dravi·∏çian, butin later times northern melodies with northern names came to beused. Sambandha’s image is set up for worship in every ≈öaivaltemple, and he is adored by Tamil poets and philosophers in thebeginning of their works. He was a great enemy of Buddhistsand Jainas; and every tenth stanza of his Padigams, or hymns,contains an impr√©cation against them. On one occasion, he wasinvited by the queen of Kuni PƒÅ·πádya of MadhurƒÅ, where he helda disputation with the Buddhists or Jainas, which ended in theconversion of the king to the Saiva faith¬π.

In an Inscription in the RƒÅjarƒÅje≈õvara temple at Tanjore theking RƒÅjarƒÅjadeva, after whom the temple was named, makes adaily allowance for the support of the reciters or singers of theTiruppadiyam or the Padigams of Tiru√±ƒÅnasambandba, beforethe twenty-ninth year of his reign¬≤. The date of RƒÅjarƒÅja’saccession to the throne has been determined by the mention of alunar eclipse in one of his inscriptions to be 984-5 A. D103. Thisis consistent with the fact mentioned in another Inscription104 thathe conquered SatyƒÅ≈õraya, who was the immediate successor ofTailapa, the founder of the later CƒÅlukya dynasty of MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠ra,and died in ≈öaka 930, or 1008 A. D. Thus before the twenty-ninthyear of RƒÅjarƒÅja, i. e. before 1013 A. D., the Padigams of Sambandha had come to be looked upon as so sacred that the recitation or singing of them was considered an act of religious meritlike the repetition of the ≈öatarudriya by the followers of theBrƒÅhma·πáic Veda. This character the hymns of Sambandhacould not have acquired unless they had come into existenceabout four hundred years before the beginning of the eleventhcentury. This is consistent with the conclusion arrived at byMr. Pillai that Sambandha flourished in the seventh century.

___________________________________________________________________________

1. The above account is mostly taken from the able paper of P. SundaramPillai published in the Ind. Ant. Vol. XXV, pp. 113ff. It is to be regrettedthat Mr. Pillai does not give us precise information as to whether it wasthe Buddhists against whom Sambandha direcss bis attacks or the Jainas.

2.South-Indian Inscriptions ed. by E. Hultzsch, Vol. I. p. 252, No. 65.

The Inscriptions in the temples at KƒÅ√±cipura contain evidenceof ≈öaivism being in a flourishing condition in the sixth century.The Pallava king RƒÅjasi·πÅha constructed a temple, and the godinside was named after him RƒÅjasi·πÅhe≈õvara. RƒÅjasi·πÅha appears.from some of the Inscriptions to have been a contemporary of theearly CƒÅlukya prince Pulake≈õin I105, who may be referred toabout the year 550 A. D., as his son Kƒ´rtivarman I, came to thethrone about the year 567 A. D.¬≤.

The ≈öaivism that prevailed in the Tamil country seems tohave been generally of the ordinary kind, since the hymns in theDevƒÅram sing the praises of ≈öiva and exhibit forvent devotionalfeeling, but there must have been some Dar≈õana or system ofphilosophy also, since in an Inscription in the RƒÅjasi·πÅhe≈õvaratemple at KƒÅ√±ci AtyantakƒÅma, which was another name of RƒÅjasi·πÅha, is represented as proficient in the system of the ≈öaivasiddhƒÅntas. And the last species of the ≈öaiva Iterature detailedabove is, it will have been seen, called SiddhƒÅnta≈õƒÅstra composedby SantƒÅna-ƒÄcƒÅryas. These must be philosophical works on≈öaivism. And the system therein taught appears in all likelihoodto be the same or similar to the ≈öaivadar≈õana, which has alreadybeen explained. But what exactly the system taught by theSiddhƒÅntas was, we have not the means of finding out, as none ofthe works is available for examination.

The PeriyapurƒÅ·πáa gives an account of sixty-three Bhaktas ordevotees of ≈öiva, and these correspond to the ƒÄlvƒÅrs of theVai·π£·πáavas. The enemies that both these classes of devotees hadto contend with were Jainas, and it appears to me that both≈öaivism and Vai·π£·πáavism penetrated to the extreme South ofIndia after the revival of BrƒÅhma·πáism in the North during thefourth and fifth centuries. Buddhism and Jainism had beenintroduced earlier, and were in possession of the field when thetwo later systems of theistic belief were introduced into theSouthern country. Hence arose the necessity of controversiesand contests which these systems carried on with their earlierpredecessors. Whether ≈öaivism extended itself to the Tamilcountry before the revival, we have not the means of determining.

___________________________________________________________________________

2.Early History of the Deccan, Second Ed., p. 61 (Volume III of this Edition, p. 68.-N. B. U.]

XIII. The ≈öƒÅktas or ≈öakti Worshippers.

¬ß 108. In the Vedic literature down to the G·πõhyas≈´tras whichwe have examined for tracing the development of the idea ofRudra-≈öiva, no female devotee of predominant power is mentioned.We have such names as Rudrant and BhavƒÅnƒ´, which are simplyderivatives and do not show a belief in the existence of anindependent powerful goddess,UmƒÅ, too, is the wife of a godand does not overshadow her male consort. In the MBh,(Bhƒ´·π£maparvan, chap. 23), however, there is a hymn addressedto DurgƒÅ by Arjuna under the advice of K·πõ·π£·πáa in which she isprayed to for granting victory in the forthcoming battle. Thisbymn itself shows that at the time when it was composed andinserted in the poem, DurgƒÅhad already acquired such animportance that she was adored by men as a powerful goddess,able to fulfil their desires. Among the names by which she isaddressed occur the following: KumƒÅrƒ´(maiden), KƒÅlƒ´(blackor female time as destroyer), KƒÅpƒÅlƒ´(wearer of skulls), MahƒÅkƒÅlƒ´(the great destroyer), Ca·πá·∏çƒ´(angry), KƒÅtyayƒÅnƒ´ (of theKƒÅtya family ), KarƒÅlƒÅ(frightful), VijayƒÅ(Victory), Kau≈õikƒ´(of the Kusika family ), UmƒÅ, KƒÅntƒÅravƒÅsinƒ´(dwelling in theforest). There is another hymn in the Vƒ´rƒÅ·π≠aparvan (chap. 6)sung by Yudhi·π£·π≠hira. It does not exist in the principal SouthernMSS., and is probably an interpolation, as it contains almost thesame matter as in a similar passage in the Hariva·πÅsa. Thepoints and epithets in this hymn which deserve notice are these.She is called Mahi·π£ƒÅsuranƒÅ≈õinƒ´(or the destroyer of the demonin the shape of a buffalo) and she is fond of wine, flesh and beasts.She was born to Ya≈õodƒÅ and dashed against a stone, whereupon

she went to heaven. She is called the most beloved of NƒÅrƒÅya·πáaand the sister of VƒÅsudeva. She resides permanently on theVindhya mountain.

It is related in the Hariva·πÅ≈õa (vv. 3236 ff.) that Vi·π£·πáudescended into the PƒÅtƒÅla, and asked sleep in the form of destroying time (NidrƒÅKƒÅlar≈´pi·πáƒ´) to become the daughter ofYa≈õodƒÅ. She is told that she would become Kau≈õikƒ´and wouldhave a permanent residence on the Vindhya mountain. There shewas told that she would kill ≈öumbha and Ni≈õumbha and wouldbe worshipped by animal sacrifices. There is given a hymn toƒÄpyƒÅ(DurgƒÅ) in which she is represented as the goddess of≈öabaras, Pulindas, Barbaras and other wild tribes, and as fond ofwine and flesh.

The goddess that killed the buffalo-demon, was, according tothe MƒÅrka·πá·∏çeya-PurƒÅ·πáa (ch. 82) made up of the fierce radianceof ≈öiva, vi·π£·πáu and Brahmadeva, and all the other gods contributed to the formation of her limbs as well as her ornaments.She is called Ca·πá·∏çƒ´and AmbikƒÅThe formation of the goddessthat killed ≈öumbha and Ni≈õumbha, according to the account.which follows, is thus explained. The gods being oppressed bythe demons ≈öumbha and Ni≈õumbha went to the HimƒÅlayas andpraised the goddess, whereupon PƒÅrvatƒ´came out to bathe in theGanges. Then ≈öivƒÅ, also called AmbikƒÅ, came out of the body ofPƒÅrvatƒ´, and said that it was she whom the gods were praising toinduce her to kill ≈öumbha and Ni≈õumbha, She was calledKƒÅu≈õikƒ´, because she sprang out from Ko≈õaor frame of PƒÅrvatƒ´’sbody. When AmbikƒÅcame out of her body, PƒÅrvatƒ´’s complexion became dark, and hence she received the name of KƒÅlikƒÅ(darkone). In the course of the fight, when ≈öumbha and Ni≈õumbhapounced upon her, her forehead became dark with anger, andfrom it came KƒÅlƒ´with a frightful face wearing a garland ofskulls and a tiger-skin and with an infernal weapon (Kha·π≠vƒ´·πÖga)in her hand. She killed the demons Ca·πá·∏ça and Mu·πá·∏ça, and wentback to AmbikƒÅ, who thereupon, since she had killed thosedemons, gave her the name CƒÅmu·πá·∏çƒÅ. The seven ≈öaktis, BrƒÅhmƒ´,MƒÅhe≈õvarƒ´, KaumƒÅrƒ´, Vai·π£·πáavƒ´, Varahƒ´, Narasi·πÅhi and Aindrƒ´, which are the powers or spirits of the gods from whom their

names are derived, are called her excellent forms (Vibh≈´tis).At the end, the goddess says that she would, in the VaivasvataManu, destroy ≈öumbha and Ni≈õumbha again by assuming theform of the goddess residing on the Vindhya mountain, and proceeds to give the other forms that she would assume on otheroccasions such as the daughter of Nanda, ≈öƒÅkambharƒ´, Bhƒ´mƒÅ,BhrƒÅmarƒ´, etc.

¬ß 109. In the account bere given, it will be seen that there isone goddess with a number of different names. But the criticaleye will see that they are not merely names, but indicate differentgoddesses who owed their conception to different historical conditions, but who were afterwards indentified with the one goddessby the usual mental habit of the Hindus. First we have UmƒÅ,the protectress, the consort of ≈öiva. Then we have Haimavatƒ´and PƒÅrvatƒ´which are the epithets of UmƒÅ, since Siva, herconsort, was Giri≈õa, or dweller on the mountain, and she was awoman born on the mountain.

Then there are goddesses, dwelling in forests and on theVindhiya mountain, to whom animals and even human beings weresacrificed, and oblations of wine were given and who were alsothe goddesses worshipped by the wild tribes, such as Pulindas,≈öabaras and Barbaras. These were fierce goddesses and have thenames of KarƒÅlƒÅ, KƒÅlƒ´, Ca·πá·∏çƒ´, CƒÅmu·πá·∏çƒÅ, and others. It must beadmitted, however, that the first two names came into use whenin an early age Rudra was identified with Agni, whose flames,which were considered his tongues, have those two names andfive others. Probably the ferocity of the later goddesses of thosenames was due to this identification and not to their being theobjects of worship to the ferocicus barbarous tribes. In all likelihood, however, both the elements contributed to give thatcharacter to KƒÅlƒ´, KarƒÅlƒÅand CƒÅmu·πá·∏çƒÅ. That an aboriginalelement should have contributed to the formation of Rudra’sconsort in later times, as it did in earlier times, towards theformation of Rudra himself as he is represented in the ≈öatarudriya, is a matter that might be expected.

A third and powerful element in the conception of thesegoddesses is that of ≈öakti, or power. The powers of willing, acting,

creating, illuding, etc. were conceived of as goddesses as thenoun ≈öakti is of the feminine gender. The seven goddessesnamed above, BrƒÅhmƒ´, Mahe≈õvarƒ´, eto. owe their origin to thisconception of ≈öakti and the powers of the seven gods. In latertimes some of the BrƒÅhma·πáic families came to have tutelarygoddesses, and thus we have KƒÅtyayƒÅnƒ´, or the goddess of theKƒÅtyas, and Kau≈õikƒ´, the goddess of the Kau≈õikas. A furtherdevelopment went on especially under the influence of the idea of≈öakti, or power, and thus we have three forms in which thegoddess was worshipped. First we have the ordinary bland.form, in which the goddess is worshipped. Then we have thefierce form, in which she is associated with the schools ofKƒÅpƒÅlikas and KƒÅlƒÅmukhas, and animals and human beings aresacrificed. And the third is the sensual form, in which she isthe object of worship with the school of the SƒÅktas, who are socalled because they are worshippers of ≈öakti.

¬ß 110. The Tantras inculcating the worship of the goddess inthese various forms, constitute a considerable body of literature.We will here notice the formation, doctrines and practices of aschool based on one of these forms, that which we have calledsensual. The goddess here is called ƒÄnandabhairavƒ´, Tripurasundarƒ´, and LalitƒÅ. Her dwelling is thus described. There isan ocean of nectar, in which there are five celestial trees. Thenthere is a row or enclosure of Nƒ´pa or Kadamba trees, in themidst of which is a pavilion made of jewel stones. In thatpavilion is situated a palace made of the wish-giving stone,where lies the great ƒ™≈õƒÅnƒ´, the great Tripurasundarƒ´, on a couch,which is ≈öiva, with Mahe≈õana for its coverlet and Sada≈õiva forits pillow. The legs of the couch are Brahmadeva, Hari, Rudraand ƒ™≈õvara. These are spirits discharging certain functions contsined in the essence of Mahe≈õvara¬π. This is a mythologicalexplanation of certain figures in the mystic cirles and of technical terms. The goddess is thus elevated to the highest position.ƒÄnandabhairava or MahƒÅbhairava, which is the name given to≈öiva, is the soul of, or is composed of, the nine collections ofthings of which the world is made up, such as time and itsvarious forms (KƒÅlavy≈´ha), existing things like the blue substance (Kulavy≈´ha), names (NƒÅmavy≈´ha), perception (J√±ƒÅvy≈´ha), the five faculties, viz. consciousness, heart, will, intelligence, and mind (Cittavy≈´ha). MahƒÅbhairava is the soul of thegoddess; therefore she also is the soul of, or composed of, thenine collections. Buth, therefore, constitute one entity. Whenthere is SƒÅmarasya, or community of joy or intonse love betweenthem, creation follows. The female olement, or MahƒÅbhairavƒ´,however, is predominant in the process of creation and the maleelement, or MahƒÅbhairava, in the work of destruction106.

___________________________________________________________________________

1.Saundaryalaharƒ´with Lak·π£mƒ´dhara’s commentary, Mysore Ed, comment. on vv. 8 and 92.

The metaphysical doctrines of what is called ≈öƒÅmbhavadar≈õana, on which the usual practices and rites of the ≈öaktasprofess to be based, are these¬≤. ≈öiva and ≈öakti are the primordialsubstances. ≈öiva in the form of PrakƒÅ≈õa (light) enters into≈öakti in the form of Vimar≈õa or Sph≈´rti (feeling or appearance)and assumes the form of a Bindu (drop); and ≈öakti similarlyenters into ≈öiva, whereupon the Bindu develops, and there arisesout of it the female element called NƒÅda (sound). These two,the Bindu and the Nada, becoming united, form one compoundBindu, and that substance represents the intense affinity betweenthe female and male energies and is called KƒÅma (love). Again,there are two drops, one of which is white and represents themale element, and the other, red, which represents the femaleelement. These form the KalƒÅ; these three again, the compoundBindu, and the white and red drops form one substance called.KƒÅmakalƒÅ. Thus there are four powers united here: (1) theoriginal Bindu representing the material of which the world ismade; (2) NƒÅda, or sound, upon which depends the naming ofthe substances, arising from the development of the Bindu.Between these two there is intense love, but no creation followssimply from it. They only contain the materials of things andspeech Therefore a productive energy is associated with themby (3) the white male drop which, however, by itself cannctproduce, and by (4) the female red drop which is fecundated bythe male drop.

___________________________________________________________________________

2. The following contains in a recast form the matter given in pp. 89-91 ofmy Report on the Search for Sanskrit Manuscripts during 1883-84[Volume II of this Edition, pp. 219-223 N. B. U.]

When all these four principles unite into one substarce,KƒÅmakalƒÅ, the whole creation of words and the things expressedby them (VƒÅgarthau), proceeds. Another substance called theHƒÅrdhakalƒÅ is also developed, according to some, along with theNƒÅda, when the female element first enters into the simple Bindu.In a certain text the highest deity, or KƒÅmakalƒÅ is spoken of ashaving the sun (compound Bindu) for her face, fire and moon(the red and white Bindus) for her breasts, and the HƒÅrdhakalƒÅ for her organ of generation. This view provides a wombfrom which creation springs out. The creative agent, therefore,is a goddess thus constituted, and she is the highest deity and iscalled ParƒÅ, LalitƒÅ, Bha·π≠·π≠ƒÅrikƒÅ and Tripurasundarƒ´. ≈öiva issymbolically identified with the letter a and ≈öakti with h, thelast letter of the Sanskrit alphabet. This is called ArdhakalƒÅ,or half part, and hence the female element, or womb, mentionedabove is called the half part in the shape of the letter A. Thish, or the half part, together with a which stands for ≈öiva is asymbolic representation of KƒÅmakalƒÅ or Tripurasundarƒ´, who isthe result of the combination of ≈öiva and ≈öakti. She is thuscalled Aham, the ego, and is invested with egoism or individuality, and hence it is that all her developments (i. e. the wholecreation) have egoism or individuality; and all souls are butforms of Tripurasundarƒ´and become Tripurasundarƒ´when theystudy and practise the KƒÅmakalƒÅvidyƒÅwith its series of Devƒ´cakras, or mystic circles. A and h, being the first and lastletters of the alphabet, contain between them all letters andthrough them all words, i. e. the whole speech; and just as allthings are produced from Tripurasundarƒ´, so are all words whichexpress the things. She is thus called ParƒÅ, the first of the fourkinds of speech. Creation is Pari·πáƒÅma, or development, and not Vivarts, or the generation of false appearances. This is thephilosophy of the ≈öƒÅmbhavadar≈õana, and it will be seen that,though it admits a male element in the beginning, still it isthoroughly subdued by the female element which becomes predominant; and the highest deity is a goddess, viz. Tripurasundarƒ´.The ambition of every pious follower of the system is to becomeidentical with Tripurasundarƒ´, and one of his religious exercisesis to habituate himself to think that he is a woman. Thus the

followers of the ≈öakti school justify their appellation by thebelief that God is a woman and it ought to be the aim of all tobecome a woman.

Tripurasundarƒ´is propitiated and eventually attained byassuming the vow (Dƒ´ksƒÅ) of a devoted worship of her. Thisvow is of three kinds. The first consists in fully concentratingthe mind on the Devƒ´ as sitting on the lap of Siva in the MahƒÅpadmavana (a garden of lotuses), as possessed of a body whichis pure joy and is the original cause of all, and as identical withone’s own self. The second is the Cakrap≈´jƒÅ, the worship bymeans of the mystic circles, which is a BƒÅhyayƒÅga, or materialworship and the third consists in studying and knowing thetrue doctrine. The second is the proper ≈öakti ceremonial. Itconsists in the worship of a picture of the female organ drawnin the centre of another consisting of a representation of ninesuch organs, the whole of which forms the ≈örƒ´cakra The picturesare drawn on a Bh≈´rja leaf or a piece of silken cloth or on a gold.leaf107. With reference to this worship it must be observed thatthere are two classes of ≈öƒÅktas: (1) Kaulika and (2) Samayin.The former worship the gross material object, while the latterhave a recourse to imagery. The worship of the pictures justmentioned is resorted to by ancient (P≈´rva) Kaulas, while themodern (Uttara) Kaulas worship the organ of a living beautifulwoman. The Kaulas worship their goddess by offering to her,and themselves using, wine, flesh, honey (Madhu ), fish and suchother things. Tke Samayins, of course, abstain from suchpractices. There are even BrƒÅhma·πáas, who secretly profess thedoctrines of the Sakta school and worship the goddess Tripurasundarƒ´in accordance with the P≈´rva-Kaula or Uttara-Kaula.way. There are no distinctions of caste when the worship of theBhairavƒ´cakra is going on. Men of all castes become BrƒÅhma·πáas,but they resume their own castes when the worship is over108.There are several more innocent and decorous modes of worshipping the goddess under the names of Lalits and UpƒÅ·πÖgalalitƒÅmentioned in the ordinary religious books. The worshipof the latter comes off on the fifth lunar day of ƒÄ≈õvina and of

the former for the first ten days. The latter, when so worshippedby women, wards off widowhood109.

XIV. The Sect of GƒÅ·πáapatyas.

¬ß 111. Rudra had his hosts of Maruts, who were called hisGa·πáas, and the leader of these Ga·πáas was Ga·πáspati. The nameRudra, as we have seen, was generalised and signified a numberof spirits partaking of the character of the original Rudra; and sowas the name Ga·πáspati generalised and meant many leaders ofthe Ga·πáas or groups. Another name, VinƒÅyaka, denoting a spiritalso came into use. In the AU. Rudra is identified with manygods or spirits, and among these there is one called VinƒÅyaka.In the MBh. (Anu≈õƒÅsanaparvan 151, v. 26) Ga·πáe≈õvaras andVinƒÅyakas are mentioned amongst the gods, who observe theactions of men and are present everywhere; and again, (v. 57)VinƒÅyakas are said to remove all evil from men when praised.Ga·πáe≈õvaras, or Ga·πáspatis, and VinƒÅyakas are here represented,as the former are in the ≈öatarudriya, many in number andpresent everywhere.

In the MƒÅnavag·πõhyas≈´tra (2. 14) is given an account ofVinƒÅyakas. They are four in number. And their names are(1) ≈öalaka·π≠a·πÖka·π≠a, (2) K≈´·π£mƒÅ·πá·∏çarƒÅjaputra, (3) Usmita, and (4)Devayajana. When possessed by these a person pounds sods of earth, cuts grass, and writes on his body, and sees in dreams.waters, men with shaved heads, camels, pigs, asses, etc., and feelshe is moving in the air, and when walking, sees somebody pursuing him from behind. Again, when possessed by these, PrincesRoyal do not obtain the kingdom, though qualified to govern.Girls do not obtain bridegrooms, though possessed of thenecessary qualities. Women do not get children, even if otherwise qualified. The children of other women die. A learnedteacher qualified to teach does not obtain pupils, and there aremany interruptions and breaks in the course of student. Tradeand agriculture are unsuccessful.signs of being possessed by VinƒÅyaka, is made to go through theA person, who shows suchceremony of bathing in waters brought from four places andwith a little earth from four different quarters thrown into them.

After bathing oblations of mustard oil extracted afresh should beoffered to the four VinƒÅyakas in a ladle made of the wood of theUdumbara tree and poured over the head of the individual.Then food of many sorts, rice, husked and unhusked, flesh, andfish, cooked as well as raw, pulse of various kinds, etc. should beput into a basket and the basket placed on the ground where fourroads meet, the ground first being covered with Ku≈õagrass.Then certain deities including evil spirits are invoked, and awish expressed that they may be satisfied, and, becoming so,satisfy the worshipper, etc. This is the ceremony which freesthe persons haunted by the VinƒÅyakas.

Yaj√±avalkya in his Sm·πõti (I. 271ff.) gives the same ceremonyBut the ceremony appearsand frequently in the same words.He beginsin a somewhat more developed or complicated formby stating that Rudra and Brahmadeva appointed VinƒÅyaka tothe leadership of the Ga·πáas, (i. e. made him Ga·πáapati), andassigned to him the functions of raising difficulties and obstructions in the actions of men. In the Sm·πõti, one VinƒÅyaka is onlyaddressed, but instead of the four names occurring in the S≈´tra,six are given, viz. (1) Mita, (2) Sammita, (3) ≈öƒÅla, (4) Ka·π≠a·πÖka·π≠a,(5) K≈´·π£mƒÅ·πá·∏çsa, and (6) RajƒÅputra, and these are said to be sixdifferent names of the one VinƒÅyaka. After the basket withvarious kinds of food has been prepared, directions are given tomake an obeisance to AmbikƒÅ, the mother of VinƒÅyaka.

The form of the ceremony contained in the S≈´tra is unquestionably more ancient than that contained in the other work.But the difference between the two shows that during the periodthat had elapsed between the composition of the S≈´tra and that ofthe Sm·πõti, the four VinƒÅyakas had become one Ga·πáapati-VinƒÅyaka,having AmbikƒÅfor his mother. It will thus be seen that, in hisown nature, this last god is an unfriendly or malignant spirit,but capable of being made friendly and benignant by propitiatoryrites. In this respect, he resembles Rudra himself. That theVinƒÅyakas had come to be objects of faith before the Christianera, may be taken to follow from the occurrence of the ceremonymentioned above in a G·πõhyas≈´tra. But the one Ga·πáapati-VinƒÅyaka, the son of AmbikƒÅ, was introduced into the Hindu pantheonmuch later.

None of the Gupta Inscriptions which I subjected to anexamination on a former occasion¬π contains any mention of hisname or announces any gift or benefaction in his honour. Butin two of the caves at Ellora, there are groups of images of KƒÅla, KƒÅlƒ´, the Seven Mothers or ≈öaktis, and Ga·πáapati¬≤. These cavesare to be referred to the latter part of the eighth century. So thatbetween the end of the fifth and the end of the eighth centurythe Ga·πáapati cult must have come into practice, and the Sm·πõtiof Yaj√±avalkya. must have been written not earlier than thesixth century. Another Inscription, and an old relic, whichindicate the prevalence of the worship of Ga·πáapati, are found ata place called Gha·π≠iyƒÅlƒÅ, 22 miles north-west of Jodhpur. Thereis a column there, on the top of which there are four images ofGa·πáapati facing the four quarters. In the opening sentence ofthe Inscription engraved on it, an obeisance is made to VinƒÅyaka.The date of the inscription is Vikrama-Sa·πÅvat 918 = A. D. 862110.

When and how the god came to have the elephant’s head, it isdifficult to determine. The images in the cave-temples at Ellorahave that head, and Bhavabh≈´ti also in the beginning of theeighth century describes him, in the opening stanza of theMƒÅlatƒ´mƒÅdhava, as possessed of such a head. Rudra-≈öiva andthe gods allied with him were connected closely with forests andwild places, in which elephants also were found. The hide wornby Rudra and by his consort also in one of her forms was thehide of an elephant, and it perhaps suited the fancy of some mento place the head of that animal over the body of a god originallymischievous. Ga·πáapati’s reputation for wisdom is, I believe, tobe attributed to the confusion between him and B·πõhaspati, whoin ·πöV. II. 23. 1 is called Ga·πáapati. B·πõhaspati, of course, is theVedic god of wisdom, and is called the sage of sages.

¬ß 112. Six varieties of the GƒÅ·πáapatya sect are mentioned byƒÄnandagiri, or AnantƒÅnandagiri as he is sometimes called, in his≈öa·πÅkardigvijaya as well as by Dhanapati in his commentary onthe corresponding work of MƒÅdhava. The first consists of thosewho adore MahƒÅga·πáapati. MahƒÅga·πáapati is, according to them,the creator, and he alone remains when Brahmadeva and othershave been destroyed at the time of the dissolution. He should bemeditated upon as possessed of his peculiar face with one toothand as embraced by the ≈öakti. By his own wonderful power, hecreates Brahmadeva and others. One, who repeats the original.Mantra and meditates on this Ga·πáapati, attains supreme bliss.The name of the person who expounds these doctrines to theƒÄcƒÅrya is given as GirijƒÅsuta.

___________________________________________________________________________

1.See my ‘Peep into the Early History of India’; JBBRAS, Vol. XX pp. 336ff.

2.In RƒÅva·πáa-ki-khai, in the circumambulatory passage and RƒÅme≈õvara temples. See Cave-Temples by Fergusson and Burgess.

Another interlocutor follows. His name is Ga·πáapatikumƒÅra,and he adores HaridrƒÅga·πáapati. He takes his stand on ·πöV. II.23. 1, and makes out this text to mean “We meditate on theewho art the leader of the group of Rudra, Vi·π£·πáu, Brahman, Indraand others, and art the instructor of sages Bh·πõgu, Guru, Se≈õa and others, the highest of all who know the sciences, the greatestlord of the Brahmans engaged in the creation of the world, i. e.adored by Brahman and others in the work of creation andothers”. He should be worshipped and meditated on as being dressed in a yellow silken garment, bearing a yellow sacredthread, having four arms, three eyes and his face suffused overby turmeric ointment, and holding a noose and an elephant-goodand a staff in his hand. He who worships the god in this form,obtains emancipation Ganapati is the cause of the whole world,and BrahmƒÅand others are his parts. The worshipper of thisGa·πáapati should bear, on buth of his arms, the marks of Ga·πáapati’s face and one tooth impressed upon them by a heated ironstamp.

Then came Herambasuta, who was the worshipper of Ucchi·π£·π≠aga·πáapati. The followers of this variety resort to the left-handedpath (VƒÅmamƒÅrga), which probably was set up in imitation ofthe Kaula worship of ≈öakti. The form of Ga·πáapati meditated.on is very obscene. There is no distinction of caste among thefollowers of this sect. No restriction is to be observed, such asmarriage imposes, and promiscuous intercourse is allowed andalso the use of wine. The follower should have a red mark onhis forehead. All the ordinary ceremonies, such as twilightadorations (Sa·πÅdhyƒÅvandana), are left to a man’s own will.

The followers of the other three Ga·πáapatis, Navanƒ´ta, Svar·πáa,and Sa·πÅtƒÅna, worship their god, they say, according to the Sruti.But since Ga·πáapati is adored in the beginning of every religiousact, he is the chief god and all the other gods are parts of himand should be worshipped as such. They regard the whole worldas Ga·πáapati and adore him as such.

Since the god Ga·πáapati-VinƒÅyaka was introduced about thesixth century, it is questionable whether these several sectsexisted at the time of Sa·πÅkarƒÅcƒÅrya. The imprinting of the faceand the tooth of the god on the arms was a custom common tothem with the MƒÅdhva Vai·π£·πáavas, though it is hardly indicativeof the period in which the sect arose. But the worship of Ga·πáapati without reference to any particular sect is practised bynearly all Hindus at the beginning of any religious ceremonyand on special occasions. His image made of clay is worshippedwith great pomp in the Maratha country on the fourth lunar dayof the month of BhƒÅdrapada (September), and at Chinchwad nearPoona there is a special establishment for the exclusive worshipof that god.

XV. Skanda or KƒÅrttikeya.

** **¬ß 113. Another god whose worship was extensively practisedin ancient times, but is now rare, is Skanda or KƒÅrttikeya. Thegeneral belief is that he was the son of ≈öiva and PƒÅrvatƒ´. Butin the RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa he is represented as the son of the god of fireand Ga·πÖgƒÅ(I. chap 37). The foetus was thrown by Ga·πÖgƒÅon the Himavat mountain, and it was nourished by the sixstars constituting the constellation of K·πõttikƒÅ (Pleiades), andwas thus called the son of the KritikƒÅs or KƒÅrttikeya. Inthe MBh. (Vanaparvan, chap. 229) also he is represented as theson of Fire, but the mother was Agni’s true wife SvƒÅhƒÅ, who hadassumed the forms of the wives of six ·πö·π£is, whom Agni loved.But here he is called the son of ≈öiva also, as Agni is a form ofthat god. There are other stories connecting him with ≈öiva andPƒÅrvatƒ´ as his parents. But whatever the legend may have beenthere is no question that he was connected with ≈öiva, and wasthe leader of one of his Ga·πáas. There is a Li·πÖgƒÅyat traditionreported in the section on that sect111that he was a founder of a

Gotra, and was a form of ≈öiva himself. His having the peacockfor his vehicle is also consistent with his connection with ≈öiva,as peacocks are found in forests of which Rudra and hisattendants were gods. His being the leader of the army of the gods was an idea probably suggested by his being the leader of aGa·πáa of Rudra. And in historical times he has been associatedwith ≈öiva. Under P. V. 3. 99, Pata√±jali mentions the images of≈öiva, Skanda and Vi≈õakha as being worshipped in his time. Onthe reverse of the coins of the Ku·π£ana prince Kani·π£ka, there arefigures with their names in Greek letters of Skando, Mahaseno,Komaro and Bizago112.The first is Skanda, and because he wasthe commander of the army of the gods, he was also called.The third isMahƒÅsena, which is the second name on the coin.KumƒÅra, which is also a name of Skanda, and the fourth is theSkr. Vi≈õƒÅkha. If the first three were the names of one deity only,there was no necessity for giving three names and three figures.These, therefore, must have been regarded as three different godsas Vi≈õƒÅkha undoubtedly was from his being mentioned separatelyfrom Skanda by Pata√±jali. In the story in the MBh. referred toabove Vi≈õƒÅkha is mentioned as having arisen from the right sideof Skanda when it was struck by Indra’s thunderbolt. This isindicative of the tendency to make the two as one person; andthey appear to have been so made in later times. Or, looking tothe fact that there are two names of Buddha on the coins, the above three may have been the names of one single deity.
