I. 25. 12, ‡§∏ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§π ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡§ø·πöV.I. 1. 2. This is lostin classical Sanskrit. The several conjugations or ways offorming the special tenses do exist, but the roots are not restrictedto any particular way, being conjugated sometimes according toone mode and sometimes according to another; as ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§ß‡•Ä ‡§π‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç. Thereare some instances in which some tenses other than the specialtenses also admit of the conjugational sign, as ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•É‡§£‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•á, perfect.Sometimes gu·πáa is substituted before the ‡§§of the second personplural imperative, though it is a weak termination, as in ‡§∂‡•É‡§£‡•ã‡§§.

The infinitive is formed by adding to roots the terminations ‡§∏‡•á,‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à, ‡§§‡§µ‡•àand ‡§§‡§µ‡•á ( PƒÅ·πáini III. 4.9), as ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á, ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∏‡•á, ‡§™‡§ø‡§¨‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à, ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡•á, ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•á.These are etymologically the forms of the dative singularof such nouns as ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç, ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç, ‡§™‡§ø‡§¨‡§ß‡§ø&c. A few other datives aresimilarly used, as ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•á, ‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à&c. (PƒÅ·πáini III, 4. 10, 11). Theaccusatives of some nouns are also used as infinitives whengoverned by ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç(PƒÅ·πáini III 4.12), as ‡§® ‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∂‡•á‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç·πöV. X. 44. 6; also in other places, ‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Æ‡•ç ·πöV. VII. 86. 3.The infinitive in classical Sanskrit ends in a, as, which isthe accusative form of such a noun as ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•Å, the dative of which,‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•á, is one of the forms of the Vedic infinitive. The potentialparticiples are often formed by adding ‡§§‡§µ‡•à, ‡§è, ‡§è‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø and ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ(PƒÅ·πáiniIIL 4.14), as ‡§®‡•à‡§∑‡§æ ‡§ó‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§æ ‡§â ·πöV. X. 14.2, ‡§® ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡•á ·πöV.VI. 56, 1, ‡§¶‡§ø‡§¶‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É, ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç. The first two, however, ought properlyto be considered as infinitives. The absolutive is sometimesformed by the addition ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø; as ‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø. There is such a form as

‡§á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç for ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ;and such others as ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä and ‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•Äfor ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ and ‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æoccur often. Those last, as also the usual or classical absolutives,are forms of the instrumental singular of the same nouns, thedative and accusative of which are used as infinitives; ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Øappears also to be an instrumental. There are a great manyother peculiarities which are noticed by PƒÅ·πáini, and which youwill find collected in the SiddhƒÅnta-Kaumudƒ´. One thing, however, should be borne in mind, that notwithstanding there isin these respects a very groat difference between the Vedic andthe classical Sanskrit, they are in the same phonetic stage, i. e.the vocal elements of words and letters remain the same. Thereare a few such instances, as ‡§∏‡§ß for ‡§∏‡§π, and ‡§ó‡•É‡§≠‡•çfor ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç, in whichthe mute has disappeared, leaving only the aspirate element, andto these may be added the terminations ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§øand ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç for ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç and‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç; but both the original and corrupt forms exist in the Vedas,and no general conclusion can be based on these few instances.You will hereafter see that the other dialects I shall speak ofdiffer greatly from the classical Sanskrit in these respects. Thefollowing specimen will give you an idea of Vedic Sanskrit :‚Äî

‡•ß. ‡§Ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø ‡••
‡•®. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡•á ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§É‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§π‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡•á ‡••
‡•´. ‡§ï‡§¶‡§æ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§µ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡•§ ‡§Æ‡•É‡§≤‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡§Æ‡•ç ‡••
‡•≠. ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§£ ‡§™‡§§‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§‡§µ‡•á‡§¶ ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§É ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É ‡••
‡•ß‡•¶. ‡§®‡§ø ‡§∑‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶ ‡§ß‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡§É ‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Å‡§É ‡••
‡•ß‡•ß. ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡§æ ‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Å‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡••
‡•ß‡•®. ‡§∏ ‡§®‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§£ ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§∑‡§ø ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•ç ‡••
‡•ß‡•Ø. ‡§á‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á‡§µ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§ß‡•Ä ‡§π‡§µ‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡•É‡§≤‡§Ø ‡•§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ö‡§ï‡•á ‡••

These eight verses contain 72 different padas or grammaticalforms, not counting the prepositions as separate padas. Of these19 have become altogether obsolete in classical Sanskrit, and 12have changed their significations. This, however, is a specimen ofone of the more intelligible hymns, but there are a great manywhich contain a much larger proportion of words that have goneout of use. It is these obsolete words that constitute the chiefdifficulty of understanding the Vedio hymns.

  1. The use of ‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•çafter ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç is unknown to the later dialect,that particle being found joined only to the pronoun ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç. Thepreposition ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞, though connected with ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§∏‡§ø, is separated from it

by three words. Though the root of this verb is given in theDhƒÅtupƒÅ·π≠ha or PƒÅ·πáini’s list of roots, it has gone out of use. Inmodern Sanskrit we should use ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Éinstead. ‡§µ‡•ç‡§∞‡§§ is notnow used in the sense in which it occurs here, though it isconnected with it. We should use ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡§® instead.‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ø means’day by day’;in classical Sankrit the word ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã means’heaven only. The verse may be translated:‚Äî “Thoughwho are like subjects break thy law, day after day, O divineVaru·πáa!” Varu·πáa is spoken of frequently as a rƒÅjan, or king,and men are his subjects, with reference to that attribute of his.

  1. ‡§µ‡§ßmeans ‘killing’, or ’execution’ in classical Sanskrit,but, since ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‘killing’ qualifies it here, it must mean some suchthing as a weapon or a blow.

‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å is obsolete. ‡§ú‡§ø‡§π‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§® is a participle of the Perfect of ‡§π‡•á‡§ô‡•ç or‡§π‡•Ä‡§ô‡•ç. The form is obsolete; and a verbal form of the root is notordinarily met with, though a word derived from it does ocour.‡§π‡•É‡§£‡§æ‡§® also is obsolete.

“Do not subject us to the killing blow of the spiteful, nor tothe wrath of the angry,” i. e. do not kill us out of spite or wrath.

  1. ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ signifies in later Sanskrit the order of the K·π£atriyas orthe warrior caste. Here it is used in the primitive sense of’valour’, ‘prowess’. ‡§®‡§∞ does not mean ‘man’ here, but is usedIn its original sense of manly, ‡§Ü and ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á are separated by aword ‡§Æ‡•É‡§≤‡•Ä‡§ï ‘favour’ is obsolete. ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç’the reach of sight’, ‘visual power’, has also gone out of use.

“When shall we call the brave, manly, and far-seeing Varu·πáahither to favour us ?”

  1. ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§É This form of the derived adjective is unknown tolater Sanskrit. The genitive singular is formed by changing ‡§à to ‡§á‡§Ø‡•ç.

“Who knows the path of the birds flying in the sir and ofthe boat on the waters.”

  1. “Enforcing his laws, the powerful Varu·πáa sits down inhis abode to exercise universal sovereignty.”

  2. ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡§æ, the termination of the accusative plural, is here dropped; ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µis Vedic for ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø; here also ‡§®‡§øis dropped.

“From this place the knowing one sees all secret deeds donor to be done.”

  1. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•çand ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§§‡•çare forms of ‡§≤‡•á‡§ü‡•çor the Vedicsubjunctive.

“May the powerful God make things easy for us all our daysand prolong our lives.”

  1. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§ß‡•Ä. Conjugated as a root of the second class, with ‡§ß‡§øasthe termination of the imperative singular, lengthened for phoneticpurposes.

“O Varu·πáa, hear this my invocation, and now be propitious.I call on thee, desirous of protection.”

The next form of the language is presented to us in theBrƒÅhma·πáas of the Vedas, such as the Aitareya of the ·πögvedaand the ≈öatapatha of the White Yajurveda. A great many ofthose peculiar words which we meet with in the hymns, andwhich are so unintelligible have disappeared, the declensionshave approached the standard of classical Sanskrit, the nominative plural in ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç, for instance, and the instrumental plural in ‡§è‡§≠‡§ø‡§Éhaving gone out of use. The roots have arranged themselves definitely under certain conjugations. The subjunctivehas mostly become obsolete, though such forms as ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•à(≈öat. I.4.1. 10), and ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§§‡•ç (Ait. II. 11) are sometimes met with. Theroots take those forms of the Aorist that PƒÅ·πáini assigns to them,and this tense is scrupulously used in the sense mentioned bythat grammarian. Such terminations as ‡§Æ‡§∏‡§øand the variousmodes of forming the infinitive have disappeared, the ordinaryone in ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç being mostly used (Ait. IV. 8, VIII. 23). Thelanguage is in most respects the same as that usually calledclassical Sanskrit. It is rich in verbal forms of all tenses andmoods. There are however a few peculiarities and archaisms. There are some antiquated words such as ‡§¨‡§∞‡•ç‡§∏ ‘an extremity’(Ait. II. 2), ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Ä‡§ï ‘a shaft,’ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§¨‡§≤ ‘a bat’ (Ait. III.26); ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§µ‘ultimate referee’ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§µ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡•É ‘one who pronounces a decree,’ ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§∏‡•çprosperous’, ‡§§‡§§ for ‡§§‡§æ‡§§(Ait. V. 14), ‡§á‡§∞‡§æ ‘food’ (Ait. VIII. 7).‡§∂‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§£ ‘powerful’ (Ait. VIII. 8. 23), ‡§Æ‡•á‡§®‡§ø‘a destructive instrument,flame’ (Ait. VIII. 24 ), &c. The dative of feminine nouns is oftenused for the genitive, as ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É(Ait. VIII. 23); ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§É‚Ä¶ ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à; the ‡§§of the third person singular of the

ƒÄtmanepada is sometimes dropped as in the old dialect, as ‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§µ‡•à ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∂‡§ø‡•á(Ait. VII. 16); a few roots form their Aorist inanother manner than that mentioned by PƒÅ·πáini, as ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§§ ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¶‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É( Ait. VII. 14), where ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§§ stands for ‡§Ö‡§ú‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡§§ ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ã ‡§µ‡•à ‡§Æ ‡§Ü‡§§ ‡§á‡§¶‡§Ç (Ait. VIII. 23 ) where ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Éis for ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡§É; the form of the infinitive governed by the word ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞is that which ends in ‡§§‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•ças ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã ‡§π ‡§§‡•Å ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§§‡•ã‡§É(Ait. VIII. 7); and ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•çappears in the formof ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•ç (Ait. III. 26). In the seventh and eighth Pa√±cikƒÅs of the ƒÄitareya BrƒÅhma·πáa some GƒÅthƒÅs or songs are quoted, thelanguage of which is more antiquated than that of the body ofthe work. Notwithstanding these irregularities, these BrƒÅhma·πáasare the best representatives extant of the verbal portion of thatlanguage of which PƒÅ·πáini writes the grammar, though he did notmean these when he spoke of the BhƒÅ·π£ƒÅ. But nearly the whole.of that literature which PƒÅ·πáini drew from, if he did so at all, hasperished, or to speak more correctly, there is no portion of theextant Sanskrit literature that accurately represents PƒÅ·πáini’sSanskrit as regards the verb and the Taddhitas or nominal derivatives. Probably the spoken language of his time formed thebasis of his grammar.

The next stage of Sanskrit is presented to us by the work ofYƒÅska, whose language appears to be more ancient than that ofthe rest of the non-Vedic literature. We find a good manyarchaic words and expressions in the Nirukta, such as ‡§â‡§™‡§ú‡§®‘proximity’, ‡§â‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø in the sense of ‘finding’ or ‘observing’‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç ‘signification’, ‡§Ø‡§•‡•ãin the sense of ‘as to’,‡§¨‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§Æ ‘variety’,‡§â‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É ‘unable to teach’. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§® ‘invested withsovereignty’, ‡§®‡•à‡§ò‡§£‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å‡§ï ‘subordinate’, ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‘celibacy’, &c. Thereare also some technical terms which we do not meet with inlater works such as ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‘weak terminations’, ‡§â‡§™‡§ú‡§® or‡§â‡§™‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß ‘augment’,‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‘a nominal termination’, &c. Afterthe time of YƒÅska, Sanskrit underwent a peculiar change, for theproper understanding of which it is necessary for a timo to consider the styles in which a man may speak or write. There iswhat may be considered as the fluent or flowing style of speech,in which the speaker looks at the actions of men in progress,actions in the course of being done or suffered. A man speakingor writing in this style will use a verb on every occasion. But a

verb may always be analysed into an attribute of the subject andthe connecting link or copula. When one’s attention is directedmore to the attribute than to the progress or course of an action,one will use verbal nouns or adjectives. Thus instead of ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•çaman may say ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢‡§É,instead of ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ω‡§µ‡•ã‡§ö‡§§‡•ç, ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§®, instead of‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç;instead of ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•ç, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç&c. In the same way a verb may be divided into a noun oradjective denoting the special action it involves, and a verbsignifying action generally, as ‡§™‡§ö‡§§‡§ø, may be analysed Into‡§™‡§æ‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø or ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø and ‡§™‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á into ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø, The later Sanskrit andthe modern Vernaculars are full of such formations. The caseforms may also be similarly analysed into attributive expressions;as ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É into ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É or ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§£ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§É ‡§ï‡§ü: into ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§ï‡§É ‡§ï‡§ü‡§ÉThe mode of thought which gives birth to such forms of expression leads also to a freer use of compound nouns by means of whicha whole sentence may be compressed into a small attribute. Inargumentation the ablative of an abstract noun saves a longperiphrasis. This may be considered a petrified form of speech,and as distinguished from the verbal style it may be called thenominal style. In the earliest literature of Sanskrit the fluentor verbal style prevailed. Since this rarely admits of attributiveor nominal expressions, the sentences are short, and the construction easy. Thus, in such books as the Aitareya and ≈öatapatha BrƒÅhma·πáas, we find short sentences, and an abundance ofverbal forms. Even in the time of YƒÅska this style prevailed toa large extent, and notwithstanding that his book is on a scientific subject, his language often reminds one of that of the earlierworks, though he must have written serval centuries afterwards.In the time of PƒÅ·πáini also verbal forms were in general use, as I shall presently attempt to show. Some time after, however,the petrified or nominal style began to supplant the other. Somehow it commended itself to the genius of the Indian ƒÄryas of thetimes, and the very richness and flexibility of Sanskrit, which allows of a root or noun being twisted in a variety of ways tosuit any sort of construction, greatly facilitated the change. TheItihƒÅsas, the PurƒÅ·πáas, and the metrical Sm·πõtis are written in thisstyle. But here it is not carried to such an extravagant extentas is done in later writings, in some of which verbal forms are

rare and in others long and bewildering compounds are frequently met with,andthe construction is complicated and involved.This is the general character of the Sanskrit in which the subsequent poetic and dramatic literature is written and if thelanguage of a certain author is graceful and easy, and not dulland involved, if he does not use long compounds, and writes in amore natural style, it is either because his taste is superior to thatof his contemporaries, or because he belongs to an earlier period.

But it was in the field of philosophy. dialectics and exegesis,scriptural or grammatical, that this nominal style was greatlycultivated and developed. The earliest work of the kind weknow of is Pata√±jali’s MahƒÅbhƒÅ·π£ya on KƒÅtyƒÅyana’s VƒÅrtikas ornotes on PƒÅ·πáini’s S≈´tras. Nearly the whole of the philosophicalliterature of the Sanskrit is written more or less in the style ofdisputation. An Indian author does not lead his readers into theprocesses his own mind has gone through in arriving at thedoctrines he lays down; in other words, he does not tell us how hehas come by the opinions he holds, but lays down these doctrinesand sets forth those opinions and conceives objections that maybe raised and answers them. Or before actually stating the truedoctrine or siddhƒÅnta, certain others, more or less opposed arestated, and reasons given in support of them (p≈´rvapak·π£a) whichare, of course, refuted. The MahƒÅbhƒÅ·π£ya is written in this manner,but it differs in a good many respects from later works of thekind. Unlike the latter, it gives the very words that an opponent,speaking in his own person, may be expected to use. It therefore really consists of a series of dialogues, often smart, betweenone who maintains the p≈´rvapak·π£a, and another who laysdown the siddhƒÅnta. Hence, the language is plain andsimple, and the sentences are short, and such as anaturally use in ordinary conversation or oral disputation. Thenominal style, however, as I have ventured to call it, in contradistinction to that of the BrƒÅhma·πáas and also of YƒÅska, isobservable; but it has of course not yet degenerated into thelong compounds and algebraic expressions of modern times, andis perfectly natural. In this respect it keeps pace with thelanguage of the Itih√§sss and Sm·πõtis. VƒÅtsyƒÅyana’s BhƒÅ·π£ya on Gotama’s NyƒÅya S≈´tra, and ≈öabarasvƒÅmin’s on that of Jaimini,

as well as the BhƒÅ·π£yas on some of the sacrificial S≈´tras, arewritten in the same sort of simple and lively style, though however they present a further stage in the downward progress. Butgradually this manner of writing ceased to be used, and thephilosophical style went on progressing until it has come to bewhat it is now. ≈öa·πÅkarƒÅcƒÅrya’s BhƒÅ·π£ya presents it in a middlestage. The sentences are much longer than those of the earlierwriters, the construction is more involved, there is a freer useof attributive adjuncts, and the form is that of an essay or alecture, instead of an oral disputation. But the great ƒÄcƒÅrya’sstyle is perspicuous throughout, fluent and charming, and notsolidified or petrified, as that of later writers is. These latterhardly ever use a verb, and of the cases only a few are to be met with in their works. The nominative and ablative singularprevail, and long compounds are constantly employed. All ourideas are thrown into the form of nouns, mostly abstract, andeven the participles have become rare. This style is the styleof formulas rather than of discourse. It has reached its climaxin the works of recent NaiyƒÅyikas, but it has been more or less usedby modern writers in all the ≈öƒÅstras. The movement which beganwith a less frequent use of verbal forms and the employmentof attributive expressions has thus ended in making Sanskrita language of abstract nouns and compound words.

I have used the word style in describing this movement, toshow what important changes in the structure of a languagemay originate from what is in the beginning but a style ormode of speaking or writing. If everybody thought and spokeabout all matters as the NaiyƒÅyika does in his own subject, ourlanguage would be just like his. It would almost have no verbs,no participles, and no cases except one or two. But it is not so.The movement could not be carried so far in other subjects.Hence the real classical Sanskrit is the Sanskrit of the Epics,the PurƒÅ·πáas, the metrical law-books, the better or earlier specimens of KƒÅvyas or poems and dramatic plays, and of the earlyphilosophical or exegetical worksAnd if we examine thisliterature we shall find that the greater use of attributive ornominal forms of expression gradually drove out a large portionof the Sanskrit verb, and gave a new character to the language,

which may be thus described:‚Äî Very few verbal forms are usedbesides those of such tenses as the Present and Future; participles are frequently met with the verbal forms of some roots,especially of those belonging to the less comprehensive classeshave gone out of use, and in their place we often have a nounexpressive of the special action and a verb expressive of actiongenerally compound words are somewhat freely employed; anda good many of the Taddhita forms or nominal derivatives havedisappeared, and in their stead we have periphrastic expressions.If the treatises of PƒÅ·πáini and others had perished, and we had toconstruct a grammar of the Sanskrit from the classical literatureI have above indicated, our Verb and the Taddhita portionwould be very mengre. Professor Benfey attributes the conditionwhich the language thus assumed to the influence of the Prakritaor the spoken vernaculars. But the process appears to me perfectly natural, and no such influence need be supposed. Thechange may in some respects be likened to that which renderedthe Vedic subjunctive and other grammatical forms obsolete inthe later stage of the language. The Prakrits may have givensome words to the Sanskrit, but that they should in this mannerhave influenced its grammatical structure is very unlikely. Itis more natural to suppose that it was the Sanskrit, from whichthe Prakrits evidently sprang, which gave to these latter theirpeculiar character. I shall endeavour to determine the exactrelation between the Sanskrit and these dialects in the concluding lecture.

We have thus observed and determined the change that cameover Sanskrit after the period that elapsed between the BrƒÅhma·πáasand YƒÅska from an examination of the literature itself. But thefact is borne witness to by K√§ty√§yana, who observed it in histime and made it the subject of a few vƒÅrtikas. Pata√±jali discussesthe points raised in the following manner.An objector orP≈´rvapak·π£in is introduced, who says:

P≈™RV. ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡•§There exist (some) words which are notused; for instance, ‡§ä‡§∑, ‡§§‡•á‡§∞, ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§™‡•á‡§ö.(These are forms of thesecond person plural of the Perfect.)

The SiddhƒÅntin, or the principal teacher, who advocates thedoctrine that is finally laid down asks:‚Äî

SID. What if they are not used?

P≈™RV. You determine the grammatical correctness of wordsfrom their being used. Those then that are not now used are notgrammatically correct.

SID. What you say is, in the first place, inconsistent, viz.,that words exist which are not used. If they exist they cannotbe not used; if not used, they cannot exist. To say that theyexist and are not used is inconsiste You yourself use them(utter them) and say (in the very breath) there are words whichare not used. What other worthy like yourself would you haveto use them in order that they might be considered correct (lit.What other person like yourself is correct or is an authority in the use of words)?

P≈™RV. ‚Äî This is not inconsistent. I say they exist since thosewho know the ≈öƒÅstra teach their formation by [laying down]rules, and I say they are not used, because they are not usedby people. Now with regard to [your remark], “What otherworthy, &o.” [ when I say they are not used ] I do not mean thatthey are not used by me.

SID.‚Äî What then?

P≈™RV.‚Äî Not used by people.

SID.‚Äî Verily, you also are one amongst the people.

P≈™RV.‚Äî Yes, I am one, but am not the people.

SID.‚Äî ( VƒÅrt, ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ ‡§á‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§§‡•ç ) If youobjectthat they are not used, it will not do (the objection is not valid).

P≈™RV.‚Äî Why not ?

SID.‚Äî Because words are used to designate things. The thingsdo exist which these words are used to designate.the words must be used by somebody. If the things exist, theThewords that denote them must exist).

P≈™RV.‚Äî (VƒÅrt. ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç). (It does not follow.) Theirnon-use is what one can reasonably infer.

SID.‚Äî Why?

P≈™RV.‚Äî Because they (people) use other words to designatethe things expressed by these words; for instance, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∑‡§ø‡§§‡§æ; in

the sense of ‡§ä‡§∑;‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§Éin the sense of ‡§§‡•á‡§∞; ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É in thein the sense of ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§É, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É in the sence of ‡§™‡•á‡§ö.(We here see thatparticiples had come to be used for verbs of the Perfect Tense.)

SID.‚Äî(VƒÅrt. ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§§‡•ç) Even if these words are notused, they should be essentially taught by rules just as longsacrificial sessions are. It is in this way. Long sacrificialsessions are such as last for a hundred years and for a thousandyears. In modern times none whatever holds them, but thewriters on sacrifices teach them by rules, simply because I tolearn what has been handed down by tradition from ·πö·π£is isreligiously meritorious. And moreover (VƒÅrt. ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á) allthese words are used in other places.

P≈™RV.‚Äî They are not found used.

SID.‚Äî An endeavour should be made to find them. Wideindeed is the range over which words are used; the earth withits seven continents, the three worlds, the four Vedas with theira·πÖgas or dependent treatises and the mystic portions, in theirvarious recensions, the one hundred branches of the Adhvaryu(Yajur-Veda), the SƒÅma-Veda with its thousand modes, theBƒÅhv·πõcya with its twenty-one varieties, and the ƒÄtharva·πáa.Voda with nine, VƒÅkovƒÅkya, the Epics, the PurƒÅ·πáas and Medicine.This is the extent over which words are used. Without searchingthis extent of the use of words, to say that words are notused is simple rashness. In this wide extent of the use ofwords, certain words appear restricted to certain senses incertain places. Thus, rafa is used in the sense of motionamong the Kambojas; the ƒÄryas use it in the derived formof ‡§∂‡§µ;‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø is used among the SurƒÅ·π£·π≠ras, ‡§∞‡§Ç‡§π‡§§‡§ø among theeastern and central people, but the ƒÄryas use only ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç; ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§øisused in the sense of ‘cutting’ among the easterns, ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ among thenortherners. And those words which you think are not used arealso seen used.

P≈™RV.‚Äî Where?

SID.‚ÄîIn the Vadn. Thus, ‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§∑ ‡•§‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∑ ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á ‡§®‡§∞‡§É ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞ ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡§®‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§

We here see that the objector says that certain words orforms are not used by people, and therefore they should not be

taught or learnt. The instances that he gives are forms of theperfect of some roots, and he observes that the sense of theseforms is expressed by using other words which are perfect participles of these roots. These statements are not denied by the SiddhƒÅntin, but he does not allow that the forms should not betaught on the account. Though not used, they should be taughtand learnt for the sake of the religious merit consequent thereon,just as the ceremonial of long sacrificial sessions, which are neverheld, is. Then the objector is told that though not used by people, the words may be ourrent in some other country, continent, or world, or they must have been used somewhere in thevast literature of the language. As regards the particular instances, two of them are shown to be used in the Vedas.

It thus follows that in the time of KƒÅtyƒÅyana and Pata√±jali,such verbal forins had become obsolete, and participles were usedin their place. But it must have been far otherwise in the timeof PƒÅ·πáini. He gives minute rules for constructing the innumerable forms of the Sanskrit verb. Our grammarians proceededupon a strictly scientific basis. Nothing is more clear fromseveral observations scattered throughout the work of Pata√±jali,besides those contained in the above passage, than this, that theIndian Grammarians do not give us the inventions of their ownbrains as they are supposed by some scholars to do. The veryperfection of their observation and analysis has rendered themliable to this reproach. But notwithstanding all that, there canbe no doubt whatever that they scrupulously adhered to usage.If so, the verbal forms taught by PƒÅ·πáini must have been currentin the language at some time. We do meet with them in theBrƒÅhma·πáas, but our grammarian does not include these formsamong the peculiarities he has given of the Vedic or Chandas andBrƒÅhma·πáa dialect, and thus does not restrict them to those works.They must therefore be understood as having been in use in theBhƒÅ·π£ƒÅ or current language, the grammar of which he teaches inhis S≈´tras. And the BhƒÅ·π£ƒÅthat he means must be that whichwas current in his time. In PƒÅ·πáini’s time, therefore, the fluentor verbal style of speech was in use, as I have observed before.But it may be argued that though he refers these forms to theBhƒÅ·π£ƒÅ, the BhƒÅ·π£ƒÅhe means may not be that which prevailed

when he lived, but another current before his time and preservedin its literature, on which PƒÅ·πáini based his rules. It mattersvery little even if we make this supposition. The only effect isthat the period when the non-Vedic Sanskrit was rich in verbalforms is placed before PƒÅ·πáini; but the fact itself that there wassuch a period is undeniable. The supposition, however, is unreasonable. For it is not at all likely that he should neglect thelanguage prevalent in his time and teach that which was currentbefore him, and speak of it as the BhƒÅ·π£ƒÅ, which word literallysignifies the “spoken language” or vernacular. And the occurrence in the S≈´tras of words that became obsolete in laterSanskrit confirms this view. The following are such words:‚Äî‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó ‘allowing one his own way’, ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§ ’excommunicated,’‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§® ’eating,’ ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø ‘including,’ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‘marrying’, ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®’throwing up’, ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∑ ’equitableness.’ You will have seen thatthe VƒÅrtika of KƒÅtyƒÅyana which starts the discussion I have translated, and Pata√±jali’s comment on it speak of wordsgenerally as having ceased to be used, though the examples givenconsist of certain verbal forms only. It is, therefore, to be understood that the observation is applicable to other forms andexpressions also taught by PƒÅ·πáini which we do not meet with inthe later literature¬π.Among such may be noticed ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ú‡•á‡§ï‡•Éand‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡•á‡§ï‡•É’to strengthen’, ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï‡•É’to be silent’, ‡§ï‡§£‡•á‡§π‡§®‡•ç and ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§π‡§®‡•ç’to fulfil one’s longing,’ &c. ‡§ï‡§£‡•á‡§π‡§®‡•ç occurs in YƒÅskaalso. Mostof the verbal derivatives ending in the technical termination‡§£‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç must also be so considered, such as ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‘feedsevery Br√§hma·πáa that he finds, ‡§ö‡•á‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§®‡•ã‡§™‡§Ç ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü,‘rained till the clotheswere wet,’ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ã‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‘supports by his own means,’ ‡§â‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡•ã‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‘withers standing’, &c. A good many Taddhita forms taught inPƒÅ·πáini’s S√ºtras must also, I think, be put in the same category.

And there is another circumstance which shows that PƒÅ·πáini’sSanskrit was more ancient than KƒÅtyƒÅyana’s. KƒÅtyƒÅyana’sV√§rlikas on PƒÅ·πáini, which I have already spoken to you of, touchon various points concerning grammar and the system of PƒÅ·πáini.

___________________________________________________________________________

1. Professor Goldstucker has used the argument based on the occurrence ofobsolete words in the S≈´tras and that set forth in the next paragraph, toprove the archaic character of the language as is existed in PƒÅ·πáini’s timeand some of the instances quoted in the text are the same as his.

The purpose of a great many of them is the proper interpretationof the S≈´tras, and there are some which supply links that arewanting in the system, also a good many which teach forms nottaught by PƒÅ·πáini, or give the correct forms, when by the strictapplication of PƒÅ·πáini’s rules we arrive at such as are incorrect.Now, this strict application of PƒÅ·πáini’s rules is often in themanner of a quibbling logician, and consequently it was probablynever meant by PƒÅ·πáini himself. Again, it may also be allowedthat some forms existing in the language may have escapedPƒÅ·πáini’s notice. But even after making allowance for all theseconsiderations, a good many forms taught by KƒÅtyƒÅyana areleft which it is impossible to believe PƒÅ·πáini did not observe orknow, if they existed in the language in his time. Though notinfallible, PƒÅ·πáini was not an indifferent grammarian. He justlydeserves the reputation he has all along enjoyed of being the preeminent teacher of grammar. He has noticed oven stray factsabout the language. If so, the only reasonable supposition isthat these forms did not exist in the language at the period whenhe lived.

For instance, according to PƒÅ·πáini’s rules the vocative singularof neuter nouns ending in ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç such as ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç and ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç is ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•çandbut KtyƒÅyana in a VƒÅrtikƒÅon VIII. 2, 8 tells us it is‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç or ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ and ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç or ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ.

PƒÅ·πáini teaches that the forms of the dative, ablative, genitiveand locative singular of the feminine of ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø and ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø areoptionally like those of the corresponding pronouns, i. e. we haveeither ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•à or ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à, ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Éor ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É &c., but KƒÅtyƒÅyanain a VƒÅrtika on 1. 1. 36 extends this option to the masculine also,and according to him we have ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø OF ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à or ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•çor‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç&o., while PƒÅ·πáini gives us only the first.

PƒÅ·πáini’s rule IV. 1, 49 allows of ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä only as the feminineof ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤, but KƒÅtyƒÅyans gives ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•Ä also ; ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä is not noticedby PƒÅ·πáini while KƒÅtyƒÅyans lays down that as well as ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Äinthe sense of ‘wife of the ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø’, So also ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ und ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ areaccording to PƒÅ·πáini, ‘a female ƒÄrya’ and a female K·π£atriya,‘but KƒÅtyƒÅyans gives ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä and ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä as well as ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æand ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ.

A good many more instances of a similar nature may begiven from other parts of Sanskrit Grammar. Are we then tosuppose that the forms ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ, ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ, ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ&c. of the vocativesingular, ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à of the dative of ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø &o, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡•Ä, ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä,‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä and many more such, escaped the observation of such a grammarian as PƒÅ·πáini, or that he did notknow them? Is the supposition that they did not exist in thelanguage in his time not more reasonable? It therefore appearsclear to me that the language in PƒÅ·πáini’s time was in a differentcondition from that in which it was in KƒÅtyƒÅyana’s. The chiefdifferences, to point out which has been the object of this discussion, may be thus stated:‚Äî In PƒÅ·πáini’s time a good manywords and expressions were current which afterwards becameobsolete; verbal forms were commonly used which ceased to beused in KƒÅtyƒÅyana’s time, and some grammatical forms weredeveloped in the time of the latter, which did not exist inPƒÅ·πáini’s.

PƒÅ·πáini’s Sanskrit must, therefore, be identified with that whichpreceded the Epics, and he must be referred to the literary periodbetween the BrƒÅhma·πáas and YƒÅska. Hence it is that the BrƒÅhma·πáas, as observed before, are the best existing representativesof the language of which PƒÅ·πáini writes the grammar. KƒÅtyƒÅyana,on the other hand, wrote when the language arrived at that stagewhich we have called Classical.

Thus then, we have been able to trace three distinct periodsin the development of Sanskrit. First, we have the Vedio period,to which the ·πögveda Sa·πÅhitƒÅ, the Mantra portion of the Yajurveda, and the more antiquated part of the Atharva-Sa·πÅhitƒÅareto be referred. Then commences another period, at the thresholdof which we find the Br√§hma·πáas, which, so to say, look backwards to the preceding, that is, they present the Vedic languagein the last stage of its progress towards PƒÅ·πáini’s BhƒÅ·π£ƒÅ; andlater on, we have YƒÅska and PƒÅ·πáini. This may be called theperiod of Middle Sanskrit. And last of all, there is the Classicalperiod to which belong the Epics, the earliest specimens ofKƒÅvyas and dramatic plays, the metrical Sm·πõtis, and the grammatical work of KƒÅtyƒÅyana.

PƒÅ·πáini’s work contains the grammar of Middle Sanskrit, whileKƒÅtyƒÅyana’s that of Classical Sanskrit, though he gives hissanction to the archaic forms of the former on the principle, as hehimself has stated, on which the authors of the sacrificial S≈´trasteach the ritual of long sacrificial sessions, though they hadceased to be held in their time. Pata√±jali gives but few formswhich differ from KƒÅtyƒÅyana’s, and in no way do they indicatea different stage in the growth of the language; hence his workis to be referred to the same period. The form which the languageassumed at this time became the standard for later writers tofollow, and KƒÅtyƒÅyana and Pata√±jali are now generally acknowledged authorities on all points concerning the correctness ofSanskrit speech. We shall hereafter see that the last two stageshave left distinct traces on the Prakrits or the derived languages.

LECTURE

PALI AND THE DIALECTS OF THE PERIOD

In the last lecture we traced the development of the Sanskritlanguage until it assumed the form in which it is usually calledClassical Sanskrit. This form it acquired several centuriesbefore Christ, as I shall hereafter endeavour to show, but it hassince preserved it unaltered. The reason is that the number ofpeople using it has been growing smaller and smaller, and nowfor a considerable period, it has remained confined to a fewlearned men who devote long time to its study and use it onlyfor religious and philosophical purposes. But in so far as It hasbeen used for these purposesit has not been free from change, aswas pointed out on the last occasion. The style and modes ofexpression used by Gadadhara Bha·π≠·π≠ƒÅcƒÅrya, the great Naiy√£yikaof modern times, are not the same as those of Ka·πáa·∏ça, Gotams,and VƒÅtsyƒÅyana, nor those used by NƒÅgojibhatts, the same asthose of KƒÅtyƒÅyana and Pata√±jali. But all these changes haverfollowed one direction. The efforts of our modern writers havebeen mostly, if not altogether, directed to systematizing andreducing to an accurate and definite shape the conceptions ofthose ancient sages, and no new ideas or methods of thought have arisen. They have thus elaborated a highly artificial style,abounding in abstract terms. In other branches of the literaturealso, we may discover some peculiarities and corruptions ofdiction and manner. But still, making due allowance for allthis, the generally received standard of good and correct Sanskritis the same as it was many centuries ago. There are certainmodels which modern writers and speakers have to conform to.

When, however, a language is living, that is, is used bypeople generally and in matters of every-day life, it must undergo very great changes. Men will not waste time and trouble inaccurately ascertaining and imitating the pronunciation of theirfathers, or reproducing exactly the several grammatical formsused by their predecessors. All that is necessary is that theyshould make themselves understood. Old modes of thinking give

place to new ones, and ideas spring up; and both must be represented in the language that is used. Sometimes accidentasin the history of a race, such as its coming in contact or beingincorporated with another race, serve to transform its languagewithin a short time. But the alterations that occur from theseand other causes obey certain laws; and hence the possibility of aScience of Language.

Now, by the operation of influences such as these. Sanskritwas, in very remote times, corrupted, and new dialects arosefrom it. We should have known nothing of these if they had notbeen preserved in their literatures. Of these dialects that which approaches Sanskrit the most is the Pali. This is the sacredlanguage of the Buddhists of Ceylon, Siam, and Burma, andpossesses an extensive literature.

I will introduce my remarks on this dialect by placing beforeyou speoimen :‚Äî

‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§¶‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§™‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§π‡•ã‡§∏‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§ö‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§£‡§™‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨‡§Ç‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§¶‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§™‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨‡§ï‡•ã ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Å ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§ï‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§π‡•ã‡§∏‡§ø ‡§™‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Æ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡•ã ‡•§ ‚Ä¶ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•ã‡§≤‡§∏‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã ‡§â‡§¶‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Ç‡§ì‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£ ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§§‡•á ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã ‡§â‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•ã ‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§™‡•á‡§π‡§ø ‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§π‡•§ ‡§≠‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ö‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§®‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≠‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨‡§Ç‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§ß‡§®‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡§®‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§ì‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•á‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§• ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§∏‡§ø‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§®‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡•ã ‡§® ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§¨‡•á‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§§‡•Å‡§ù‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§≠‡•á‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§ß‡§æ‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§•‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§§‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ç‡§Ü‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§≠‡•á‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•á‡§¨‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã‡§¨‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§π‡•ã‡§∏‡§ø ‡•§

This is from the A·π≠·π≠hakathƒÅor commentary by Buddhagho·π£aon the Dhammapada. It was written in the fifth century afterChrist, long after Pali had ceased to be & vernaculsr. The following is from the Dhammspada itself, which we have reason tobeliove is much more ancient :‚Äî

129.‡§∏‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨‡•á ‡§§‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•Å‡§®‡•ã‡•§
‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§â‡§™‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§® ‡§π‡§®‡•á‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§® ‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§Ø‡•á‡••

131. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§®‡•ã ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•á‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§™‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§® ‡§≤‡§≠‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ç‡••

133. ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ã‡§ö ‡§´‡§∞‡•Å‡§∏‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¨‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡§ü‡§ø‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å ‡§§‡§Ç‡•§
‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡§ü‡§ø‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ ‡§´‡•Å‡§∏‡•á‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å ‡§§‡§Ç‡••

134. ‡§∏‡§ö‡•á‡§®‡•á‡§∞‡•á‡§∏‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ã ‡§â‡§™‡§π‡§§‡•ã‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§è‡§∏ ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§∏‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ã ‡§§‡•á ‡§® ‡§¨‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§§‡§ø‡••

The Sanskrit of these passages is as follows:‚Äî

‡§Ü‡§¨‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•à‡§ö‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§®‡§§‡§Æ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§µ‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§∏‡§§ ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§ï‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ã‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§É‡•§ ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∑‡•ã‡§°‡§∂‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó ‡§â‡§¶‡§™‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡•§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£ ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ø‡•à‡§®‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π ‡•§‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏ ‡§ö‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡•§ ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§ß‡§®‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡§®‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø ‡•§‡§Ö‡§•‡§ï‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ß‡§®‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§¶‡•ã‡§® ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡§∏‡•ç‡§™ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§≠‡•à‡§∑‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§•‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§§‡•ç ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ó‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∏ ‡§§‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§≠‡•à‡§∑‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡§è‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ã‡§ó‡•ã‡§¨‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç ‡•§

129. ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§É‡•§
‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§® ‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡§Ø‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡••

131. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§∏ ‡§® ‡§≤‡§≠‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

133. ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ã‡§ö‡§É ‡§™‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡§¶‡•á‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§æ ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡§•‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§É ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∂‡•á‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

134. ‡§∏ ‡§ö‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§∞‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§™‡§π‡§§‡§Ç ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡•§
‡§è‡§∑‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§∏‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡••

“In ≈örƒÅvastƒ´there was a Brahman of the name of Adattap≈´rvaka(literally ‘one who had not given swsy anything before’).He never gave anything to anybody, whence they called himAdattap≈´rvaka. A son was born to him, pleasing and delightful.When he was sixteen years old, he got jaundice. Seeing the sonthus, the mother said, “O Brahman, your son has got a disease, puthim under medical treatment.” “Lady, if I get a physician, foodand salary will have to be given to him. You do not see that thiswill entail expense (lit, lessen my money ). " What then will you do, Brahman?” “I will do what will not involve expense(lessen my money ). He then went to physiolans and asked,What medicine do you use against such and such a disease?They spoke to him at random of the bark of some tree. He broughtit and gave it as a medicine to his son,As he went on doing so,the disease was aggravated.

  1. “All are afraid of being hurt, all fear death. Takingone’s own self as a model, one should not kill and cause to bekilled.”

  2. He, who looking to his own happiness, inflicts injuryupon creatures that equally desire their happiness, does not obtainfelicity after death.”

  3. “Do not speak harshly to anybody; they may speak toyou in return. For angry altercation is painful, and revenge willovertake you.”

  4. “If then, like a bottom of a shattered metallic vessel,you will not stir yourself (utter), then you have reached NirvƒÅ·πáa,and you will have no angry altercation.”

(A)

PHONOLOGY OF THE PALI DIALECT

Here you will see a great many instances of the laws we laiddown in the last lecture. And first, as regards phonetic corruption, we have in these passages ‡§§‡•ç‡§§ for ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ as in ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§for ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, for ‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ asin ‡§≠‡§§‡•ç‡§§for ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§, and for ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ as in ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§ for ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§ and ‡§™‡•ç‡§™ for ‡§§‡•ç‡§™ as in ‡§â‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®for ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®. This change is usually called assimilation of consonants.

In pronouncing a conjunct, one has to pass from one positionof the vocal organs to another without letting off the breathchecked or compressed in the first, an operation of great difficulty.The sound of the first member is indistinct, but when the secondis a weak consonant such as a nasal or a semi-vowel, it glidesinto the first almost as a vowel does, and thus the sound of thefirst acquires greater prominence. In the first position, the vocalorgans strike and press againt each other strongly, and themomentum necessary for this effort is acquired by uttering forcibly and with a jerk the vowel that precedes the conjunct, i. e. ‡§Öfor instance in the word ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§, just as aman previous to strikingand pressing anything with his fist moves the hand with forcethrough some distance. The previous forcible vowel breath andthe subsequent strong contact and pressure form the characteristicof a conjunct consonantal sound. This is the only way of rendering the two members at all distinct, for the first is thus utteredwith the preceding vowel and the second with the following,

Thus, ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§pronounced in the manner I have described becomes ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç-‡§§,but, if the previous vowel sound is weak, it becomes ‡§≠-‡§ï‡•ç‡§§,in which case, in consequence of the absence of momentum, thepressure cannot be strong, and the conjunct character is not fullybrought out.

What we find in the Pali, therefore, is that the passage fromone vocal position to another is avoided, and the more distinctsound only, whether of the first member or the second, is pronounced with this forcible previous vowel breath and the succeeding strong contact and pressure; that is, we have a conjunctas before, but it is made up not of two different letters, but oftwo of the same kind. Hence the instances noted above and also ‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ for ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ, ‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ for ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ, ‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞for ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û, ‡§∏‡§¶‡•Éfor ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶, ‡§¶‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß for ‡§¶‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß, ‡§ñ‡§ó‡•ç‡§ófor ‡§ñ‡§°‡•ç‡§ó, ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó for ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§Ö‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§§ for ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡•Å‡§§, ‡§≤‡§¶‡•ç‡§ßfor ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß, ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ for ‡§â‡§≤‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ, ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§™for ‡§Ö‡§≤‡•ç‡§™, ‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§® for ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£, ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø for ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø &c. But an attempt is made topronounce the other sound also, and such of its elements as cango in, with that which is uttered without involving changeof position, are transferred to it, that is, in effect, the Pali speakertreated a conjunct consonant as one sound possessing the characteristics of both. Thus the heavy ≈õvƒÅsa or simple breath of ‡§∏‡•ç, ‡§∂‡•ç,and ‡§∑‡•ç in the conjuncts ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç, ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç, ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•ç, ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•ç and ‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡•ç is combined withthe distinct sounds ‡§ï‡•ç, ‡§ö‡•ç, ‡§¶‡•ç, ‡§§‡•ç, and ‡§™‡•ç, and we have ‡§ñ‡•ç, ‡§õ‡•ç, ‡§¶‡•ç, ‡§∂‡•ç, and ‡§´‡•çfor those conjuncts; but, when preceded by a vowel and pronounced with the usual conjunctal characteristic, they become‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ,‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ, ‡§ü‡•ç‡§†, ‡§§‡•ç‡§•, and ‡§™‡•ç‡§´‡•ç; as in ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ç for ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç and ‡§´‡•Å‡§∏‡•á‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Åfor‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡•É‡§∂‡•á‡§Ø‡•Å‡§Éin the sbove, and in ‡§ñ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß for ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§ß, ‡§™‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§∞ for ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞, ‡§™‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ for‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç, ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø for ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ü‡•ç‡§†for ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü, ‡§™‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§†for ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü, ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§ï for ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï, ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡•Åfor ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§´‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®for ‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§®, and ‡§™‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§´ for ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™.

In ‡§®, ‡§∂‡•ç‡§®, ‡§∑‡•ç‡§£, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ, ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ, and ‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ, the consonantal portion of thedistinct sounds, being made up of nƒÅdaor intonated breath, theheavy ≈õvƒÅsaor simple breath of the sibilant is first made heavynƒÅda, that is, the sibilant is changed to the aspirate and we have‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡•ç, ‡§£‡•ç‡§π‡•ç, or ‡§∏‡•ç‡§π‡•ç for these conjuncts; as in ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§πfor ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§®, ‡§â‡§£‡•ç‡§πfor ‡§â‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§ø for ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π for ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ, and ‡§ó‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§πfor ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ. These correspondto the ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ, ‡§õ &c., in the above instances, and must, like them, beconsidered as simple sounds, and in our modern languages theyare pronounced as such in certain places, but when preceded by

a vowel they must have, as in other cases, the characteristic ofconjunctal sounds, and be pronounced as ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡•ç‡§π, ‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡•ç‡§π or ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π thoughthey are not so written.

I have already observed that when a following semi-vowel ornasal glides into the sound of the first consonant, this latteracquires prominence. But there are cases in which the semivowel ‡§Ø‡•ç does not so merge into the preceding; and this takesplace when it is preceded by a dental mute. The palatal ‡§Ø‡•ç andthe labial ‡§§‡•ç have since remote times been often pronounced intwo ways;‚Äî one in which the organs approach each other soclosely that it is difficult to distinguish them from ‡§ú‡•ç and ‡§¨‡•ç; andanother in which they are kept more distant. Hence the confusion between ‡§Ø‡•ç and ‡§ú‡•ç and ‡§µ‡•ç and ‡§¨‡•ç that we find so often inmodern pronunciation and in the modern languages. TheBengali invariably makes ‡§¨‡•ç of the Sanskrit ‡§µ‡•çand in most cases‡§ú‡•ç of ‡§Ø‡•ç and the people of Northern India follow him to a greatextent. In the Hindi we have many such forms as ‡§ú‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§æfor ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§æ,‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏ for ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂, ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ù for ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ.

The heavy or close pronunciation of ‡§Ø‡•ç, is favoured by a preceding dental. In pronouncing letters of this class the tongue isnearly horizontal. Consequently, when after the formation of thedental mute it is moved upwards to form ‡§Ø‡•ç, the force with whichit separates from the teeth carries it nearer to the palate than itshould be. In the cerebral position, in which, the tongue formsa curve with the concave side inwards, the force with which itstip separates acts downwards; hence if a ‡§Ø‡•ç has to be pronouncedafterwards, the effort is in no way aided, but, if possible, hindered.In this case, therefore, the ‡§Ø‡•ç is always light; and for a similarreason, it is so when preceded by a guttural. It is also lightwhen preceded by the dental ‡§®‡•ç, since a large portion of theobstructed breath passes through the nose, and the tongue is notseparated from the teeth with any force. Thus in the word ‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø inthe passage I have placed before you, and in ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø &e. the ‡§Ø‡•çbeing heavy, does not glide or merge into ‡§¶‡•ç, and, being the latterof two successive consonantal sounds, acquires greater distinotness; and the preceding sound must, in virtue of the laws wehave been examining, communicate all its elements to it, except

of course the organic position. The element that is communicatedin this case is the complete contact, wherefore the heavy ‡§Ø‡•ç becomes a complete ‡§ú‡•ç, and this, when pronounced like a conjunctbecomes **‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç,**In such words as ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§¨‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø &c., the preceding has got its heaviness of nƒÅda or tone to communicatebesides the complete contact, and thus the ‡§ú‡•ç becomes ‡§ù‡•ç andthence ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡•ç; and so we have ‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù, ‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù, ‡§â‡§™‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§æ‡§Ø &c.In ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø&c., to the ‡§ú‡•ç formed as above must be added the hardness or≈õvƒÅsa of ‡§§‡•ç, i. e. the letter ‡§ú‡•ç must be pronounced not with theglottis contracted but stretched, wherefore we have ‡§ö‡•çand, withthe conjunctal characteristic, ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•ç. Those words therefore become ‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•Å, ‡§™‡•á‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö,and ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö. If ‡§Ø‡•ç precedes instead of ‡§§‡•ç, the heavy ≈õvƒÅsa requiredfor its pronunciation is transferred to ‡§ú‡•ç, and so it becomes ‡§õ‡•ç, andthence ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ; as in ‡§∞‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ for ‡§∞‡§•‡•ç‡§™‡§æ, ‡§®‡•á‡§™‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ for ‡§®‡•á‡§™‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø &c.

The semi-vowel ‡§µ‡•çis also heavily pronounced when it formsa conjunct with another semi-vowel, and thus we have ‡§™‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨for ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ, ‡§∏‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨ for ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ, &c. There are also instances of this pronunciationwhen ‡§µ‡•ç is preceded by a dental mute as in ‡§â‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨‡•á‡§ófor ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ó, ‡§∏‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡§øfor ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§É&c. In ‡§ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ the preceding ‡§ß‡•ç, as in ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø, transfers its heavynƒÅda or tone to ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç, and makes it ‡§≠‡•ç, and so we have ‡§â‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠; but ‡§ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µis changed ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß also.

The conjunct ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç or ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç must in some cases have been pronounced in ancient times like ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∂, as it is invariably so pronounced by the lower classes of the Marathi people at the presentday. This latter sound is easier to be made than ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç, first becausethe passage from the guttural position of to ‡§ï‡•ç the palatal whichIs nearest to it is more natural than that to the more distantcerebral position of ‡§∑, and also because, in the latter case, afterthe guttural contact, the tongue has to be rounded and thetip brought near the cerebral position. Thus, the whole weightof that organ has to be supported; while in the case of ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç, whenits middle approaches the palatal position in pronouncing ‡§∂‡•ç, theforepart falls into a natural position, and no effort is required tohold it there. Now in this ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç, the sound of ‡§∂‡•ç, being the latter ofthe two, is by the general rule more distinct than the other;and the complete contact of ‡§ï‡•ç being transferred to it, it become‡§õ‡•ç, because sibilants are produced by the heavy ≈õvƒÅsa as the hard

aspirates are, and thence ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç; as in ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ïfor ‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ï, ‡§õ‡§£for ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£inthe sense of ‘a festival’, ‡§õ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶for ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞, &c.

In such words as ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏ and ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç, the prevailing sound is thatof ‡§∏‡•ç which, with the complete contact of the preceding ‡§§‡•ç and ‡§™‡•ç,ought to become ‡§Ø‡•ç, as ‡§∂‡•çbecomes ‡§õ‡•ç in the above case, on thetheory that ‡§Æ‡•ç is a dental. But it is not properly a dental, sinceit is formed not at the root of the upper teeth as ‡§§‡•ç, ‡§•, ‡§¶‡•ç &c. are,but considerably above, and not by the tip of the tongue but by apart of it further inwards, which is made into a curve, havingits convex side upwards, and brought near to that position. Inthis last respect it resembles the palatals, though the part of thetongue employed in their case is still further inwards, i. e. themiddle. The sibilant ‡§∏‡•ç therefore, has no mute corresponding toit in the sounds of the Sanskrit and Pali languages. The Marathidento-palatals ‡§ö‡•ç, ‡§õ‡•ç, ‡§ú‡•ç, ‡§ù‡•çanswer to it completely, being formedin the same position as itself; so that ‡§∏‡•ç, when the organic contact is complete, should become the Marathi ‡§õ‡•ç. But these soundsare unknown to the Pali; the speakers of that language couldnot pronounce the Marathi dento-palatals, as the Gujaratis andother northern nations cannot at the present day, and just asthese turn them into pure palatals, so did their ancestors. Hence,that sound which should properly be the dento-palatal ‡§õ‡•ç becomethe palatal ‡§õ‡•ç, and we have ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ for ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏, ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§∞‡§æfor ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•çand‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§∞ for ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞.

The dentals following a ‡§∞‡•çin a Sanskrit word are in Palioften changed to cerebrals; as in ‡§¨‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§¢‡§§‡§ø for ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§§‡•á, ‡§µ‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§§‡§ø for ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á, ‡§õ‡§°‡•ç‡§°‡•á‡§§‡§øfor ‡§õ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø, ‡§Ö‡§ü‡•ç‡§† for ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§• &c.Here, as in the cases we haveexamined, the distinct sound is by the general rule the second,as we may observe even from the optional form for ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§§‡•á, andarea for ard. But, as before remarked, in all these Pali transformations of Sanskrit conjuncts we see an attempt to pronounceboth the members. When the speaker, being about to put thevocal organs into the position necessary for the utterance of thefirst letter, which he has first heard though indistinctly, seesthat the second which he has distinctly heard cannot be producedthere, he gives it up, and then passes immediately to the nextposition. But if, at the first, he thinks he can produce somethinglike the second sound, which he has distinctly heard, he pro

nounces the letter there, and does not give up that position.Thus in pronouncing ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡•ç, he feels that nothing like the sound ‡§™‡•çcan be produced at the position of ‡§∞‡•ç, and hence gives it up andpassing on to the lips forms **‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡•ç;**but in ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§ the ‡§¶‡•ç that he pronouncesat the cerebral point sounds a great deal more like ‡§§‡•ç than ‡§™‡•ç, andtherefore he does not pass on to the dental position. But such ofthe Pali speakers as could distinguish between ‡§§‡•ç and ‡§¶‡•ç did notstop at the cerebral position to pronounce their conjunct, butpassed on to the dental; hence the optional forms we have noticed.

Such words as ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞, &c., differ from ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß, ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§ &c., inhaving the after the ‡§∞‡•ç distinct sound, so that the speaker resortsfirst to the dental position, and uttering the distinct sound there,is not carried away by the following ‡§∞‡•ç to the cerebral position,the sound of ‡§∞‡•ç being weaker. But if in the same word a dentalfollows such a conjunct, that dental is changed to the corresponding cerebral; as in ‡§™‡§ü‡§øfor ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§øand ‡§™‡§†‡§Æ for ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ. The cerebralelement of these words has made a distinct impression on thespeaker’s ear, and he is conscious that his transformation of ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞into ‡§™, which was necessitated by his inherent inability to pronounce the two consonants together, has not brought it out. Hetherefore realizes it by changing the following ‡§§‡§øand ‡§• to ‡§ü‡§ø and ‡§†.But if a consonant of another species follows, or if the conjunct ends the word, he cannot give effect to this impression.

The conjuncts in which the second sound is weak and consequently gives way to the first are ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç, ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç, ‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç, ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç, ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç, ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç, ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•ç, ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•ç, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ, ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ, ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç, ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç, ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç, ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ,&c., which have a semi-vowel for their latter member, and ‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡•ç, ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ, ‡§¶‡•ç‡§®, ‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•ç,&c., which have a nasal.Thus we have ‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï for ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø or ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ‡§® for ‡§Ü‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®, ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó for‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§™ for ‡§ï‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§Ö‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ for ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞, ‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§§‡§ø for ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø, ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏for ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø,‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï for ‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó for ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§ for ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•É‡§ïfor ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï, ‡§ó‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß for ‡§ó‡•É‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞,‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§™ for ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠for ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ for ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ, ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§µ for ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ, ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ïfor‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤, ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï for ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ, ‡§™‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤‡§§‡§ø for ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§§‡§ø, ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§§for ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§µ, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∏for ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∑,‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ for ‡§Ö‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ, ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ for ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ, &c., and ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§øfor ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø, ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ for ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ,‡§õ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶ for ‡§õ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ, ‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§™ for ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§®, &c. The semi-vowel ‡§Ø‡•ç after ‡§®‡•ç in goingout turns the into the palatal ‡§û‡•ç, this latter representing thecombined effect of both; as in ‡§Ö‡§û‡•ç‡§ûfor ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§û‡•ç‡§ûfor ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø, &c.

We have noticed above the change of ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•çto ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç. but more frequently it is transformed into ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ. This change is due to thelatter ‡§∑‡•ç being pronounced not incorrectly like ‡§∂‡•ç, but correctly asa cerebral sound, which being hollow and distinguishable, islost in the sound of ‡§ï‡•ç. This last is distinctly heard, and the effect of ‡§∑‡•ç is only to add heavy ≈õvƒÅsa to it and render it ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ; and thus thewhole becomes ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡•ças in ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ for ‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§£ for ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£, ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñfor ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑,&c. Upon the principles we have laid down, it does not matterwhether the Sanskrit conjunct is composed of two or three consonants, since what is done in the Pali is to reproduce only thedistinct consonantal sound with the other attendant characteristics; and thus we have ‡§£‡•ç‡§π for ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£ or ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£ as in ‡§∏‡§£‡•ç‡§π for ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£ and‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§π‡§ø for ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§ø, and ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π for ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æas in ‡§™‡§Æ‡•ç‡§πfor ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ, in which words thelast is the distinct sound, and for as in it for ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ as in ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡•Ä for ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä, where the must have been pronounced so as to merge into theprecoding ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç.

A Sanskrit conjunct at the beginning of a word is reduced toa single letter; and the reason is obvious. For, as I have alreadyobserved, the distinctive oharacteristic of a conjunct consists inthe previous vowel being pronounced with rapidity and force, andin the subsequent strong pressure of the vocal organs, which isrendered possible by the momentum acquired by that forcibleutterance. It is the reproduction of this characteristic thatmakes a single consonant that is pronounced at any one of thevocal positions look like a double. When a previous vowel doesnot exist, that is, when a conjunct begins & word, this characteristic cannot be reproduced; hence there is no double consonant.Thus, we have ‡§ñ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§ for ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§ø‡§§, ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•á‡§£ for ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§£, ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∞ for ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∞, ‡§´‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ for‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂, &c.

You will have seen that in all the changes of conjunct consonants which we have examined, no element of the two sounds isomitted by the Pali speakers. They had not the patience to hearand reproduce the two consonants immediately after each other,by putting their vocal organs into two different positions, or theylaboure Iunder a physical inaptitude for doing so, their tonguenot being sufficiently trained for the successive movements. Butshort of this, all the constituents of the sound, the ≈õvƒÅsa, light and

heavy, the completeness of contact, and the force of utterance,are represented in their pronunciation, and the amount of muscularexertion involved is the same as in the case of the original.This may be called the energetic mode of pronouncing conjuncts.

There are, however, a few instances in which the componentsare separated by inserting a vowel between them. Thus Sanskrit‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ is changed to ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡•Å‡§Æ, ‡§î‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï to ‡§ì‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ï, ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ to ‡§∏‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§§‡§ø to‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∞‡§§‡§ø, ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä and ‡§π‡•ç‡§∞‡•Äto ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä and ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä, ‡§¨‡•à‡§≤‡•ç‡§¨ to ‡§¨‡•á‡§≤‡•Å‡§µ and to ‡§î‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï to ‡§ì‡§™‡§∏‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï.The separating vowel is generally such as can be easilypronounced along with the previous or the following consonant,that is, belongs to the same organic position as oither. Thus inthe first four instances we have the labial ‡§â in the syllables ‡§ñ‡•Åand ‡§∏‡•Å owing to the influence of the following ‡§Æ‡•ç.

The conjuncts ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç and ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡•ç are almost invariably dissolved into‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ç and ‡§∞‡§π‡•ç as in ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø, ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø, ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∞ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø &c.and ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§π ‡§ó‡§∞‡§π‡§æ, ‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§π&c. for ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø or‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø &cand ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§π,, ‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§æ, ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§π&c.; and in oneor two instances, we have the first change when the ‡§Ø‡•ç is precededby a consonant other than ‡§∞‡•ç as in ‡§ö‡•å‡§§‡§ø‡§Øfor ‡§ö‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø. This change isto some extent due to the ‡§Ø‡•ç being pronounced weak, i. e. almostlike ‡§á.

In the same way, we have ‡§∏‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï, ‡§∏‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§∏, ‡§∏‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§ò‡§æ, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§∏, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤‡§®‡•ç‡§§,‡§ó‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§®, ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§®, ‡§™‡§ø‡§≤‡•Å‡§µ‡§§‡§ø, ‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡§ø‡§® ‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß, ‡§®‡§π‡§æ‡§® or ‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§® &c. for ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï, ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑,‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ò‡§æ, ‡§ï‡•á‡§∂, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§, ‡§ó‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§®, ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§®, ‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§®,‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§® &c. This mode ofutterance wants the force of the one we have examined, but boththe sounds of a conjunct are clearly reproduced in it.You willhave observed that the second member of the conjunct dissolvedin this way is what may be called an imperfect consonant, *i. e.*a semi-vowel, aspirate, or nasal, in pronouncing which the breathis not completely stopped. They therefore act like a vowel, andrender the sound of the first consonant comparatively distinct andaudible, but are not so weak themselves as to melt away into thatsound. Hence both the sounds are audible; but the Pali speakernot being able to put his vocal organs into two consonantal positions successively, as we have seen, reproduced the two sounds byinterposing a vowel between them. But when in some cases thesecond member was weakly pronounced, it melted away into thefirst, and so we have the optional forms ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§§‡§ø for ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞‡§§‡§ø, ‡§∏‡•á‡§π‡•ç‡§Æfor ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ,‡§∏‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§™ for ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§® &c. When, however, ita pronunciation

became stronger than that of the first, it prevailed, and so wehave ‡§ï‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Øfor ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø and ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø for ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø.

Some conjuncts appear also unchanged in this dialect; as ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞ inthe words ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ, ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø and ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§π‡•á‡§§‡§ø, ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø in ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ß‡§ø, ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß, ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó &c., ‡§™‡•ç‡§≤ in ‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó, ‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§§‡§ø,and ‡§™‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§® in ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§π&c., Such as have a nasal for their firstmember and a mute for the second are also unchanged, since thenasal, even according to the rules of Sanskrit, belongs to the same organic position as the mute.

We will now proceed to notice the changes of single consonants. An unaspirate is changed to an aspirate when it isfollowed in the same word by a sibilant as in ‡§´‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å for ‡§™‡§∞‡§∂‡•Å, ‡§´‡§∞‡•Å‡§∏for ‡§™‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑, ‡§´‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏for ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§™, ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞ for ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§•‡•Å‡§∏for ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑&c. The heavy≈õvƒÅsa that forms a constituent of the sibilant sound has made sucha strong impression on the ear of the hearer, that he immediatelyprepares himself to let it out, and thus uses it even in pronouncingthe letters which precede the sibilant and do not require it. Thepronunciation of a word is rendered easier by transferring one ofthe elements of a sound to another or others, that is, by assimilating them to each other as much as possible. In a few instancesthe simple breath or sausa of a previous surd is transferred to thefollowing, originally a sonant, as in ‡§•‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡§øfor ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ó‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø. The cerebral unaspirated sonant ‡§ô‡•ç between two vowels is softened intothe corresponding semi-vowel ‡§≤‡•ç, as in ‡§§‡§æ‡§≤‡§®for ‡§§‡§æ‡§°‡§®, ‡§™‡•Ä‡§≤‡§®for‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡§®, ‡§§‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï for ‡§§‡§°‡§æ‡§ï &c. This peculiarity distinguished the oldVedic Sanskrit also; and the sound exists in the modern Marathiand Gujarati, though it is unknown to the other vernaculars.

I have already given instances in which the cerebral ‡§∞‡•ç of aprevious syllable in going out changes the dental of the followingto the cerebral, and to these I msy now add ‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡§£‡•ç‡§† for ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§•, ‡§µ‡§£‡•ç‡§üfor ‡§µ‡•É‡§®‡•ç‡§§, ‡§ï‡§ü for ‡§ï‡•É‡§§ &c. In some instances, this change takesplace without such an influencing cause, as in ‡§°‡§∏‡§§‡§ø and ‡§°‡§Ç‡§∏for ‡§¶‡§∂‡§§‡§øand ‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∂, and ‡§°‡§æ‡§πfor ‡§¶‡§æ‡§π. The same phenomenon is observable in some conjuncts, as in ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ü‡§°‡•ç‡§¢for ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß, ‡§π‡•á‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§æfor ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç and ‡§†‡§æ or‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§æ for ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æin the several derivatives from that root as ‡§†‡§æ‡§§‡§ø, ‡§†‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Ä, ‡§â‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§® &c.The dental nasal ‡§®‡•ç is also similarly changed to ‡§£‡•ç in afew cases, as in ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£, ‡§ì‡§£‡§§, ‡§ì‡§£‡•Ä‡§§, ‡§∏‡§£‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ç for ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®, ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§®‡§§, ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§, ‡§∂‡§®‡§ï‡•à‡§É&c. The operation of this process is very limited, but still it

exists, and cannot be accounted for in any other way than bysupposing that the vocal organs or the vocal habits of the Palispeakers were more adapted for the production of cerebral sounds,or, in other words, the people had a natural aptitude for them.

Sanskrit ‡§∂‡•ç and ‡§∑‡•ç are changed to ‡§Æ‡•ç, which is the only sibilantin the language. This change involves an economy of effort.The tongue in its several movements becomes a lever with thefulcrum at the inner end where it is fixed in the mouth, and theweight in its centre of gravity. The advantage increases withthe distance from the fulcrum of the point which is moved, thatis, the point where power is applied. Hence gutturals are themost disadvantageous, palatals next, and dentals, the least. Thecerebrals being pronounced by rounding the tongue and raisingit very high, it is a question whether this additional effort doesnot neutralise the advantage they possess over the palatals bytheir position being more distant. Thus ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞ is the weakest of thesibilants. But in the Pali the change is so universal, that wemust suppose a special inaptitude in the speakers of that languagefor pronouncing ‡§∂‡•ç and ‡§∑‡•ç, as we had to suppose in the case of theconjuncts.

When, however, in a few cases, the peculiarity of the palatal‡§∂‡•ç was distinctly preceived, and it was felt that the substituted ‡§∏‡•çdid not bring it out, that sibilant was changed to the corresponding mute of its position, i. e. to ‡§õ‡•ç, which resembles ‡§∂‡•ç in theheaviness of the simple breath required for pronouncing it. Wehave thus ‡§õ‡§µ for ‡§∂‡§µ, ‡§õ‡§ï for ‡§∂‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç and ‡§õ‡§æ‡§™ for ‡§∂‡§æ‡§¨. The change of‡§∑‡§ü‡•ç ‘six to ‡§õ is also to be similarly accounted for.

I have already remarked that sometimes ‡§∑‡•ç must at an earlyperiod have been pronounced very much like ‡§∂‡•ç. Besides thesechanges there are solitary instances of others, such as the softeningor toning of surds as in ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§ó for ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§ï, or the dropping of the muteelement of the sonant aspirates as in ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§ø and ‡§π‡•á‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§æfor ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§øand‡§Ö‡§ß‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•ç. But these will be more fully discussed in connectionwith the Prakrits and the vernaculars, in which these processeshave a much wider range.

The vowel ‡§ã is changed to ‡§Ö as in ‡§ï‡§∏‡§ø for ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡§ø, ‡§§‡§£‡•ç‡§π‡§æfor ‡§§‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§æ,‡§ó‡§¢‡§º for ‡§ó‡•É‡§π, ‡§ò‡§§ for ‡§ò‡•É‡§§, ‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•Å for ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å &c. to ‡§á as in ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ü‡•ç‡§†for ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü, ‡§§‡§ø‡§£ for

‡§§‡•É‡§£, ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ó for ‡§Æ‡•É‡§ó, ‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø for ‡§§‡•É‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß for ‡§ó‡•É‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞ &c.; and to ‡§â as in ‡§≠‡•Å‡§∏ for ‡§≠‡•É‡§∂, ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•Åfor ‡§Æ‡•É‡§¶‡•Å ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ for ‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡§æ, ‡§¨‡•Å‡§∏, ‡§µ‡•Å‡§∏ for ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑, ‡§µ‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§ø for ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø &c. The lastchange generally takes place when the vowel is preceded by alabial; so that the vocal position of the consonant influences thatof the vowel. When there is no such influence, it is changed to‡§Ö and ‡§á. Now, the vowel ‡§ã is composed of a consonantal anda vowel element, the former of which is subordinated to thelatter. On this account it does not give to the consonant to whichit is added the character of a conjunct, and the preceding vowel is not rendered heavy^(1**.)In Pali this consonantal element disappears in virtue of the inherent inability, which we have considered at such length, of passing from one vocal position toanother without letting off the breath; but the previous consonant is not doubled because the usual character of a conjunct isabsent. Or the disappearance may be accounted for by the factthat the consonantal element is so subordinated to the vowelelement as to escape notice, and that the letter, as a whole, isdifficult to pronounce. The vowel element of is pronounced bybringing the root of the tongue in contact with the root of thepalate, i. e. in the position of the gutturals; and is unrepresentedindependently in the Sanskrit or Pali alphabet. Hence it ispronounced either lower down, in the position of ‡§Ö, or higher upin that of ‡§á, while it is sometimes carried so far to the outside asthe position of ‡§â, especially when a labial precedes. That thecerebral or ‡§∞‡•ç element did exist, and was occasionally preceived bythe Pali speakers is proved by such examples as ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•áfor ‡§ã‡§§‡•á and‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ** for ‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑, and also by the circumstance that in some cases,though it disappears, it changes the following dental to a cerebral, as in ‡§µ‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§øfor ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§ü for ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•É‡§§, ‡§ï‡§ü for ‡§ï‡•É‡§§ &c.. From theseobservations it would appear that the vowel we have been considering must have been in those days pronounced just in themanner in which Marathi Pandits of the present day pronounceit, and not like ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç, ‡§á‡§∞‡•ç, ‡§∞‡•ç, or ‡§∞‡§øas is supposed by several European

___________________________________________________________________________

1. This fact is accounted for by the authors and the commentators of thePrƒÅti≈õƒÅkhyas by supposing that the vowel element envelops the ‡§∞‡•ç on allsides i. e. precedes it and follows it. (See VƒÅjasaneyi-PrƒÅti≈õƒÅkhya, inIndische Studien, Volume V, p. 145; and Atharva-PrƒÅti≈õƒÅkhya, editedby Whitney I, 37.)

scholars. If ‡§ò‡•É‡§§ were really ‡§ò‡§∞‡•ç‡§§, or ‡§Æ‡•É‡§ó, ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó, the Pali corruptionswould be ‡§ò‡§§‡•ç‡§§ or ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó; and if ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•É‡§§ were ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§§, or ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂ were ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂,we should have ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§§ or ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂instead of ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡§§and ‡§§‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏, and thereis no reason why ‡§ã‡§§‡•Å and ‡§ã‡§∑‡§ø should have lost their and become‡§â‡§§‡•Å and ‡§á‡§∏‡§ø if they were really pronounced like ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•Å or ‡§∞‡§§‡•Åand ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∑‡§øor ‡§∞‡§∑‡§ø¬π.

The sounds of the Sanskrit diphthongs ‡§ê and ‡§îare like thoseof ‡§Ö‡§áand ‡§Ö‡§âuttered rapidly, *i. e.*without allowing any appreciable time to elapse between the two elements.
