Then by the law of false analogy the lessused and less known declensional and conjugational forms havebeen in many cases brought over to the type of those more usedin Sanskrit and consequently better known. So that in the vocabulary and the grammar, the laws of growth I traced in the opening lecture are in operation, but their range is limited, and thedialect is in what may be called the first stage of departure fromSanskrit. We then examined the language of the Inscriptions ofA≈õoka and found that it is either the same as Pali or in the same stage of development, and that there existed in those times two orthree varieties of speech slightly differing from each other. Today I propose to examine certain other dialects which echibit amuch greater departure from the parent tongue. These are theso-called Prakrits. For a knowledge of these languages we havenot to go beyond India, as in the case of the one we have examined. Prakrit dialects possessed a literature and a portion of it hascome down to us.

THE PRAKRITS.

There exist about six treatises on Prakrit grammar, the mostancient of which is Vararuci’s PrƒÅk·πõtaprakƒÅ≈õa. Next comesHemacandra, a Jaina scholar of Gujarat, who lived in the twelfthcentury. His work on grammar is known by the name ofHaimavyƒÅkara·πáa, the eight chapter of which he devotes to thegrammar of the Prakrits. Hemacandra’s treatment of thesedialects is fuller than Vararuci’s; and his observation was wider. He shows a very intimate knowledge of the existing literature ofthese languages, both sacred and profane, Jaina or Brahmanical.His work, and especially the last portion, is full of quotations. Hemust have availed himself of the labours of former scholars, since

he often mentions P≈´rvƒÅcƒÅryas. Hemacandra also wrote a Ko·π£aor thesaurus of the De≈õƒ´words existing in these languages. Vararuci gives the grammar of four dialects, which he calls.MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´, ≈öauraseni, MƒÅgadhi, and Pai≈õƒÅicƒ´. The names of thefirst three themselves would show that they were the languagesspoken or used in the provinces from the names of which theyare derived, but doubts have been raised as to their genuineness,which will be hereafter considered. The MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´ is called theprincipal Prakrit. For instance, Da·πá·∏çin in his KƒÅvyƒÅdar≈õa says-

“The language prevalent in MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠ra they regard as thePrƒÅk·πõta pre-eminent; it is the ocean of jewels in the shape ofgood literary works, and the Setubandha and others are writtenin it¬π.”

Vararuci devotes the first nine chapters of his work to theMahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´, and then a chapter each to the rest. The peculiarities only of the latter dialects and their differences from theMahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´ are given, and in other respects they are to be considered similar to the first. Hemacandra follows the samemethod; but he does not mention the name MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´ and speaksof the dialect only as the Prakrit. These grammarians and allothers who have written on the subject treat of the grammar ofthe language etymologically. They take Sanskrit as the originallanguage or prak·πõti and give rules about the various phoneticaland grammatical changes which have reduced Sanskrit to thePrakrit form. The Pali grammarian KaccƒÅyanatreats thedialect not as one derived from Sanskrit as these writers do, butas an independent language, though it is very probable he knewSanskrit, since he uses Sanskrit grammatical terms, and hisS≈´tras greatly resemble those in the KƒÅtantra and even P√§·πáini.Vararuci and Hemacandra derive ≈öaurasenƒ´also from theSanskrit as they do the MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´ or the principal Prakrit, butmake the ≈öaurasenƒ´the Prakrti or basis of the Magadhi and thePai≈õƒÅci. This appears to be the tradition; whence it would seemthat older and more developed language or the language of respectable people was the Saurasent, and the other two were thedialects of border countries used by persons in a lower scale ofsociety. They have some of the peculiarities of the ≈öaurasenƒ´,and come nearer to it than to the MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´. Hemacandra givesthe grammar of two more dialects, the C√ºlik√§ Pai≈õ√§ciand theApabhra·πÅ≈õa, the latter of which was according to Da·πá·∏çin, thelanguage of ƒÄbhƒ´ras (cowherds) and others. Another grammarian of the name of Trivikramo gives in his PrƒÅk·πõtas≈´trav·πõttithe grammar of these six dialects. He lived after Hemacandra,since he mentions him in the introduction to his work,and his book resembles Hemacandra’s a good deal. There isanother work by Candra called ·π¢a·∏çbhƒÅ·π£ƒÅcandrikƒÅwhich is ameagre production. Another still of the same nature, the authorof which is Lak·π£mƒ´dhara, mentions the same six dialects: so that the expression ·π¢a·∏çbhƒÅ·π£ƒÅseems to have become proverbial.

___________________________________________________________________________

1. ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§É ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡••

The MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´derived its importance from its literature.From the manner in which Da·πá·∏çin speaks of that literature it appears to have been very extensive and valuable. He himselfmentions one work, the Setubandha, a poem attributed to KƒÅlidƒÅsabut written by one Pravarasens, whose “fame,” BƒÅ·πáa says in hisHar·π£acarita,” reached the other side of the ocean by means of theSetu.” I find in a Ms. in the colophon at the end of each ƒÅ≈õvƒÅsaor canto, sometimes ‡§á‡§Ö ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡•á‡§£‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§è ‡§¶‡§π‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡§µ‡§π‡•á(thus in the Da≈õamukhavadha composed by the prosperous Pravarasena), and sometimes, ‡§á‡§Ö ‡§™‡§∞‡§µ‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§á‡§è ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§¶‡§π‡§Æ‡•Å‡§µ‡§π‡•á‡§π (thus in the Da≈õamukhavadhu, the work of KƒÅlidƒÅsa, composed by Pravarasena). Somekings of Ka≈õmir bore the name of Pravarasena, but there is nothingto show that any one of them was the poet who wrote this work.There is a collection of seven hundred songs, chiefly of anamorous nature, by a poet of the name of Hale, which is calledthe Sapta≈õatƒ´. We have an edition of this in Roman charactersby Prof. Weber. Another long poem entitled the Gau·∏çavadhakƒÅvya by a poet named VƒÅkpatirƒÅja, who lived at the court ofYa≈õovarman, king of Kanoj, in the early part of the eighth century,was discovered by Dr. B≈´hler about three years ago. And severalother works may turn up, if diligent search is made for them.The K√§vyaprakƒÅ≈õa contains about 75 Prakrit verses quoted toillustrate the rules laid down by the author, and ≈öƒÅ

r·πÖgadharaalso gives a good many in his Paddhati.

The religious books of the Jainas form another very extensive

branch of Prakrit literature. Prof. Weber thinks the language ofthese to be later than the Pali and earlier than the Prakrits, so asto occupy a middle position, and calls it Jaina-MƒÅgadhƒ´. ButHemacandra himself, who must have known his religious bookswell, and was, as I have observed, a great Prakrit scholar, treatsit as the principal Prakrit or

‡•§

, and in his grammar ofthis he in several places gives forms of words peculiar to hissacred language, which after the example of his Brahmanicbrothers he calls ƒÄr·π£a PrƒÅk·πõta¬π. In giving his first rule aboutthe MƒÅgadhƒ´ dialect, viz., that the nom. sing. of Masc. nouns takesthe termination ‡§è, he says:‚Äî “As to what the fathers have saidabout the ƒÄr·π£a (works) being composed in the Ardha-MƒÅgadhƒ´dialect in such words as these: the ancient S≈´tra is composed inthe Ardha-MƒÅgadhƒ´ dialect’, they have said so in consequence ofthe observance of this rule and not of those that follow¬≤. Thus ifone chooses to call the sacred language of the Jainas Ardha-MƒÅgadhƒ´ on account of this MƒÅgadhƒ´ peculiarity and a few otherarchaisms, one may do so; and I shall presently have to observethat the great many dialects which writers on poetics give, differedfrom each other in such insignificant particulars only. But it isclear that Hemacandra considers the distinction to be slight, andidentifies the dialect with the principal Prakrit; and both he andthe Jaina fathers refer it to the class of the Prakrits of thegrammarians¬≥.

___________________________________________________________________________

1. ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§ ‡•© ‡•§ ‡§ã‡§∑‡•Ä‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§§‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§Ø‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§É ‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•á ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á ‡•§ He hasalso said before, that therules he is going to give even with regard to the ordinary Prakrit shouldnot be considered universal.

2. ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡§π‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§µ‡§á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡§ß‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•à‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¶‡§™‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡•§

3**.** The only specific grounds one can find in Prof. Weber’s book in support ofthe assertion that the Jaina dialect occupies a middle position are these :‚Äî1. That uninitial ‡§ï‡•ç, ‡§ó, ‡§ö‡•ç, ‡§ú‡•ç, ‡§§‡•ç, ‡§¶‡•çand other consonants are dropped in theMahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´leaving only the vowel, and preserved or softened in the Pali,while in the Jaina books ‡§Ø‡•ç is substituted for them; i. e, the differentstages of phonetic corruption in this case are, the consonants in theiroriginal or softened forms, then for them, and lastly their clision. 2. That‡§®‡•ç is preserved in the Pali, and changed every where to ‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡•çin the ‡•§;while in the Jaina dialect initial ‡§®‡•ç remains unchanged except in enclytics.3. That the loc, sing. of nouns in ‡§Öends in ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Çor ‡§∏‡§øwhich we find in the

But it is in the dramatic plays that we find these dialectsprincipally used. Writers on Poetics prescribe that a particulardramatic person should speak a particular dialect. Sanskrit isassigned to respectable men of education, and women in holyorders; ≈öaurasenƒ´, to respectable ladies in their prose speeches,and the MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´or the principal Prakrit, in the songs or versesput into their mouths. ≈öaurasenƒ´is also assigned to inferiorcharacters; and the MƒÅgadhƒ´and Pai≈õƒÅcƒ´to very low persons.The general rule is that a dramatic person should speak thelanguage of the country to which he or she is supposed to belong.Later writers give more minute rules. For instance, the authorof the SƒÅhityadarpa·πáa assigns MƒÅgadhƒ´ to the attendants in theroyal seraglio, ArdhamƒÅgadhƒ´to footmen, royal children, and

___________________________________________________________________________

language of the column inscriptions; while it is ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø and ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§øin the Pali and‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø in the Prakrit.

Now as to the first, the ‡§Ø‡•ç is not prior to the elision, but contemporaneousor subsequent to it, being found even in the modern vernaculars. It wasintroduced simply to facilitate pronunciation; i. e, it is a strengthenedform of the vowel. Thus the Prakrit of ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶ foot is ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ö, but in Marathi wehave ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø; so‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç Skr.,‡§∞‡§æ‡§ÖPr.,‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø II.; ‡§∏‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞ Skr., ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ö‡§∞ Pr.,‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ø‡§∞‡§æM., &c. &c. The ‡§Ø‡•ç occurs not only in Jainn books, but everywhere, *e. g.*in the Gau·∏çavadhakƒÅvya (see below); and Hemacandra does tell us in hisS≈´tra ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø‡§Éthat the ‡§Öthat remains after the elision of a consonant is pronounced like a soft ‡§Ø. With regard to the second, initial ‡§®‡•çisfound unchanged in the Gau·∏çavadha in a great many places. Thus instanza 242 we have the negative particle ‡§®, in 241 ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§°‡§á for ‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡§§‡§ø, in245 ‡§®‡§æ‡§π for ‡§®‡§æ‡§•, and in 251 ‡§®‡§π for ‡§®‡§ñ. These instances I have found onsimply opening the Ms. at random and no grent search was necessary.Hemscandra also in his S≈´tra ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡•åfollowing another, ‡§®‡•ã ‡§£‡§É,says thatthe initial ‡§®‡•ç is sometimes changed to ‡§£‡•ç, sometimes not. As to the third,the termination ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Çmay constitute a peculiarity of the language, butit is by no means au index to its higher antiquity, since it occurs in thepronominal locative of the principal Prakrit. There are several peculiaritios in the Jainn books, and a good many of them are noticed by ourGrammarian, but they do not show an earlier stage of development.

This continues still to be my view, notwithstanding all that has sincebeen published on the subject. Dr. Hoernle, in the introduction to hisedition of Ca·πá·∏ça’s PrƒÅk·πõtalak·π£a·πáamakes an elaborate attempt to provethat the dialect, the grammar of which is given in that book, is more ancient than the Prakrit of Vararnci and Homacandra. But it is not at alldifficult to see that he is altogether on a wrong track. He says there is

merchants, PrƒÅcyƒÅto the Vid≈´·π£aka and others, ƒÄvantikƒ´tosharpers, warriors, and clever men of the world, DƒÅk·π£i·πáƒÅtyƒÅtogamblers, ≈öƒÅkƒÅri to ≈öakƒÅras. ≈öakas, and others, BƒÅhlikƒÅto celestialpersons, DrƒÅvi·∏çƒ´to Dravi·∏ças and others, ƒÄbhirƒ´to cowherds,CƒÅ·πá·∏çalƒ´kƒ´to outcastes, ƒÄbhirƒ´and ≈öƒÅbarƒ´, also to those who livehy selling wood and leaves, and Pai≈õƒÅcƒ´to dealers in charcoal.Hand-maids, if they do not belong to a very low class, shouldspeak ≈öaurasenrƒ´. Some of the modern grammarians also mentionas large a number of dialects. But whether these were actuallyused by writers of dramatic plays in accordance with the rules ofRhetoricians, or, if they were, what constituted the exact difference between these various languages, it is impossible to determine so long as we have not got satisfactory editions of the plays.

___________________________________________________________________________

nothing in Hemacandra corresponding to the rule given by Ca·πá·∏ça aboutdropping the final vowel of the first member of a compound when theinitial vowel of the second is followed by a consonant, in such words asdhana+ƒÅ·∏çhya, deva + indra,. &c.,which in that Prakrit have the formsdhana·∏ç·∏çha, devinda, &c. This change, however, does come undor Hemacandra’s rule I. 84, which provides for the shortening of a long vowelwhen followed by a conjunct consonant. The short vowels corresponding to‡§è and ‡§ì are ‡§áand ‡§â; grand among the instances given by Hemacandra, wehave narindo for narendra, aburu·π≠·π≠ha for adharo·π£·π≠ha, n√Øluppala for n√Ølotpala &c. Dr. Hoernle thinks the changes of i to short e and of u to short oare later Prakrit changes. But he will find many instances of them in thePaliwhich certainly is an older dialect than any JainaPrakrit. Theyare, he says, unknown to Ca·πá·∏ça. Ca·πá·∏ça’s work is a very meagre production,in which very little endeavour is made to classify faces; and thus bemust be supposed to include these changes under his very general rule thatone vowel takes the place of another vowel(II. 4). The instance gi·πáhatiincidentally given by him in connection with another rule does not showthat in his Prakrit the form ge·πáha did not exist. much less that the changeof i to e was unknown. Then with regard to consonants. Dr. Hoernle saysthat there are five points in which the “older Prakrit” of Ca·πá·∏ça, as he callsit. differs from the Prakrit of Vararuci and Hemacoudra. One of these is"the preservation of the dental n in overy ease.” For this statement theDoctor quotes the authority of a S≈´tra in which we are told by Ca·πá·∏ça that‡§ô‡•ç and ‡§û‡•ç do not exist in the Prakrit, ns compared with another version ofthat S≈´tra which says that ‡§ô‡•ç, ‡§®‡•ç,and ‡§û‡•ç do not exist (II, 14). This lastversion no doubt provides for the change of ‡§®‡•ç in all cases; but the otherwhich denies the non-existence or affirms the existence of ‡§®‡•ç cannot meanthat it exists or la unchanged in all cases. The denial of non-existence or

Still in those cases in which we have the assistance of the olderPrakrit grammarians, the characteristics of each can be madeout with fulness and certainty. To illustrate his rules about theMƒÅgadhƒ´, Hemacandra quotes from the speeches of the fishermanand the two policemen in ≈öakuntal√§, of the K·π£apa·πáaka from theMudrƒÅrƒÅk·π£asa, and RudhirapriyƒÅfrom the Ve·πáƒ´sa·πÅhƒÅra.

The points in which the MƒÅgadhƒ´ chiefly differs from theprincipal Prakrit and ≈öaurasenƒ´are these:‚Äî‡§∞‡•ç and ‡§∏‡•ç of these arechanged to ‡§≤‡•ç and ‡§∂‡•ç;‡§∏‡•ç‡§•and ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•of Sanskrit to ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§, and ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü to ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü;and‡§∏‡•ç is not assimilated as in ‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§¶‡§øfrom ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§§‡§ø, the nom. sing. ofmase. nouns ends in ‡§è instead of ‡§ì, which is the Prakrit ending;the gen. sing. of masc, and neut. nouns optionally in ‡§Ü‡§πas ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§É;and the form of the nom. sing. of the first personal pronoun is ‡§π‡§ó‡•á.

___________________________________________________________________________

affirmation of existence only proves its existence or remaining unchangedin some cases. Besides we have a specific rule where we are told that alatter of the ‡§¶‡•ç class takes the place of the corresponding letter of the ‡§§‡•çclass ( III. 16), thus providing for the change of ‡§®‡•ç to ‡§£‡•ç; and the instancegiven is ‡§ß‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§Çfor ‡§ß‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç. But this rule, the Doctor thinks, holds good incases, for which however there is no authority whatever, and he givesnone. Again, he says that his statement is proved by the uniform spollingof the Prakrit examples with w in MSS A and B, which, necording to himcontain the older version of the work. I, however, find that the spellingin his edition, which is the spelling of A and B, follows uniformly, with oneor two exceptions, in which we must suppose a mistake, the rule laid downby Hemacandra, *viz.,*that initial n is optionally changed to ·πá, whilemedial n is necessarily so changed. The instances are:‚Äî all the caseterminations which are to be traced to the Sanskrit terminations having nin them, such as ‡§£‡•ã, ‡§£‡§ø, and ‡§£‡§Ç; ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§£‡§ø‡§£‡•ã for ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•ç(I.1), ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§£‡§ì for‡§ó‡§ó‡§®‡§§‡§É (I. 16), ‡§Æ‡§£‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ A. II. 21), ‡§®‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä (1.24) for ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä, ‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∏‡§æ‡§£‡§æ for‡§∂‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä ( II 1), ‡§ï‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ( IH. 15), ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§£‡§Ç for ‡§ó‡§ó‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç (II. 21), ‡§™‡§≤‡§ø‡§£‡§Ç for ‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç( II. 24), ‡§®‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç for ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç ( III. 6), ‡§ú‡•Å‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§£‡§Çfor ‡§Ø‡•å‡§µ‡§®‡§Æ‡•ç( III. 15) and ‡§∞‡§Ö‡§£‡§Çfor ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡§Ç (III. 30). The second point is “the preservation of themedial single surd unaspirate consonants with the only exception of k.“This simply means the preservation of c, t, and p which according to theother grammarians are generally dropped. Ca·πá·∏ça agrees with those indropping not only k, but g, j, and d. Whether therefore the preservationof c,t, and p, supposing that Ca·πá·∏ça really allows it, marks off hisPrakrit as older than that of Hemacandra or Vararuci is more thanquestionable. But, as a matter of fact in III. 12, he does provide for theirchange to j. d. and *b;*and the change of t to d is n ≈öaurasenƒ´, *i. e,*a local change, and does not indicate priority of time. Besides, even

If we apply the test furnished by these rules to the severadialects used by the characters in the M·πõcchaka·π≠ika as it is inexisting editions, which play contains a large variety ofcharacters, and consequently of speech, we shall find that thelanguage of the CƒÅ·πá·∏çalas, the ≈öakƒÅra, his servant SthƒÅvaraka,and even Kumbhƒ´raka and VardhamƒÅnaka, is MƒÅgadhƒ´, thoughthe rules about ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•, ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•, and ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü are scarcely observed. There ishardly any dialectic difference in their speeches.But theSƒÅhityadarpa·πáa would lead us to expect his CƒÅ·πá·∏çƒÅlika and ≈öƒÅkƒÅrƒ´respectively in the first two cases, and Ardhamagadhi in the lastthree. the dropping of these consonants must have been contemplated by him.For in the instances given in the book, they are dropped in all the manuscripts used by Dr. Hoerale, even in A and B, which according to him contain the older version. Thus we have ‡§è‡§áfor ‡§è‡§§‡§ø(I. 12), ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§£‡§ì-‡§âor ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§£‡§æ‡§ì-‡§â for ‡§ó‡§ó‡§®‡§§‡§É (I, 16), ‡§ï‡§Ø‡§ÇFor ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç (I. 23 and everywhere else),‡§á‡§π‡§æ‡§ó‡§ì-‡§â for ‡§á‡§π‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§É ( II. I.). ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§Ö‡§Ç for ‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç (II. 3). ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç for‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç;‡§∏‡•Å‡§á‡§£‡§Çfor ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç (II. 4), ‡§®‡•á‡§â‡§∞‡§Ç for ‡§®‡•Ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç (II. 4). ‡§ò‡§Ø‡§Ç for ‡§ò‡•É‡§§‡§Æ,‡§ï‡§æ‡§â‡§£ for ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ, ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∏‡§á for ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ( II. 5) ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§áfor ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§§‡§ø ‡§¨‡§á for ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§É( II. 10 ). ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ü‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ( II. 11), ‡§ó‡§á-‡§à for ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§É, ‡§Æ‡§á-‡§à for‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø‡§É (II.17), &c. &c. It is very much to be regretted that the Doctor shouldin all these cases have set aside the readings of his manuscripts and invented his own with the ‡§§‡•ç, ‡§ö‡•ç and ‡§™‡•çstanding in the words, instead of being dropped. This invention or restoration, as he calls, it, is based on asingular inference that he deduces from a single word, ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç given as aPrakrit word in the book. He says it must originally have been ‡§ï‡§§‡§Ç, but thecopyist, not knowing of such a word being in the later Prakrit which heknew, took it as the Sanskrit ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç, and wrote accordingly. If, therefore,‡§ï‡§§‡§Ç was the Prakrit word in this case, it must have been so in all thosecases in which ‡§ï‡§Ø‡§Ç occurs in the book, and so Dr. Hoernle makes it ‡§ï‡§§‡§Çthroughout. But it did not strike him that if the copyist knew Prakritenough to see that ‡§ï‡§§‡§Ç was not a Prakrit word, he must have seen that‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Ç also was not a Prakrit word and could not have given it as such. Nowthe reason why these consonants were not admitted by Ca·πá·∏ça, accordingto the manuscripts A and B, among those that are dropped, but onlyamong those that are softened must be that all these rules are only generaland not universal, and there were as many instances of softoning as ofdropping. Besides, I have already said that Ca·πá·∏ça’s work is perfunctory,

the Prabodhacandrodayn, The dialect used byMƒÅthura, thekeeperof the gambling-house in the M·πõcchaka·π≠ika, is somewhatdifferent. In his speeches, we sometimes find ‡§≤‡•ç and ‡§∂‡•çused for‡§∞‡•ç, and ‡§Æ‡•ç,sometimes not. The nom. sing. endsin ‡§ì, asinthe MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´or ≈öaurasenMahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´, in some cases, in others it ends in ‡§èas in the MƒÅgadhƒ´, and sometimes ‡§â as in the Apeabhra·πÅ≈õa;and the gen. sing. sometimes ends in ‡§Ü‡§πas in the MƒÅgadhƒ´.Ifthe text is to be depended on, the DƒÅk·π£i·πáƒÅtyƒÅwhich Vi≈õvanƒÅtha^(1)attributes to gamblers may be such a mixed languae.

Itwould thus appear that if all these inferior dislects did existand were used hy dramatic writers, they differed from each otherin unimportant particulars, and that most of them belonged tothe MƒÅgadhƒ´ species, since the MSS. have confounded tham withthe MƒÅgadhƒ´ of the grammarians. Hente we are justified intaking the real number of Prakrit dialects used for literary purposes to be six, viz., those mentioned by Hemacandra, Trivikrama,and Lak·π£mƒ´dhara.

The thirdpoint is the preservation of the medial single surd aspirate consonnntswith the only exception of kh; i. e.,‡§†‡•ç, ‡§•‡•ç, ‡§´‡•ç are preserved. There is therefore, ne question that the Prakrit, ameagre grammar ofwhich is given in the work edited by Dr. Hoernle, ia not older than Hemecandra’s.‚Äî(1887).

1. Another gambler without a name is introduced in the game scene,whose linguage Prof. Lassen thinks is DƒÅk·π£i·πáƒÅtyƒÅand MƒÅthura‚Äôs, ƒÄvantikƒ´. Very few speathes however, ire given tothe former, aod it fs notpossible to come to any ilotinite conclusion from them; butso far as theygo, there is hardly any difference betwoen bis dialect und that of MƒÅthura.The Professoris led to attributetwo languages to gamblers by the annotater on the ≈öƒÅhityadarpa·πáawhom be quotes, and who explains ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§by‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç. But if the word is to be so understood, ‡§¶‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç in the next lineis not wanted, ond neithar ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ß nor ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï, For, supposing tha warriorsand clever worldly mon ware gamblers, gambling was oot confined to them;whence thereis no reason to mention then lo particular.

Da·πá·∏çin mentions a work of the name of B·πõhatkathƒÅwritten inthe language of the ghosts, i.e.. in the Pai≈õƒÅcƒ´. Dr. B√ºhler hasrecently obtained a trace of the work, and arrangements have beenmade for getting it copied¬π. It is traditionally ascribed to a poet ofthe name of GunƒÅ·∏çhya.

Let us now examine cursorily the principal Prakrit and the ≈öaurasenƒ´which ranks next to it in literary importance, but, which, as the model of the inferior dialects and as the language used by the higher class. of Prakrit-speaking dramatic persons in their prose speeches, is more important than the other. Here, as before, I will place a specimen of each before you:‚Äî

The Sanskrit of this would be:‚Äî

61. ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ø‡•à‡§µ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§ó‡•å‡§∞‡§µ‡§Ç ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡•§

63. ‡§¶‡•å‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§™‡§ø ‡§∏‡•å‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§µ‡•á‡§™‡§ø ‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•Å‡§É‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡•§

67. ‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§ö‡•ã‡§™‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•ã ‡§≤‡§µ‡•ã‡§™‡§ø ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§¨‡§ø‡§°‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø‡••

99. ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡§®‡§ø‡§É‡§∂‡•á‡§∑‡§≠‡•Å‡§µ‡§®‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§≠‡§ø‡§®‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§É‡•§
‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ã‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡§É‡••

  1. " Victorious are the great poets who establishing theirgreatness by their own words, do obtatin praise only.”

___________________________________________________________________________

1. So Dr. Bubler told me at the time, and on a subsequent occasion I myselfthought I had found a trace of the work. But up to this time all our searchbas proved fruitless. (1887).

  1. “Those whose hearts appreciate the true besuty of poetryexperience joys even in poverty and sorrows even in prosperity.”

  2. “Even a small degree of Lak·π£mƒ´when enjoyed adornsand delights, but the divine Sarasvatƒ´if imperfect is an unspeakable mockery.”

  3. “There lives a king named Ya≈õovarman who delighteIndra by removing all the distresses of the world and whosevirtues have reached the ends of the quarters.”

[≈öaurasenƒ´]

‡§ï‡§ß‡§Ç‡§Ö‡§£‡•Å‡§ó‡§π‡•Ä‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§ø ‡•§‡§á‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∏‡§£‡§Ç‡§â‡§£ ‡§™‡§ø‡§Ö‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä‡§è ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡•á‡§£ ‡§£‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§£‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•Ä‡§Ü‡§¶‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§π‡§ø ‡§ï‡§†‡•ã‡§∞‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§™‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§≤‡•ã‡§Ö‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ ‡§¶‡•á ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú ‡§£‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§´‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ã‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§Ö ‡§Æ‡§â‡§≤‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§π ‡§µ‡§Ö‡§£‡•á‡§£ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§µ‡•á‡§π‡§ø ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§£‡§Ç ‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§è ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§≠‡§æ‡§á‡§£‡•Ä‡§è‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ö‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ö‡§≤‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ ‡§¶‡•á ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∏‡§£‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ã
‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡§∏‡§µ‡•ã ‡§≤‡•ã‡§Ö‡§£‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç ‡•§

The Sanskrit of this would be:‚Äî

‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§á‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡•á‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§Ç ‡§®‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§ñ‡§ø ‡§ï‡§†‡•ã‡§∞‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂ ‡§è‡§µ‡§§‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§∂‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§É ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§™‡§Ø ‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§®‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®‡•á‡§® ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∞‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§µ‡•ã‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡•§

‚ÄúWhat! thou hast obliged me. Here I embrace. But I donot catch a glimpse of my dear friend, my sight being obstructedby the flow of tears. Friend, the contact of thy body, hairy likea ripened lotus, cools my body in & peculiar manner to-day.Moreover, with thy hands clasped and placed over thy head, doat my request humbly say to that person, Unfortunate as I am,I have not feasted my eyes long, by looking freely at the moonof thy face which rivals the blown lotus in beauty.”

In the MS. of the Gau·∏çavadha, from which the firstextract is given ‡§Ö, and ‡§Ü preceded by ‡§Ö and ‡§á, aremarked as ‡§Ø and ‡§Ø‡§æ. In MSS. of other works, the doesnot appear; but there can be no question that it representsthe later pronunciation correctly, since as already remarkedin a note, this is observed in some of the modern vernnaoulars. But it is to be pronounced like a strengthened ‡§Ö or ‡§Ü

and not like the heavy semi-vowel that I mentioned in my observations on the PƒÅli.

(I) PHONETIC CHANGES COMMON TO PALI AND PRAKRITS

From these extracts you will observe that phonetic decay hasmade greater progress in these dialects than in the one we haveexamined. The changes in the Pali are, with a few exceptions,such as may be attributed to the circumstances and vocal peculiarities of a foreign race. But in the Prakrits the ususal processes of curruption have a wider range of operation; thoughteven here we shall, as we proceed, find it necessary to ascribe agood deal to an ethnological cause.

And first as regards the phonetic transformations which wehave noticed in the Pali, I have to observe that Prakrits alsoexhibit the same with but slight differences. The vowel ‡§ã ischanged to ‡§Öas in ‡§ò‡§Ö, ‡§§‡§£, ‡§Æ‡§Ö, &c. for ‡§ò‡•É‡§§, ‡§§‡•É‡§£, ‡§Æ‡•É‡§ó, &c.; to ‡§á as in ‡§ï‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ, ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ö‡§Ö, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏, &c. for ‡§ï‡•É‡§™‡§æ, ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø, ‡§ï‡•É‡§∂, &c.; to‡§â as in ‡§™‡•Å‡§π‡§à, ‡§™‡§æ‡§â‡§∏, ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§†,&c., for ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•É‡§∑‡•ç, ‡§µ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß, &c. When standing alone, it is more oftenchanged to ‡§∞‡§ø than in Pali; as in ‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•Ä and ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ for ‡§ã‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§øand ‡§ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑;‡§∞‡§ø‡§£ or ‡§Ö‡§£, ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡•Ç or ‡§â‡§ú‡•Ç, &c., for ‡§ã‡§£, ‡§ã‡§ú‡•Å, &c., while the Pali formsof these words are ‡§á‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø, ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ, ‡§Ö‡§£ and ‡§â‡§ú‡•Å.

The diphthongs and at are, as in Pali, changed to ‡§èand ‡§ì,as in ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏, ‡§µ‡•á‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, ‡§ï‡•á‡§°‡§µ, &c. for ‡§ï‡•à‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏, ‡§µ‡•à‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§ï‡•à‡§ü‡§≠, &c.; and in ‡§ú‡•ã‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§£,‡§ï‡•ã‡§Æ‡•Å‡§à ‡§ï‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡•Å‡§π &c. for ‡§Ø‡•å‡§µ‡§®, ‡§ï‡•å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•Ä, ‡§ï‡•å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≠ &c.; but in a good manyinstances they are dissolved into their elements ‡§Ö‡§áand ‡§Ö‡§â, as in‡§¶‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§≠‡§á‡§∞‡§µ, ‡§¶‡§á‡§µ‡§Ö, ‡§∏‡§á‡§∞, &c., for ‡§¶‡•à‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§≠‡•à‡§∞‡§µ, ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§§, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§∞, &c.;and ‡§™‡§â‡§∞, ‡§ï‡§â‡§∏‡§≤,‡§∏‡§â‡§π, ‡§Æ‡§â‡§≤‡•Ä, &c., for ‡§™‡•å‡§∞, ‡§ï‡•å‡§∂‡§≤, ‡§∏‡•å‡§ß, ‡§Æ‡•å‡§≤‡§ø, &c. This change resembles the dissolution of conjunct consonants into the different members,and like it, is due to a weak or languid way of pronunciation. In‡§ê and ‡§î at the first element or ‡§Ö is rapidly pronounced, and thetemporal value assigned to it by the authors of the PrƒÅti≈õƒÅkhyasis, you will remember, half a matra, while in the Prakrti transformations it is one mƒÅtrƒÅ.

The long vowels are, as in Pali, shortened when followed bydouble consonants; and there is the same or even stronger evidence of the existence of short ‡§è and ‡§ì. In Pali short ‡§á and ‡§âfollowed by a conjunct are in certain cases changed to ‡§è and ‡§ì,and from that fact we inferred that they were short. Here in a

great many more cases, when so followed, short ‡§á is optionallyInterchangeable with ‡§è, and short ‡§â is necessarily replaced by ‡§ì,as in ‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§° or ‡§™‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§°, ‡§™‡§ø‡§ü‡•ç‡§†or ‡§™‡•á‡§ü‡•ç‡§†, ‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æor ‡§®‡•á‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ,&c.;and ‡§§‡•ã‡§£‡•ç‡§°, ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§£‡•ç‡§°, ‡§™‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§∞,&c.; for ‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°, ‡§™‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü, ‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ, ‡§§‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°, ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§° ‡§™‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞, &c. In several cases ‡§è,not followed by a conjunct, is optionally changed to ‡§á, as in ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ö‡§£‡§æor ‡§¶‡•á‡§Ö‡§£‡§æfor ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§®‡§æ, ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ö‡§∞ or ‡§¶‡•á‡§Ö‡§∞ for ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∞ &c. The ‡§è in these wordsmust for some reason that we will hereafter consider have beenpronounced short and hence interchangeable with ‡§á. Sometimesthe consonant following on ‡§è or ‡§ì is doubled, as in ‡§§‡•á‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤, ‡§™‡•á‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ, ‡§∏‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§§,‡§ú‡•ã‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§®, &c. for ‡§§‡•à‡§≤, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§∏‡•ç, ‡§Ø‡•å‡§µ‡§®, &c.;which could only bebecause those vowels were pronounced short, and the loss ofquantity thus occasioned was made up for by rendering the pronunciation heavy and forcible. In other coses the ‡§èwas so pronounced by some and not by others; and so we have ‡§è‡§ï‡•ç‡§ïor ‡§è‡§Öfor ‡§è‡§ï, ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æor ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ for ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§æ &c. The syllables ‡§Ö‡§Øand ‡§Ö‡§µarechanged to ‡§èand ‡§ìoftener than in Pali, the ‡§Ö‡§Øof the causativeand the tenth class becoming ‡§è necessarily throughout, as in‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§á,‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•á‡§á,‡§ï‡§π‡•á‡§áfor ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø, ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø, ‡§ï‡§•‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø &c.

All the sibilants are reduced to ‡§∏‡•ças in the Pali, but in theMƒÅgadhƒ´ dialect to ‡§û‡•ç;‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§∂, ‡§™‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂ for ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏, ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑, &c. Thesedialects do not possess the cerebral ‡§≤‡•ç, and therefore we have ‡§≤‡•çin the place of the Pali ‡§≤‡•ç, and in some cases the original Sanskrit‡§ô‡•ç as in ‡§§‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ö, ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Å‡§≤, ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§≤‡§áfor the Pali ‡§§‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó, ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Å‡§≤, ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‡§ø andSanskrit ‡§§‡§°‡§æ‡§ó, ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Å‡§°, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§°‡§§‡§ø, &c., ‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤ or ‡§ó‡•Å‡§°, ‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä or ‡§£‡§æ‡§°‡•Äfor thePali ‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤,‡§®‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä, &c.and ‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡•á‡§á, ‡§®‡•Ä‡§°for the Pali ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§§‡§ø, ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤&c.

There are a good many more examples of the change of dentalsto cerebrals than in the Pali, both through the influence of aneighbouring ‡§∞‡•ç or without it. The ‡§ü‡•çand ‡§†‡•ç which correspond to‡§§‡•ç and ‡§•‡•ç are in most cases softened to ‡§°‡•ç and ‡§¢‡•ç. Thus we have ‡§™‡§°‡§øfor the Pali ‡§™‡§ü‡§ø, as in ‡§™‡§°‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ, ‡§™‡§°‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞, for ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§∞ &c. and‡§™‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§°‡§ø‡§™‡§°‡§£, ‡§µ‡§π‡•á‡§°‡§Ö for ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§ø, ‡§™‡§§‡§®, ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡§ï; ‡§°‡•ã‡§≤‡§æ or ‡§¶‡•ã‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§°‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠ or‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠,‡§°‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠ or ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠ for ‡§¶‡•ã‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠, ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠, &c.; ‡§™‡§¢‡§Æ ( Pali ‡§™‡§†‡§Æ), ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¢‡§ø‡§≤, ‡§Æ‡•à‡§¢‡•Ä, ‡§ì‡§∏‡§¢for ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ, ‡§∂‡§ø‡§•‡§ø‡§≤;‡§Æ‡•á‡§•‡§ø, ‡§î‡§∑‡§ß, &c.

In Pali the dental nasal is changed tour in but a few instances;but here it is so changed throughout, necessarily when uninitial,and optionally when at the beginning of a word; as ‡§ï‡§£‡§Ö, ‡§Æ‡§Ö‡§£,‡§¨‡§Ö‡§£, for ‡§ï‡§®‡§ï, ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§®, ‡§µ‡§¶‡§® &c.,and ‡§£‡§∞ or ‡§®‡§∞, ‡§£‡§à or ‡§®‡§à, ‡§£‡•á‡§á or ‡§®‡•á‡§á, for

‡§®‡§∞, ‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä, ‡§®‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø, &c. The opposite process is however observable inthe Pai≈õƒÅcƒ´ dialect, where not only have we no instances of thischange but even the original Sanskrit ‡§£‡•ç is changed to ‡§®‡•ç as in‡§ó‡•Å‡§®, ‡§ó‡§®, for ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£, ‡§ó‡§£, &c.

The conjunct consonants are transformed in the Prakrit in thesame way as in the Pali. In the former however, ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ç and ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§™‡•ç arechanged to ‡§£‡•ç‡§£, and not to ‡§û‡•ç‡§û‡•ç as in the latter, as in, ‡§£‡§æ‡§£, ‡§∏‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ, ‡§Ö‡§£‡•ç‡§£,‡§∏‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§£, for ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®, ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ, ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø, &c. To be thus corrupted, ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ç mustin the original Sanskrit have been pronounced as if it werecomposed of ‡§ú‡•ç and ‡§®‡•ç; and sometimes the latter must have beenso weakly pronounced that the sound of ‡§ú‡•ç prevailed over it and thewhole became ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç, as in ‡§ú‡§æ‡§£ or ‡§£‡§æ‡§£, ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú or ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§£‡•ç‡§£, ‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã‡§ú or ‡§Æ‡§£‡•ã‡§£‡•ç‡§£,for ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®, ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û, ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§û, &c. In the Pai≈õƒÅcƒ´ and the Pai≈õƒÅcƒ´, however,the Pali transformation is retained; as in‡§Æ‡§û‡•ç‡§û‡§æ, for ‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§û‡•ç‡§û, ‡§ï‡§û‡•ç‡§û‡§ï‡§æ, ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§û‡•ç‡§û, for ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®, ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û, ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§û, &c. In the Pai≈õƒÅcƒ´ and Pai≈õƒÅcƒ´, however, the Pali transformation is retained; as in ‡§Æ‡§û‡•ç‡§û‡§æ, ‡§∏‡§ï‡•ç‡§û‡•ç‡§û, ‡§ï‡§û‡•ç‡§û‡§ï‡§æ, ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§û‡•ç‡§û, for ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ, ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û, ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ, ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å&c.

The conjunct ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç is sometimes changed to ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç corresponding tothe ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç of the older dialect, and ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø to ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡•çto in which case the heavynƒÅda of ‡§π‡•çis transferred to the ‡§ú‡•çwhich takes the place of ‡§Ø‡•ç as in change of ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç to ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡•ç.

In Pali the consonants of ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø only interchange places; i. e. itbecomes ‡§Ø‡§π‡•ç. From this and from the change of the initial uncombined ‡§Ø‡•ç to ‡§ú‡•ç, it appears that very often the Sanskrit ‡§Ø‡•ç, waspronounced heavily when the Prakrits arose. The ≈öaurasenƒ´andthe dialects allied with it have, however, both the Pali and thePrakrit corruptions of ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç.

A dental forming a conjunct with a following ‡§¨‡•çis in a fewcases changed to the corresponding palatal; as in ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ for ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ, ‡§ö‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞for ‡§ö‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞, ‡§™‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Ä for‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ç for ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®, ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§æ for ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ, ‡§ù‡§Ö for‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú ‡§ù‡•Å‡§£‡•Ä for ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø, ‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§∏ for ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏ &c. This seems to srise fromthe fact that ‡§µ‡•ç was pronounced so lightly that it lost its distinctive character, and the conjuncts came to be confused withthose containing a dental and ‡§Ø‡•ç which, you will remember, arechanged to a double palatal. In Pali the ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç is retained in theseinstances, and the ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç and ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç are changed to ‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç and ‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç according tothe general rules, and the ‡§•‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç of ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•ç‡§µ‡•Äbecomes ‡§•‡§µ‡•ç. Besides theconjuncts disjoined in Pali by the interposition of a vowel, wehave ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡•ç and ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç also so treated in the Prakrit, sometimes optionally

and sometimes necessarily. Thus ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂becomes ‡§Ü‡§Ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏ or ‡§Ü‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§∏,( P. ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏ ): ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®, ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§£or ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∏‡§£, ( P. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§®); ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑, ‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏ or ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏( P. ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏) : ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂, ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏, ( P. ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏ ): ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏, ( P. ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏).

(II) PHONETIC CHANGES IN THE PRAKRITS

Having noticed the changes common to the Prakrits with thePali, we will proceed to consider others distinctive of the former.Most of these were due to the continuous operation of processeswhich come into play in a living language. The Pali exhibitsbut few instances of these processes. The changes observable init are mostly to be traced to one or two vocal peculiarities of themen who spoke it. At the time when the language received theform in which we now find it, the tradition of the originalSanskrit was still distinct; the Pali had not lived an independentlife detached from its mother for a long time. But with thePrakrits the case is different. They show a great many moreinstances of the usual processes, and consequently a much greaterdeparture from the parent tongue. We will begin by noticingwhat may be called the softening process.

The vowels ‡§á and ‡§â are softened, as we have seen, to short ‡§èand ‡§ìbefore conjunots. These latter sounds are, as indicated inthe last lecture, more open than the former; that is, do not requirethe tongue to be raised so high as in the case of ‡§á and ‡§â. Theyare therefore softer. But since the change principally takes placebefore doubles it may, I believe, be traced to their influence, as Ihave already observed. In that case this would be an instance ofassimilation. But the change of long ‡§à and ‡§ä to long ‡§è and ‡§ì isdue to softening alone; as in ‡§™‡•à‡§ä‡§∏ for ‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§∑ ‡§Ü‡§™‡•á‡§≤ for ‡§Ü‡§™‡•Ä‡§¢, ‡§¨‡§π‡•á‡§°‡§Öfor ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡§ï, ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏ for ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§¶‡•É‡§∂, and ‡§è‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏ for ‡§à‡§¶‡•É‡§∂, ‡§®‡•á‡§° for ‡§®‡•Ä‡§°, ‡§™‡•á‡§°for ‡§™‡•Ä‡§†,‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤ for ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•Ç‡§≤, ‡§§‡•ã‡§£‡•Ä‡§∞ for ‡§§‡•Ç‡§£‡•Ä‡§∞, ‡§•‡•ã‡§∞ for ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ç‡§≤, and ‡§ó‡§≤‡•ã‡§à for ‡§ó‡•Å‡§°‡•Ç‡§ö‡•Ä Inthe same way, ‡§á and ‡§â are in rare cases softened to ‡§Ö, as in ‡§π‡§≤‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ for‡§π‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡§°‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§Ö for ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç and ‡§ú‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§≤ for ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ø‡§∞. ‡§Ö requires no movementof the tongue or lips, while ‡§áand ‡§â do. It is therefore softer thanthose two vowels. Both these changes contradict another principle to be hereafter noticed, the operation of which is wide, andthey must therefore be considered special or peculiar changes.The manner in which ‡§ã is softened has been already detailed.

The semivowel ‡§Ø‡•ç is often softened to ‡§á, as in ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ö‡§£ for ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®,‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ö for ‡§µ‡•ç‡§™‡§≤‡•Ä‡§ï, ‡§•‡•Ä‡§£ for ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®, ‡§â‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§¢for ‡§â‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§¢for ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§¢; ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§Ü for ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ &c.

Here the effort necessary to bring the middle of the tongue closerto the palate is economized, while the position of the organs inother respects is the same. The ‡§Øof the conjunct ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Øis sometimessoftened in this way to ‡§á and sometimes to ‡§á‡§Ö. In the formercase the resulting ‡§á is transferred to the previous syllable andforms ‡§è with the ‡§Ö contained in it; as in ‡§™‡•á‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§ for ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§, ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§∞ for‡§Ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§¨‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§ö‡•á‡§∞ for ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§∞ for ‡§∏‡•å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç, &o. Similarly is changedto ‡§â as in ‡§ù‡•Å‡§£‡•Ä for ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø, ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§∏‡•Å‡§Ç for ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç, ‡§ó‡§â‡§ì for ‡§ó‡§µ‡§Ø, ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§áfor ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å for ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø. &c.

The surds are softened into sonants. The pronunciation of theserequires, as you will remember, less exertion than that of theformer. For, sonants such as ‡§ó‡•ç, ‡§ò‡•ç, ‡§¶‡•ç, ‡§ß‡•ç, &c., are pronounced bymeans of nƒÅda, or vocal sound which is produced when the glottisis in its natural condition and the chords vibrate, and the surds‡§ï‡•ç, ‡§ñ‡•ç, ‡§§‡•ç, ‡§∂‡•ç,&c. are uttered by sending forth simple breath or≈õvƒÅsa, to produce which it is necessary to stretch the glottis.This effort is saved by changing the surds to sonants. Thus ‡§ï‡•ç ischanged to ‡§ó‡•ç as in ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ó‡§Ö for ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§§ and ‡§ó‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§Ü for ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï; ‡§ü‡•çto ‡§°‡•ç as in ‡§®‡§°, ‡§≠‡§°, and ‡§ò‡§°, for ‡§®‡§ü, ‡§≠‡§ü, and ‡§ò‡§ü and in ‡§™‡§°‡§ø for ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø and theother instances given above; ‡§†‡•çto ‡§¢‡•ças in ‡§Æ‡§¢, ‡§∏‡§¢, ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§¢, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§¢‡§æ‡§∞, and‡§™‡§¢, for ‡§Æ‡§†, ‡§∂‡§†, ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§†, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§†‡§æ‡§∞, and ‡§™‡§†;and ‡§§ and ‡§• to ‡§¶ and ‡§ß as in ‡§™‡§¶for ‡§è‡§§, ‡§®‡§æ‡§ßfor ‡§®‡§æ‡§•&c. (in ≈öaur.). The cerebral, and ‡§†‡•çresultingfrom the original dentals ‡§§‡•çand ‡§•‡•ç are also similarly softened to‡§ô‡•ç and ‡§ô‡•ças in ‡§™‡§°‡§øfor ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø (‡§™‡§ü‡§øin Pali), ‡§™‡§π‡•Å‡§°‡§ø for ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§ø, ‡§¨‡§π‡•á‡§°‡§Ö for‡§¨‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡§ï, ‡§π‡§∞‡§°‡§à for ‡§π‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ï‡•Ä, ‡§Æ‡§°‡§Ö for ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ï &c. and ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¢‡§ø‡§≤ for ‡§∂‡§ø‡§•‡§ø‡§≤, ‡§™‡•Å‡§¢‡§µ‡•Ä for ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä, ‡§™‡§¢‡§Æ for ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ, &c. The sonant answering to ‡§™‡•ç is ‡§¨‡•çbut this is further softened to ‡§µ‡•ç, as in , ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§µ, ‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§µ, ‡§§‡§µ‡§á, &c.,for ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§™, ‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§≤, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§£‡§™, ‡§§‡§™‡§§‡§ø, &c.

An original ‡§ô‡•ç is softed to ‡§≤‡•ç, in which case there is a savingof two efforts. The complete contact necessary for the pronunciation of ‡§ô‡•ç being avoided, we have ‡§≤‡•ç. This sound is similar to ‡§≤‡•çinthe fact that the breath before the break of the contact or closeapproach is allowed to pass out by the sides of the tongue, but ismore difficult or harder because its position being higher upthe tongue has to be raised higher than in pronouncing‡§≤‡•ç, the position of which is near the root of the upper teeth. Thisadditional exertion is saved by proceeding from ‡§ô‡•ç, at once to ‡§≤‡•ç.We have thus ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Å‡§≤, ‡§§‡§Ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ö, ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§≤‡§á, ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ, ‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤, ‡§®‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä, for ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Å‡§°, ‡§§‡§°‡§æ‡§ó,

‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§°‡§§‡§ø, ‡§¶‡§æ‡§°‡§ø‡§Æ, ‡§ó‡•Å‡§°, ‡§®‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä &c.. In the Pali, however, you willremember and probably in some unwritten Prakrits also, thecerebral character of the letter was preserved, and we have ‡§≤‡•çinstead of ‡§≤‡•ç.

Sometimes ‡§ô‡•ç is softened to ‡§∞‡•ç only. The position of this islower than that of ‡§°‡•ç, and the contact is incomplete. It is therefore softer than but harder than ‡§°‡•ç. This last sound is producedlower still, but a light close approach is formed, and the breath isallowed to escape by the sides of the tongue; while in uttering ‡§∞,the tongue is kept in its position with greater force, and the breathis allowed to vibrate. This change is principally to be met within the case of the ‡§°‡•ç resulting from an original ‡§¢‡•ç in such wordsas ‡§è‡§Ü‡§∞‡§π ‡§¨‡§æ‡§∞‡§π ‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡§π, &c, for ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡§∂, &c., the ‡§¶‡•ç ofwhich must first have become ‡§°‡•ç. In ‡§ï‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨, ‡§¶‡•ã‡§π‡§≤, and ‡§™‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§, for‡§ï‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨, ‡§¶‡•ã‡§π‡§¶, and ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡•ç‡§§, we have instances of an original ‡§¶‡•ç passing ‡§≤‡•ç.

An original ‡§∞‡•ç is changed to ‡§≤ which, as just observed, is softerthan ‡§∞‡•ç, as in ‡§π‡§≤‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä, ‡§¶‡§≤‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶, ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡§≤, ‡§á‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§≤, &c. for ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ, ‡§¶‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§∞,‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞, &c. When the ‡§∞‡•ç forming the first member of a conjunct issoftened in this way, and the following member is weak or isitself capable of becoming , the whole conjunct becomes ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤; as‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ becomes ‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§§‡•ç‡§•, ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£, ‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§£;‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§Ö‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤ or ‡§ì‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤;‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶, ‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤, &c,The sibilant ‡§Æ‡•ç, which is the only one we have in the MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´and ≈öaurasenƒ´, is sometimes softened to , that is, the simpleheavy breath somewhat compressed at the dental position is madeuncompressed heavy vocsl sound; as in ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§π, ‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§£, ‡§¶‡§π, ‡§è‡§Ü‡§∞‡§π,‡§¨‡§æ‡§∞‡§π &c., for ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏, ‡§™‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ‡§£, ‡§¶‡§∂, ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂ &c.

Another phenomenon characteristic of the Prakrits is the dropping away of single uninitial consonants. The ‡§ï‡•ç is dropped, as in‡§∏‡§Ö‡§°, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§Ü‡§∞ for ‡§∂‡§ï‡§ü, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞, &c.; ‡§ó‡•ç as in ‡§®‡§Ö, ‡§®‡§Ö‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ö‡§∞, for ‡§®‡§ó,‡§®‡§ó‡§∞, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞, &c.; ‡§ö‡•ç as in ‡§µ‡§Ö‡§£, ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§à, for ‡§µ‡§ö‡§®, ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ö‡§ø, &c.;‡§ú‡•ç asin ‡§∞‡§Ö‡§Ö,‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ü, ‡§ó‡§Ö for ‡§∞‡§ú‡§§, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ, ‡§ó‡§ú, &c.; ‡§§‡•ças in ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ü‡§£, ‡§™‡§Ü‡§µ‡§à, ‡§ó‡§Ö,for ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§®,‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ø, ‡§ó‡§§ &c.; ‡§¶‡•ças in ‡§Æ‡§Ö‡§£, ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ö, ‡§ï‡§Ö‡§≤, for ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§®, ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶, ‡§ï‡§¶‡§≤, &c.; ‡§™‡•çfollowed by any vowel except ‡§Ö, as in ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ä, ‡§ï‡§à, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§â‡§≤, for ‡§∞‡§ø‡§™‡•Å ‡§ï‡§™‡§ø,‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•Å‡§≤ &.; ‡§Ø‡•ças in ‡§µ‡§æ‡§â‡§£‡§æ, ‡§£‡§Ö‡§£, for ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§®‡§æ, ‡§®‡§Ø‡§®, &c.; as in ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ú, ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ö‡§π,for ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏ &c.The vowel ‡§Ö or ‡§Ü that remains after thealision is, when proceded by ‡§Ö or ‡§Ü, pronounced like a light ‡§Ø.Wo find it written in mss. also as in ‡§∏‡§Ø‡§¢, ‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§Ø‡§∞‡•ã, ‡§®‡§ó‡§∞, &c.

In the same way, the mute element of the aspirates is dropped,except in the case of the palatals and of, the or the heavynƒÅda or vocal sound being alone preserved. Thus we have ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π,‡§≤‡§ø‡§π, ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä, for ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ ‡§∏‡§ñ‡•Ä, &c., ‡§Æ‡•á‡§π, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π, ‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§£, for ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ò, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ò, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ò‡•Å‡§£,&c.; ‡§®‡§æ‡§π, ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π‡•Å‡§£, ‡§ï‡§π‡§æ, for ‡§®‡§æ‡§•, ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§•‡•Å‡§®, ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ, &c.; ‡§¨‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§∞, ‡§µ‡§π‡•Ç, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•Å, for ‡§µ‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§µ‡§ß‡•Ç, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å, &c.; ‡§≤‡§æ‡§π, ‡§∏‡•ã‡§π‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó, ‡§∏‡•ã‡§π‡§æ, for ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠, ‡§∏‡•å‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§∂‡•ã‡§≠‡§æ, &c.

The range of the operation of these processes is very wide, andthe number of words transformed in accordance with them isvery large. Now, the principle which is at the bottom of thisclision of consonants is the same as that which brings aboutsoftening, viz., economy of exertion. But in a growing languagewhich knows of no accidents in the course of its history, thereis another principle which counteracts this, viz., the necessity ofpronouncing words in the manner to be understood by others.Hence a wholesale elision is impossible; and the natural course isto soften sounds away, until finally they are elided. This of coursemust be a very slow process. But in the Prakrit, and especiallythe MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´, we do not find it to be slow.

Elision seems to be a distinguishing characteristic which strikesone very forcibly on reading a Prakrit passage. It is too regular,systematic, and far-reaching, to have been the product of a longcourse of softening. In fact, because it is so systematic andgeneral, some writers have doubted whether the Prakrits weregenuine dialects, and have expressed their belief that they are thecreation of Pa·πá·∏çits. But we shall find that the modern vernaculars retain the words shorn of their elements by the Prakrits inthis way; and that these latter dialects were the immediateparents of those we now speak in Northern India. If this generalmutilation of words was brought about by a natural decay, wemust suppose the process to have gone on for a great manycenturies. The Prakrit vocables that have descended to themodern vernaculars have not, since the period when the Prakritsarose about fourteen centuries ago, suffered at all so much asSanskrit words in passing into the Prakrits. We have not droppedaway any of the elements of Prakrit vocables, though we mayhave re-arranged them In some cases. If, then, fourteen centurieshave not been sufficient to make words lose any of their elementsby the action of natural causes, the process by which Sanskrit

words were mutilated and became Prakritmust, if it was naturaland ordinary, have been in operation for a considerably longerperiod, a supposition which appears extremely improbable. And itis questionable whether a language which has not been exposedto accidents in the course of its history suffers so much, evenafter the lapse of any conceivable time. The Teutonic languages,though they have been going through an independent course ofdevelopment, since the period when the ancestors of the modernEnglish and Germans separated from the ancestors of the Hindusin pre-historic ages, have preserved the elements of old Aryanvocables which the Prakrits lost. They may have transformedthe words, but have not mutilated them to any great extent. TheEnglish words father, mother, brother, foot, and others, have all theelements of the old ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É, ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•É ,‡§™‡§¶‡•ç(‡§™‡§æ‡§¶), and others; while the Prakrit ‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ü or ‡§™‡•Ä‡§â, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ü, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§á or ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§â, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§Ü or ‡§≠‡§æ‡§â, and ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ö, and themodern vernacular ‡§™‡§ø‡§â, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§â, ‡§Æ‡§æ, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§à, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§à, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§â, and ‡§™‡§æ or ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø, havelost all except the first consonantal sound.

The elision of consonants on a large scale in the Prakrits istherefore to be accounted for in another way than by attributingit to a natural process of decay. The Prakrit words must be takento represent the pronunciation of the corresponding Sanskritwords by an alien race. The vocal organs of the people of thatrace were unused to the utterance of Sanskrit sounds and in thisrespect, they were in the condition of children, making their firstattempts at articulate speech, and elided uninitial consonantalsounds and assimilated cojunct consonants as these do. When a child or a barbarous foreigner listens to an elderly or morecivlized person, he has not the patience to attend to all the soundscomposing a word and to reproduce them carefully, or has notacquired the habit of doing so. The first letter alone makes a strongimpression on his ear, and this he faithfully reproduces; and asto the rest, he realizes their quantity by pronouncing the vowels,but his tongue being untrained, the peculiar movements necessaryfor uttering the consonantal sounds he cannot go through, andavoids. In going over the Pali we had to attribute the assimilation of conjuncts and other peculiarities observable in that dialectto such a cause; and now the elision in the Prakrits that we

have been considering must, I believe, be accounted for in thesame way.

But what could be the historical events which led to thewholesale assimilation of consonants in the first place and to thesimilar elision of uninitial consonants in addition to the assimilation, in the next ? I would put forward the following hypothesis.It would appear that when the Aryas moved from the land of thefive rivers and settled in the country known afterwards asBrahmƒÅvarta and Kuruk·π£etra, ‚Äî that is the country aboutThƒÅne≈õvar, they formed a consolidated community, in which anaboriginal or alien race was incorporated and the language represented by the Pali was the language of this race. When, however,the consolidated community spread eastwards and southwards, they met other alien races, and the dialect, spoken by the lowestclass of the consolidated community, was learnt by these newalien races, and the words which were in the Pali stage, werefurther corrupted into the forms which we find in Prakrits. Thedialects of the A≈õoka edicts do not show instances of the Prakritrule of elision, though some peculiarities of one or two laterdialects are discernable in them. Does this necessarily showthat the Prakrits had not developed in the time of A≈õoka ?I think not. The dialects of the edicts represent the spokenlanguage of the more cultured portion of the consolidated community, and not that used by the races, which were newly incorporated with the community, and formed a class lower in thescale, though the Prakrits must have begun to be developedabout the time of A≈õoka. In the Nasik cave inscriptions of aboutthe second century of the Christian era, we observe someinstances of the Prakrit peculiarity of elision, whence it wouldappear that the Prakrits had then come into existence, thoughthey were still regarded as vulgar and were neglected, theprincipal inscriptions being in the Pali which had then become alearned language. The conclusion we came to in the last lecture,that the Pali represents middle Sanskrit in a vernacular form,while the Prakrits correspond to the last or classical stage, is inharmony with this view.

Another process which transforms the words of a language isassimilation. We have already discussed the assimilation of the

members of a conjunot and of the dipthongal sounds ‡§ê and ‡§î,and will now consider the application of the process to thedifferent syllables composing a word. The ‡§Öof the second syllableof ‡§à‡§∑‡§§‡•ç, ‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡§∏‡•ç,and ‡§ï‡•É‡§™‡§£, is changed to ‡§á, because the vowel in thefirst is ‡§á or ‡§è, the ‡§ã of ‡§ï‡•É‡§™‡§£ being changed to ‡§á;and we have ‡§à‡§∏‡§ø,‡§µ‡•á‡§°‡§ø‡§∏, and ‡§ï‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§£.Similarly, the ‡§Ö of ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö and ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ä, and the ‡§áof‡§á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å are changed to ‡§á, ‡§è,and ‡§â through the influence of thefollowing ‡§á, ‡§à, and ‡§â; and the forms are ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ö, ‡§µ‡•á‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ä, and ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Å.

Sometimes, when ‡§Ø‡•ç as a member of a conjunct is changed toa palatal, it influences the preceding vowel and brings it over toits own position, as in ‡§∏‡•á‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ for ‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§ø‡§Æ for ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ, ‡§ó‡•á‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù for ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø,&c. An original palatal also produces similar effect, as in ‡§ú‡§ø‡§Æ‡§áor ‡§ú‡•á‡§Æ‡§á for ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§§‡§ø.

In the words ‡§™‡•Å‡§¢‡§Æ for ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ ‡§™‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ for ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ, and ‡§ì‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡•á‡§áfor ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø, theadjoining vowel is changed to a to make it go easily with thelabial ‡§™. You will observe that it is that yields so readily tothe influence of an adjoining letter, because in pronouncingit no movement of the tongue is necessary. It is soundedby letting off nƒÅda or intonated breath, without offering anyobstruction to it; and this current gives rise to the differentvowels when it is obstructed in various degrees by variousmovements of the tongue and the lips; so that if the organicposition of the previous consonant remains a little longer,or if the following is begun a little earlier, the currentassumes the form that that position gives it. An aspirate or anaspirated mute existing in a word influences an adjoining vowelor a consonant; that is, the heavy breath that is necessary for theutterance of the aspirate mingles itself with the other sounds also.Thus ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§§ becomes ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ö;‡§™‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑, ‡§´‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∏; ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß, ‡§´‡§≤‡§ø‡§π; ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ, ‡§´‡§≤‡§ø‡§π‡§æ;‡§™‡§®‡§∏, ‡§´‡§£‡§∏; and ‡§¨‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä, ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä, in which instances ‡§ï‡•ç, ‡§™‡•ç, and ‡§¨‡•ç arechanged to ‡§ñ‡•ç, ‡§´‡•ç, and ‡§≠‡•ç. In other cases the heavy breath istransferred to an adjoining vowel which becomes ‡§π‡•ç;as in ‡§´‡§≤‡§ø‡§πfor ‡§∏‡•ç‡§´‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï;‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§∏ for ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§∑, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä for ‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡§¨‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä for ‡§µ‡§∏‡§§‡§ø, ‡§≠‡§∞‡§πfor‡§≠‡§∞‡§§, in which cases, by the dropping of the mute, we should have,but for this heavy breath, ‡§´‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ö, ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ö‡§∏ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä, ‡§µ‡§∏‡§à, and ‡§≠‡§∞‡§Ö. Thewords ‡§∏‡§ü‡§æ and ‡§∂‡§ï‡§ü become ‡§∏‡§¢‡§æ and ‡§∏‡§≠‡§¢, the ‡§†‡•ç & resulting from thetransference of the heavy breath being softened to ‡§¢‡•ç.

Another kind of assimilation must be noticed here. Thevowels are open sounds and the consonants close. These beingused together, the openness of the former has a tendency to diminish to assimilate them to the latter, and the closeness of the latter has a similar tendency to yield to the openness of theformer. This latter change involves economy and is the same assoftening; ‡§§‡•ç and ‡§™‡•çfor instance become more and more likevowels, when they are changed to ‡§¶‡•ç and ‡§¨‡•ç, and thence ‡§≤‡•ç to and ‡§µ‡•ç;while the latter ultimately does become the vowel ‡§â. But, theformer does not involve softening in itself but rather hardening,since ‡§è or ‡§á, and ‡§ì or ‡§â, to which ‡§Öis sometimes changed, occasion motions of the tongue and the lips. which the latterdoes not. But in this change, there is an ease of pronunciation,such as is involved in assimilation. Immediately after oneclosing of the passage of the breath, it is easier to make a shorteropening for it such as ‡§á and ‡§â require, before another closing,than a longer one, such as the pronunciation of ‡§èand ‡§ì requires,or a complete one, such as is necessary for ‡§Ö. This last vowel therefore has a tendency to pass off into ‡§è and ‡§á, or ‡§ìand ‡§â.But whether the shorter opening is to be made at the middle ofthe palate or at the lips, that is, whether ‡§Öis to be changed to ‡§èand ‡§á, or ‡§ì and ‡§â, depends on the vocal habits of a people. Someare accustomed to open their lips and round them, others not.Similarly, whether the opening shall be the least possible or alittle more, that is, whether ‡§Ö is to be changed to ‡§è or ‡§ì first,and then to ‡§á or ‡§â, or at once to ‡§á or ‡§â, depends upon habit. Andthe ease of pronunciation involved in this kind of assimilation isalso relative. Some people may feel the muscular effort requiredfor ‡§á and ‡§â to be more intolerable than the wider or completeopening, and prefer ‡§è and ‡§ìor even ‡§Ö, as in the instances givenunder vowel softening, and in others occurring in some of themodern vernaculars. The Prakrits change ‡§Ö to ‡§á in virtue ofthis law of assimilation, as in ‡§™‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ïfor ‡§™‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï, ‡§á‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§≤ for ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞, ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§á‡§ô‡•ç‡§ófor ‡§Æ‡•É‡§¶‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó, ‡§∏‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§£ for ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§®, and ‡§£‡§ø‡§°‡§æ‡§≤ for ‡§≤‡§≤‡§æ‡§ü; and to ‡§è in ‡§Æ‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§Ü for‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï, ‡§è‡§§‡•ç‡§•for ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ for ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑&c.

Opposed to this process of assimilation is dissimilation. Whenthe same vowel occurs in two successive syllables, it is felt to beburdensome, and hence a dissimilar vowel is substituted for it in

one of the two. We have thus ‡§¨‡§π‡§°‡•á‡§Öfor ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡§ï, ‡§∏‡§¢‡§ø‡§≤ for ‡§∂‡§ø‡§•‡§ø‡§≤,‡§™‡•Å‡§π‡§∑‡•Ä for ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§µ‡•Ä, ‡§Æ‡§â‡§≤, ‡§Æ‡§â‡§¢and ‡§Æ‡§â‡§∞ for ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§≤, ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü and ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞, ‡§≠‡§ø‡§â‡§°‡•Ä for‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Ä, ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏ for ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑, ‡§®‡§ø‡§â‡§∞ or ‡§®‡•á‡§â‡§∞ for ‡§®‡•Ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∞, ‡§¶‡•Å‡§Ö‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤for ‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•Ç‡§≤, ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤ for‡§∏‡•å‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§Ö‡§ó‡§∞‡•Å for ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å, ‡§ó‡§≤‡•ã‡§áfor ‡§ó‡•Å‡§°‡•Ç‡§ö‡•Ä, and ‡§ó‡§∞‡•Å‡§Ö for ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï.

The words ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§¶‡•Ä and ‡§π‡§∞‡§°‡§à for ‡§á‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§¶‡•Äand ‡§π‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ï‡•Ä must also beconsidered as instances of the same law, though another syllableintervenes between the two containing the same vowel. Instancesof this process must necessarily be few, since there are not manywords containing the same vowel in successive syllables. But wehave got so many here, that the substitution of a dissimilar vowelin such cases may be considered a general characteristic of thePrakrits. It will also be seen that in these instances, ‡§Öis subsituted for ‡§á throughout, and for ‡§âmostly; so that these may alsobe considered as instances in which the most open sound ‡§Öwaspreferred by the Prakrit speakers to ‡§á or ‡§â, as involving lessexertion.

The first ‡§Ö of ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•É‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§ü, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡•ç, ‡§∏‡§¶‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑, & is lengthenedoptionally and we have ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø or ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø, ‡§™‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø or ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø, ‡§™-‡§™‡§æ‡§Ö‡§°,‡§™-‡§™‡§æ‡§°‡§ø‡§µ, ‡§∏-‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ, &c. On the other hand, the ‡§Ü of ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ, ‡§§‡§•‡§æ,‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§, ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ï‡•É‡§§, ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞ &c. is optionally shortened; andthese words become ‡§ú‡§π-‡§π‡§æ,‡§§‡§π-‡§π‡§æ, ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§Ö-‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ö, ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§†‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ö-‡§†‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ö, ‡§™‡§Ö‡§°‡§π-‡§™‡§æ‡§Ö‡§°, ‡§π‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ö-‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§û, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∞-‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞ &c.

The ‡§à of ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø, ‡§Ö‡§≤‡•Ä‡§ï, ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‡§ó‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∞, ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø, ‡§§‡•É‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø, &c., is necessarilyshortened, and we have ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§Ö, ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ö ‡§ú‡§ø‡§µ‡§á, ‡§ó‡§π‡§ø‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•Å‡§á‡§Ö ‡§§‡§π‡§Ö, &c.

Changes of this nature seem to be due to some kind of accentwith which the words must have been pronounced. When oneof the syllables of a word is accented, the whole vocal weight ofthat word gravitates towards that syllable. It is sounded withgreater force and pitch and with a jerk which are apt tocause a wider opening between the organs of speech than isnecessary. Hence the less open vowels ‡§Ö, ‡§á, and ‡§â have atendency to become more open, *i. e.,*‡§Ü, ‡§è, and ‡§ì. Similarly theforce and the jerk tend to prolong the time occupied by theutterance of the vowel, that is, to lengthen it. And long vowelsoccurring in the unaccented syllables often become short, sincethey are uttered hurriedly or carelessly. Supposing ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§™‡§¶‡•ç waspronounced with the accent on ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞, that would be a reason why the

‡§™‡•ç‡§∞ should become ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æin the course of time; and if ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Øwaspronounced with the accent on ‡§Ø, we can understand why the‡§§‡•Ä should become short.

But the real nature of the old Sanskrit accents, notwithstandingthe labours of the grammarians, is little understood. How wordswere actually pronounced in this respect it is difficult to say.If the udƒÅtta was really the acute accent, it falls in some of theabove words on syllables, by being on which, it could not haveoperated in the manner indicated above. The supposition thatthe svarita was the acute accent fails equally. But perhaps theold accents went out of use very early, and others took up theirplace. Whatever may have been the case, the changes we havebeen considering seem to have risen from an accent of some sort.

The ‡§è of ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§®‡§æ, ‡§ö‡§™‡•á‡§ü‡§æ, ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§∞, and ‡§ï‡•á‡§∏‡§∞ is optionally changed to ‡§á;for, supposing that the accent fell on the second or third syllable,the force necessary to pronounce it could not be successfullyexerted if the mouth had to be previously opened wide for sounding ‡§è. It is thus reduced to the close vowel ‡§á; and so wehave ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ö‡§£‡§æ, ‡§ö‡§µ‡§ø‡§°‡§æ, ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ö‡§∞ and ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡§∞. The dropping of initial vowels as in ‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§£ for ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø, and ‡§≤‡§æ‡§¨‡•Çfor ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§æ‡§¨‡•Çmust also be traced tothose vowels being unaccented. The accent on the penultimatevowel, which is very general in the vernaculars, as will benoticed in the next lecture, had probably its beginning in thesePrakrits, and of this fact these six words are instances. Thispenultimate accent seems to have had a wider range in the laterstage of these dialects represented by the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa.

There are several instances in these dialects of the interchangeof consonants. The word ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡§æbecomes ‡§∏‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§π‡§æ, while regularly itought to be ‡§£‡•ç‡§π‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ; ‡§£‡•ç‡§π‡•çand ‡§Æ‡•ç thus interchange places. Similarly,‡§ï‡§∞‡•á‡§£‡•Ç is transformed to ‡§ï‡§£‡•á‡§∞‡•Ç, ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡•Ä to ‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ä, ‡§Ö‡§ö‡§≤‡§™‡•Å‡§∞ to ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§ö‡§™‡•Å‡§∞,‡§Ü‡§≤‡§æ‡§® to ‡§Ü‡§£‡§æ‡§≤, ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Å to ‡§π‡§≤ ( ‡§≤‡§π‡•Å also being used ), ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞ to ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§π‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü, &c.In the case of ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Å‡§Öfor ‡§µ‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï, we have an interchange of vowels,for the ‡§â resulting from ‡§ã is transferred to ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö, and its ‡§á to ‡§µ. Inordinary life we often find that s man, speaking hastily, makesthe sounds of a word thus interchange places. When severalpeople happen to do so in the case of particular words, the newtransformations come in the course of time to be regarded as thetrue words and acquire a recognized position.

The Prakrits sometimes change a labial to the nasal of itsclass as in ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ for ‡§®‡•Ä‡§™, ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•á‡§≤ for ‡§Ü‡§™‡•Ä‡§°, ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß for ‡§ï‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß, ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•Ä for‡§®‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø, ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞ for ‡§∂‡§¨‡§∞, and ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§£ for ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§®. These are optional changes;the forms of the words with ‡§µor ‡§¨ instead of ‡§Æ also existing.Though the change involves softening, since a portion of thebreath is sent through the nose and the force of the contactweakened, it must be attributed to a tendency to speak throughthe nose.

Similarly, the Prakrits introduced an anusvƒÅra into wordswhich did not originally contain it; where also the breath wasdischarged through the mouth as well as nose.In this manner,‡§µ‡§ï became ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§ï ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å, ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Å, ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å, ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Å;‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂, ‡§´‡§Ç‡§∏; ‡§™‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ, ‡§è‡§Ç‡§õ;‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¢‡§æ;‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§®, ‡§¨‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ß;‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§®, ‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∏‡§£, ‡§µ‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§ï, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡•Å‡§Ö;‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞, ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞; ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡•ç, ‡§™‡§°‡§Ç‡§∏‡§Ü, &c.

The last syllable of the absolutive termination ‡§ä‡§£ and of thecase endings ‡§è‡§£ and ‡§è‡§∏‡•Å is also sometimes nasalised, as in ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ä‡§£‡§Çor ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ä‡§£ for ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ and ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§£‡§Ç or ‡§£and ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á‡§∏‡•Å‡§Çor ‡§∏‡•Å for ‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§£ and ‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§∑‡•Å.

On the other hand, the existing ausvƒÅra of a few wordsis dropped, probably from a feeling that its existence in thosewords was due to a mistake and from a desire to correct it. Thuswe have ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏ or ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§∏ for ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏ or ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§∏ for ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å or ‡§™‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Å for ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Å,‡§¶‡§æ‡§£‡§ø or ‡§¶‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§Ç for ‡§á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç, and of ‡§£‡§Ç or ‡§£as the termination of thegen. pl. The letter ‡§≤‡•ç is, in a few cases optionally, sometimesnecessarily, transformed into ‡§£‡•ç, as in ‡§£‡§æ‡§π‡§≤ or ‡§≤‡§æ‡§π‡§≤, ‡§£‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤ or‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤, ‡§£‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ç‡§≤ or ‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤and ‡§£‡§°‡§æ‡§≤ or ‡§£‡§ø‡§°‡§æ‡§≤, for ‡§≤‡§æ‡§π‡§≤, ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤, ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤, and‡§≤‡§≤‡§æ‡§ü. In the last instance ‡§ü‡•ç is softened and made to exchange its place with the second ‡§≤‡•ç, and the ‡§Ö of ‡§£ becomes ‡§á optionally.This also points to the Prakrit characteristic of speaking throughthe nose.

The remarks I have hitherto made apply to the MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´orthe principal Prakrit. The ≈öaurasenƒ´differs from it in but a fewparticulars. It does not drop ‡§§‡•ç and ‡§•‡•ç, but softens them into ‡§¶‡•çand ‡§ß‡•ç, as in ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡§ø, ‡§§‡§ß‡§æ, ‡§®‡§æ‡§ß, &c., for ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§§, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§§‡§ø, ‡§§‡§•‡§æ, ‡§®‡§æ‡§•,&c.The conjunct ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ is often changed to ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç as in ‡§®‡§ø‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã, ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§°‡§∞ for‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É‡§™‡•Å‡§∞ &c.

In addition to these peculiarities, in the MƒÅgadhƒ´ the ‡§∞‡•ç and ‡§∏‡•çof the principal Prakrit are represented by ‡§≤‡•ç and ‡§£‡•ç as in ‡§®‡§≤, ‡§ï‡§≤,‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡§∂, ‡§™‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂, for ‡§®‡§∞, ‡§´‡§∞, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏, ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑, &c. The ‡§∏‡•çof a conjunct is not

assimilated but preserved, and the ‡§∑‡•ç changed to ‡§∏‡•ç, as in ‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§¶‡§ø‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä for ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§§‡§ø ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä, ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡•Å for ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å, ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü, for ‡§ï‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü &c. The double‡§¶‡•ç and the conjunct ‡§∑‡•ç‡§† are changed to ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç, and ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•ç and ‡§∞‡•ç‡§• to ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§; ‡§†‡•çand ‡§∂‡•ç being thus softened to ‡§¶‡•ç and ‡§§‡•ç. Thus we have ‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ for‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ, ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å, for ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Å. ‡§â‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§¶ for ‡§â‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§ ‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§¨‡§æ‡§π for ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§µ‡§æ‡§π, &c.The consonant ‡§ú‡•ç whether original, or derived, as in the Prakritcorruptions of ‡§Ø‡•ç or ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, was pronounced lightly, that is softened to‡§Ø, as in ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø for ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø, ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø for ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø&c. The conjuncts ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ç, ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç,and ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç are, as before mentioned, changed to ‡§û‡•ç‡§û‡•ç, as in Pali; and‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•çto ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•ç, as in ‡§ó‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö, ‡§™‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§öfor ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ, ‡§™‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ, &c. The ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•çof ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•çand ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•çis changed to ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡•ç, as in ‡§™‡•á‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§¶‡§ø for ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•á and ‡§Ü‡§ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø for ‡§Ü‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•á.

In the Pai≈õƒÅcƒ´, the changes of single consonants that we havenoticed in the case of the MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´and ≈öaurasenƒ´do not takeplace; that is, the consonants are not dropped or softened, nor arethey transformed by the process of assimilation. The dentalsare not changed to cerebrals, but the original Sanskrit cerebralsare optionally changed to dentals, as in ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ï or ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ï for‡§ï‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§ï; and an original ‡§£‡•ç to ‡§®‡•ç throughout as in ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§ó‡§® for ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§ó‡§£.Tha sonant ‡§¶‡•çis hardened to ‡§§‡•ç, asin ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§§‡§∞ for ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞, ‡§™‡§§‡•á‡§∏ for‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¶‡•á‡§∂, &c. The sibilants are changed to ‡§Æ‡•ç as in Pali and theprincipal Prakrit, and ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ç and ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç to ‡§û‡•ç‡§û‡•ç as in the former.

In the C≈´likƒÅPai≈õƒÅcƒ´, the sonants are throughout changed tosurds, as in ‡§®‡§ï‡§∞, ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§®, ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ñ, ‡§¨‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ, ‡§ö‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§§, &c., for ‡§®‡§ó‡§∞, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§£, ‡§Æ‡•á‡§ò,‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ, ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§§, &c.

Phonetically, the Pai≈õƒÅcƒ´appears to be in nearly the same condition as the Pali, but the hardening of sonants is peculiar, andmay be compared to the change of Sanskrit sonants to surds in theTeutonic languages, as in foot for ‡§™‡§¢‡•ç, tooth for ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç, know for ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ, &c.Such changes involve no economy whatever; and like the changeof dentals to cerebrals, they must be attributed to certain peculiarities of the vocal organs. Even in the operation of the usualprocesses we have, as you will have seen, found very wide scopefor the play of similar special aptitudes. The characteristic ofthe dialect we have been considering, of not changing dentalsto cerebrals as the Pali and the Prakrits do, and even the dentalizing of cerebrals, would appear to be truly Aryan. Perhapsthen, this was the language of an Aryan tribe that had remained

longer in the original seat of the race, and was connected with theancestors of Teutons, so as to develop a phonetic peculiarity resembling theirs, and emigrated to India at a very late period and settledon the borders. Or it might be, that the tribe came to Indiaalong with the others; but living in the mountainous countrieson the border, in a sort of rude independence, it developed thispeculiarity of pronunciation, which to my mind betokens a rudeand uncontrollable force of breath. Since, under this supposition,they could not have come in very close contact with their morecivilized brethren of the plains, their language did not undergosome of those phonetic modifications, which Sanskrit underwentin the mouths of the aboriginal races. And in a Sanskrit versequoted by Mr. Ellis in his preface to Campbell’s Grammar of theTelugu language, the countries where the Pai≈õƒÅcƒ´ is said to haveprevailed are such border countries as GƒÅndhƒÅra or Afghanistan,Nepal, BƒÅhlika or Balk, &c¬π.

III THE GRAMMAR OF THE PRAKRITS

We will now proceed to examine the Grammar of the Prakrits.As in the Pali, the dual and the dative case are wanting. Thetermination of the instr. pl. is ‡§π‡§ø, the other Pali ‡§≠‡§ø having disappeared. The ablative pl. which was lost in the older dialectis made up by adding ‡§§‡•ã, Skr. ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç, to the ‡§π‡§øof the instr. pl., whichwas used in Pali for the abl., and to ‡§∏‡•Å, the termination of thelocative, and using ‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã and ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã as the terminations for allnouns. This ‡§§‡•ã in the from of ‡§¶‡•ãand ‡§¶‡•Å is also used to form theabl. sing of all nouns. This is according to Vararuci. ButHemacandra gives ‡§¶‡•ã and ‡§¶‡•Å as the ≈öaurasenƒ´terminations and ‡§ìand ‡§â as those in the principal Prakrit, which is according totheusual phonetic rules. The grammarian gives ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ãas an additional termination for both numbers, and ‡§ìand ‡§âto the pluralalso, and ‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ãto the singular¬≤. In Prakrit, sometimes consonants are doubled even when there is no conjunct in the originalSanskrit. Hence we have ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã; and the reason why this and ‡§¶‡•ã and ‡§¶‡•Å or ‡§ì and ‡§â are extended to the plural is that in Skr. the expression made up of a noun and this termination has both senses; as ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§§‡§É may mean from a village or villages. The gen. sing. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ from the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø of Sanskrit nouns in ‡§Ö is generalized as in Pali and applied to all masc. and neut. nouns; and the pl. is formed by the old Skr. term. ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç, Prakritized to ‡§£‡§Ç, as in the older dialect. The Pali pronominal abl. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ or ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ has disappeared and the loc.‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø for fir has assumed the form of ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø and is used for all nouns of the masc, and neut. genders as in the other language. The voc. pl. is as in Skr. and Pali the same as the nom. pl.

___________________________________________________________________________

1. Names of other countries in Central or Southern India also occur ; butthe reading of the verse is evidently corrupt.

2. I shall in all my observations on the Prakrits follow Hemacandra, sinceheis full and explicit. Vararuci is indistinct in several cases, and hisrules on that account have been misunderstood by all writers who havefollowed him; and be is incomplete.

Masculine Nouns in ‡§Ö

The nom., acc., and instr. cases of nouns in ‡§Ö are the same as in Pali; but here the nom. pl. form ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ is optionally transferred to the acc. pl. also, thus giving another instance of the strong. tendency to confuse the nom, and acc. that I have spoken of The dat. sing. in ‡§Ü‡§Ø like that in Pali, is preserved in solitary instances in which it has the sense of " for the sake of “. The abl. sing., besides the general forms mentioned above, has the old one ending in T, as in Pali, and a new one in ‡§Ü‡§π‡§ø which is used in the plural also. This ‡§Ü‡§π‡§ø is used in Sanskrit in the words ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§æ‡§π‡§ø and ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§ø,130which have an ablative signification. It must in its origin be considered the same as the instr. termination ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç. The loc, sing. besides the general form has, as in Pali, the old one in g. The voc. sing. has also the two Pali forms, ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ and another ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•ã the same as the nom. sing.

Masculine Nouns in ‡§¶ and ‡§â

The nom. pl. has a form made up according to the analogy of neuter nouns or nouns ending in ‡§á‡§®‡•ç;as ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§£‡•ã and ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§£‡•ã, This does not exist in the Pali, the analogy being there extended to the gen. and loo. sing. only. The Prakrit has also the two Pali forms ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä and ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§Ø‡•ã, which latter is transformed into ‡§ú‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§ì and ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§â and ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•Å and ‡§∏‡§æ‡§á‡§µ‡•ã, the latter appearing also in the form of ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§ì and ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡§â. The acc. pl. has also the neuter form for ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡•ã or ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§£‡•ã in addition to the Pali ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä or ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•Å. Besides the generalforms mentioned above, the abl. has in the sing, the neuter form ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§£‡•ã or ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§£‡•ã‡§Ç also. The Pali loc. sing. ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§æ‡§£ does not appear.

The other forms of these nouns are like those in the older dialect. The voc. sing. is ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø or ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•Å as in Pali, and ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡•Ä Or ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•Ç. We here see the analogy of neuter nouns or nouns ending in ‡§á‡§®‡•ç extended to all vowel cases except the loc. sing.

Masculine Nouns in ‡§ã

Two bases, one ending in ‡§Ü‡§∞ an as in ‡§≠‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§∞ from ‡§≠‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡•É and the other in ‡§â as ‡§≠‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å, are used, the former throughout all the cases. and the latter in all except the sing. of the nom. and soc. The first is declined like nouns in ‡§Ö, and the second like those in ‡§â as ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•Å. The nom. sing. has also the old form ‡§≠‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ. In the Pali, you will remember, the first base is used in the plural of four cases, and the second in the gen. sing. only while the singulars of three cases have the old Sanskrit forms.
