Here the two bases. have been extended much further and one old form only, that of the nom, sing, remains. Nouns expressive of relationship such as ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É, ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•É and ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É are declined similarly, the final syllable ‡§Ü‡§∞ being shortened to ‡§Ö‡§∞ as it is in Sanskrit and Pali in those cases where the base is used. The voc. sing. is ‡§≠‡§§‡•ç‡§§, and of the latter. cless of nouns it ends in ‡§Ö or ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§Ç, as ‡§™‡§ø‡§Ö or ‡§™‡§ø‡§Ö‡§∞‡§Ç.

Masculine Nouns in ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç ‡§Ö‡§§ ( present participle), ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç, ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç &c.

‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç has four bases. The old one ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç with the old Sanskrit forms only phonetically corrupted (‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ç becoming ‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡•ç) is used in all the singulars except that of the loc. and in the nom. pl.; as ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ü, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ü‡§£‡•Ä, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ü‡§£‡§Ç, ‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ, ‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡•Ä and ‡§∞‡§£‡•ã. In Pali it is used in the loc. sing, and gen. pl. also. The second , Prakritised into , ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ö, is used in both numbers of all cases except the nom. sing., and in Pali in all except the nom. sing. and pl. and the acc. pl. It is declined like a noun in ‡§Ö; as ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ü nom. pl., tri acc. sing., ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ü-‡§∞‡§æ‡§ê ace. pl., ‡§∞‡§æ‡§è‡§£ instr. sing., &o. The third, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§®‡•ç, is employed in the gen. sing., in the older dialect; but here, as , in all cases. and numbers except the nom. sing. It is declined like an ordinary Sanskrit noun’in ‡§á‡§®‡•ç as ‡§∞‡§æ‡§á‡§£‡•ã nom, and acc. pl., ‡§∞‡§æ‡§á‡§£‡§Ç acc. sing., ‡§∞‡§æ‡§á‡§£‡§æ instr. sing., &c. The fourth is ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®, Pr.‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ü‡§£, used in all cases and both numbers. Vararuci, however, does not give this, and omits the others in some of the cases. This base is unknownto Pali, but occurs in the word ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç in the form of ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§£, and is used in the plurals of the instr. and loc,, while here it is extended

to all cases. This noun and such others ending in ‡§Ö‡§®‡•çare in thePrakrit declined like ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç;the base in ‡§Ü‡§£is general to all andused throughout, but the others occur in certain case only. Thevoc. sing, of ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç is ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ö‡§Ç or ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Öin the ≈öaurasenƒ´, the former ofwhich does not occur in the MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´.

The base of the present participles ends in ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§ and they aredoclined like nouns in ‡§Ö. The Pali, you will remember, uses theold base in some of the cases and has the old forms; but here theyhave disappeared. Similarly ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç become and ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ and ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§throughout, i. e., end in ‡§Ö. Other final consonants are droppedand in feminine nouns sometimes ‡§Üis added.

Feminine and Neuter Nouns

The Prakrit feminine declension differs from the Pali in littlemore than a phonetic corruption of the terminations.

The ‡§Ø of the instr., abl., gen. and loc. of nouns in ‡§Ü, and the‡§Ø‡§æ of those in ‡§á or ‡§à, are weakened into ‡§è or ‡§áor dropped, leavingonly ‡§Öand ‡§Ü. In the latter class of nouns this ‡§Ü is furtheroptionally shortened to ‡§Ö. Thus we have ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§è-‡§á-‡§Öand ‡§®‡§à‡§è-‡§á-‡§Ü-‡§Ö,&c.

The optional loc. forms in ‡§Ø‡§Ç are lost; and the ‡§Ø‡•ãof thenom. plurals ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã and ‡§®‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ãleaves only the vowel ‡§ìwhich isagain shortened to ‡§â. The abl forms in ‡§¶‡•ã-‡§¶‡•Åor ‡§ì-‡§âare ofcourse new. Fem. nouns in ‡§ã substitute ‡§Ü for the final andare declined like nouns in ‡§Ü; as, ‡§®‡§£‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ, ‡§®‡§£‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§ì, &c. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É,however, has another base ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§∞‡§æwhen it signifies a “goddess.“In the Pali four bases are used, the old one, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§∞, declined likemasc. nouns in ‡§Ö, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•Å, and ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§æ. This last is used in the gen.pl. only along with ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§£, and ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•Ç‡§®‡§Ç.

The nom. and acc. of neuter nouns in ‡§Öare in the Prakritthe same as in Skr. only phonetically corrupted, as ‡§µ‡§£‡§Çsing.,‡§µ‡§£‡§æ-‡§á‡§Å-‡§á‡§Ç-‡§£‡§ø pl.;while the sing. of those in ‡§á and ‡§â have an anusvƒÅra optionally attached to them, as ‡§¶‡§π‡§ø or ‡§¶‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç a sing., ‡§¶‡§π‡•Ä‡§á‡§Å-‡§á-‡§£‡§ø‡§Ç,pl. The optional Pali plurals in ‡§Üand ‡§è are lost. Sanskrit neuternouns in ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç and ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç become nouns in ‡§Ö, and are masculine.

Pronouns

The nom. pl. in ‡§èis preserved, as in ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á, ‡§ú‡•á &c. The gen. pl. has ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Çfor its termination formed by adding a light ‡§á to the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç of

Sanskrit, which, according to the usual rules, should be corrupted to ‡§∏‡§Ç, and is also fromed upon the model of the correspondingnouns as ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç or ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§¨‡§æ‡§£-‡§£‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡•á‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç. or‡§ú‡§æ‡§£-‡§£‡§Ç&c. The Palihas ‡§∏‡§Ç,and its double gen. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§Çis wanting. The loc. sing. has the termination ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç, a form not existing in the older dialect, in additionto the ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§øused for nouns, both of which are to be traced to theSkr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç as in or ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§Çor ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø, ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç or ‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø &c. This ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§Çisfurther changed to ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ças in ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç, &c., or better, this lattermay be traced to the Pali ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§ø. Another loc. sing. term. is ‡§§‡•ç‡§• whichreperesents ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, as ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§•, ‡§ú‡§§‡•ç‡§• &c. The abl. sing. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç is optionallyused after ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§Ø‡§¶, and ‡§§‡§¶‡•çonly in the form of‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ, as ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ, ‡§ú‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ,and ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ; in Pali it is necessarily used after all pronouns. Inother respects pronouns are declined like the correspondingnouns; as ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç, ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•áacc.,‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§£ ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç Instr., ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã-‡§¶‡•ã-‡§¶‡•Å, ‡§∏‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã-‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç abl. The instr. sing. is optionally formed like that of nounsing ‡§á in the case of some; as ‡§á‡§Æ‡§ø‡§£‡§æ, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§£‡§æ&c.

You will thus observe, that except in the nom. pl., there is nodistinction between the two declensions; the peculiar pronominalforms I have mentioned being only optional. Of the fem. of‡§§‡§¶‡•ç, ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç, and ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç, the gen. sing. is optionally ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ or ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∏‡•á &c.,where the base is ‡§§‡•Ä&c. The other forms are like those of nounsin ‡§à. as ‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ü-‡§à-‡§è &c. This base is used throughout along with theother in ‡§Ü. In Pali it is used in the gen. and loc. sing. onlyalong with the other, and the gen forms are ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ and ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø,the latter of which is, as I have said, a double genitive. Thisthe Prakrit has preserved in the form of ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∏‡•á,originally ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•á,where the ‡§è represents the ‡§Ø of the older dialect, as it does in thefeminine nouns. The other base of ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•çand ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç has also itsgenitive singular in ‡§∏, as ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏, formed by transferring the masc.termination or it is to be traced to ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ. The genitive pluralforms of the masc., such as ‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡§ø‡§Çand ‡§§‡§æ‡§£, are also sometimes usedin a feminine sense. The loc. sing. of ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç,and ‡§§‡§¶‡•çis optionallyformed by extending the masc. termination ‡§π‡§ø‡§Çto the base in ‡§Ü,as ‡§§‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç&c. These peculiarities are only optional; so that thefeminine pronouns are declined like nouns in ‡§Üor ‡§à. Thus wehave ‡§ú‡§æ, ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ì-‡§â, ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ì-‡§â nom., ‡§ú‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ì-‡§â, ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ì-‡§â acc., ‡§ú‡§ø‡§£‡§æ, ‡§ú‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç,‡§ú‡•Ä‡§π‡§ø‡§Çinstr., ‡§ú‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã-‡§¶‡•Å ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§¶‡•ã-‡§¶‡•Å,‡§ú‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã, ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã &c. abl. ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ,‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ, ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§∏‡•á, ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∏‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡•á‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡§æ‡§£, ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§£‡§Çgan., ‡§ú‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å, ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§∏‡•Åloc.

The optional instr., abl., gen., and loc. singulars are ‡§ú‡§æ‡§è-‡§á-‡§Ö and‡§ú‡•Ä‡§è-‡§á-‡§Ü-‡§Ö.

The pronoun ‡§® in the form of ‡§£ exists as in the Pali; ‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç hastwo bases, ‡§á‡§Æ, which is used throughout, as ‡§á‡§Æ‡•ã, ‡§á‡§Æ‡•ánom., ‡§á‡§Æ‡§Ç, ‡§á‡§Æ‡•á acc.,**‡§á‡§Æ‡•á‡§£-‡§Æ‡§ø‡§£‡§æ, ‡§á‡§Æ‡•á‡§π‡§ø,**instr. &c; and ‡§Ö from which we have optionally ‡§Ö‡§Ö‡§Ç nom. sing., ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏and ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø, gen. and loc. sing, and ‡§è‡§π‡§ø‡§Çand ‡§è‡§∏‡•Åinstr., and loc. plural, and ‡§Ü‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç instr. pl. of the feminine.‡§á‡§Æ‡•ã, ‡§á‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏, ‡§á‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç &c. are also in use. The base ‡§Ö is used in thePali in the instr. sing., gen pl. and abl. sing. also.

The demonstrative ‡§Ö‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç, has one base only, ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•Å, which is declined like nouns in ‡§â;as ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ç, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§£‡•ãnom., ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§£‡•ã acc., ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§£‡§æ, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§Çinstr., &c.

The pronoun of the second person has, according to Vararuci,five bases ‡§§, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç or ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ, ‡§§‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ, ‡§µ‡•ã and ‡§≠‡•á. The first is derived from the ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ of ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç;‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç or ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ from the same with the ‡§µ softenedto ‡§â; ‡§§‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù from ‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç through the intermediate Pali from ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§Ç,the last conjunct of which is changed to ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù, by a rule formerlygiven; ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π is made up by putting together the ‡§§‡•Å of the singularand the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ of the plural, as explained in going over the Pali; ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æis another form of ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π; ‡§µ‡•ã is the old Sanskrit ‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç; and ‡§≠‡•á seems to bederived from the ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á of ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á as ‡§µ‡§µ‡•ç‡§≠‡§£ is from ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£. Hemacandraadds ‡§§‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠, to be derived from the Sanskrit ‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç or from ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π,‡§Æ‡•ç‡§πbeing changed to ‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡§â‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù, from ‡§§‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù by the dropping of ‡§§‡•ç; ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§πand ‡§â‡§Ø‡•ç‡§π, other forms of ‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç;‡§§‡•Å‡§µ, from ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ by the insertion of ‡§â; ‡§§‡•Å‡§π,from ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ø‡•ç‡§π‡§Ç; ‡§â‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π, by the dropping of the ‡§§‡•ç of ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π; and ‡§â‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠, by treating‡§§‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠ in the same way. The Pali has only a, ‡§§, ‡§§‡•Å, and ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π; and theseveral old forms it had are lost in the Prakrit.

Nominal terminations are used in a good many cases. Thuswe have ‡§§‡§Ç, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç, ‡§§‡•Å‡§µ‡§Ç, ‡§§‡•Å‡§π, and ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§Ç for the nom. sing., these and ‡§§‡•Å‡§èand‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•á for the acc. sing., ‡§§‡§á, ‡§§‡§è, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§á, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§è, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•á, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§á, and also ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§Ç, ‡§≠‡•á,‡§§‡•á, ‡§¶‡•á, and ‡§¶‡§ø for the instr. sing. The form ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§Ç properly belongs to the nom.and acc. cases and to the gen., ‡§¶‡•á and ‡§¶‡§øbeing only ‡§§‡•á softened; but several cases are here confounded. Theabl sing. has ‡§§‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã-‡§ì-‡§â-‡§¶‡•ã-‡§¶‡•Å-‡§π‡§ø-‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã, ‡§§‡•Å‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã-‡§ì &c. ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã-‡§ì &c.,‡§§‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã-‡§ì&c. ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã-‡§ì &c., ‡§§‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã-‡§ì &c. also ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ø‡•ç‡§π, ‡§§‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π, and‡§§‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù. The gen. sing. has twenty-one. forms, viz. ‡§§‡§á‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç, ‡§§‡•á, ‡§§‡•Å‡§π, ‡§§‡•Å‡§π‡§Ç, ‡§§‡•Å‡§µ, ‡§¢‡§Æ, ‡§¢‡§Æ‡•á, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç, ‡§á, ‡§¶‡§ø, ‡§á, ‡§è, ‡§§‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠, ‡§â‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠, ‡§â‡§Ø‡•ç‡§π, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π, ‡§§‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù, ‡§â‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π,

and ‡§â‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù. The loc. sing has ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•á, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§è ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§á ‡§§‡§á, ‡§§‡§è, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø, ‡§§‡•Å‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø, ‡§§‡•Å‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø,‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø and ‡§§‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø. The plurals are as follows:‚Äî‡§≠‡•á, ‡§§‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡•á,‡§â‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡•á ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ø‡•ç‡§π‡•á, ‡§â‡§Ø‡•ç‡§π‡•á, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á, ‡§§‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡•á nom. ‡§µ‡•ã ‡§§‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡•á, ‡§â‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡•á, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á, ‡§§‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡•á, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ø‡•ç‡§π‡•á, ‡§â‡§Ø‡•ç‡§π‡•á,‡§≠‡•á acc., ‡§≠‡•á, ‡§§‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç,‡§§‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç, ‡§â‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç, ‡§â‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç,‡§§‡•Å‡§Ø‡•ç‡§π‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Çand ‡§â‡§Ø‡•ç‡§π‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç instr.;‡§§‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡•ã-‡§¶‡•Å-‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã-‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ø‡•ç‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã-‡§¶‡•ã &c., ‡§â‡§Ø‡•ç‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã-‡§¶‡•ã &c., ‡§â‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã-‡§¶‡•ã &c.,‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã-‡§¶‡•ã &c.and ‡§§‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã-‡§¶‡•ã &c. abl; ‡§≠‡•á, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ø‡•ç‡§π, ‡§§‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠, ‡§â‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠, ‡§§‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§£-‡§£‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§£-‡§£‡§Ç,‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£-‡§£‡§Ç, ‡§§‡•Å‡§π‡§æ‡§£-‡§£‡§Ç, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§£-‡§£‡§Ç, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π, ‡§§‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù, ‡§â‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π, ‡§â‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù,‡§§‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§æ‡§£-‡§£‡§Ç, gen.; ‡§§‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å, ‡§§‡•Å‡§µ-‡§µ‡•á‡§∏‡•Å, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ-‡§Æ‡•á‡§∏‡•Å, ‡§§‡•Å‡§π-‡§π‡•á‡§∏‡•Å ‡§§‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠-‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ-‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡•á‡§∏‡•Å,‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ-‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á‡§∏‡•Å,‡§§‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù-‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§æ-‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡•á‡§∏‡•Å loc.

The points to be observed in these forms are these. The nom.sing, has mostly the same forms as the acc. sing. This is due tothe fact that the Sanskrit ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•çof the acc. becomes, when the ‡§Üis shortened by a Prakrit phonetic rule, ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ç, i. e., the same as thenom. sing. Hence its Prakrit representatives ‡§§‡§Ç, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç, ‡§§‡•Å‡§µ‡§Ç at and ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§Çare the same for both the cases. But a more probable reason,which explains a similar fact in the case of the first personalpronoun also, is that the plurals of the nom, and acc. having bynatural processes already explained become exactly alike, thetwo cases came to be confounded; and the sing. forms also of theone were used for the other. The forms as, ‡§§‡§á, ‡§§‡§è, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§á, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§è, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•á, and ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§áare common to the instr, and loc. sing. This probably arisesfrom the fact that the Sanskrit ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ, when the ‡§Øis softened to ‡§èor ‡§á, becomes ‡§§‡§èor ‡§§‡§á, and so does the ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§øof the loc.; and whenthe base ‡§§ is seen to be interchangeable with ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ in the nom., theterminations ‡§è and ‡§á which are common to the two cases areapplied to ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ also. ‡§§‡•áand its softened forms ‡§¶‡•á and ‡§¶‡§ø, and ‡§§‡§áarecommon to the instr, and gen. sing.; ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ø‡•ç‡§π, ‡§§‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π, ‡§§‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù are common to the abl. sing. and the gen. sing. and pl.; and ‡§≠‡•áto the instr. sing. and pl. and the gen. sing.

Such a confusion of the case-relations must be expected incourse of time. Even in Sanskrit the gen. and instr. &c. areused alike in connection with some participles and the identification of the abl. and the instr. we have already noticed in thePrakrits. The gen. forms ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ø‡•ç‡§π, ‡§§‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ø‡•ç‡§π, ‡§§‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù, ‡§â‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠, ‡§â‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π, and ‡§â‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù,all derived from the Sanskrit dat. ‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•çand referred to the gen.when that case was lost, are taken as bases, and the terminations‡§è of the nom, and acc. pl., ‡§π‡§øof the instr. pl., ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã, ‡§¶‡•ã, ‡§¶‡•Å, ‡§ìand ‡§â ofthe abl., ‡§£or ‡§£‡§Ç ot of the gen. pl., and ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§øand ‡§∏‡•Å of the loc. sing. and

pl. are tacked on to them to form these cases. Here the tendencyto use the genitive form as a base for the formation of the othercases, a trace of which only we observed in the Pali, is seenmore developed.

The pronoun of the first person has, according to Vararuci,the following bases:‚Äî ‡§π‡§Ç or ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç and ‡§Æfrom the Sanskrit singulars,‡§Æ‡§Æ the gen. sing., ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π from ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ and ‡§£‡•ã from ‡§®‡§∏‡•çof which ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§πis used in the plural. Hemacandra adds ‡§Æ‡§πand ‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù from ‡§Æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•çand ‡§≠‡•áfrom ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á or ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á. He also gives ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§ø, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø, and ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø for thenom, and ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§øfor acc. sing. The first is clearly from ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø1stpers. sing. present of ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç, often used in Sanskrit as an indeclinableparticle; and the others are also corruptions of the sanie, just asthe termination ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§øof the loc. is a corruption of ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç. Thesingular forms, therefore, are:‚Äî ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø, ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§ø, ‡§π‡§Ç, ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç, ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ø‡§Çnom.;‡§£‡•á, ‡§£‡§Ç, ‡§Æ‡§ø, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π, ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π, ‡§Æ‡§Ç, ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§Ç, ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ç acc.; ‡§Æ‡§ø, ‡§Æ‡•á, ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§è, ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§á,‡§Æ‡§á, ‡§Æ‡§è, ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§á, ‡§£‡•á, instr.; ‡§Æ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã-‡§¶‡•ã-‡§¶‡•Å-‡§ì-‡§â-‡§π‡§ø-‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã, ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã, ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã &c.,‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã &c. abl; ‡§Æ‡•á, ‡§Æ‡§π, ‡§Æ‡§Æ, ‡§Æ‡§π, ‡§Æ‡§π‡§Ç, ‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù, ‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§Ç, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§Ç gen.; ‡§Æ‡§ø, ‡§Æ‡§á,‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§á, ‡§Æ‡§è, ‡§Æ‡•á, ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø, ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø, ‡§Æ‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø loc. The plurals are:‚Äî ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á,‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•ã, ‡§Æ‡•ã,‡§µ‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•á nom. ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•ã, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π, ‡§£‡•á acc.;‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§π‡§ø, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á,‡§£‡•á instr. ; ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•ã, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§§‡•ã, ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã-‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã, ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•á‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á,‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã abl; ‡§£‡•á, ‡§£‡•ã, ‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§Ç, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•ã, ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§£, ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£, ‡§Æ‡§π‡§æ‡§£, ‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§æ‡§£gen.; ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π-‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ-‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á‡§∏‡•Å-‡§Æ‡§Æ-‡§Æ‡•á‡§∏‡•Å, ‡§Æ‡§π-‡§π‡•á‡§Æ‡•Å, ‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù-‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡•á‡§∏‡•Å loc. Here also the sameobservations as those made in the case of the last pronoun areapplicable.

In the MƒÅgadhƒ´ the ‡§ìof the nom. sing. of nouns ending in ‡§Öis replaced by ‡§è as ‡§è‡§∂‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§∂‡•á for ‡§è‡§∑ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É. The ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ of the gen.sing. is sometimes changed to ‡§πand the preceding ‡§Öis lengthened;as ‡§∂‡•ã‡§£‡§ø‡§¶‡§æ‡§π ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•á for ‡§∂‡•ã‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§É.The plural of this case isformed by adding ‡§Ü‡§π‡§Ç, as ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç for ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç, The anusvƒÅrarepresents the ‡§£of the original termination ‡§Ü‡§£, and ‡§π is introduced from the analogy of the sing. The regular forms ‡§∂‡•ã‡§£‡§ø‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏and ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç are also admissible. Such forms as these we shallmeet with hereafter; and they belong to a later stage in the decayof our grammar.

IV. THE PRAKRIT VERB

  • Conjugations*:‚ÄîAll the Skr. conjugations, with the exceptionof the second in the case of a few roots ending in a vowel, have

been brought over to the ‡§Ötype, i. e., to the first, sixth, and thetenth. Some of the others have left a few traces; as, the fifth andthe ninth have preserved their ‡§£ in such instances as ‡§∏‡•Å‡§£, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§£, ‡§ú‡§æ‡§£, ‡§≤‡•Å‡§£, ‡§™‡•Å‡§£, ‡§ß‡•Å‡§£,‚Äî both conjugations being, as you mayremember, confounded in the Pali, the third the root ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§π‚Äîpres.tense ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§π‡§¶‡§ø‚Äîthe ‡§á standing for ‡§≠; the fourth has preserved its ‡§Øassimilated in a good many roots such as ‡§£‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö, ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù, ‡§ú‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù, ‡§§‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü, ‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏&c.; and the seventh has preserved its ‡§®‡•ç in ‡§∞‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§ß and others. But you will see that to these forms ‡§Öis added and they are made roots ending in ‡§Ö; while a greatmany have lost even such traces. In the Pali, you will remember,the conjugational signs added to some of the roots are entire, asthe ‡§®‡§æof the sixth and the ‡§®‡•ãof the fifth, and ‡§Ö is appended toroots of the seventh conjugation only, ‡§®‡•ç being inserted before thethe last consonant. But here the at takes the place of the endingvowel of the signs of the fifth and other conjugation also, so wehave ‡§∏‡•Å‡§£, ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§£, and ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§π.

Thus in the Prakrit most roots end in ‡§Ö. There are some endingin other vowels, such as ‡§π‡•ãand ‡§†‡§æ, but the rule of conjugation isthe same for all, viz., to add the terminations to the root directly.There can be no consonantal root. Some forms, such as those of‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç, have come down from the parent language only phoneticallychanged; but these are not formed in the Prakrit. They are reallySanskrit forms in what I have ventured to call a petrified condition. The roots ending in ‡§Öchange it to optionally, i. e. theyare conjugated according to the model of the first and of the tenth,as is the case to a great extent in the Pali also. The distinctionbetween the special and the general tenses is of course forgotten.

The Prakrits have retained the Present and Future tenses andthe Imperative mood entire; while the Potential and the Aoristhave left the third person singular only. An isolated form ofthe Imperfect such as ‡§Ü‡§∏‡§ø from the root ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•çremains.

The terminations of the Present Tense are‚Äî 3rd pers. sing. ‡§¶‡§øand ‡§¶‡•á in ≈öaur. and ‡§á and ‡§è in the principal Prakrit, pl. ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§øand ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á;2nd pers. sing. ‡§∏‡§øand ‡§∏‡•á, pl. ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æand ‡§π for which last the ≈öaur.has ‡§ß; 1st pers. sing. ‡§Æ‡§ø, pl. ‡§Æ‡•ã, ‡§Æ‡•Å, and ‡§Æ.

Of these ‡§¶‡•á, or ‡§è, ‡§∏‡•á, and ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á, of which the last is not given by

Vararuci, are remnants of the old ƒÄtmanepada, and the firsttwo are used after roots ending in ‡§Ö only. With the exceptionof the first pers. pl. ‡§Æand the 2nd pers. pl. ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ, the terminationscan readily be traced to the corresponding Skr. Parasm. TheSanskrit 2nd pers. pl. ‡§•becomes ‡§ß in the ≈öaurasenƒ´and ‡§π in theMahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´by the phonetic rules already noticed, and ‡§Æ‡•ãor itsshortened form ‡§Æ‡•Å is the Skr. ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç. In these points the primitiveand derived languages perfectly agree; but ‡§Æ and ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ are newterminations and were first used in Pali, the latter however in theform of ‡§§‡•ç‡§•. The first is, as I have observed, transferred from theImperative and other tensos, and ‡§§‡•ç‡§• is the Skr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§• 2nd pers. pl. ofroot ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç. To this is prefixed in the Prakrit the usual augment ‡§á,which ‡§Æ‡•ã and ‡§Æ‡•Å also take optionally. The terminations ‡§Æ‡•ã and ‡§Æ‡•Åare unknown to the Pali.

Other forms of the first pors. sing. and pl., made up by adding‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§ø and ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π or ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•ã, as in ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§ø, ‡§ï‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π, ‡§ó‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π &c., ocour in theplays, though the grammarians have not noticed them. Theseterminations are evidently the Skr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø, 1st pers. sing., and ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§É or ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ,pl. of ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç¬π. You will remember that a good many verbs aremade up in the Pali by adding forms of this root. Hemacandranotices also another termination of the 3rd pers. pl. viz. ‡§á‡§∞‡•á, whichis transferred from the Perfect.

The Imperative forms are made up by adding ‡§¶‡•Å ≈öaur. ‡§âPrakrit, 3rd pers. sing., and ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å pl.; ‡§∏‡•Å and ‡§π‡§ø 2nd pers. sing. and ‡§ß≈öaur., ‡§á Prakrit, pl.: and ‡§Æ‡•Å 1st pers. sing. and ‡§Æ‡•ã pl. The originalform of the root ending in ‡§Ö is also used as the second pers. sing.Of these ‡§ü‡•Å, ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å, ‡§π‡§ø or ‡§Öand ‡§∏‡•Å from ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ ƒÄtm. are both Skr. and Pali;‡§π (Skr. ‡§•) transferred from the Present is used in Pali; but ‡§Æ‡•Å and‡§Æ‡•ã are peculiar to the Prakrit, the Pali using only the termination of its present. Of these ‡§Æ‡•ã istransferred from the PrakritPresent, and ‡§Æ‡•Å is made up by adding the ‡§â which is peculiar tothe Imperative and distinguishes it from the present. The firstpers. pl. takes ‡§Æ also sometimes as in the Pali, but it is not noticedby the grammarians.

___________________________________________________________________________

1. Prof. Lassen traces these to the root ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç, but ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ to the Skr. ‡§• to which‡§§‡•ç is, he says, prefixed because the previous vowel must have been pronounced with some accent. But considering that many forms of ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•çare used asterminations it is more natural to take this also as such a form.

The consciousness that the future is made up by prefixing ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø = ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏Pr. & Pali to the terminations of the present has never beenlost, and whatever changes these terminations undergo are transferred to the future; so that the ≈öaurasenƒ´and MƒÅgadhƒ´ futurediffers from the Pali in those respects only in which the Presenttenses of the two differ. The ‡§Æ‡§ø of the first person sing., however,is optionally changed to an anusvƒÅra; or the anusv√§ra may be aremnant of the conditional terminations; as ‡§π‡§∏‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç.In the prineipal Prakrit the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø is still further corrupted to ‡§π‡§ø, ‡§Ø being dissolved into ‡§á and ‡§∏‡•çchanged to ‡§π, as in ‡§π‡•ã‡§π‡§ø‡§πfor ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø, ‡§π‡•ã‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§≠‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, &c. In the first pers. we have, in addition to this ‡§π‡§ø, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ which is lengthened as in Skr. and also its other form ‡§π‡§æaswell as ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç for the whole as in the ≈öaurasenƒ´, i e., ‡§π‡•ã‡§π‡§ø-‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ-‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡§øor ‡§π‡•ã‡§π‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç, &c. A beginning in the direction of the ‡§π‡§øwas, youwill remember, made in Pali. We have also a few petrified Skr.forms such as ‡§¶‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Ç for ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Ç for ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø which are more conditional than future in their origin; and to these as bases, areadded the terminations of the present and also of the future toform new futures: as ‡§¶‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§á ‡§¶‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§á, &c. We have also ‡§ï‡§æ‡§π‡•áand ‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§Çfrom ‡§ï‡•Éand ‡§¶‡§æ.

The only Potential form left is that of the 3rd pers. sing.; as ‡§π‡§∏‡•á‡§ú‡•ç‡§úor ‡§π‡§∏‡•á‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ, ‡§π‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§úor ‡§π‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ. The termination is the same as in Pali, the‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø of the 3rd pers. sing. being altered to ‡§ú, and the general formof the termination ‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ to ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ. After bases ending in ‡§Ö, ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú or ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æbecomes ‡§è‡§ú‡•ç‡§úor ‡§è‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ, as in skr. and Pali¬π. This being an isolatedform and derived from the Potential, which does not signify anyparticular time, it is used in the sense of the Present, Future, orImperative in all numbers and persons; and after roots in ‡§Ö theterminations ‡§∏‡•Å and ‡§π‡§øof the second pers. sing. of the Imperativeare added to to ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú make up new forms of that mood, as ‡§π‡§∏‡•á‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§∏‡•Å, ‡§π‡§∏‡•á‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§π‡§ø; and another form ‡§π‡§∏‡•á‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•á is also mentioned¬≤. This Potentialform of roots ending in vowels other than is used as a base,and the terminations of the two tenses and one mood are attachedto it to make up now forms for them as ‡§π‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§á, ‡§π‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§á ‡§π‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§â,‡§π‡•ã‡§ú‡§æ‡§â, &c.

___________________________________________________________________________

1. This fact strongly supports my derivation of the forms. Prof. Lassenderives them from the Precative. But the Precative was lost at an earlystage, since it does not exist even in the Pall. The ‡§è is not the ‡§Ö‡§Øof the10th conj, as the Prof. thinks, but the ‡§è, which bases ending in ‡§Ötake inthe Pot. in Skr.

2. Prof. Lassen derives these also from the Precative, and against theargument that that mood is rarely used in Skr. itself and was lost in thePali states that the Precative is found in the Vernaculars. But I have notfound it. The forms ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ú‡•á, ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ú‡•Ä G.‚Äö‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á, ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã H.IItrace to the PrakritPotential forms spoken of above.

The Aorist also has left its 3rd pers. sing. only; the termination to be added to roots ending in a vowel, is ‡§∏‡•Ä, ‡§π‡•Ä, or ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ö and‡§à‡§Ö to those ending in a consonant or ‡§Ö, i. e., such as take theaugment ‡§á or change the ‡§Öto ‡§á. Of these, ‡§∏‡•Äand ‡§π‡•Ä are derivedfrom the Parasm. ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡•çof the fourth form; the first is found inPali, and ‡§π‡•Ä is only another form of it. The Pali has ‡§à also forthe 3rd pers. sing. corresponding to the ‡§à‡§§‡•çaffixed to Sanskritroots that take the augment ‡§á. This is very likely the origin of‡§à‡§Ö also, since we have it after the roots which necessarily admitthe augment; but the ‡§Öof this and of ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Öis difficult to explain.‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ömust correspond to some such form as ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ø or ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§ which, the‡§Æ‡•ç being dropped after the augment ‡§á, is reduced to ‡§à‡§Ö. These‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ø and ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§ are forms of the Potential ƒÄtm. of ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç, and they mayhave been added as terminations to form the Aorist as otherforms of ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•çare in this and other tenses in the Pali. Or the ‡§∏‡•Äof the Aorist may have been confounded with ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§the pot. of ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•çfrom its resemblance to it.

These are rare and isolated forms, and past time is mostlyexpressed by the past participle passive which in the case ofintransitive and some transitive verbs has also an active sense.The Sanskrit termination ‡§§is only phonetically changed to ‡§¶inthe ≈öaurasenƒÄand to ‡§Ö in the Prakrit. Roots ending in ‡§Öchangeit to ‡§á before the past participial termination. The past participlesof some roots are not newly formed, but the old Skr. forms havecome down only phonetically altered. This fact should alwaysbe remembered, that there are in all these derived dialects newformations called by Hemacandra ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•, as well as old formations, ‡§∏‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•. This arises from the fact of the analogies notbeing made applicable throughout, as they would have been ifthe languages had been artificial Contingency or condition isexpressed by the present participle, as we do in our modernvernaculars.

The infinitive is formed as in Skr. by the addition of ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•çchanged to ‡§â‡§Ç, the Pali ‡§§‡§µ‡•ábeing lost, and the absolutive by affixingthe termination ‡§ä‡§£ (‡§¶‡•Ç‡§£ ≈öaurasenƒ´) from the Pali ‡§§‡•Çand theVedic ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®or ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§®. But the termination that is most used in the≈öaurasenƒ´is ‡§á‡§Öfrom the Sanskrit ‡§Ø of roots with prepositionsprefixed. Hemacandra also gives for the principal Prakrit ‡§§‡•Ç‡§£and ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ü‡§£, the origin of which is the same as that of ‡§ä‡§£, ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æfrom‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ, ‡§§‡•Å, by the dissolution of the semi-vowel of ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ, ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç, by a confusion with the infinitive, and ‡§á‡§Öwhich is used in the ≈öaurasenƒ´.Of these, however, ‡§ä‡§£is the one that prevails; the others are rare.

The passive is formed by adding ‡§à‡§Ø and ‡§á‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú,both of whichcome from the Sanskrit with the augment ‡§áprefixed as in Pali, the ‡§Øbeing transformed to ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú in one case and leaving its ‡§Ö onlyin the other or being dissolved into ‡§á‡§Ö. Hemacandra gives agood many roots which preserve the Skr. forms, only phoneticallychanged as ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∏‡§á from ‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á, ‡§µ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§áfrom ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á, ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§á from ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡§áfrom ‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á, ‡§¨‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§áfrom ‡§¨‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á &c.

The causol terminations are ‡§è from ‡§Ö‡§Øand ‡§Ü‡§µ‡•áfrom ‡§Ü‡§™‡§Ø.These two are the same as in the Pali, the Sanskrit forms, alsoexisting in the latter, being lost. Hemacandra adds ‡§Öand ‡§Ü‡§µ,i. e., the ‡§è, answering to ‡§Ö‡§Ø, is lost. But the Sanskrit vowelchanges are preserved even when the ‡§Ö‡§Ø gives place to ‡§Ö; as‡§¶‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§á.

The terminations of the absolutive, the infinitive, the potentialparticiple ( ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ from Skr. ‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø), and of the Future take theaugment ‡§á which also is transformed into a short ‡§èof the samenature as that which is found before conjunct consonants, as in ‡§™‡•á‡§£‡•ç‡§°or ‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°. We have thus ‡§π‡§∏‡§ø‡§ä‡§£ or‡§á‡§∏‡•á‡§ä‡§£, ‡§π‡§∏‡§ø‡§°‡§Ç or ‡§π‡§∏‡•á‡§â‡§Ç&c.

You will thus have observed a much greater progress in theoperation of those principles, which we found at work in theconstruction of the Pali. Here as before we find that the lessknown forms are made up on the model of the more known. Thenumber of old forms which still remained in some of the Palideclensions and conjugations, has been greatly reduced in thePrakrits, and a further advance been made in the introductionof uniformity and simplicity in the grammar of the language.

It is also worthy of remark, that in a great measure, the samefalse analogies which are used in the Pali have come down tothe Prakrit, and their range extended. Thus the analogy ofnouns in ‡§á‡§®‡•ç or neuter nouns in ‡§á or ‡§â has been carried muchfurther in the declension of masculine nouns ending in ‡§á or ‡§â.Nouns in ‡§ã, ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç and ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç have adapted themselves more closely tothe model of those ending in ‡§Ö, their Sanskrit nom. casesupplying the new ‡§Öbase; and the ‡§Ö conjugations have moregenerally prevailed over the rest. The device of using such caseforms as ‡§Æ‡§Æand ‡§Æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç as bases, and making up the cases byappending the proper terminations has also been more largelyavailed of. Some of these phenomena may be attributed to theoperation of the same invariable laws in the development ofeither, without being an index to a more intimate connectionbetween the two dialects. But there are individual forms in thetwo languages which, though they might be different, are yet thesame in both. Such, for instance, are ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á acc. pl., the loc. sing.ending in the pronominal ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§ø or ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø, the double gen. ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø, the2nd pers. pl. ending in ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æof the present tense, and a good manyothers. The consonantal and vowel changes also, so far as theygo in the older language, are the same. We may therefore safelyconclude that the Pali represents generally an earlier stage of thesame language which afterwards became the Prakrit or Prakrits.

But there are again in the Prakrits such forms as those of theablative in ‡§¶‡•ã and ‡§Ü‡§π‡§ø instead of the old pronominal ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ, the firstpers. pl. of the Pres. in ‡§Æ‡•ãor ‡§Æ‡•Å instead of the Pali ‡§Æ, the 1st pers.sing. of the Imperative in ‡§Æ‡•Åinstead of the Pali ‡§Æ‡§ø, the ≈öaurasenƒ´absolutive in ‡§á‡§Öcorresponding to the Sanskrit ‡§Ø, which does notexist in the older dialect, and others. These Prakrit forms cannothave been developed out of the Pali forms, but must have grownindependently from the Sanskrit originals.

In the same way, though the Prakrit sounds are generallythe same as, or further developments, of the Pali sounds, thereare a good many which could not have grown out of the latter.Thus the ‡§∞‡§ø of the Prakrit words ‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø, ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ, ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£, ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡•Å, &c. cannothave been developed out of the ‡§á or ‡§Ö of the Pali ‡§á‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø, ‡§Ö‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ, ‡§Ö‡§£,‡§â‡§ú‡•Ç &c, or the ‡§Ö‡§á and ‡§Ö‡§âof such words as ‡§¶‡§á‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö, ‡§≠‡§á‡§∞‡§µ, ‡§™‡§â‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§â‡§∏‡§≤,

&c., from the ‡§è and ‡§ìof the corresponding Pali words, or the‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡•ç for Sanskrit ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•çfrom the Pali ‡§û‡•ç‡§û‡•ç, though this latter exista insome of the Prakrit dialects, or the ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏for ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂ or ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑ in such wordsas‡§Ü‡§Ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§£ ‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•á, and ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏ from the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ or ‡§∏ of the Pali‡§Ü‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏, ‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§®, ‡§µ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏, and ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∏. The Prakrit sounds must in thesecases be traced directly to the corresponding Sanskrit sounds.

It therefore appears that the Prakrits had also an independentdevelopment, which may be accounted for on the supposition,that they sprang not from the Pali but a sister dialect or dialects;or that, though originally they were the same as the Pali, theirsubsequent development was influenced by the parent language,and thus, other sounds and forms not existing in the earlierdialect, came in fresh from Sanskrit. But the first supposition isdiscountenanced by the fact that the resemblance between thePali and the Prakrits extends even to isolated cases; and thesecond is supported by the circumstance that in one importantparticular, the Prakrits resemble the Sanskrit in the last stage ofits development, while the Pali differs in that particular fromboth and agrees with an earlier form of the parent language.We have seen that in later Sanskrit verbal forms, especially ofthe past tenses were rarely used, and participles were employedinstead; and we find that the Prakrits have mostly lost all theSanskrit tenses and moods except three, and past time is generallyexpressed by the past participle and contingency by the present;while the Pali has, as we have seen, preserved eight, includingall the past tenses and the conditional. Middle Sanskrit bearsto later or Classical Sanskrit the same relation, in this respect,that the Pali bears to the Prakrits. The change that came overSanskrit between the two periods left its impress on what maybe called the Vernacular speech. This could not have been thecase, unless Sanskrit had continued to influence that form ofspeech, represented first by the Pali and afterwards by thePrakrits. And it was because it continued so to influence it,that the Prakrits came to have sounds and grammatical formsalso derived direct from Sanskrit and not through the Pali. Thisleads to the conclusion, which will be developed in detail in thelast lecture, that when the Pali and the Prakrits came into existence, Sanskrit had not been dead but was as much a living

language as either of the other two, and both were spoken orused for ordinary purposes, one by men of culture and the otherby ordinary people.

Sanskrit writers distinguish three elements in the Prakritvocabulary which they call Tadbhava, Tatsama, and De≈õya.Such words as are derived from Sanskrit are called Tadbhavasuch as‡§¶‡§∏‡§£, ‡§´‡§∏, ‡§Æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó, ‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§£, &c. Tatsamas are those that arethe same in Sanskrit and Prakrit as ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤, ‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤, &c., the phoneticlaws of the Prakrits not necessitating a change in them, andDe≈õyas are such as cannot be derived from Sanskrit and mustbe referred to another source. A good many words of this naturewe find used in Prakrit literature; and there exists a ko≈õa orthesaurus of De≈õya words by Hemacandra. A large number ofthese De≈õya words exist in the modern vernaculars, such as:‚Äî

** ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ** a sister, M., ‡§Ü‡§ï‡§æ131,a term of honour used for an elder sister.

** ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ò‡§æ‡§°‡•ã**an herb; M. ‡§Ü‡§ò‡§æ‡§°‡§æ..

‡§Ö‡§µ‡§°‡•ã awell; M. ‡§Ü‡§°.

‡§â‡§°‡§ø‡§¶a kind of pulse; M. H. the same.

‡§â‡§ô‡•ç‡§ò‡§ásleeps; H. ‡§â‡§Ç‡§ò‡§®‡§æ G. ‡§â‡§Ç‡§ò‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç.

‡§ï‡•Å‡§°‡§Ç, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§º‡§°‡•ç‡§°‡§Ç, ‡§ï‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§°‡§Ç, wonder; M. ‡§ï‡•ã‡§° old.

‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç a town M, ‡§ï‡•ã‡§ü a fort.

‡§ï‡•ã‡§°‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•ã a basin of wood for water; M. ‡§ï‡•ã‡§†‡§Ç‡§¨‡§æ.

‡§ï‡•ã‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§ a firebrand; M. ‡§ï‡•ã‡§≤‡§ø‡§§.

‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ö‡§Ç to mix a liquid with a solid substance and stir it up;M. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•á.

‡§ó‡•ã‡§π‡•ã a man, a warrior; M. ‡§ò‡•ã‡§µ husband.

‡§ö‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§°‡§á a man, a warrior; M. ‡§ò‡•ã‡§µ husband.

‡§ö‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§°‡§á rubs, anoints; M. ‡§ö‡•ã‡§™‡§°‡§£‡•á‡§Ç.

‡§õ‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡•ã

‡§õ‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡•Ä an adulterer or adulteress; M. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§¶‡§≤.

‡§õ‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã

** ‡§õ‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä**

‡§™‡•ã‡§Ü‡§≤‡•ã an ox; M. ‡§™‡•ã‡§≤.

‡§™‡§°‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Äa cow that has no milk; M. ‡§™‡§æ‡§â‡§∂‡•Ä.

‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§Ç slanting; M. ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§≤‡•á‡§Çlying down with the face upwards.

‡§™‡•ã‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§Ç belly; M. ‡§™‡•ã‡§ü, H.G. ‡§™‡•á‡§ü.

‡§´‡§∏‡§ádeceives; M. ‡§´‡§∏‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡•á‡§Ç.

‡§´‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§æfalse, vain; M. ‡§´‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ.

‡§¨‡§æ‡§â‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•Äadoll; M. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§â‡§≤‡•Ä.

‡§¨‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡•ã father, a brave man: M. H. G. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§™, M. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æan able-bodied man.

There are a great many words set down as De≈õyas, which onclose examination will be found to be Tadbhavas. They differfrom ordinary Tadbhavas in having undergone great corruption.The following are instances. Some of the words in the above list.may also be considered to be of the same nature. Thus ‡§´‡§Ç‡§∏‡§á‘deceives’ is a denominative or nominal verb from the word ‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‘asnare’;which in our modern dialects has the form of ‡§´‡•ã‡§∏; whence‡§´‡§Ç‡§∏‡§à is ’to ensnare’ or ’entrap.’ So also ‡§ï‡•Å‡§°‡§Ç, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§°‡•ç‡§°‡§Ç, ‡§ï‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§°‡•Å‡§Ç, and the old M.‡§ï‡•ã‡§á are in all likelihood to be traced to the Skr. ‡§ï‡•å‡§§‡•Å‡§ï.

‡§â‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨‡§°‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§ìthrown upwards; Skr. ‡§â‡§á‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§≤.

‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§†‡•ç‡§† alotus; from Skr. ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§•.

‡§ï‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§°‡•ã humpbacked. This may be traced to Skr. **‡§ï‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§ú-‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠-‡§ï‡•Å‡§π;**and ‡§ô is a termination which is used in a great many nouns.

‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö disliked, evidently from Skr. ‡§ï‡•Å and ‡§∞‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø.

‡§ï‡•ã‡§£‡•Ä black; Skr, ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£-‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§°-‡§ï‡•ã‡§£‡•ç‡§π-‡§ï‡•ã‡§£,

‡§â‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§πdesolate; from Skr. ‡§â‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤ bright, pure, cleared of everything, desolate.

‡§¨‡§á‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤ a bullock; from Skr. ‡§¨‡§≤‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶.

‡§õ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ä rind, bark; may be from Skr. ‡§∂‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§∂‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï.

‡§õ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä whey may be from Skr. ‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞.

‡§õ‡§ø‡§µ‡§átouches; from ‡§õ‡•Å‡§™‡•çby a change of vowel.

‡§õ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§™ a tail; from Skr. ‡§™‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ by the consonants interchangingplaces, and the palatal ‡§õ having its vowel ‡§á.

‡§™‡§°‡•ã‡§π‡§∞ the hind part of a house; from Skr. ‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ó‡•É‡§π.

‡§™‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç, ‡§™‡•á‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤,a measure, a certain quantity, occurs in the Pali andis traced to Skr. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø. It may also be connected with ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø.

‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§á speaks; from Skr. ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç by the change of ‡§∞‡•ç to ‡§≤‡•ç and thetransference of the vowel to the first consonant‚Äîathing oftenobservable; ‡§¨‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ç-‡§¨‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤-‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤.

The Sanskrit etymology of some of the words given by thelexicographers is evident; and one does not know how they cameto be regarded as De≈õyas. Other words changed their sense inthe course of time and so were referred to this class.

‡§™‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Å‡§∏‡§á forgets; from Skr. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∑to steal,‚Äîa thing forgotten is asit were stolen.

‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•ã a wicked person:from Skr. ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ, because a wickedperson puts on many faces or appearances.

‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•ã‡§∞‡•ã an ass; ‚Äî a son of KƒÅma or love, devoted to pleasure,is often a donkey.

‡§ï‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§Æ‡§àpregnant; Skr. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø originally ‘side’, came to signify’womb,’ and that womb is worthy of the name which bears achild, hence ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§Æ‡§§‡•Älit‘having a womb’ came to have the signification given.

A good many of the words given by Hemacandra do not occurin the modern Vernaculars, and we have regular Tadbhavas instead; as., ‡§á‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•Äa tiger, ‡§à‡§∏‡•Åa nail, &c.

The number of De≈õya words, if properly examined, would begreatly reduced. Still a De≈õƒ´element in the Prakrits and theVernaculars must be admitted. These words must have comeinto the dialects from the language of the aborigines whom theƒÄryas conquered; and some are found in Sanskrit also.

THE APABHRA·πÄ≈öA

The dialect called the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa by the grammarians presents Indian speech in a further stage of decay, and occupies &middle position between the Prakrit and the modern vernaculars,to some of which, especially to the old Hindi, the Brajabh√§s√§, andthe Gujarati, it bears striking resemblances, as I shall hereaftershow.

As mentioned before, we have the grammar of this dialect fromHemacandra, Trivikrama, and Kramadƒ´≈õvara; but Vararuci doesnot mention it. The Apabhra·πÅ≈õa had a literature of its own.Hemacandra illustrates each of his rules about this dialect byquoting a verse. In the fourth Act of the Vikramorva≈õƒ´the Prakritspeeches of the king in his madness are in this dialect. But it isa question whether they existed there originally, since in several

manuscripts on this side of India they do not appear. The metresemployed in these and in Hemacandra’s quotations are the sameas those popularly used in old and modern Hindi or Braj via, dahƒÅor copai. Pandit Vrajalal mentions a work of the name of Mu√±jarƒÅsa, written in the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa, from which he gives a shortextract, and another the hero of which is a king of the name ofPrasenajita. He also quotes from another work; but the languageof all those appears to be more modern than Hemacandra’s Apabhra·πÅ≈õa, and that of some of the verses makes a very near approachto the Gujarati. As before, I will introduce my remarks on thisdialect by a specimen.‚Äî

APABHRA·πÄ≈öA

‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§π‡•á ‡§§‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø ‡§ò‡§∞‡§ø ‡§≤‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§≤ ‡§ß‡§æ‡§á‡•§
‡§™‡§ø‡§Ö ‡§™‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§µ‡§ó‡•ã‡§∞‡§°‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§≤‡§ï‡§π‡§ø‡§Å‡§µ‡§ø ‡§® ‡§†‡§æ‡§á‡••

‡§ú‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Å ‡§¶‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ö‡§π‡§°‡§æ ‡§¶‡§á‡§è‡§Ç ‡§™‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§£‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§£ ‡§ó‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§è ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§â ‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ü‡§â ‡§®‡§π‡•á‡§£‡••

‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§â ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§® ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§π‡§â‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§£‡•Å ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•Å ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§® ‡§á‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•Å‡•§
‡§¶‡•ã‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∏‡§∞‡§ø ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§°‡§ø‡§Ö‡§á‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø‡§£‡§∏‡§Æ ‡§ó‡§£‡§á ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§π‡•Å‡••

‡§ú‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£ ‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§á‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡§æ ‡§™‡§Ø‡§°‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§π ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡•§
‡§§‡§Æ‡•Å ‡§π‡§â‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§ú‡•Å‡§ó‡§ø ‡§¶‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§π‡§π‡•ã‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø ‡§ï‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§â‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Ö‡§£‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡••

‡§ó‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•á‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§£ ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ö‡§ì ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§∏‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§• ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•á‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡•§
‡§ï‡•Ä‡§≤‡§¶‡§ø ‡§§‡§ø‡§¶‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ó‡§â ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§â ‡§ú‡§ø‡§£‡•á‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡••

The Sanskrit of this would be:‚Äî

‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•á ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡§ø‡•§
‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•á‡§¨ ‡§ó‡•å‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡§ø ‡§® ‡§§‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§§‡§ø‡••

‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§¨‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡•§
‡§§‡•á‡§∑‡§æ‡§Ç ( ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡•ç) ‡§ó‡§£‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ú‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§®‡§ñ‡•á‡§®‡••

‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§® ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ç‡§ß‡§®‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§® ‡§á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡•§
‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§∏‡§∞‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•É‡§£‡§∏‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ó‡§£‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§É‡••

‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§
‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡•á ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§¨‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§∏‡•É‡§ú‡§®‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡••

‡§ó‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ø‡§É ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§• ‡§ó‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡•§
‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§°‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡§∂‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ó‡§§‡§É ‡§∏ ‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡••

“The unsteady goddess of wealth runs to this door and that,this house and that; like a fair one separated from her lover shedoes not remain firm anywhere.”

“My fingers have worn away, rubbed against by my nailswhile counting, again and again, the days named by my lover[as the period of his absence], when he set out on his journey.”

“To whom is life not dear and to whom is wealth not an objectof desire? But when the occasion comes, a worthy man regardsthem as straw.”

“I worship that good man, so rarely to be met with in thisKali age, who conceals his own merits and gives publicity to thoseof others.

“He who dies after having gone to the Ga·πÖgƒÅand to ≈öivatƒ´rtha, triumphs over the power (world) of death and sports in thehabitation of the gods.”

THE PHONOLOGY OF THE APABHRA·πÄ≈öA

The vowel of the derivatives of the pronouns ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç, ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç,and ‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç is changed to ‡§á or ‡§è. In the principal Prikrit we havenoticed a tendency to such a change, and one of our instanceswas ‡§è‡§§‡•ç‡§•for ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞. From the same tendency we have in the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa ‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Åfor ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§§‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡•Åfor ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, and ‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡•Åfor ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, the ‡§â of the latterbeing replaced by ‡§èin virtue of the analogy of the other pronouns.In the same way ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç “in that manner,” which aftor dropping thefinal consonant becomes ‡§§‡§ô‡•ç, is changed to ‡§§‡•á‡§Æ, ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç to ‡§ú‡•á‡§Æ, and‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç to ‡§ï‡•á‡§Æ. This ‡§è is also rendered a more close vowel andchanged to ‡§á, and thus we have ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§Æ, and ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ. Thus the basesof these pronouns came to be considered as ‡§§‡•á or ‡§§‡§ø, ‡§ú‡•á or ‡§ú‡§ø, and‡§ï‡•á, or ‡§ï‡§ø, and so we have ‡§§‡§ø‡§ßfor ‡§§‡§•‡§æ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ßfor ‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ and ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ß for ‡§ï‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç.The mute element being dropped, these forms become ‡§§‡§ø‡§π, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§π, and ‡§ï‡§ø‡§π, and further ‡§§‡•á‡§π‡•Å, ‡§ú‡•á‡§π‡•Åand ‡§ï‡•á‡§π‡•Å. For similar reasons wehave ‡§§‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ú or ‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ö for ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§ï, ‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ö‡§Ç or ‡§ú‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ö for ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§ï, ‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ö or‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Öfor ‡§ï‡§ø‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§ï, &c. even in the Prakrits.

The nom. sing. termination of nouns ‡§Ö in is shortened to ‡§â,and since a great many nouns were pronounced with this final ‡§âand its original sense was forgotten, it was transferred by way ofanalogy to other words or grammatical forms that did not possess

it before and thus we have ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•Å and ‡§¨‡§ø‡§£‡•Å for ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É and ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§æ and ‡§ú‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å,‡§§‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡•Å, ‡§ú‡•á‡§π‡•Å, &c., in the above.

The long vowels are sometimes shortened as in the word ‡§ó‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æin the last of the above verses.

The consonants ‡§ï‡•ç and ‡§ñ‡•ç are sometimes softened to ‡§ó‡•ç and ‡§ò‡•çinstead of being dropped, ‡§§‡•ç and ‡§•‡•ç to ‡§¶‡•ç and ‡§ß‡•ç, as in Sauraseni,and ‡§™‡•ç and ‡§´‡•ç, to ‡§π‡•ç and ‡§≠. In the principal Prakrit also this issometimes the case. The labial ‡§¨‡•ç is changed to ‡§Æ‡•ç in a few moreinstances than in the Prakrits as in ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ and ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ for ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç and‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç, and ‡§ú‡•á‡§Æ or ‡§ú‡§ø‡§Æ, ‡§§‡•á‡§Æ or ‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ, &o. in the above for ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç, ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç &e.The complete contact of the lips necessary for the pronunciationof ‡§Æ‡•ç is avoided in a great many cases, and thus we have ‡§û‡•ç for ‡§Æ‡•ças in ‡§≠‡§µ‡§Å‡§∞‡•Å for ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∞, ‡§ï‡§µ‡§Å‡§≤‡•Å for ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤, &o This is the prevailing rulein most of the vernaculars, as we shall hereafter find. The conjunct ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•çis changed to ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•ç, that is, the aspirate ‡§π‡•çhas been labialized and assimilated to the preceding ‡§Æ‡•ç, as in f for Prakrit ‡§ó‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§πand Sanskrit ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ. A few instances of this change we didfind in the Prakrits and we shall find more in the vernaculars.

The Sanskrit conjunct ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç is changed to ‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡•ç; for as ‡§§‡•ç was oftenpronounced as ‡§ó‡•ç, this ‡§ó‡•ç instead of merging into the precedingmute, as semi-vowels often do, acquired prominence as ‡§§‡•ç does,when preceded by a dental; and the being assimilated to it,the whole become ‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡•ç as ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•çbecomes ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö, as in ‡§™‡§áfor ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§£ or ‡§™‡§£for the abstract termination ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§®, and ‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§£ for ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç, the suffix ofthe absolutive. In the Prakrits the ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æof ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•çsimilarly becomes‡§™‡•ç‡§™ and so we have ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§æ for ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ.The letter ‡§∞‡•ç, when the lattermember of a conjunct, is sometimes not assimilated, as in ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø,‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§â for ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§É, &c., and sometimes it is introduced even when itdoes not exist in the original, as in ‡§ß‡•Å‡§Çfor ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ for ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏, &c.With these few exceptions, the rules about the assimilation ofconjuncts, the elision of consonants, and others hold good.generally as in the Prakrits, as you will see from the above extract.

DECLENSION IN THE APABHRA·πÄ≈öA

Nouns in ‡§Ö

The decay of the case terminations is, however, a distinguishing feature of thisdialect. The distinction between the nom.and

acc. case forms which we observed lessening at each stage in thegrowth of our languages is here altogether lost. The ‡§ìof thenom. sing. of masculinenouns in ‡§Öis shortened to ‡§â, and used inboth the cases, as ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ö‡§ânom. for ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡§É, ‡§ó‡§° for ‡§ó‡§§‡§É ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§° for‡§è‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç; and applied to neuter nouns as well, as ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡•Å. The nasalof the neuter is preserved only in nouns which are augmented bythe addition of ‡§ï changed to ‡§Ö, as‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§â‡§Çfor ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç. The nom.and acc. pl. of the masculine ends in ‡§Ü; as ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ö‡§π‡§°‡§æ, ‡§™‡§Ø‡§°‡§æ &c. inthe above. The neuter nouns preserve the Prakrits ‡§á‡§Ç of the pluralas in ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤‡§á‡§Ç. Sometimes words are used in these two caseswithout any terminations; as ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§≤nom. sing., ‡§®‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§≤nom. sing.,‡§ó‡•Å‡§£ acc. pl., ‡§ó‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó acc. sing., ‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§•acc. sing., in the above extract.

The principle observable in the other cases is the same as wehave noticed in the older dialects, viz., a gradual reduction of allthe declensions to a uniformity. The instrumental singular ofnouns in ‡§Öhas two forms, one in ‡§è‡§Ç as ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç, and the other the oldone ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§£. The former is derived from this old form, the final ‡§Öbeing dropped, and the nasal assuming the form of an anusvƒÅra.This new termination is transferred to nouns in ‡§á or ‡§â also, as‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§è‡§Ç. The instrumental pl. is the old one in ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç, but the changeof the ending vowel to ‡§èis only optionally made; as ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Çor‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç.

One ablative termination is ‡§π‡•áwhich is appended to all nouns,and the other ‡§π‡•Å asin ‡§¨‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§π‡•á‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§π‡§à‡§´‡§≤‡§à or ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§π‡•Å ‡§ó‡•É‡§£‡•ç‡§π‡§á, ‚Äúgathersfruits from trees.”

Of course we may trace the first to ‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ãby supposing it firstto be changed to ‡§π‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã by the usual Prakrit rule, and afterwards tohave dropped its second syllable; and to something else. Butit appears to me that a good many of the terminations havingbeen reduced to ‡§π‡•çby natural phonetic changes, the others alsohad this inserted in them by analogy, just as the nominativetermination ‡§âis introduced in words and forms in which it did. not exist. This process we shall necessarily have to suppose whenwe examine the forms of the present tense. Or the ‡§π‡•ç may havebeen introduced simply to prevent a histus and connect thevowel-termination with the base. And this is rendered probableby Hemacandra’s rule, that the ending syllables ‡§â‡§Ç, ‡§π‡§Ç, ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç, and ‡§π‡§Ç,are to be lightly pronounced, as the ‡§è that is introduced in the

place of a dropped consonant is. The real syllables in these casesare therefore **‡§Ö‡§Ç, ‡§â‡§Ç, ‡§á‡§Ç,**and ‡§Ö‡§Ç; and this is confirmed by the factthat the remnants of these Apabhra·πÅ≈õa terminations existing insome of the modern vernaculars are destitute of this ‡§π‡•ç and aremere vowel-terminations, as will be seen in a subsequent lecture. Thus, then, ‡§π‡•á may be considered as the aspirated form of the ‡§è ofthe Prakrit feminine ablative, and ‡§π‡•Å of the ‡§â of the masculine ablative¬π. The operation of the law of false analogies is very wide.The abl. pl. ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç, as in ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç, may with Lassen be traced to ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã, the ‡§Æ‡•ç being changed to ‡§π‡•ç and the syllable ‡§§‡•ã dropped, as ‡§§‡§øis in the case of the 3rd pers. pl. of the present, as we shall see.

The genitive singular ‡§∏‡•Å and ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å as in ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Ö‡§£‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å and ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å inverse 4 above, I trace to the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ of the Prakrits, the ‡§â addedby analogy as observed before. Lassen traces is to ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ, which, hesays, must have been added to these nouns to form the genitive;and the being softened to ‡§â, it is reduced to ‡§∏‡•Å. But this doesnot account for the double ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏of the other form; and the additionof such a word as ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ to make up a case-form is altogether unexampled. The suffix ‡§π‡•ã, as in ‡§¶‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§π‡§π‡•ãin the same verse, is butanother form of ‡§∏‡•Å.The genitive plural ‡§π‡§Ç, as in ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•Å‡§∏‡§π‡§Ç for‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç, may with Lassen be derived from the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•çof theSanskrit pronominal declension. But the transference of thistermination to nouns is nowhere seen in the Prakrits; ‡§π‡§Ç isoptionally appended to nouns in or also; and the characteristic ‡§£‡§Çof the gen. is wanting in this dialect. The more probableexplanation, therefore, is that the ‡§£ lost its cerebral element andwas reduced merely to a nasal ‡§Ö, or ‡§Ö with an anusvƒÅra, as isthe case in the instrumental singular, and the ‡§π‡•ç is added, asobserved before, simply to facilitate the pronunciation.

The loc. sing. ends in ‡§è, as in ‡§§‡§≤‡•á, which we see is the oldtermination, or in ‡§á, as in ‡§§‡§≤‡§ø, which is a shortened form of ‡§è.Kramadƒ´≈õvara gives also ‡§π‡§ø‡§Çwhich might be traced to the Pali ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§ø,the Sanskrit ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç, or the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§Çof the Prakrit pronominal declension.The language of Jaina works has this ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§Çin the case of nounsalso. But even here the Prakrit ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø, may, withreason, besupposed to have changed to ‡§á‡§Ç, and the ‡§π‡•çto be, as before, a merespiritus lenis. We have this locative ‡§á‡§Ç in the Marathi. The ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç isextended to the plural also of these nouns. The vocative is formedby using which is evidently an interjection; as ‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§£ ‡§π‡•ã“O young men.”

____________________________________________________________________________________________

1**.** Kramadƒ´≈õvarain Lassan’s extract gives ‡§¶‡•Çinstead of ‡§π‡•Å;but this is anevident misreading.

Nouns in ‡§á or ‡§â

There is no distinction between the nom. and acc. sing. andpl., the original base being used without any modification oraddition.

The instrumental singular is formed by adding ‡§è‡§Ç or ‡§£, as inthe last class of nouns, or simple anusvƒÅra; as ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§è‡§Ç, ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§£, ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§Ç,As ‡§è‡§£ becomes ‡§è‡§Çby dropping the final vowel, so does the ‡§á‡§£‡§æ ofthe Prakrit instrumental here become ‡§á‡§Ç.

The abl. sing. ends in ‡§π‡•á as in ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡•á and ‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡•á; and the gen.sing. also according to Kramadƒ´≈õvara, Hemacandra being silent.These have been transferred from the feminine. Kramadƒ´≈õvaraalso gives ‡§π‡•ã and ‡§π‡§Ç as the terminations of the sing. of these two.cases; but there must be some misreading here in Lassen’sextract from the author, since is a distinctive plural termination. The gen. pl. termination is ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç or ‡§π‡§Ç as in ‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç, ‡§∏‡§â‡§£‡§ø‡§π‡§Ç (‡§∂‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ).The latter has been traced to the old gen.‡§£, and the formerappears to be only another form of it, with the addition of theusual ‡§â.

The loc. sing. has ‡§π‡§ø, as in ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§π‡§ø; and the pl. has ‡§π‡§ø‡§Çand ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç, as in ‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡§ø‡§Çand ‡§â‡§¶‡•Å‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç,.The first must be considered to be the same as fe derivedfrom ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§Çor ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§øwith the anusvƒÅra dropped; or as the ‡§á of Prakritfeminine nouns with the spiritus lenis ‡§π‡•ç. This explanation seemsto be probable, since we have seen other feminine terminationsalso used for the cases of these nouns. The third is to be tracedto the Prakrit ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ç. Kramadƒ´≈õvara in Lassen’s extract gives ‡§π‡§Ç forthe ‡§π‡•Å‡§Çof the abl. pl.‡§π‡•á, and for that of the gen. pl.; but I have tomake the same remark here as before. The instr, and abl. pluralsare the same as those of nouns in ‡§Ö; as ‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡§ø‡§Çand ‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç. Thus theplural of three cases ends in ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç , derived separately of course, andthe plurals of two in ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç.

Feminine nouns

The plurals of the nom. and acc. of feminine nouns preservethe old ‡§ì, or its shortened form ‡§â, as in ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§â ‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ü‡§â in the

second verse, and ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§ñ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§ì ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä‡§ì. The sing. is theoriginal base, as ‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ü, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä &c.

The instr. sing. termination is ‡§è, the old one, as in ‡§∏‡§∏‡§ø‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§≤‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§Æ‡§è, ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§è&o,: the abl is ‡§π‡•á as in ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§π‡•á for ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É,which is an aspirated ‡§è; and the genitive ‡§π‡•á as in ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§°‡§π‡•áfor ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§ò‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§É (‡§°being a nominal suffix) may be similarlyexplained or traced to the of the gen. sing. fem. of thepronouns, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç,and ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç, in the Prakrit. I prefer the formerexplanation. This ‡§π‡•á has been transferred to masculine nouns in‡§á or ‡§â as we have seen. The abl. and gen. pl. ends in ‡§π‡•Å, as in‡§ö‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ö‡§π‡•Å for ‡§µ‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§É or ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç, The anusvƒÅra of the ‡§π‡•Å of theother classes of nouns is here omitted and if correctly so, the ‡§π‡•Åof the abl. may be considered an aspirated form of the ‡§âwhichis the ablative termination in the Prakrit: and that of thegenitive may be traced to the ‡§∏‡•Å of the singular of masculinenouns. The instr. pl. and the loc. sing. and pl. take the sameterminations as masculine nouns in ‡§á or ‡§â;as ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø, ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§π‡§ø, and‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç. Lassen gives other terminations; but he appears to menot to have interpreted Kramadƒ´≈õvara correctly. Those I havegiven are all that I have been able to find.

You will thus see how by the various influences at work, thenatural transformation of ‡§∏‡•çto ‡§π‡•ç, the elision of some of theelements, and the aspirated pronunciation of the vowels, most ofthe old terminations have been reduced to syllables composed of ‡§π‡•çand a vowel with or without an anusvƒÅra. Terminations withsuch weak sounds are not adapted to serve the purposes ofordinary intercourse, since they require on the part of thespeakers such care in pronunciation to render themselves intelligible to each other as we have not seen displayed in the courseof our lingual history. The nominative and accusative throughout, and in certain classes of nouns, the other cases also havecome to have the same forms. So that the purpose of expressingthe different relations can be no longer performed by these poorremnants of the old declensional system; and a process of reconstruction must take place. It has already begun in the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa; but we shall find it carried on much further in thevernaculars, which may now be said to have completed theirnew declensional system.

The abl. sing. of pronouns ends in ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç, as ‡§ú‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç, &o., which is tobe traced to the Sanskrit ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•çand the Prakrit ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ, and the loc.sing. in ‡§π‡§ø‡§Çwhich has been explained. The gen. sing. of **‡§Ø‡§¶‡•ç, ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç,**and ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç sre optionally ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å, ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å, and ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å, made up by adding theususl ‡§â to ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∏, ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏, and ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏, which again are other forms of ‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏,‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏, and ‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏, with one of the consonants dropped and thepreceding vowel lengthened as a compensation, a phenomenonto he noticed in going over the vernaculars. In the feminine,these pronouns have ‡§ú‡§π‡•á, ‡§§‡§π‡•á,and ‡§ï‡§π‡•á optionally for the gen. sing.,which are derived from the Prakrit ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡•á, ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•á and ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•á and thePali ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø, ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø, and ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø. The base, however, in theApabhra·πÅ≈õa ends in ‡§Öand not ‡§à, or, the more probable explanation is, that this ‡§π‡•á is the aspirated form of the ‡§èof feminine nours.

‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç has ‡§Ü‡§Ø for its base; the instr. and gen. singulars, forinstance, are ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•á‡§£ and ‡§Ü‡§™‡§π‡•ã. This seems to be taken from thenom. sing. ‡§Ö‡§Ö, or ‡§Ö‡§Øby the rule of the substitution of ‡§Ø for ‡§Ö‡§Ç.The neuter nom. and acc. sing, is ‡§á‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ç.

‡§è‡§π‡•ã er is nom. and acc. sing. masc. of ‡§è‡§§‡§¶‡•ç corresponding to ‡§è‡§∏‡•ã,‡§è‡§π fem. to ‡§è‡§∏‡§æ, and by the application of ‡§âto these we have theneuter ‡§è‡§π‡•Å.‡§è‡§áis the nom. and acc. pl. answering to ‡§è‡§èPrakrit,with the latter ‡§è shortened; and ‡§ì‡§á of ‡§Ö‡§¶‡§∏ which corresponds tothe form ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•á, the ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•Å being changed to ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•Å‡§Çby a rule beforementioned, and afterwards to ‡§ì; and ‡§ï‡•á to ‡§è, shortened to ‡§á. Inother respects all these pronouns are declined like the corresponding nouns.

The pronouns of the 1st and 2nd persons are thus declined :‚Äî
1st pers. 2nd pers.
sing. pl. sing. pl.
Nom. ‡§á‡§â‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§π‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§π‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á-‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§á‡§Ç
Acc. ‡§Æ‡§π‡§Ç ‚Äî‚Äî ‡§§‡§á‡§Ç ‚Äî‚Äî
Instr.‚Äî ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§á‡§Ç, ‡§§‡§á‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç
Abl. ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Å-‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§π‡§Ç ‡§§‡§â, ‡§§‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù, ‡§§‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§π‡§Ç
Gen.‚Äî‚Äî ‚Äî ‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî ‚Äî
Loc. ‡§Æ‡§á‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å ‡§™‡§á‡§Ç, ‡§§‡§á‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡•Å

Here we have not the wilderness of forms which we observedin the principal Prakrit. The nom. sing. of the 1st per. is ‡§á‡§â‡§Ç

corresponding to ‡§Ö‡§π‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç, the initial ‡§Ö and the ‡§ï‡•ç being elided andthe usual Apabhra·πÅ≈õa ‡§âadded. In the Prakrits ‡§Ö‡§π‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç, is represented by ‡§Ö‡§á‡§Ö‡§Ç or ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ø‡§Ç, ‡§Æ‡§á‡§Ç is to be traced to the Sanskrit instr.‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ and the ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ø, both of which are reduced to the form of ‡§Æ‡§áin the Prakrit. Here it is extended to the acc. also. The pl. base is‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π, which has been explained. The nom. pl. ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§á‡§Çcorresponds tosuch a form as ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ánom. pl., not loc. as Lassen says, through.‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§è; and the gen. pl. has the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa termination ‡§π‡§Ç. Therest are old. ‡§§‡•Å‡§π is a base derived, as I said in going over thePrakrits, from ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ø‡•ç‡§π‡§Çand is used in the Prakrit also, ‡§™‡§á‡§Çand ‡§§‡§á‡§Ç ofthe acc. instr. and loc. are from ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æand ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§ø.The second isfound in the older dialects, the first is peculiar to this. Of thecorruption of ‡§§‡•ç‡§µto ‡§™‡•ç‡§™have already spoken.

The abl. and gen.‡§§‡§âcorresponds to a form ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§ïwhich withthe Apabhra·πÅ≈õic ‡§â is ‡§§‡§â, the ‡§ï being dropped. Or it may betraced to ‡§§‡§µ with the ‡§µ dissolved into ‡§â. ‡§§‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù is a form found inthe Prakrits also and explained by me as a corruption of the dat.‡§§‡•Å‡§Ø‡•ç‡§π‡§Ç in the Pali and Prakrits, derived from the Skr. ‡§§‡•Å‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç.Thedative forms, you will remember, are put under the gen in theolder dislects. The ‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞of ‡§§‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞is a peculiar Apabhramsic conjunct,formed from ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡•ç. The neuter of ‡§§‡§¶‡•çis similarly ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç and ‡§ß‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç. Thebase of the plural is ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π, the same as in the Prakrit; and the nom.pl. ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§á‡§Çis to be traced to ‡§§‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•áfor ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•á nom. pl. All the formsare similar to those of the first personal pronoun.

THE VERB IN THE APABHRA·πÄSA

The Present tense of the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa verb admits, besidesthose of the corresponding Prakrit or ≈öaurasenƒ´ tense, thefollowing forms :‚Äî 1st pers. sing. ‡§≤‡§π‡§â‡§Ç, pl. ‡§≤‡§π‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç; 2nd pers. sing.‡§≤‡§π‡§π‡§ø, pl. ‡§≤‡§π‡§π‡•Å; 3rd pers. sing. ‡§≤‡§π‡§á, pl. ‡§≤‡§π‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç.

It appears that some of these forms have arisen from & confusion of the Present Indicative with the Imperative. The prevailing and distinguishing final of the latter is the vowel ‡§â; and here
we see it is appended to the forms of the 1st pers. sing. and 2ndpers. pl., though it does not occur in those forms in any of theolder dialects.

The ‡§π‡•ç is another characteristio of these paradigms. That ofthe second pers. sing. we get from the old ‡§∏‡§ø, and that of the pl.

exists in the Prakrit, being derived from the Skr. ‡§•. But thethird pers. pl. and the 1st pers. pl. get it simply by an extensionof the analogy or It may have been introduced to prevent ahiatus and thus may, like those of the cases, have been simplya spiritus lenis. The ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç of the latter, however, may be traced to‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•ã, ‡§ìbeing shortened to ‡§â, just as ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æand ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§øof the declensionsbecome ‡§π‡§æ‡§Çand ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç.Instead of the 3rd pers. pl. ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§øwe have ‡§π‡§ø‡§Çinwhich, though the ‡§πis due to analogy, the characteristic ‡§á andthe nasal are preserved.

You will thus see that in the declensions as well as conjugations the prevails ‡§π‡•çin this dialect. The Imperative second pers.sing. ends in , ‡§á, ‡§è or ‡§â. The first two may be traced to the Prakritand Sankrit ‡§π‡§ø, ‡§π‡•ç being dropped as in the Vernaculars; and thelast seems to be substituted for the ‡§Ö of one of the forms in theoriginal dialects by analogy; or it may be the remnant of ‡§Æ‡•Å,changed first to ‡§π‡•Å, and then to ‡§â. But a better and, I may say, the trueexplanation of these forms will be given in going over theVernaculars.

Hemacandra does not give any more forms for the Imperative,but Kramadƒ´≈õvara gives ‡§ä for the second person plural whichmust very likely be ‡§π‡•Å, the same as in the Present, and ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç for thefirst pers. pl. which we have in the Present also. In one of theverses quoted by Hemacandra occurs ‡§™‡§ø‡§Ö‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç which seems to correspond to ‡§™‡§ø‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å, if the reading is correct. The truth seems tobe that the forms of the Imperative were lost, and the sense confounded with that of the Present, but the distinctive forms werethose of the second pers. sing., and in this respect there is ananalogy with Hindi and Gujarati which resemble the Apabhra·πÅ≈õathe most.

The Future has the Prakrit and ≈öaurasenƒ´forms in ‡§π‡§ø and ‡§á‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏;but one ‡§Æ‡•ç of this latter is dropped, and then the terminations ofthe Apabhra·πÅ≈õa Present are added.

The terminations of the absolutive are ‡§á. ‡§á‡§â, ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø, ‡§á‡§µ‡§ø, ‡§è‡§µ‡§ø,‡§è‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡•Å,‡§è‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§ø, ‡§è‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•Å, ‡§á. is the same as the ≈öaurasenƒ´ ‡§á‡§û‡•ç from the Skr.‡§Ø, ‡§á‡§âis the same, with the usual ‡§â added to it, or is to be tracedto the ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç or ‡§á‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç which is, as we have seen, confounded in thePrakrit with the absolutive, and the rest are various forms of the

Vedic ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§® with the Prakrit augment ‡§á or ‡§è,This ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§®is, by arule before mentioned, changed to ‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§£, which with ‡§âbecomes ‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•Åand by dropping the final ‡§®we have ‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø. This, however, may bederived also from such a form ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä found in the Vedas. This ‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§øor ‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•Åis then softened to ‡§µ‡§ø or ‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡•Å, as ‡§™‡•ç is so softened in manycases. When the augment ‡§á or ‡§èis not prefixed, we have ‡§µ‡§ø inthe form of ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ø, the ‡§Ö being the final vowel of the root.

Some of the terminations of the absolutive are also used toform the infinitive, on account of the prevailing confusion between the two. In consequence of this very confusion, recourseis had to other ways of forming the latter which are similar tothose existing in the Prakrits; but these will be noticed hereafter.

The termination ‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø of the potential participle assumes theforms of ‡§á‡§è‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§â‡§Ç, ‡§è‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§â‡§Çand ‡§è‡§µ. The first two represent the formwith the addition of ‡§ï; and the ‡§á of ‡§á‡§è‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§â‡§Çis the usual augmentThe ‡§Ö of the ‡§§of ‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Øwhich remains after the consonantal portionis dropped, is by the influence of the preceding ‡§á changed to ‡§è.

In these points which are not noticed here, the Apabhra·πÅ≈õafollows chiefly the ≈öaurasenƒ´, and the principal Prakrit also tosome extent. Thus in a great measure it represents those dialectsin a further stage of decay; but it must be considered to havederived some words or forms independently also. Thus the ‡§™‡§á ofthe second person pronoun cannot be derived from the Prakrit ‡§§‡§á,nor ‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§£of the absolutive from ‡§§‡•Ç‡§£ or ‡§ä‡§£, or ‡§™‡§£of abstract nounsfrom ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§£, but directly from the Sanskrit ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§® and ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§®. Thiscorruption of ‡§§‡•ç‡§µmust have existed in some of the older dialectstoo, since, as observed before, we have it in A≈õoka’s inscriptions;and the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa derived it as well as a few such peculiarities from them.

LECTURE IV

P ONOLOGY OF THE VERNACULARS OF NORTHERN INDIA

We have now traced the gradual decay of Sanskrit from theform in which it is presented to us in the oldest literary recordsto that which it assumed in the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa dialect. We haveseen how words lost some of their vocal elements on account ofthe natural tendency of men to economize effort, as well as inconsequence of the fact that the vocal organs of the people, whothrough historical nooidents had to speak that language thoughit was not theirs, were untrained to utter the sounds of thatlanguage, and that they imported into it some sounds to whichthey themselves were previously accustomed. We have alsoobserved the effects of the operation of the law of analogy insimplifying the grammar of the language ‚Äî an operation, therange of which, in consequence of the ignorance of those sameforeigners, was very extensive. The declensions and conjugations gradually lost their variety, and became reduced to one or two types by the generalization of the rules, originally applicableonly to the nouns and verbs frequently used in ordinary intercourse. At the same time the terminations themselves of someof the cases, tenses, and moods came through numberless analogies to have the same or similar forms, and their vocal bodygradually became attenuated and in some instances they werealtogether dropped. Thus these processes of simplification werecarried on much further than was consistent with intelligibilityin ordinary intercourse. Hence the necessity arose of inventingnew modes of expression for those relations which came to beimperfectly expressed or ceased to be expressed in the old way.As observed in the last lecture, such new expressions are to bemet with in the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa dialect.

If the Prakrits and the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa which we have examinedreally represent the speech of the Indian people at certain periodsof their past history, we should expect to find a relation of continuity between them and the prevailing speech of modern times.The words and grammatical forms in the modern vernaculars

should either be the same as those existing in those dialects, orshould be easily deducible from them by laws which we haveobserved to be in operation; and if in the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa thegrammatical forms came to be in a condition in which reconstruction was necessary, and if accordingly it was begun, weshould find it carried on much further in the vernaculars andthat on principles used in the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa and the other dialectsand out of materials existing in them. We will therefore proceednow to the examination of the vernaculars with a view to tracethis continuity.

The varieties of speech prevailing in Northern India at thepresent day are almost innumerable. If even a few peculiaritieswere to be regarded as giving individuality to a language, thenumber of dialects spoken in this part of the country wouldexceed even the proverbial fifty-six. But they may be dividedinto classes on the principle of resemblance; and generally thedialects spoken in the adjoining provinces are so alike eachother that they may be regarded as constituting one class or evenone language. Thus we have nine principal languages; andstarting from ourselves, and going northwards, first on thewestern side of the country and then turning to the east andsouth-east, I may state them as the Marathi, the Gujarati, theSindhi, including the Kacchi, the Panjabi, the Kashmiri, the Hindi, the Nepali, the Bengali, and the Oriya.

Of these the Kashmiri and the Nepali have not yet been studied,and no grammars or books are available. Hence my observations will not extend to them. Each of these has its dialects; butthose of some, such as the Gujarati and the Sindhi, differ fromthe main language in unimportant particulars. The same is thecase with the Marathi, except in some corners of the Marathacountry. But in these there are five dialects differing in a greatmany important particulars from the main Marathi. Thus, theGoanese prevails in Goa; the Malvani, my own native tongue,and the Savantvadi, both of which, notwithstanding some minordifferences, may be considered as one, are spoken in the Malvan,Vengorla, and Savantvadi districts. The Chitpavni is used onlyby the caste of Chitpavan Brahmans in the district aboutRatnagiri; the Salsetti is spoken by the original inhabitants of

that island and of Bombay; and the Khandeshi, which is a mixtureof Marathi and Gujarati and contains to an appreciable degreea barbarous element, probably from a Bhil source, prevails inKhandesh.

The Hindi has a great many dialects. Two at least may bedistinguished among the variety of speech prevalent inRajputana, the Mewari spoken in Mewar and the adjoiningdistricts, and the Marwari which prevails in Marwar, Jesselmere,and the other provinces. These, as may be inferred from theirgeographical position, are midway between the Gujarati and theHindi dialects of the North, displaying some of the peculiarcharacteristics of both. Furthernorth, we have the Brajprevailing in the country about Mathura; and to the east,the Kanoji. There is not much difference between these.The language of the history of eighty-four Vai·π£·πáavasand other books of the VallabhƒÅcƒÅryan sects, whichis ordinarily supposed to be the Braj,grammatical forms identical with those mentioned by a recent grammarian as peculiar to the Kanoji. There is a good deal of confusion as regards this matter, the characteristics of one beingfound in the printed books together with those belonging toanother. Then further north, we have the Garhawali and theKumaoni spoken in the provinces of Garhawal and Kumaon.

To the east, we have the Avadhi or the dialect of the provinceof Avadha or Ayodhya, and to the south of this again is theRewai spoken in the State of Rewa. Further to the east is theBhojpuri and kindred dialects prevailing in Bihar and theadjacent districts on the confines of Bengal.

The old literature of the Hindi is principally written in twodialects, the Braj, and what is called the Purbi. S≈´radƒÅsa’s works,Beharilal’s Satasai, and others are written in the former; and tothese I may add the Vallabhha works I have already mentioned.The RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa and Tulasidasa’s other works are written in thelatter. The chief distinction between the idioms of S≈´radƒÅsa andTulasƒ´dƒÅsa appears to me to be, that the latter uses a great manygrammatical forms which are old, and from which those used bythe former are derived. In this respect Purbi might be considered to be a very old form of the Braj. But there are a few other

distinctions, though it is questionable whether they are enough tojustify the Purbi being considered an independent dialect. Thelanguage of Kabƒ´ra’s Ramainƒ´and SƒÅkhiƒ´s presents a few peculiarities found in neither of the above. But the characteristics ofS≈´radƒÅsa and Tulasƒ´dƒÅsa are also to be found in it; so that if weleave out of consideration the other works of Kabƒ´ra, in whichthere is probably another variety of speech, the dialect used bythese Hindi poets may be considered to be the same. This hascome to be regarded as the poetic dialect, and most of the otherHindi poets have written in it. Its modern representative is theBraj, in which the commentaries on Tulasƒ´dƒÅsa’s, Kabƒ´ra’s andBehƒÅrilƒÅl’s works, and on the tenth book of the BhƒÅgavatathat Ihave seen, are written. This then is the Hindi literary dialect.The language, however, which is used as the medium of instruction in the Government schools in the North-Western Provinces,and in which the books published by the Educational Departmentare written, is now regarded as the Standard Hindi, and its grammatical structure is identical with that of the Urdu spoken bythe Mussalmans. This is rather the dialect in which the Hindusof the different provinces in Northern India communicate witheach other, than that which they speak in their own provinces.
