Skr. ‡§ï‡§ü‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç a wristlet, Pr, ‡§ï‡§°‡§Ö‡§Ç, M. (Goan., Mal. and Chit.).

Skr. ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ü‡§ï‡§É a worm, Pr. ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§°‡§ì , Ap.‡§ï‡•Ä‡§°‡§â, M. ‡§ï‡§ø‡§°‡§æ, H. P. ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§°‡§æ . B. ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§°‡§æ, and the other words given in Table 6.

It may be urged that in modern prcnunciation when the penultimate ‡§Ö is accented, it does not become ‡§Ü even though pronounced long, as observed before. How is it then that it becomes ‡§Ü here? In modern times several new modes of pronunciation have arisen, but as regards the matter in hand, to lengthen ‡§Ö into ‡§Ü was the old process. And often when the old processes have disappeared from what is considered the standerd form of a language, they are found preserved in some dialect of that language. Thus, while in the standard Marathi the penultimate ‡§Ö is simply pronounced long, it becomes ‡§Ü in the Goanese and Malvani dialects.
Thus:‚Äî
[Table 37: Penultimate a preserved dialectically ]
St. M. Mal.Goan.
‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§≤ garment, or thin. ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§≤
‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡§°cloth. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§°.
‡§µ‡§§‡§®hereditary property. ‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§®.
‡§ú‡§§‡§®careful preservation. ‡§ú‡§§‡§æ‡§®.
‡§ß‡•ã‡§§‡§∞garment. ‡§ß‡•ã‡§§‡§æ‡§∞.
‡§ñ‡§°‡§™arock. ‡§ñ‡§°‡§æ‡§™.

In this manner, then, the penultimate ‡§Ö in consequence of the accent became ‡§Ü, and the final ‡§â and the ‡§Ö of the final ‡§Ö‡§Ç being dropped, itself became final, and has preserved its accent.

An unaccented ‡§Ö, ‡§Ü, or ‡§â is, you will have observed from the above instances, dropped after a close or dissimilar vowel. For, if preserved, its effect would be to change the preceding close vowel to the corresponding semi-vowel. But being accented, that vowel resists the influence and in its turn overpowers the unaccented, and consequently weak, vowel. But when it is possible to combine both into one sound the final is sometimes not dropped.

Thus the ‡§Ö stand ‡§â in the above examples are combined into ‡§ì in the Gujarati, the Sindhi, and the Goanese, Malvani, and Chitpavni dialects of the Marathi, and the Marvari, Mevari, Kumaoni, and Garhavali dialects of the Hindi; and we have ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ã, ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã, ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã, or ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•ã, ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§¨‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä, ‡§¨‡•á‡§π‡§°‡•ã, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ü‡•ã, ‡§ó‡•ã‡§≤‡•ã, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã, ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡•ã, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡•ã‡•ç, and ‡§ï‡§ø‡§°‡•ã.

When ‡§Ö follows anothe ‡§Ü , the former, you will remember, is generally changed to a light ‡§Ø in the Prakrits. Those dialects tolerated a hiatus when one or both of the vowels were close. But ‡§Ö or ‡§Ü followed by ‡§Ö or ‡§Ü required two complete openings of the mouth, which could not be borne, and hence a close sound ‡§è was interposed. Thus ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§Ö‡§Ç and ‡§ï‡§°‡§Ö‡§Ç , in the above, became ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§Ø‡§Ç and ‡§ï‡§õ‡§Ø‡§Ç, and the ‡§Ø being almost as light as the vowel ‡§á and being unaccented, is dropped in the Malvani and the other dialects; but in the standard Marathi, as formerly observed, the ‡§Ö and ‡§Ø‡§Ç are combined into ‡§è‡§Ç, and so we have ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ç and ‡§ï‡§°‡•á‡§Ç.

In the Apabhramsa, you will remember, the masculine termination ‡§â is transferred by analogy to neuter nouns, and Hemacandra tells us that neuter nouns having a ‡§ï at the end do not drop their nasal termination. Thus, we have ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§â‡§Ç and ‡§ï‡§°‡§â‡§Ç from which by combination we have the Gujarati ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§•‡•Ç‡§Ç and ‡§ï‡§°‡•Ç‡§Ç. Here the nasal sound gives a sort of fixity to the vowel, and hence it does not pass into ‡§ì as in the case of masculine nouns, but absorbs the preceding ‡§Ö. The ‡§ì, ‡§è‡§Ç and ‡§â thus formed are accented like the ‡§Ü of the masculine nouns in the Marathi and others, since they contain the accented penultimate.

Similarly, final unaccented ‡§á is not dropped after ‡§Ö or ‡§Ü, but is slurred over and the least possible time is allowed to it, in consequence of which it sounds like the consonant ‡§è, and thus forms a sort of diphthong with the preceding ‡§Ö or ‡§Ü.

[Table 38 A: Pr. final changed to ‡§Ø‡•ç ]

M. ‡§µ‡§π or ‡§µ‡§Ø‡•çhedge, Pr. ‡§µ‡§á, Skr. ‡§µ‡•É‡§§‡§ø.

M. ‡§∏‡§áor ‡§∏‡§Ø‡•çremembrance, Pr. ‡§∏‡§à Skr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø.

M. (Mal. and Chit.) ‡§®‡§á or ‡§®‡§Ø, H.‡§®‡§á, S.‡§®‡§á, Pr. ‡§®‡§á, Skr.‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä.

M. ‡§∂‡•á‡§£‡§µ‡§áor ‡§Ø name of acaste, Pr. ‡§∏‡•á‡§£‡§æ‡§µ‡§á, Skr. ‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ø.

H. ‡§¨‡§π‡§®‡•ã‡§ásister’s husband, Pr. ‡§≠‡§á‡§£‡•Ä‡§µ‡§á, Skr. ‡§≠‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§™‡§§‡§ø.

Sometimes the final vowel ‡§á absorbs the preceding ‡§Ö; as in

[Table 38 B: Pr. final ‡§á merged in preceding ‡§Ö]

G. ‡§¨‡§®‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä for ‡§¨‡§π‡§®‡•ã‡§á.

M. ‡§∂‡•á‡§£‡§µ‡•Ä.

M. ‡§¶‡§≤‡§µ‡•Ä for Pr. ‡§¶‡§≤‡§µ‡§á, Skr ‡§¶‡§≤‡§™‡§§‡§ø.

You will have seen that the Sanskrit nouns, composed of three or more syllables, given in Table 36, with ‡§Ö at for their penultimate. vowel and ‡§ïor any other similar syllable ending in for the final, have dropped one syllable and become nouns ending in ‡§Ü in Marathi, Hindi, Panjabi, and Bengali, and in Oriya also in some cases, and in ‡§ìin Gujarati, Sindhi, and in the dialects of the Marathi and Hindi spoken of above. Such of them as are neuter have acquired the ending ‡§è‡§Ç or ‡§Ü‡§Çin Marathi and in ‡§ä‡§Ç in Gujarati.

But these are not the only nouns with a final ‡§Üand ‡§ìand ‡§è‡§Ç, ‡§Ü‡§Çand ‡§ä‡§Ç in these languages. There are a good many more, both substantives and adjectives, which have these endings. In the BrajabhƒÅ·π£a also a great many adjectives, nominal and verbal, end in ‡§ìor ‡§î. The Sanskrit words from which they are derived. are not composed of three syllables, with ‡§ï or another syllable like it preceded by an ‡§Ö, as the final. Thus the substantives H. M. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡•á‡§≤‡§æ ‚Äòadisciple’, ‡§™‡•Å‡§°‡§æ‘a parcel’, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§¢‡§æ ’ a decoction, and the adjectives H. ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ,M. ‡§®‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‘blue’ H. ‡§™‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ, M.‡§™‡§ø‡§≤‡§≤‡§æ ‚Äôyellow’, and past participles, H. ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ ‘gone’, ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‘dead’, M.‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§Æ‡•á‡§≤‡§æ&c., and the corresponding Gujarati, ‡§ö‡•á‡§≤‡•ã, ‡§™‡•Å‡§¢‡•ã, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§¢‡•ã, ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡•ã, ‡§™‡•Ä‡§≤‡•ã, ‡§ó‡§Ø‡•ã and ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§µ‡•ã,are

derived from the Sanskrit ‡§ö‡•á‡§ü‡§É, ‡§™‡•Å‡§ü‡§É, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§•‡§É,‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡§É, ‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡§≤‡§É, &c. Similarly such neuter nouns as M. ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç(dial.‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç), G.‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•Å‡§ÇM. (dial. ‡§∏‡•ã‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç), G.‡§∏‡•ã‡§®‡•Ç‡§Ç are derived from the Skr. ‡§ï‡§¶‡§≤‡§Æ‡•çand ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§Æ‡•ç. How then did they get their ‡§Ü and ‡§ìand ‡§Ü‡§Ç, ‡§è‡§Ç and ‡§ä‡§Ç ?

A great many nouns in our languages end in , which has now become silent; and these, as I have explained, are derived from the Sanskrit nouns ending in ‡§Ö, the nominative termination being, because it was unaccented, at first reduced to‡§â and afterwards dropped in most of them, but preserved in Sindhi. By that same law of accentuation which brought about the elision of this ‡§ì, we have seen, that nouns ending in ‡§ï or such othersyllable preceded by ‡§Öcome to have ‡§Ü-‡§ì and ‡§è‡§Ç-‡§Ü‡§Ç-‡§ä‡§Ç for their final. By an obvious inference, therefore, those other substantives and adjectives also must have got ‡§ï‡§Éor ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç in the Prakrits and the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa in the forms of ‡§ì or ‡§Ö‡§Çand ‡§âor ‡§â‡§Ç, though in Sanskrit they do not possess them.

The suffix ‡§ï, though actually found in certain words only in Sanskrit, must have been largely used in the spoken language of ancient times, since PƒÅ·πáini and his expositors allow of its being appended to all nouns and even verbs and participles, to indicate littleness, contempt, tenderness, the state of being unknown, resemblance or copy, and a species founded on some of theseparticularities. Words formed by the addition of such a suffix in such senses cannot, of course, be much used in literary works. They are adapted for colloquial purposes, such as our Marathi PƒÅ·πáinifor Rama and PƒÅ·πáinifor Govinda are.

Accordingly, in the Prakrits and Apabhra·πÉ≈õa, which were derived from the spoken languages, we find the practice of adding the suffix to be very common. Thus in the fourth act of the Vikramorva≈õƒ´we have PƒÅ·πáinifor PƒÅ·πáiniformed from the analogy of PƒÅ·πáini but properly PƒÅ·πáini for PƒÅ·πáini

for ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§≤‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç; ‡§ú‡•Å‡§Ü‡§£‡§ì for ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§µ‡§ï‡§É; ‡§Ü‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ìfor ‡§Ü‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§É; ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§•‡§∞‡§ì for ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§•‡§∞‡§ï‡§É; ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§è for ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§ï‡•á; ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤‡§è for ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§ï‡•á; ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡§ìfor ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡§∏‡§ï‡§É; ‡§™‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§ìfor ‡§™‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡§ï;‡§≤‡•Ä‡§£‡§ì for ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§®‡§ï:; ‡§ó‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§ì for ‡§ó‡§ú‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§Éand many others. So also in Hemacandra’s quotations from Apabhra·πÅ≈õaworks, we have ‡§ò‡§°‡§ø‡§Ö‡§âfor ‡§ò‡§ü‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡§É; ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡§â for ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï‡§É; ‡§â‡§°‡•ç‡§°‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ö‡§è for ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§Ø‡§æ; ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§â for ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡§É; ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§π‡§â‡§Çfor ‡§¨‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç;‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ö‡§âfor ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡§É &c.

Now the question is, why is it that certain nouns only which have ‡§Üand ‡§ìor ‡§Ü‡§Ç,‡§è‡§Ç, and ‡§â‡§Ç in our vernaculars had ‡§ï appended to them in the Prakrits and not others? The suffix was used only where some additional sense was intended to be expressed. Hence there were some words to which it was not appended at all, and of those to which it was two forms existed, of which the one augmented had unaugmented sense. And in our modern dialects a good many words have these two forms, and of these that with ‡§Üconveys an additional sense, such as is attributed to ‡§ï by the Sanskrit grammarians.

Thus ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§ in Marathi expresses & ’tooth’ but ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§æa copy of the animal tooth, that is, ’the tooth‚Äô of such an instrument as a saw; ‡§Æ‡•á‡§≤ signifies ‘union’ ‘agreement’, but ‡§Æ‡•á‡§≤‡§æ expresses a certain union, viz., a concourse of people in a fair or on some festive occasion; ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞ signifies t’he elbow’,but ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡§æany corner, resembling that made by the elbow; ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∞means ‘a string‚Äô, generally, but ‡§¶‡•ã‡§∞‡§æa particular string, that is, ’thread’ used for sewing, ‡§™‡§æ‡§üdenotes generally ‘a strip,‘and thence the piece of wood used for sitting on, but ‡§™‡§æ‡§ü‡§æa slab of stone used for pounding spices; ‡§´‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏ signifies ‘a noose‚Äô, generally, but ‡§´‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æa snare for birds or beasts, and also ‚Äôa catch,’ for fastening anything. In the Hindi, Panjabi and Gujarati ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏or ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏means a bamboo, as does ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Åin Sindhi; but in Marathi ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æmeans ‘a bambu used as a rafter’ and thence a rafter generally, &c. In Marathi and Hindi ‡§ó‡§æ‡§≠signifies‚Äòfoetus’ or ‘womb, but ‡§ó‡§æ‡§≠‡§æ the internal spadix or fruit-receptacle of the plantain-tree or the core or heart of anything. The Panjabi ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠ and ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ also mean ‚Äòthe womb’ and the heart or core of anything respectively.

Thus then ‡§ï was appended to a word in the Prakrits to denote some additional sense; and both the augmented and unaugmentedforms of it were in use; and these in some cases have descended to the vernaculars. But in the course of time, in consequence of the frequent use of the augmented forms, the things expressed by the unaugmented words came to be thought of with the addi. tional property, to denote which the ‡§ï was in the first instance affixed. Hence the forms without ‡§ïwent out of use, gradually those with it lost the additional sense. It was not possible to preserve this sense except by a comparison with the signification of the unaugmented forms. But as these disappeared, the comparison was impossible. And in some cases the additional sense was so slight, that in the course of time it gradually dropped away, though the two forms of the word did exist. Thus wel have in ’ Marathi ‡§ö‡•Ç‡§∞ or ‡§ö‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ ‘fragments’, ‡§ò‡•á‡§∞ or ‡§ò‡•á‡§∞‡§æ‘circumference’, ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¶ or ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ ’the shoulder’, ‡§ú‡•ã‡§° or ‡§ú‡•ã‡§°‡§æ ‘a pair,’ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∏ or ‡§≠‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‘chaff‚Äô, and others; but there is no preceptible difference in the sense of the two forms, though in the last three cases usage has restricted one of them to one state of things and the other to another. So also one of our dialects has the augmented form, and another the original, the sense being the same.Thus:‚Äî

[Table 39: Augmented and unaugmented forms of the same words]

B. ‡§¨‡§°, H. P. ‡§¨‡§°‡§ælarge or great.

M. ‡§ñ‡•á‡§≤, H. P. ‡§ñ‡•á‡§≤, B. ‡§ñ‡•á‡§≤‡§æ a play.

H. ‡§¶‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ, B. ‡§°‡§æ‡§á‡§®, O ‡§°‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§£ right hand,

M. ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨, M. (dial.) ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡•ã, G. ‡§ñ‡§Ç‡§≠, H. P. ‡§ñ‡§Ç‡§≠ or‡§ñ‡§Ç‡§≠‡§æ, B. ‡§ñ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§æ, O, ‡§ñ‡§Ç‡§¨apillar.

B. ‡§Ü‡§Æ, H. ‡§Ü‡§Æ or ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨, P. ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§¨, M. ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§¨‡§æ, G. ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§¨‡•ã the mango tree.

P. ‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ, H. B. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§õ, M. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ a fish.

B.‡§≠‡§æ‡§≤, H. P. M. ‡§≠‡§≤‡§ægood.

It thus appears that originally the suffix was not necessarily applied to any nouns, but optionally to such as admitted of the additional signification.This additional signification has been preserved in some cases, but lost in others.

THE ORIGINAL AND DERIVATIVE ACCENTS IN THE
VERNACULARS.

You will now have seen, that the Sanskrit and Prakrit final vowels having, for the most part, been dropped by the influence of the accent, the final ‡§Ü, ‡§Ü‡§Ç, ‡§à, ‡§à‡§Ç, ‡§ä, ‡§ä‡§Ç, ‡§è‡§Çand ‡§ìthat we have

now got were originally penultimates or have arisen from a combination of the penultimate and final. The accent which originally fell on the penultimate falls now in consequence of this change on these new finals. Thus, these two accents, that on the penultimate when a word ends in the silent ‡§Ö, and that on the new final, are now to be met with in the vernaculars. The first may be called the original accent, and the second derivative.

The Marathi is of all our dialects the most sensitive to them, and shortens all the other vowels of the word in order to throw the whole force of utterance on the accented syllable. The Sanskrit ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï ‘mourning’, ‡§®‡•Ç‡§§‡§® ’new’, ‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡§≤‘brass,’ and the Sanskrit and Prakrit ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ (from ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É or ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã) are pronounced as ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•ë‡§ï‡•ç, ‡§®‡•Å‡§§‡•ë‡§®‡•ç, ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•ë‡§≤‡•ç, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§µ‡•ë‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç, &c, with the penultimate ‡§Ö long and the first vowel short. In this way, in a word composed of three syllables. with the final ‡§Ö silent, the first syllable must be short in Marathi. When a word is composed of more than three syllables, the of the antepenultimate is elided, as in, ‡§Ö‡§°‡§ö‡§£, ‡§∂‡§π‡§æ‡§£‡§™‡§£, pronounced ‡§Ö‡§°‡•ç‡§∞‡§ö‡•ë‡§£‡•ç‡§∂‡§π‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§™‡§£‡•ç, &c.

Similarly, when a word ends in the accented and the other vowels, the preceding vowels are shortened as in the following:‚Äî

[Table 40: Accent shortening preceding vowels ].

** ‡§ï‡§ø‡§°‡§æ**, Skr.‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ü‡§ï‡§É, Pr.‡§ï‡•Ä‡§°‡§ì, and the others in Table 6.

Also ‡§ö‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ and ‡§≠‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ which without the ‡§Ü are ‡§ö‡•Ç‡§∞ and ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§∏ (See p. 422), ‡§µ‡§ø‡§°‡•Ä, ‡§ú‡•Å‡§àand such others occurring in Table 35.

‡§™‡§ø‡§°‡•Ä a step in the scale of descent, a generation, Skr. ‡§™‡•Ä‡§†‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ.

‡§ú‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ gambling by means of dice, Skr.‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï‡§É(by a change of gender).

‡§®‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ-‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç-‡§≤‡•Äblue, Skr. ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡§ï‡§É-‡§ï‡§Ç-‡•¶‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ.

‡§™‡§ø‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ-‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç-‡§≤‡•Ä yellow, Skr. ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ï‡§É-‡§ï‡§Ç-‡•¶‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§æ.

When, together with the accented final, a word is composed of three or more syllables, or, more generally, when the accented syllable is preceded by two others or more, the ‡§Öof that which Immediately precedes is silent or elided, as in the case of ‡§Ö‡§°‡•ç‡§ö‡§£ or above, and any other vowel in its place is shortened and sometimes dropped: The other vowels are also pronounced short. Thus ‚Äî

[Table 41: Elision of ‡§Ö through Accent.]

‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ï imper. 2nd ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§£‡•á‡§Ç inf. to learn,
pronounced as
per. sing.the origina‡•§
form of the root.
‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§£‡•á‡§Ç.

‡§™‡•Ç‡§∏ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡§£‡•á‡§Ç inf. ’to ask‚Äô ‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§£‡•á‡§Ç.
‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∏ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∏‡§§‡•ã pres. part.‘he is

                     angry'

‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ã.

‡§∂‡•Ä‡§µ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ past part.‚Äòtouched‚Äô ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ.

‡§∂‡•Ä‡§µ has similarly ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§£‡•á‚Äòto sew‚Äô inf. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§§‡•ã ‘he sews,‚Äô ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ ‚Äòsewn.‚Äô

‡§ï‡§∞ ‘do,’ *pres. part.*unaugmented ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§, sugmented ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã or ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ã pronounced as ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç ‡§§‡•ã

.

So also ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡§ï‡§É is ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ç‡§†‡§æ, and ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡§ï‡§É, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ the penultimate ‡§â being dropped.

When the final is unaccented, it is the penultimate that is emphasized, but when it is accented, the penultimate is slurred over. Thus the accentuation of the penultimate leads to the elision of the final vowel, and the accentuation of the final brings about an elision or shortening of the penultimate.

ACCENT IN HINDI

In Hindi also the accent leads to the elision of the ‡§Öof the previous syllable when more than one precede the accented syllable. Thus ‡§â‡§¨‡§ü‡§®‚Äòa cosmetic‚Äô is pronounced is pronounced as ‡§â‡§¨‡§ü‡§®, ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ñ‡§™‡§®as‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ñ‡•ç‡§™‡§® as‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ñ‡§™‡§® as ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡§ñ‡•ç‡§™‡•ë‡§®, ‡§â‡§¨‡§ü‡§®‡§æinf. ’to rub the body with a cosmetic‚Äô, as ‡§â‡§¨‡§ü‡•ç‡§®‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æas ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç ‡§®‡§æ. The Braj present participle ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§ is pronounced as ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ë‡§§‡•ç since one syllable only precedes the accented penultimate; but the Hindi ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æis ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç ‡§§‡§æas two syllables precede the accented ‡§§‡§æ. The accent leads to the shortening of the preceding vowels in some cases. Thus ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§≤ ‘cowherd,’ and ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§≤ ’the lower regions,‚Äô are sometimes pronounced and written as ‡§ó‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§≤ and ‡§™‡§§‡§æ‡§≤;so does ‡§Ü‡§∏‡§ø‡§∑‡•çbecome ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Ä‡§∏. In such words as ‡§â‡§™‡§ú‘produce,‚Äô ‡§â‡§∏‡§æ‡§∏‘respiration,‚Äô and ‡§â‡§¨‡§ü‡§® ‚Äòa cosmetic‚Äô, from the Pr. ‡§â‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, ‡§â‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§∏, and ‡§â‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§£, Skr. ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏, and ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§®, it prevents the lengthening of the initial ‡§â, as by the general rule it should be long, since one member of the following double consonant is dropped. The

derived socent also shortens the preceding vowels in such instances as the following :‚Äî

[Table 42: Accent in Hindi shortening preceding vowels].

H. ‡§¶‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡§æ southern, Pr. ‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§£‡§ì, Skr. ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£‡§ï‡§É.

H. ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ alamp, Pr. ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ì, Skr. ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï‡§É .

H. ‡§ú‡•Å‡§Ü gambling, Pr.‡§ú‡•Ç‡§Ö‡§ì.Skr. ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï‡§É (by a change of gender).

H. ‡§Ö‡§ó‡§≤‡§æforemost, the first part of which is ‡§Ü‡§ó, from Pr. ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó. Skr. ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞.

H. ‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡§æ one’s own,…….. ‡§Ü‡§™ from Pr. ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§™, Skr ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ.
‡§á‡§ï‡§†‡•ç‡§†‡§æ together,…‚Ä¶‚Ä¶‡§è‡§ï.

H. ‡§´‡§ø‡§∞‡§æwalked, ‡§™‡§ø‡§Ø‡§ædrunk, ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æsewn, ‡§õ‡•Å‡§Ütouched, past participlesof ‡§´‡•Ä‡§∞‡§®‡§æ, ‡§™‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ, ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§®‡§æ ‡§õ‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ, &c. ‡•Æ‡•¶.

In the same way it prevents the lengthening of a preceding vowel in such cases as ‡§â‡§™‡§ú‡§®‡§æ’to be produced,’ ‡§â‡§†‡§®‡§æ’to rise,‚Äô‡§â‡§°‡§®‡§æ ’to fly, ’the last two being derived from the Prakrit ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§£ and ‡§â‡§°‡•ç‡§°‡§Ø‡§®.

EXCEPTIONS TO THE ABOVE.

But in a great many cases the accent does not affect the preceding close vowels. The Sanskrit words ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï, ‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡§≤, &c., the first syllable of which is shortened in Marathi, retain it long in the Hindi. The words ‡§â‡§™‡§ú,‡§â‡§™‡§ú‡§®‡§æ, ‡§â‡§∏‡§æ‡§∏, and othershave their initial vowel optionally lengthened, and in a few cases, such as ‡§ä‡§™‡§∞ and ‡§ä‡§ñ‡§≤, it is lengthened without any apparent reason. Similarly, the Hindi forms of ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ü‡§ïand the other words in Table 6 retain the long vowel. It has also ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§°‡•Ä, ‡§ú‡•Ç‡§π‡•Äand ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ú‡•Ä as in Table 35, and ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‘blue’, ‡§™‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‚Äòyellow‚Äô, ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ñ‡§æ, learnt’, ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§†‡§æ‘sweet’, ‡§™‡•Ç‡§õ‡§æ‘asked’, ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§Ü ‘dead’, ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ñ‡§®‡§æ’to learn, ‡§™‡•Ç‡§õ‡§®‡§æ‚Äòto ask’, ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ &c., while in all these cases the Marathi has short ‡§á and ‡§â. Perhaps, this weakening of the accent as regards previous ‡§à and ‡§ä is due to the development of another accentin Hindi on the initial syllable. To such an accent as this might be attributed the almost universal change of ‡§Ö‡§Øand ‡§Ö‡§µ to ‡§ê and ‡§îthat we have already noticed. The ‡§Öof the initial syllable, being accented, draws to itself the ‡§Øor ‡§µof the following and

deprives it of its ‡§Ö, in which cases the ‡§Øor ‡§µ becomes ‡§á or ‡§â, and then the two form ‡§ê and ‡§î.

THE ACCENT IN GUJARATI

The Gujarati follows the Hindi completely, sometimes shortening the preceding vowels as in ‡§ï‡•Å‡§µ‡•ã, ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡•ã, and ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ã ‘delicate’, ’tender’, and dropping it as in ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã ‘father-in-law’, (Skr.‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞‡§ï‡§É) and‡§Ü‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡•Ä ‘finger’ (Skr. ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ), sometimes preventing their being lengthened, as in ‡§â‡§™‡§ú, ‡§â‡§†‡§ò‡•Å‡§Ç, &c., and very often preserving them long as in ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ã ‘full’, ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç, ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã, &c.

THE ACCENT IN PANJABI

The Panjabi also keeps the short vowel in such cases as ‡§â‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ ‘utterance’, ‡§â‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ ’light’, though a member of a double is droppedand preserves the long in such casesas ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ or ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§µ‡§æ, ‡§ú‡•Å‡§Ü, ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§°‡§æ, ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡§æ, ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‚Äòa cake’, &c. It has even fewer instances of shortening than the Hindi.

THE ACCENT IN SINDHI

The Sindhi has ‡§ú‡•Å‡§Ü‘gambling’, ‡§°‡§ø‡§ì‘a lamp,’ ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§≤&c., but has such words as ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï, ‘mourning’, ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§°‡•ã ‘a worm’, ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§°‡•ã ‘a roll of betel leaves, (Skr. ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ü‡§ï‡§É), ‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡•ã‘drunk’, &c. In a great many words such as ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•ã‘dried’, ‡§µ‡•Å‡§ß‡•ã‘heard’, ‡§õ‡•Å‡§§‡•ã’touched’, ‡§¶‡•Å‡§ß‡•ã‘milked’, the vowel of the preceding syllable is short; but that is due not to the accent on the last syllable but to the peculiarity of the Sindhi not to lengthen the preceding vowels even when a member of a double is dropped.

THE ACCENT IN BENGALI AND ORIYA

The Bengali is more like the Marathi in this respect than the Hindi. Thus we have ‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡§∞, H. ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡§∞ ‘in the interior‚Äô, ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ dry, H. ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§ï‡§æ; ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ or ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ó‡§æ ‘wet‚Äô, H. ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§ú‡§æ or ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§ó‡§æ; ‡§ï‡§ø‡§°‡§æ ‘a worm’, H.‡§ï‡•Ä‡§°‡§æ; ‡§ú‡•Å‡§§‡§æ ‘shoes’, H.‡§ú‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ; ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‘a nail’, H. ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§â‡§™‡§ú‡§® ’to be produced, &c. It thus shortens ‡§á and ‡§â in the unaccented syllables like the Marathi.

The Oriya follows the Bengali, having ‡§ú‡•Å‡§°‡§æ, Skr. ‡§ú‡•Ç‡§ü‡§ï‘a knot of hair‚Äô, ‡§ú‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‘shoes’, ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‘wet’, ‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡§∞ ‘in the interior’, &c. All these languages, however, treat the unaccented ‡§Ö in words of three or more syllables as the Marathi and Hindi do.

THE ACCENT ON VERNACULAR TERMINATIONS

In Marathi the termination of the oblique form of cases and that of the plural of neuter nouns in ‡§è are also accented. The reasonwhy they bear the accent will be considered hereafter. The accent on the causal termination, in consequence of which the preceding vowels are shortened in the Hindi and the Gujarati, has already been mentioned. This also seems to be the same accent that we have been considering. Thus in G. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§°‡§æ‡§µ‘make him sew, or ‡§ß‡•ã‡§µ‡§°‡§æ‡§µ ‘make him wash’, the ‡§Übeing penultimate bears the accent and the final ‡§Öis dropped. Similarly in ‡§ß‡•ã‡§µ‡§°‡§æ‡§µ‡§µ‡•Å‡§Çby the general rule, the final vowel being accented the penultimate ‡§Ö is silent. It is because it is so, and the ‡§µ‡§µ‡•Å‡§Çforms the conjunct‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç, that the ‡§Ülooks as if emphasized just as the first ‡§Öof ‡§Ö‡§°‡•ç‡§ö‡§£ and ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç ‡§§‡§æ is. In the Marathi and other dialectsalso, there is this accent in the case of the causal, and the preceding ‡§à and ‡§ä are shortened; as in ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡•ë‡§µ‡•ç ‘make him sleep’, ‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡§µ‡•ç‡§£‡•á‡§Ç’to make one sleep’, from the original ‡§®‡•Ä‡§ú ‘sleep’, in ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡•çcause him to do ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç‡§£‡•á‡§Çor‡§ï‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§£‡•á‡§Ç ‚Äôto cause one to do’, &c. In the standard Hindi the ‡§µ is dropped, but still the way of pronunciation remains the same as it was when it existed. In ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ’to show,‘for instance, the ‡§ñ‡§æ is pronounced as it would have been if the word had been ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ. And the forms with ‡§µ exist in the Braj.

ACCENT IN VERNACULAR COMPOUNDS

Compounds in the vernaculars, most of which belong to the Tatpuru·π£a, KarmadhƒÅraya, or Dvandva class have an accent on the penultimate or final of the last word, as in the H. ‡§™‡§®‡•ç ‡§∏‡§æ‡•ë‡§≤ ‘a place where water is provided for passengers’, in which the first word‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•Äbecomes ‡§™‡§®‡•ç, ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ‡•ë‡§àa forest of mango-trees’, in which the ‡§Üof ‡§Ü‡§Æis shortened, ‡§ò‡•Å‡§°‡§∏‡§æ‡•ë‡§≤ ‘a stable’, in which we have ‡§ò‡•Å‡§°for ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§æ, ‡§∞‡§®‡•ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏ ‘harem’, the ‡§∞‡§®‡•ç of which is a shortened form of ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä, and in the G. ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§Æ‡•Å‡§à‘half dead‚Äô, and the M. ‡§Ö‡§ß‡§Æ‡•ë‡§£‚Äôhalf a maund‚Äô.In the Marathi ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§∞‡§æ‡•ë‡§á, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•Ç‡•ë‡§∏,‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ë‡§∞, the ‡§Ü of the first syllable is short though not changed to ‡§Ö; and in ‡§§‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§ü‡•á‘an arrow and bow’, the first word is ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∞‡•çwith the ‡§à shortened.

An unaccented initial vowel is dropped in the following instances:‚Äî

[Table 43: unaccented initial vowels dropped in vernaculars]

Skr. ‡§â‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂ sit, Pr. ‡§â‡§µ‡§á‡§∏, M. H. B. O. ‡§¨‡•à‡§∏, G. ‡§¨‡•á‡§∏, S.‡§¨‡§ø‡§π.

Skr. ‡§â‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡§É sat, Pr. ‡§â‡§µ‡§á‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§ì, H. P. ‡§¨‡•à‡§†‡§æ, G. ‡§¨‡•à‡§†‡•ã, S, ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§†‡•ã,

Skr. ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞inside, H. ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡§∞, B. M. (dial.) ‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡§∞.

Skr.‡§Ö‡§∞‡§ò‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü, a water-wheel, Pr.‡§Ö‡§∞‡§π‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü?, H.‡§∞‡§π‡§ü, M.‡§∞‡§π‡§æ‡§ü.

Skr. ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç to soak, M. ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡§£‡•á‡§Ç, H. ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§ú‡§®‡§æ, G. ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç, B, ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ.

Skr.‡§è‡§ï‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ï‡§Æ‡•çin one place, Pr.‡§è‡§ï‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§Ö‡§Ç, H. P. ‡§ï‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§æ, or ‡§á‡§ï‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§â‡§™‡§∞‡§ø . above, Pr. ‡§â‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø, M. ‡§µ‡§∞.

Skr.‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ï‡§Éleft, Pr. ‡§â‡§ú‡•ç‡§õ‡•Å‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§ì, H. ‡§ú‡•Ç‡§†‡§æ ‘what is left after eating’.

Skr. ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø a preceptor, M. ‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ, P. ‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‡•á.

Skr.‡§â‡§¶‡•Ç‡§¢‡§ï‡§É, Pr. ‡§â‡§¶‡•Ç‡§¢‡§ì abridegroom, H. P. ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§æ.

Of the two instances of this change in the Prakrits ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ç a ‘pumpkin’ exists in Hindi, and ‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§£in the form of ‡§∞‡§æ‡§® in M. and P. and of ‡§∞‡§® in H. Medial ‡§ê is dropped in Marathi, Bengall, and Oriya in the word ‡§¨‡•à‡§∏, and others enumerated before. It is dropped in the G. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•Äfor H. ‡§Æ‡•å‡§∏‡•Ä(see p. 391). This elision does not appear to be due to accent since according to our theory it must fall on the ‡§êin some at least of the cases. The change is due to the process of softening, sitice what takes place here is the simple dropping away of the close element of the diphthong.

THE AVOIDING OF THE HIATUS IN THE VERNACULARS

We will now briefly notice the manner in which the hiatus caused by two vowels coming together in consequence of the olision of uninitial consonants in the Prakrits is avoided. We have seen that ‡§Öand ‡§á and ‡§Öand ‡§â are combined into ‡§ê and ‡§îin some of the dialects, and into ‡§è and ‡§ìin others. Final unacdented ‡§Öand ‡§Üare dropped when preceded by ‡§á or ‡§â as in the words given in Table No. 35, and unaccented ‡§â preceded by ‡§Öis dropped in some of the vernaculars, as in Table No. 36, and combined into ‡§ìor ‡§â in others. Final ‡§á is preserved or changed to ‡§Øafter ‡§Öin some cases, and combined with it to form ‡§àothers.

Final accented ‡§Üand ‡§â or ‡§ä are preserved and a hiatus is tolerated; as in H. P. ‡§ú‡•Å‡§Üor ‡§ú‡•Ç‡§Üfor ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï, and S. P. ‡§™‡§ø‡§â, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§â, and theM. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§äfor ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡•É‡§ï, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ï‡§æ, ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ï, &c.

Sometimes ‡§è or ‡§µ‡•ç is inserted in such cases after ‡§áand ‡§â, as In H. ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ for ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ü‚Äòalamp’ and M. ‡§ú‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ, H. ‡§ú‡•Ç‡§µ‡§æ for ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§§‡§ï.

The syllable ‡§Ö‡§Ø aru, formed in the Prakrits by interposing a ‡§è between ‡§Ö and ‡§Ö, Is changed to ‡§ê in modern Hindi as in the words in Table No.16 and to ‡§èin the Gujarati and the Sindhi. This latter was the older process; and hence even in the Prakrits we have ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤ for ‡§ï‡§Ø‡§≤, Skr, ‡§ï‡§¶‡§≤, and ‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡§π, ‡§§‡•á‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∏‡§æ, ‡§§‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§∏‡§æ for ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§¶‡§∂, ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡§ø, ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§§‡•ç &c. And in Hindi alsowe have‡§è in ‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‚Äòa plum’ from ‡§¨‡§Ø‡§∞for Skr. ‡§¨‡§¶‡§∞, which must have existed in the Prakrits, though the form given by the Grammarians is ‡§¨‡•ã‡§∞ for ‡§¨‡§µ‡§∞.

Though the Marathi does not, like the Hindi or Gujarati, nowchange ‡§Ö‡§Ø to ‡§ê or ‡§è, still as formerly observed, when in a state of formation, it did form ‡§èout of it, as in the instances there given, and in the neuter singular termination ‡§è‡§Ç. The termination ‡§®‡•á‡§∞ occurring at the end of the names of Gujarati and Marathi towns such as ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ç‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§∞, ‡§¨‡§°‡§®‡•á‡§∞, ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®‡•á‡§∞, ‡§™‡§ø‡§Ç‡§™‡§≤‡§®‡•á‡§∞, &c, is derived from Pr. ‡§®‡§Ø‡§∞for Skr. ‡§®‡§ó‡§∞’town‚Äô. The syllables ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§æ, arising ‡§Ö from ‡§Ü, are also sometimes changed to ‡§è as in H. ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ß‡•á‡§∞ or ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ß‡•á‡§∞‡§æ, M.‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ß‡•á‡§∞, Pr.‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ß‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞, Skr. ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞.After ‡§Ü, the ‡§Ø is sometimes changed to ‡§êand ‡§è in the Hindi and Gujarati as in the instances in Tables No.18 and 20, and also in the Marathi in the instance ‡§∂‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä from Pr. ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ö‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ü, Skr. ‡§õ‡§æ‡§ó‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ; but often ‡§Ü‡§Øand ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§æremain unchanged as in :‚Äî

[Table 44: ‡§è inserted to avoid Hiatus]

H. G. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∞ timid, Pr. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∞, Skr. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡§∞.

H. G. M. ‡§ò‡§æ‡§Ø wound or blow, Pr. ‡§ò‡§æ‡§Ö or ‡§ò‡§æ‡§§.Skr. ‡§ò‡§æ‡§§.

H. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ø wind, Pr. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ö, or ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ø, Skr ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§.

M. ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø the foot, Pr. ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ö or ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø, Skr. ‡§™‡§æ‡§¶.

M. H. G. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø a king, Pr. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Üor ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ,.Skr. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ.

H. ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ gone, G ‡§ó‡§Ø‡•ã, Pr. ‡§ó‡§Ö‡§ì, or ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§ì, Skr. ‡§ó‡§§‡§ï‡§É.

G. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡•ãthe cold sesson, S. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã, Pr. ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§Ö‡§Ü (‡§Ø‡§æ)‡§≤‡§ì, Skr. ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§É.

Sometimes the interposed ‡§Ø‡•çis so light that it is dropped and the vowels ‡§Öand ‡§Ü, or ‡§Üand ‡§Ö, and in rare cases, ‡§Öand ‡§Ö, combine and form ‡§Ü as in:‚Äî

[Table 45 A: The interposed ‡§Ø‡•çdropped]

B. ‡§™‡§æ, and B. G. ‡§ò‡§æfor‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø and ‡§ò‡§æ‡§Ø in the above.

M. ‡§Ü of ‡§Ü‡§≤‡§æ, Pr. ‡§Ü‡§Ö‡§Ö, Skr, ‡§Ü‡§ó‡§§.

M. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞ a potter, Pr.‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§Ü‡§∞, Skr. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞, and generally, the termination ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞as in ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‘a goldsmith’ and others, also M. ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞ for ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞.

G. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Ç a promise, Pr. ‡§µ‡§Ö‡§£‡§Ö‡§Ç, Skr. ‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç.

H. ‡§¨‡§∞‡§æ‡§§, M. ‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§ a bridal procession, Skr. ‡§µ‡§∞‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ.

In some cases ‡§µ‡•çis inserted instead of ‡§Ø‡•ç to prevent the hiatus, as in:‚Äî

M. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§µfor ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ö ‘a king’.

H. ‡§™‡§æ‡§µfor ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ö’the foot’.

M. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µin ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§≤‡•Ä for ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ö in ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ; ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ for Pr. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§Ö, Skr. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§§‡§∞‡§ï; ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µin ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ for Pr. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Öfrom Skr. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï and a few others.

In the principal Prakrit also we find ‡§™‡•Ä‡§µ‡§≤‡§Öfor Skr.‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡§≤‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‘yellow’, from which we have the Marathi ‡§™‡§ø‡§µ‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç, and ‡§¨‡•ã‡§∞ has been mentioned above.

A medial ‡§Ö is dropped after ‡§á, ‡§è or ‡§â a short or long, as in:‚Äî

[Table 45 C: Medial ‡§Ö dropped after, ‡§á, ‡§è or ‡§â]

M. ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞ for Pr. ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ö‡§∞‘husband’s brother’.

G. ‡§™‡•Ä‡§≤‡•Å‡§Ç, H. ‡§™‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ ‘yellow’ for Pr. ‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ö‡§Ç, Skr. ‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡§≤‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç.

M. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç‚Äòstale‚Äô, H. ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ ‘damp’, ‘cool’, ‘Pr. ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ö‡§Ç, Skr.‡§∂‡•Ä‡§§‡§≤‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç.

M. ‡§µ‡•á‡§£a throe,’ Pr.‡§µ‡•á‡§Ö‡§£‡§æ, Skr.‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§®‡§æ; M.‡§ú‡•Ç‡§≤or ‡§ú‡•Ç‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç ’twins‚Äô, Pr. ‡§ú‡•Å‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ç or ‡§ú‡•Å‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ö‡§Ç, Skr. ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç or ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§≤‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç. Sometimes with the previous ‡§á, it forms ‡§è; that is, a vowel, partaking of the character of both, is substituted for them; as in:‚Äî

[Table 45 D: medial ‡§Öchanged to ‡§è]

S.‡§®‡•á‡§≤‡•Å‘a fetter, Pr.‡§®‡§ø‡§Ö‡§°‡•ã,Skr.‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡§°‡§É.

H. P. ‡§®‡•á‡§°‡•áor ‡§®‡•á‡§∞‡•á ‚Äònear‚Äô, Pr. ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ö‡§°‡•á, Skr. ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§ü‡•á.

M. ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ç‡§°‡•Ä’the tuft of hair on the head’, Pr. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§π‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§Ü, Skr.‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ, the ‡§πbeing softened to‡§Ö.

H.‡§¨‡•á‡§®‡§æ ‘a fan,’ Pr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ö‡§£‡§Ö, Skr. ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‡§ï.

‡§®‡•á‡§°‡•á has the form ‡§®‡•Ä‡§°‡•áalso, in which case ‡§Öis simply dropped and the vowel rendered long as in the M.‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞.

The long ‡§Üis preserved and changes the preceding ‡§á to ‡§á‡§Ø or ‡§Øas in the H. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞ or ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞ ‘jackal’ for Pr. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ü‡§≤, Skr. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ó‡§æ‡§≤; ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π ‘marriage,‚Äô for Pr.‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ü‡§π, Skr.‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§π, &c.

CONSONANTAL CHANGES IN THE VERNACULARS.

We will now proceed to the consideration of consonantal changes; and first of those due to the process of softening. The semivowel ‡§Ø‡•ç is often softened to ‡§á. In the Prakrits, ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®‚Äòa fan’ becomes ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ö‡§£ which is preserved in the H. ‡§¨‡•á‡§®‡§æ and ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§® is changed to for ‡§•‡•Ä‡§£. This word does not occur in the vernaculars, butthe Hindi and Marathi have got ‡§•‡§ø‡§ú‡§§‡§æand ‡§•‡§ø‡§ú‡§£‡•á‡§Ç ‚Äòto congeal’ from the verb ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ø‡§§‡•á, in which ‡§Ø‡§æis softenedto‡§á. From ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ú‡§®, or rather such a word as ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§ú‡§®, we have by a similar softening M. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ú‡§£‡§æ, H.‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ú‡§®‡§æ, G.‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§£‡•ã, S, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§û‡§ø‡§£‡•Å. More modern instances are:-

[Table 46 Pra. ‡§Ø‡•ç changed to Verna. ‡§á]

H. P. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§à, P.‡§∏‡§≤‡§æ‡§à, Pr.‡§∏‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ, M.‡§∏‡§≤‡§àa pencil, probe, Skr. ‡§∂‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ.

B. ‡§∂‡•á‡§≤a dart, Skr.‡§∂‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø; the ‡§Ø, being changed to ‡§á, is transferred to the preceding syllable.

H. P. ‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡§§ a bridal procession, Skr. ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ.

H. ‡§ù‡§æ‡§à‡§Ç shadow, P. ‡§õ‡§æ‡§à‡§Ø‡§æ, Skr. ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ.

H. P. ‡§¨‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§ passed, Skr, ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§§.

H.P. ‡§¨‡§ø‡§•‡§æpain, Skr.‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ; ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞business, performance, Skr.‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞.

H. P. ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ü‡§£ welfare, Skr. ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£, ‡§¨‡§ø‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ü learning, Skr.‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ,

P.‡§™‡§§‡•Ä‡§ú faith, belief, Skr.‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø.

H.‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§õvisible, Skr.‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑.

The Panjabi always dissolves a Sanskrit ‡§Ø contained in a conjunct into ‡§á + ‡§Ö, or sometimes into ‡§á simply, while the Hindi often resorts to the latter change. The other languages do not seem to possess many instances of this process. The change of ‡§Ö‡§Øor ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§æto ‡§è, formerly noticed, is also due to this softening process.

In the Prakrits, ‡§µ‡•ç is dissolved into ‡§â in‡§ù‡•Å‡§£‡•Ä for Skr ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§®‡§ø, ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§á, for ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡§ø‡§§‡§ø, ‡§¶‡•Å for ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø, ‡§§‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞ for ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞, &c. In Hindi we have ‡§ù‡•Å‡§® in the sense of ‘a slight resemblance,’ a remote sound of the property possessedby another. But another derivative from the word exists in the form ‡§ß‡•Å‡§®or ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§®in that language, and of ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§® or ‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡§ï in Marathi. From ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ H. has ‡§∏‡•ã ‚Äòto sleep,‚Äô P. ‡§∏‡•å, G.‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ, and B. and O.‡§∂‡•Å or ‡§∂‡•Å‡§á. ‡§¶‡•Å occurs in the forms of ‡§¶‡•ãor ‡§¶‡•Å when the word stands alone or is compounded, as in H.‡§¶‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ, B.‡§¶‡•Å‡§®‡§æ, M.‡§¶‡•Å‡§£‡§æ, &c., for Pr.‡§¶‡•Å‡§Ö‡§£, Skr. ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ó‡•Å‡§£‚Äòtwo-fold,’ and ‡§§‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞by a further dissolution becomes the P. ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§®‡§æto go,’ H. P. ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§Ç‡§§, G.‡§§‡§∞‡§§‘instantly, pr. part., M. ‡§§‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‚Äòat present‚Äô.

More modern instances are:‚Äî

[Table 47: ‡§µ‡•ç changed to ‡§âor ‡§ì]

H. P. ‡§™‡§∞‡•ã‡§∏ to serve food, Skr.‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∑.

H. P.M ‡§™‡§°‡•ã‡§∏‡•Ä a neighbour, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§∂‡•Ä.

H. P. ‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡§ä, Pr. ‡§ú‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Ö, Skr. ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ã‡§™‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§.

The ‡§µ and ‡§µ‡§Ç to which ‡§™ and‡§Æ are softened aresimilarly changed to ‡§â or ‡§ì.

H. P. ‡§¨‡§π‡§®‡•ã‡§à sister‚Äôshusband, Pr. ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§µ‡§à, Skr, ‡§≠‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§™‡§§‡§ø.

H. P. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã name of a month, Pr.‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§µ‡§ÖSkr, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§¶.

H. P. G. ‡§ñ‡•ã-[‡§®‡§æ-‡§£‡§æ-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç] to lose, Pr. ‡§ñ‡§µ, Skr.‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§™.

H. P. B. ‡§õ‡•Ç to touch, Pr. ‡§õ‡§ø‡§µ, or ‡§õ‡•Å‡§µ, Skr. ‡§õ‡•Å‡§™.

H. ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ã‡§ñ‡§æ unexpected, Pr. ‡§Ö‡§£‡§µ‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ-[‡§Ö], Skr. ‡§Ö‡§®‡§™‡•á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑-[‡§ï].

H. ‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡§æ, P. ‡§®‡•á‡§â‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ, G. ‡§®‡•ã‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§Ç, invitation, A.P. ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§-[‡§â] or **‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞-[‡§â]**Skr.‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞-[‡§ï‡§É], H, has ‡§®‡•á‡§µ‡§§‡§æalso.

H. ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç the full-moon day, Ap. ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç, Skr. ‡§™‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ.

H. ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ç‡§π (of ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ç‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç) face to face, Ap. ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç‡§π, Skr. ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ.

M. ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ç‡§™ to entrust, Ap.‡§∏‡§µ‡§Ç‡§™‡•ç‡§™, Skr. ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™.

It will be seen that the ‡§ìor ‡§â to which ‡§µ‡•ç is softened often prevails over the preceding and following vowels, as in the words‡§™‡§∞‡•ã‡§∏ and ‡§™‡§°‡•ã‡§∂‡•Ä.

The change of ‡§Ö‡§µto ‡§î, formerly noticed, I consider as due to the elision of the final ‡§Öof ‡§µ, consequent upon an accent on the first syllable, though afterwards there is a softening of the ‡§µ‡•ç to ‡§â. But in the above instances the change of ‡§µ‡•çto ‡§ìor ‡§â is due to a weak pronunciation or softening alone. The diphthong ‡§ìrequires, as I have several times observed, a passage from one vocal position immediately to another which involves energetic utterance. The Pali, Prakrit, Gujarati, and Sindhi substitute for it, viz.‡§ì, is due to assimilation. The Hindi ‡§îand the corresponding Gujarati ‡§ì, therefore, are not due to a weakening of the ‡§µ‡•ç, but the ‡§ìin the above instances is, since it is not a substitute for ‡§îand consequently does not arise from an assimilation of the two sounds, involved in that diphthong.

The following are still more modern instances:‚Äî

[Table 48:‡§µ‡•ç changed to ‡§â]

H. P. ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞ God, Skr ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞.

M. H. P. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞ or ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞ a musical note, Skr.‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞.

H. P. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§ânature, Skr.‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ.

P. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•Ämaster, Skr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ä.

In this manner the Panjabis always pronounce the ‡§µ‡•ç of Sanskrit words and to a smaller extent, the Hindi people. The Marathi has not many instances of this softening of ‡§µ‡•ç.

In the Prakrits there are according to the grammarians but. three instances of the change of ‡§ï‡•ç to the sonant ‡§ó‡•ç. Of these ‡§ó‡•á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§Ö for Skr.‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§ïoccurs in the vernaculars. With these exceptions the initial ‡§ï‡•ç remains unchanged and the medial is dropped. But the vernaculars, adopting pure Sanskrit wordagain and again in the course of their history, have changed them as we have seen or changed the Prakrit words that came down

to them in virtue of the general or special laws which regulate the development of human speech. Thus, though they did not receive more words with a softened ‡§ï‡•ç from the Prakrits, they have now come to possess a good many. Thus:-

[Table 49: Medial ‡§ï‡§Ωoftened to ‡§ó‡•ç]

M. ‡§¨‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ, H. P. ‡§¨‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ, G. ‡§¨‡§ó‡§≤‡•ã, S. ‡§¨‡§ó‡•ã, B. O. ‡§¨‡§ó Skr. ‡§¨‡§ï or ‡§¨‡§ï‡§ï‡§É, a crane.

The instances in which the cerebral ‡§ü‡•ç resulting from an original ‡§§‡•ç has been softened in the Prakrits to ‡§°‡•ç have been preserved by the vernaculars. The following are some of these:-

[Table 52: ‡§ü‡•ç( from original ‡§§‡•ç) softened to ‡§°‡•ç]

‡§π‡§∞‡§°‡§æ or ‡§π‡§∞‡§°‡•Ä and ‡§¨‡•á‡§π‡§°‡§æ asin Table 29; M. ‡§™‡•Å‡§¢‡•á‡§Ç forward, so forth, Pr. ‡§™‡§π‡•Å‡§°‡§ø, Skr. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§ø.

‡§™‡§° of M. ‡§™‡§°‡§£‡•á‡§Ç, G. ‡§™‡§°‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç, H. ‡§™‡§°‡§®‡§æ to fall, Pr. ‡§™‡§° Skr. ‡§™‡§§‡•ç.

M. ‡§Æ‡§¢‡§º‡•á‡§Ç a corpse, from Pr. ‡§Æ‡§°‡§Ö‡§Ç, Skr. ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç.

‡§â‡§ñ‡§æ‡§°‡§®‡§æto dig out, to root out, from the Skr. ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ‡§§.

Of the change of ‡§§‡•ç to ‡§¶‡•ç there are some instances in the ≈öaurasenƒ´, and corresponding to these, we have a few in the Panjabi, Sindhi and Gujarati, thus:‚Äî

[Table 53: ‡§§‡•ç softened to ‡§¶‡•ç]

P. ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§â‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ ’living’, ≈öaur. pres. part. ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã, Skr. ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§§.

‡§¶‡§æ of the present participle of roots, as ‡§ï‡§∞‡§¶‡§æmasc. ‘doing’, ‡§Ü‡§ñ‡§¶‡§æ masc. ‘saying’ &c. A modern instance is ‡§∏‡§ó‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¶ for the Sanskrit ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø.

The Sindhi preserves the ≈öaurasenƒ´ present participial affix ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã or ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã, sometimes changed to ‡§á‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã throughout, as in ‡§π‡§≤‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã ‘moving’, ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã ‘doing’, ‡§π‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã ‘being’, &c. The same change is observable in other words also as in ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¶‡§ø for Sanskrit ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø.

The Gujarati has the few instances of the ≈öaurasenƒ´ past passive participle in ‡§¶ as in ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§Ç ’eaten’, ‡§™‡•Ä‡§¶‡•Å ‘drunk’‡§ï‡•Ä‡§¶‡•Å‡§Ç ‘done’, &c. Marathi has ‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶ for Skr. ‡§§‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§¶ ‘belly’, and Gujarati ‡§¶‡•Å‡§Ç‡§¶.

The labial surd ‡§™‡•ç is, when uninitial, softened in the Prakrits to ‡§µ‡•ç. The ‡§µ‡•ç is preserved by the Marathi unchanged, but the Hindi softens it in some cases still further to ‡§â as already shown(p. 433), and drops it in a great many more cases, according to a very general rule to be hereafter noticed, while the Gujarati changes it sometimes to ‡§Æ‡•ç. The Sindhi and Bengali follow the Hindi to a large extent in this latter respect. Thus:‚Äî

[Table 54: ‡§™‡•ç softened to ‡§µ‡•ç or ‡§â or ‡§Æ‡•ç]

Skr. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä 3 well, Pr. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä, M. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§µ, G. H. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§µin ‡§¨‡§æ‡§µ‡§°‡•Ä, S. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§á P. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§â in ‡§¨‡§æ‡§â‡§°‡•Ä.

Skr. ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§É & well, Pr. ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§µ‡•ã, G. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§µ‡•ã, H, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ü, 8, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§π‡•ã for ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ì.

Skr. ‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§ü a door, Pr. ‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§°, M. ‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§°, H. ‡§ï‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§°, G. ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§æ‡§°.

Skr. ‡§õ‡•Å‡§™‡•ç to touch, Pr. ‡§õ‡§ø‡§µ or ‡§õ‡•Å‡§µ, M. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ-[‡§£‡•á‡§Ç], H. P. B. ‡§õ‡•Ç-[‡§®‡§æ &c,] O.‡§õ‡•Å‡§Ç or ‡§õ‡•Å‡§Ç‡§á, S.‡§õ‡•Å‡§Ö-[‡§£‡•Å] or ‡§õ‡•Å‡§π-[‡§£‡•Å].

Skr. ‡§§‡§æ‡§™ to hest, Pr, ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ, M. G. H. ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ-[‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç-‡§®‡§æ]. S. ‡§§‡§æ‡§á [‡§£‡•Å].

Skr. ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§ a barber, Pr. ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ö or ‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ö M. ‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä, G. ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä H. S. ‡§®‡§æ‡§à.

Skr. ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‚Äì‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï a cowherd, Pr. ‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤-‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ö, M. ‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ, M. G. ‡§ó‡§µ‡§≤‡•Ä, G. ‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã H. ‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä, ‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤ (= ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ü‡§≤), ‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä, S. ‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å.

Skr. ‡§ï‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§™‡§É a tortoise, Pr. ‡§ï‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§µ‡•ã H. ‡§ï‡§õ‡•Å‡§Ü, S. ‡§ï‡§õ‡§â‚Äå‡§Ç, ‡§ï‡§õ‡•Ç‡§Ç, M. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ.

Skr. ‡§∏‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä a fellow-wife, Pr. ‡§∏‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä, M. ‡§∏‡§µ‡§§, H. ‡§∏‡•å‡§§.

Skr. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§™‡§¶ name of the sixth month, Pr. ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§µ‡§Ö, M. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§¶‡§µ‡§æ, H. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã, S. ‡§¨‡§°‡•ã.

The lingual surd aspirate ‡§†‡•ç is, it will be remembered, changed in the Prakrits to ‡§¢‡•ç, and the vernaculars, especially the Hindi, have preserved the instances and even added to them, as will be seen from the following:‚Äî

[Table 55: ‡§†‡•ç changed to ‡§¢‡•ç]

Skr. ‡§™‡§† to read Pr. ‡§™‡•ù, M. H. P. S. ‡§™‡§¢ in ‡§™‡•ù‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§®‡§æ-‡§£‡•Å. In H. and P., however, the pronunciation of ‡§¢is somewhat different from what it is in M, and in S. it sounds like the conjunct ‡§°‡•ç‡§π.

Skr. ‡§™‡•Ä‡§†‡§ï & stool, Pr. ‡§™‡•Ä‡§¢‡§Ö, H. ‡§™‡•Ä‡§¢‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§™‡•Ä‡§†‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ & series (of generations), Fr. ‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§Ü, H. ‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡•Ä, M. ‡§™‡§ø‡§°‡•Ä, G. ‡§™‡•á‡§¢‡•Ä.

Skr, ‡§Æ‡§† or ‡§Æ‡§†‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ a small temple, Pr. ‡§Æ‡§¢, H. P. ‡§Æ‡§°‡•Ä, old M. ‡§Æ‡§°.

Skr ‡§¶‡§Ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ, Pr. ‡§¶‡§æ‡§¢‡§æ, H. ‡§°‡§æ‡§¢, M. G. ‡§¶‡§æ‡§¢.

Similarly we have H. ‡§≤‡•Å‡§¢‡§®‡§æ ’to roll’ from Skr. ‡§≤‡•Å‡§†‡•ç. In the word ‡§¶‡§æ‡§¢‡§æ, the ‡§¢‡§æ does not represent ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•ç‡§∞ but ‡§†‡•ç‡§†, to which thst Skr. conjunct must by the general rules be reduced in the Prakrits. One of

the two ‡§†‡•ç is dropped, and the preceding vowel lengthened according to a general rule in the vernaculars to be hereafter noticed. The remaining ‡§†‡•ç is softened to ‡§¢‡•ç. There are other instances of the same change in our dialects. Thus:–

[Table 56:‡§ü‡•ç changed to ‡§¢‡•ç].

‡§µ‡•á‡§¢ of M. ‡§µ‡•á‡§¢‡§£‡•á‡§Ç 8. ‡§µ‡•á‡§°‡§π‡§£‡•Å, ‡§¨‡•á‡§¢ of H. ‡§¨‡•á‡§¢‡§®‡§æ, ‡§¨‡•á‡§° of B. ‡§µ‡•á‡§°‡§® ’to surround’ from Skr. ‡§µ‡•á‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü through Pr.‡§µ‡•á‡§¢. The Gujarati, however, has ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§†‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç.

‡§ï‡§æ‡§¢ of M. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§¢‡§£‡•á‡§Ç, G. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§¢‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç, H. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§¢‡§®‡§æ; ‡§ï‡§¢ of S ‡§ï‡§¢‡§£‡•Å, B. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§°‡§Ç to draw out, ‘from Pr.,‡§ï‡§ü‡•ç‡§† Skr.‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü.

‡§ï‡•Ç‡§¢ ofH. ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§¢‡§®‡§æ to mourn, from Pr.‡§ï‡•Å‡§†‡•ç‡§†, Skr.‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü. Even here the Gujarati has ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§ü‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç.

H.‡§ï‡•ã‡§¢, M. G.‡§ï‡•ã‡§°, S.‡§ï‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§π‡•Å white leprosy, from Skr. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü through Pr.‡§ï‡•ã‡§†‡•ç‡§†.

The ‡§†‡•ç arising from the Sanskrit ‡§•‡•ç is also similarly changed to ‡§¢‡•ç. M.‡§∏‡§¢‡§≤, H.‡§¢‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ, &c., from the Skr.‡§∂‡§ø‡§•‡§ø‡§≤ as in Table 29.

M. ‡§ï‡§¢‡§£‡•á‡§Ç to boil, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§¢‡§æ decoction, ‡§ï‡§¢‡•Ä urry, ‡§ï‡§¢‡§à cauldron, G, ‡§ï‡§¶, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ü‡•ã, &0. H. ‡§ï‡§¢‡§®‡§æ, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§¢‡§æ, ‡§ï‡§¢‡•Ä, &c., all from the Skr. root ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§•‡•ç.

We have noticed the change of ‡§°‡•ç to ‡§∞‡•ç and ‡§≤‡•ç, and of ‡§∞‡•ç to ‡§≤‡•ç, in the Prakrits. Not only have the vernaculars preserved the words so changed, but have carried on the process to such an extent that ‡§≤‡•ç and ‡§∞‡•ç have become mutually interchangeable in some of them, especially the Hindi.

[Table 57: ‡§°‡•ç changed to ‡§≤‡•ç]

Skr. ‡§§‡§°‡§æ‡§ó a tank, Pr.‡§§‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ö, M. G.‡§§‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ, H.‡§§‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç,H.‡§§‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ, S. B.‡§§‡§≤‡§æ‡§â.

Skr. ‡§¶‡§æ‡§°‡§ø‡§Æ pomegranate, Pr. ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ, M. ‡§°‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¨, G. ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ, H. B. ‡§°‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ H. ‡§¶‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ.

Skr.‡§ó‡•Å‡§° molasses, Pr.‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤,

Skr. ‡§™‡•Ä‡§° of ‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡§Ø‡§§‡§øto torment, to twist, Pr. ‡§™‡•Ä‡§≤, M. ‡§™‡§ø‡§≤‡§£‡•á‡§Ç, G. ‡§™‡§≤‡§ø‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç, H. ‡§™‡§ø‡§≤‡§®‡§æ, &c.

The numerals with their ‡§¶‡•ç changed in the Prakrits to ‡§∞‡•ç through an intermediate ‡§° have come down to the vernaculars:‚Äî
[Table 58:‡§¶‡•çof Skr. Numerals changed to ‡§∞‡•ç]

The other Prakrit words ‡§¶‡•ã‡§π‡§≤ and ‡§ï‡§≤‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨ in which the ‡§¶‡•çof the Sanskrit ‡§¶‡•ã‡§π‡§¶ and ‡§ï‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨ is changed to ‡§≤‡•çare preserved in Marathi in the forms of ‡§°‡•ã‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ snd ‡§ï‡§≤‡§Ç‡§¨. Similarly ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æand ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞ with the ‡§∞‡•ç so changed appear in the vernaculars as shown before.

S. ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ö‡§∞‡•Å, ‡§®‡•á‡§∞, or ‡§®‡•á‡§≤‡•Å fetters, from Skr. ‡§®‡§ø‡§ó‡§°.

H. P. ‡§®‡•á‡§∞‡•á, Pr. ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ö‡§°‡•á, Skr. ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§ü‡•á near.

Though the change of ‡§≤‡•ç to ‡§∞‡•ç does not involve softening, but, must be considered to be due to a predilection for the sound, it would be convenient to notice it here. There is only one instance of this change given by Hemacandra as existing in the MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´,

but there are a great many in the vernaculars, so that this appears to be a peculiarly modern process. The Hindi and the Sindhi have, however, of all the vernaculars, the largest number of examples, the rest presenting but a few stray ones. Sometimes both the forms with ‡§≤‡•ç and ‡§∞‡•ç are in use, especially in the Hindi.

[Table 60: ‡§≤‡•ç changed to ‡§∞‡•ç in vernaculars]

Skr.‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡•Ç‡§≤, Pr**.‡§•‡•ã‡§∞**, M.‡§•‡•ã‡§∞ large, great.

H. G.‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ó‡§∞, M.G. ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§∞, S.‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ó‡§∞‡•Å, Skr. ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤ a plough, or anchor.

H. ‡§ï‡•å‡§∞ or ‡§ï‡•å‡§≤, Skr. ‡§ï‡§µ‡§≤ a morsel; ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§∞ or ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§≤, Skr. ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§≤‡§ø dust; ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞, Skr. ‡§∂‡•É‡§ó‡§æ‡§≤, & jackal; ‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§®‡§æ, Pr. ‡§∏‡§≤‡§æ‡§π, Skr. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ò‡•ç to praise; ‡§¶‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§∞ Skr. ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡•ç‡§≤‡§≤ & spoilt child; ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä, Skr. ‡§∂‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ñ‡§≤‡§æ a chain; ‡§¨‡§æ‡§∞‡§®‡§æ, Skr. ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤ (caus. of ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤) to burn; ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ã (Braj) for ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ, Skr. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ï dark.

S. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡•ã, Skr. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ï‡§É dark; ‡§™‡§ø‡§™‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å, Skr. ‡§™‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§≤‡§É a certain tree; ‡§™‡§ú‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•Å, Skr. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤ to light or burn; ‡§™‡§ß‡§ø‡§∞‡§£‡•Å, Skr. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ó‡§≤ to melt; , Skr. ‡§π‡§≤ a plough, &c.

G. ‡§Ö‡§ü‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä, Skr. ‡§Ö‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ a high mansion; M. ‡§∂‡•á‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä or ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨‡§∞‡•Ä, Skr. ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤‡•Ä the silk-cotton tree.

[INTERCHANGEABLENESS OF ‡§°‡•ç, ‡§∞‡•ç AND ‡§≤‡•ç]

N‚Äåotable instances of the interchangeableness of ‡§°‡•ç, ‡§∞‡•ç and ‡§≤‡•ç, are afforded by the causal forms of verbal roots in some of the vernaculars. In Hindi, the causal of roots ending in a vowel is formed by inserting ‡§≤‡•ç between it and the termination ‡§Ü which is the remnant of the old Prakrit ‡§Ü‡§µ pr‚Äåeserved in the Braj and other dialects; as ‡§™‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ caus. of ‡§™‡•Ä ’to drink, ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ of ‡§ñ‡§æ to eat, ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ of ‡§¶‡•á ’to give’, ‡§ß‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ of ‡§ß‡•ã ’to wash’, &c. In Gujarati we have ‡§°‡•ç for ‡§≤‡•ç as ‡§ñ‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç to cause to eat,’ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç ’to cause to give,’ ‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç’to cause to bathe,’ ‘wash’ &c. Sometimes instead of ‡§°‡•ç, ‡§∞‡•ç is optionally used as in ‡§ñ‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç ’to cause to eat,’ ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§π‡•Ä‡§¨‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç ’to threaten,’ &c. But in Sindhi ‡§∞‡•ç always represents the Hindi ‡§≤‡•ç and the Gujarati ‡§¢‡•ç, as in ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ü‡§∞‡§£‡•Å ’to cause to give, ‡§ß‡•Å‡§Ü‡§∞‡§£‡•Å’to cause to wash,’ ‡§µ‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•Å ’to cause to sit’.

What the origin is of the ‡§°‡•ç of these forms, which is more primitive than the ‡§≤‡•ç and ‡§∞‡•ç to which it was afterwards changed, will be considered in the next lecture.

Another peculiarly vernacular process, of which Hemacandra gives only one instance, is the transformation of ‡§®‡•ç into ‡§≤‡•ç, in which ‡§®‡•ç is deprived of its nasal element and the complete contact of the vocal organs avoided. Thus:‚Äî

[Table 61 Skr. ‡§®‡•ç initial changed to ‡§≤‡•ç in vernaculars]

Skr. ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨ a certain tree, Pr. ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨ or ‡§®‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨, for, M. ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¨.

M. ‡§≤‡§µ‡§£‡•á to bow, Skr. ‡§®‡§Æ‡§®; ‡§≤‡•ã‡§£‡•Ä butter, Skr. ‡§®‡§µ‡§®‡•Ä‡§§ H. ‡§≤‡•å‡§ü‡§®‡§æ to return, Skr. ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§, Pr. ‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü; G.‡§≤‡•Ä‡§≤ blue, Skr. ‡§®‡•Ä‡§≤; P.‡§≤‡§≤‡•á‡§∞, a cocoanut, Skr. ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•á‡§≤, H. ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á‡§≤.

But there are more instances of the opposite process in the Prakrits; and these have come down to the vernaculars.

[Table 62: Skr. initial ‡§≤‡•ç changed to ‡§®‡•ç in vernaculars]

M. G. ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§∞ a plough or anchor, P. ‡§Æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§É or ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§≤.

M. ‡§®‡§ø‡§¢‡§≤, S. ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§°‡•Å, Pr. ‡§®‡§ø‡§°‡§æ‡§≤ or ‡§£‡§°‡§æ‡§≤, Skr. ‡§≤‡§≤‡§æ‡§ü forehead.

The H. ‡§®‡•Ç‡§® salt, Skr. ‡§≤‡§µ‡§£ ‚Äåis a later instance.

The sibilant ‡§∏‡•ç, whether original or derived from the Sanskrit ‡§û‡•ç, or ‡§∏‡•ç, is in a few cases changed to ‡§°‡•ç in the Prakrits. For ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§∏ ‘a day’ we have ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§π or ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ö‡§π, for ‡§™‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ‡§£ ‘a stone’ ‡§™‡§π‡§æ‡§£, and for ‡§¶‡§∂‡§®‡•ç ’ten’ ‡§¶‡§π. These words, so changed, have come down to the vernaculars, and are found in one or other of them. The various forms of the numerals having the word ‡§¶‡§∂ at the end have been given above. Of the other words G. has ‡§¶‡§ø‡§π ‘a day’ and ‡§¶‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§°‡•ã with the suffix ‡§°‡•ã, P. ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π and ‡§¶‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§°‡§æ‡§º, and S. ‡§°‡§ø‡§º‡§Ç‡§π‡•Å and ‡§°‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§¢‡•ã; and S. ‡§™‡§π‡§£‡§â ‘a stone’. The Sindhi and the Panjabi have given a wider range to this process, as will be seen from the following:‚Äî

[Table 63: ‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§∂‡•ç or ‡§∑‡•ç changed to ‡§π in Vernaculars]

S. ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å or ‡§¨‡•Å‡§π‡•ã chaff, Skr. ‡§¨‡•Å‡§∏, M. ‡§≠‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ.

S. ‡§¨‡§ø‡§π‡•Å lotus-stalk, Skr. ‡§¨‡§ø‡§π‡•Å, M. ‡§≠‡§ø‡§∏‡•á‡§Ç.

S. ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø a buffalo, Skr. ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡•Ä, M. ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•à‡§∏.

S. ‡§µ‡•á‡§π‡§£‡•Å to sit, Skr. ‡§â‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂, M. ‡§¨‡•à‡§∏‡§£‡•á‡§Ç, G. ‡§¨‡•á‡§∏‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç.

S. ‡§¨‡•á‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•Å trust, Skr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏.

P. ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§π, S. ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§π twenty, Skr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂-[ ‡§§‡§ø], M. ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∏.

P. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π or ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏, S. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡•Å or ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ñ‡•Å poison, Skr, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑, M. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏.

P. ‡§∏‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ, S. ‡§∏‡§π‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã, Skr ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞, M. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ father-in-law.

P. ‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ thirst, Skr. ‡§§‡•É‡§∑‡§æ.

P. ‡§´‡§æ‡§π‡§æ or ‡§´‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä, S. ‡§´‡§æ‡§π‡•ã or ‡§´‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä & snare noose Skr. ‡§™‡§æ‡§∂, M. ‡§´‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏.

Gujaratis, especially of the uneducated classes, pretty freely pronounce ‡§Æ‡•ç as ‡§π‡•ç as in ‡§π‡§Æ‡§ú‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç for ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§ú‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç ’to understand,’ ‡§¨‡§∞‡§π for ‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏ ’s year’ ‡§π‡§æ‡§ö‡•Å‡§Ç for ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ö‡•Å‡§Ç ’true’, &c. but the forms with ‡§Æ‡•ç are also in use. The other dialects do not seem to have many instances of this change. The termination ‡§Æ‡•ç of verbs of the future tense is in several dialects of the Hindi changed to ‡§π as in ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡•à, G. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§∏‡•á ‘he will do’.

The change of ‡§Æ to ‡§µ‡§Ç seems to be an almost entirely later process of which there are scarcely any instances in the Prakrits. It is seen in full operation in the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa.

[Table 64 Skr. ‡§Æ changed to ‡§µ]

Skr. ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ name, M. ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ, H, ‡§®‡§æ‡§ì‡§Ç, old H. ‡§®‡§æ‡§ä‡§Ç, also ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ, P. ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§â‡§Ç, S. ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç‡§â‡§Ç also ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å and ‡§®‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã.

Skr. ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ a tying rope, M. ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ç, P. ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç‡§â, H. ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ in ‡§¶‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä.

Skr. ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ & village, M. H. ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ, H. ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ also; S. ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç‡§â, ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å.

Skr. ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§£ to turn round, M. ‡§≠‡•ã‡§Ç‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§Ç, P. ‡§≠‡•å‡§Ç‡§Ç‡§£‡§æ, S. ‡§≠‡•å‡§Ç‡§£‡§£‡•Å; from the same root, M. ‡§≠‡•ã‡§Ç‡§µ‡§≤, H. ‡§≠‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞, S. ‡§≠‡•å‡§Ç‡§∞‡•Ä.

Skr. ‡§®‡§Æ‡§®, M. ‡§≤‡§µ‡§£‡•á, H. ‡§®‡§µ‡§®‡§æ-‡§≤‡•å‡§®‡§æ-‡§®‡•á‡§µ‡§®‡§æ.

Skr, ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§®‡§Æ‡§® to bow down, M.‡§ì‡§£‡§Ç‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§Ç.

Skr. ‡§Ü‡§ö‡§Æ‡§® to rinse the mouth, M. ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§Ç, H. ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§®‡§æ, & also ‡§Ö‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡§æ.

Skr, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ rest, M. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ, S. ‡§µ‡•á‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø.

Skr. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤ dark-complexioned, M. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ, H. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ-‡§∞‡§æ. P. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ and ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ, 8. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã.

Skr. ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ï son-in-law, M. ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§à, but H. ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§æ‡§à, P. ‡§ú‡§µ‡§æ‡§á or ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§æ‡§á.

Skr. ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§® rising M. ‡§â‡§ó‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§Ç, but P. ‡§â‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§Æ‡§£‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡§≤‡§ï & kind of myrobalans, M. P. ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ, H. P. ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ, P. ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ also, S. ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§â‡§∞‡•ã.

Skr. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ a chief, M. H. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§§.

Skr. ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Æ‡§∞na sort of fly-brush, M. ‡§ö‡•å‡§∞‡•Ä, H. P. ‡§ö‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∞, B. ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•Å.

Skr. ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤ a lotus, H. P. ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§µ‡§≤, M. ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤, S. ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•Å.

Skr. ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§®caus. spending, wasting. H. ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ, P. ‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§â‡§£‡§æ, S. ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§á‡§£‡•Å, but M. ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§µ‡§£‡•á.

Skr, ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§∞ bee, H. ‡§≠‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ Or ‡§≠‡•å‡§Ç‡§∞‡§æ, P. ‡§≠‡•å‡§Ç‡§∞ or ‡§≠‡•å‡§Ç‡§∞‡§æ, S. ‡§≠‡•å‡§Ç‡§∞‡•Å.

Skr. ‡§™‡§û‡•ç‡§ö‡§Æ fifth, M. ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§æ, H. ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç, P. ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ú‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç, &c., and other ordinals.

Skr. ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Æ‡§≤ delicate, tender, M.‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§® eating, M. ‡§ú‡•á‡§µ‡§£, H. ‡§ú‡•á‡§µ‡§®, P. ‡§ú‡•á‡§Ç‡§â‡§£‡§æ,

Skr. ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ mud, H. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ã, G. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§µ.

From the fact that the Marathi, Hindi, Sindhi, and Panjabi contain many instances of this change it is to be gathered that though it does not appear in the Prakrits proper, it must have begun very early, before the vernaculars received their distinctive forms and were isolated from each other. Of all the dialects the Marathi alone has preserved the ‡§µ‡•ç of this ‡§µ‡§Ç in most cases, the Hindi and the others having dropped it or softened it to ‡§â in good many instances; while the Gujarati changes it back again to ‡§Æ‡•ç. Thus, such of the above words as exist in Gujarati have the following forms:‚Äî
[Table 65:‡§µ‡§Ç (Skr.‡§Æ‡•ç) changed to ‡§Æ‡•ç in Gujarati]
‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ name. ‡§ö‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ä a fly-brush.
‡§ó‡§æ‡§Æ a village. ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤ a lotus.
‡§≠‡§Æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç to turn round, ‡§≠‡§Æ‡§∞‡•Ä giddiness, corresponding to M. ‡§≠‡•ã‡§Ç‡§µ‡§≤. ‡§≠‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ã a bee.
‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§µ‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç wasting. ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§Æ‡•ã, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§§‡§Æ‡•ã, &c., fifth, seventh, &c.
‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ã rest. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ã delicate.
‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§≤‡•ã a dark-complexioned. ‡§ú‡§Æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç eating.
‡§ú‡§Æ‡§æ‡§á son-in-law. ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ myrobalans.

The reason why I consider this as a change of ‡§µ‡§Ç back to ‡§Æ‡•ç and not a preservation of the original Sanskrit and Prakrit ‡§Æ‡•ç, is that the Gujarati changes ‡§µ‡•ç to ‡§Æ‡•ç in other cases where there is no question as to the ‡§µ‡•ç (or ‡§™‡•ç) being the original sound. Thus:‚Äî

[Table 66: ‡§µ‡•ç or ‡§™‡•ç changed to ‡§Æ‡•ç in Gujarati]

G. ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§æ‡§° a door, H. ‡§ï‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§°, M. ‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§°, Pr. ‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§°, Skr. ‡§ï‡§™‡§æ‡§ü.

G. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ blackwood, M. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∏‡§µ‡§æ, Pr. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡§µ, Skr. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§™.

G. ‡§™‡§æ‡§Æ‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç to attain, M. ‡§™‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§Ç, Pr. ‡§™‡§æ‡§µ, Skr. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™.

G. ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ in ‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ç‡§°‡§ß‡§æ‡§Æ running, Skr. ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç.

Where in Marathi we have ‡§µ‡•ç or ‡§¨‡•ç, the Gujarati has in some cases ‡§Æ‡•ç, as in G. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ä a blow, M. ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ä, G. ‡§†‡§æ‡§Æ ‘& place of residence’, M. ‡§†‡§æ‡§µ, derived in some way from Skr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™.

There are traces of this change in some of the other dialects too :‚Äî

[Table 66 A: ‡§Æ‡•ç for ‡§™‡•ç ]

S. P. ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§®‡§§, B. ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡§§‡§ø, corresponding to M. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø, H. ‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡§§‡§ø, Pr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, Skr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‘solicitation’; B. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§õ‡§ø‡§Æ, Pr. ‡§ï‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§µ, Skr. ‡§ï‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§™ ’tortoise’: H. ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Æ‡§∞, Skr. ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§µ‡§∞ ‘a fisherman’; old M. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§, G. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§§, Skr. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ’news’: B. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§õ, H. ‡§™‡•Å‡§Ç‡§õ [ ‡§®‡§æ ], Skr ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§û‡•ç‡§õ‡•ç ’to wipe away’.

This phenomenon of the change of ‡§µ‡•ç to ‡§Æ‡•ç the vernaculars, and especially the Gujarati, have inherited from the Piakrits. Of the words so changed the Gujarati has preserved ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§£‡•Å‡§Ç ‘a dream’, the Prakrit form being ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§£ or ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§£, and some of the others, ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Æ ‘kind of tree’. This last is ‡§®‡•Ä‡§™ in Sanskrit; but probably there was an intermediate form ‡§®‡•Ä‡§µ.

The vernaculars have thrown away the aspiration of hard and soft aspirate mutes in a good many cases. Thus:‚Äî

[Table 67: Disaspiration in the Vernaculars]
M. ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ï learn, Pr. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ, H. ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ñ.
M. ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§ï beggary, Pr. ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ, H. ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§ñ,S. ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ñ.
M. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡§£‡•á‡§Ç to dry, Pr. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï or ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ, H. ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ñ‡§®‡§æ,S. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡§£‡•Å.
M. ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§ï hunger, Pr. ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ü‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ H. ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§ñ,S.‡§¨‡•Å‡§ñ,
M. ‡§π‡§æ‡§§ hand, Pr. ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§•, H. ‡§π‡§æ‡§•.
M. ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Äelephant, Pr. ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä, H. ‡§π‡§æ‡§•‡•Ä.
G. ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§®‡•ã afraid, Pr. ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§¶‡•ã or ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§ì, M. ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ.
G, ‡§¨‡§°‡§æ‡§à greatness, Pr. ‡§µ‡§°‡•ç‡§¢ H. ‡§µ‡§¢‡§æ‡§à.
G. ‡§¨‡§ó‡§æ‡§°‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç to spoil, Pr. ‡§¨‡§ø‡§ò‡§°, M. ‡§¨‡§ø‡§ò‡§°‡§£‡•á.
B. ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡§ø a book, Pr. ‡§™‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§Ü, H. M. ‡§™‡•ã‡§•‡•Ä.
B. ‡§™‡§° to learn, Pr. ‡§™‡§¢, H. M., &c. ‡§™‡§°.
B. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§° to grow, Pr. ‡§µ‡§°‡•ç‡§¢, H. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¢-[‡§£‡•á‡§Ç],H.‡§¨‡§æ‡§¢-‡§¢‡§¨-[‡§®‡§æ].
B. ‡§µ‡•á‡§° to surround, Pr ‡§µ‡•á‡§¢, M. ‡§µ‡•á‡§°-[‡§£‡•á‡§Ç], H. ‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç‡§¢-[‡§®‡§æ],&c,
B. ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§∞ stones Pr. ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§∞, M. ‡§™‡§æ‡§•‡§∞, H. ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§∞ or ‡§™‡§æ‡§ö‡§∞.
B. ‡§™‡§ø‡§ü back, Pr. ‡§™‡§ø‡§†‡•ç‡§† or ‡§™‡§†‡•ç‡§† H. ‡§™‡•Ä‡§†, M. ‡§™‡§æ‡§†.
B. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶ wish, Pr. ‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ, S, P. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§•.

B. ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡§É (in ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ‡§®) to dry, Pr. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ, or ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï, H. ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ñ‡§®‡§æ.

B. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§° (in ‡§ï‡§æ‡§°‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ) to take out, Pr. ‡§ï‡§†‡•ç‡§†, H. M. &c. H.M &c. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§°.

B. ‡§™‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞ a pond, Pr. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä.

And in such forms as ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ‡§á‡§≤‡•á ‘worn’ from Pr. ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç, ‡§®‡§æ‡§á‡§§‡•á , ‘for bathing’ from Pr. ‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ, or ‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ and ‡§°‡§æ‡§á‡§® ’to the right hand,’ Pr.‡§¶‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§£, the aspirate ‡§á is dropped, so that the Bengali has, in a large number of instances, thus weakened the pronunciation of aspirated sounds. In the instances given from Marathi, it will be seen that the letters other than those which are softened are aspirates; hence the weakening consists simply in dropping the heavy breath in one of two aspirated sounds, as in the case of the Sindhi ‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ñ and ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ñ. The aspirates are preserved when occurring singly, which is not the case in Bengali. Hence Bengali utterance is the weakest, and the Hindi and Panjabi the strongest.

The Marathi reduces a Sanskrit or Prakrit ‡§Æ‡•ç invariably to ‡§∏‡•ç, and in this respect differs from all its cognate dialects. Thus:‚Äî

[Table 68: Skr. or Prk. ‡§õ‡•ç reduced to ‡§∏‡•ç in Marathi]

Skr. ‡§á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å sugarcane, Pr.‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Å, M. ‡§ä‡§∏. The H. has ‡§à‡§ñ or ‡§ä‡§ñ.

Skr. ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø fish, Pr. ‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ, H, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§õ, M. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏ a calf, Pr. ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ, H. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§õ, M. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏ in ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ç.

Skr. ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ a knife, Pr. ‡§õ‡•Å‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ü, H. ‡§õ‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä, M. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä.

Skr. ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ a fly, Pr. ‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø‡§Ü, H. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§õ‡•Ä, M. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä.

Skr. ‡§™‡•É‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ to ask, Pr. ‡§™‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ, H. ‡§™‡•Å‡§õ‡§®‡§æ, M. ‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡§£‡•á‡§Ç.

Skr. ‡§ï‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§™ tortoise, Pr. ‡§ï‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ, H. ‡§ï‡§õ‡•Å‡§Ü, M. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ,

Skr. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø a side of the abdomen, Pr.‡§ï‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ø, M. ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§∏. The H. has ‡§ï‡•ã‡§∏.

Skr. ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ a field, Pr.‡§õ‡•á‡§§, M. ‡§∂‡•á‡§§. But H. has ‡§ñ‡•á‡§§.

Skr. ‡§õ‡•Å‡§™ to touch, Pr. ‡§õ‡•Å‡§µ, H. ‡§õ‡•Ç-[‡§®‡§æ], M.‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ-[‡§£‡•á‡§Ç].

Skr. ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ s‚Äå‚Äåhade, Pr.‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ü, H.‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ, M.‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ-[‡§≤‡•Ä].

Skr. ‡§ó‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õa bunch, Pr.‡§ó‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ, H.‡§ó‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ, M.‡§ò‡•ã‡§Ç‡§∏.

Skr. ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ólap, Pr. ‡§ì‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó, M. ‡§ì‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó.

Skr. ‡§õ‡§æ‡§ó‡§≤‡•Ä a she-gost, Pr. ‡§õ‡§æ‡§Ö‡§≤‡•Ä or ‡§õ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä, H. ‡§õ‡•á‡§∞‡•Ä, M, ‡§∂‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä.

Skr. ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§£worn out, wasted, Pr. ‡§õ‡•Ä‡§£, M. ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§£-[‡§£‡•á‡§Ç].

Skr. ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£a festival, Pr. ‡§õ‡§£, M.‡§∏‡§£.

According to a general rule in Marathi, ‡§Æ‡•ç is changed to ‡§∂when followed by the palatal vowel ‡§áor‡§è. This change of ‡§≤‡•ç to ‡§∏‡•ç in this dialect is to be accounted for by the fact that the vocal organs of the Marathas have a predilection for the dento-palatals, ‡§ö, ‡§õ, ‡§ú, ‡§ù, to which the Sanskrit palatals are in almost all cases reduced by them, except when they are followed by ‡§á, ‡§è, or ‡§Ø‡•ç. The Sanskrit ‡§õ‡•ç therefore becoming the dento-palatal ‡§õ‡•ç passes into ‡§Æ‡•ç which differs from it only in the contact of the vocal organs being somewhat less incomplete. The only instances in the Prakrits in which the change appears to be the same as that we have been considering are ‡§ä‡§∏‡§µ‡•ã for ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§µ‡•ã and ‡§ä‡§∏‡•Å‡§ìfor ‡§ä‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ì.

I have already given instances of the many words with their uninitial consonants dropped which the vernaculars have inherited from the Prakrits, and shown what further changes they have undergone. This process of elision has not been continuedby any of the vernaculars unless we consider the disappearance of uninitial ‡§µ‡•ç (which is very general in Hindi, Sindhi, and Bengali) to be an instance of the process.

[Table 69: Uninitial ‡§µ‡•çdropped in Hindi, Bengali, &c.]

B. H. ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ, S. ‡§°‡§ø‡§ì lamp, Pr. ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§µ‡§ì, Skr. ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï‡§É, M. ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ.

H. ‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ, S. ‡§®‡§ì‡§Ç new, Pr. ‡§®‡§µ‡§ì, M. ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ.

H. ‡§ú‡•Ä, S. ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§â life, Pr. ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§ì, Skr. ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ‡§É M. ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§µ.

H. S. ‡§®‡§æ‡§à, B. ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ø a barber, Pr. ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ö or ‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ö, Skr. ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§, M. ‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä.

H. ‡§ï‡§õ‡•Å‡§Ü, S. ‡§ï‡§õ‡§â‡§Çtortoise, Pr. ‡§ï‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§µ‡§ì, Skr. ‡§ï‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§™‡§ï‡§É, M. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§µ.

H. ‡§õ‡•Ç-[‡§®‡§æ], S. ‡§õ‡•Å‡§Ö-[‡§£‡•Å], B. ‡§õ‡•ã(‡§õ‡•ã‡§Ø‡§æ s.) to touch, Pr. ‡§õ‡§ø‡§µor ‡§õ‡•Å‡§µ, Skr. ‡§õ‡•Å‡§™, M. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ-[‡§£‡•á‡§Ç].

H. ‡§™‡§æ-[‡§®‡§æ], S. ‡§™‡§æ‡§á-[‡§£‡•Å], Pr, ‡§™‡§æ‡§µ, Skr. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™, M. ‡§™‡§æ‡§µ-[‡§£‡•á‡§Ç].

H. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ü, S. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§π‡•äfor ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ì, B, ‡§ï‡•É‡§Ø‡§æa well, Pr. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§µ‡§ì, Skr. ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§É, G. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§µ‡•ã.

H. ‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤-‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ü‡§≤, B, ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ a cowherd, Pr. ‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ö, Skr, ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ï, M. ‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ.

H. ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§π = ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ü‡§π S. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§â marriage, Skr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§π.

H. ‡§™‡§†‡§æ-[‡§®‡§æ], S. ‡§™‡§†-[‡§£‡•Å], B. ‡§™‡§æ‡§†‡§æ‡§à-[‡§µ‡§æ] to send, Pr. ‡§™‡§†‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§µ, Skr. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™, M. ‡§™‡§æ‡§†‡§µ.

H, ‡§§‡§æ-[‡§®‡§æ], S. ‡§§‡§æ‡§á-[‡§£‡•Å] to heat, Pr. ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ, Skr. ‡§§‡§æ‡§™, M. ‡§§‡§æ‡§µ-[‡§£‡•á‡§Ç].

H. ‡§¶‡•Å‡§Ü‡§∞, B. ‡§¶‡•ã‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞ door, Pr. ‡§¶‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞ or ‡§¶‡•Å‡§Ü‡§∞ Skr. ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞.

B. ‡§¶‡•Å‡§átwo, Pr.‡§¶‡•Å‡§µ‡•á, Skr. ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•å.

B. ‡§®‡§Ø nine, Skr.‡§®‡§µ, M.‡§®‡§µ, H.‡§®‡•å.

B. ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ moss, Skr. ‡§∂‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤, H. ‡§∂‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤.

THE OF THE CAUSAL TERMINATIONS IN THE VERNACULARS.

This elision of ‡§µ‡•ç appears also in the Hindi causal forms such as‡§â‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡§æ, ‡§ö‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ, ‡§ú‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ, in which the ‡§Ü only of the Prakrit or Marathi termination ‡§Ü‡§µor ‡§Ö‡§µ is retained. The whole termination appears in the Braj and other dialects and in old books, sometimes in the form of ‡§î.

The Sindhi causal termination is ‡§Ü‡§áas in ‡§¨‡§ß‡§æ‡§á‡§£‡•Å ’to cause toincrease.‚ÄôThe ‡§á here as well as in some of the Sindhi words given above represents the ‡§Ø which according to the Prakrit rule, takes the place of the dropped ‡§µ, and is, as shown before, changed to ‡§è in the other vernaculars. The Sindhi ‡§á is a shortened form of this ‡§è. The termination ‡§Ü‡§áappears sometimes in its more original form of ‡§Ü‡§Ö as in ‡§µ‡§†‡§æ‡§Ö‡§£‡•Å ’to cause to take.‚Äô

The Bengali too forms its causal by adding ‡§Ü‡§áas in ‡§ß‡§∞‡§æ‡§á‡§§‡•á‡§õ‡•á‚Äôis causing to be held,‚Äô but the ‡§á here seems to be an euphonic addition, which even in their primitive form the verbs take, as in ‡§ß‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•á‡§õ‡•á‚Äòisholding,‚Äô so that the ‡§µ‡•ç is here dropped and the vowel ‡§Öcombined with the preceding as in the Hindi. In the speech of the Maratha lower classes of Southern Konkan ‡§µ‡•ç is very often elided, and the causal termination of the Savantvadi dialect is ‡§Ö‡§Ø, as in ‡§ï‡§∞‡§Ø ‘cause to do, which corresponds to the Sindhi ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§á-[‡§£‡•Å].

[Table 69 A : of ‡§Æ‡•ç dropped in the Vernaculars ]

There are instances also in which the ‡§µ‡•ç resulting from ‡§Æ‡•çis elided:‚Äî

H. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§∞ ‘a boy,‚Äô‚Äòa prince,‚Äô Pr.‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§∞, Skr. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞; ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ’left-hand-side, Pr. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§Ö, Skr. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§É, ‡§ß‡•Å‡§Ü‡§Ç ‚Äòsmoke,‚Äô Pr. ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§Ö, Skr. ‡§ß‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ï;‡§Ö‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡§æ; ‚Äòto rinse the mouth,‚Äô Pr. Skr. ‡§Ü‡§ö‡§Æ; or ‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡§æ’ ‚Äòtomock‚Äô,Skr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§°‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨; ‡§≠‡•Å‡§à ‚Äòground,‚Äô Skr.B.

There are traces of this change in other dialects too, as in the Oriya ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç for ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Æ ‚Äòleft,‚Äô Gujarati ‡§≠‡§æ‡§Ç‡§Ø = ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§à, S. ‡§≠‡•Å‡§á‡§Ç,Skr. ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø, and the Marathi‡§≠‡•Å‡§Ç‡§à and the termination ‡§à‡§Ç of the locative, which is to be traced to the Pr. ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø, Skr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç. In all these instances we may regard ‡§Æ‡•ç as directly elided, and not the ‡§µ‡•ç resulting from it. Hemacandra notices a few instances of the process in the Prakrits.

The vernaculars possess a large number of those Prakrit words, in which the mute element of hard and soft aspirates was dropped leaving only the ‡§á. Thus:‚Äî

[Table 70: Vernacular ‡§á for Skr. ‡§ñ]

Skr. ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡•Å‡§ï flattened rice,Pr.‡§™‡•Å‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü (?), M. ‡§™‡•ã‡§π‡•á, S. ‡§™‡•á‡§π‡•Ç‡§Ç.

Skr. ‡§¶‡§ß‡§ø curds Pr. ‡§¶‡§π‡§ø, H. M. G.P. O. ‡§¶‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç S. ‡§°‡§º‡§π‡§ø.

Skr. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‡•Å honest, good, Pr. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•Å, H. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•Å-‡§∏‡§æ‡§π M. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ.

Skr. ‡§µ‡§ß‡•Ç a young lady daughter-in-law H G.S. ‡§µ‡§π‡•Ç,O.‡§¨‡•ã‡§π‡•Å or ‡§¨‡•å.

Skr. ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ dressing, Pr. ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§æ, H. ‡§™‡§π‡§ø‡§∞-[‡§®‡§æ]. G. ‡§™‡•á‡§π‡§∞[‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç] S. ‡§™‡•á‡§π‡§∞[‡§£‡•Å],

P. ‡§™‡§π‡§ø‡§∞[‡§£‡§æ] by the consonants interchanging places.

[Table 74: Vernacular ‡§π for Skr. ‡§≠]

Skr. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ or ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§§ light, dawn, Pr, ‡§™‡§π‡§æ, ‡§™‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç‡§Ö, ‡§™‡§π‡§æ‡§¶, H. ‡§™‡§π or ‡§™‡•ã‡§π, G. ‡§™‡•ã‡§π, M. ‡§™‡§π‡§æ‡§ü. The S. ‡§™‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§πmust be a later form. From the same root with the prepositions ‡§µ‡§ø and ‡§∏‡•Å we have H. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§® morning, S . ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡§æ‡§â light, &c.

Skr. ‡§∂‡•Å‡§≠ to become to adorn, Pr. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π, H. ‡§∏‡•ã‡§π- [‡§®‡§æ]. S. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π-[‡§£‡•Å]

Skr, ‡§∏‡•å‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø prosperity good fortune, Pr. ‡§∏‡•ã‡§π‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó, H. ‡§∏‡•ã‡§π‡§æ‡§ó or ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡§æ‡§ó.

Similarly, H. ‡§™‡§π‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§® ‚Äòrecognise‚Äô is from Skr. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ, the consonants interchanging places; G. ‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã or ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡•ã‚Äòdear‚Äô from Skr. ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠‡§É‡§∏‡•á‡§π‡§≤‡•ã ’easy‚Äô from ‡§∏‡§≤‡§≠; ‡§µ‡•á‡§π‡§ö - [‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç] to ‚Äòdistribute or divide’ from ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡§ú‡•ç &c.

The existence of many such words as M. H. P. ‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§ß‘injury,‘H. P. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ß‚Äòa good man,’ M. G. H. P. ‡§Æ‡§ß ‘honey, H. G‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ,‡§≤‡§ñ ’to write,’ M. G. H. ‡§®‡§ñ‚Äònail,‚Äô S. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§≠‡§æ‡§£‡•á‘in the morning‚Äô shows that the popular speech of Northern India has now for a long time ceased to have recourse to this process of dropping the mute element of the aspirates of the Sanskrit words, adopted from time to time from the parent language. Still, however, a few laterinstances, such as S. ‡§™‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§π ‚Äòdawn,‚Äô H. G. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‚Äòmiddle‚Äô from ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ßand ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø, and some of the compounds of ‡§ò‡§∞ noticed above show that it has not been entirely absent.

The elision of simple mutes and of the mute element of aspirates is a natural phenomenon which one always meets with in the course of lingual development; but its operation is generally slow and it is only in consequence of its systematic occurrence. in the Prakrits that I have attributed it to an ethnological cause and have supposed that the Prakrit speakers belonged to another race than those who spoke Sanskrit and, being unused to Sanskrit sounds, caught only the initial consonants from their Sanskrit teachers and dropped the rest or the mute portion of the rest. When, however, in the course of time they became used to those sounds and the Sanskrit and Prakrit speaking races became united into one community, they ceased to be so dropped, except through the slow and gradual operation of the usual phonetiol laws; and hence it is that in modern times we find Sanskrit words, not shorn of their elements in the manner in which they were in ancient times, as indicated above.

This elision, though it involves economy and is a natural process, constitutes a peculiarity of the Prakrits in so far as it is duel to peculiar historical incidents. We will now notice the peculiarities which do not involve economy and must be attributed to vocal predilections. Of the words in which a Sanskrit dental is changed to a cerebral in the Prakrits the vernaculars have preserved the following:‚Äî

[Table 75: Skr. Dentals changed to Cerebrals in Vernaculars]

Skr. ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡§ïmyrobalan,Pr.‡§¨‡§π‡•á‡§°‡§æ‡§ì,M. ‡§¨‡•á‡§π‡§°‡§æ, &c. as in table 8.

Skr. ‡§™‡§§to fall, Pr, ‡§™‡§°, M. G.H. ‡§™‡§°- [‡§£‡•á-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç-‡§®‡§æ].

The Sindhi has the largest number of instances, and the Hindi and the Panjabi come next. The Marathi and Gujarati have the smallest number.

S. ‡§°‡§ø‡§º‡§†‡•ãseen, H. P. ‡§°‡•Ä‡§†, G. ‡§¶‡§ø‡§†‡•ã, Skr. ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü.

O. ‡§°‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç‡§£, B. ‡§°‡§æ‡§á‡§®to the right hand, H. ‡§¶‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡§æ.

Thus then the Pali and Prakrit tendency to pronounce dentals. as cerebrals is seen in a much more exaggerated form in the Sindhi and next to it in the Hindi and the Panjabi, while the other modern dialects seem to have kept it quite within the bounds in which we find it in the ancient dialects, though they have changed more words in that way than they.

In the following instances the cerebral mute in the place of the dental is to be considered as due to the influence of an adjoining ‡§∞‡•ç.

[Table 78: Dentals adjoining ‡§∞‡•çchanged to cerebral mute]

Uninitial is changed to ‡§£‡•ç in the Prakrits invariably, but when it is the beginning of a word is undergoes that change or optionally. In the vernaculars the initial remains unchanged, but when medial it becomes mostly in the Marathi, Gujarati, Sindhi, and Panjabi.

There are a few instances in which we have the original‡§®‡•ç in the body of a word, as in M. G. P. ‡§Æ‡§®,S.‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å, Skr. ‡§Æ‡§®‡§É ‘mind,‚ÄôG. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Ç‘promise’, for Skr.‡§µ‡§ö‡§®, and G. ‡§¨‡•á‡§®,as above. But the general in the rule seems to be that these four dialects have a medial ‡§®‡•ç place of the double ‡§£‡•ç of the Prakrits, resulting from a Sanskrit conjunct of which ‡§®‡•ç is a member. Thus:‚Äî

[Table 82 Prk. ‡§£changed to ‡§®‡•ç in the vernaculars]

Skr. ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø, Pr. ‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§£, M. G. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§® wilderness.

Skr. ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£, Pr. ‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§£, M. G. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®, P. ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§®, S. ‡§ï‡§®‡•Å ear.

Skr. ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§£, P. ‡§™‡§£, M. G. ‡§™‡§æ‡§®, P. ‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ. S. ‡§™‡§®‡•Å a leaf.

Skr. ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ (‡§ú‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ï‡§É), Pr. ‡§ú‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§£, M. ‡§ú‡•Å‡§®‡•á‡§Ç, G. ‡§ú‡•Å‡§®‡•Ç‡§Ç,. S. ‡§ù‡•Å‡§®‡•ã old.

Skr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§™, Pr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§µ, M. G. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§µ, - (‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç) to solicit.

Skr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, M. G. ‡§¨‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç‡§§‡•Ä, S. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§§‡•Ä,P. ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡§§solicitation.

Skr. ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ, Pr. ‡§∏‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ, G. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®, P. ‡§∏‡§® mark, sign.

Skr. ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ Pr. ‡§ú‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ, P. ‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡§§ a bridal procession also;S. ‡§ú‡§û, Skr, ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø, Pr. ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§û.

Skr. ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ã‡§™‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§, Pr. ‡§ú‡§£‡•ã‡§µ‡§à‡§Ö, G. ‡§ú‡§®‡•ã‡§à, P, ‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡§ä, M. ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç, 5 ‡§ú‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã, the Brahmanic sacred thread.

Skr. ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø, Pr. ‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§£ M. G. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®-[‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç]. S. ‡§Æ‡§®‡§£‡•Å, P. ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§£‡§æ to think, to regard, to obey.

But even here in Marathi, the purely Deshastha Brahmans living in the eastern part of the Deccan or MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠ra pronounce the ‡§®‡•ças ‡§£‡•ç; and the ordinary ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®, ‡§™‡§æ‡§®, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø, &c., of that dialect become in their mouths ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§£, ‡§™‡§æ‡§£, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø, &c. They have, therefore, preserved in its integrity the old habit of the Prakrit speakers to pronounce the ‡§®‡•ç as ‡§£‡•ç throughout. On the other hand, the lower class of the Konkani population preserve the Pai≈õacipeculiarty of reducing ‡§£‡•ç in all cases to ‡§®‡•ç and pronounce of, ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä, ‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä,‡§ï‡•ã‡§£, &c, as ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä, ‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä, ‡§ï‡•ã‡§®, &c, and this peculiarity we find in its fulness in the Hindi, and next to it in the Bengali. Thus the words with a ‡§£‡•ç in them in the Marathi, Gujarati, Sindhi and Panjabi, given above, have the following forms in Hindi:‚Äî

‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Ç‡§∏, ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§®‡§æ, ‡§ú‡§®, ‡§ï‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä, ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä, ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§æ, ‡§ï‡•å‡§®, ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§®,or‡§¨‡•à‡§®, ‡§ï‡§†‡§ø‡§®, ‡§ú‡§®‡§®‡§æ, ‡§≤‡•Ç‡§® or ‡§®‡•Ç‡§®,‡§Ö‡§™‡§®‡§æ, ‡§ü‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§æ or ‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§æ, ‡§®‡§®‡§¶ or‡§®‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä.

And such of these words as are in use in the Bengali have the following:‚Äî

‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Ç‡§∂, ‡§ú‡§®, ‡§ï‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä, ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§®, ‡§´‡•ã‡§®, ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§® or ‡§¨‡•ã‡§®, ‡§ï‡§†‡§ø‡§®, ‡§ú‡§®‡§®, ‡§≤‡•ã‡§£, ‡§Ü‡§™‡§®‡§æ, ‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§æ, ‡§®‡§®‡§¶.

Other words, in some of which even in Sanskrit a ‡§£‡•ç appears, are in the Hindi and Bengali thus:‚Äî

[Table 83: Original ‡§£‡•ç preserved]

Skr. ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£, H., ‡§¨‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§®, or‡§¨‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®,B.‡§¨‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®,but S.‡§¨‡§æ‡§≠‡§£‡•Å, a Brahman.

Skr. ‡§∂‡•É‡§£in ‡§∂‡•É‡§£‡•ã‡§§‡§ø, H. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®-[‡§®‡§æ], B. ‡§∂‡•Å‡§®-[‡§®], S. **‡§∏‡•Å‡§£-[‡§£‡•Å]**to hear.

Skr. ‡§¶‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§£, H. ‡§¶‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡§æ, A. ‡§°‡§æ‡§á‡§®, right hand.

Skr. ‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§£ (?), H, B. ‡§ó‡§π‡§®‡§æ, S. ‡§ó‡§π‡§£‡•ã, an ornament worn on the person.

Skr. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§£-[‡§ï‡§É], H. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§® or ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ, B. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§æ, S. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§£‡•ãblind of one eye.

Still ‡§£‡•çdoes appear in Bengali books in a few words such as ‡§ï‡§æ‡§£’ear’, ‡§≤‡•ã‡§£, ‘salt’, &c. In the Hindi it seems to be entirely absent.

In the principal Prakrit and the ≈öaurasenƒ´, all the Sanskrit sibilants are reduced to ‡§∏‡•ç. Sanskrit words, therefore, containing the palatal ‡§∂‡•çand the cerebral ‡§∑‡•ç, which in the Prakrits came to have the dental ‡§∏‡•ç instead, have the last in the Hindi, Panjabi, Sindhi, Gujarati, and Marathi. But according to a law of Marathi pronunciation, this ‡§∏‡•ç, when followed by the palatal vowel or semi-vowel ‡§á, ‡§è, or ‡§Ø‡•ç, is transformed into the palatal ‡§∂‡•ç.The foregoing list of words contain many instances that provethese points. Thus:‚Äî

[Table 84 A: Skr. ‡§∂‡•ç or ‡§∑‡•ç changed to ‡§∏‡•ç in the Vernaculars]
