Even in words adopted later, and consequently treated somewhat differently, from the way in which they were treatedin the Prakrits, the Sanskrit ‡§∂‡•ç and ‡§∑‡•ç are reduced to ‡§∏‡•ç, as in the H. ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§∏‡§®‡§æ ’to thirst,‚Äô Skr. ‡§§‡•É‡§∑‡•ç ; ‡§™‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∏ ‚Äòentrance,‚Äô Skr. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡•á‡§∂ ; ‡§™‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å ‚Äòahatchet,‚Äô Skr. ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•Å ; ‡§®‡§ø‡§∏‡§™‡§§‡§ø‚Äòlord of the night,’ ’the moon,’ Skr. ‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§æ‡§™‡§§‡§ø;S. ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Å ‚Äòrace,‚Äô ‚Äòdescent,‚Äô Skr. ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§∂;‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∏‡§£‡•Å‚Äòto rain,‚Äô Skr. ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑ ; ‡§µ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•Å ‚Äòto subdue,‚Äô Skr. ‡§µ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ , P. ‡§∏‡•ã‡§ó ‘sorrow,‚Äô Skr.‡§∂‡•ã‡§ï; ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§ ‘quietness,‚Äô Skr. ‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ;‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞ ‘God,‚Äô Skr. ‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞; H. ‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏, G. ‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏ ‘a year,‚Äô ‘Skr, ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑; G, ‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç ‚Äòto rain,‚Äô Skr. ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑ &c.

The present speakers of the Hindi, the Panjabi, and the Sindhi retain therefore the vocal peculiarity of their Prakrit ancestors of pronouncing Sanskrit ‡§∑‡•ç and ‡§∂‡•ç as ‡§∏‡•ç.

Of the words given above, the ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§ó, ‡§∏‡•á‡§Æ‡§≤, ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ñ and ‡§∏‡•á‡§ú of the Hindi become ‡§∂‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó, ‡§∂‡•á‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä, ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï and ‡§∂‡•á‡§ú in Marathi, because they are followed by a palatal vowel. Similarly, we have ‡§∂‡•á‡§£‚Äòcowdung‚Äô Skr. ‡§∂‡§ï‡§®‡•ç; ‡§∂‡•á‡§ó‡§ü ‘atree,‚Äô Skr. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞ ; ‡§∂‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤ ‘moss,‚Äô ‘Skr. ‡§∂‡•à‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤; ‡§∂‡§ø‡§°‡•Ä ’ladder,’ Skr. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§°‡•Ä, &c. Even the original ‡§∏‡•çof Sanskrit words is pronounced by the Marathas as ‡§∂‡•ç under those conditions, as ‡§∂‡•á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞ ‚Äòred lead,‚Äô Skr. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ç‡§∞‡§É ; ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§Ç ’to sew,‚Äô Skr. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§µ‡•ç ;‡§Æ‡§æ‡§â‡§∂‡•Ä‘mother’s sister,‚Äô Skr. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ, &c.

Gujarati too shows the same tendency though it is not so decided; and we have thus ‡§∂‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó‚Äòa horn,‚Äô ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç’to learn’ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§µ‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç‚Äòto sew,‚Äô ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‚Äòblackwood,‚Äô Skr. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∂‡§™, ‡§∂‡•á‡§ú,Skr. ‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ &c. But we have also such words as ‡§∂‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç‘sprinkling,‚Äô Skr. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö, ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ú‡§µ‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç’to boil,’ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§°‡•Ä‚Äòladder, &c. So that the Marathi rule does not seem to be strictly applicable to the Gujarati. Still the sound ‡§∂‡•çis as natural to the Gujaratis as to the Marathas, as is shown by such forms as ‡§∂‡•Å‡§Çfor ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Ç‚Äòwhat?’, ‡§ï‡§∞‡§∂‡•ã‘do,‚Äô &c., and in some provinces it is freely used for ‡§∏‡•çin many words.

The Bengali forms of such of the above words as are used in the language have ‡§∂‡•çfor the Hindi ‡§∏‡•ç, as:‚Äî

B. H. B. H.
‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ñ‡§®‡§æ to dry ‡§∂‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ a jackal.
‡§∂‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡§®‡§æ to hear. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§Æ‡•Å‡§≤ the silk cotton tree.
‡§∂‡•Å‡§á‡§µ‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ã‡§®‡§æ to sleep. ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§° ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ç‡§°, ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§° trunk of an elephant.
‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏ near.
‡§∂‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ó‡§æ a horn. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§∂‡•Ç ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§∏‡•ã blackwood.
‡§°‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∂ ‡§°‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏a mosquito. ‡§∂‡•á‡§≤ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§≤a dart.
‡§≠‡§à‡§∂ ‡§≠‡•à‡§Ç‡§∏a buffalo. ‡§¶‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∂‡§≤‡§æ‡§à ‡§¶‡§ø‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§≤‡§æ‡§à & fire-match.

Bengali books and dictionaries contain a good many words, derived from the old Prakrits or recently adopted from Sanskrit, which contain ‡§∏‡•çin them. The object of the authors in these cases is to give the correct Prakrit or Sanskrit forms, and not to represent the correct Bengali pronunciation. But it is not necessary to hear a Bengali speak or read his language or even Sanskrit for a long time to arrive at the clear conviction that his vocal habits do not admit of the pronunciation of ‡§∏‡•ç or, ‡§∑‡•ç,but only of ‡§∂‡•ç.

Sanskrit and Prakrit ‡§∏‡•ç becomes ‡§∂‡•ç in his mouth. Thus the Bengalis of the present day possess the same vocal characteristic that is attributed to their ancestors, the speakers of the MƒÅgadhƒ´, by the Prakrit grammarians.

[Table 85 A : ‡§∂‡•çchanged to ‡§õ‡•çin the vernaculars]

‡§∂‡•ç has a tendency to pass off into ‡§õ‡•ç as we observed in going over the Pali. For the Pali ‡§õ‡§ï from the Skr. ‡§∂‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•ç‚Äòcowdung,” we have ‡§õ‡•á‡§£‡•Å in S., ‡§õ‡§æ‡§£‡§æin G., &, from ‡§∂‡§ï‡§®‡•ç, another form of the word; and for the Pali ‡§õ‡§æ‡§™, Skr. ‡§∂‡§æ‡§µ‚Äòthe young of an elephant,‚Äôwe have ‡§õ‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ in H. M. &c., the Pr. form being ‡§õ‡§æ‡§µ. For the Skr. ‡§∂‡•á‡§µthe G. has ‡§õ‡•á‡§µ‡§ü, ‡§õ‡•á‡§°‡•ã, and ‡§õ‡•á‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‚Äòlast,’ ’end,‚Äô with the suffixes. ‡§ü, ‡§° and ‡§≤ ; for Skr. ‡§∂‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‚Äòrind,‚Äô H. has ‡§õ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•Ä, for Skr. ‡§∂‡§£ ‚Äòhemp,‚Äô O. has ‡§õ‡§£ ; for ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‘carpenter,‚Äôwhich is ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§∞in the other dialects and must have been pronounced ‡§∂‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§∞by the Bengalis, the B. has ‡§õ‡•Å‡§§‡§æ‡§∞and O. also. Other instances may be found.

[Table 85 B : ‡§∑‡•ç changed to ‡§ñ‡•çin Hindi]

In Hindi Skr. ‡§∑‡•çis often pronounced as ‡§ñ‡•ç as in ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ñfor ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑, ‚Äòspoken dialect’, ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§ñ for ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑, ‡§≠‡•á‡§ñfor ‡§µ‡•á‡§∑, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ñ‡§Æ for ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡§Æ &c. This is to be identified with the practice of the followers of the MƒÅdhya·πÅdina recension of the White Yajurveda who read the ‡§∑‡•çoccurring in their books throughout as ‡§ñ‡•ç. But other dialects also have a few instances of this change, as ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ñP. M. G., ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ñ‡•ÅS. for Skr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑.

[Table 86 A : Aspiration transferred]

In some cases the aspirate sound is absorbed in the adjoining mute, and it ceases to exist as a separate component of a word. Thus, from the Pr. ‡§™‡§π‡•Å‡§°‡§ø, Skr. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•É‡§§‡§ø, we have the M. ‡§™‡•Å‡§¢‡•á‡§Çin ‡§π‡•ç which the combines with ‡§°‡•ç, and the M. dial. ‡§´‡•Å‡§°‡•á‡§Çin which it combines with ‡§™‡•ç. In the same manner the Skr. ‡§Æ‡•á‡§∑‚Äòsheep’ becomes, with the usual Apabhra·πÅ≈õa suffix ‡§°or ‡§°‡§Ö, ‡§Æ‡•á‡§∏‡§°‡§â or ‡§Æ‡•á‡§π‡§°‡§â, which in M. and G. assumes the form of ‡§Æ‡•Ü‡§Ç‡§¢‡§æand ‡§Æ‡•Ü‡§Ç‡§¢‡§æ, the ‡§π combining with ‡§°. and in H. and P., of ‡§≠‡•á‡§°‡§æ, in which the being combined with the preceding ‡§Æ‡•á destroys the nasal character of the sound. P. has ‡§Æ‡•á‡§¢‡§æalso, and G. ‡§≠‡•á‡§°‡§æ, and B. and O. ‡§Æ‡•á‡§°‡§æas well as ‡§≠‡•á‡§°‡§æ. By a similar absorption of the ‡§π‡•ç sound and the reduction of the nasal to a mere AnusvƒÅra, we have H. P. ‡§≠‡•à‡§Ç‡§∏(masc. ‡§≠‡•à‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ), G. ‡§≠‡•á‡§Ç‡§∏, B.‡§≠‡§Ç‡§à‡§∂, from Skr. ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§∑‡•Ä‚Äòa female buffalo,’ and G. M. ‡§≠‡•á‡§≤ from Pr. ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏, Skr. ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞with the suffix ‡§≤, through an intermediate form ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π‡§≤ or ‡§Æ‡•á‡§π‡§≤. We have a more ancient instance of the process in the Pr. ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡§∞for Skr. ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§∞, through the intermediate form ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§∞, which has been preserved by the G. in ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§≠‡§∞‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç’to remember ‘or ‘remind.‚Äô

Sometimes a mute is aspirated without any appsrent resson in the Prakrits, and these instances have come down to some of the vernaculars : ‚Äî

[Table 88 : Mutes aspirated]

Skr. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§ú humpbacked, Pr. ‡§ñ‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ã, M. ‡§ñ‡•Å‡§ú‡§æ; but P. ‡§ï‡•ã‡§ù‡§æ, H. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ú‡§æ, B. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ã, O, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ú‡§æ, S, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§¨‡•ã ;M. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§¨‡•ú‡§æ also.

Skr. ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§≤‡§ï‡§Éa nail, Pr. ‡§ñ‡•Ä‡§≤‡§ì, M. ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ, G. ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã, B.O. ‡§ñ‡•Ä‡§≤ or ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ; the rest ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§≤.

Skr. ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§∞ potsherd, an earthen cup, Pr. ‡§ñ‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§∞, M. ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§™‡§∞, H. P. ‡§ñ‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§∞, O. ‡§ñ‡§™‡§∞‡§æ B. ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¨‡§∞‡§æ.

Later instances are:‚Äî

P. ‡§ó‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ç‡§π‡§æ, S. ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§π‡§æ a well, Skr. ‡§ï‡•Ç‡§™‡§ï‡§É.

P. ‡§õ‡•Å‡§π‡§£‡§æ to touch, H. ‡§õ‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ Skr. ‡§õ‡•Å‡§™.

M. ‡§ò‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞, P. H. ‡§ó‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞, Skr. ‡§ó‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ.

G. ‡§ñ‡•ã‡§≤‡•ãlap Skr. ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§°.

Of the instances in the Prakrits in which the consonants contained in a word interchange places we have :‚Äî

[Table 89 : Interchange of Consonants]

‡§π‡§≤‡•Ç ‘slow’ in M. Pr. ‡§π‡§≤‡•Å‡§Öand Skr. ‡§≤‡§ò‡•Å‡§ï, ‡§π‡•å‡§≤‡§æ in H. and P and ‡§π‡§≤‡•Ç and ‡§π‡§≤‡§µ‡•á in G.

M. ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§® ‘dsughter-in-law, Pr. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§π‡§æ, Skr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡§æ.

M. ‡§®‡§ø‡§°‡§æ‡§≤ ‘forehead, Fr. ‡§£‡§°‡§æ‡§≤, Skr. ‡§≤‡§≤‡§æ‡§ü, &c.

There are a good many more modern instances -

H. ‡§™‡§π‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§æ to recognize Pr. ‡§™‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§π‡§ø‡§Ü‡§£ Skr. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ-(‡§ú‡§æ) ‡§®, P. ‡§™‡§õ‡§æ‡§£‡§®‡§æ.

H. ‡§™‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§®‡§æ to dress, Pr. ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§£, Skr. ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ß‡§æ‡§® P. ‡§™‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§â‡§£‡§æ to cause to dress. In both the last two syllables are assimilated and we have ‡§™‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ also ; G. ‡§™‡§∞‡•á‡§µ‡•Åby the loss of ‡§π‡•ç.

G. ‡§µ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡•Å‡§Çbeloved, Pr. ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§π, Sir, ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§≠.

‡§∏‡•á‡§π‡§≤‡•Å‡§Çeasy, Pr. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§≤‡§π, Skr. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§≤‡§≠.

‡§¨‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä a cat, Skr. ‡§¨‡§ø‡§°‡§æ‡§≤ ; ‡§â‡§•‡§≤‡§™‡§æ‡§•‡§≤ topsy-turvy, the M. form being ‡§â‡§≤‡§ü‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ü, Pr. ‡§â‡§µ‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§•-‡§†‡•ç‡§† ‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§•-‡§†‡•ç‡§†. ‡§â‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§.

M. ‡§∂‡•á‡§™‡•Ç‡§ü or ‡§∂‡•á‡§™‡§ü‡•Ä tail, G. having ‡§™‡•Ç‡§õ‡§°‡•Å‡§Çor ‡§™‡•Ç‡§õ‡§°‡•Ä, Skr. ‡§™‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ, with the suffix ‡§ü, the ‡§õ‡•ç being changed to ‡§∂‡•çby the usual Mrule and the palatal vowel being brought in by the palatal ‡§∂‡•ç.

M. ‡§•‡•ã‡§°‡§ï‡•á‡§Çlittle, Pr.‡§•‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï, Skr.‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ã‡§ï, with the suffix ‡§°.

S. ‡§õ‡•Å‡§ó‡•ã abunch of flowers,Skr. ‡§ó‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ ; ‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø‡§°‡•ã loose, Pr. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§°‡§ø‡§≤, Skr. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§•‡§ø‡§≤.

H. M. ‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•Ä, &c., from Skr. ‡§§‡§ø‡§≤‡§ïas in Table 75.

TREATMENT OF SKR. CONJUNCTS IN THE VERNACULARS,

We will now trace in the vernaculars the Sanskrit conjunct consonants assimilated in the Pali and the Prakrits, in the order I have observed in treating of them in the lecture on the Pali. And first I will give a few instances of those in which the second member being strong prevails over the first and is doubled.

[Table 90: Second Member of the Conjunct preserved and doubled]

Skr. ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ act, business, Pr.‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ, P. ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ, S.‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Å, H. G. M. O.‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ.

Skr. ‡§ò‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æheat of the sun, Pr. ‡§ò‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ, H.‡§ò‡§æ‡§Æ, M. G. B. O. ‡§ò‡§æ‡§Æin the sense of ‚Äòsweat.‚Äô

Skr. ‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ skin, leather, Pr.‡§ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ, P. ‡§ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ, S. ‡§ö‡§Æ‡•Å, H. G. B. ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Æ, 0. ‡§ö‡§Æ, M. ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Æ in ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Æ‡§°‡•á‡§Ç.

Skr.‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø, Pr.‡§ï‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§Ç, S. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ú‡•Å, M. G. H. P. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ú. The M. has, however, the dento-palatal ‡§ú here.

Skr. ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§£ ear, Pr.‡§ï‡§£‡•ç‡§£, P. ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§®, S. ‡§ï‡§®‡•Å, H. G. M. B. O.‡§ï‡§æ‡§®.

Skr. ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§£a leaf, Pr. ‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§£, P.‡§™‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ (of a book), S. ‡§™‡§®‡•Å, H. G. M. ‡§™‡§æ‡§®, G. ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§Ç (of a book ), P. S. O. ‡§™‡§æ‡§®in the sense of ‘betel leaf.‚Äô

Skr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§™to solicit, supplicate, Pr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§µ, H.G. M. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡§µ-[‡§®‡§æ-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç-‡§£‡•á‡§Ç]; H. also ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•å‡§®‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•Äa queen, Pr. ‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡•Ä(?), G. P. S. M. B. O.‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä, H. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä.

Skr. ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ & signal, Pr. ‡§∏‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ, P. ,‡§∏‡§® H. G. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§®; H.‡§∏‡•à‡§® also.

Skr. ‡§Ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡•ã‡§™‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§ the sacred thread, Pr. ‡§ú‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡•ã‡§µ‡§à‡§Ö (?), H. P. ‡§ú‡§®‡•á‡§ä, S. ‡§ú‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã, G. ‡§ú‡§®‡•ã‡§á, M. ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç.

Skr. ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§™to make over, Pr.‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§™, G. ‡§Ü‡§™-[‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç].

Skr.‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™to consign, deliver, Pr. ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§™, H. P. S. ‡§∏‡•å‡§Ç‡§™-[‡§®‡§æ-‡§£‡§æ-‡§£‡•Å], M. G. ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ç‡§™-[‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç].

Skr. ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§™aserpent, Pr.‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§™, P.‡§∏‡§™‡•ç‡§™, S. ‡§∏‡§™‡•Å, H. G. M. B. O. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§™.

Skr. ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§≠ sacred grass, Pr. ‡§¶‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠, S. ‡§°‡§≠‡•Å, H. ‡§°‡§æ‡§≠or ‡§°‡§æ‡§¨, G. ‡§°‡§æ‡§≠or ‡§°‡§æ‡§≠‡•ã.

Skr. ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ sound, call, Pr.‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶, P.‡§∏‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶(subs. & verb), H. M. G. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶.

Skr, ‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞ afrog, Pr. ‡§¶‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞, P. H. G. ‡§¶‡§æ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞, S. ‡§°‡•á‡§º‡§°‡§º‡§∞‡•Å.

Skr. ‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§boiled rice, Pr. ‡§≠‡§§‡•ç‡§§, P. ‡§≠‡§§‡•ç‡§§, S, ‡§≠‡§§‡•Å, H. M. G. B.O. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§§.

Skr. ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ red, Pr. ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§§, P. ‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ, S. ‡§∞‡§§‡•ã, H. G. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•ã, M. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§æ in ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡§æ ared sour fruit of a certain tree.

Skr. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§ slept, Pr. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§, P. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§æ, S. G. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•ã.

Skr, ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æmud, Pr. ‡§ï‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§Æ, H. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡•å or ‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§æ, G. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§µ.

Skr. ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§ï to look out for, gaze wistfully, Pr. ‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï, P, ‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡§æ, B. ‡§§‡§ï‡§£‡•Å, M. ‡§ü‡§º‡§ï‡§£‡•á‡§Ç, O. ‡§ü‡§æ‡§ï‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ, H. G. ‡§§‡§æ‡§ï- [‡§®‡§æ-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç].

The following are instances in which though the second member of a conjunot prevails, some of the elements of the first sound are added to it:‚Äî

[Table 91: Some element of the first added to the second member of a Conjunct]

(a) Conjuncts of a sibilant and a mute.

Skr ‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ hand, Pr. ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§•, P. ‡§π‡§•‡•ç‡§•, S. ‡§π‡§•‡•Å, H. G. ‡§π‡§æ‡§•, M. B. O. ‡§π‡§æ‡§§.

Skr. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø fist, Pr. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§†‡•ç‡§†‡§ø, P. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§†‡•ç‡§†. S. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§†‡•ç‡§†‡§ø,H. G. ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§†-‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§†‡•ç‡§†‡•Ä, M. ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§†, O. ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§†‡§ø, B. ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§ü.

Skr ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ stone, Pr. ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§∞, P. ‡§™‡§•‡•ç‡§•‡§∞, S. ‡§™‡§•‡§∞‡•Å, H. G. ‡§™‡§•‡•ç‡§•‡§∞ or‡§™‡§æ‡§•‡§∞, M. ‡§™‡§æ‡§•‡§∞, B. ‡§™‡§æ‡§•‡§∞ or‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§∞, O. ‡§™‡§•‡§∞.

Skr. ‡§™‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§† baok, Pr. ‡§™‡•Å‡§†‡•ç‡§†-‡§™‡§ø‡§†‡•ç‡§†-‡§™‡§†‡•ç‡§†, vernaculars as in Table 4.

Skr. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§™‡§® sending. Pr. ‡§™‡§†‡•ç‡§†‡§æ‡§µ‡§£, S, ‡§™‡§†‡§£‡•Å, H. ‡§™‡§†‡§æ‡§®‡§æ, Braj ‡§™‡§†‡•ã‡§®‡•å, M. ‡§™‡§æ‡§†‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§Ç, B. ‡§™‡§æ‡§†‡§æ‡§á‡§µ‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§æ a kind of grass, Pr. ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ, vernaculers as in Table 5.

Skr. ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï head, Pr. ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§Ö, P. ‡§Æ‡§•‡•ç‡§•‡§æ, S. ‡§Æ‡§•‡•ã, H. M. B. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§•‡§æ, G. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§•‡•Å‡§Ç, M. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§•‡•á‡§Ç, O. ‡§Æ‡§•‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§â‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü sat, Pr. ‡§â‡§µ‡§á‡§†‡•ç‡§†vernaculars as in Table 43.

Skr. ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡§ø or ‡§¶‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü sight or seen, Pr. ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§øor ‡§¶‡§ø‡§†‡•ç‡§†, P. ‡§°‡§ø‡§†‡•ç‡§†‡§æ-‡§°‡§†‡•ç‡§†, and the rest as in Table 2.

Skr. ‡§â‡§∑‡•ç‡§£hot, Pr. ‡§â‡§£‡•ç‡§π, G. ‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç,M. ‡§ä‡§® ;M. G. S. ‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§π as in ‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ- ‡§≤‡•ã-‡§∞‡•ã for ‡§â‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤ the hot season.

Skr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æto bathe, Pr. ‡§£‡•ç‡§π‡§æor ‡§®‡§π‡§æ, P. H. M.G. ‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ- [‡§â‡§£‡§æ-‡§®‡§æ-‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç] P. H. ‡§®‡§π‡§æ also.

Skr. ‡§Ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§†thumb, Pr. ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§†‡•ç‡§†, P. ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡•Ç‡§†, S, ‡§Ü‡§ô‡•Ç‡§†‡•ã, H. ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡•Ç‡§†‡§æ, G, ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡•Ç‡§†‡•ã, M. ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§ó‡§†‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï‡§ø‡§∞ to spread,Pr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§ø‡§∞, P. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§∞‡§®‡§æ, S. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ñ‡•á‡§∞‡§£‡•Å, H. G. M. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ñ‡§∞-[‡§®‡§æ-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç-‡§£‡•á‡§Ç] to be scattered.

Skr. ‡§∂‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§ï dry, Pr. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ, P. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ, S. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•ã, H. ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ñ‡§æ, G. ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ñ‡•ã, M. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ, B. O. ‡§∂‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§™vapour, Pr. ‡§¨‡§∑‡•ç‡§´, S. H. G. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§´, M. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§´, P. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§´, B.O. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§™.

Skr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§ß shoulder, Pr. ‡§ñ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß, H. M. ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ, G. ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ã; but H. mostly hes ‡§ï‡§Ç‡§ß‡§æ and ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§æ, P. ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ B. O. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß.

Skr ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§æ‡§§‡•ç behind, Pr. ‡§™‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ, P. ‡§™‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•á H. ‡§™‡•Ä‡§õ‡•á‡§™‡§æ‡§õ‡•á, G. ‡§™‡§æ‡§õ‡•Å‡§Ç.

Skr. ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ hot season, Pr. ‡§ó‡§ø‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ, M. dial ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§Æ.

[Table 92 : the Same as in Table 91]

(b) Conjuncls of a dental and a heavy ‡§Ø‡•ç.

Skr ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø true, Pr, ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö, P. H. ‡§∏‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö, S. ‡§∏‡§ö‡•Å, H. M. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ö, G. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ö‡•Å‡§Ç,B. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§®‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø of ‡§®‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø to dance, Pr. ‡§®‡§ö, P. ‡§®‡§ö or ‡§®‡§ö-[‡§£‡§æ], S. ‡§®‡§ö-[‡§£‡•Å], H. M. G. ‡§®‡§æ‡§ö-[‡§®‡§æ-‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç],B. O. ‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§®‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø a dance Pr. ‡§®‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö, P. ‡§®‡§æ‡§ö, S ‡§®‡§æ‡§ö‡•Å, H. M. G. B. O. ‡§®‡§æ‡§ö.

Skr. ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å death, Pr. ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•Å, H. ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§ö.

Skr. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§® of ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§≠‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§ø to recognize, Pr. ‡§™‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡§π‡§ø‡§Ü‡§£, H. ‡§™‡§π‡§ø-‡§ö‡§æ‡§®, P. ‡§™‡§õ‡§æ‡§£, B. ‡§ö‡§ø‡§® or ‡§ö‡§ø‡§®‡§ø‡§¨‡§æ, by dropping the first two consonants.

Skr. ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Øof ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á to be produced, Pr. ‡§â‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, P. S. H. M. G. ‡§™‡§ú-[‡§£‡§æ-‡§£‡•Å-‡§®‡§æ-‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç].

Skr. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Øof ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§øto be intoxicated, Pr. ‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, M. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡§£‡•á‡§Ç.

Skr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§ lightning, Pr. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•Ç, M. G. ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§ú, P. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, S. ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•Å.

Sk1. ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§Øto-day, Pr. ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, P. ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, S, ‡§Ö‡§ú‡•Å, H. M. G. B. ‡§Ü‡§ú, B.O. ‡§Ü‡§ú‡§ø.

Skr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§óof ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§ø to sweat also to boil, Pr. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, P. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§£‡§æ to be soaked, S. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ù‡§£‡•Å, H. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ù‡§®‡§æ-‡§∏‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ (casual), M. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ú‡§£‡•á‡§Ç, G. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ú‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç, 0. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§µ‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æabarren woman, Pr. ‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§æ Or ‡§¨‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§æ, P. ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§ù‡§æ, S. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ù, H.O. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ù, G. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ù-[‡§£‡•Ä], M. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ù or ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ú, B, ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ù‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ evening, Pr. ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§æ, P.S. ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ù‡§æ, S. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ù‡•Ä, H. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ù, M.G, H. B. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ú, O. ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú.

Skr. ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø of ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á to know, Pr. ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù, P. ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§£‡§æ, H. S. ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ù-[‡§®‡§æ-‡§£‡•Å]; B. O. ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ù‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ, M. G. ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ú-[‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç].

Skr. ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø middle, Pr. ‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù, P. ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ùor ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù,S. ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ù‡•Å, H. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ù or ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù, M. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§Ç, B. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù.

Skr. ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß battle, Pr. ‡§ú‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù of ‡§ú‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§á for ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø, P. ‡§ú‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù, H. ‡§ú‡•Ç‡§ù‡§æ, B. ‡§ù‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ú (in ‡§ù‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞), M. ‡§ù‡•Ç‡§ú.

When ‡§µ‡•ç as the latter member of a conjunct is heavily pronounced, the double consonant that takes the place of the conjunct is ‡§™‡•ç‡§™, ‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨, and ‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠ according as the preceding member is asurd, a sonant, or an aspirated sonant. Sometimes, when the preceding member is a dental, the substitutes are ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö, ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, and ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù. The following are instances of these changes in the vernaculars:‚Äî

[Table 93 :‡§µ‡•ç as second member of a conjunct changed to ‡§™‡•ç‡§™, ‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨, ‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠,‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö,‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù]

Skr. ‡§§‡•ç‡§µabstract termination, Apabhr., ‡§™‡•ç‡§™,H. ‡§™‡§æas in ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¢‡§æ‡§™‡§æold age, ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ü‡§æ‡§™‡§æ fatness, S ‡§™‡•ã as in ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§™‡•ãhumanity, from ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Åman.

Skr. ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§® abstract terminstion, Pr. ‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§£, Apabhr. ‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§£, H. ‡§™‡§® or ‡§™‡§®‡§æ as in ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ü‡§∞‡§™‡§® celibacy; S. ‡§™‡§£‡•Å or ‡§™‡§£‡•ã as in ‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡§™‡§£‡•Å womanhood, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§π‡•Å‡§Ö‡§™‡§£‡•Å humanity ; M. ‡§™‡§£ or ‡§™‡§£‡§æ as in ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•Å‡§∏‡§™‡§£ or ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•Å‡§∏‡§™‡§£‡§æ humanity ; P. ‡§™‡•Å‡§£ as in ‡§®‡§ø‡§Ü‡§£‡§™‡•Å‡§£ childhood &c.

Skr. ‡§â‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§ó feeling of repulsion, Pr. ‡§â‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨‡•á‡§ó, M. ‡§â‡§¨‡§ó.

Skr. ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞ door, Pr. ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞ or ‡§¨‡§æ‡§∞, P. H. G. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§∞, P. ‡§¶‡§∞ S. ‡§¶‡§∞‡•Å. M. ‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞.

Skr. ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ all, Pr. ‡§∏‡§¨‡•ç‡§¨, H, ‡§∏‡§¨, P. ‡§∏‡§≠, S. ‡§∏‡§≠‡•Å, G. ‡§∏‡§π‡•Åfor ‡§∏‡§µ.

Skr ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤ to burn, Pr, ‡§ú‡§≤ or ‡§¨‡§≤, S. ‡§¨‡§∞‡§£‡•Å, P. ‡§ú‡§≤‡§®‡§æ-‡§¨‡§≤‡§£‡§æ, H. ‡§ú‡§≤‡§®‡§æ-‡§¨‡§≤‡§®‡§æ G. M. ‡§ú‡§≤‡§£‡•á‡§Ç and ‡§™‡•ã‡§≤‡§£‡•á‡§Ç where ‡§¨seems to be hardened, B. O. ‡§™‡•ã‡§°‡§º in ‡§™‡•ã‡§°‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ above, erect, Pr, ‡§â‡§¢‡§≠, S. ‡§â‡§≠‡•ã, M. O. ‡§â‡§≠‡§æ, B. ‡§â‡§¨‡•Å.

Skr. ‡§ú‡§ø‡§π‡•ç‡§µ‡§ætongue, Pr, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ, M. H. P. G. ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§≠, B. O.S. ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≠.

Skr. ‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú banner, Pr. ‡§ù‡§Ö with the suffix ‡§°‡§æ or ‡§°‡•ã, S. ‡§ù‡§Ç‡§°‡•Ä, P. H. ‡§ù‡§Ç‡§°‡§æ, M. ‡§ù‡•á‡§Ç‡§°‡§æ.

Similarly ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç, with the loss of the nasal sound of ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ, becomes ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§£ in the Prakrits and ‡§Ü‡§™‡§£ in M. O. G. ‡§Ü‡§™‡§® in B., ‡§™‡§æ‡§£ in S. and ‡§Ü‡§™ in H.P.

[DENTALS CHANGED TO PALATALS]

Dentals have a tendency to become palatals even when not followed by ‡§Ø‡•ç or ‡§µ‡•ç, probably because they do so become when followed by those semi-vowels. Thus, from the Skr. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¶‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø ‚Äòto sound’ or ‘play on a musical instrument,’ we have P. ‡§¨‡§ú‡§æ‡§â‡§£‡§æ,H. ‡§¨‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ, M. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú‡§µ‡§ø‡§£‡•á‡§Ç, &c.; from Skr. ‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‘sleep,‚Äô M. ‡§®‡•Ä‡§ú; P. H. ‡§ì‡§õ‡§æ;’trifling,’ ‘vain’, S. ‡§ì‡§õ‡§æ,from very probably, Skr. ‡§µ‡•É‡§•‡§æ ;M. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§ú,H. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ú‡§æfrom Skr. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡§¶ which appears even in the Prakrits to have assumed the form of ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§ú,though ‡§∏‡§æ‡§µ‡§Øis usually given; M. H. G. ‡§õ‡•Ä ‡§õ‡•Ä, M. ‡§õ‡•á ‡§õ‡•á,Pr. ‡§õ‡§ø ‡§õ‡§øfrom Skr. ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç ‡§ß‡§ø‡§ï&c.

[Table 94: (c) The conjunct ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç(when the sibilant is pronounced like ‡§∂‡•ç,) and ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏, and ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø]

Skr. ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ a moment, Pr. ‡§ñ‡§£, P. ‡§õ‡§ø‡§£, S. ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§£, H. ‡§õ‡§ø‡§®, G. ‡§ñ‡§£, M. (dial.) ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§£a festival, Pr. ‡§õ‡§£, M. ‡§õ‡§ø‡§®, M. ‡§∏‡§£for ‡§õ‡§£.

Skr. ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§∞‡§ï-‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ aknife a razor, Pr. ‡§õ‡•Å‡§∞‡§Ö-‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ü, P. ‡§õ‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ-‡§∞‡•Ä, S. ‡§õ‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä, H. ‡§õ‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ-‡§∞‡•Ä, B. O. ‡§õ‡•ã‡§∞‡§æ-‡§õ‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä, M. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ä.

Skr. ‡§§‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑to shave, hew, Pr. ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ,P. ‡§§‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§£‡§æ, M. ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡§£‡•á‡§Ç, G. ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç.

Skr. ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏a calf, Pr. ‡§µ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ, P. ‡§¨‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ, S. ‡§µ‡§õ, H. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§õ‡§æ, ‡§¨‡§õ‡§æ, ‡§¨‡§õ, G. ‡§µ‡§õ, ‡§µ‡§æ‡§õ-[‡§∞‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç]. Skr. ‡§Æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø & fish, Pr. ‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ, P, ‡§Æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ, S. ‡§Æ‡§õ‡•Å, H. ‡§Æ‡§õ or ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§õ, B. O. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§õ, M. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§ô‡•ç‡§ólap, Pr.‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó, H.‡§â‡§õ‡§Ç‡§ó, M. ‡§ì‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó.

The conjunct ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•çsometimes appears in the Prakrits, and perhaps even in Sanskrit, in the form of ‡§ù‡•ç. The Sanskrit ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§∞ is ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§∞in the Prakrits, and this we have in the H. ‡§ù‡§∞‡§®‡§æ, M. ‡§ù‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§Ç and ‡§™‡§æ‡§ù‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§Çin which last ‡§™‡§æstands for the preposition ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞. ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§øis Pr. ‡§ù‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§ùfrom which we have M;‡§ù‡§ø‡§ú‡§£‡•á‡§Ç’to waste away’, and from ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§£we haveS. ‡§ù‡•Ä‡§£‡•ã, H. ‡§ù‡•Ä‡§®, &c.

Skr. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ßa half more, Pr. ‡§∏‡§°‡•ç‡§¢, H. P. B. O. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¢‡•á, S. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§¢‡§æ-‡§¢‡•Å. H. M. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§°‡•á, G. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§°‡§æ.

We will now proceed to instances in which the first member of a conjunct prevails over the second and is doubled:‚Äî

[Table 96: Instances where the first member of a conjunct remains]

Skr ‡§≠‡§ó‡•ç‡§®-[‡§ï‡§É] fled away, Pr. ‡§≠‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó- [‡§ì], H ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ, S. ‡§≠‡§ó‡•ã.

Skr. ‡§®‡§ó‡•ç‡§®-[‡§ï‡§É] naked, Pr. ‡§®‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó-[‡§ì], P. H. ‡§®‡§Ç‡§ó‡§æ, S. ‡§®‡§Ç‡§ó‡•ã, G. ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡•ã, M. ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó-[‡§°‡§æ], O. ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§∞‡§∂‡•ç‡§Æ‡§øa cord, a rope, Pr. ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§ø, P. H, ‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•Ä, S. B. G. O. ‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ä, H G. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏in the sense of ‚Äòreins.‚Äô

Skr. ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø fit, Pr. ‡§ú‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó, P. ‡§ú‡•ã‡§ó or ‡§ú‡•ã‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ, S. ‡§ú‡•ã‡§ó‡•Å, H. G. ‡§ú‡•ã‡§ó, H. M. ‡§ú‡•ã‡§ó‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§∂‡•Ç‡§®‡•ç‡§Øvoid, empty, Pr. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§£, P. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§® or ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§æ, S.‡§∏‡•Å‡§Ç‡§®, H. ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§® or ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®‡§æ,M. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§æ, ‡§∏‡•Å‡§Ç‡§® has acquired the sense of “insensibility” also.

Skr. ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø of ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á to regard, Pr. ‡§Æ‡§£‡•ç‡§£, P. ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§£‡§æ, S. ‡§Æ‡§®‡§£‡•Å, M. G.H. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®-[‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç-‡§®‡§æ].

Skr. ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§® to explain, Pr. ‡§µ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ‡§£, P. ‡§µ-‡§¨‡§ñ‡§æ‡§£‡§®‡§æ, H, ‡§¨‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡§®‡§æ explain or praise, S. ‡§¨‡§ñ‡§æ‡§£‡§£‡•Å praise, G. ‡§µ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§£‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç, H. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§£‡§£‡•á‡§Ç.

Skr. ‡§Ö‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø desert, Pr. ‡§∞‡§£‡•ç‡§£, M. G. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§®, G. ‡§∞‡§®, S.‡§∞‡§ø‡§£‡•Å.

Skr. ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞ a tiger Pr. ‡§µ‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß, P. H. B. O. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ò, S. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ò‡•Å M. G. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ò.

Skr. ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞ front part, Pr. ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó, S. ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ã;H. ‡§Ü‡§ó‡§æ; P ‡§Ü‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡•Åbefore, G. ‡§Ü‡§ó‡•ã, G. ‡§Ü‡§ó‡§≤ before, B. ‡§Ü‡§ó‡•á O. ‡§Ü‡§ó‡•Åfirst of all.

Skr.‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞a wheel, Pr. ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï, P. ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï, S. ‡§ö‡§ï‡•Å (both) apotter‚Äôs wheel, H. ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ï, ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•Ä, in the sense of a ‚Äòmill-stone’, G. M. ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ï, B, ‡§ö‡§æ‡§ï‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ a leaf, Pr. ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§, P. ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§, S. ‡§™‡§§‡•ã aplaying card, H. ‡§™‡§æ‡§§, ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§æ, ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§G, ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§∞‡•Å‡§Ç, M. ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§Ç blade of a knife, M. ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡§æ a collection of dry leaves.

Skr. ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ moon, Pr. ‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶, P. ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶. S. ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§°‡•Å, H. G.M, B.O. ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¶. H. ‡§ö‡§Ç‡§¶ also.

Skr ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç as in Tab 34.

Skr.‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞acloud, Pr, ‡§Ö‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠, H, ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§æ‡§≤, M. ‡§Ö‡§≠‡§æ‡§≤ or‡§Ü‡§≠‡§æ‡§≤ (from ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø), G. ‡§Ü‡§≠.

Skr. ‡§ú‡•ç‡§µ‡§≤, Pr.and other forms with ‡§ú as in Table 93.

Skr.‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ side, Pr. ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏ S. ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•ã, P. ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ, H. ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏, G, ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•á, M. ‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§Çnear, i. e. by one’s side.

When ‡§∞‡•çfollowed by ‡§Ø‡•ç is changed to ‡§≤‡•ç, this last sound prevails. over the ‡§Ø‡•ç, and the conjunct becomes ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•ç in the Prakrits. The following instances of this change have come down to the vernaculars:‚Äî

[Table 97: ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Øis changed to ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤]

Skr. ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ changed, Pr. ‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§†‡•ç‡§†or ‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§•, P, H. ‡§™‡§≤‡§ü‡§æ, P. ‡§™‡§≤‡§ü‡§æ, M. G. ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§ü.

Skr. ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ô‡•ç‡§ïa bedstead, Pr. ‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ô‡•ç‡§ï, P. ‡§™‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ò, S. ‡§™‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ó‡•Å, H. M. G. ‡§™‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ó, B. ‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï or‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ó, O. ‡§™‡§≤‡§Ç‡§ï.

The following are instances of other cases of the same change;

Skr. ‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶to squeeze, rub, knead, Pr. ‡§Æ‡§≤, P. M. G. ‡§Æ‡§≤-[‡§®‡§æ-‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç], H. S. ‡§Æ‡§≤- [‡§®‡§æ-‡§®‡•á‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç].

Skr. ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï ginger, Pr. ‡§Ö‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§Ö, M. ‡§Ü‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç. H. P. B. have ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§æ, G. ‡§Ü‡§¶‡•Å‡§Ç, from Pr. ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ü.

H. has ‡§Ü‡§¶‡§æ also from Pr.‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§¶‡§Ö.

P.H. M. ‡§≠‡§≤‡§æ, G. S. ‡§≠‡§≤‡•ã, B. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§≤, from Skr. ‡§≠‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞, through the change of ‡§∞‡•ç to ‡§≤‡•ç and of the conjunct to ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡•ç.

When ‡§ï‡•ç, the first sound of ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç, prevails and adds to itself the heavy aspiration of ‡§∑‡•ç, the conjunct becomes ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡•ç. Of this change there are many instances in the vernaculars :‚Äî

[Table 98 :‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ changed to ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡•ç]

H. ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§∏, Skr. ‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ a tree, Pr, ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ, P. ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ñ.

Skr, ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ to keep to protect, Pr. ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ, P. ‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§£‡§æ, S. ‡§∞‡§ñ‡§£‡•Å, H. ‡§∞‡§ñ‡§®‡§æ aslo ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ‡§®‡§æ M. G. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ-[‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç] B. O. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§â‡§™‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ to mark, Pr, ‡§â‡§™‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ,M. G. ‡§ì‡§≤‡§ñ acquaintance.

Skr. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ to learn, Pr. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ, P. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ñ‡§£‡§æ, S. ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ñ‡§£‡•Å,H. ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§ñ‡§®‡§æ, G. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç,M. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§£‡•á‡§Ç, B. O. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ.

Skr. ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ field, Pr. ‡§ñ‡•á‡§§, P. ‡§ñ‡•á‡§§ S. ‡§ñ‡•á‡§§‡•Å or ‡§ñ‡•á‡§ü‡•Å, H. B. O. G. ‡§ñ‡•á‡§§ in ‡§ñ‡•á‡§§‡•Ä agriculture.

Skr. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§øaside of the abdomen, Pr. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§ø,P. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ or ‡§ï‡•ã‡§ñ, S. ‡§ï‡§ñ‡§ø, H. ‡§ï‡•ã‡§ñ, G. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ñ.

Skr. ‡§¨‡•Å‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ hunger, Pr. ‡§¨‡•Å‡§¶‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ, P. ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ, S. ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ñ, H. G. B. ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§ñ, M. B. ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§ï, O. ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ï.

Skr. ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ to anoint, an unguent, Pr. ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§£, P. ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§£ butter, S. ‡§Æ‡§ñ‡§£ anoint, butter, H. ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§® or ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ñ‡§® butter, B.O. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ñ‡§® butter ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ to anoint, M. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ñ‡§£‡•á fo anoint, G. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ñ‡§£ butter.

Skr. ‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ examination, Pr. ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ, H. P. B. O. ‡§™‡§∞‡§ñ‡•á‡§Ç M. G. S, ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ñ.

Skr. ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø the eye, Pr. ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§ø, P. ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ, S. ‡§Ö‡§ñ‡§ø, H. G. ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§ñ, B. O. ‡§Ü‡§ñ‡§ø.

Skr. ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∞ milk, Pr. ‡§ñ‡•Ä‡§∞, S. ‡§ñ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•Å, P. H. M. G. ‡§ñ‡•Ä‡§∞ dish of rice and milk, O. ‡§ñ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•Ä.

Skr. ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ and ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ as in Table 93.

Skr. ‡§á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å sugar-cane, Pr. ‡§â‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•Å or ‡§á‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡•Å, H. ‡§ä‡§ñ or‡§à‡§ñ, P. ‡§á‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ.

Though accordingto Hemacandra and Vararuci, the ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç of ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø,‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø,‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∞, ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡§æand ‡§á‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Åis changed to ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•çin the MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rl or principal Prakrit, still we see that most of the vernaculars derive their forms of these words from such Prakrit formal as had ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡•ç for the Sanskrit ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç. But with the exception of ‡§á‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡•Åand ‡§ñ‡•Ä‡§∞ which are mentioned as occurring in the Jaina sacredbooks, these forms are not given as existing in any of the dialects.

This and other similar omissions show that the observation of the Prakrit grammarians was by no means perfect. The Marathi forms of these words, however, with the exception of ‡§Ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø, which is unknown to the language, and of ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä‡§∞,which is ‡§ñ‡•Ä‡§∞,have ‡§Æ‡•ç or ‡§∂‡•ç, which is representative of the Prakrit ‡§õ‡•ç, and hence they are the same as those given by Hemacandra and Vararuci. Here we have one of several indications that the modern Marathi is the direct daughter of the old MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rlof the grammarians.

It will be seen from the lists given above that the Hindi, Gujarati, Marathi and Bengali mostly drop one component of the doubled consonants, and to make up for the quantity thus lost, lengthen the preceding vowel. In other words, the speakers of those dialects take the same time to pronounce two syllables the latter of which contains a double consonant which the speakers of the Prakrit did; but the preceding forcible vowel utterance and the subsequent strong contact and pressure being avoided, the effect is that one of the two consonants is dropped and the previous vowel lengthened. This then is essentially a case of softening.

The Sindhi drops one of the two consonants, but does not. lengthen the preceding vowel; while the Panjabi generally preserves. the doubled consonants handed down to it by the old Prakrits. The Hindi contains more instances in which the original Prakrit pronunciation is preserved than the other three dialects. Hemacandra notices in the Prakrits the softened pronunciation we have been considering in the case of only, one of which is according to him dropped and the preceding vowel is lengthened, as in ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§á for ‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§á, Sk. ‡§™‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø, ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∏‡§Ç for ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç, Skr, ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•ç, &c. This lengthening of the previous vowel is in the four dialects prevented, as observed before, by the accent falling on a subsequent syllable.

In the ‚ÄòPali and the Prakrits, you will remember, the components of some conjuncts such as ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç, ‡§à, ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç, ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç, ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ç, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•ç, ‡§ó‡•ç‡§≤‡•ç, ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≤‡•ç, &c., are not assimilated but separated by the interposition of a vowel. The vernaculars have preserved some instances of this process:‚Äî

[Table 99 Interposition of a vowel between the members of a conjunct]

H. ‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡§®‡§æ to praise, Pr. ‡§∏‡§≤‡§æ‡§π Skr. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§ò.

H. ‡§Ö‡§ó‡§®‡•Ä, P. ‡§Ö‡§ó‡§®, B. ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Å‡§® fire, Pr. ‡§Ö‡§ó‡§£‡•Ä Skr. ‡§Ö‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡§ø.

H. ‡§¨‡§∞‡§∏, ‡§¨‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏, M. ‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏ a year, Pr. ‡§µ‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏, Skr. ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑. So also H. P.‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏-[‡§®‡§æ-‡§£‡§æ],G. ‡§µ‡§∞‡§∏‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç, Skr. ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑.

H. ‡§ó‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§® tired, Pr. ‡§ó‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§£, Skr. ‡§ó‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§®.

M. ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤‡§∏disgust, Pr. ‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§∏, Skr. ‡§ï‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§∂distress.

M. ‡§∂‡§ø‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï, stanza, Skr. ‡§∂‡•ç‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï G. ‡§π‡§∞‡§ñ joy, Skr. ‡§π‡§∞‡•ç‡§™ G. ‡§∏‡§≤‡§ñ‡§Æ, P. Mg, Skr., are later instances of the same nature.

In modern times other conjuncts also are similarly dissolved, and we have a ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§æ‡§™S. M., &c. ’exploit’ for ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§™, ‡§ñ‡•á‡§§‡§∞, P. G., &c. ‘a field’ for ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ÅS. ‘a lotus’ for ‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Æ, ‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§óP. for ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó. ‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§∏‡•ÅS., others ‡§§‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏, ‘vexation’ for ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏, ‡§ß‡§∞‡§Æ‘virtue’ H. M. G., &c., for ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ, &c.

But the books and dictionaries of some of these languages contain a good many Sanskrit words the conjuncts in which are not changed in any way. This is due to the fact that those languages are now the spoken languages of the educated as well as the uneducated portions of the different communities, and the former pronounce the words correctly, and the forms given to them by the latter are not taken into account by the authors of those books. Again, even the latter, though they interpose a vowel between the components of some conjuncts as shown above, have, to a certain extent, become used to Sanskrit sounds and can pronounce others correctly. But in some of the provinces. the old disability of the Prakrit speakers has been inherited in certain cases by their modern descendants, whether educated or uneducated, and it is very much to be regretted that the writers of books should in such cases write words in their Sanskrit forms. which, when they are read by themselves or others, are read in a quite different way.

The people of Sindh¬π, whether belonging to the higher or lower classes, and the Bengalis pronounce the conjuct ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•çinvariably as ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡•ç.Thus Sanskrit ‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ as ‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä as‡§∏‡§æ‡§ñ‡•Ä, ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ as‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñor ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ñ,&c. The speakers of the Hindi more often pronounce as ‡§ö‡§æ than as ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡•ç,‡§®‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ becoming ‡§®‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Ç‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ with them; ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Ä, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡•Ä; ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ ; ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£, ‡§≤‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§Æ‡§® ; ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£‡§æ, ‡§≤‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§®‡§æ ; ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø, ‡§ñ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä or ‡§õ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ; ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Ø, ‡§õ‡§Ø ; ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Æ, ‡§õ‡§Æ ;&c. The Panjabis pronounce the first three words as ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ñ‡•Ä, and ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ, ‡§≤‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£ as‡§≤‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§£, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø as ‡§ñ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø, &c. so that they also agree with the Hindi people, but seem more inclined towardsmaking ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡•ç of the conjunct. The Marathas, however, pronounce the ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•çproperly, though ordinarily they make ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç of it rather than ‡§ï‡•ç-‡§∑‡•ç, as remarked on a former occasion. Similarly, the Bengali assimilates conjuncts the latter member of which is ‡§µ‡•ç or ‡§Ø‡•ç, ‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞becoming ‡§á‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡§∞ and ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§® ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ‡§® in his mouth. Similarly be pronounces Skr. ‡§Ü‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ as just as his Prakrit ancestors did though it is written correctly.

ASSIMILATION OF MEMBERS OF CONJUNCTS CONTAINING NASALS

Some of the vernaculars assimilate the components of a conjunct made up of a nasal and a mute. Thus the Panjabi hast ‡§°‡§®‡•ç‡§®for ‡§¶‡§£‡•ç‡§° ‘penalty ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§£‡§æ for ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§®‡§æ ’to shave ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§® for ‡§∏‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°, Skr. ‡§∂‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§æ’the trunk of an elephant’, ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§π‡§æ for ‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§æ,Skr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‘shoulder’, ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§πfor ‡§¨‡§®‡•ç‡§ß ‘binding’, ‡§ñ‡§®‡•ç‡§®for ‡§ñ‡§®‡•ç‡§° ‘a piece’, ‡§≠‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§£‡§æ ’to break for ‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§®‡§æ or‡§≠‡§ú‡§®‡§æ, ‡§•‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ for ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠ ‘a pillar, &c.In the Bengali ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§® ‚Äòa piece’, one of the two ‡§®‡•ç sounds of ‡§ñ‡§®‡•ç‡§® is dropped and the preceding vowel lengthened. Similarly we have ‡§•‡§æ‡§Æ ‚Äòto stop‚Äô from ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠. In Sindhi we have ‡§≠‡§û‡•Å ‚Äòinterruption’,for‡§≠‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó, ‡§ö‡§ô‡•ã‘good’ for ‡§ö‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•ã, M. ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ ;‡§Æ‡§û‡•Å‡§† ‘madder’ for ‡§Æ‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ; ‡§™‡§ø‡§®‡•Å‘a ball‚Äô for ‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§°; ‡§ñ‡§®‡•Å ‘apiece of bread‚Äô for ‡§ñ‡§£‡•ç‡§° ; ‡§ö‡•Å‡§Æ‡§£‡•Å ’to kiss‚Äô for ‡§ö‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨, &c. Here the Sindhi, as is usual with him, drops one component of thedoubled consonants. With this exception, the modern dialects have got no cases of the assimilation of the members of a conjuner unknown to the Prakrits, while, as shown above, the speakers of those dialects tenaciously retain the vocal habit of assimilation of their Prakrit ancestors in a few cases.

                *

1

While I was Head Master of the High School at Hyderabad in Sindh, I introduced about the beginning of 1865 the study of Sanskrit, and the first thing I had to do was to teach correct pronunciation to my pupils. I bad no great difficulty, so far as I can now remember, in making them pronounce the other conjuncts, but when I came to ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç, all ny endeavours to teach its correct pronunciation failed. I got the most intelligent of my boys to pronounce first ‡§ï‡•ç and then ‡§∑‡•ç. This he did very well, whereupon I told him to utter both the sounds one after another immediately; but instead of making ‡§ï‡•ç-‡§∑‡•çof them the invariably gave them the form of ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡•ç. I then gave up attempt in despair.

And now I close this part of my inquiry. The results at which we have arrived are these: ‚Äî The vernaculars of Northern India contain the instances and, in some cases, a large number of them, given by the Prakrit grammarians or occurring in Prakrit literature, of every one of the rules or processes of change grouped by me under the heads of softening, assimilation, dissimilation, interchange of places, accentuation, and peculiarities by which Sanskrit words become Prakrit. Most of these processes have been continued and their rangewidened, to such an extent in some of the dialects as to render them distinctive characteristics of those dialects Other processes scarcely or rarely observable in the Prakrits have come into operation, such as the original accent on the penultimate syllable and the final accent derived from it, the avoiding of the hiatus caused by the elision of consonants in the Prakrits in different ways, the change of to and the dropping of one component of a double consonant and the lengthening of a previous vowel; and these have further transformed the Prakrit vocables and changed also those Sanskrit words that have been adopted in later times.

Some of the vocal tendencies and habits of the Prakrit speakers are exihibited by the speakers of the vernaculars. Thus, like the former, the ordinary Gujarati pronounces ‡§êand ‡§î as ‡§è and ‡§ì, the Deshastha Brahmans and other people of Eastern MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠ra have a predilection for ‡§£‡•çto which they reduce ‡§®‡•ç in most cases, the Sindhis make ‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡•ç of ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•ç, the Bengalis do the same and also pronounce ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡•ç, ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç and ‡§§‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ç as ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç, and ‡§§‡•ç‡§§, and the Hindi people reduce ‡§≠‡•ç to ‡§õ‡•ç. These again and the Konkan lower classes pronounce ‡§£‡•ç as ‡§®‡•ç like the speakers of the Pai≈õƒÅcƒ´, and the Bengali reduces all the sibilants to ‡§∂‡•çlike the speakers of the MƒÅgadhi; while the speakers of the Hindi, Sindhi and the Panjabi exhibit the old MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠ri and ≈öaurasenl characteristic of reducing them to ‡§∏‡•ç.

The tendency to pronounce dentals as cerebrals is common to all, though it appears in a very strong form in the mouth of the Sindhis, and next to them in that of the Panjabis and the Hindi people.

The general or almost universal elision of certain uninitial consonants, which was a characteristic of the Prakrits, has disappeared except in isolated cases, and the assimilation of the components of a conjunct, which was also very general, hast become restricted to the few cases I have mentioned, though the words changed in the Prakrits in accordance with these two processes have come down to us in large numbers. While, therefore, this fact shows that the speakers of the Prakrits were in a condition which rendered the two phenomena very general in their speech, and that we are now free from it, the fact that we exhibit some of the same vocal peculiarities which they possessed leads to the conclusion that we are their successors or lineal descendants. And the fact that the vocables in ordinary use in our modern dialects are the same as those in the old Prakrits, whether of a De≈õya or Sanskrit origin, and in the latter case, whether derived by the transformation of Sanskrit words in accordance with processes which have ceased or which have continued to operate in the vernaculars, affords strong evidence in favour of the hypothesis that these dialects are but a more developed form of the Prakrits. But to place this hypothesis beyond the reach of cavil we must examine the grammar of our vernaculars; and this I propose doing in the next two lectures.

LECTURE V

REMNANTS OF THE OLDER GRAMMATICAL FORMS IN THE NORTHERN VERNACULARS

I have already directed your attention to the accent on the penultimate syllable of words in the vernaculars of Northern India and the effect it has had in mutilating and transforming the Sanskrit and Prakrit words existing in their vocabularies. Through its influence, you will remember, the final vowel or the vowel of the last syllable is shortened in some cases, and often entirely dropped and the word ends in a consonant or silent . When the consonant of the last syllable is dropped in consequence of the Prakrit law of the elision of uninitial consonants, the final vowel and the vowel of the penultimate syllable are brought together and when they are in this condition, it is possible for them to unite into one sound and thus the final vowel is dropped in some cases and combined with the preceding in others. The Sindhi, however, oftentimes resists the influence of this accent as I have already mentioned.

CASE TERMINATIONS IN THE VERNACULARS.

Now on account of these processes, the nominative singular termination ‡§ì of masculine Prakrit nouns ending ‡§Ö in is sometimes shortened to ‡§âand in this form we have it in the Sindhi and in old Marathi and Hindi literature. In the other dialects. including the modern Marathi and Hindi, it is dropped except in instances such as ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ü‡§∏‡§∞‡•ÅM. and** ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Å** ‘command’ H. The Prakrit plural terminations ‡§Öand ‡§è of this case are also dropped everywhere for the same reason and we have such forms as ‡§π‡§æ‡§•S., ‡§π‡§æ‡§• H., ‡§π‡§æ‡§§ M. G. &c. for the nom. pl. and these are the sing. forms also except in the case of the Sindhi, which has ‡§π‡§•‡•Å.

In the Prakrit the plurals of the nominative and accusative cases of all nouns are alike and so are they alike in the vernaculars. The analogy came to be extended to the singulars also in the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa and accordingly the singulars of the two cases. are the same in the vernaculars. An independent accusative

case made up by affixing a termination to a noun is given in ordinary grammars; but it has the sense of the dative, or rather of the Sanskrit genitive, which expresses relation in general. Thus we say ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç M. ‚ÄòI do work,‚Äô ‡§π‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡§õ‡•Ç‡§ÇG., ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§Æ‡•Å‡§•‡•ã ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç B., ‡§Æ‡•à ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§¶‡§æ P., ‡§Æ‡•à‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•Ç‡§Ç H., ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡§ø or ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø or ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§õ‡§ø B., ‡§Æ‡•Å ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§õ‡§ø O., in which instances ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æetc. are really accusatives and we do not use ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∏, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§®‡•á, ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§ñ‡•á, ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ã, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•á and ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•Å, which forms are generally referred to the accusative.

The masculine nom, and acc. sing. form in‡§â was in the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa extended by analogy to the neuter singular also; and, though the peculiar neuter plural termination was preserved, the fact shows that in the vernacular speech of the times there was a tendency to forget the distinction between the two genders. Accordingly we now find that in the Sindhi, the Panjabi, the Hindi, Bengali and Oriya the distinction is entirely lost. In Gujarati also nouns ending in ‡§Öhave retained none of the two neuter terminations, but the Prakrit and Apabhra·πÅ≈õa ‡§á‡§Ç plural of that gender exists in the Marathi combined with the preceding ‡§Öinto ‡§è‡§Ç as ‚Äòa fruit’ sing., ‡§´‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç ‘fruits’ pl.

This neuter pl. termination is applied in Hindi, Sindhi, and Panjabi to the pl. of fem. nouns ending in ‡§Ö as in ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§Ç’nights’ H., ‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‚Äòwomen’ S. and ‡§ó‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç‘words’ P., though the ‡§áis changed to ‡§Üin the last two cases.

The change of the final syllables ‡§Ö‡§ìof Prakrit words resulting from such Sanskrit words as ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§ï‡§É-‡§ï‡•ã, ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§É-‡§¶‡•ã, ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§ï‡§É-‡§ï‡•ã etc. to ‡§Üby the dropping of the final and lengthening of the penultimate through the force of the general accent on the penultimate in some of the modern dialects such as the Marathi and the Hindi and to ‡§ì, into which the two vowels are combined in consequence of the weakness of the accent in such languages as the Gujarati and the Sindhi and in some of the minor dialects of the Marathi, has already been noticed in the last lecture. Similarly the change of the Prakrit final syllables of neuter nouns ‡§Ö‡§Ö‡§Çor ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç arising from such Sanskrit words as ‡§ï‡§¶‡§≤‡§ï‡§Æ, ‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç have been changed to ‡§è‡§Ç in the Marathi and to ‡§â‡§Ç in Gujarati and to ‡§Ü‡§Çin some of the dialects of the Marathi. This also has been explained. The pl. of such neuter nouns, most of which are formed by

the addition of ‡§ïand may be called augmented nouns, is formed by the addition of the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa ‡§á‡§Ç, which being rendered emphatic by the nasal sound absorbs the previous ‡§Öor light ‡§Ø and thus wehave ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ç for Ap. ‡§ï‡§Ö‡§≤‡§Ö+ ‡§á‡§Ç= Skr. ‡§ï‡§¶‡§≤‡§ï + ‡§Ü‡§®‡§ø.

Fem. nouns in ‡§á or ‡§à add ‡§Ü‡§Ç as‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•Ä-‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç H., ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§ø‡§Ü‡§Ç P. This ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Çor ‡§Ü‡§Çrepresents the combination of ‡§Øor ‡§Öwith ‡§á‡§Ç; such nouns as ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•Äbeing derived from ‡§ò‡•ã‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ = ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§ø‡§Ü. In Panjabi after fem. nouns in ‡§Ü the ‡§à‡§Ç appears distinct, as ‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ a calamity, ‡§¨‡§≤‡§æ‡§à‡§Ç nom. pl. In Sindhi the neuter termination is added to the original Prakrit fem. pl. ‡§â, shortened from ‡§ì, ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ç‘mares’nom. pl. ‡§π‡§ö‡§æ‘murder’ ‡§π‡§ö‡§æ‡§ä‡§Ç‚Äòmurders’; ‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤a ‘woman,’ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ç‡§Ç‘women’ nom. pl. This last ‡§ú‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç has it also like the P. ‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç. In Marathi also it is not very unusual to speak of women in the neuter pl. when respect is intended as ‡§∞‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§¨ ‡§Ü‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ç. This transference of neuter termination to the fem. must have taken place when gendersbegan to be confused in the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa period.

The nom. pl. termination of masc. nouns, which in the Prakrit was ‡§Ü,is preserved by the class of nouns we have been considering i. e. augmented nouns, in Sindhi and Gujarati; while the ‡§è of the Prakrit acc. pl. is used for those nouns in the Marathi and its dialects and the Hindi and the Panjabi. When the two cases were thoroughly confounded, one can easily see how this came to pass. Other or unaugmented nouns have dropped both the terminations in all the languages, as has been already noticed.

The Marathi has preserved the Apabhramsa instr. sing. ‡§è‡§Ç which is used after nouns in ‡§Ö and the plural ‡§π‡§ø‡§Çreduced to ‡§á‡§Ç. In all the modern languages the ‡§π of the Apabhra·πÅ≈õaforms is dropped. These terminations are appended to the old instrumental termination ‡§® and we have ‡§®‡•á‡§Çand ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Çwhich are now ordinarily used. These you will see are double forms and of such we have many in the various languages. Goan., Mal. and Cit. have ‡§®‡•ç for the sing. and the last has ‡§á‡§Çfor the pl.

The loc. Apabhra·πÅ≈õa‡§π‡§ø‡§Çfrom the Pali ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§øand the Skr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•çis also used, as ‡§ò‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡§æ; this is peculiar to nouns in ‡§Ö, and in Marathi it is reduced to ‡§Ü‡§Çafter the augmented nouns in ‡§Ü, as ‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§•‡§æ‡§Çetc. There are instances of the other locative in ‡§èsuch as ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á and ‡§Æ‡§§‡•á (‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡•á ‚Äòyou should go in my opinion,‚Äô

where ‡§Æ‡§§‡•áis hardly an instrumental); but here evidently the termination ‡§è is confounded with the ‡§è‡§Ç of the instrumental and we have ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§§‡•á‡§Çlit. “by my opinion.”

The dative ‡§∏ is generally considered a remnant of the Skr.‡§∏‡•ç‡§Øand Pr.‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏. But I have not found it in the J√±ane≈õvarƒ´and in its place we have ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§Çin the old poets, which is connected with a similar post-position in other languages which will be considered hereafter. None of the minor dialects of the languages have anything like it, but still the derivation may be correct.

Gujarati has the old instrumental in ‡§è‡§Ç, but it is confounded. with the corresponding ‡§è of the fem. and with the locative ‡§è and we have one termination for both, with the nasal dropped. The shortened Apabhra·πÅ≈õa form in ‡§á is found in old Gujarati. It is confounded with that in ‡§á‡§Ç, the anusvƒÅra being dropped.

(1) ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§§‡§£‡§á‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§á‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§π ‡§ò‡§∞‡§ø ‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø …… ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§≠‡§µ‡§®‡§ø ‡§®‡§µ‡§®‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø.

‘The wealth or affluence of Kanha was as great as that of Indra."

From the chronicle of Kanhadade-prabandha given in the Gujarati School-paper.

(2) ‡§™‡§õ‡§ø ‡§π‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§á‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ó‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡•§ ‡§™‡§õ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¨‡•Ä‡§ú‡•á ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡§ø.

PancopƒÅkhyƒÅna, the story of Hira·πáyaka.

In this latter, however, there occurs an anusvƒÅra, which should be correct, the termination is a remnant ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç. The Gujarati has also the double instrumental ‡§£‡•á‡§Çin pronouns, as ‡§§‡•á‡§Ç‡§£‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡•á‡§Ç‡§Ç‡§£‡•á‡§Ç, etc.

The Sindhi has got the ablative terminations ‡§Ü‡§Ç, ‡§ì‡§Ç, ‡§ä‡§Ç,‡§Ö‡§âand ‡§Ü‡§â. The first is from the pronominal instrumental ‡§π‡§æ‡§Çof the Apabhra·πÅ≈õaand ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æof the Prakrit; ‡§ì‡§Çand ‡§ä‡§Ç from ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç of the former ‡§Ö‡§â and ‡§Ü‡§â and from the corresponding Prakrit. The locative ‡§è and its shortened form ‡§á are also preserved, but they are used after nouns in ‡§Öas in the older dialects, as ‡§ñ‡•Å‡§π‡§øor ‡§ñ‡•Å‡§π‡•á‡§™‡§ø‡§ì‘he fell into a well.’

The Panjabi possesses the abl. in ‡§π‡•Å‡§Çwith the ‡§π dropped and the ‡§â‡§Ç amalgamated with the preceding ‡§Öinto ‡§ì‡§Ças ‡§ò‡§∞‡•ä‡§Ç‚Äòfrom a house, the locative pl. ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ças ‡§ò‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ç ‚Äòin the house,‚Äô the instrumental pl. ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ças ‡§â‡§Ö‡§∏‡§¶‡•á‡§Ç ‡§π‡§•‡•Ä‡§Ç‚Äòby the hands‚Äô and the locative sing. in ‡§è as ‡§â‡§∏‡§¶‡•ã‡§¶‡§∞‡§ó‡§æ‡§π‡•á‚Äòin his court.‚Äô The instr. in ‡§®‡•á‡§Ç is also ordinarily used in the form of ‡§®‡•à‡§Ç.

The Hindi has scattered instances of the loc. in ‡§è‡§Ç, but the instrumental ‡§®‡•áis common. The Bengali has preserved the former. The instrumental also has ‡§è, though the grammarians do not give it, as‚Äî

‡§∏‡§∞‡•ã‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á ‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏ ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§ø ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•á ‡§ö‡§≤‡§ø‡§∏ ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ò‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡••

‚ÄòThe beautiful one having seen the swan in the lake went in haste with a desire to catch it.‚Äô

‡§∂‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≠‡•à‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§® ‡§Ö‡§®‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§™‡•Ä‡§°‡§ø‡§≤‡•§

‚ÄòHaving heard (this) the heart of Bhaimƒ´was oppressed by love.‚Äô

‡§ó‡§ó‡§®‡§•‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§ï‡•á‡§Æ‡§® ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§™‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•á ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§£

‘How do the moon and the sun in the form of lamps shine in the plate of the sky !‚Äô

The Oriya also possesses the loc. in ‡§èand as in the B. and G. it is confounded with the instr. in ‡§è‡§Ç, the nasal being lost, as ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§Ç‘in or by the hand.‚Äô This dialect has the Pr. abl. in ‡§âalso as ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‘from the hand.‚Äô

The nom. pl ‡§ìor ‡§âof fem. nouns in ‡§Ü or‡§à is preserved in the Mal., Goan and Cit. as ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§≠, ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≠‡•ã ; ‡§∏‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã; and ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•Ä, ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ;but the two latter are derived from the Skr. ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æand ‡§ò‡•ã‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æwhich are nouns ending in ‡§Ü. The final ‡§Ü, which alone. remains after the elision of the consonant ‡§ï‡•ç, is dropped in consequence of the penultimate accent and we have ‡§∏‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä and ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•Ä. The ‡§ìor ‡§â of the plural of the original Prakrit ‡§∏‡§æ‡§°‡§ø‡§Ü‡§ì-‡§âalso isdropped like the ‡§ì or ‡§â of ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§ì-‡§â in the ordinary Marathi ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§æ;and, just as the previous vowel; in this latter is lengthened in consequence the accent and the resulting form is ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§æ, so the previous ‡§Ü of ‡§∏‡§æ‡§°‡§ø‡§Ü-‡§ì-‡§â and ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§ø‡§Ü-‡§ì-‡§â, being accented, remains and we have ‡§∏‡§æ‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ, and ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æfor ‡§∏‡§æ‡§°‡§ø‡§Ü and ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§ø‡§Ü; but in the dialects of the Marathi, in which the ‡§ìor ‡§âMasc. nouns in the sing. is preserved, we have ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ãand ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ü‡•ãetc.; so also is the ‡§ì-‡§âof the fem. preserved and we have , ‡§∏‡§æ‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã,‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ãetc.

As to unaugmented fem. nouns in ‡§á or ‡§à, the final is, of course,dropped by the penultimate accent, but in the plural it ispreserved, being accented, and the termination of the plural ‡§ì-‡§âwhich is unaccented is dropped, as ‡§µ‡•á‡§≤ sing., ‡§µ‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä pl., Skr. ‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ø,‘creeper’;‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§£ sing., ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä pl. Skr. ‡§≠‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä ‘sister; ‡§ï‡§∏ sing.‡§ï‡•Å‡§∏‡•Ä-‡§∂‡•Äpl. ‘sides’;‡§ï‡•á‡§≤ sing., ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•Äpl., Skr. ‡§ï‡§¶‡§≤‡•Äetc.

As in the dialects of the Marathi, the pl. ‡§ì is preserved inGujarati; but there it is transferred to the pl. of all nouns whatever and the process is going on even in our times, beingextended to the masc. nouns ending in ‡§ì also, which formedtheir nom. and acc. pl. formerly by adding ‡§Ü, as ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ã sing., ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§æpl., but now often ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§æ‡§ì. The sindhi also has preserved thefem. ‡§ä, as I have already observed, but the nasal of the neuter iscombined with it to form the nom, and acc. pl.

PRONOUNS IN THE VERNACULARS

The nom. sing. of the relative pronoun is in ‡§ú‡•ã M. H. P. S. and‡§ú‡•á in G. O. and B. O. have ‡§ú‡•á‡§â‡§Ç also. The ‡§è of the latter is anotherform of the nom, a to be traced perhaps to the old Magadhl nom.Sing. as in ‡§ê‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§∏ for Skr. ‡§è‡§∑‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§É. The correlative is ‡§§‡•ã in M.and H. and ‡§§‡•á in G. and ‡§∏‡•ã in P. S. and ‡§∏‡•á in B. and O. TheHindi has ‡§∏‡•ã also. The ‡§∏‡•ãis the old Pr. nom. sing., but theoblique base in P. S. B. and O. is the old ‡§§.

The base of the interrogative pronoun is ‡§ï as in the olderlanguages. The nom. sing. is ‡§ï‡•å‡§® H., ‡§ï‡•å‡§£ P. and ‡§ï‡•ã‡§£ G.M.and‡§ï‡•á O. and B.‚Äîalso ‡§ï‡•á‡§â‡§Ç O. The ‡§ï‡•ã‡§£and its varieties are to be tracedto the Pr. ‡§ï‡§â‡§£which stands for the Skr. ‡§ï‡§É ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§É.

The near demonstrative is ‡§á‡§πor ‡§è‡§πin H. P. nom. sing, whichis also pronounced in other ways; and the nom. pl. ‡§Ø‡•á. The first is to be referred to the Ap. ‡§è‡§π‡•ã, Pr. ‡§è‡§∏‡•ã, skr. ‡§è‡§∑‡§É; and thelatter to ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•á Ap. The ‡§Ö‡§Ø of the Skr. ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•çis generalised in thislanguage and is to be found in all cases of the pronoun. Hence‡§Ü‡§Ø‡•áis the nom. pl. The G. has ‡§è, M. ‡§π‡§æ m., ‡§π‡•Äfem., ‡§π‡•á‡§Ç n., ‚Äîdial.‡§π‡•ã-‡§π‡•Ä-‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç for the nom. sing., and the regular ‡§π‡•á m., ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ. fem., ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç n. forthe pl.; O. has ‡§è, ‡§è‡§π‡§ø, ‡§á‡§π‡§ø nom. sing., and B. ‡§èall of which arefrom the Ap. ‡§è‡§π‡•ã-‡§è‡§π or ‡§è‡§π‡•Å.The general oblique base is ‡§Ø or ‡§π inM., ‡§è G., ‡§á or ‡§π‡§ø S., and ‡§á in the rest, the origin of which is the

same, M. ‡§Ø, however, being referred to the Ap. ‡§Ü‡§Ø which is thegeneralised form of ‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç.

The distant demonstrative has ‡§â for its base. The nom, sing. inH. is ‡§â, ‡§ì, ‡§µ‡§π, pl. ‡§µ‡•á; in P. ‡§â‡§π, S. ‡§π‡•Ç and ‡§π‡•ã and B. ‡§ìfor both.The S. has also for the sing. G. has ‡§Ü for the sing. and itsusual ‡§Ü‡§ì for the pl. All these are to be derived from the Ap.‡§ì nom. and ‡§ì‡§á acc. pl., traced to ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•Å of the Skr. pronoun ‡§Ö‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç.The M. and O. have lost this pronoun.

PERSONAL PRONOUNS IN THE VERNACULARS

The nom. sing. of the first personal pronoun in M. is ‡§Æ‡•Ä and Cit.‡§Æ‡•á both of which are to be traced to the Ap. acc. instr. and loc. ‡§Æ‡§á‡§Ç,Pr. ‡§Æ‡§á, Skr. ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ and ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§ø. The Goon.has ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ, the G. ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç, old H. dialects ‡§π‡•å. ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç, the Dogar dialect of the P. ‡§π‡§â‡§Ç, which are all from theAp. ‡§π‡§â‡§Ç to be traced to the Skr. ‡§Ö‡§π‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç¬π, the ‡§âof which is, you willremember, that of the nom. sing, which in that dialect was freelyused as the G. si is at present. The Sindhi si and si are furthercorruptions of these. H. P. have also ‡§Æ‡•à‡§Ç like the Cit. ‡§Æ‡•á the originof both being the same. The B. and O. have ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§á and ‡§Æ‡•Å which maybe traced to the Ap. abl. and gen. sing. ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Å, but I should preferconsidering the ‡§á of the Ap. and M. forms to be changed to ‡§â inconsequence of the usual fondness of the B. and O. for the ‡§â soundas noticed in the last lecture.

The pl. of this pronoun in M. is ‡§Ü‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä, dial. ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•Ä, B. ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡§ø, which is the same as the Ap. ‡§Ö‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§á traced by me to the Skr. ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡•á.The G. ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•á and the O. ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•áare from the usual Ap, and Pr. from ‡§Ö‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•áfrom ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•ágeneralised from the usual Skr. base ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ by false analogy. In ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡•á, ‡§π‡•ç‡§Øis changed to ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠ as it often is. The H. ‡§π‡§Æis this‡§Ö‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ but the aspiration is transferred to the initial ‡§Ö, and the ‡§Æ, towhich it is attached in the older and the other dialect, is left free.The termination ‡§Ö is also dropped. The S. and P. have ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ç. Skr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æis sometimes changed in the Pr. to ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ as in the MƒÅgadhƒ´ and Mah.from locative; but in the written Prakrits that have been handeddown to us, the ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ of ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§¶‡•ç is not found corrupted to ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏. It may,however, have been so in some part of the country.

___________________________________________________________________________

1. Mr. Beames traces them to ‡§π‡§Æ‡•Å Ap., ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•çSkr., but such forms do not exist.Prof. Lassen to whom he refers, only conjectures ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡§Çto account for ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ö‡§Ç,but ‡§Ö‡§π‡§Ö‡§Çis clearly derived from ‡§Ö‡§π‡§ï‡§Æ‡•çwhich exists even in Skr. The reading ‡§π‡§Æ‡•Å in the passage from KramƒÅdƒ´≈õvara given by Lassen is questionable.Hemacandra has ‡§π‡§â‡§Ç distinctly and the form oscurs in many verses.

The second person sing.is in ‡§§‡•Ç‡§Ç all the languages except B.which has ‡§§‡•Å‡§á. The H. has ‡§§‡•à‡§Ç also. Of these ‡§§‡•Ç‡§Ç is the same as theAp. ‡§§‡•Å‡§π‡§Ç, the ‡§π of this dialect being, as you know, dropped throughout; and ‡§§‡•Å‡§π and ‡§§‡•à‡§Çare transferred from the instrumental. The pl.is ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä in M. from the Ap. ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§ásimilar to ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§á, and the B. ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§øissoftened from this. The G. has ‡§§‡§Æ‡•á, softened from ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•á, the ‡§â beingchanged to ‡§Ö by a peculiarity of the Gujarati, which has beenfully noticed in the last lecture. In the O. ‡§§‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ the final ‡§è is dropned and a softened form of this is the Hindi ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ. The P. has ‡§§‡•Å‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Çto be darived from ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ or ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Æ in the same way as ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ç from ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ.The S has ‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§§‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§§‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§§‡§à‡§Ç, ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç, ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•Ä, ‡§Ö‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§Ü‡§à‡§Ç and ‡§Ö‡§à‡§Ç. In ‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç we have the ‡§Öto which ‡§â is reduced as in G, and the ‡§Æ‡•ç of ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä analysed into its labial and nasal elements. The other three are softenedforms of this same, and in the rest the initiala ‡§§ is dropped as wehave seen it dropped in the Pr. in the bases ‡§â‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ for ‡§§‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ, ‡§â‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù for‡§§‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù, ‡§â‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠for ‡§§‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠and ‡§â‡§Ø‡•ç‡§π for ‡§§‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø, both of which exist in thatdialect.

THE VERB IN THE VERNACULARS

The Skr. conjugational distinction is, you will remember, lostin the Prakrits; but the increments that roots undergo in theseveral classes, are preserved and made parts of the roots themselves. Now these roots so augmented have descended to thevernaculars Thus we have ‡§µ‡§ø‡§πold M. G. ’to fear’ from the Skr.‡§¨‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ä of the 3rd class; ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ù M. G. ’to understand,’ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ú M.’ to becooked, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ù S. ’to throw, ’ M. G. H., etc.to dance,‡§â‡§™‡§úM. G. ’to be born,’‡§®‡§ø‡§™‡§ú M. G. ’to issue forth,’‡§ú‡•Å‡§ù M. ’to fight,’‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ú M. G. ’to be maddened’ and ‡§ñ‡§ø‡§ú old M. G. ’to be sad’ fromthe Skr. ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§®‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§™‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø and ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø, all balonging to the 4th class; ‡§∏‡•Å‡§® or ‡§∏‡•Å‡§£ H. S. B. P. O. from Skr. ‡§ó‡•É‡§£of the5th; ‡§Ü‡§£ M. G. H. P. etc. to know, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§£ B.O.’to buy’ and ‡§ó‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§πS.’ to take’ from the Skr., ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§æ, ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§£ and ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ of the 9th class. Wehave roots also in the forms which they have in the second andsixth classes, as ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æand ‡§ú‡§æfrom ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡§æ and ‡§Ø‡§æ of the 2nd, and ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ, ‡§≤‡§ø‡§π, ‡§§‡•Å‡§ü, ‡§´‡•Å‡§ü, ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§™, M., ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ç‡§µ S., ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§ (Skr. ‡§ï‡•É‡§®‡•ç‡§§), also ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ü’to out,’ ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö fromthe 6th.

VERBAL TERMINATIONS THE PRESENT

Of the three Pr. tenses and moods the Marathi has preservedtwo, the Present and the Imperative. The third, viz. the Future,is not lost, but the form became by phonetic corruption similarto those of the Present and you will remember, that the differencebetween the two tenses consisted in the intercalatory ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø, afterwards dissolved into ‡§∏‡§ø, and thence softened to ‡§π‡§ø, which, havingdropped its ‡§π in the vernaculars, melted away and another signhad to be added to the Present forms to indicate the Future. ThePresent was used in old Marathi and is used even at present inpoetry, but in ordinary speech it has acquired a past habitualsense. It has a potential signification in some cases as ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡•á‡§á‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á‡§•‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§ ‡§§‡•á‡§•‡•á‡§Ç ‡§•‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¨.In the Gujarati it has acquired a potential sense inaddition to the old and, to indicate present time distinctly, theforms of the present tense of the substantive verb are used in conjunction with it, as ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§õ‡•Å‡§Ç. The BrajbhƒÅ·π£√£ agrees with the G.in this respect and adds its it ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç as ‡§Æ‡•à‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•å‡§Ç ‡§π‡•à‡§Ç. In the H. P. and S. itsignifies potentiality only, and in the last ƒÅmasc., ƒÅfem, areadded to the forms to denote present time. ‡§•‡•ã is the past part, ofthe root ‡§•‡§ø‡§Ö‡§£‡•Åfrom Skr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§, Pr. ‡§•‡§ø‡§Ö, which means ‘become’ inSindhi. The old Hindi or Braj poots use this tense in the presentalso. In all these languages, however, the old Present tense ofthe auxiliary ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç or ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç indicates present time alone. B. O. preserve this tense in the old sense throughout.

M. has two forms of this old Present :‚Äî

2nd ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§π‡§∏‡§∏ ‡§π‡§∏‡§æ
3rd ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§π‡§∏‡•á ‡§π‡§∏‡§§

In poetry we have ‡§§‡§ø and ‡§∏‡§ø for ‡§§ and ‡§∏ as‚Äî

J√±ƒÅne≈õvarƒ´, III. 162.

The termination ‡§á‡§Ç of the first person sing. is derived from thePr. ‡§Æ‡§ø, ‡§Æ‡•ç, being simply converted into an anusv√§rs, *i. e.,*‡§Æ‡§ø when

pronounced without closing the lips, becomes ‡§á‡§Ç. In the same waythe Pr. ‡§Æ‡•Å of the pl. becomes ‡§â‡§Ç. The 2nd per. sing. ‡§∏‡§ø remainsunaltered, but in ordinary usage the final ‡§á is dropped inconsequence of the usual accent on the penultimate. The ‡§π ofPr. pl. loses its aspiration, as we have found it to have done in theand thus we have ‡§ï‡§∞ + ‡§Ö = ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ. The 3rd per. sing. terminationis the same as in pr., viz. ‡§á. The pl. has lost its nasal and incurrent Marathi they ‡§á also , on account of the penultimate accent.

In the other set the 3rd per. sing. termination is ‡§è, the same asin Pr., and to be traced to the Skr. ‡§§‡•á of the ƒÄtm. In the Prakritthere is no ƒÄtmanepada termination for the 1st per. sing., butstill we have ‡§è‡§Ç there. This vowel is inserted before all theconsonantal terminations of the present tense of the verb ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á.We have also ‡§à in ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏ and ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§, though it has no place in the Pr.This is probably due to the transference of the final ‡§á in ‡§ï‡§∞‡§∏‡•Äand ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä to the penultimate syllable.

The first of the two, i. e., the Parasm, set of forms, is used fortransitive verbs and the second or ƒÄtmanepade for those that areintransitive and some that are transitive but denote a sort ofreflexive action as ‡§™‡§¢ ’to read’, ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï to ’learn’, ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤ ’to speak’, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó’to tell’, etc.

The Cit. has both the padas and the ‡§èof the ƒÄtm. is confinedto the 3rd pers sing. in the root ‡§Ö‡§∏ as ‡§§‡•ã ‡§∏‡•á but ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç or ‡§∏‡§á‡§Ç. Inthe Mal, we have ‡§Ü, and the Goan. ‡§Ö long for ‡§è as ‡§Ü‡§∏‡§æ, ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§æand‡§Ö‡§∏, the final ‡§Ö being long. In these dialects the 2nd pers. pl.termination is ‡§§, which is transferred from the corresponding 3rdor is a remnant of the Pr. ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ and the vowels of the first pers.form v·πõddhi dipthongs with the preceding base in both the padas;as ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§∞‡•à‡•á‘I do’, or ‘I used to do’, ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§∞‡•å‡§Çwe do^(1),’ or ‘used to do.‘The Goan, and Cit., however, have the first pers. sing. ƒÄtm.in ‡§Ü‡§Ç also. The √Ñtm, is not used for roots ending in other vowelsthan ‡§Ö. though tney may be intransitive, as ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§æ, ‡§ú‡§æ, ‡§π‡•ã, ‡§¶‡•á, etc.,andin this particular the Marathi remarkably agrees with the old Pr.
___________________________________________________________________________

1. These v·πõddhi forms appear to be due to the penultimate ‡§Ö being pronouncedlong through the accent according to the usual rule and by the combinationof ‡§á‡§Ç or ‡§â‡§Ç with It; so that the combined sound in ‡§Ö‡§á‡§Ç and ‡§Ö‡§â‡§Ç. When thelangthened ‡§Ö becomes ‡§Ü it overpowers the final ‡§á and this latter isdropped and we have ‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§ÇCit. or ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç Goan., ‘I do or used to do,just as in ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§â a horse’ the penultimate is lengthened into ‡§Ü and thefinal ‡§â is dropped and we have ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§æ.

O. and B. have the following forms for the Present Tense :‚Äî
O. B.

O. has lost the ‡§∏ of the 2nd pers.sing. and has ‡§â in itsplace. This form ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã isthe same us the M. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ fromthe Pr. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§π. O. has preserved the3rd pers. pl. ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø intact; B. has lost the ‡§§and ‡§á.

The other languages have:‚Äî
G. H.
‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á ‡§Æ‡•à ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§π‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•á‡§Ç

S.Tr.
‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§ä‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ü‡§Ç-‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ä‡§Ç-‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ç

‡§π‡•Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§π‡•Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡§ø-‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡§ø
S.Intr. P.
‡§π‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§π‡§≤‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•à ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§Ø‡•á
‡§π‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç ‡§π‡§≤‡•ã ‡§§‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•á‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã
‡§π‡§≤‡•á ‡§π‡§≤‡§®‡§ø ‡§â‡§π ‡§ï‡§∞‡•á ‡§â‡§π ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£

The Hindi 2nd and 3rd person sing. and pl. are derived directly from those in Ap. The ‡§πof ‡§ï‡§∞‡§π‡§ø-‡§π‡•Å-‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç being dropped as ususl; the forms are ‡§ï‡§∞‡§á-‡§¶-‡§á-‡§á‡§Ç and, when the vowels are combined,we have ‡§ï‡§∞‡•á-‡§∞‡•ã-‡§∞‡•á-‡§∞‡•á‡§Ç.

The G. P. and B forins are exactly slmilar, the only differenceconsisting in the nasal of the 3rd. pers. pl., which has been elidedin the first, as is done in the instrumental singular. The P. and

≈ö.‡§£and ‡§®‡§ø must be referred to ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø of the Pr. since the Ap. possessed the Pr. forms as well as the new ones. In old G. MSS, it isusual to write the and of these forms separately. The G. andH. first pers. sing. ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å‡§Ç is from the Ap. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§â‡§Ç, while the art of the P.‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§Çand the S. ‡§π‡§≤‡§æ‡§Çis to be traced rather to the f of the Pr., thanto this ‡§â‡§Ç as that of the ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç in the Cit. and Goan, by the elision of ‡§áand the lengthening of the preceding vowel. There are instancesof this change given in the Pr. as we have seen. The S. ‡§â of the1st pers. pl. is the same as that in M. and O. and is to be derivedfrom the Ap. ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç and the Pr. ‡§Æ‡•Å. The ‡§è‡§Ç of the Hindi 1st per. pl. isbrought over from the 3rd person and this transference was facilitated by the nasal of the original termination; or, since in theAp. both ‡§Æ‡§øand ‡§â‡§Ç exist, when in a later stage of the language theletter was appropriated and fixed for the sing, the former wasadopted for the pl. and changed to ‡§á‡§Ç which became by amalgamation. The G. and P. further dropped the nasal of this ‡§è and interposed a vowel which is probably of the same nature as that in theS.‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ç. The S. like the M. inserts ‡§á before the terminations in thecase of transitive verbs, as in the forms of ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞ given above, anddoes not when the verbs are intransitive or reflexive as ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ïand ‡§™‡§¢.

The forms of the Ap. Present occur in the older Hindi poets. Thus in Tulsidas’s RƒÅmƒÅya·πáawe have :‚Äî

3rd per. sing.

‡§∂‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Å ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•É‡§∑‡§æ ‡§® ‡§π‡•ã‡§à‡•§ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û ‡§ú‡§æ‡§® ‡§∏‡§¨ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§à ‡•§

BƒÅla-KƒÅ·πá·∏ça.

‘But ≈öambhu’s word is not false.
Everybody knows ≈öiva to be omniscient.’

‡§®‡§ø‡§∂‡§ø‡§ö‡§∞ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ß‡•Å ‡§Æ‡§π ‡§∞‡§π‡§à‡•§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§®‡§≠‡§ï‡•à ‡§ñ‡§ó ‡§ó‡§π‡§à ‡••

≈öundars-kƒÅ·πá·∏ça.

‘An evil spirit dwells in the sea and having recourse to deceitcatches hold of the birds in the sky.’

‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§ ‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§£ ‡§ó‡§π‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§™‡•à ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡•§

BƒÅla-kƒÅ·πá·∏ça.

‘Good men like swans admit merit like milk leaving off thewatery pollution.’

‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶ ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ñ ‡§ú‡•Å ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§®‡§∞‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§∂ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§® ‡§§‡§ú‡§ø ‡§π‡•ã‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡••

BƒÅla-K.

‘Those men and women that listen to the advice of NƒÅradabecome beggars having abandoned their homes.’

2nd per. pL :

‡§ï‡§∞‡§π‡•Å ‡§ï‡§µ‡§® ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§§‡§™ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡•§

BƒÅla-K.

1st pers. sing. :

‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶ ‡§µ‡§ö‡§® ‡§® ‡§Æ‡•à‡§Ç‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§∞‡§ä‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§¨‡§∏‡•å‡§≠‡§µ‡§® ‡§â‡§ú‡§∞‡•ã ‡§®‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§°‡§∞‡§ä‡§Ç ‡••

BƒÅla-K.

‘I shall not neglect the advice of NƒÅrada and shall not beafraid even if thereby the world stands or falls (becomesdesolated).’

1st pers. pl :

‡§§‡§æ‡§§ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§π‡•Å‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§® ‡§≤‡§æ‡§à‡•§ ‡§ï‡§π‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§•‡§æ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡§æ‡§à ‡••

BƒÅla-K.

‘Dear one, do hear with an attentive mind; [we] narrate theplessing story of RƒÅma.’

Another reading is ‡§ï‡§π‡•å‡§Ç which is sing, and the sense is ‘Inarrate.’

The old 2nd pers. sing. in ‡§∏‡§ø is met with thus:‚Äî

‡§≠‡§∞‡§§ ‡§∏‡§™‡§• ‡§§‡•ã‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§π‡•Å‡§™‡§∞‡§ø ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø ‡§ï‡§™‡§ü ‡§¶‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§á‡•§
‡§π‡§∞‡§™ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§£ ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§á‡••

Ayo.-K.

‘I charge thee in the name of Bharata; tell me the truth laying aside all insincerity. On the occasion of joy thou art gloomy;explain to me the reason.’

There are also specimens of the ƒÄtm.:

‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§π‡§Ç ‡§§‡§π‡§Ç ‡§∞‡§ò‡•Å‡§™‡§§‡§ø ‡•§

BƒÅla-K.

‘Sees Raghupati here and there.’

‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§¨ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•å‡§Ç‡§∏‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§® ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§ü‡•à‡§≠‡§ï‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡§• ‡§π‡•ã‡§á ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§§‡•Ä ‡••

BƒÅla-K.

‘If now you are amorous towards the Satƒ´(PƒÅrvatƒ´), the wayof devotion will end and immorality (will) result.’

‡§ö‡§≤‡•á ‡§¨‡§∏‡§π ‡§ö‡•ù‡§ø ‡•§

BƒÅla-K.

‘He goes having sat on the bull.’

And it appears that the ‡§è of the Present is used after verbs ofthe same kind as in Marathi. The vowel ‡§á of the 3rd pers. sing.does not become ‡§è as in the modern Hindi and other languages,where the distinction between the two padas is lost, but retains.its original forms as in ‡§ß‡§∞‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§õ‡•Ä ( ‡§ó‡§á ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§™ ‡§Æ‡§π‡•á‡§∂ ‡§§‡§¨ ‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡•Ç‡§õ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•Å‡§∂‡§≤‡§æ‡§§‘when she went near, Mahe≈õa smiling asked her how she fared’ ).

THE IMPERATIVE

The Marathi, Oriya, and the Bangali have preserved theImperative mood entire; the others, only the second person sing.,the rest being taken over from the old present or the modernPotential.
M. O. B.
1st ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ç-‡§∞‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø
2nd ‡§ï‡§∞-‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞-‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§π ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ì
3rd ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å or ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å‡§®‡•ç

In the 1st per. sing. the ‡§Æ‡•Å of the Pr. is changed to ‡§â‡§ÇM. i. e.‡§Æ has lost its labial element as in the Present. O. and B. have.got the form of the Present for it, the nasal being dropped.The ‡§Æ‡•ãof the pl. is similarly changed to ‡§ì‡§Çand is also shortenedor resolved into ‡§ä‡§Ç. The B. has the same form as the sing. The2nd pers. sing. in M. has the form without the termination as inthe Pr., the other made up by adding ‡§à‡§Ç corresponds to that in theAp. ending in that vowel. Intransitive and reflexive roots have‡§è‡§Ç instead of ‡§á‡§Ç, which form is also found in the Ap. a ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§Ç,‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡•á‡§Ç.

The O. and B. do not possess these terminations but the latterhas ‡§∏‡•ç which is to be traced to the Pr. ‡§∏‡•Å. The pl. is the same as inthe Pr. the having left its trace in the lengthening of the vowel.

The O. and B. ‡§ï‡§∞ is also really ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ pronounced broadly ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ãandthe latter retains ‡§π unchanged also. The 3rd pers. sing.termination ‡§â of the Pr. is amalgamated with the precedingvowel into ‡§ì in M. and ‡§â in O. and B. M. has also sometimes ‡§âfor ‡§ì.

The ‡§ï of the B. is a later addition and is probably to betraced to the Interrogative pronoun beginning with ‡§ï. It is tobe compared with such M. expressions as ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ä‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç.The O.preserves the 3rd per. pl. ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å unchanged but in the optional formthe final ‡§â is dropped. M. and B. have transferred thecharacteristic ‡§â to the preceding syllable and the former hasdropped the nasal and the latter the ‡§§. In M. the ‡§âis, as in thesing, changed to ‡§ì, but in some cases it is preserved and wehave such forms as ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ä‡§§, ‡§¶‡•á‡§ä‡§§etc. We find instances in whichthe ‡§â preserves its place after ‡§§as in the O. Thus in J√±√§ne≈õvar! :‚Äî

‡§π‡•á ‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§≤‡§§‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•Å ‡•§ ‡§Ü‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø ‡§è‡§•‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§™‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•á‡§Ç‡§ò‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡•§ ‡§®‡§ö‡§ø‡§Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡•• I‚Äì225.

‘These on their part may do an unwelcome thing, just hereand now kill us but we should not think of doing injury.’

H. P. and G. have ‡§ï‡§∞ for the sing. as in the above; and ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ãpl.the same as that of the Present, which itself is from the Ap. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§π‡•Å,the characteristic Imper. ‡§âbeing attached to the ‡§π of the Pr.;and even in the Pr. and M. B. and O. the 2nd per. pl. is the same asin the Present. The P. has also the form in ‡§à. The SindhiImperative 2nd per. sing. of intransitive and reflexive verbs endsin ‡§â as ‡§π‡§≤‡•Å and of transitive verbs and a few others ‡§á as ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø.The ‡§â occurs in the Ap. along with the ‡§á and ‡§è as already noticed.

Though Modern Hindi has lost the Imperative forms for otherpersons than the second, old Hindi poets use them; and for thesecond per. sing. also, they have the Ap. form in ‡§á preserved inS. and M. Thus Tulsidas:‚Äî

The 2nd pers.sing. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å ‡§π‡§®‡•Å‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§π‡§ø ‡§ï‡§π‡§æ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ù‡§æ‡§à‡•§
in ‡§á ‡§ò‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§á‡••

‘The lord said to Hanumants, “Assume the form of a boy andgo to the city of AyodhyƒÅ.”’

The 2nd pers. pl. is the same as that of Present which prevailsIn all the languages from the Pr. downwards.

‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§™‡§π‡§Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§á ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§Æ‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å ‡•§

“Having gone to PƒÅrvatƒ´examine her devotion.”

The 3rd per. sing. ends in ‡§ìor ‡§îas in the M. and O.

‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§µ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ ‡§π‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ß‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡§ø ‡§∏‡•ã‡§á‡•§

‚ÄîBehƒÅrƒ™lƒÅla.

“May that polished R√§dh√§ remove my worldly distress.”

‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§π ‡§∏‡•ã‡§á ‡•§ ‚ÄîTuls. R.

“May he confer favours.”

The 3rd pers. pl. has ‡§π‡•Å which is an Ap. form found in some ofHemacandra’s quotations. The ‡§π has been introduced simply todistinguish it from the sing.

‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤ ‡§¨‡§Ç‡§¶‡•å‡§Ç‡§∏‡§¨‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡•á‡•§ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§µ‡§π‡•Å ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤ ‡§Æ‡§®‡•ã‡§∞‡§• ‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•á ‡•• ‚ÄîTuls. R.

“I adore the lotus-like feet of all. May they fulfil all my desires.”

The 1st per. sing. is the same as that of the Present and it indifficult to distinguish it; but in such a construction as thefollowing the M. would have the imperative:

‡§ö‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§§‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ ‡§Ü‡§™‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡§æ‡§à‡•§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•å‡§ï‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§à ‡••

“The Satl having got ≈öiva’s permission went, and was thinking what deception to use.”

The pl. also must be the same. Old G. has also the Imper.forms in ‡§á and ‡§â as:‚Äî

‡§™‡•Ç‡§õ‡§á‡§¨‡§æ‡§§ ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§∂‡§æ‡§π ‡§á‡§∏‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§ú‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§π‡•Ä‡§á‡§ï‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ä ‡••

“The emperor asked this matter “how is Gujarat ? "

‡§ó‡•Å‡§ú‡§∞‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§°‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§≤‡§π‡•Å ‡•§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§•‡§á ‡§ï‡§ü‡§ï ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡§≤‡•Å ‡••

“If you will declare war against Gujarat, send an army with me.”

The G. and S. have another form for the 2nd per. of the Imper.;the terminations of this are ‡§á‡§ú‡§øS., ‡§ú‡•á G. for the sing.and ‡§á‡§ú‡•ãand ‡§ú‡•ãfor the pl. The H. has ‡§ú‡•á and ‡§ú‡•ãfor roots ending in ‡§à and ‡§äand ‡§á‡§Ø‡•áand ‡§á‡§Ø‡•ãfor the rest. The P. and B. have ‡§á‡§ìfor the pl.and in the former the singular is confounded with the usual ‡§átermination. In M. such form is not now ordinarily used. Inaddresses on letters, however, such expressions as ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§µ‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ú‡•á, ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ú‡•áare used and these forms are found in the works of the oldMarathi poets. Thus in J√±ƒÅne≈õvarƒ´:‚Äî

‘‡§™‡§∞‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§ò‡§æ‡§§ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ú‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§ó ‡§Ü‡§™‡§£ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ó‡§ø‡§ú‡•á ‡•§
‡§π‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•á‡§Ç ‡•§ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§∂‡§ï‡•á ‡•• I-213.

‘This my mind cannot think of doing even in a dream that Ishould kill them and enjoy afterwards the pleasures of sovereignty.’

‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ç‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§® ‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ú‡•á ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§ó ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§π‡•ã‡§à‡§ú‡•á ‡•• IX - 1.

‘Give your attention alone and qualify yourself for allhappiness.’

‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡•á ‡§®‡•É‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§• ‡•§ ‡§ú‡§®‡§Æ‡•á‡§ú‡§Ø‡§æ‡••
‡§ú‡•á ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ø ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§Æ ‡•§ ‡§™‡§µ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•à‡§ï ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•Å‡§™‡§Æ‡•§
‡§™‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≤‡§ò‡§æ‡§Æ ‡•§‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡•ã ‡•• I-48,49.

“The Muni narrates this story to Janamejayathe king, saying(you should) attend to this which is unique, excellent, the holything, the unsurpassed and the highest abode of all auspiciousthings.”

**‡§Ü‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§á‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§® ‡§§‡•Å‡§ù‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡•á‡§® ‡••**I-8.

‘Give attention now; I will speak what you make me speak.’

These forms have been traced by Dr. Trump in his SindhiGrammar to the Pr. base in ‡§á‡§ú‡•ç‡§úused in the Present, Imperativeand Future, and derived by Lassen from the present, and by mefrom the Potential; and so far as the form in the S. and G. isconcerned there is used no objection. But these forms are used inthe vernaculars when respect for the person spoken to isintended and the Potential as distinguished from the Imperativeis by no means more respectful in Skr.
