The H. forms are notassigned each to each number, but both of them are used in thesing, or pl. and its ‡§Ø can by no means be derived from ‡§ú; for,though the contrary process, namely, the changing of ‡§Ø to ‡§ú,iscommon, there is, so far as I am aware, no single well-establishedinstance of the other.

In Skr. nothing is more usual than to use the Passive of the3rd pors. sing. Imperative in respectful solicitation. The secondpers. of the active Imper. is the least respectful, since there is adirect reference in that voice to the agent, and such a referenceto great men is regarded as improper, or in the case of others,not courteous. The 3rd pers, with ‡§≠‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç as the nom. is more so,because the reference is indirect; but the most respectful construction is the Passive as it does not point to the agent at all, butto the thing done by him. Thus the ‡§ú in these forms is from the‡§Ø of the passive and the Hindi ‡§à‡§Øfrom ‡§à‡§Ö, which is the othercorruption of that termination in the Pr.

The M. ‡§¶‡•á‡§á‡§ú‡•ãcorresponds to Skr. ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç, the Imper. 3rd pers.sing. termination in that language being ‡§â. ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ú‡•ácorresponds to‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§§‡•á of the Present and the Potential sense may be attributed tothe fact that the whole tense has assumed that sense in thevernaculars The agent may, if the forms are passive, be anyperson and any number since it does not agree with the verb;and this explains the Hindi usage. But generally in solicitationthe person addressed is the second person, though he is referredto indirectly, and he is, when cases are used, put in the instr.as in the J√±ƒÅne≈õvarƒ´:‚Äî

‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•ã‡§£‡§æ‡§§‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§£‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§ú‡•á ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§∏‡§´‡§≤ ‡•§

“He said to Dro·πáa everything should be looked after by you.”

These forms become in the G. and S. identified with the secondperson, easily because one of the terminations ‡§ìhappens to bethe same as that of the Imper. 2nd pers. pl. in those languages;and it got confused with the other Pr. Potential forms in ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú;wherefore we find in the S. the Imper. 2nd pers. sing. terminations ‡§á and ‡§â applied to the base as ‡§•‡§ø‡§ú‡§ø‘become’, ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•Å‘hear.‘This confusion extended to the Hindi also since to roots in ‡§á or ‡§âit appends ‡§ú‡•á and ‡§ú‡•ã; at for the Potential increment ‡§ú is given inthe Pr. to roots ending in ‡§Ü, ‡§á, ‡§ì etc., i. e. any vowel except ‡§Ö.In the progress of a language confusion is natural and frequentlyobservable.This double etymology explains all the facts ofthe case; while, if we confine ourselves to one, some are notaccounted for.

We have seen that there are two classes of verbs in M. one ofwhich takes the augment ‡§á in the Present before the consonantalterminations as ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏, ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§ and the other takes ‡§è or ‡§Ö as‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§§.The Imper. 2nd pers. sing. of the former is made up by adding ‡§áin old or poetic Marathi and of the latter by adding ‡§è. Theformer takes ‡§á in the Future necessarily in the 1st and 3rd pers.sing as ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≤, ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§® and optionally in some others as ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤ or ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤,‡§ï‡§∞‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤ or ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤. This option is extended even to to the Present‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•ã or ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ã and the past participle ‡§ß‡§∞‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç or ‡§ß‡§∞‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç; while in the

present participle these verbs necessarily take ‡§á as ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡§Ç.The latter class takes ‡§è in the Future 1st and 3rd pers. sing. andthe option in the last is not allowed, ‡§Öbeing added in all, including the present part as ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§≤, ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤ not ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤, ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ not‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§§‡•ã and ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á; so that this olass must have ‡§è insome cases and ‡§Ö in the rest.

The Sindhi has a similar distinction. Those roots that take ‡§ábefore the termination of the Pres. as ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§•‡•ã “I do” from theirImper. 2nd pers. sing. in ‡§á and insert this in the present part. as‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã; while the rest do not add this ‡§á as ‡§π‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç1st per. sing., ‡§π‡§≤‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ãpres, part, and take ‡§â in the Imper, sing., ‡§π‡§≤‡•Å Imper. 2nd pers. sing. We thus see that we have ‡§á in the one case and opposed to it arethe vowels ‡§è, ‡§Öand ‡§â in the other. The former is a characteristicof the transitive or the non-reflexive nature of a root while thelatter is that of the opposite.

Why should it be so? The vowels ‡§á and ‡§è form the distinctivemarks of the Parasm. and ƒÄtm. in Skr. and Pr. A consciousnessof this and of the difference between Parasm, roots and √Ñtm.roots has been preserved in the modern S. and M. and hencethere is an attempt to insert those vowels in all possible cases;and the base itself of the roots is made to end in them. But inthe Prakrits and to a great extent even in Skr. the base of most ofthe roots (‡§≠‡§£, ‡§π‡§∏ etc.) has an imperative signification. Hencethe newly constituted base ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ç and ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç also come to have animper. sense. Now these are the forms of the Imper, not only inour language but the old Apabhramia also; hence the process Imention must have been gone through even then. This is abetter explanation of the Ap. forms than deriving them bothfrom ‡§π‡§ø, especially since this is a dialect so prone to bring in ‡§πeven when it cannot be had that it is not likely to reject analready existing one.

You will thus see how subtle the operation of the law ofanalogy is in the development of a language.

Now as regards the Ap. form ‡§â, we see that we have it inSindhi where the other languages have ‡§Ö, so that it is the oldinorganic ‡§âwhich prevails so much in the Ap. And we have

seen that ‡§à is used in many more grammatical forms in M. than‡§è, whilst, instead of it, in other places and in the Sindhi in allbut the Imper. 2nd pers. sing. we have ‡§Ö; so that ‡§á is made thedistinctive mark of the Parasm. character of a root while itsabsence or the insertion of ‡§è indicates the ƒÄtm. character.

THE FUTURE

The third Skr. tense preserved by the Prakrits is the SecondFuture. It has descended to the Gujarati. Thus:‚Äî
‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•Å‡§Ç
‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§∏‡•á ‡§§‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡§∏‡•ã
‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡§∏‡•á ‡§§‡•á‡§ì ‡§ï‡§∞‡§∏‡•á

The ‡§∏ of these forms is the old Skr. ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Øcorrupted to ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ in the ≈öaur.and ‡§∏ in the Ap. From the Skr. downwards the terminations of the Present in each of the languages are appended, as formerly observed, to this tense. So in G. we find in the 2nd and 3rd pers. the terminations ‡§è and ‡§ì of the G. Present attached to ‡§∏. But the consciousness of the etymology of these forms has been partially lost;wherefore in 1st pers. we have not ‡§ï‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å‡§Ç for the sing. corresponding to ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ç, and ‡§ï‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•ácorresponding to ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ç,But G. has derived its 1st. pers. pl. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§∏‡•Å‡§Çdirectly from the Skr. or Ap. pl. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å or ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å, and the sing. ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§∏ from ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§Ç, which, you will remember, was an optional Saur. form in addition to ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ø, the nasal being dropped according to the usual Guj. rule.

We have these forms in the Braj-Bh√§·π£√§but the ‡§∏ is corrupted
to ‡§πas it very often is. Thus:‚Äî
‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡•å‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡•à‡§Ç
‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡•à ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡•ã
‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡•à ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡•à

Here in the 1st pers. sing. we have the ‡§î‡§Çof the Pres. Braj asin ‡§ï‡§∞‡•å‡§Ç, unlike the G. and in conformity with the ancient practice.You will also observe that the old augment ‡§á is preserved. Itmay be suspected that these forms are derived from those in thePr. which have ‡§π instead of ‡§∏, but you will have observed thatthere we have ‡§π‡§ø as in ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§á and here ‡§π which represents the≈öaur, and Apbhr. ‡§∏.The old Future occurs in TulsidƒÅsa’sRƒÅmƒÅya·πáa.

3rd per. sing. ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ã‡§ö ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§¨ ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡•§
‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§ø‡§® ‡§®‡§ø‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§â‡§∏‡•ã‡§á ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡••

“Dear, leave off all anxiety, remember the great God. He whocreated PƒÅrvatƒ´ will do her good.”

If the dot on ‡§π‡§ø is a mistake this is 3rd pers. sing.,

3rd pers. pl. ‡§õ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§π‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§® ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§∞‡§ø ‡§¢‡§ø‡§ü‡§æ‡§à‡•§
‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§ö‡§® ‡§Æ‡§® ‡§≤‡§æ‡§à‡••

“Good men will pardon my temerity and hear the words ofthis) child with attention.”

2nd pers. pl.‡§ï‡§π‡§§ ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡§® ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§ö‡§æ‡§à ‡•§ ‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø‡§π‡§π‡•Å ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§ø‡§π‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø ‡§ú‡§°‡§§‡§æ‡§à ‡••

“I am ashamed in my mind to tell the truth; for, hearing, atmy stupidity you will laugh.”

In these forms the terminations of the Apbhr. Present areappended to the ‡§π derived from ‡§∏; but the following are threeinstances of the Braj form occurring in the same work.

1st pers. pl.‡§§‡§¨ ‡§§‡§¨ ‡§¨‡§¶‡§® ‡§™‡•à‡§†‡§ø‡§π‡•å‡§Ç‡§Ü‡§à ‡•• ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§π‡•å‡§Ç‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§ø ‡§ú‡§æ‡§® ‡§¶‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§à ‡••

“Then I will enter thy mouth: I tell you the truth, let me go,muther. "

3rd pers. pl. ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§∏‡•á‡§§‡•Å ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§¶‡§∞‡§∂‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•Å‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§≠‡§µ‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞ ‡§§‡§∞‡§ø‡§π‡•à‡§Ç‡••

“They who will visit this bridge constructed by me willcross the ocean of life without trouble.”

In an essay published in the Bengal Asiatic Society’s Journal,1873, Mr. Beames gives the forms of the Future found in theearliest Hindi poet Cand, which are exactly similar to those inthe Braj, and misled by the latter parts ‡§π‡•à, ‡§π‡•à, ‡§π‡•ãetc., which resemblethose of ‡§Ö‡§∏ or ‡§Ü‡§∏ so greatly, traces them to the PeriphrasticFuture of the Skr. ‡§ö‡§≤‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø-‡§∏‡§øetc. But this future is in the firstplace rarely used in Skr. and altogether discarded by the Paliand not a trace of it is to be found in any of the numerousPrakrits. Besides if we derive these forms from the PeriphrasticFuture, we must have in the 3rd pers. such forms as ‡§ö‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ü-‡§ö‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æand ‡§ö‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ü‡§∞. And the old forms which Tulsidas uses of the typeof ‡§ö‡§≤‡§ø‡§π‡§π‡§ø, from which evidently the others are derived, willremain unexplained. There can be little doubt that this derivation is wrong. We have seen the several steps by which wegradually rise to ‡§ö‡§≤‡§ø‡§π‡•à from ‡§ö‡§≤‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø and the chain is so wellconnected that this etymology must be admitted as correct.The resemblance to that form in Gujarati also must not beforgotten.

THE PAST TENSE

Past time is, in all the vernaculars, expressed by means ofthe past participle as in the Pr., all the Skr. past tenses being lost,as you will remember, except in isolated cases. This participleis in the older languages passive in the case of transitive verbsgenerally and active when the verb is intransitive and also inthe cases of some transitive verbs such as ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡•ã‡§Ç, ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡•ã‡§Çetc.This rule is strictly observed in most of the modern dialects andhence in the past tense we have generally no active voice whenthe verb is transitive and the agent is, as in the older languages,put in the instr. thus in H. ‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡§ï‡§®‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ã‡§•‡•Ä ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡•Ä, P. ‡§â‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ,S. ‡§π‡•Å‡§® ‡§´‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ñ‡•á ‡§ß‡§®‡•Å‡§°‡§ø‡§£‡•ãG. ‡§ú‡§¨‡•á‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§∏ ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã, M. ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§Ç‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ. In all these sentences the last words are past participles and they agree with the object in the Nom. case in number,gender and person. In the O. and B., however, all distinctionbetween gender, number and person being lost, the agreementwith the object is not perceptible. In these languages, and tosome extent in Marathi, this participle is made the base of theregular verbal forms; wherefore I shall have to discuss thispoint again.

THE PAST PARTICIPLE

The Hindi participle ends in ‡§Ö which of course is the sametermination as in Pr., thus Skr. ‡§ó‡§§, Pr. ‡§ó‡§Ö, the consonant beingelided, and with the connecting ‡§Ø‡•ç, ‡§ó‡§Ø. When augmented by theaddition of ‡§ï in the manner I have shown in the last lecture andalso in this it is ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ, the ‡§Öalone of the ‡§ï being left. In thefeminine the augmented form is ‡§ó‡§Ø‡•Ä and where this ‡§Ø is notinserted it is ‡§ó‡§à. By adding this augmented form to any rootwhatever the Hindi past participle is formed as ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ, ‡§™‡§¢‡§æ etc.An euphonic ‡§Øintervenes when the root ends in a vowel as ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ,‡§™‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ etc. Similar to this is the B. and O. past participle as ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§æin ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§µB, ‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡§æ, ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ O. The S. terminstion is ‡§á‡§ì and the P.

‡§á‡§Ü As ‡§Ü‡§ó‡§ø‡§ì from ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡§£‡•Å ’to be awake,’ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ñ‡§ø‡§ìfrom ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§ñ‡§£‡•Å ’to remain,’‡§ó‡§á‡§Ü ‘gone’, ‡§ò‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ü ‘sent;’ the nom. termination ‡§â and the augment‡§Ö for ‡§ï heing left out of consideration it is reduced to ‡§á‡§Ö. TheG. hss ‡§Ø‡•ã and the Braj. ‡§Ø‡•åas in ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•å ‘kept’ from ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ,‡§ï‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã, ‡§ï‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•å’told’ from ‡§ï‡§π, where also the ‡§ì being dropped the termination is i. e. g ‡§á‡§Ö hastily pronounced. These languages therefore preserve the old termination with augment prefixed to itas in the Pr, as ‡§π‡§∏‡§ø‡§ì, ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ì etc. Some of the vernsculars andnotably the Sindhi have also inherited from the Pr. readymadeTadbhava forms of the past passive participles as:‚Äî

[TABLE]

The Sindhi seems to have made up the forms of a few rootson the analogy of these though they do not exist in the Pr. as‡§ù‡§≤‡•ç‡§§‡•ã from ‡§ù‡§≤, Skr. ‡§ß‡•É‡§§, Pr. ‡§ß‡§∞‡§ø‡§ì; ‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡•ã drunk, ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§§‡•ã done; ( P. hasthis also ); but some of these may be modern Tadbhavas.

Marathi does not possess this form and past tense is expressedin that language by a form ending in ‡§≤‡§æ-‡§≤‡•Ä-‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç. This is adjectivalin nature and passive in the case of transitive verbs and activein that of intransitive or reflexive verbs. It is in every respectthen like the Skr. and Pr. past participle preserved in the otherdislects. But here we have ‡§≤ (‡§≤‡§æ) for the ‡§Ö (‡§Ü) of those,

This ‡§≤ has been traced to the Skr. ‡§§; but since in the MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´or principal Prakrit that termination leaves its ‡§Ö only,it must be derived from the ≈öaur.‡§¶ which often becomes ‡§°, and‡§° is frequently confounded with ‡§∞ and ‡§≤ as we have seen.In Sindhi Skr. ‡§¶ is always ‡§° as ‡§°‡•á‘give’ from ‡§¶‡§æ, ‡§°‡•Å‡§ß‡•ãfrom ‡§¶‡•Å‡§ó‡•ç‡§ßand ‡§°‡§ø‡§†‡•ãetc. Similarly even in the Prakrit period, such a changemust have taken place in several words; for instance, the Skr.‡§¶‡§∂ in ‡§è‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§∂ and in some of the succeeding numerals, becomesin the Pali ‡§¶‡§∏, but is changed to ‡§∞‡§π in the Pr., which shows that‡§¶ must have become ‡§° before it aesumed the form of ‡§∞. ‡§° is interchanged with ‡§≤ even in Skr. as ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§°‡§æ‡§∂ or ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•ã‡§≤‡§æ‡§∂; and in the Pr.and modern dialects we have ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§≤ for ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§°, ‡§™‡•Ä‡§≤ or ‡§™‡•Ä‡§≤ for Skr. ‡§™‡•Ä‡§°,‡§°‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Æ for ‡§¶‡§æ‡§°‡§ø‡§Æetc. So that this etymology is possible; but I shall presently show to you that it is not to the ≈öaur. that weshould first look for the origin of M. words and forms; especiallyin cases when it stands alone. That the Marathi only shouldexhibit these consonantal changes in the past participle andnone of the other sister dialects and that no instance of theintermediate step between the ≈öaur. ‡§¶ and the M. ‡§≤ should befound here or elsewhere as we find them in similar cases, goesa great way against this derivation.

The Marathi past participle in ‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§≤‡•Ä, ‡§≤‡•á‡§Çis, I think, of thesame nature as similar participles in other cognate languagesending in that termination. We have in G. besides ‡§ï‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã, ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã, ‡§ï‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§≤‡•ãand ‡§ï‡§∞‡•á‡§≤‡•ã and in s. besides ‡§¨‡§ø‡§ì and ‡§¶‡§ø‡§†‡•ã, ‡§¨‡§ø‡§Ö‡§≤‡•Å and ‡§¶‡§ø‡§†‡§≤‡•Å.There is a little difference in the sense, but both are promiscuously used in ordinary usage. B. and O. form their Preteritewith this participle as the base as ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡•á ‡§ï‡§π‡§ø‡§≤B. ‘Gopaltold us’;‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á ‡§ï‡§≤‡§Æ ‡§¶‡•á‡§π ‡§≤‡•á‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤ O. ‘I wrote with a pen.’ It is alsoused as an adjective as ‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®the past day,’ ‡§™‡§°‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ó‡§õ’the fallentree.‘Though it does not occur in high Hindi and is notgiven in the grammars of the languages, the lower classes ofthe Hindi population use this participle very commonly as‡§µ‡•á‡§ö‡§≤ H. ‘sold,’ ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§≤‘gone’; and it is also found in the works ofKabƒ´ra, though I have not seen it in Tulsƒ´dƒÅsa’s RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa, whichis accounted for by the fact that Kabƒ´ra was a S≈´dra himselfand consequently belonged to those classes which use it at thepresent day. Thus:‚Äî

‡§§‡§¨ ‡§¨‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§™‡•Ç‡§õ‡§≤ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§§‡•ã‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑ ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡••

‚ÄîRƒÅmƒÅya·πáa II-4.

“Then BrahmƒÅasked his mother: ‘Who is thy husband andwhose wife art thou !’”

‡§ö‡§π‡•Å‡§ú‡•Å‡§ó ‡§≠‡§ó‡§§‡§® ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§≤ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ü‡•Ä ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ù‡§ø ‡§® ‡§™‡§∞‡•à‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ü‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§´‡§æ‡§ü‡•Ä ‡••

‚ÄîRƒÅmƒÅya·πáa V-7.

“In all the four ages holy men constructed ways but theydid not know that the bundle they had tied had given way orwas torn!”

Now in the Sindhi participles ‡§≤ is a termination appendedto other or old participles; as ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ö and ‡§¶‡§ø‡§† with the suffix ‡§≤become ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ö‡§≤ and ‡§¶‡§ø‡§†‡§≤. The Gujarati ones are of the samenature; in ‡§ï‡§π‡•á‡§≤‡•ã, ‡§≤‡•ã is the suffix and ‡§ï‡§π‡•á is the original participlein ‡§á‡§Ö or ‡§Ø or ‡§ï‡§π‡§ø‡§Ö or ‡§ï‡§π‡•ç‡§Øwhich is changed to ‡§è, as ‡§Ø often is.Even in Marathi in the forms ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§Ü‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§≤‡•ã in the minordialects, ‡§ú‡§æ‡§π‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§Æ‡•á‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ etc., ‡§ó‡•árepresents ‡§ó‡§Ø (Pr. ‡§ó‡§Ö,Skr. ‡§ó‡§§ ); ‡§ï‡•á, ‡§ï‡§Ø ( Pr. ‡§ï‡§Ö, Skr ‡§ï‡•É‡§§); ‡§Ü‡§Ø ,‡§Ü‡§Ö(Pr. ‡§Ü‡§Ö‡§Ö, Skr. ‡§Ü‡§ó‡§§);‡§ú‡§æ‡§π, ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ö(Pr. ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ö, skr. ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§) ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Æ‡§Ø ( Pr. ‡§Æ‡•É‡§§) ‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ-‡§≠‡•Ä‡§Ü, ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ-‡§™‡•Ä‡§Üand so on. In the B. too we have ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤, ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤, ‡§Ü‡§á‡§≤ which are justlike the Marathi forms and are to be explained in the same way.In old Marathi we similarly find this ‡§≤ appended to real pastparticiples. In an old Inscription dated ≈öaka 1128 = 1206 A. D.,the latter portion of which is in the Marathi of the time and being so was difficult to decipher, there occurs the expression‡§Æ‡§¢‡§æ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§≤‡§æ‘given to a monastery’ in which we see that ‡§≤‡§æ isappended to ‡§¶‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§πwhich is the same as the old Pali and Pr. participle ‡§¶‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§£of the root ‡§¶‡§æ.

In Skr. a great many roots formed their participles by adding‡§® instead of ‡§§and we find several of these and others formedon the analogy of these in old Hindi and Marathi poetry. Inthe works of Tulsƒ´dƒÅsa, Kabƒ´ra, Canda and others ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§π‘done’‡§≤‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§ø’taken,’ ’ ‘known,’ ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§π ‘given’ and such others occur :‚Äî

‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§∂‡§ø‡§∑ ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡•Ä ‡••

“The sage worshipped him in several ways, praised him andgave him a blessing.”

In the Marathi poets we have added to ‡§® as J√±ƒÅne≈õvarƒ´.

‡§§‡•á ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§¨‡•ç‡§¶ ‡§Ö‡§ö‡§æ‡§ü ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡§≤‡•á ‡§è‡§ï‡§µ‡§ü ‡•§

‘Both these dreadful noises mingled together.’

‡§∏‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§∂‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§®‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§¨‡§∏‡§æ ‡•§

“The hopes of Sanaka and others increased greatly.”

EkanƒÅtha.

‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§ò‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§≤‡§æ ‡•§

‘Ran towards Dharma or virtue.’

‡§ê‡§ï‡•ã‡§®‡§ø ‡§π‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§®‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡•§

‘Hearing this, Govinda smiled’.

Rukmi·πáƒ´Svaya·πÉvara.

In the following ‡§≤‡§æis applied to old Tadbhava participles:‚Äî

‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡•á‡§ú‡•á ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡§≤‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§™‡•ç‡§®‡§∏‡•Å‡§ñ‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡§≤‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§ó ‡§§‡•ã ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ‡§®‡•ã‡§¶‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•á‡§á‡§≤‡§æ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§£‡•ã‡§®‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‡••

J√±ƒÅn. V-47.

“Because when he slept on the bed of delusion he enjoyed thepleasures of a dream and then awoke when the sun of knowledgerose.”

‡§≠‡•Ä‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§≤‡§æ ‡§â‡§†‡§æ ‡§â‡§†‡•Ä‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§ú‡•á‡§• ‡§ú‡§ó‡§ú‡•á‡§†‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£ ‡••

‘Went in where the lord of the world ≈öri K·πõ·π£·πáa was.”

Here ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§§ and ‡§™‡§æ‡§§, are from ‡§∏‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§,‡§≠‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§ and ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§ Pr. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§™‡•ç‡§§, ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§§ snd ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§§Skr.; and to these ‡§≤‡§æ, is added. There are other instances in theseworks in which ‡§≤‡§æis added to past Tatsams or later TadbhavaParticiples such as ‡§¶‡§ó‡•ç‡§ß‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§≤‡•Å‡§¨‡•ç‡§ß‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§π‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§π‡§£‡§ø‡§§‡§≤‡§æ; and in theInnguage of the day we have ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§≤‡•á, ‡§ò‡•á‡§§‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ß‡•Å‡§§‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç and oneor two others. In the J√±ane≈õvarƒ´we have also such forms as ‡§¨‡§ø‡§∏‡§£‡•à‡§≤‡§æ’excited’, ‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡•à‡§≤‡§æ‘slept’, and ‡§Ü‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞‡•à‡§≤‡§æ where the ‡§ê represents the‡§Ö‡§Ø or ‡§á‡§Ö of the old participle resembling in this respect the Guj‡§´‡§π‡•á‡§≤‡•ã.

When the ‡§Ö or ‡§Üof the old participle became too weak to beexpressive, this form with the suffix ‡§≤ attached was oftener usedand gradually supplanted the other; and ‡§≤ came in the course oftime to be regarded as the past participle termination. Hence itis applied to roots directly without the intervention of the old ‡§èthat we have in ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡§æ and ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡§æ; and in low Hindi also, it is appliedin the same way. The original participle was mostly used

predicatively as it it is in classical Skr. also, and this ‡§≤ wasattached to it to form an attributive expression to be used beforenouns. But after time this new form also came to bepredicatively used; and it is now so used in M., G., S. and H.In M. however, when it was put to this purpose, it drove out theold one, and its own attributive sense became faint, though evennow it is not entirely lost in such instances as ‡§ù‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä‡§∏‡§â‡§™‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç’there is no remedy against the thing that has alreadytaken place.’

Then another ‡§≤ came to be attached to it to adapt it forattributive use, and thus we have now in M. the form ‡§ï‡•á‡§§‡•á‡§≤‡§æ, ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•á‡§≤‡§æetc. with a double ‡§≤. This ‡§≤ is to be traced to the Pr. ‡§á‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤or ‡§â‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤which according to Hemacandra is applied in the sense of BhƒÅvai.e. being the thing signified by the base as ‡§â‡§µ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§Ç, ‡§Ö‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡•Å‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§Ç. These twowords aro in M. ‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≤ or ‡§µ‡§∞‡§≤‡§æ and ‡§Ü‡§™‡•Å‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç or ‡§Ü‡§™‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç, in which instanceswe see that the initial ‡§á or ‡§â of the suffix is optionally dropped.Or according to other writers, quoted by our grammarians, ‡§Ü‡§≤is also used. And in works such as the Gau·∏çavadha and in theBhagavatƒ´we find these suffixes frequently used. These aregenerally applied to all bases; but ‡§≤ is another terminationwhich is restricted to certain nouns such as ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§§‡•ç, ‡§™‡•Ä‡§§, ‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§∞, ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§ß,from which we have ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§≤, ‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡§≤ etc. In Skr. also this suffix hasn pretty wide range as ‡§ö‡•Ç‡§°‡§æ‡§≤ PƒÅ·πáini V. 2 96 ‡§∏‡§ø‡§ß‡•ç‡§Æ‡§≤, ‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§≤, ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§≤,‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡§≤, ‡§∏‡•ç‡§®‡•á‡§π‡§≤ etc, V. 3. 97 ‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡§≤ V. 2.98; ‡§´‡•à‡§®‡§≤ V. 2-99.

THE PRESENT PARTICIPLE IN THE VERNACULARS

The present participle of the Pr. has lost its ‡§® M. as ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§§, ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§§, in G. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‘doing’, ‡§ö‡§¢‡§§ ‘ascending’, in H. as ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ and in B.as ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§§, ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§ø‡§§,while the O. has preserved it as ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§, ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§®‡•ç‡§§. The S.and P. have preserved the ≈öaur. form which has ‡§¶ instead of ‡§§and the former has preserved the nasal throughout while theIntter has dropped it after roots in ‡§Ö as S. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ã, ‡§π‡§≤‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ã, P. ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ñ‡§¶‡§æ‘writing” but ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ‘going’, ‡§π‡•ã‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ‘becoming,’ this participle is used,as in the Pr., in the sense of Skr. Conditional, equivalent to theEnglish Pluperfect Conditional, as M. ‡§§‡•ã ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡§∞ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•á‡§Ç‘if he haddone it, it would have become, G. ‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§ ‡§§‡•ã ‡§•‡§æ‡§§; B. ‡§∏‡•á ‡§Ø‡§¶‡§ø ‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ï‡•á‡§ï‡§π‡§ø‡§§ ‡§§‡§¨‡•á ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡§ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ ‡§®‡§æ; if he had told you, you would nothave believed;’ O.‡§ú‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§â‡§¶‡§Ø ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§ ‡§§‡•á ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§® ‡§∞‡§π‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‘if the sun

had arisen, the darkness would not have remained’; H. ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•à‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§π‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§æ‡§§ ‡§® ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§§‡§æ‘if I had told, he would not have listened to mywords;’ S. ‡§ú‡•á‡§π‡•Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•á ‡§® ‡§§‡§∞‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ã‘if he had not been swimming’, ‡§ú‡•á ‡§Æ‡•à ‡§ò‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§¶‡§æ ‘if I were to send.’

THE ABSOLUTIVE IN THE VERNACULARS

The absolutive in M. is formed by adding the termination ‡§ä‡§®, as ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç‡§®, the same as the MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´‡§ä‡§£. Vararuci, you willremember, gives this termination only, but Hemacandra adds more.

The G. has ‡§á, the same as the Ap. ‡§á and Pr. ‡§á‡§Ö, Skr. ‡§Ø, and ‡§á‡§®‡•áfrom the Ap. ‡§è‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡§ø‡§£‡•Å or ‡§è‡§™‡•ç‡§™‡•Ä, the Vedic Skr. ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡•Ä‡§®; or the ‡§®‡•á of ‡§á‡§®‡•á maybe the same as the particle ‡§®‡•áwhich means ‘and’ added to ‡§á.

The Sindhi has ‡§á for intransitive and reflexive roots and ‡§è fortransitive and another ‡§á‡§ìor ‡§Ø‡•ã for both, as ‡§∏‡•Å‡§£‡•Ä‘having heard’,‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•á having beaten’ and ‡§∏‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ãor ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç. The first is the same asthe G., but in the ‡§èof the transitive roots the ‡§Öof the original‡§á‡§Ö seems to be preserved and this termination added to the rootwith the Parasm. sign ‡§á. Thus we have first ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Äand then, ‡§á‡§Ö or ‡§á‡§Øbeing added, we have ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ø, whereupon the ‡§Ø with thepreceding ‡§á becomes ‡§è and we have ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•á. The last ‡§Ø‡•ã is the sameas the ‡§á‡§â of the Ap., traced to the infinitive, which, you willremember, is confounded with the absolutive.

The H. drops the ‡§á of this form and the original root, as ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤,‡§ú‡§æ etc., is used in the sense of the Absol., but to make the sensedistinct ‡§ï‡•á or ‡§ï‡§∞ is added, as‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§ï‡•á or ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§ï‡§∞, ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ï‡•á or ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞. Ofthese ‡§ï‡•á is a real absolutive derived from the ≈öaur. ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Öand ‡§ï‡§∞is the same as ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤, i. e. the usual form of it. Now when one formis felt to be not distinct enough, it is usual in our languages toadd another to it of the same nature. You have instances ofthisprocess in the Pali double genitive ‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡§æ‡§®‡§Ç, and in the instr.‡§®‡•á‡§Ç and ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Çof some of our vernaculars.

P. agrees with the H. In H., however, the ‡§á is pronounced bya great many people. It is also found in the old posts and in theBrajabhƒÅ·π£ƒÅ. The absolutive always ends in this vowel as ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø,‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø, though often ‡§ï‡•à the same as H.‡§ï‡•á is added, as ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•à, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡•à, etc.

The O. also has ‡§á as ‡§ï‡§∞‡§øand the B. has ‡§á or ‡§è or ‡§á‡§Ø‡§æ as ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§ø,‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡•á or ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ ‘having seen’. In the last the ‡§Ö of the original ‡§á‡§Öis preserved and longthened, and the ‡§Ø is ouphonic.

THE INFINITIVE OF PURPOSE IN THE VERNACULARS

The infinitive of purpose is preserved in M. as ‡§§‡•ã ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§≤‡§æ ‘he began to study.’ The form in the Pr. is ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§â‡§Ç, but theaugment ‡§á is lost in M. O. also has it, but its use is somewhatlike that of the Absolutive ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Å ‡§ï‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡•á ‘considering he spoke,’ ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§â ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§â ‡§§‡•É‡§™‡•ç‡§§ ‡§π‡•ã‡§á‡§≤‡§æ ’eating and eating he was satisfied.’ But theoriginal sense is somewhat preserved, and it is in this sensemade the basis of the present tense definite, which will be considered hereafter. This infinitive and the absolutive are, I havealready observed, confused in the Pr., and in some of the moderndialects the absolutive is used where we in Marathi use theinfinitive: as G. ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§õ‡•Å‡§Ç‘I am able to do it,’ H. ‡§Æ‡•à ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç, ‡§¨‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§π‡•à ‘whom speech cannot express,’ Br. ‡§Æ‡•à ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ï‡•å‡§Ç ‡§π‡•ã‡§Çfor M. ‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§ï ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§ï‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç. For this infinitive the modernvernaculars however have got a reconstructed form which willbe mentioned in its proper place.

THE POTENTIAL PARTICIPLE IN THE VERNACULARS

The potential participle in Skr. ‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø, Pr. ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ, is much used inthe modern dialects and made the base of various verbal formations. In M. we have ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç ‘should be done,’ G. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§¶‡•Å‡§Ç. S. ‡§™‡§∏‡§ø‡§¨‡•ãfrom ‡§™‡§∏to see, Braj ‡§ï‡§∞‡§µ‡•å‡§Ç, B. & O. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§¨‡§æ. The H. has lost it, soalso the P.

The Skr. verbal noun in ‡§Ö‡§®appears as ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§Çin M., ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•Å S., ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•åBraj., ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§æ H. and P., ‡§ï‡§π‡§®O. & B., but in these latter it isprobably a modern Tatsama. G. does not possess it. Theseforms are called infinitives by the Vernacular grammarians.Prof. Hornle traces them to the Skr. potential participle in ‡§Ö‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø;but, as before remarked, the transition from ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Çto ‡§®‡§Ø‡§Ç and thento ‡§®‡•á‡§Ç is taken for granted; regularly ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ø ought in the vernacularsto be changed to ‡§®‡•Äas in ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä. According to the observations Imade before the ‡§è‡§Ç of ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§Ç and ‡§î‡§Ç of ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•å‡§Ç must be due to ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç-‡§Ö‡§Ö‡§Ç-

‡§Ö‡§Ø‡§Ç Pr. and ‡§Ö‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç-‡§Ö‡§â‡§ÇAp., as in M. ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•á‡§Çand G. ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•Å‡§Ç; so that the verbalnoun in M. and H. is an augmented form of the correspondingone in Skr., while that of the Sindhi is from the unaugmentedform. A great many other verbal derivatives have come downto the vernaculars, but I must not go further.

THE PASSIVE IN THE VERNACULARS

The Pr. passive base in ‡§à‡§Öand ‡§á‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú has been preserved onlyin P. & S. Thus ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ö ‘he may be beaten’ and ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ö‡§® ’theymay’ be beaten’ are forms of the 3rd pers. sing. and pl. of thepassive old Pres, and modern Potential; while ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§¶‡§æthe presentpart. is used as a base to form various tenses. This is the Pr.form in ‡§á‡§Ö the ‡§Ö being lost. Sindhi has ‡§ú as ‡§™‡§ú‡§ø‡§£‡•Å ’to be drunk,’‡§ò‡•ã‡§á‡§ú‡§£‡•Å ’to be washed,’ ‡§µ sing, ‡§ß‡•ã‡§á‡§ú‡§®‡§ø pl 3rd pers. Pres or Pot.The pres part is wanting the potential porticiple from ‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Øbeing used instead as ‡§ß‡•ã‡§á‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç. The augment ‡§á is introduced beforethis ‡§úwhere euphony requires it. Old M. possessed these formsand they are very frequently to be met with in our poets as inJ√±ƒÅne≈õvarƒ´:

‡§Ü‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡§æ ‡§µ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ø‡§ï‡•§ ‡§ú‡•á ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§¢ ‡§ß‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§∏‡•à‡§®‡§ø‡§ï ‡•§ ‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ó‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§á‡§ï ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§ú‡§§‡§ø ‡••

‘Now inoidentally will be mentioned, the leaders, provedwarriors and soldiers in our army.’

‡§§‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§§‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§ú ‡§ù‡§ï‡§ä‡§® ‡§® ‡§Ø‡•á‡§∏‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§µ‡§æ‡•§
‡§ú‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ ‡§ì‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ú‡•à‡§≤‡••

“In thst msnner, O lord MƒÅdhava, you will abandon me andwill not come to me if the moisture of virtue is dried up(IIt will be destroyed).

‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Ç ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§®‡•Å ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•Å‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ú‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡•Å ‡•§
‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ß‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§Ç ‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡•Å ‡•§ ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§•‡•Ä‡••

‘Think, Arjuna, you are being msde contemptible by sorrow;say, is the sun ever swallowed up by darkness ?’

Here we have instsnces of the Present and Future Old Guj.had the passive :

‡§ú‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§ú‡§á ‡§∏‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ ‡•§ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§™‡§ø‡§á‡§ú‡•á ‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡•§
‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§à ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ø‡§á ‡•§ ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§£‡§ø ‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§æ‡§ó‡•ç‡§Ø‡•§
‡§ú‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∑‡§ü‡•ç‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡§® ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ú‡§π ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ó ‡•§ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç‚Ä¶‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡§æ‡§£ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ù‡•Ä‡§á‡••
‡§®‡§µ ‡§ñ‡§Ç‡§°‡•á ‡§Ö‡§™‡§ï‡•Ä‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§∞‡§π‡•Ä‡•§ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ß‡§µ‡§ø ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≤‡•á‡§õ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§π‡•Ä‡••

‘Where ≈öƒÅlƒ´grƒÅma is worshipped, where the name of Hari ismuttered in meditation and Sm·πõtis, PurƒÅ·πáas and the cows arerespected, in which country sacrifices are performed, where thereare the six philosophies, and alms are given, where Vedas,PurƒÅ·πáas and duty are understood, there MƒÅdhava for certainbrought the Mlechha and infamy rests (on his name) in the ninedivisions (of the world).’

Here we have instances of the forms in ‡§úas ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§ú‡§á and in ‡§à(Pr. ‡§á‡§Ö) ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ù‡•Ä‡§á; and also of the modern forms as ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ø which willbe presently considered. In old H. poets we meet with suchforms now and then. Thus Tulsƒ´dƒÅsa :

‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Å ‡§ú‡§æ‡§® ‡§ó‡§£‡§∞‡§æ‡§ä ‡•§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§•‡§Æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§ú‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§ä ‡••

‘The greatness of which (RƒÅma’s name) the lord of theGa·πáas (Ga·πáapati) knows, he is first worshipped; this is theachievement of the name.’

‡§ö‡§π‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§ ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§∞ ‡§≤‡§ñ‡§ø ‡•§ ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ö‡§® ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§≤ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï ‡•• BehƒÅrƒ´lƒÅla.

‘Many couples of eyes are wanted to see the couple of youngpersons (RƒÅdhƒÅand K·πõ·π£·πáa).

Hero ‡§™‡•Ç‡§ú‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§ and ‡§ö‡§π‡§ø‡§Ø‡§§ are forms of the passive in ‡§à‡§Ø. Theverb ‡§ö‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á in mod. H. is also a passive forms as ‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§á‡§Ø‡•áG. and‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§ú‡•á M.

There are also, as in the Pr., Siddha Tadbhava forms of thepassive ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ù‡§£‡•ÅS. ’to be heard,’ S. ’to be broken,’ H. ’to fleeaway,’ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§£‡•ÅS. ’to be fried,’‡§õ‡§ø‡§ú‡§£‡•ÅS. ’to be plucked’ from pr. ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù,‡§Æ‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú, ‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú and ‡§õ‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§úand Skr. ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§≠‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§≠‡•É‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§Ø and ‡§õ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø,‡§™‡§ö-‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§™‡•Å-‡§®‡§æ-‡§£‡•Å-‡§®from ‡§™‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö Pr., ‡§™‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø Skr. ’to be cooked’ in all, though the sense issomewhat altered. ‡§≤‡§æ‡§≠‡§£‡•á‡§Ç M., ‡§≤‡§≠‡§£‡•Å S. from Pr. ‡§≤‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠,Skr. ‡§≤‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø’to beobtained,’ ‡§¨‡§ù‡§£‡•Å S., ‡§¨‡§ù‡§®‡§æ H. from Pr., ‡§¨‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù, Skr. ‡§¨‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø ’to be bound;’‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§∑‡•Å‡§Ç-‡§®‡§æ M, G. H. P. from Pr. ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∏, Skr.‡§¶‡•É‡§∂‡•ç‡§Ø ’to be seen’ also ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ñ‡§®‡§æH.; ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ú‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§£‡•Å‡•ÅM. S., ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§ú‡§®‡§æH. P. from Pr.‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤, Skr. ‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø’to be known.’ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ö‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•Å‡§ÇM. G. from ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö Pr., Skr. ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö ’to occur to one’etc.

THE CAUSAL IN THE VERNACULARS

The causal is formed in M. by appending ‡§à‡§µ or ‡§Ö‡§µ as ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§Çor ‡§ï‡§∞‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§Çor ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§Ç; you will remember, I have identified.the ‡§à that non-reflexive transitive roots take in M. with the

Parasm. ‡§á, and ‡§è or ‡§Öof the intransitive and reflexive with theƒÄtm. Now when a root becomes causative, its reflexive characteris lost, all verbs become transitive, and hence we have ‡§Ö or ‡§àpromiscuously used after all roots. For this reason even inSkr. all causal verbs are both Parasm. and ƒÄtm. I do not derivethe rule about M. verbs taking ‡§Öor ‡§á from that in Skr., butattribute it to the same causes. In the Goan. and Cit. we have‡§Ö‡§Ø for ‡§Ö‡§µ, the ‡§Ø being pronounced as a consonant and often likethe vowel ‡§á, as ‡§ï‡§∞‡§Ø‡§£‡§Ç or ‡§ï‡§∞‡§á‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç. In the Savantvadi and Vengurladistricts it is formed in the same way, but in the other portionsof the area over which the MƒÅlva·πáƒ´is spoken it is formed as inthe principal Marathi. The ‡§Ø stands for ‡§µ; for this semi-vowelis often, by the vulgar, dropped leaving the vowel insteed, as‡§®‡§Ü for ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ like the H. ‡§®‡§Ø‡§æ for ‡§®‡§µ‡§æ, ‡§®‡§æ‡§à for ‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä etc.

In G. the causal termination is ‡§Ü‡§µas ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç ’to cause to do,’ ‡§§‡§™‡§æ‡§µ‡§¨‡•Å‡§Ç ‘make hot;’ in S. ‡§Ü‡§á as ‡§µ‡§ß‡§æ‡§á‡§£‡•Å ’tocause increase,’ ‡§ò‡•ã‡§Ü‡§á‡§£‡•Å ’to cause wash; in P. ‡§Ü‡§ä or ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ä as ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§â‡§®‡§æ or ‡§ï‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§â‡§®‡§æ.

In H, it is ‡§Ü as ‡§®‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡§æ, ‡§™‡§¢‡§æ‡§®‡§æ, but ‡§®‡§ö‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ and ‡§™‡§¢‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡§æ are alsoused;and the termination ‡§µ‡§æ is invariably added to the first causalto form asecond or double causal as ‡§®‡§ö‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ, ‡§™‡§¢‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ from ‡§®‡§ö‡§æ‡§®‡§æand ‡§™‡§¢‡§æ‡§®‡§æ. The ‡§Ü‡§µoccurs in first causals in poetry, as Tulsƒ´dƒÅs:‡§Ö‡§¨ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§§ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§µ‡§π ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§ø ‘Narrate(lit. make me hear) to me the history of the lord;‘also:‚Äî

‡§Ø‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï ‡§µ‡•á‡§∑ ‡§ß‡§∞‡§ø ‡§®‡•É‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡•à‡§®‡§ü ‡§ï‡•ã‡§á‡•§
‡§∏‡•ã‡§á ‡§∏‡•ã‡§á ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§µ‡•à‡§Ü‡§™‡•Å‡§® ‡§π‡•ã‡§á ‡§®‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ã‡§á‡••

‘As an actor assuming various masks dances; so he (the lord)shows this character and that but is not himself that ( what heshows ).’

The B. and O. causal is also similarly formed by adding ‡§Ü as‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§á ‘I cause to do,’ ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§æ‡§à‘I show’ etc. Here also as in the H.,the ‡§µ of ‡§Ü‡§µis elided.

The ‡§á of the S. ‡§Ü‡§ámust be the ‡§á which we have observed isused after transitive and non-reflexive roots in Pot., the pres. part.etc. as ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ã.

Thus then the causal termination in all the languages is‡§Ü‡§µ or ‡§Ü‡§µ, which is the same as one of the three in Pr. For, you

will remember, the Pr. has ‡§è, ‡§Ü‡§µ‡•áand, the ‡§è of the latter beingdropped, there is another ‡§Ü‡§µ. We have also a good manyexamples in the vernaculars of the Pr. causals mentioned byHemacandra as formed by dropping all terminations and preserving the vowel changes, guns or viddhi, which roots takebefore the Skr. ‡§Ö‡§Øor Pr. ‡§è Thus:‚Äî
M. G. H. ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç-‡§®‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç-‡§®‡§æ.
H. ‡§ñ‡•Å‡§≤‡§®‡§æ ‡§ñ‡•ã‡§≤‡§®‡§æ
M. G. H. S. ‡§§‡•Å‡§ü‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç-‡§®‡§æ-‡§£‡•Å ‡§§‡•ã‡§°‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç-‡§®‡§æ-‡§£‡•Å
M. G. H. ‡§´‡•Å‡§ü‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç-‡§®‡§æ ‡§´‡•ã‡§°‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç-‡§®‡§æ
H. ‡§´‡§ü‡§®‡§æ ‡§´‡§æ‡§°‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç
G.H. ‡§õ‡•Å‡§ü‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç-‡§®‡§æ ‡§õ‡•ã‡§°‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç-‡§®‡§æ
M. ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ü‡§£‡•á‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•ã‡§¢‡§£‡•á‡§Ç
M.G. ‡§™‡§°‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§°‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç
M. ‡§ö‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡•Ü‡§Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•á‡§Ç
S. ‡§µ‡§∞‡§£‡•Å ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•Å
M. S. ‡§ó‡§≤‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§ó‡§∞‡§£‡•Å ‡§ó‡§æ‡§≤‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•Å
S. ‡§™‡§¢‡§£‡•Å ‡§™‡§æ‡§¢‡§£‡•Å

I have already mentioned that the causal of some roots isformed in H. by inserting ‡§≤ before the causal termination ‡§Ü.G. has ‡§° and Sindhi ‡§∞for ‡§≤, ‡§ñ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¢‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç ’to cause to eat’ from ‡§ñ‡§æto eat, ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç ’to cause to give,’ ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§æ‡§°‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç ’to show’ from ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ’to see,’‡§ß‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç to cause to run,’ ‡§°‡§ø‡§Ö‡§£‡•Å’to give,’ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ü‡§∞‡§£‡•Å’to cause to give,’‡§∏‡§ø‡§ñ‡§£‡•Å-‡§∏‡•á‡§ñ‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•Å, ‡§¨‡•á‡§π‡§£‡•Å-‡§µ‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§£‡•Å ’to cause to sit.’ In these instances wehave ‡§µ‡§æ or ‡§Übefore ‡§°; but in G. all these forms have ‡§Ü‡§µ optionally added to them when the previous ‡§Üis dropped as ‡§µ‡§ö‡§°‡§æ‡§µ‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç ’to cause to run,’ ‡§ñ‡§µ‡§°‡§æ‡§µ‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç ’to cause to eat ’etc.; and inS. we have the causal ‡§Ü‡§áappended to ‡§∞ after roots ending in ‡§Üas ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§á‡§£‡•Å ’to cause to eat,’‡§ò‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§á‡§£‡•Å ’to cause to wound,’ ‡§ß‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§á‡§£‡•Å’to cause to suok’ or ’ to suckle;’ so that the intervening ‡§Ü isinterchangeable in both these languages with the causal termination and hence some way conveys the same sense. M. has atrace of these forms as ‡§≠‡•ã‡§Ç‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§Ç ’to turn,’ to cause to turn,’‡§ò‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§Ç ‘run,’ ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§°‡§£‡•á‡§Ç’to cause to run,’ ‡§≠‡§ø‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§≠‡•á‡§°‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§Ç’to threaten.‘Hemacandra mentions ‡§≠‡§Æ‡§æ‡§°‡•ã as the causal base of ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ and gives‡§µ‡§æ‡§â in the sense of pushing which is very likely a causal form of‡§µ‡§æ. We have this ‡§ò‡§æ‡§°in the sense of sending in M.

We have seen that ‡§¶ or‡§§ is sometimes changed to ‡§° and thenceto ‡§∞ or ‡§≤ in the Pr. and vernaculars; whence it appears that‡§™‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡§æ is a denominstive or nominal root from ‡§™‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ or ‡§™‡§ø‡§°‡§æor ‡§™‡•Ä‡§§,by the application of the usual denominative termination ‡§Ü‡§™‡•ç,which is also the causal termination. In Skr. such a denominative has the sense of doing the thing expressed by the base as ‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ã‡§§‡§ø-‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø,≈öaur. ‡§™‡•Ä‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§ø.

We have a great many denominatives from past participles;first in the sense of being the thing expressed by the base, inwhich case the participle has simply the verbal terminationsappended to it, as ‡§≤‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§á from ‡§≤‡§ó, ‡§Ö‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡§ø‡§°‡§á from ‡§Ö‡§≠‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§§, ‡§ï‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡§áfrom ‡§ï‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü,‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§ü‡§á, ‡§™‡§≤‡•ç‡§≤‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§á from ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ etc.; and secondly in the sense of doing,when ‡§Ü‡§µ or ‡§Ü‡§µ‡•á intervenes between the base and the terminations,as ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§øin MƒÅlatƒ´-MƒÅdhava, from which we have in M, ‡§≠‡•á‡§°‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§Ç.The forms in which we have ‡§Ü before ‡§° as ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç, ‡§ñ‡§∑‡§æ‡§°‡§∑‡•Å‡§Çetc. aredenominatives from the past participles of original Pr. cauealsas ‡§¶‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶ or ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶, the causal fermination ‡§Ü‡§µ being changed to ‡§îand ‡§Üas in the H. in ordinary causals. In the vernaculars wehave also the first class of denominatives expressive of beinglike the thing denoted by the base, as:‚Äî

[TABLE]

We have another verbal base in M. which involves the ides ofpower and ability as ‡§ï‡§∞‡§µ‡§§‡•á‡§Ç ‘can be done,’ ‡§¨‡§∏‡§µ‡§§‡•á‡§Ç‘can be sat.‘These forms are passive when the original verb istransitive, andimpersonal when it is intransitive. In old M. ‡§™is somesimesseen for ‡§µ:‚Äî

‡§ú‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡•á‡§Ç ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å‡§§ ‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß ‡§≠‡•á‡§¶ ‡§∏‡§ö‡§ø‡§≤‡•á ‡•§ ‡§§‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§™‡§£ ‡§π‡§ø‡§§‡§Ü‡§™‡•Å‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§Ç‡§ö‡§ø ‡§ò‡•á‡§™‡•á ‡••

‘Even if the Veda has told much and indicated a great manydistinct things, still one should take that which is beneficialto himself.’

‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§ù‡§£‡§ø‡§™‡•á ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û ?

‘Who should be called ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§ø‡§§‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ú‡•ç‡§û ?’

Here the sense is simply passive and does not involve thenotion of power. These forms are to be derived from the pass.of the causal, whence ‡§ï‡§∞‡§µ‡•áis ‡§ï‡§∞‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§áPr. for ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§™‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á,Skr. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á.Power is implied on account of the forms being derived in thismanner; for, ‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•á‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡•á ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æin Skr. means the work is causedto be done by me by Govinda; when the agent caused istaken to be the same as that who causes, the sense is the work incaused to be done by me by myself, i. e. ‘I am the causer of myselfto do it i. e., ‘I can do it.’ In G. this causal pass. ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ is transformed into ‡§Ü, as the causal ‡§Ö‡§µso often is, and the sense is simplypassive in some cases and passive and causative in others, as‡§Ü‡§Ç ‡§õ‡•ã‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡•ç‡§ñ ‡§ú‡§£‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§õ‡•á’ this boy is known to be & fool; ’ ‡§Ü ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ‡§•‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§®‡§•‡•Ä ’this work cannot be done from me. There are tracesof these forms in the other languages also, though the grammariars do not notice them, as H. ‡§è‡§ï‡§µ‡§ö‡§® ‡§¨‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§¨‡•Å‡§ù‡§æ‡§Ø‘By thesingulars the number of a thing is known to be one,’ ‡§µ‡§π ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ï‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡§æ ‡§π‡•à ’that is called a sentence’ etc^(1).

Thus then you will see that we have nearly the whole of thegrammar of the Prakrits, i. e. all their grammatical forms, inour vernaculars. The cases in the forms which they assumedin the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa have been preserved, some in this languageand some in that, but not all in one and the same. And alongwith them there are sometimes newly constructed forms also.The pronouns are the same as in the Pr. and the Apabhramsa. The two Prakrit tenses and one mood are preserved. All thevernaculars have the Present, though, except in the O. and B.,it has acquired another sense and another word or expression iswanted to restriot it to the signification of the present time.G. S. P. and H. have lost the Imperative, but it is preserved bythe other three languages. The Future is retained by the G. andthe Braj; while this latter possesses the solitary form of the Aoristthat the old Pr. had retained. These are the only really simpleor uncompounded verbal forms existing in our languages; therest are made up by compounding or by using Pres. participlesas bases and appending the Pres. verbal terminations, as will behereafter shown. Past time is almost universally expressed bythe past participle, and this retains the passive, in some casesthe active, character it had in Skr. and Pr. in all those languagesthat have not thoroughly lost the distinction of gender andnumber. The several other Prakrit participles are preserved andwe have no other. The passive forms are seen in Sindhi andPanjabi, the former having one set and the latter the other.The Pr. causal termination is preserved almost unchanged bythe M. and G. while in the other languages it is somewhattransformed. So that, as they are at present, our vernacularshave between them preserved all that the Prakrits had andpreserved nothing that the Prakrits lost.

___________________________________________________________________________

1. Mr. Beames traces the vernacular causal terminations ‡§Ö‡§µ, ‡§á‡§µ, ‡§â, ‡§Ü etc.to the Skr. ‡§Ö‡§Ø. But this is evidently a mistake. The Pr. ‘‡§Ü‡§µ‡•á or ‡§Ü‡§µ hasescaped him somehow. The ‡§≤ of the Hindi causal forms he alse derivesfrom the ‡§Ø of ‡§Ö‡§Ø. But this ‡§Ø is too weak to be changed to any other letterthan the vowel ‡§è, and ‡§Ø is never changed to a semi-vowel excepting inthe doubtful instance ‡§≤‡§ü‡•ç‡§ü‡•Ä from ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü.

And as we ascend higher up in the history of each of theselanguages, we find in use such forms as it has now lost. All ourvernaculars must at one time have been in the condition inwhich we find the Apabhra·πÉ≈õa, but the dialect of that namewhich is treated of by the grammarians, and specimens of whichwe find in the scraps of literature I have noticed, resemble the G.and the Braj and in a less degree the S. P. and the ordinary H.

The old literary dialect of the H. area was the Braj; and theworks of Tulsƒ™dƒÅs, BihƒÅrilƒÅl, Kabƒ™ra and others are in that dialect,though these are called old Hindi poets, instead of old Braj poetsas they should be called and as they are called by natives. Inthis old Braj literature we find the Apabhra·πÅ≈õaforms of thePresent tense unchanged; and from these has directly been derived the Present tense of the modern S., G., P., Braj aud H. TheApbhr. Future is found in the G, and in modern Braj and in the

poets in an older and less corrupt form also, though the ‡§∏ isohanged to ‡§π. Such Apbhr. forms as ‡§ú‡•á‡§Æ, ‡§§‡•á‡§Æare preserved in theG.; and the neuter sing. in ‡§â‡§Ç in that dialect as well as in theBraj, where it occurs especially in the verbal nouns or infinitives.The first pers. sing. ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç exists in G., old H. and a dialect of thePanjabi. The other dialects also possess, as I have observed,some Ap. peculiarities, but the four named above bear a closerconnection to it.

And since the Apabhra·πÉ≈õa is referred by the grammarians tothe ≈öaurasen√Ø type, we may regard these four modern dialects,viz the G. S. P. and H., as the representatives of the old ≈öaurasenƒ´,which from the name seems to have been the dialect of thecountry about MathurƒÅ.

The distinction between this and the old MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´was, aswe have have seen, not very great and some of the peculiaritieswere such as could not last for many centuries. The change of‡§§ and ‡§• to ‡§¶ and ‡§ß, for instance, instead of elision and ‡§π is ofsuch a nature. The law of elision which operated in a greatmany other cases could not long be kept from extending itselfto ‡§§. But still we do find in the modern G. such forms as ‡§ï‡§ø‡§ü‡•Å‡§Ç,‡§™‡§ø‡§ü‡•Å‡§Ç,‡§ñ‡§æ‡§ü‡•Å‡§Çetc. for ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§™‡•Ä‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç snd ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç. This change was madein some cases in the ≈öaurasenƒ´as in ‡§∏‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§≤‡§æ, for ‡§∂‡§ï‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§≤‡§æ, and inothers not, as ‡§Ö‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§§ for ‡§Ü‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞. And the change of ‡§®‡•ç‡§§ to ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶and‡§¶ we find in the S. and P. Present Participles. The ≈öaur.Future which had an intercalatory ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ instead of the MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´‡§π‡§ø is, as we have seen, preserved in the G. and the Brai with theslight modification it underwent in the Apabhra·πÉ≈õa. Then, ifwe follow Vararuci, the ≈öaur. Absolute termination was ‡§á‡§Ö,and in the prose speeches in the dramatic plays it is this alonethat we find. The absolutive in these four modern languagesis formed by adding this same termination with the ‡§Ö dropped.

Now all these peculiarities are absent from the M. In theold MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´verses, occurring in the plays, as well as according to Vararuci, the absolutive termination was ‡§ä‡§£, which wefind in the M. alone. The past passive participle of ‡§ï‡•É and ‡§µ‡•É inold Mahr. was ‡§ï‡§Ö and ‡§Æ‡§Ö, and we have these forms in the M. in‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡§æ and ‡§Æ‡•á‡§≤‡§æ, as we have seen, while ‡§ï‡§ø instead of ‡§ï‡•á, ‡§∏‡•Åinstead of

‡§Æ‡•á occur in the four ≈öaurasenic dialects and these we find in theplays.The Pres. and Imper. of the M. have been derived fromthe Pr. and not from the Apbbr. forms. Thus then, the M. is themodern representative of the old MahƒÅrƒÅ·π£·π≠rƒ´, so that it hardlyadmits of any doubt that the two old languages derived theirnames from the provinces in which they prevailed. The B. and O.have a few peculiarities of the ≈öaur.; and they seem to occupya middle position between M. on the one hand and the four Apbhr.or ≈öaur, languages on the other; while the consonantal changes,especially the reduction of all the sibilants to the palatal ‡§∂, pointto their being the descendants of the oldMƒÅgadhƒ´.

LECTURE VI

NEW GRAMMATICAL FORMATIONS IN THE NORTHERN
VERNACULARS

We will now proceed to consider those forms in the grammarof our languages which are not derived from correspondingSanskrit or Prakrit forms, but which have been constructed inrecent times. Such new forms owe their origin to various causes.The old ones lose their distinctive portions and become confusedby phonetic decay; or, having been in long use, lose all freshnessof meaning, and cease to be as expressive as one would wish themto be, or their sense is not exactly that which one desires toconvey. Thus the old Present and Future got confused in ourvernaculars and a new Future was wanted. The old Present itselfacquired a potential sense in some cases and a past habitual sensein others, whence for the expression of present time anotherset of forms was required.

In Sanskrit itself such a phrase as ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ç‡§É‘gruel for aBrahman’ is not so expressive as ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡§æ ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ç‡§É ‘gruel for aBrahman’s purpose’; which again is analysed into its separateelements for greater distinctness into ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á ‡§Ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ç‡§É‘gruel forthe purpose of a Brahman’.

When different words so brought together are kept distinctand consciously used, there is no growth of new forms. But if byfrequent use and the oblivion of etymology such an expressionas ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•ácomes to be looked upon as an independent word meaning"for the sake of” and applied promiscuously to all nouns,including such as could not originally by the usage of Sanskrithave it, as in ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•á, it becomes a termination, and a new caseform grows up and the old one often goes out of use. Then againphonetic decay sets in and by reducing this expression to ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡§†‡•ç‡§†‡•áand ultimately to ‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•á ( M. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä‡§Ç the original word being ‡§∏‡§ü‡•ç‡§†‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø),irrevocably stamps it with the character of a case terminationhaving no meaning by itself. Lastly, if one wishes to say of abook that it belongs to him and looks upon it as possessing thatattribute and subordinates him to it, the expression ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç

will not serve his purpose, but he must have some such as ‡§§‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç. And if this way of looking at things becomes general, ‡§§‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Øsupersedes ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø. In this way our new forms have grown up.

THE OBLIQUE FORMS

The case terminations are, in the majority of the languages,applied not to the original noun itself but to a certain modifiedform of it called the oblique form, or by the native Marathigrammarians the SƒÅmƒÅnya-r≈´pa or the common form, because it is used in all the cases.

THE OBLIQUE FORM IN THE MARATHI

There are two SƒÅmƒÅnya-r≈´pas for the two numbers. In theold languages plurality is expressed by independent terminations,but the new terminations of the modern languages being the samefor both numbers, plurality is denoted by a distinctive obliqueform. Some of the modern languages that have no SƒÅmƒÅnya-r≈´pa have recourse to a novel way of expressing plurality. Ofall the vernaculars it is the Marathi that is the most particularin the formation of the oblique and has minute rules. Sindhicomes next, then the Hindi and the Panjabi; after these theGujarati, and lastly the Bengali and the Oriya; which may besaid to have no oblique form at all.

The Marathi oblique forms are made up by adding theseterminations :‚Äî
(1) Sing. ‡§Ü Pl. ‡§Ü‡§Ç
(2) ‚Äû ‡§à ‚Äû ‡§à‡§Ç
(3) ‚Äû ‡§à ‚Äû ‡§Ü‡§Ç
(4) ‚Äû ‡§ä ‚Äû ‡§ä‡§Ç
(5) ‚Äû ‡§è ‚Äû ‡§Ü‡§Ç

(1) The following classes of nouns take the first‚Äî

(a) Masc. and Neut. nouns in ‡§Ö as a ‡§π‡§æ‡§§ ‘hand’. ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡§æ obl., ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§∏sing. ’to a hand’, ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏pl. ’to hands’.

(b) Masc. nouns in ‡§Üand neuter nouns in ‡§è‡§Çwhich combinethe final and the termination into ‡§Ø‡§æ, but to ‡§è in the speechof the Konk·πá√ØKarhƒÅ·∏çƒÅs and in the CitpƒÅvanƒ´andoptionally to ‡§Ø‡§æ or ‡§è in adjectives: as ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ ‘a mango, ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§ò‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ

obl., ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ sing. ’to a mango’; ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç‘a plantain’, ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ obl.,‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ sing. ’to a plantain’; ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§¨‡•á‡§∏ ’to a mango’in theKonka·πáƒ´KarhƒÅ·∏çƒÅs, ‡§™‡§ø‡§µ‡§≤‡§æ ‘yellow’, ‡§™‡§ø‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æor ‡§™‡§ø‡§µ‡§≤‡•áobl.,‡§™‡§ø‡§µ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ or ‡§™‡§ø‡§µ‡§≤‡•á ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§¨‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏sing. ’to a yellow mango,‘respectively.

(c) A good many Masc. nouns In f, the of which is changedto ‡§Ø‡§æ before ‡§Ü as‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä nom., ‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ obl., ‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ sing.‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏ pl.

All neuter nouns in ‡§à‡§Ças ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ç-‡§Æ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ-‡§Æ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏-‡§Æ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏.

(d) Some Masc. and nearly all neuter nouns in ‡§ä. Some ofthese change ‡§ä to ‡§µ‡§æ, and others drop it, since it is the‡§ä of the nom. sing. Apbhr., as ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ä ‘a brother’; ‚Äì ‚Äì ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ obl.,sing. ’to a brother’, ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏pl. ’to brothers’; ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ü‡§∏‡§∞‡•Ç’travellor’, ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ü‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ obl., ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ü‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏ sing., ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ü‡§∏‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏ pl.; ‡§ó‡§≤‡•Ç‡§Ç-‡§ó‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ-‡§ó‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏sing., ‡§ó‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏ pl. ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ç-‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ-‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§∏ sing., ‡§≤‡•á‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏ pl.Some nouns of this class take ‡§Üoptionally as ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡•Ç-‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ö‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ-‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏sing., ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏ pl.

(2) The following nouns take the second form ‡§à, ‡§à‡§Ç :‚Äî

(a) Tatsamas in short ‡§á as ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø-‡§ï‡§µ‡•Ä-‡§ï‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∏.

(b) A few masc. nouns in ‡§à as ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä ’elephant, ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä-‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§∏sing., ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§∏ pl.

(c) A good many femininine nouns in ‡§Ö as ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§manner,‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä-‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§∏ sing, ‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§∏ pl; ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤ ‘a plantain tree,’ ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä-‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä‡§∏ sing., ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§∏ pl.

(d) Some feminine nouns in ‡§à as ‡§≠‡•Å‡§à‘ground,’ ‡§≠‡•Å‡§à-‡§≠‡•Å‡§à‡§∏sing., ‡§≠‡•Å‡§à‡§Ç‡§∏pl.

(3) A good many feminine nouns take the third format ‡§à-‡§Ü‡§ÇBs ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•Ä ‘amare,’ ‡§ò‡§æ‡§Ç‡§°‡•Ä sing. ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç pl., ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•Ä‡§∏ sing, ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏ pl.;‡§∏‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä ‘a garment worn by females,’ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§°‡•Äsing., ‡§∏‡§æ‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ pl., ‡§∏‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä‡§∏sing.,‡§∏‡§æ‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏ pl. In the Goan. and MƒÅl., however, this form doesnot exist and these nouns take the fifth form ‡§è-‡§Ü, as ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á-‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï sing, ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï pl.; ‡§∏‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä-‡§∏‡§æ‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï sing.,‡§∏‡§æ‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ïpl.

(4) Some masc. and feminine nouns in ‡§ätake the fourth form ‡§ä-‡§ä‡§Ç, as ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§ä-‡§ñ‡§æ‡§ä‡§∏ sing., ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§ä‡§Ç‡§∏ pl.; ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ú‡•Ç f. ‘a aide,’ ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ú‡•Ç-‡§¨‡§æ‡§ú‡•Ç‡§∏ sing., ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ú‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§∏ pl.

(5) The following classes take the fifth form:‚Äî A good manyfem. nouns in ‡§Ö as ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§≠‘a tongue,’ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≠‡•ásing., ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§Çpl., ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≠‡•á‡§∏ sing.,‡§ú‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏ pl.; a good many fem. nouns in ‡§à in the Goan. and MƒÅl.dialects; see instances given above; some fem. nouns in ‡§ä, as‡§ú‡§≤‡•Ç ‘aleech’, ‡§ú‡§≤‡§µ‡•á sing., ‡§ú‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§Çpl., ‡§ú‡§≤‡§µ‡•á‡§∏ sing. ‡§ú‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏ pl.;‡§ú‡§æ‡§ä‘husband’s brother’s wife,’ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§µ‡•á-‡§ú‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Çetc. Some nouns takethis form optionally as ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§∏ or ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡•á‡§∏; ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§∏ or ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏. The usagein several cases is still unsettled as regards some of these forms.You will observe that there is an anusvƒÅra in the pl. of all forms.Another fact should also be borne in mind that nouns in ‡§à and ‡§äoften take the ‡§Ü-‡§Ü‡§Çor ‡§è-‡§Ü‡§Çforms though these properly belongto nouns in ‡§Ö.

THE OBLIQUE FORM IN SINDHI

(1) The following classes of nouns take ‡§Ö for the obl. sing.and ‡§Ü‡§Ç, ‡§è‡§Ç and ‡§Ö‡§®‡§øfor the pl.:‚Äî

(a) Masc. nouns, the nom. sing. of which ends in ‡§â, as‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•Å ‘a country’, ‡§¶‡•á‡§π-‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§®‡§ø obl., ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§ú‡•ã sing. ‘of a country’, ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§®‡§ø‡§ú‡•ãpl. ‘of countries’, also ‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç-‡§¶‡•á‡§π‡•á‡§Ç-‡§ú‡•ã.

(b) Masc. nouns in ‡§ì, which,however, combine the finaland the termination into ‡§èas in the Cit. Mar. as ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¢‡•ã‘acarpenter’, obl. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¢‡•ásing., ‡§¨‡§æ‡§¢‡§®‡§ø, ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¢‡§æ‡§Çand ‡§µ‡§æ‡§¢‡•á‡§Çpl.

(2) The following nouns take ‡§Öfor the obl. sing. and ‡§®‡§ø, ‡§Ö‡§®‡§øand ‡§â‡§®‡§ø for the pl. in addition to ‡§Ü‡§Ç and ‡§è‡§Ç :‚Äî

(a) Maso, nouns in ‡§à as ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä ‘a peasant’, ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ö or ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ü‡§Ç sing.,‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§è‡§Ç, ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡§ø, ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø and ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§®‡§ø pl.

(b) Fem. nouns in ‡§à as ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•Ä‘a mare’, obl. ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§ø‡§Ösing. ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§ø‡§Ü‡§Ç,‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§ø‡§è‡§Ç, ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§ø‡§®‡§ø, ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡§ø and ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§Ø‡•Å‡§®‡§øpl.

(c) Masc. nouns in ‡§ä; as ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§π‡•Ç‘a man’, obl. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§π‡•Å‡§Ö sing.,‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Å‡§®‡§ø, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Å‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡•Å‡§Ü‡§Ç and ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§π‡•Å‡§è‡§Ç pl.

(3) Nouns in short ‡§á have no separate form for the sing. ofthe obl., the nom. form being used; the pl. they form like theabove class, as ‡§ó‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§øf. ‘a story’, obl. ‡§ó‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§øsing., ‡§ó‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§Ü‡§Ç, ‡§ó‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§è‡§Ç, ‡§ó‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§Ö‡§®‡§ø, ‡§ó‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§â‡§®‡§øand ‡§ó‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡§øpl. Masc. nouns in ‡§á, however, donot take the forms in ‡§Ö‡§®‡§øand ‡§â‡§®‡§ø; as ‡§ï‡•á‡§π‡§∞‡§ø ‘a lion’ sing., ‡§ï‡•á‡§π‡§∞‡§ø‡§®‡§ø-‡§Ü‡§Ç-‡§è‡§Çpl.

(4) Fem, nouns in ‡§Ö, ‡§Üand ‡§â have no separate form for thesing, while in the pl. they take as a ‘wish’, obl. ‡§∏‡§ßsing., ‡§∏‡§ß‡•Å‡§®‡§øpl.; ‡§π‡§ö‡§æ‘a murder’, obl. ‡§π‡§ö‡§æsing., ‡§π‡§ö‡§æ‡§â‡§®‡§ø pl.; ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•Å’lightning’, obl.‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•Å sing.,‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú‡•Å‡§®‡§øpl. The first has ‡§∏‡§ß‡§æ‡§Çand ‡§∏‡§ß‡•á‡§Çalso for the pl. Herethere is one type for one class of nouns and not two, as is the casesometimes in the M. The form in ‡§â‡§®‡§øis taken by all femininenouns in ‡§Ö, ‡§Ü and ‡§àand also masc. nouns in ‡§à. Masc. nouns in ‡§äand fem. nouns in ‡§â have ‡§â in the original base itself and it doesnot belong to the termination.

THE OBLIQUE FORM IN PANJABI

The Panjabi has the termination ‡§è for the sing. obl. of nounsending in ‡§Ü. The sing. of all other nouns has no special formwhile ‡§Ü is appended to all nouns to form the obl. pl., beforewhich the final ‡§Üof nouns preceded by a consonant is changedto ‡§á, as ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§æ ‘a horse,’ obl. sing. and ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§ø‡§Ü‡§Çpl. Final ‡§âpreceded by a vowel combines with this ‡§Ü‡§Çto form ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç, as ‡§™‡§ø‡§∑‡•ç‡§†or ‡§™‡•á‡§â ‘father,’ ‡§™‡•á‡§µ‡§æ‡§Çobl. pl.; and final ‡§Öforms ‡§Ü‡§Ç as ‡§µ ‘man’, ‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Çobl. pl. There are no other changes.

THE OBLIQUE FORM IN HINDI

The Hindi, like the Panjabi, has an oblique sing. for nounsin ‡§Üonly. It ends in ‡§è, as that of the S. and Cit. M. nouns in‡§ì, Karh. M. and P. noubs in ‡§Ü as; ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•á-‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•á‡§ï‡§æ.The pl. obl. ofall nouns whatever is formed by adding ‡§ì‡§Ç which amalgamateswith the preceding ‡§Ö of all nouns and the ‡§Üof such as aremasculine, and combines with ‡§á to form ‡§á‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç; as ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‘a village.’‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡•ã‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ pl. ‘of villages’; ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§æ‘a horse’, ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ã‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æpl. ‘of horses’;‡§™‡§§‡§ø‘a master’, ‡§™‡§§‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æpl. ‘of masters.’ In other cases it is simplyadded to the noun as ‡§≠‡§æ‡§Ç‡§≤‡•Ç ‘a jackal,’ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§≤‡•Å‡§ì‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ pl. ‘of jackals’.

In the BrajbhƒÅ·π£ƒÅand in the old poets the obl. pl. of all nounshas ‡§® or ‡§®‡§ø instead of ‡§ì‡§Ç, as ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‘a good man’ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§§‡§®‡§ï‡§æpl. ‘of good men’.This termination is also added to the nom. sing, to form the nom.pl. of those nouns that have no distinctive form for it; as ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ó‘people’ sing. ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ó‡§® pl.; ‡§≠‡§ó‡§§ ‘devotee’, ‡§≠‡§ó‡§§‡§® pl. ( ‡§ö‡§π‡•Å‡§ú‡•Å‡§ó ‡§≠‡§ó‡§§‡§® ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§ü‡•Ä‚Äî Kabƒ´r).

THE OBLIQUE FORM IN GUJARATI

In G. the obl. form of masc. and neuter nouns ending in ‡§ìand ‡§â‡§Ç is formed by substituting ‡§Ü for those vowels. The latter

take an anusv√§ra in the pl., and the forms of the former for bothnumbers are alike as ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ã-‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§æ-‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§æ‡§®‡•á sing.and pl. ’to a horse orhorses’; ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•Å‡§Ç ‘a plantain’, ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡§æ-‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•á sing ’to a plantain’, ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§Çpl.’to plantains.’ But the nom. pl. forms of these are ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§æand ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç,whence it appears that in the pl. the obl. cases are formed simplyadding the terminations to the nom. pl. and there is no such thingas a common oblique form. And this is the case with the sing, aswell as the pl. of all other nouns; as ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‘a man’ nom. sing.,‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ã nom. pl ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡§®‡•á sing., ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡•ã‡§®‡•á‡§Ç pl. The plural termination is‡§ì and is thus used in all cases. It is added in these days evento the final ‡§Ü and ‡§Ü‡§Çof nouns in ‡§ìand ‡§â‡§Ç to distinguish the pl.forms from the sing. as ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§æ or ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§æ‡§ì nom. pl, ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§æ‡§®‡•á or ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§æ‡§ì‡§®‡•ádat. pl. But the practice has not yet established itself andmostly the forms without ‡§ìare used. Masc. and neut. nounsending in ‡§ìor ‡§â‡§Ç are often used in the pl. without it in suchinstances as ‡§§‡§ø‡§π‡§æ ‡§ò‡§£‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§∏ ‡§õ‡•áin the nom. and other cases.And this is the usual practice in old G. literature; as ‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§®‡§æ ‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§π ‡§π‡•ã‡§à‡§õ‡•Ä(Panch.): ‘The marriages of the sons of other people areperformed;’ ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§®‡•ã ‡§™‡§∞‡§ø‡§ö‡§Ø ‡§õ‡•á‘he has a knowledge of all the≈öƒÅstraa’.

‡§ï‡§≤‡§ú‡•Å‡§ó‡§®‡§æ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£ ‡§ú‡•à‡§ü‡§≤‡§æ
‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§® ‡§•‡§æ‡§∏‡•á ‡§§‡•á‡§ü‡§≤‡§æ
‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ò‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡•ã‡§§‡§æ ‡§§‡§£‡§æ‡§Ç
‡§∏‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ó‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‡§π‡§£‡§®‡•ã ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ß‡•Ä ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§•
‡§ú‡•á‡§π‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤ ‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§™‡§Ç‡§•

SvƒÅrgroha·πáa by Sundarabha·π≠·π≠a.

‘All the Brahmans of Kaliyuga will be without virtue. Theywill build their homes there. The work SvargƒÅroha·πáa wascomposed in which there is the way of all virtues.’

‡§Ö‡§®‡•á‡§ï ‡§™‡§Ç‡§ñ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡•ã‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•§ ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§ú‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≤ ‡§¨‡§π‡•Å ‡§°‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ó‡§∞‡§æ ‡§¨‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¶‡§∞‡§®‡§æ ‡§†‡§æ‡§†

KƒÅvyadohans, Tulasƒ´.

‘Many birds raise a noise. There are mountains, forestsmany hills; over these is a crowd of monkeys.’

The ‡§ì however is seen in fem. nouns ending in ‡§à:‚Äî

‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§®‡•Ä ‡§®‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡•ã‡§∏‡•á ‡§á‡§∏‡•á ‡§§‡•á‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ß‡•Ä ‡§ú‡§≤ ‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ú‡§∏‡•á ‡••

SvargƒÅroha·πáa.

‘The water of the sea and of the rivers on land (in villages)will be dried up.’

‡§Æ‡•ã‡§†‡§æ ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§∑‡§§ ‡§®‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ø‡•ã‡§ú‡•à‡§π ‡•§ ‡§§‡•á‡§π ‡§§‡§£‡•Ä ‡§®‡§π‡§ø ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡•á‡§õ‡•á‡§π‡••

KƒÅvyadoha·πáa, Tulasƒ´.

‘There is no end of great mountains and rivers that exist.’

It therefore appears that in masc. and neut. nouns the ‡§ìis amodern innovation and that there was no distinction between thesing. and pl. cases except the nom. of nouns in ‡§ì and ‡§â‡§Ç. Thetrue explanation therefore of the modern ‡§ìof the pl. is that fem.nouns in ‡§Üand ‡§à preserved this termination, since they had it inthe Prakrits, as the minor M. dialects have done, and, the sing.and pl. forms of mase. nouns being alike, the fem. ‡§ì was transferred to them afterwards to distinguish the pl. as is now beingdone to nouns in ‡§ì and ‡§â‡§Ç. Thus then the G. noun may be said to have no real SƒÅmƒÅnya-r≈´pa or oblique form. Adjectives in ‡§ìhowever have a form ending in ‡§è when they are used to qualify asubstantive in the instr. or old loc, case in ‡§è as ‡§Ü ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•á ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§ß‡•Å‡§Ç ’this thing was done by a good man’, ‡§§‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•á ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ü‡•á ‡§õ‡•ã‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ó‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‘boys went to the margin of a tank’, but this may be explainedas a remnant of the old agreement between the noun and itsadjective and ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡•ámay be regarded as an instr. form and ‡§§‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§®‡•áa locative.

ABSENCE OF THE OBLIQUE FORM IN BENGALI AND ORIYA

The Bengali and Oriya apply the case terminations directly tothe nom. and there is no oblique form. The new terminationsbeing, as in all the modern languages, the same for both numbersand there being no oblique form to express the distinctionbetween them as in M. S. H. etc., these languages, like the Guj.,were under the necessity of deriving some expression for denotingplurality. The G. found its fem. ‡§ìand employed it for thispurpose, but the B. and O. had no such distinctively pl.termination left to fall back upon and so they have recourse tothe use of a word signifying collection such as ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó originally’direction, row, line’, ‡§ó‡§£, ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§πand ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤ etc., after the noun, theplurality of which is to be expressed. Thus ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ ‘a king’, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‘of a king’, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡•á‡§∞‘of kings’ lit. ‘of the direction row or line of a

king.’ Sometimes the word ‡§¶‡§ø‡§óis attached to the gen. sing. as‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‡•á‡§∞ to express the gen relation between the ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ and ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó,which is understood in the first expression. To nouns denoting inferior animals ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§π and such words are appended and suchothers as ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤ to those signifying inanimate creatures as ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡•á‡§∞of a dog’ ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Å‡§π‡•á‡§∞‘of dogs.‘The Oriya sign of the plural is‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® for rational and animate creatures and ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ etc. forirrational or inanimate, as ‡§™‡•Å‡§∂‡•Å ‘abeast’, ‡§™‡•Å‡§∂‡•Å‡§∞sing. ‘of a beast’,‡§™‡•Å‡§∂‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡§∞ ‘of beasts.‘The B. adds ‡§∞‡§æ to the nom, sing. of names ofrational creatures to form the nom. pl., while ‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§π, ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤, etc. areapplied to the rest, as ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‘a king’. ‘kings’, ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‘kings’; ‡§ï‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞ ‘adog’,‡§ï‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§ï‡•Å‡§∞‡§∏‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§π‘dogs’. The O. adds ‡§è to ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®to form the nom. pl. as‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á.This is the same as that of ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•áin M. and H.

THE NATURE OF THE OBLIQUE FORM

Now the question is what is the nature of this SƒÅmƒÅnya-r≈´paor oblique form, why does a noun undergo a certain modificationbefore it becomes fit to receive the termination and what is thesignification of the modified form and of the nasal that appearsin the plural. Let us see how we, at the present day, join certainwords expressive of relation such as ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§®‡§ø‡§ßor ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•Ä with & noun.We say ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡•à‡§®‡§ø‡§ß or ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•Ä i. e. put the noun into the gen.case. Now this ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§Ç is convertible with ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ú‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§Ç, inwhich ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§úis the oblique form of ‡§§‡•ãthe demonstrative.Similarly we append even some of the case terminations tothe gen as ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§µ‡§§ ‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç I cannot do the work; ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä ‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç’there is no spirit (lit. water) in him.’

May the SƒÅmƒÅnyar√ºpa then be an original genitive? The gen.is used in the Prakrits and even in Pali, not only with independentwords, but is made the base of some cases also, as we have seen,and the case terminations attached to it; thus ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§Çis acc. sing. of‡§Ö‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‘I’ in the Pali and the Pr., ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§à instr, ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§¶‡•ã, ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø abl.,‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§øloc. in the latter, in which instances the usual terminations ofthose cases are added to the original gen. form ‡§Æ‡§Æ. We findeverywhere in the history of our languages that after a time theterminations in some cases come to have an independent senseand then they are detached from the original base and used like

ordinary post-positions. Thus, before the loc. ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø was appendedto ‡§Æ‡§Æ, it must have acquired some such sense as ‘in the interiorof’ and that the whole expression ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ømight mean in theinterior of me’. Similarly in the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa, some of the postpositions which came into use and which, as I shall hereaftershow, have grown into our case terminations are used with thegen. of the noun to which they are attached.Thus:‚Äî‡§π‡§â‡§Ç‡§ù‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§â‡§Ç‡§§‡§â ‡§ï‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§Ö ‡§§‡•Å‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§π ‡§∞‡•á‡§∏‡§ø ‘I pine sway for thee, ohbeloved, but thou for another’, in which we have the postposition‡§ï‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç and ‡§∞‡•á‡§∏‡§ø having the sense of ‘for’ used with the genitives ‡§§‡§â‡§Ç’thy’ and ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§π‘of another.’

ANALYSIS OF THE MARATHI OBLIQUE FORM

And if we examine the oblique forms themselves, we shall findthat that they are derived from the Apbhr. and Pr. genitives.Thus the form in ‡§Ü sing, and ‡§Ü‡§Ç pl. which nouns in ‡§Ö, ‡§Üetc.take is derived from the Apbhr. ‡§π sing. and ‡§π‡§Ç or ‡§Ö‡§Ç pl. derivedfrom Pr. ‡§∏ and ‡§£‡§Ç. The grammarians give the Apbhr. sing.termination as ‡§π‡•ã, but ‡§π is also found, as in ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§®‡§π in the abovequotation, and in the following occuring in an old work:‚Äî

‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞ ‡§§‡§£‡§á‡§∏‡§Ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§á‡§∏‡•Ä ‡•§ ‡§ú‡§ø‡§∏‡•Ä ‡§á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§π ‡§ò‡§∞‡§ø ‡§∞‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø ‡••

‘The wealth of Kanha was like the affluence in the house ofIndra’ where ‡§á‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§π is gen. sing. The ‡§π of ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§π, for instance, isreduced to ‡§Ö, the aspirate being lost, as is often the case in thevernaculars, and we have ‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æor ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡§æ. Similarly ‡§Ö‡§Çof the pl.combines with the preceding ‡§Öinto ‡§Ü‡§Çand we have ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç.

The second form ‡§à and ‡§à‡§Ç is derived from the gen. of nouns in‡§á or ‡§à masc. or fem. Thus ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä‡§á is the Pr. gen. sing. from whichwe have ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•Äthe sing. obl., and ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡§ø‡§£‡§Çpl., the ‡§£‡§Ç of which isreduced to ‡§Ö‡§Ç as in the other case, and we have ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ö‡§Ç, -‡§Ö, as provedin the last lecture, generally goes out in the vernaculars, after along vowel even when medial, and after a short dissimilar vowelwhen final, and hence we have ff the obl. pl. Or the sing. ‡§àmay be derived from another fem, gen. termination ‡§Ö or the masc.‡§Ö for ‡§π, which, before the preceding short ‡§á, goes out since it isfinal, as ‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§π-‡§ï‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ö-‡§ï‡§µ‡•Ä.

The fourth form ‡§âand ‡§ä is similarly derived from masc. andfem. nouns in ‡§äor ‡§ä; as ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏-‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§á-‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ö-‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•Ç obl. M., thoughwe have not this word in this form in M. where it is ‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç-‡§∏‡§∞‡§∏‡•Ç ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏‡•Å‡§Ögen ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ç, obl. sing. M.; ‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§£‡§Ç-‡§∏‡§∏‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§Ö‡§Ç-‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§Ç obl.pl. M.

The fifth form in ‡§è sing, and ‡§Ü‡§Çpl. is from fem. nouns in ‡§Ü;Pr. ‡§ú‡§ø‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§á or ‡§ú‡§ø‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§è-‡§ú‡§ø‡§≠‡•áM. obl. sing. and ‡§ú‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§£‡§Ç-‡§ú‡§ø‡§¨‡•ç‡§≠‡§æ‡§Ö‡§Ç-‡§ú‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§ÇM.obl. pl.

The third form ‡§à sing. and ‡§Ü‡§Çpl. is a mixture of the secondand the fifth and the nouns that take it form their oblique onthe type of the fifth in the Goan. and MƒÅl.

ANALYSIS OF THE SINDHI OBLIQUE FORMS

The Sindhi in its ‡§Öof the sing. of its first and second forms,shortens the ‡§Üof the M., i. e. the two ‡§Ö form one strong ‡§Ö; whilein its third or fourth, it either dispenses with the special obliqueor this is the same as the nom., as in the case of the M. ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø, ‡§≠‡•Å‡§à, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Çetc. The Sindhi plural oblique has one form ‡§Ü‡§Ç, like thecorresponding M. ‡§è‡§Ç, which appears to be from the Apbhr. ‡§π‡•á‡§Ç of thegen. pl. of nouns in short ‡§á or ‡§â given by KramƒÅdƒ´≈õvara and therest presents the gen. ‡§® in an uncorrupted form. Of these ‡§â‡§®‡§øwhich all fem. nouns and one set of masc, nouns take appears tobe a combination of the fem. nom. pl. ‡§â and the gen. ‡§®‡§ø; i. e. tothe nom. pl. of these nouns the obl. was added instead of tothe original base.

THE HINDI AND THE PUNJABI OBLIQUE FORMS

The P. pl. ‡§Ü‡§Çis the same as the M. and the H. ‡§ì‡§Çis fromthe Apbhr. ‡§π‡•Å‡§Çof nouns in ‡§á or ‡§â. Or it may be explained as acombination of the fem. ‡§ì‡§Çwith the nasal of the gen, as theSindhi ‡§â‡§®‡§øis.

The Braj ‡§® also presents the gen. termination in an unchangedform.

This then is the way in which the oblique forms are derived,but as usual the law of false analogy and simplication has beenin operation even here and thus while the M. represents them ina pristine condition, the Sindhi has reduced them to fewer typesand the P. and H. and perhaps the G. to one and the B. and O.have dropped them altogether.

It now remains to show why nouns with various endingsinflect the obl. in M. and S. according to the same type. I havealready shown that the oblique terminations ‡§Ü and ‡§Ü‡§Ç properlybelong to nouns in ‡§Ö. Sindhi mase. nouns in ‡§â are, as observed on a former occasion, really nouns in ‡§Ö, ‡§âbeing the nom. singtermination, whence they take in the sing, ‡§Üshortened to ‡§Ö.Nouns in ‡§Ü Mar, and P. and in ‡§ìS. also form their obliqueaccording to this type. But the sing, base ends in ‡§Ø‡§æor ‡§è in M.and ‡§è in others. These nouns, as shown in the last but onelecture, were originally nouns augmented by the addition of ‡§ï.Thus Skr. ‡§ò‡•ã‡§ü‡§ï isPr. ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§Ö or ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§Ø, since ‡§Ö is pronounced ‡§Ø, andwith ‡§π or ‡§Ö the gen. termination becomes ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§Ø + ‡§Ö = ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§Ø‡§æ, whichby hasty pronunciation becomes ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ; but in the older M. poetswe find ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§Ø‡§æalso. Now in the state of ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§Øit may become, asI have once stated, ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•á, is ‡§ï‡§Ø‡§≤for ‡§ï‡§¶‡§≤ becomes ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤ or ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤, andafter a long vowel the following ‡§Ö is elided, whence we havethe form of the M. dialects and S. and P. and H. Similarly wehave the plural ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç.

Neuter nouns in ‡§è‡§Ç are also nouns with a final ‡§ï, as has beenshown, hence their oblique is like that of the Masc. nouns in ‡§Ü.‡§ï‡§¶‡§≤‡§ï‡§Æ‡•ç-‡§ï‡§Ø‡§≤‡§Ö‡§Ç-‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç and ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡§Ø + ‡§Ö of the gen. = ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡§Ø‡§æ-‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ.Similarly ‡§∏‡•ã‡§®‡•á‡§Ç = ‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§Ö =‡§∏‡•Å‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡§ï etc.

Masc. nouns in ‡§à also take this form. If they do so, theymust be nouns in ‡§Ö originally and as a matter of fact we dofind some of them at least to be so. Thus ‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä is ‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ö Pr., ‡§®‡§æ‡§™‡§ø‡§§Sk wherefore we have ‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ú + ‡§Ü = ‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ; ‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï is Pr.‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡§ø‡§≠ and with the gen. ‡§π or ‡§Ö the obl.‡§§‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§¨‡•ã‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ; ‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§ú Pr, ‡§µ‡§æ‡§£‡§ø‡§Öand with for our obl. etc. Similarly is , wherewith gen. ‡§Öwe have M. ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•Ä is ‡§™‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ö and thence ‡§™‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ.S. ‡§π‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä is Skr. ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï, Pr. ‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Öwhich is the S. obl. form, since theeffect of two ‡§Öcoming together is in this language to preventthe usual elision and form one strong ‡§Ö.

We thus see that most Mar. and S, masc. nouns in ‡§à and M. neuternouns ‡§à are derived from Pr. nouns having a final ‡§ÆrepresentingSkr. ‡§ï or any other syllable. In the same way Skr. ‡§≤‡§°‡•Å‡§ïis Pr.‡§≤‡§°‡•Å‡§≠ thence ‡§≤‡§æ‡§°‡•Å‡§Öand with the gen, ‡§Ö for ‡§π ‡§≤‡§æ‡§°‡§µ‡§æ the M. obl.;so also M. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§âmust be Pr. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§â‡§Ö., Skr. ‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡•É‡§ï; M. ‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡•Å, Pr. ‡§®‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§≠,

Skr. ‡§®‡§™‡•ç‡§§‡•É‡§ï, in order that with the gen. ‡§Ö they may yield. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§µ‡§æor‡§®‡§æ‡§§‡§µ‡§æ Neuter ‡§ó‡§≤‡•Å‡§Çis ‡§ó‡§°‡•Å‡§Ö, Skr. ‡§ó‡§°‡•Å‡§ï and hence by the combinationof ‡§ó‡§π‡•Å‡§Ö + ‡§Ö we have ‡§ó‡§°‡§µ‡§æor ‡§ó‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ. S‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§π‡•Ç must have been ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§πfrom ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑and the aspiration being transferred to ‡§® we have‡§Æ‡§æ‡§£‡•ç‡§π‡•Å‡§Öwhich is the obl. form. Thus then those M. and S. masc.nouns in ‡§â and M. neuter nouns in ‡§ä‡§Ç which take this obliqueform were Pr. nouns in ‡§Örepresenting a Skr. syllable ending in‡§µ, mostly ‡§ï. Now these vernacular nouns in ‡§á or ‡§àand ‡§µ or ‡§äwhich in Skr. bave not a syllable like ‡§§or ‡§ï at the end musthave the ‡§ï attached to them in the Pr. and Apbhr., as we haveseen it was, to nouns in ‡§Ö which on that account have becomenouns in ‡§ìor ‡§Üin the modern languages.

Those fem. nouns in ‡§Ö that have ‡§à or ‡§à‡§Ç for their SƒÅmƒÅnyar≈´paterminations must be Skr, and Pr. nouns in ‡§á or ‡§àas they are ass matter of fact; as ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤ is Pr. ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä or ‡§ï‡§Ø‡§≤‡•Ä, Skr ‡§ï‡§¶‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§≠‡§ø‡§Ç‡§§ is Pr.and Skr, ‡§≠‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø; ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ß,Skr. ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•ç‡§ß‡§ø, Pr. ‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡§ß‡•Ä;‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§£, Skr. ‡§≠‡§ó‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä, Pr. ‡§¨‡§π‡§ø‡§£‡•Ä;‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ, Skr. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§™‡•Ä, Pr. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä, and a good many modern Tadbhavassuch as ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§, ‡§ó‡§§, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§ from ‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§‡§ø, ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø, ‡§µ‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§ø etc. others that end in‡§à and take these terminations were also originally nouns in ‡§áor ‡§à as ‡§≠‡•Å‡§à, Skr. ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Æ‡§ø and others. Some masc. nouns in ‡§à whichform their obl, in this way must also be derived from corresponding nouns in ‡§à, as ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Äis from the Skr. and Pr. Nom. sing. ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡•Ä.And modern Tatsamas in ‡§á or ‡§à of course can only take thisform. Similarly those nouns that form their oblique by taking‡§ä and ‡§ä‡§Çmust be originally nouns in ‡§â or ‡§ä. Modern Tatsamasending in these vowels also take these forms.

The fifth form has already been traced to the Pr. gen. of fem.nouns in ‡§Ü, whence those nouns that take the form in M. musthave been originally nouns ending in that vowel.
