Thus ‡§ú‡•Ä‡§≠,Pr. ‡§ú‡§ø‡§ó‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ, Skr. ‡§ú‡§ø‡§π‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ ‡§≠‡§æ‡§ï-Skr. ‡§≠‡§æ‡§∑‡§æ ( mod. Tad. ); ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤-‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ-‡§Æ‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ; ‡§≠‡•Ä‡§ï‚Äì‡§≠‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§ñ‡§æ-‡§≠‡§ø‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§æ;‡§®‡•Ä‡§ú or‡§®‡•Ä‡§¶-‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ-‡§®‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ; ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ú-‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ú‡•ç‡§ù‡§æ-‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ; ‡§∏‡•á‡§ú-‡§∏‡•á‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§æ-‡§∂‡§Ø‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ etc.All modern fem. Tatsamas in rare inflected in this way. From the fact that fem. nouns in ‡§à take ‡§Ü‡§Ç forthe pl. obl. it would appear that they were originally nouns in ‡§Ü.‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•Ä we know must have been Skr. ‡§µ since the masc. is ‡§ò‡•ã‡§ü‡§ï.Its gen. pl. in Pr, therefore was ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§ø‡§Ü‡§Ö‡§Ç, whence we have ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç,but the sing. obl. ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•Äwhich is the same as the nominative is not

formed, as it should be, according to our theory. But, as observedbefore, the Goan and MƒÅl. have faithfully preserved the oldtradition here though the ordinary M. has lost it and in thisinstance applies the case terminations to the Nom. and not tospecial obl. form as the other languages do to a much greaterextent. The Goan, and MƒÅl. SƒÅmƒÅnyar≈´paof ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•Äis ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á fromPr. gen. ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§ø‡§Ü‡§á, the last two vowels combining into ‡§è and the ‡§áand ‡§è into ‡§Ø‡•á. Other instances are ‡§∏‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä, Skr. ‡§∂‡§æ‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ, ‡§¨‡§æ‡§°‡•Ä-‡§µ‡§æ‡§ü‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ,‡§®‡§≤‡•Ä-‡§®‡§≤‡§ø‡§´‡§æ, ‡§ï‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä-‡§Æ‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä-‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ, ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•Ä-‡§Æ‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ, the sing. obl of which in the Goan. and MƒÅl. are , ‡§∏‡§æ‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á, ‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á, ‡§®‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•áetc.Similarly those fem. nouns that take this type of the obl. musthave been nouns in ‡§Ürepresenting such a syllable as ‡§ï‡§æ.Thus M. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ç is Pr. ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡•Å‡§Ü, Skr ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ, and ‡§¨‡§æ‡§≤‡•Å‡§Ü with the ‡§á or ‡§èof the Gen. sing. is ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡•áand with ‡§Ü‡§Çof the pl. ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏; also ‡§ú‡§≤‡•Ç-‡§ú‡§≤‡•ã‡§Üor ‡§ú‡§≤‡•Å‡§Ü-‡§ú‡§≤‡•å‡§ï‡§æ; ‡§ä a louse Skr. ‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§ï‡§æ, ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç-‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡§æ. The lastand also ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤‡•Çhave also the obl. form in ‡§ä and ‡§ä‡§Ç. Several othernouns also, masc, and fem, endingin ‡§àand ‡§ä, have the ‡§àand ‡§äform of the obl. as well as the ‡§Üor ‡§èand ‡§Ü‡§Çform. This arises fromthe practice of adding ‡§ï or ‡§ï‡§æoptionally in the Pr. just as thereare some nouns which, as we have seen, end both in ‡§Öand ‡§Ü.

In this way the several types of the M. sƒÅmƒÅnyar≈´pa arosefrom different sets of Pr. nouns, but it is not meant that all thosenouns that in the present state of the languages take one or otherof those types were derived from the corresponding Prakrit set.After the forms came into use, words-from foreign languages forinstance ‚Äîwere introduced which cannot of course be traced to thePrakrit and those were assigned to some one form according tothe gender in the first place and then to fancy or accident; thereis no reason why ‡§¶‡•å‡§≤‡§§ should be ‡§¶‡•å‡§≤‡§§‡•Äfor its oblique and not‡§¶‡•å‡§≤‡§§‡•á or ‡§´‡•å‡§ú ‡§´‡•å‡§ú‡•áand not ‡§´‡•å‡§ú‡•Ä; the tradition with regard to somePr. nouns also must have been forgotten and then they also havebeen in the condition of these foreign nouns and must have beentreated likewise; and to a certain extent oblivion is the reason whywe have two forms in the case of some nouns and no other.

This then is clearly the origin of the oblique forms; and allthe facts, especially in the Marathi language, harmonize socompletely with it that there can be no doubt whatever as to itstruth. And no other case than the gen. would have served the

purpose of reconstruction. When a language is in an early stage of growth and case forms such as the loc. sing. are made up byJoining two words such as ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‘a shining being’ and ‡§á ’this” or “here”,imagination is wanted to connect the ‘hore’ or ’this’ with the shiningbeing, i. e. in the place of the shining being. But when alanguage has got the means of expressing the relation denoted byof, it is necessary that it should be used in connection with thenew post-position; otherwise the sense would be incomplete.And thus in Skr., Pr. and the modern languages all such post-positions are appended to the gen. case. The gen. forms of nounsas they were in the Prakrits and the Apabhra·πÉ≈õa have descendedto the Marathi only somewhat phonetically altered, while theprincipal change that the nouns or crude forms have undergoneis the loss of final ‡§Öor ‡§Üanswering to such a Skr. syllable as ‡§§, ‡§ïor ‡§ï‡§æ when preceded by a dissimilar vowel, i e. ‡§á or ‡§â; while theother languages have, in most instances, taken this mutilatedcrude or nom. form as the base for all oblique cases, the M.confines it to its own place and uses the old gen. everywhere andwithout exception if we take the minor dialects also into consideration. The other languages have of course, as has been shown,preserved this gen. in some cases and of them all the S. in thelargest number of instances. Some such as the H. and P. havegeneralized the pl. form of one set of nouns and use it for all.The M. cases are thus more difficult to the learner than those of theother languages, but that is a matter with which we are notconcerned here.

NEW TERMINATIONS IN THE VERNACULARS

We will now proceed to the consideration of the new terminations. These have not necessarily sprung up from independentwords. We have seen that the old terminations such as the ‡§® ofthe instr. have been detached and constituted into post-positions.But the most common method the vernaculars have resorted tois to attach the case forms of certain words to the gen. of thenouns. The acc. and dat. terminations in the various dialectsare these : H. ‡§§‡§à‡§Ç, ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç, Braj. ‡§ï‡•å‡§Ç‚Äö B. ‡§ï‡•á, ‡§§‡•á,O. ‡§µ, S. ‡§ñ‡•á, ‡§§‡•á,P. ‡§®‡•Ç‡§Ç,‡§§‡§æ‡§à‡§ÇG. ‡§®‡•á,M. ‡§∏, ‡§≤‡§æ, and ‡§§‡•á‡§Ç used in poetry. Of these ‡§∏ has been discussed.The MƒÅl, and Goan, have ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Çfor pronours and the former ‡§ï for

nouns and the latter ‡§ï‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç. KhƒÅnde≈õƒ´has ‡§≤‡•á, P. has ‡§§‡§æ‡§à‡§Ç also for ‡§®‡•Ç,Old Bengali has also a dative in ‡§∞‡•á.

‡§¨‡•à‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ‡•Ä‡§∞‡•á ‡§π‡§Ç‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§π‡•á‡§Æ‡§®‡•Å‡§∑‡•ç‡§Ø‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡•á

Mah. Nalop. I.

‘The swan said to Vaidarbhƒ´with human speech.’

THE ORIGIN OFE IN THE VERNACULAR TERMINATIONS

Here we see that a good many languages have the terminationwith an initial ‡§ï. What is its origin? Dr. Caldwell traces it to theDravidian ‡§ï‡•Å. But in our whole investigation we have not yetmet a Dravidian influence in the grammar of our languages. Dr.Trump derives the S. ‡§ñ‡•á and B. ‡§ï‡•á from ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á. The last may notunlikely have been derived from it, but the aspiration of the S.‡§ñ‡•á is not accounted for. Trump attributes it to the vowel ‡§ã; butwe have seen that in the old Pr. this goes out, leaving nothingbut ‡§Ö, ‡§á or ‡§â, i. e, the consonantal portion of it, which is subordinated to the vowel portion, leaves no trace. There is no otherinstance in which ‡§ã is known to exert such an influence. TheHindi ‡§ï‡•å‡§Ç he also derives from ‡§ï‡•É‡§§ and not ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á. But here theAnusvƒÅra is not accounted for and regarded as inorganic. Besides,B Mr. Beames remarks, ‡§ï‡•É‡§§ is not a word likely to yield thesense of a dative. It is never used in Skr. or Pr. as equivalent to‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡•á.

To be able to arrive at the probable or correct etymology ofany of these terminations it is necessary to collect and compareany more ancient forms of it that may possibly be found. Nowthere are such forms in the case of the H. ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Çand the Braj ‡§ï‡•å‡§Ç.The old H. poets often use ‡§ï‡§π‡§Ç, ‡§ï‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç and even ‡§ï‡§æ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç; for instance inTulsidƒÅs’s RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa we have:‚Äî

‡§≠‡§æ‡§®‡•Å ‡§ï‡•É‡§∂‡§æ‡§®‡•Å ‡§∏‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ ‡§∞‡§∏ ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç‡•§ ‡§§‡§ø‡§® ‡§ï‡§π‡§Ç‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§¶ ‡§ï‡§π‡§§ ‡§ï‡•ã‡§° ‡§®‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡••

“The sun and fire swallow all liquids. Nobody calls themstupid.”

‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ú‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø ‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§ï‡§π‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡•§ ‡§ï‡•É‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ß‡•Å ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§Ö‡§§‡§ø‡§≠‡§≤ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ ‡••

‘He burned KƒÅma but gave a boon to Rati; this was anexcellent act done by the ocean of mercy.’

‡§ï‡§™‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§® ‡§ï‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§æ‡§® ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ß‡§ø ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡••

‘He gave various gifts to the monkeys and the Brahmans.’

‡§Ü‡§∏‡§® ‡§â‡§ö‡§ø‡§§ ‡§¶‡§Ø‡•á ‡§∏‡§¨‡§ï‡§æ‡§π‡•Ç‡•§ ‡§ï‡§π‡•å‡§Ç‡§ï‡§π‡§æ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ ‡§è‡§ï ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§õ‡§æ‡§π‡•Ç‡••

‘Proper seats were given to all; my mouth is one, how shall Irelate the festivities?’

‡§ï‡•à‡§ï‡§à ‡§ï‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡•á ‡§Æ‡§®‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§õ‡•ã‡§≠ ‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§á‡•§

‘Met Kaikayƒ´again, but the agitatiton of the heart did notsubside !’

Now we have seen that often in the modern languages the ‡§π ofolder words is dropped; and thus from ‡§ï‡§π‡•Å‡§Çwe have ‡§ï‡§â‡§Ç and then‡§ï‡•ãor ‡§ï‡•å‡§Ç by the usual rule that we have noticed in going over thevowel changes. From ‡§ï‡§π‡§Ç the MƒÅlva·πáƒ´and Goan. ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Çis derived.The ‡§ï‡§π‡§Ç and ‡§ï‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç are also traced to ‡§ï‡•É‡§§ by Dr. Trump. But Mr.Beames derives them from ‡§ï‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ ‘arm-pit, side’, which becomes‡§ï‡§æ‡§ñ and then ‡§ï‡§æ‡§π, and the anusvƒÅra he traces to the accusativeand thus supposes ‡§ï‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§Çto be the original of ‡§ï‡•å‡§Ç. ‡§ï‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑ is preserved inthe modern languages in the form of ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ñ, but the further changeof ‡§ñ to ‡§á in the suffix he accounts for by considering it to be alater Tadbhava. And corresponding to these two forms he says wehave the two forms of ‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®in the ordinary word ‡§•‡§æ‡§®H. ‘a place’and in the ‡§πof ‡§ï‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç. I have no hesitation in saying that Mr.Beames is altogether wrong in deriving ‡§ï‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç, ‡§ú‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç etc., and furtheron ‡§§‡§à‡§Ç or ‡§§‡§æ‡§à from ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®, ‡§Ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§®, ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§® etc. Such new expressions in the face of the many good old words existing in Skr. and Pr. couldnot have come in ordinary vernacular use. The B. ‡§è‡§•‡§æ‡§Ø, ‡§ì‡§•‡§æ‡§Ø, ‡§ï‡•ã‡§•‡§æ‡§Øetc., which have led Mr. Beames to this etymology aremanifestly new combinations of ‡§è and ‡§•‡§æ‡§Ø. ‡§ì and ‡§•‡§æ‡§Ø, ‡§ï‡•ã and ‡§•‡§æ‡§Ølike the barbarous compounds ‡§è‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§∏‡•á‡§ñ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§Ç of Skr. and foreignwords derived by the Bengali in its poverty of the old Tadbhavaelement. Neither should we derive the M. ‡§è‡§•and later ‡§è‡§•‡•á‡§Çfrom‡§è‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∏‡•ç‡§•‡§æ‡§® in the face of the Pr. ‡§è‡§§‡•ç‡§•from Skr. ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ or ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§∞ which we findeverywhere in Pr. works. Now as regards ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ñ, in addition to theobjection which Mr. Beames has not succeeded in answering, it isto be observed that the word is found nowhere used in that sensein old H., G. or M. literature and, that it might be the original ofthe dat, case-affix in nearly all the languages, it is necessary thatit should have been used extensively in Skr. or Pr. or in the oldliterature of the modern languages.

One chief and important source of the modern case affixes hasbeen overlooked by all those who have written on varnacularphilology. The words most fitted to express case relations are thepronouns and the old Aryan case endings have properly beentraced by comparative philologists to pronominal roots. Even inthe vernacular speech of the day we use pronominal expressions.when a simply general sense is wanted as ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§ø‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§ö‡•á ‡§è‡§•‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç‘I went to (lit.) the here of Govinda, i. e. to Govinda’s place; ‡§Æ‡•à‡§®‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§™‡§ï‡•á ‡§Ø‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡§ï‡•ã ‡§≠‡•á‡§ú‡§æ ‡§•‡§æ‘I sent my servant to your here’, i. e. yourplace; ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∞‡§≤‡•Ä‡§ß‡§∞‡§®‡•á ‡§§‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§π‡§§‡•ã‘I went to Murlidhar’s there’ i. e.,place. These ‡§è‡§•‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§Ø‡§π‡§æ‡§Çand ‡§§‡§π‡§æ‡§Çare really remnants of the old Pr.locatives of ‡§á‡§¶‡§Æ‡•ç (in the forms ‡§á or ‡§Ö ) and ‡§§‡§§‡•ç. If these weremore extensively used, they would in the course of time becometerminations, and ‡§§‡§à‡•áfor ‡§§‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç, the Pr. Apbhr. loc. of ‡§§‡§¶, has becomea termination in H. as ‡§Æ‡•à‡§Ç ‡§∂‡§π‡§∞‡§ï‡•á ‡§§‡§à‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ‘I went to the there of thetown’; ‡§â‡§∏‡§ï‡•á ‡§§‡§à‡§Ç ’to him. or for him’. In the Apabhra·πÅ≈õa,according to Hemacandro, ‡§ï‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Çand ‡§§‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Çwere used as postpositionsin the sense of ‘for’ ‘on account of as in the verse formerly given‡§π‡§â‡§Ç ‡§ù‡§ø‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§â‡§Ç ‡§§‡§â ‡§ï‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡§ø‡§Ö &c. These, as they are,appear likeinstrumental plurals of the pronouns ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç and ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç and they may beso really. The instr. and abl. may pass into the dat, and this intoeither. For, of the several relations denoted by the first twocases one is that between a cause and its effect or reason andconclusion, and a confusion between an antecedent cause orreason and the final cause or purpose is natural. This last isgenerally indicated by the dat. case. Even the English preposition’for’ has these two senses. In the sentence, ‘I bought the book formy own use, it signifies the purposes and in such a one as ‘for this, let people beware’ it denotes an antecedent reason. In thesame way ‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä‡§Ç or ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç are in M. used in both these senses. In‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§á‡§§‡§ï‡§æ ‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‘I took so much trouble for him’ it hasa dative sense and in ‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§Ö‡§∂‡•Ä ‡§ó‡•ã‡§∑‡•ç‡§ü ‡§ï‡§ß‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç ‡§®‡§Ø‡•á‘for this, such athing should never be done’ it has an ablative sense. This factmust be borne in mind as we go on discussing the origin of thecase forms. ‡§ï‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç and ‡§§‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç are therefore may be instrumentals.

This explanation is supported by the fact that another Apbhr.post-position in the sense of ‘for’ or ‘on account of given byHemacandra is ‡§§‡§£‡•á‡§£which is evidently the sing. instr. of ‡§§‡§£,

a possessive suffix to be hereafter mentioned. The pl. case formsmay become adverbs or postpositions as the Skr. ‡§∂‡§®‡•à‡§É’ slowly’ ,‡§®‡•Ä‡§ö‡•à‡§É and ‡§â‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö‡•à‡§É’low’ and ‘high’ which must originally have beeninstr. plurals. Another explanation of these forms is that theyare derived from the Pr. gen. plurals ‡§ï‡•á‡§∏‡§ø‡§Çand ‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç, the ‡§∏ beingchanged to ‡§π. The gen. has all along been used in the sense ofthe dat. In Skr. itself it is often so and in the Pr. it drove outthe old dat. altogether and was used instead. In old M. poetrythe obl. form, which we have traced to the Pr. gen., is often usedfor this case or, since in the Apabhr. nouns the termination ‡§π‡§ø‡§Çwas used for loc. pl. also, the forms ‡§ï‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç and ‡§§‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Çare not unlikelyto be referred to that case. The loc. is another case which canreadily be adapted to express a dat. acc. sense. TulsidƒÅsafrequently adds ‡§π‡§ø‡§Çto nouns to form this case. Thus‚Äî

‡§∞‡•Å‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§¶‡§® ‡§≠‡§Ø‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡•§

‘The god of love was afraid when he saw Rudra.’

‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§∏‡•å‡§™‡§ø‡§Ø ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§®‡§æ‡§á ‡§ï‡§Æ‡§≤ ‡§™‡§¶‡§Æ‡§æ‡§•‡•§
‡§∏‡•Å‡§§ ‡§ï‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§ø ‡§µ‡§® ‡§ú‡§æ‡§á ‡§Æ‡§ú‡§ø‡§•‡§∞‡§ò‡•Å‡§®‡§æ‡§•‡••

‘Having restored JƒÅnakƒ´to RƒÅmaand bowing your head athis lotus feet and giving the kingdom to your son, go to a forestand adore RaghunƒÅtha."

That these several cases may pass into the dat. acc. is alsoproved by the fact that the forms of the Apabhra·πÉ≈õa gerund ofinfinitive of purpose, which has essentially a dative sense, arederived from them. Thus Hamacandra gives these terminationsof the infinitive: ‡§è‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ças in ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç ‘for giving’ which is an acc. of the pot. part. ‡§¶‡•á‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ‡§Æ‡•ç, ‡§Ö‡§£ as in ‡§ï‡§∞‡§£ ‘for doing’ in which thecase termination is dropped, ‡§Ö‡§£‡§á‡§Æ‡•ç so as in ‡§≠‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ú‡§£‡§á‡§Ç‘for breaking’which is the gen. pl of ‡§≠‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§®and ‡§Ö‡§£‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç as in ‡§≠‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ú‡§£‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‘for enjoying’which is loc, sing, or pl. of ‡§≠‡•Å‡§û‡•ç‡§ú‡§£ Pr. for Skr. ‡§≠‡•ã‡§ú‡§®. Thus then in the Apabhra·πÉ≈õa pronominal forms had begun to be used as postpositions for expressing case relations. It is not unreasonable,therefore, to expect that we should find traces of the practice inour modern case forms and the forms themselves that were usedin that dialect.’

The Apabhra·πÉ≈õa dat. postposition ‡§ï‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Çsurvives in the S. ‡§ñ‡•á; theaspiration is thrown on ‡§ï‡•á so as to make it ‡§ñ‡•á and the followingvowel is dropped. We have already seen several instances ofthis process, but I will add one or two more to the point. The Pr.‡§ï‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‘where’ is in the Goan. and MƒÅl. ‡§ñ‡§Ç‡§Ø, ‡§§‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç’there’ ‡§•‡§Ç‡§Ø, ‡§Ö‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‘here‡§π‡§Ç‡§Ø. Often the old ‡§π is dropped in the modern dialects and thuswe have from ‡§ï‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç the B.‡§ï‡•á. The old H. termination ‡§ï‡§π‡§Ç is the Pr.‡§ï‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‘where,’ so that originally the sense of ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§π‡§Ç was RƒÅma’ssomewhere. ‘‘Send to R√§ma’s somewhere and give it to RƒÅma’ssomewhere came afterwards to mean send it to R√§ms and"give it to RƒÅma. The ‡§á of the loc. ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø is here dropped as ismostly the case in the pronominal locatives which in the modernlanguages as well as the Prakrit have become adverbs of place;such are ‡§ú‡§π‡§ø‡§Çrelative ‘where,’‡§§‡§∞‡•ç‡§π‡§ø’their,’ ‡§Ö‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‘here’ and ‡§ï‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‘where’(interrogative) which have become ‡§ú‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç, ‡§Ø‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç and ‡§ï‡§π‡§æ‡§Çand in TulsidƒÅs ‡§ú‡§π‡§Ç, ‡§§‡§π‡§Ç and ‡§ï‡§π‡§Ç. Sometimes the ‡§á is preserved inthe current speech as in ‡§ï‡§π‡§æ‡§Çor ‡§ï‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§Ç H., ‡§Ö‡§π‡•Ä, ‡§Ø‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç G. The other dat.termination ‡§ï‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç, the origin ‡§ï‡•å‡§Ç of ‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç, is either the ablative orgenitive form of ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•çsince ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç was in Apabhr. the termination of both these cases. The O. ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç is another form of this ‡§ï‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç. The M.‡§§‡•á‡§Ç is from the Apabhr. ‡§§‡§π‡§ø‡§Ças ‡§ï‡•á from ‡§ï‡•ã‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç. The B. has this affixalso used principally in the case of inanimate creatures.

‡§ß‡•Å‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç‡§§‡•á ‡§ó‡§®‡•ç‡§ß ‡§Ü‡§õ‡•á ‡§ì ‡§§‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•ã‡§Ø ‡•§

‘There is smell to smoke and from that harm to the eye results.’

‡§§‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π ‡§ï‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡•§

‘The lion said to him.’

The S. has it also.

‡§∏‡•ã‡§π‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§∂‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•á ’ He went for hunting.’ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ì ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§∏ ‡§´‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ö‡§§‡•á ‘wenton a travel’

The P. ‡§§‡§æ‡§á like the H. ‡§§‡§à‡§Ç is from ‡§§‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ’there.’

The M. ‡§≤‡§æis to be connected with similar terminations in itsown dialects and the other languages. KhƒÅnde≈õi has. ‡§≤‡•á. H.possesses a post-position ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Øor ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á, P. ‡§≤‡§à, S. ‡§≤‡§æ‡§áall in the senseof ‘for,’ Braj. ‡§≤‡•å‡§Çor ‡§≤‡•ã‡§Ç ‘up to’. The old H. poets have also ‡§≤‡•à or‡§≤‡§æ‡§à in the sense of the M. ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Çi. e. ’to’ or’ at’: ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§Ç‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§™‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§≤‡•à ‡§™‡§¶‡§π‡•Ä‡§Çagain and again they fall at her feet;’ ‡§π‡§∞‡§∏‡§ø ‡§â‡§†‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡•á ‡§â‡§∞‡§≤‡§æ‡§à

joyfully he arose and pressed him to his bosom.‘Then thereare other forms in all the languages from ‡§≤‡§ó. Goan has ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§Çinthe sense of ’to’ or ‘with,’ as ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ù‡•á ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§â‡§≤‡§™ ‘speak to or withme.’ H. ‡§≤‡§ó ‘up to ‘; P. ‡§≤‡§ó’ near, to’; ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç ‘from contact with;’ S. ‡§≤‡§ó‡•Ä-‡§≤‡§ó‡•á ‘on account of;’ B. ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§ø‡§Ç-‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ-‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•á ‘for, on accountof.’ In G. and H. poetry ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§Ç, ‡§≤‡§ó‡•Äor ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§ø are used in these sensesand M. has ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ç‡§® or ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•Å‡§®‡§ø also.

All these forms are derived from the old Skr. root ‡§≤‡§óto adhereor stick. The past pass. part, of this is ‡§≤‡§ó‡•ç‡§®, Pr. ‡§≤‡§ó‡•ç‡§®. This, likemany similar participles, is made the base of verbal forms inPr. and we have ‡§≤‡§ó‡•ç‡§ó‡§á = ‡§≤‡§ó‡•ç‡§®‡•ã ‡§≠‡§µ‡§§‡§ø ‘adheres, sticks.‚Äô From thiswe have ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§£‡•á‡§Ç-‡§µ‡•Å‡§Ç-‡§µM. G. B. by the usual rules, but S. generallyand H. sometimes do not lengthen the preceding vowel when oneof the two consonants is dropped and we have ‡§≤‡§ó‡§£‡•Åand ‡§≤‡§ó‡§®‡§æ,though ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§®‡§æ is also used in the latter. There is another form‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§§‡§ø of this root which is made up according to the 10thConjugation or which is properly the causal and, when thetermination is dropped as is often the case, we have ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§àand bythe elision of ‡§ó‡•ç the root becomes ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Öand thence, by the usualintroduction of ‡§Øor ‡§µ, ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø or ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ.Now ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§æ exists in the Gosn.and ‡§≤‡§æ‡§á‡§£‡•Å in the S. while M. has ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§Ç.These mean ’to make toadhere,‘‘apply,‚Äô ‘bring in contact.‘From ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§£‡•áand ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ø‡§£‡§æ or ‡§≤‡§æ‡§µ‡§£‡•á‡§Çall the forms we have above noticedhave originated. ‡§≤‡§æ‡§à, ‡§≤‡•à, ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ä, ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æare absolutives as also M. ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•ã‡§®‡§ø,while the otherM. form ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§Çis the loc. sing. of the noun ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó ‘contact’ or ’nearness.‘The Braj. ‡§≤‡•å‡§Ç must be from the oldApabhr. abso., ‡§≤‡§æ‡§â‡§Ç of ‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ö.. The M. dat. ‡§≤‡§æmust be from such a form as ‡§≤‡§æ‡§â‡§Ç‘havingapplied’ or ‘for applying, ‘since the final ‡§âof terminations isdropped in this language as in ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ ’tongues’ from ‡§ú‡§ø‡§≠‡§æ‡§â.

The dative pl. termination ‡§®‡§æ‡§Ç represents an euphonic changeof ‡§≤‡§ænecessitated by the preceding anusvƒÅra. Instances of thischange of ‡§≤ to have been given in a previous lecture. Cit. hasboth ‡§®‡§æ and ‡§®‡•ç‡§≤‡§æ. This ‡§®‡§æis by some traced to the ‡§£‡§Çof the Pr. gen.pl. as ‡§∏ to the ‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏ of the gen. sing. The Cit. however has‡§®‡§æ or ‡§®‡•ç‡§≤‡§æin the pl. while ‡§≤‡§æalone is the sing. termination and the samenessof the sing, and pl. terminations is the great peculiarity of themodern dialect, whence the Cit. ‡§®‡§æis a form of ‡§≤‡§æand if so, thenit must be so in the standard Marathi also.

Mr. Beames thinks the G. ‡§®‡•áto be originally ‡§≤‡•á and thus tobelong to the class of terminations we have just examined, the ‡§≤being changed to ‡§®. I have not satisfied with this derivation as thereis no corroborative evidence, though the change of ‡§≤to ‡§® is notimpossible or unexampled. The gen. termination ‡§®‡•ã-‡§®‡•Ä-‡§®‡•Å‡§Çin thislanguage is derived from the old Apabhra·πÅ≈õa termination ‡§§‡§£, bythe elision of the initial ‡§§, as will be hereafter shown. In thesame manner the of the acc, dat, must have been derived fromthe Apabhr. dat. post-position ‡§§‡§£‡•á‡§£, which, as I have alreadyobserved, is the instr. of ‡§§‡§£. The last ‡§£ of this is changed toan anusv√§ra, as that of ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§£is, and, just as this becomes ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§§‡§£‡•á‡§£becomes ‡§§‡§£‡•á‡§Çand by the loss of ‡§§, ‡§®‡•á‡§Ç . Or the process which in theApabhr. led to the formation of ‡§§‡§£‡•á‡§£from ‡§§‡§£may have beenresorted to when ‡§§‡§£became ‡§® in the G. and thus ‡§®‡•á‡§Ç is the instrumental or locative of the gen. ‡§® or its obl. form. But theanusv√§ra of which is lost in the G. instr. would show that it isderived directly from ‡§§‡§£‡•á‡§£. P. ‡§®‡•Å‡§Ç may likewise be referred to aa form ‡§§‡§£‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç the abl of ‡§§‡§£.

THE ORIGIN OF ‡§∏IN THE VERNACULAR TERMINATIONS

In H. the termination is applied in a dative sense to nounsgoverned by verbs denoting speaking ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡§π‡§æ ‘The kingspoke to the Brahman’. It is used in the sense of the instr.,‡§§‡§∞‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§∏‡•á ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ü‡§æ ‘Hecut off his head with a sword,’ ‡§∞‡•Å‡§ï‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ø‡§®‡•Ä‡§ï‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡§∂‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ä‡§ï‡•É‡§∑‡•ç‡§£‡§ö‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡§∏‡•á ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ü ‘Rukminƒ´’s marriage with ≈öri K·πõ·π£·πáacanda tookplace; and in that of the abl. ‡§á‡§§‡§®‡§æ ‡§µ‡§ö‡§® ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§£‡§ï‡•á ‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ñ‡§∏‡•á ‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§≤‡§æThesewords fell from the mouth of the Brahman.’ In Braj, we have‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ç for ‡§∏‡•á, as‡§ï‡§¨‡•Ä‡§∞‡§ú‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§ï‡•à‡§Æ‡•ã‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•å‘Kabir came and said tome;’ ‡§ó‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Ç‡§õ‡§ø ‡§≤‡•á‡§á‘He should get it explained from the guru.‘In old H. also it is used in the form of ‡§∏‡•å‡§Ç. In old M., as I havealready remarked, we have in the sense of the modern dat.acc. ‡§∏ as:‚Äî

( 1 ) ‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§•‡•Ä ‡§∂‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡§ß‡§∞ ‡•§ ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§®‡•á‡§∏‡•Ä ‡••

J√±ƒÅn. I-141.

‘≈öƒÅr·πÖgadhara was charioteer to Arjuna.’

( 2 ) ‡§™‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§°‡§º‡§æ ‡§§‡•Å‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ó‡§Ç‡§ß‡§∞‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Ä ‡••

II-10.

‘Thou hast made a song for Gandharvas.’

( 3 ) ‡§ú‡•á ‡§®‡•á‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ø‡§∂‡•ã‡§¶‡•á‡§∏‡•Ä ‡•§
‡§§‡•á ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§ß‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§™‡•Ç‡§§‡§®‡•á‡§∏‡•Ä ‡••
‡§∏‡§Æ‡§æ‡§® ‡§¶‡•á‡§£‡•á‡§Ç‡§Ö‡§∞‡§ø‡§Æ‡§ø‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ç‡§∏‡•Ä‡•§
‡§â‡§¶‡§æ‡§∞‡§§‡•á‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§£‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡••

Rukmi·πáƒ´Svaya·πÉvara I-82.

“He gave that salvation to P≈´tanƒÅwhich he did not gave toYa≈õodƒÅand Devakƒ´. His gifts to friends and foes are alike.How shall I describe his bounty?”

(1) ‡§™‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§∑‡§£‡•á‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ù‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç‡•§‡§¶‡•á ‡§∞‡§£‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç‡••

J√±ƒÅn. I-171.

‘It is necessary in the battlefield to see with whom I shouldfight.’

(2) ‡§Ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§ú‡•Å‡§® ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§§ ‡•§ ‡§§‡•ã ‡§¶‡§≤‡§≠‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§∏‡§Æ‡§∏‡•ç‡§§ ‡•§ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡•á‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡••

J√±ƒÅn. I-176.

‘Arjuna was looking at the whole force with an agitated heart.’

( 3 ) ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø ‡§™‡§∞‡§≤‡•ã‡§ï‡§π‡•Ä ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§≤ ‡•§ ‡§ê‡§π‡§ø‡§ï‡•á‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡••

J√±ƒÅn. II-27.

‘And the interest of the future life will be lost along with thoseof this’

In these last three examples Thas the sense of an instrumental.We do not now use it in the sense in which it is used in the lasttwo passages and say ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§≠‡•ç‡§∞‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§§‡•ã and ‡§ê‡§π‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§ ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§§‡§∞‡•á‡§≤. In theSalsette dialect, however, ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Çhas these senses and also that of anabl. as that of ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§Ø‡§≤‡•ã‘He came from the village.’

Now we see that the old M. poets do not make a distinctionbetween the ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ç, which corresponds to our modern ‡§∏, and thatwhich even now we use in the sense of ‘with’. They all use it inother senses in which it is used in H., but not in the M. of theday. The Salsette dialect, however, agrees with the H. in its useof this affix. H. uses ‡§∏‡•á in one case ‡§â‡§∏‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡§π‡§æ in which we use ‡§∏,as ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§ø‡§§‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç. Some of these circumstances favour the supposition that the origin of the M. dative affix ‡§∏is the same as that ofH. ‡§∏‡•á and M. ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ç. G. poetry has this in the form of ‡§∂‡•Å‡§Ç or ‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ç. as‡§ó‡•Ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§æ‡§§‡§ø‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç‡§°‡§ø‡§∏‡§ø ‡§ï‡§≤‡§π Declare war with Gujarati.’ S. has ‡§∏‡•á‡§Ç and ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Çin the sense of with.

All these are derived from the word ‡§∏‡§Æ. As is usual, is inmodern vernaculars changed to ‡§µ‡§Ç and thus we have ‡§∏‡§µ‡§Çand withthe instr. affix ‡§è we have the ‡§∏‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç of the M. poets. I have ina former lecture given a great many instances in which ‡§µ is dissolved into ‡§â, which combines with the preceding vowel into ‡§î.We thus get the old H. ‡§∏‡•å‡§Çand the Braja ‡§∏‡•ã‡§Ç, when ‡§Öand ‡§â form ‡§ì,while in G. the resulting vowel is ‡§â‡§Ç in ‡§∂‡•Å‡§Ç. Another change of ‡§Æthat we have noticed is its loss of the labial element and reductionto a vowel and anusv√§ra, wherefore the word becomes ‡§∏‡§Ö‡§Çor ‡§∏‡§Ø‡§Ç.Thence the ‡§Ö‡§Ø passes off into ‡§è, as we have several times noticed,and so we have ‡§∏‡•á‡§Ç, which with the anusvƒÅra dropped is the H. ‡§∏‡•á.The ‡§Ø is sometimes, as we have seen, changed to ‡§à as in ‡§∞‡§æ‡§áfrom ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Ö-‡§∞‡§æ‡§Øand so we have the M. ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ç. Sometimes ‡§Ø does not take theplace of the elided consonant and the vowels are combined,whence we have the S. ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ç. Now the original sense of this wordis with, but this with expresses many relations, the differencesbetween which become wider in the course of time and thus theword ‡§∏‡§Æ has come to signify ’to, according to, with (as an instrument) and from’.

This instr. termination ‡§®‡•á‡§Ç (sing.)‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç(pl.) M., ‡§®‡•á H., ‡§®‡§á P. have beentraced by Mr. Beames to ‡§≤‡•á or ‡§≤‡•à, which are forms of ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ó‡§ø‡§Çor ‡§≤‡§áetc. derived from the root ‡§≤‡§ó. One great objection is that thisderivation does not account for the anusv√§ra of ‡§®‡•á‡§Ç or ‡§®‡•à‡§Ç. Hisargument is that the old ‡§è‡§®of the instr. having been reduced to ‡§è‡§Ç,there was no other instrumental case to furnish the ‡§® of themodern instr. ‡§®‡•á‡§Ç-‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç; but in the Apabhr, according to Hemacandraboth these forms existed and the instance he gives is

‡§ú‡•á ‡§Æ‡§π‡•Å ‡§¶‡§ø‡§£‡•ç‡§£‡§æ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ö‡§π‡§°‡§æ ‡§¶‡§á‡§è‡§Ç ‡§™‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§£ ‡•§
‡§§‡§æ‡§£ ‡§ó‡§£‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§è ‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ó‡•Å‡§≤‡§ø‡§â ‡§ú‡§ú‡•ç‡§ú‡§∞‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§â ‡§®‡§π‡•á‡§£ ‡••

‘By counting (again and again) [the number of] days whichwere mentioned to me by my beloved when he set out on histravels [ the skin of] my fingers has worn away by the nail.‘Here ‡§¶‡§á‡§è‡§Ç, ‡§™‡§µ‡§∏‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á‡§£ and ‡§®‡§π‡•á‡§£ are instances of the instrumental. Thefirst two are expressive of the agent in the passive constructionand the third of the simple instrument; so that the ‡§è‡§£or ‡§£ of theinstrumental must have descended to the vernaculars. Again Mr.Beames says that the old H. poets do not use the instr. in ‡§®‡•á‡§Ç; butthe oldest M. poet J√±ƒÅ·πáe≈õvara does use it in some cases.His

agent instrumental is very often that which ends in ‡§è‡§Ç, butinstances of the use of ‡§®‡§ø, which is another form of ‡§®‡•á‡§Ç, also occur.

As:‚Äî

‡§ï‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡§ø ‡§ú‡§æ‡§§ ‡§Ü‡§π‡•á‡•§

J√±ƒÅn. 13-197.

“Or whether he is going away by the wind.”

‡§¶‡§ø‡§∏‡•á ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡•á‡§®‡§ø ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á ‡§ú‡§æ‡§á‡§≤‡•§

J√±ƒÅn. 13-214.

‘Appears as if it will go away by the wind.’

‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ï‡•á‡§®‡§ø ‡§ò‡•á‡§§‡§≤‡•á ‡§Æ‡•å‡§® ‡§ú‡•à‡§∏‡•á‡•§

J√±ƒÅn. 13-280.

“As the dumb may be said to have assumed silence deliberately.”

‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡§ø ‡§ú‡•ã ‡§® ‡§§‡§æ‡§™‡•á ‡•§
‡§π‡§ø‡§Æ‡§µ‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§® ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ç‡§™‡•á ‡••
‡§ï‡§æ‡§Ø‡§∏‡•á‡§®‡§π‡•Ä ‡§® ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§™‡•á ‡•§‡§™‡§æ‡§§‡§≤‡•á‡§Ø‡§æ ‡••

J√±ƒÅn. 13-347.

‘He is not oppressed by heat or does not shiver by cold and isnot terrified by anything that takes place.’

Here are instances of the instr. both indicative of the agentand of the simple instrument, but the termination is ‡§®‡§ø insteadof ‡§®‡•á‡§Ç. Besides these there are instances of the instrumental in ‡§£‡•á‡§Çof pronouns as ‡§Ø‡•á‡§£‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§ÇJ√±ƒÅn. 13-200 ‘By this standard,’ ‡§ú‡•á‡§£‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§§‡•ã‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç13-244 ‘By which satisfaction’, ‡§§‡•á‡§£‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡§æ‡§¶‡•á‡§Ç18-1147 ‘By that grace.‘Now I have stated my view in the last lecture that ‡§®‡•á‡§Ç is a doubleinstrumental, the first part being ‡§® of the old instrumental in ‡§è‡§®or ‡§è‡§£, and the second part ‡§è‡§Ç, to which that ‡§è‡§£is reduced. Nowinstead of ‡§è‡§Ç, the instr. ‡§á‡§Çis added here. The instr. ‡§á‡§Ç represents the‡§á‡§£ of the Apabhr. instr. in ‡§á‡§£, which we have in such forms as‡§™‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§£ mentioned by Pischel. Hindi poets as a rule indicate theagent instrumental by the oblique form, but S≈´rdƒÅs uses the formending in ‡§®‡§ø or ‡§®‡•á‡§Ç also.

‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§π ‡§ï‡•ã ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø ‡§ó‡•ã‡§µ‡§∞‡•ç‡§ß‡§®‡§§‡•á‡§Ç ‡§î‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§®‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•Ç‡§ú‡§æ‡•§
‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø ‡§∏‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ø‡§π ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§®‡•Ä ‡§¨‡§°‡•ã ‡§¶‡•á‡§µ ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø‡§∞‡§æ‡§ú‡••

SursƒÅgar, pada 12, page 252.132

‘KƒÅnha said, “There is no other God besides the mountainGovardhan.” Taking it to be the truth the king of mountainswas regarded by the cowherds as a great God."

Here ‡§ó‡•ã‡§™‡§®‡§ø is agent instrumental in ‡§®‡§ø.

‡§∏‡§¨‡§®‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§ï‡§ü ‡§Æ‡•Ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø ‡§∏‡§π‡§∏‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§ú‡§æ ‡§™‡§∏‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡•§
‡§∞‡•Å‡§ö‡§ø ‡§∏‡§π‡§ø‡§§ ‡§ó‡§ø‡§∞‡§ø ‡§∏‡§¨‡§®‡§ø ‡§Ü‡§ó‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‡§≤‡•à‡§≤‡•à ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ø‡••

SursƒÅgar, pada 24, page 254.

‘The manifested form with the thousand arms stretched out wassoen by all; with taste the mountain taking hold of every thingby his hands etc."

Here ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡§øis the instrumental.

‡§Ü‡§π‡§ø‡§∞‡§®‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§ú‡•ç‡§û‡§æ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§∏‡•ã ‡§´‡§≤ ‡§â‡§®‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§§‡•Å‡§∞‡§§ ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ñ‡§æ‡§µ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç‡•§

SursƒÅgar, pada 44, page 257.

‘Disrespect of the Lord has been shown by the cowherds; showto them the fruit of it.’

‡§è‡§ï ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§®‡•á ‡§Ü‡§ú ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§ø ‡§∏‡§™‡§®‡§æ‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§®‡•ã‡§Ç‡•§

SursƒÅgar, pada 29, page 255.

“Today a certain dream was shown me by a Being.”

Here ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑‡§®‡•á is agent instrumental.

The Ablative termination in M. is ‡§π‡•Ç‡§®, MƒÅl. ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®,Cit. ‡§†‡•Ä‡§Çor ‡§™‡§æ‡§∑‡•ç‡§†‡•Ä(from ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏ and ‡§•‡•Ä‡§Ç), Sals, ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç, G. ‡§•‡•Ä, S. ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ç-‡§ñ‡§â‡§Ç-‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ã ‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç, P. ‡§§‡•á‡§Ç-‡§•‡•Ä‡§Ç-‡§•‡•ã‡§Ç,H. ‡§∏‡•á, Braj. ‡§§‡•á, H. dial. ‡§∞‡•ç‡§•‡•Ä, B. ‡§π‡•ã‡§á‡§§‡•á ‡§§‡•á‡§Ç. The Sindhi ‡§ñ‡§æ‡§Çis the Pr. andApabhr, abl. ‡§ï‡§π‡§æ‡§Çof ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç, the aspiration being thrown on ‡§ï, as inthe case of the dat. ‡§ñ‡•á and the other instances formerly given;so that the S. abl. etymologically means ‘from his somewhere.’‡§ñ‡§â‡§Ç and ‡§ñ‡•ã‡§Ç are from the Ap. ‡§ï‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç abl. pl. In the same way ‡§§‡§æ‡§Çis theold abl. ‡§§‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç and ‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç, the abl. pl. ‡§§‡§π‡•Å‡§Çof ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç, in both of which theaspirate is elided but in the P. ‡§•‡•ã‡§Ç it is compounded with thepreceding ‡§§. The form ‡§•‡•Ä ‡§•‡•Ä‡§Çof the G. and P., and H. dial. andthe Cit. ‡§†‡•Ä‡§Çare derived from ‡§§‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç, the loc. sing. Pr. and Ap. of ‡§§‡§§‡•çwith the aspiration thrown on ‡§§.

The differences between some of the significations of thedifferent cases are, as I have already observed, so minute thatthey frequently run into one another and when on account ofthis resemblance, one case form becomes identified with anothercase, it afterwards acquires senses more widely different from itsoriginal. Thus ‡§§‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡•Å‡§∏‡•ç‡§§‡§ï ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡•á i. e. (lit.) ‘The bookmet me in vicinity of RƒÅmƒÅ’, easily passes into ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§® ‡§Æ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§≤‡•á‘met me from RƒÅmƒÅ’, i. e. ‘got from RƒÅmƒÅ’. And the B. ‡§Ü‡§™‡§®‡•á ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡•Å‡§∞

‡§ï‡§æ‡§õ‡•á ‡§§‡§æ‡§π‡§æ ‡§™‡§æ‡§á‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ is generally considered equivalent to ‘I got it fromthe master’, though ‡§ï‡§æ‡§õ‡•áis like ‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§Ça loc. form meaning ‘in thevicinity of. Thus the old loc. ‡§§‡§π‡§ø‡§Çmeaning ‘in that’ was used asa postposition and thence came to mear ‘from that.’ Or thetransition is first from the loc, to the dat., which I have spokenof, and thence to the causal abl. and afterwards to the local abl.The Braj. and P. ‡§§‡•á‡§Ç is from the Apabhr. affix ‡§§‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç(=for) mentionedbefore in which we have an instance of this passage of the dat.into the abl., as illustrated before in the M. postposition ‡§∏‡§æ‡§†‡•Ä‡§Ç.In M., S. and B. ‡§§‡•á‡§Ç has preserved the dative sense. B. has the abl.‡§§‡•á‡§Ç also, though some grammarians do not give it, but its seseis that of causal abl. or instr. as:‚Äî

‡§∂‡•É‡§ô‡•ç‡§ó‡•á‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§∞‡•ç‡§ò‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§Ü‡§®‡§Ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§§ ‡§π‡§á‡§≤‡•§

“Became glad on account of the length of its horns.’

‡§§‡§æ‡§π‡§æ‡§§‡•á ‡§ö‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡•Å‡§§‡•á ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§®‡§æ ‡§π‡•ã‡§Ø ‡•§

“From that there is harm to the eye.”

Of a different origin are the M. ‡§π‡•Ç‡§® and ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§®and the B. ‡§π‡•ã‡§á‡§§‡•á.The first ‡§π‡•Å‡§® Mr. Beames, following Lassen, traces to the ‡§π‡§ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã and‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã of the Pr. from a fusion, as it is called, of both, out of whicharose ‡§π‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã, and, the ‡§§‡•ãbeing lost, the form is ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§®. In a similarway ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§® may be traced to ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã,though its independent existencewould make the supposed fusion a fiction. M. however has noinstance of the loss of final ‡§§and the preservation of ‡§®; but thechief objection to this derivation is the want of corroborativeevidence. It is possible, but there is nothing to make it certainor even probable. Mr. Beames quotes passages from Canda inwhich ‡§π‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§and ‡§π‡•Å‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•ã occur in the sense of ‘from.’ But they maybe derived from the present participle. The B. abl. affix ‡§π‡•ã‡§á‡§§‡•á isthe loc. of the present participle of ‡§π‡•ã, corresponding to M. ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç,which has the sense of the Skr. loc. absolute as ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Çin ‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§§ ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•ã ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‘while I was doing he went away.’ In B. too thisloc. has the same sense as ‡§¶‡§ø‡§® ‡§•‡§æ‡§ï‡§ø‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‘work while it is day.‘In H. also it is used in the same sense: ‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞‡§™‡§∞ ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§π‡•à ‡§ï‡§ø ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§æ ‡§™‡§°‡§æ ‡§π‡•à ’looking at the door what did he find ? he found that alion was lying dead (lit. what is there,‚Äìa lion lying dead);’ ‡§≠‡•ã‡§∞ ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•á‡§π‡§ø ‡§â‡§∏‡§®‡•á ‡§∏‡§ñ‡•Ä‡§∏‡•á ‡§ï‡§π‡§æ ‘She told it to her friend immediatelyafter dawn (lit. after it had dawned).’

In this sense as in that of the Skr. loc. absolute, the actiondenoted by the present participle is made the starting point ofanother action. ‘My doing’ in the first instance was the starting point of his going. And herein is the germ of an ablative. In H. ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•áis sometimes used in this sense as ‡§Æ‡§ï‡§æ‡§®‡§∏‡•á ‡§π‡•ã‡§§‡•á ‘outsideof the house, from the house.’

In the B. ‡§µ‡•É‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§π‡§á‡§§‡•á ‡§´‡§≤ ‡§™‡§°‡§ø‡§§the original sense is ’the tree beingthere, & fruit fell. The M. ‡§¶‡•ç‡§∞‡•Ç‡§® is the absolutive of ‡§π‡•ãand equivalent to ‡§π‡•ã‡§ä‡§® having become which yields an ablative sensemore directly. The ‡§π is sometimes dropped and the termination‡§ä‡§® itself is attached in this sense to ‡§Ü‡§Ç‘in’, ‡§µ‡§∞ ‘above and‡§™‡§æ‡§∏ ‘side ’ to signify from in ‘,’ from above’, ‘from the side as‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§§‡•Ç‡§®, ‡§µ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§® and ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§® which are the sblative affixes used in caseswhen ‡§π‡•Ç‡§® cannot be applied, and ‡§ä‡§® is sometimes affixed tonouns in ‡§Ö directly and not to the oblique form, as ‡§ò‡§∞‡•Ç‡§® ‡§Ü‡§≤‡§æ.Thus ‡§ó‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§π‡•Ç‡§® ‡§Ü‡§≤‡§æmeans lit. “the village having been, he came.‘The M

ƒÅl. ‡§∏‡•Ç‡§® is the absolutive of ‡§Ö‡§∏ instead of ‡§π‡•ã. The H. ‡§∏‡•á hasbeen explained.

We have seen that in the course of the development of ourmodern languages the genitive which even in Skr. expressedrelation in general was used for the dative and sometimes forother cases also. The dative thus went out of use and, to expressthe relations which it indicated, various new suffixes, given andexplained above, were brought into use and the old genitive beingattenuated was felt to be too weak to express the usual genitiverelation and it was adapted to serve as the base of all obliquecases to which the newly constituted terminations were appended. The relation of possession as well as other genitive relations,such as that of a thing and the material of which it is made, had thus no special expression left for them. ln Skr. such relationsare indicated, besides the genitive case, by adjectives formed fromthe name of the possessor, material etc. by the addition of specific terminations and from these mostly the genitive terminationsin the modern languages are derived and consequently areadjectival in their nature and agree with the gender of thething possessed or made. The genitive terminations are asfollows:‚Äî
M. ‡§ö‡§æ-‡§ö‡•Ä-‡§ö‡•á‡§Ç P. ‡§¶‡§æ-‡§¶‡•Ä
G. ‡§®‡•ã-‡§®‡•Ä-‡§Æ‡•Å‡§Ç B. ‡§á‡§∞ or ‡§è‡§∞
S. ‡§ú‡•ã-‡§ú‡•Ä O. ‡§∞
H. ‡§ï‡§æ-‡§ï‡•Ä

In the first lecture I have remarked that in the third stage ofthe development of Sanskrit the nominal style came into useinstead of the verbal style or fluent style. When the languagewas in this condition, adjectival forms expressive of possessionor other relations came into use instead of the genitive case andsuch forms, as :

‡§§‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ’the house belonging to him,’

‡§Æ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§É ‡§õ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É ’the pupil belonging to me.’

‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§ñ‡•Ä ’the female friend belonging to thee,’

came into use instead of ‡§§‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‡§ó‡•É‡§π‡§Æ‡•ç ‘his home,’ ‡§Æ‡§Æ ‡§õ‡§æ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§É‘my pupil,’‡§§‡§µ ‡§∏‡§ñ‡•Ä ’thy female friend.’ When the use of such adjectivesbecame general the real genitive case, so far as it expressed possession and such other relations between nouns, was driven out andadapted to express the various other relations mentioned before.Thus then we find that the case forms expressive of possessionand other relations mentioned in the vernaculars are of anadjectival character. It is, however, curious to find that in ourseven modern languages they are derived from seven differentforms in Sanskrit and Prakrit.

The M. ‡§ö‡§æ-‡§ö‡•Ä-‡§ö‡•á‡§Çmust be traced to the ‡§§‡•ç‡§Øwhich certainindeclinables takte in Sanskrit asr or start as ‡§á‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø or ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‘of this place,’ ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø ‘of that place,’ ‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø or ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø ‘of what place.’ ‡§á‡§π‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø or ‡§Ö‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ømust by the usual rules be changed to ‡§á‡§π‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö,‡§è‡§•‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö; ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø to ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö;‡§ï‡•ç‡§µ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø or ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡§∏‡•ç‡§Ø to ‡§ï‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö or ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö or ‡§ï‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö. ‡§§‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§ö‡•ç‡§öis ‡§§‡•á‡§•‡§ö‡§æ, ‡§è‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§ö‡•ç‡§öis‡§è‡§•‡§ö‡§æ, ‡§ï‡•ã‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö is ‡§ï‡•ã‡§†‡§ö‡§æ.This ‡§ö‡•ç‡§ö was generalised and graduallycame to be applied to all nouns to indicate possession and otherrelations.

The G. ‡§®‡•ã-‡§®‡•Ä-‡§®‡•Å‡§Ç are derived from the Sanskrit termination ‡§§‡§®,which is applied in the sense of possession to indeclinablesexpressive of time, such as ‡§Ö‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§§‡§® ‘of this day, ‡§á‡§¶‡§æ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§§‡§® ‘of thepresent time,’ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§Ø‡§Ç‡§§‡§® ‘of evening time, ‡§ö‡§ø‡§∞‡§Ç‡§§‡§® ‘of the olden time’etc. This was generalised and Hemacandra gives ‡§§‡§£ as a nounexpressive of ‘something related to’ or ‘belonging to’ in hisgrammar of the Apbhr. dialect. In the line of the verge of

PremƒÅnanda‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§ø‡§∞‡§π‡§§‡§£‡•Ä ‡§µ‡•á‡§¶‡§®‡§æ’the agony of separation afflictsand in the expressions previously given, such as ‡§™‡•ã‡§§‡§æ‡§§‡§£, and‡§§‡•á‡§π‡§§‡§£‡•ã ‡§®‡§π‡§ø ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ß‡•á ‡§õ‡•á‡§π etc., this ‡§§‡§£ remains, it will be seen, unchangedand in this form it is often used in G. poetry. By the droppingof the consonant ‡§§, it is reduced to ‡§Ö‡§£ or ‡§Ö‡§® and thence to ‡§Æ‡•ç,which with masc., fem., neut. terminations ‡§ì-‡§à-‡§â‡§Ç becomes**‡§®‡•ã-‡§®‡•Ä-**‡§®‡§Ç.

The S. ‡§ú‡•ã-‡§ú‡•Ä are derived from the Sanskrit possessive termination ‡§à‡§Ø applied to a great many nouns and all pronouns, as‡§§‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Ø belonging to him, ‡§∂‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ø belonging to the house ‡§ó‡•ã‡§Ç‡§®‡§∞‡•ç‡§¶‡•Ä‡§Øbelonging to or living in Gonarda. Dr. Trump assigns a differentorigin to this Sindhi ‡§ú‡•ã-‡§ú‡•Ä, which, as well as the etymologies ofthe corresponding possessive terminations existing in othercognate dialects, hardly bears examination.

Another way of expressing possession is furnished by derivetives of the root ‡§ï‡•É ’to do or make. The roar of a lion is his ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Øor act. The roar of a lion is a ‡§∏‡§ø‡§Ç‡§π‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Øor lion act, i. e. it is something which belongs to the lion. The word ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Ç therefore is adapted to express ‘something belonging to one.’ Now this ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø is inthe Pr, reduced to ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞, as the ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Øof ‡§™‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡§®‡•ç‡§§ to ‡§™‡•á‡§∞, and the ‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Øof ‡§Ü‡§∂‡•ç‡§ö‡§∞‡•ç‡§Øto ‡§õ‡•á‡§∞. From this ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞, we have ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡§ï‡•ã which means ‘somethingbelonging to one’ or his property. MadayantikƒÅin the MƒÅlatimƒÅdhava calls her body Makaranda’s or ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡§Ö or ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡§ï,since he hadsaved it from the mouth of a lion. Hemacandra gives ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞ as anoun in the Apabbr. dialect expressive of the thing connectedwith another. The instance he gives is ‡§ú‡§∏‡•Å‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡§è ‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§è ‡§∏‡•Å‡§π‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§™‡§°‡§Ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§§‡§£‡§æ‡§á‡§Ç‘From whose mouth grass falls down in consequence of theroar which is the ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡§Ö of the lion. He also gives in his grammarof the principal Prakrit ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞ as a termination having the sense ofpossession as in ‡§§‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï‡•á‡§∞ ‘yours’ like ‡§§‡§£. Thus then ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞ which wasfirst a noun came to be used as a postposition expressive ofpossession and was used as such in the principal Prakrit and bythe G. and H. poets:

‡§Ö‡§Ç‡§ß‡§æ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§≤‡§æ‡§ï‡§°‡•Ä ‡§π‡•à ‡§¶‡•Å‡§¨‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§®‡•Å ‡§ß‡§®‡•§

Tulasi.

‘I am the stick of the blind [women ] and the wealth of aweak I (woman).’

‡§π‡•Å‡§ï‡•Å‡§Æ ‡§π‡•ã‡§Ø ‡§π‡§ú‡•ã‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∂‡•ã‡§∑‡•Ä ‡§®‡§æ‡§ñ‡•ã ‡§¨‡§æ‡§ß‡•ã‡§∏‡§æ‡§ó‡§∞‡••

SƒÅmaladƒÅs.

‘If the command of the lord is received, I will dry up thewhole ocean.‚Äô

One of Kabƒ´ra’s SƒÅkhƒ´is‚Äî

‡§¶‡§∞‡•ç‡§™‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ì ‡§ó‡•Å‡§´‡§æ ‡§∏‡•ã‡§£‡•ç‡§π‡§æ‡§™‡•à‡§†‡§æ ‡§ß‡§æ‡§Ø‡•§
‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§§ ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Ü‡§™‡§®‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§ñ‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§ñ‡§ø ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§ñ‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§∞‡§ø ‡§ú‡§æ‡§Ø‡••

‘A dog enters a room [made up] of mirrors and runs aboutand, seeing his own image, he barks and barks until he dies.’

There is another instance :

‡§Ö‡§Æ‡•É‡§§‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡•ã‡§ü‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§∏‡§ø‡§∞‡§∏‡•á ‡§ß‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§â‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡•§
‡§ú‡§æ‡§π‡§ø ‡§ï‡§π‡•ã ‡§Æ‡•à‡§Ø‡•á‡§ï ‡§π‡•å‡§Æ‡•ã‡§π‡§ø ‡§ï‡§π‡•à‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡•à‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡••

‘I put down from head the parcel containing nectar. To whomsoever I say that I am one, to me he speaks in return two or four.’

Here we have ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡•Ä a possessive postposition. Similarly inTulsidƒÅs’s RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa we have ‡§ï‡§π‡•Å ‡§ñ‡§¨‡§∞ ‡§¨‡§ø‡§≠‡•Ä‡§∑‡§£ ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡•Ä ‚Äõgive us newsabout Bibhƒ´·π£a·πás, where also we have the same postposition.When the initial ‡§ï is dropped we have ‡§è‡§∞ which we find in theHindi ‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡§æ and ‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡§æ as in Kabƒ´r’s SƒÅkhƒ´,

‡§ú‡•ã ‡§§‡•Ç ‡§ö‡§æ‡§π‡•å‡§Æ‡•Å‡§ù‡§ï‡•ã ‡§õ‡•ã‡§°‡•Å‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§Ü‡§∏‡•§
‡§Æ‡•á‡§∞‡§æ ‡§ê‡§∏‡§æ ‡§µ‡•ç‡§π‡•à‡§∞‡§π‡•à‡§∏‡§¨ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§õ‡•Å ‡§§‡•á‡§∞‡•á ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡••‡••

‘If you want me, give up the desire for everything else;become mine; and you will have everything else with you.‚Äô‡§è‡§∞ is the general postposition in the B. as ‡§™‡§æ‡§™‡•á‡§∞ ‚Äôof sin,’‡§à‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‚Äôot God,’ ‡§ò‡§∞‡•á‡§∞‘of a house.‚Äô

Prof. H√∂rnle and Mr. Beames derive the suffix from theSkr. past part. ‡§ï‡•É‡§§ which they say is reduced to ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§Öand thenceto ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞. But I have not met with a trace of ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§Ö as the Pr. form of ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§Öof ‡§ï‡•É‡§§. The usual form of it is ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ö or ‡§ï‡§Ö. Besides the ‡§áis inorganic, being simply & euphonic augment. Such aeuphonic augment cannot persist throughout centuries as the ‡§è of ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞has done until it was perpetuated in the form of ‡§è‡§∞ in the B.Besides, ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡§ï is, as we have seen, used as a noun in the sense ofproperty. There is no indication that a past pass. part can be soused. It may be used as an abstract noun, as ‡§ó‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç in the sense of

‘going.’ So ‡§ï‡•É‡§§‡§Æ‡•ç may at the best acquire the sense of ‘doing”, butthe transition of ‘doing’ to ‘property’ is hardly possible.

Another derivative of the root has also supplied the vernaculars with a termination expressive of the genitive sense; andthat is ‡§ï‡§∞. A good many words in Sanskrit have this ‡§ï‡§∞ appendedto them such as ‡§Ø‡§∂‡§∏‡•ç‡§ï‡§∞‘bringing fame’, ‡§µ‡§ö‡§®‡§ï‡§∞ ‘obedient,’ ‡§ï‡§ø‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‘servant’, ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞ ’the sun,’ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞‘a writer’, etc. The originalsense is ‘one who does the thing’ expressed by the nouns to whichis appended, but the derived senses are many, such as cause,habit, obedience and any other relation into which the doing ofa thing brings one with another. When the particular nature ofthis relation is left out of sight, the general sense is ‘related to‚Äô or"belonging to.‚Äô Thus ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≠‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞originally meaning ’the maker oflight‚Äô comes to denote ‘belonging to light’; a certain person whois ‡§≤‡§ø‡§™‡§ø‡§ï‡§∞ or the doer of the writing is a person related or belonging to the writing. Thus ‡§ï‡§∞came gradually to signify agenitive relation like the termination ‡§à‡§Ø, ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø, ‡§§‡§®etc., noticedabove. In the Marathi ‡§ï‡§∞ is applied in ordinary use to thename of a place to denote ‘one residing in it’ or generally"belonging it it’ as ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§ï‡§∞ ‘belonging to KƒÅ≈õƒ´’, ‡§™‡•Å‡§£‡•á‡§ï‡§∞ ‚Äôbelonging toPoona.‚Äô Instances of this ‡§ï‡§∞ occur in the old Hindi poets; thusin TulsidƒÅs’s RƒÅmƒÅya·πáa we have‚Äî

‡§§‡§ú‡•å‡§Ç ‡§® ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡§¶‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§â‡§™‡§¶‡•á‡§∂‡•Ç ‡•§

BƒÅlak.

“I will not set aside the advice of NƒÅrada.”

‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§ø ‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§ø ‡§π‡•É‡§¶‡§Ø ‡§µ‡§ø‡§ö‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø ‡§ò‡§∞‡§ø ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§§‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§∞‡•Ç‡§™‡•§

(Ditto).

‘Again and again reflecting in her mind she (PƒÅrvatƒ´) assumedthe form of Sƒ´tƒÅ.‚Äô

‡§Æ‡•à‡§Ç‡§∂‡§Ç‡§ï‡§∞‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§ï‡•ú‡§æ ‡§® ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡§æ ‡•§

(Ditto).

‘I did not obey the word of ≈öa·πÅkara.’

‡§≠‡§∞‡§¶‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§ú ‡§∏‡•Å‡§®‡•Å ‡§Ö‡§™‡§∞ ‡§Ö‡§Ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ú‡§®‡•ç‡§Æ‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§π‡•á‡§§‡•Å‡•§

“Oh BharadvƒÅja, hear now another reason for the birth ofRƒÅma.”

In Kabƒ´r too we meet this termination as in:‚Äî

‡§§‡§¨ ‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡§æ (‡§¨‡•ç‡§∞‡§π‡•ç‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç) ‡§™‡•Ç‡§õ‡§≤ ‡§Æ‡§π‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡•§
‡§ï‡•ã ‡§§‡•ã‡§∞ ‡§™‡•Å‡§∞‡•Å‡§∑ ‡§ï‡§æ ( ‡§ï‡•á) ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ ‡§®‡§æ‡§∞‡•Ä‡•§

Kabƒ´r’s RƒÅmaintƒ´, 1-4th Chaupai.

‘Then the mother was asked by Brahma “who is thy husbandand whose wife art thou.”

Here we have ‡§ï‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø or ‡§ï‡•á‡§ï‡§∞‡§øin which we have the feminineof the termination ‡§ï‡§∞. In Sanskrit ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞is almost as much usedas ‡§ï‡§∞ after nouns and the signification is similar. This ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞issometimes used in the Bengali in a genitive sense as in ‡§Ü‡§™‡§®‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‘of your honour,’ ‡§Ü‡§ú‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‘of to-day,’ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§ø‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‘of yesterday.‘From ‡§ï‡§∞, when the initial consonant is dropped, we have theOriya genitive suffix ‡§Ö‡§∞as in ‡§ò‡§∞‡§∞, while ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ gives us the ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞ ofthe Hindi ‡§§‡•Å‡§ù‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‘youre,’ ‡§π‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§æ ‘ours snd of the Guj ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã’thing,’‡§§‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã‘yours,’ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‘mine,’ ‡§Ö‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ã ‘ours.’

Another derivative of the root ‡§ï‡•É. the past pass. part. ‡§ï‡•É‡§§changed to ‡§´‡§Ö in the Prakrit, has been appropriated in Hindi to express genitive relations. As the obl. form has been determined to be a remnant of the old genitive, the ‡§ï appended to itmust mean’ done of (by) the thing or person’ denoted by theobl. form. The idea of a thing done by one’ passes easily intoa thing belonging to one. ‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡•É‡§§ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø ‘apoem composed bya Pandit’ becomes easily ‡§™‡§£‡•ç‡§°‡§ø‡§§‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø i.e. the poem of a Pandit.The terminations ‡§ï‡§æ, ‡§ï‡•Ä exist in old Hindi along with ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡§æ, ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡•Äsnd ‡§ï‡§∞, ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä.

The easiest explanation of the Panjabi ‡§¶‡§æ-‡§¶‡•Äappears to bethat, like the Hindi ‡§ï‡§æ-‡§ï‡•Ä, they are derived from the pastpass, part of ‡§¶‡§æ to give ‚Äôin the form of ‡§¶‡§Ömade up on theanalogy of ‡§ï‡§Ö from ‡§ï‡•É. Other explanations may also be given.It may be said that the ‡§∞‡•ã-‡§∞‡•Äof the Marvari dialect and certainG. and H. pronouns, which results from the Sanskrit ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞, waschanged to ‡§°‡•ã-‡§°‡•Äor ‡§°‡§æ-‡§°‡•Ä, as these consonants are frequentlyconfounded with each other; and thence ‡§°‡•ã-‡§°‡•Ä or ‡§°‡§æ-‡§°‡•Ä passedinto ‡§¶‡•ã-‡§¶‡•Ä or ‡§¶‡§æ-‡§¶‡•Ä. The Sanskrit suffixes used by the vernacularsto express genitive relations must have a final ‡§ï added to them,since, like augmented nouns, the masc. nom. sing. ends in ‡§ì or

‡§Ü and the feminine in ‡§à. Thus for the original of the M.‡§ö‡§æ-‡§ö‡•Ä-‡§ö‡•á‡§Çwe must have ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§ï, for the G. ‡§®‡•ã-‡§®‡•Ä-‡§®‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§§‡§®‡§ï, for S, ‡§ú‡•ã-‡§ú‡•Ä‡§à‡§Ø‡§ï, for H ‡§ï‡§æ ‡§ï‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•Å‡§§‡§ï, and for old H. ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡§æ and ‡§∞‡•Ä ‡§ï‡•á‡§∞‡§ï and for‡§ï‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ï and for ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§∞‡§ï. In the fourth lecture I have givenseveral instances of the addition of to all sorts of nouns andadjectives.

The new loc. termination in H. are ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç, Braj. ‡§Æ‡•à‡§Çand ‡§™‡•à, P.‡§§‡•á, S. ‡§Æ‡•á,G.‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ç, M. ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§§and B. ‡§§‡•á. The forms with an initial ‡§Æ are derivedfrom the Skr. ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø which has undergone several transformations.In old H. and G. poetry it occurs in the forms of ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Çantil ‡§Æ‡§π‡§Çeto., as :‚Äî

‡§∂‡§ø‡§µ ‡§∏‡§Ç‡§ï‡§≤‡•ç‡§™ ‡§ï‡•Ä‡§®‡•ç‡§π‡§Æ‡§®‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡•§

Tulsi, BƒÅla-K.

‘Siva resolved in his mind.’

‡§ú‡•á ‡§π‡§ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§ñ‡•á ‡§∞‡§ò‡•Å‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∞ ‡§§‡•á ‡§â‡§™‡§∞‡•á ‡§§‡•á‡§π‡§ø ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§Æ‡§π‡§Ç ‡•§

(Ditto).

‘Those were safe at that time whom Raghuvƒ´ra protected.’

‡§è‡§ï‡§µ‡§æ‡§∞ ‡§§‡•ç‡§∞‡•á‡§§‡§æ‡§Ø‡•Å‡§ó‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡•§

(Ditto).

‘Once in TretƒÅyuga’

‡§™‡•Å‡§®‡§ø ‡§Æ‡§Ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§∞ ‡§Æ‡§à ‡§¨‡§æ‡§§ ‡§ú‡§®‡§æ‡§à‡•§

‘He announced the intelligence in the palace.’

‡§∏‡•Å‡§¶‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ ‡§Æ‡•á‡§Ç ‡§™‡•É‡§•‡§ø‡§µ‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡•§‡§≤‡•Ä‡§ß‡§æ ‡§¶‡§∂ ‡§Ö‡§µ‡§§‡§æ‡§∞ ‡••

PremƒÅnand’s SudƒÅmƒÅnu·πÉCaritra.

‘O SudƒÅma, I have gone through ten incarnations on this earth.’

‡§∏‡•ã‡§∞‡§† ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§∏‡§π‡•Å‡§ï‡•ã ‡§®‡§æ‡§†‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡•§

‘Everybody fled to Sora·π≠ha.‚Äô

The Braj. ‡§Æ‡•à‡§Çis from ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç, the ‡§π being olided and ‡§Ü and ‡§á combining into ‡§ê, while in the S. and H. ‡§Æ‡•á they form ‡§è. In the G.‡§Æ‡§æ the whole ‡§π‡§øof B is dropped. ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç is loc. sing of ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§π for ‡§Æ‡§ß‡•ç‡§Ø.

The P. and B. ‡§§‡•á is from ‡§§‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç, the loc. of ‡§§‡§¶‡•ç, or ‡§§‡•á‡§π‡§ø‡§Çwhich we havenoticed as an Apbhr. dative postposition.

H. ‡§™‡•à is from Skr.‡§™‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§∂‡•ç‡§µ, which first becomes ‡§™‡§∏‡•ç‡§∏, then ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏, andthen ‡§™‡§æ‡§π or ‡§™‡§π, and the loc.of ‡§™‡§æ‡§π is ‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Çor ‡§™‡§π‡§Çwhich is its shortened form. ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏ is used as a post-position in H. and ‡§™‡§æ‡§∏‡•á and ‡§™‡§æ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§Ç.the loc. forms, in G. and M. respectively. The forms ‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç and ‡§™‡§π‡§Çoccur in the old H. poets, as :‚Äî

‡§∂‡§Ç‡§≠‡•Å ‡§ó‡§Ø‡•á ‡§ï‡•Å‡§Ç‡§≠‡§ú ‡§ã‡§∑‡§ø ‡§™‡§æ‡§π‡•Ä‡§Ç‡•§

Tulsi, BƒÅla-K.

‚Äô≈öa·πÅbhu went to Agastya.’

‡§ó‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§ï‡§™‡§ø ‡§∞‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§™‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç‡•§

Tulsi.

‘The monkey went to RƒÅma.’

The M. ‡§Ü‡§Ç‡§§ is from Skr. ‡§Ö‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§É and its initial ‡§Ü is dropped aftera dissimilar vowel as ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§§‡•Ä‡§§‡§Ç etc.

NEW VERBAL FORMS

We will now briefly examine the reconstructed verbal forms.We have observed that the materials out of which the case formsare constructed are not only independent words having, as in anearlier stage of a language, specific significations, the combination of which nearly constitutes the idea required to be expressed,but also independent case forms and existing terminations whichhave acquired a specific sense. Thus when the terminations cameinto use for both numbers of the cases, the B. and the O. have hadrecourse to the use of independent words such as ‡§¶‡§ø‡§ó‘a row.‘and ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‘a measure or class,’ ‡§∏‡§ï‡§≤ ‘all etc. to express plurality,while the G. employed the already existing plural termination‡§ì; and such forms as ‡§§‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç and ‡§ï‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç loc. and ‡§ï‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç abl. were used toexpress case relations and afterwards grew into terminationswhen their etymological sense was forgotten. We have also scenthat, as in the case of the new words that come into a language,the new forms at first express inadequately the sense they aredesigned to convey, but in the course of time imagination andusage give them a definite signification; or like words the formscome by natural transitions to express different relations fromthose they did before. Thus it was that the abl. ‡§ï‡§π‡•Å‡§Ç and the loc.‡§ï‡§π‡§ø‡§Ç or ‡§§‡§π‡§ø‡§Çbecame dat, affixes or the loc. of the present participle‡§π‡•ã‡§á‡§§‡•á came to express an abl. relation.

We shall find these principles at work in the reconstructionof the verb also; and there too you will meet with verbal formsmade up by applying the old personal and other terminationsto new bases which are adjectival in their nature or by addingverbal forms to them or by appending independent words. The

M., S., B. and O. make up some of their tenses and moods in thefirst way; the others do not. We will first examine these. Thebases for their formation are as a matter of course the participlesthat have come down from the Prakrits and there are no other.These are the present, past and the potential participles whichare, as I have just said, adjectival in their nature. Since anadjective must agree with the noun which it qualifies in numberand gender, our new verbs must express both these and the personof the nominative. The old verbal forms examined in the lastlecture express, as Skr. and Pr. verbs do, only the number andperson because they have descended to us from those languages.

In the modern dialects those adjectives only that end in ‡§ì or ‡§Üagree with the noun to which they are referred, i. e. take thefem.termination ‡§à when the noun is feminine and the pluralones when it is plural, as ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡§æ-‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§æ M. H. ‘a black horse,’‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä-‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•Ä ‘a black mare, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á-‡§≤‡•á ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•á ‚Äõblack horses,’ ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ, ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç. Similarly, G. and S. When the qualifiednoun is in an abl. case, sing. or pl., these adjectives take the obl.sing form ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ M., ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•á ‡§ò‡§æ‡§Ç‡§°‡•á‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç H.,‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ö‡•ã‡§°‡•Ä‡§∏ M., ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç H. Hindi has no obl. form for other nouns than thosewhich end in ‡§Üand hence in ‡§ï‡§æ‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•Ä‡§ï‡•ã‡§Çthe adjective remainsunchanged.

Adjectives with other endings are not thus inflected as ‡§ñ‡§∞‡§æ‡§¨‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§æ-‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•á-‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•Ä-‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ-‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡§ø‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç-‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•á‡§ï‡•ã‡§Ç etc. M. H.; while in theB. and O. no adjectives whatever.

Here then we see that, like nouns in ‡§ì-‡§Ü, adjectives alsowith those endings have preserved the old terminations. Nowthe three participles I have mentioned end in ‡§Ü or ‡§ì arisingfrom the original affix ‡§ï, wherefore they must be inflected. InM. and G., however, under certain circumstances the presentparticiple ends in ‡§Ö and therefore is not inflected. The oldPresent has in M. acquired another sense whence a new one cameinto use, the forms of which are as follows:‚Äî
Sing. Pl.
1st pers. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç-‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á or ‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ç-‡§§‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç
2nd pers. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ã‡§∏-‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§∏, ‡§§‡•Ä‡§∏-‡§§‡•á‡§Ç‡§∏ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç
3rd pers. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ã-‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á, ‡§§‡•Ä-‡§§‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§§

These are made up by adding the terminations expressive ofgender and person to the pres. part. which is ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§. White the fem. ‡§àthis becomes ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä, but there is another form in ‡§Ø‡•á which appearsto have been arrived at thus:‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§Ö ( for ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ï )-‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§Ø-‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§Ø+‡§àof fem.‚Äî‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§Ø‡•á‚Äî‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á.The neuter form is ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•á.These threeforms are used in the sing. while the gender is neglected in the pl.There is however such a form as ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ used for the 3rd pers. pl.in the pure Deccan in which ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ is the fem. pl. of ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•Ä. Tothese adjectival bases are appended the personal terminations ofthe old Pres. for the two numbers, which, you will remember, are3rd pers. sing. ‡§á. pl. ‡§§; 2nd pers. sing. ‡§∏, pl. ‡§Ü; 1st pers. sing. ‡§á‡§Ç,pl. ‡§ä‡§Ç.

In the 1st pers. sing. of the new present the ‡§á‡§Ç of the 1st pers.sing. is represented by the characteristic anusv√§ra, the vowelsexpressive of gender necessitating the elision of ‡§á. In the pl.‡§ï‡§∞‡§§ and ‡§ä‡§Ç become by combination ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ã‡§Ç. The 2nd pers. sing. hasthe ‡§∏ of the old Pres. and the pl. the ‡§Ü which with the ‡§§ forms‡§§‡§æ, to which however an inorganic anusvƒÅra is added bysome. The 3rd pers. sing. has no personal termination, theadjective in its own form expressing that idea, while in the pl.the ‡§§of the old Pres. is added.

In these forms we see that the of the nom. which is droppedin ordinary nouns and adjectives is retained and we have ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•ãbut not ‡§ö‡§æ‡§Ç‡§ó‡§≤‡•ã.

In the Goan. and MƒÅl. the gender is not attended to and theforms are the same for all. This arises from the use of the unaugmented participle ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§ and not ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§Ö which retains the inflections. The forms are:‚Äî
Sing.
1st pers. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•à‡§Ç or ‡§§‡§Ç‡§Ø MƒÅl. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç Goan.
2nd pers. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§∏ MƒÅl. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§∏ Goan.
3rd pers. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ MƒÅl. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ Goan.
Pl.
1st pers. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡•å‡§Ç‚Äî‡§§‡§Ç‡§µMƒÅl. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ Goan.
2nd pers. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§§ MƒÅl. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§§ Goan.
3rd pers. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§§ MƒÅl. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§§ Goan.

The terminations are those of the old Pres. of intransitiveroots in these dialects, i. e. the real Pr. terminations without thetransitive or Parasm, augment ‡§à. The 2nd pers. pl. ‡§§, which Ihave traced to the Pr. ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ, is peculiar to the Goan. and MƒÅl. andit is not altogether absent from the ordinary M. In the 1st. pers.sing. MƒÅl, we have the old ‡§á‡§Ç from ‡§Æ‡§ø distinct and not reduced toan amusv√§ra as in the standard dialect and also the Goan.

A process the reverse of that observable in M. as regards thechange in the sense of verbal forms has taken place in theO. and B. The old Pres. in M. has acquired the sense of the PastHabitual and the forms made up by appending the old terminations to the pres. part. express present time, but in the O. and B.this new Present of the M. expresses habitual past action andthe old Pres. retains its present signification. In H. too thepres. part. used alone has the signification of the Past Habitual.

The reason why forms expressive of present time have cometo denote past time is to be sought for in that natural use of thePres, which is called Historic Present. A man in narrating astory transports himself for the sake of vividness into that timewhen the actions are supposed to have taken place and speaks ofthem as if they were present; and when this habit becomes generalin a language, the fact of such an imaginary transfer is forgottenand the Present Tense becomes Past Tense. We have manyinstances of this use of the Skr. Pres. in such books as the Pa√±catantra. The forms of the O. Past Habitual are these :‚Äî
Sing. Pl.
1st pers ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç
2nd pers. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•Å ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§
3rd pers. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§®‡•ç‡§§‡•á

As in the M., the 3rd pers. sing. has no personal termination;and the pl. is the M. and H. pl. of nouns in ‡§Ü as ‡§ò‡•ã‡§°‡•á which wefind in the O. nom. pl. ‡§™‡§∂‡•Å‡§Æ‡§æ‡§®‡•á ‘beasts’ also. The second personhas the same termination as the corresponding old Present, viz.‡§Ö and ‡§â. The first person sing. has ‡§áand the pl. ‡§ä‡§Ç and they arethe same as the ‡§á‡§Ç and ‡§â of the Pres., but there is some confusionabout the anusvƒÅras.

Before proceeding it is necessary to mention that O. and B.use the sing, forms in speaking of, and to, inferiors, while thepl. is used in an honorific sense. This is so in all the languages;but these two use even in a singular nominative with the honorific forms or real plurals and a plural one with the inferior forms.This is due to the loss of the original plural of nouns in theselanguages, which I have before mentioned; so that one sameform of the nom. came to be used for both the sing. and pl. verbalforms; but, since the usage common to all our vernaculars didexist, the pl. forms came to be understood in a simply honorificsense, and the sing. in the sense of inferiority. There was nothing in the form of the nom. which expressed plurality and hencethe verbs also ceased to indicate it, though originally fitted todo so. Similarly, the pl. forms of personal pronouns which werenot lost came to be restricted to an honorific signification andthe sing, to that of inferiority. The words which were broughtinto use to indicate plurality expressed an aggregate or collection and thus, being themselves sing., the necessity of pl. verbalforms in connection with them was not felt; and hence they take& verb in the real old sing. But there is this consistency in theuse of the verb, that the honorific pers. pronouns take an honorificverb and the inferior an inferior, i.e. an original pl. nom.takes an original plural verb and an original sing. a singular.

These same forms that we have been discussing have in theS. acquired a future signification and constitute the regularFuture tense of that dialect. The Pres, expresses in all languagesan immediate future‚Äîa man’s intending shortly to do a thing isconsidered as good as actually doing it. This is the germ offuturity in the signification of forms of the Present tense; andusage may take hold of it and constitute them into a regularFuture. The Sindhi forms are‚Äî
Masc. Fem.
Sing. Pl. Sing. Pl.
1st pers. ‡§π‡§≤‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡§ø ‡§π‡§≤‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§π‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§Ü‡§∏‡§ø-‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡§ø ‡§π‡§≤‡§Ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§ä‡§Ç-‡§ó‡•Ç‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ç
2nd pers. ‡§π‡§≤‡§Ç‡§¶‡•á‡§Ç ‡§π‡§≤‡§Ç‡§¶‡§â‡§®‡•ç‡§¶‡•å ‡§π‡§≤‡§Ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§Ö‡§Ç-‡§è‡§Ç ‡§π‡§≤‡§Ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§ä‡§Ç-‡§ó‡•Ç
3rd pers. ‡§π‡§≤‡§Ç‡§¶‡•ã ‡§π‡§≤‡§Ç‡§¶‡§æ ‡§π‡§≤‡§Ç‡§¶‡•Ä ‡§π‡§≤‡§Ç‡§¶‡§ø‡§ä‡§Ç-‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ç

Here ‡§π‡§≤‡§Ç‡§¶is the old pres part.The 3d pers, as in the O. andalso M., partially has no personal terminations. The sing, and

the pl. are like those of corresponding adjectives in ‡§ì. The 2ndpers, has the termination ‡§è‡§Ç and ‡§â of the S. old Pres. In the fem.the first is optionally reduced to ‡§Ö‡§Ç and the ‡§â combines with thefem. pl. ‡§ä‡§Ç. The first pers. pl. has the corresponding S. pronoun‡§Ö‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ç ‘we’ attached to it as a termination as in an early stage ofa language. The sing. ‡§∏‡§ø or ‡§Ö‡§∏‡§øis perhaps the same without thenasal and shortened, which changes are made probably to adaptit to the expression of singularity. The adjectival maso. termination appears also in the first pers. sing., as in M., but it is shortened to ‡§â and the fem. sing. ‡§à and the pl. ‡§ä or ‡§à ‡§ä optionallycombined into ‡§Ø‡•Ç throughout. In the M. the adjectival genderterminations are not used in the pl. Dr. Trump considers thesepersonal terminations as the remnants of the old Pr. forms of ‡§Ö‡§∏‡•ç,which, however, are quite different from these.

The old past part. is similarly made the base of verbal formsexpressive of past time. In S. they are made up just in the sameway as the above, the 3rd pers. having the purely adjectivalforms, without the personal terminations, and the gender affixesappearing in the same places as in the above.

Masc.
Singular Plural.
‡§π‡§≤‡§ø‡§â‡§∏‡§ø-‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∏‡§ø ‡§π‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ü‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ç-‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏‡•Ä‡§Ç

Fem.
Singular Plural.
‡§π‡§≤‡§ø‡§â‡§∏‡§ø-‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§∏‡§ø ‡§π‡§≤‡§ø‡§Ø‡•Ç‡§Ç‡§∏‡§ø

When the verb is transitive, the participle is passive and theagent, if used, is put in the instr. case. The verb takes the person,gender and number of the object in the nom. case and the formsare just the same as the above, as ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∏‡§ø ‘I was beaten’, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•àthouwert beaten.

Sing. Pl. Sing. Pl. Sing. Pl.
1st. ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•á‡§Ç-‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•ã‡§Ç
2nd. ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä‡§∏ ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç‡§∏ ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§§
3rd. ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•á ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ç

Here as before we have simply adjectival forms for the 3rdpers.; and the verbal terminations of the old Pres. appear in thefirst and second united with the nominal affixes indicative ofgender and number, which however are dropped where they cannot be easily combined with the other, as in the first and secondperson plural mase. It should be remarked that the old masc.termination ‡§â or ‡§ì is preserved in the 1st pers. sing., as in thenew Pres., and the 2nd pers. pl. has in some cases the affix ‡§§.,which I have already noticed and traced to the Pr. ‡§á‡§§‡•ç‡§•‡§æ.

The Cit. and Goan. dialects agree with this in the main, butuse ‡§§ for the 2nd pers. pl. of the Masc. also, as ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•á‡§§. Their masc.sing, is ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•ãand fem. pl. ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã, since they do not drop the old ‡§â ofthe fem. nom. pl.

The MƒÅl, discards gender in the first and second persons, whenthe verbal terminations are appended, and the first pers. sing.termination is the old ‡§á‡§Ç, which before the ‡§ìof the others isreduced to an anusvƒÅra, and we have ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•á‡§á‡§Ç‚Äî‡§≤‡•à‡§Ç ‘I went. The 2ndpers. pl. termination is ‡§§throughout, as in the other dialects.

Goan.
‡§π‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µ ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•ã‡§Ç-‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ç-‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•ã‡§Ç-‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã‡§Ç-‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ç
‡§§‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•ã-‡§≤‡•Ä-‡§≤‡§Ç‡§∏ ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•á-‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã-‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§§
‡§§‡•ã-‡§§‡•Ä-‡§§‡•á‡§Ç-‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•ã-‡§≤‡•Ä-‡§≤‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á-‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã-‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ç-‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•á-‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã-‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ç

MƒÅl.
‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡§á‡§Ç ‡§Ü‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•å‡§Ç
‡§§‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡§∏ ‡§§‡•Å‡§Æ‡•Ä ‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡§æ‡§§-‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§
‡§§‡•ã-‡§§‡•Ä-‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç-‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•ã-‡§≤‡•Ä-‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§§‡•á-‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã-‡§§‡•Ä‡§Ç-‡§ó‡•á‡§≤‡•á-‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã-‡§≤‡•Ä‡§Ç

In transitive verbs M. attempts a curious combination. The participle being passive, it must agree with the object and take its number and gender and, if made the base of the verbal forms, its personalso. But unliked the Sindhƒ´, the M.does not use this passive participlefor an object in the first and second persons. Thus ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§Ø‡•à‡§Ç and ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Å‡§∏‡§ø in

S. mean ’thou wert beaten’ and ‘I was beaten’, but we do not use’.such forms as ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏ or ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§≤‡•ãto express this sense, though asolitary line from Moropant containing ‡§ß‡§∞‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§∏ has been oftenquoted. In these cases we use the impersonal constructionputting the agent and the object in the instr. and dat. and using,the sing, neuter form of the past part., as ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§£‡•á‡§Ç ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ or ‡§§‡•Å‡§≤‡§æ ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç.Thus then this participle can have a nom, object only of the thirdperson. Properly then it ought to take no personal terminationsat all; but when the agent which is always in the instr. caseis of the 2nd pers., the characteristic sing., ‡§∏and pl. ‡§§of that pers.are appended to the participle, so that it takes the gender andnumber of the object which is in the nom, case and the pers. andnumber of the agent which is in the instr. case. Thus we have‡§§‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ã‡§•‡•Ä‡§≤‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡§∏ ’thou transcribedst a book ‡§§‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ã‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§™‡§æ‡§∏ ‡§§‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç‡§∏ ’thou didst a work’. ‡§§‡•Å‡§π‡•ç‡§Ø‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§™‡•ã‡§•‡•Ä ‡§≤‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡•Ä‡§§, ‡§™‡•ã‡§•‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§≤‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§.

These forms are condemned by the Translation Departmentof the Director of Public Instruction, but the Marathi speakerscannot dispense with them; ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•á‡§Ç, ‡§§‡•ç‡§µ‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ã‡§•‡•Ä‡§≤‡§ø‡§π‡§ø‡§≤‡•Ä, theproposed substitutes, are felt to be weak and emasculated. Andthe Konka·πáis are not satisfied with second personal forms aloneof this nature and have devised a way of affiliating the past part.with the third personal agent also and, as the old terminations ‡§¶and ‡§§ are not expressive enough, they append to that participle thelast syllable of the agent forms, i. e. the ‡§®‡•á‡§Ç or ‡§® of the instr. sing. and ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç of the pl. as ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§¨‡§æ‡§®‡•á‡§Ç-‡§®‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§¨‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§∏‡•á‡§Ç ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç’the Saheb gaveme & reward’ ‡§§‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡•Ä ‡§Æ‡§≤‡§æ ‡§¨‡§ï‡•ç‡§∑‡§ø‡§∏‡•á ‡§¶‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç ’the Sahebe gave merewards’,where the ‡§® and ‡§®‡•Ä‡§Çof and ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§¨‡§æ‡§® are ‡§∏‡§æ‡§π‡•á‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ç‡§®‡•Ä‡§Ç added tothe verbs to connect them with them. These forms are not usedin the Deccan except by some Konka·πáƒ´Brahmans settled there;and they are condemned by all good writers.

The O. and the B. do not inflect their adjectives, whether theyend in ‡§ì or any other vowel and have no agent case or instrumental. When the languages came to be in this condition, there wasnothing to mark off the passive nature of the transitive participle.Hence it was forgotten and we have now active verbal formsonly, which are constructed as in the other languages.
O. B.
Sing. Pl. Sing. Pl.
1st. pers. ‡§ï‡§≤‡§ø ‡§ï‡§≤‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§Æ‡•ç
2nd pers. ‡§ï‡§≤‡•Å ‡§ï‡§≤ ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§ø ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ-‡§≤‡•á
3rd pers. ‡§ï‡§≤‡§æ ‡§ï‡§≤‡•á ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤ (or ‡§≤‡•ç) ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡•á‡§®‡•ç

As in the Pres., the O. like the other languages does not addverbal terminations to the third pers., but the forms are likethose in M., namely the nom. sing. and pl. masc., though they donot indicate gender here. The other persons have the terminationsof the Present.

The B. has no termination in the third pers. singular, whilethe pl. has the corresponding of the Present in that language.The 2nd pers. sing, has ‡§á and the first person sing. ‡§Æ‡•ç, which arenot used in the B. Present, but are to be traced to the Apabhr.Present preserved in the ‡§á and ‡§ä‡§Ç of the H and others; ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤ + ‡§ä‡§Çis ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µlike the Goan ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§‡§æ‡§Ç‡§µfrom ‡§ï‡§∞‡§§ + ‡§â‡§Ç, and the anusvƒÅraand the ‡§µare hardened into ‡§Æ‡•ç. The first pers. pl. has the sameform as the sing., and such a confusion is easy in a languagewithout distinction of number. The second pers. pl. appears to bethe old adjectival pl. like the M. ‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•á and the O.and the otherform is ‡§¶‡•á‡§ñ‡§ø‡§≤‡§æ sing., the two being confounded.

THE FUTURE TENSE

The Skr. potential participle in ‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø, Pr. ‡§Ö‡§µ‡•ç‡§µ, which impliesduty, has become the base of the O. and B. Future. In Skr. ‡§Æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ï‡§∞‡•ç‡§§‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§Æ‡•ç means ‘it is to be done by me’ i. e. it is my duty to do it,and the transition from this idea to ‘I shall do it is natural. Thevery word ‘shall’ in English, which primarily signifies ‘I owe’and has now become the sing of the English Future, is anexample of it. This participle in Skr. and Pr. is impersonal whenthe root is intransitive and passive when it is transitive. Likethe past part, this has lost its passive character in these languagesfor the same reasons. The usual personal terminations areapplied to it as‚Äî
O. B.
Sing. Pl. Sing. Pl.
1st. pers. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•Å-‡§µ‡§æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ
2nd pers. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•Å ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§ø ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡§æ-‡§µ‡•á
3rd pers. ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•á ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•á‡§®‡•ç

In the O., the third pers. sing. has no terminations and the pl.has the nom. pl. ‡§è, which we have found in so many cases. Theothers have the usual affixes. The optional ‡§µ‡§æof the first pers. pl.appears to be the adjectival sing. ‡§µ‡§æ.

The B. first pers. has no termination; the second has the sameas those we examined in the case of the Past tense and the thirdhas the affixes of the regular Present.

This participle is similarly made the base of a future tense inSindhi; but since its passive character was not forgotten by theSindhis, as by the Bengalis and the Oriyas, the Future tense itforms is the Passive Future. The same terminations as those wehave examined before are appended to it, as ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§µ‡•Å‡§∏‡§ø ‘I shall bebeaten’, ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§¨‡•á ’thou shalt be beaten’ and ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§∞‡§ø‡§¨‡•ã‘he will be beaten.“The third person has, as before, no personal affixes. When theverb is intransitive, this participle is used only impersonally inthe masc. sing., the agent being in the instrumental.

In M. however the optional participle has preserved its oldsense and is passive and impersonal, and, when used as a base forverbal forms, takes only the second pers. sing. affix ‡§∏ and the pl. ‡§§.Like the past participle when it is passive it takes the gender andnumber of the object in the nom, and the person and number ofthe agent in the instrumental, 88 ‡§§‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡§ó‡•ç‡§∞‡§Ç‡§• ‡§≤‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§∏, ‡§™‡•ã‡§•‡•Ä ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∏ ‡§Ü‡§£‡§ø‡§¶‡•Å‡§∏‡§∞‡•á‡§Ç ‡§ï‡§æ‡§Æ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç‡§∏ thou shouldst write a work, read a book and dosome other work.‚Äô When the object is in the pl., we have ‡§≤‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§∏,‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§µ‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§∏, ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§Ç‡§∏; and when the agent is in the pl. and the objectsing., we have ‡§≤‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§§, ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§, ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç‡§§; and when both are in the pl.‡§≤‡§ø‡§π‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§§, ‡§¨‡§æ‡§Ø‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§§ and ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§§. When the verb is Intransitive, it isimpersonal i. e. has no Nom, with which it should agree, sincethe object alone can be Nom., but it takes the ‡§∏ and ‡§§of the agent,as‡§§‡•Å‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç‡§∏‚Äî‡§§‡•Å‡§ù‡•Ä‡§Ç ‡§ú‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§Ç‡§§.

Dr. Trump and Mr. Beames (Jour. R. A. S. Vol. VII), misledby the circumstance that in the B., O. and S. the ‡§µ is pronouncedlike ‡§¨, have likened these forms to the Latin bo and explain themas made up of the principal root and the Skr. ‡§≠‡•Ç. But this latterhas in none of the vernaculars assumed the form of ‡§¨ by dropping the vowel and the aspiration, nor are ‡§≠ or the aspiratedconsonants generally ever known to become the corresponding

unaspirates. The genius of the Prakrits and their descendantsis to preserve the aspirate element and to drop the mute. In rarecases the former is thrown on an adjoining letter, but never lost.The usual form in which we have ‡§≠‡•Ç is ‡§π‡•Ç. And this etymologywould not account for the fact that the forms with ‡§Øare passivein S.

In these verbal forms then we observe fresh instances of thelaw of generalization or false analogy. For the Present andFuture tenses verbal or predicative forms, *i. e.*such as indicatethe person of the Nom., were wanted; and so great is the necessityof such forms that we in M. make up such verbs as ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§µ‡•Ä‡§∏and‡§ï‡•á‡§≤‡•Ä‡§∏ agreeing with both the agent and the objectas noticedabove. But the languages being in spite of this want condemned to use participles only, they made the best of what they hadand extended the analogy of the old Pres., which they possessed, to the participles, which they could not avoid, and thus applied thepersonal terminations to the participles and mads verbs of them.The B. and O. rather than make the verbs agree with the object,as the passive nature of the participle base of the verb required,dropped the passive character altogether and made the participlestake the personal tarminations of the agent, while M. reconcilesboth and makes the verb based on the passive participles agreewith the person and number of the agent and the gender andnumber of the object.

We have next to examine the forms that are made up byadding independent words. There are not many of this class.The H. and P. Future is constructed by affixing ‡§ó‡§æ sing., ‡§ó‡•á pl.masc., and ‡§ó‡•Äsing. and ‡§ó‡•Ä‡§Ç pl. fem to the forms of the Present. This ‡§ó‡§æ appears to be the past participle of ‡§ó‡§Æ‡•çand ordinarily it isused in the form of ‡§ó‡§Ø‡§æ. Participles of other roots also are in H.sometimes reduced to monosyllabic forms as ‡§¶‡•Äfor ‡§¶‡§ø‡§à, ‡§ï‡•Ä for ‡§ï‡§ø‡§à;these are feminine and the corresponding masc. monosyllabicforms are er ‡§¶‡§æand ‡§ï‡§æ. We have seen that these ‡§ï‡§æ-‡§ï‡•Ä and ‡§¶‡§æ-‡§¶‡•Äare appended to the obl. case form to make up the genitive in H.and P. Similarly the participle ‡§ó‡§æ-‡§ó‡•Ä is used to form the Future,so that ‡§ï‡§∞‡•á‡§ó‡§æ means ‘gone that he may do.’ The M. Future isformed by adding ‡§á‡§≤ or ‡§≤ to the old Present, as you will see fromthe following forms:‚Äî
Sing. Pl. Sing. Pl.
1st. ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§® ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ç‡§Ç ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡•á‡§® ‡§ß‡§æ‡§¨‡•Ç‡§Ç
2nd. ‡§ï‡§∞-‡§∞‡§ø‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§æ‡§≤ ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§∂‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§æ‡§≤
3rd. ‡§ï‡§∞‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§ï‡§∞‡§ø‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤ ‡§ß‡§æ‡§¨‡•á‡§≤ ‡§ß‡§æ‡§µ‡§§‡•Ä‡§≤
